Clinical examination
Question 1:
A soldier posted in Siachen is brought unconscious to the emergency ward. In order to rule out hypothermia, how will you best measure his temperature?
Oral
Rectal
Infrared tympanic thermometer
Axillary
Question 2:
A patient in the emergency ward stays still while lying supine and hesitates to move. He also has very shallow breathing. This attitude of the patient is most likely due to which of the following conditions?
Renal colic
Peritonitis
Acute pancreatitis
Meningitis
Question 3:
An alcohol addict presented with easy fatiguability. On examination, he is found to have pallor. Peripheral smear showed macrocytes and anisocytosis. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
Atrophic glossitis
Migratory glossitis
Strawberry tongue
Macroglossia
Question 4:
A woman presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the following may be responsible for the given symptoms except:
Methemoglobin exceeds 1.5 gm%
Sulfhemoglobin exceeds 0.5 gm%
Reduced hemoglobin exceeds 2 gm%
Oxygen saturation below 85%
Question 5:
Which of the following skin findings is not associated with an endocrine abnormality?
Acanthosis nigricans
Diffuse hyperpigmentation
Casal’s necklace
Purple striae
Question 6:
What are petechiae?
Large extravasation of blood in the skin

Skin hemorrhages measuring 1-2 mm

A 28-year-old woman presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. Which of the following conditions is/are associated with this lesion?
subject: Medicine

Question 8:
You observed the following finding in a patient in the OPD. Which among the following conditions is least likely to cause this finding?

Endocarditis

Question 9:
A 40-year-old patient presents with loss of appetite, jaundice, and easy bruisability. He is a chronic alcohol user, and the following abnormality is noted on examination. What is the most likely cause of this nail change?

Question 10:
A resident is examining a patient with bilateral leg swelling below the knees. He notes that on applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. What is the likely cause of the edema?
Myxedema

While examining a patient’s pulse, you note a tapping impulse when you raise his arm above his head. Which of the following conditions would you not suspect in the patient?

Question 12:
True about the definition of Postural Hypotension:
Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing
Decrease in Diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing

A 30-year-old African farmer presents with Winterbottom’s sign. This sign is due to the involvement of:

A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with a fever for the past 5 days. On examination, tender lesions were found on his extremities as marked below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Question 17:
On examination of the chest wall, the presence of thrills indicate:

As an intern in the emergency ward, which of the following method would you consider as correct regarding nasogastric tube length estimation?

Solution to Question 1:
In the given clinical scenario, the rectal temperature would be the best site to measure the core body temperature.
At extremes of high or low temperatures, like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures are highly misleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperature.
The infrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum which is representative of the core body temperature. However, it often ends up measuring the temperature of the ear canal. This is because of inadequate insertion into the ear canal due to poor manufacturing design or the presence of cerumen. Hence, it is not a reliable method of measuring the core body temperature.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of peritonitis. A patient with peritonitis lies supine without movement and has shallow breathing as any movement exacerbates the pain.
Option A: In renal colic, patients have a restless attitude, often rolling around because of pain.
Option C: In acute pancreatitis, the patient usually bends forward and assumes a knee-chest position because of abdominal pain.
Option D: Patients with meningitis present with neck stiffness.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia likely due to folate deficiency caused by alcohol addiction. Folate deficiency leads to atrophic glossitis because of damage to the epithelial surfaces.

Option B: Migratory glossitis / geographic tongue is due to rapid loss and regrowth of filiform papillae of the tongue. It is a benign inflammatory condition of the tongue associated with psoriasis and reactive arthritis.

Option C: Strawberry tongue is due to the hypertrophy of fungiform papillae. It is seen in scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease.

Option D: Macroglossia is an abnormal enlargement of the tongue and can be congenital or acquired. New-onset macroglossia in adults is highly suggestive of amyloidosis.

Solution to Question 4:
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes is suggestive of cyanosis. Cyanosis is seen when the concentration of deoxygenated or reduced hemoglobin exceeds 4 gm/dL.
Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin 1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin 0.5 gm%.
Central cyanosis is detectable when the oxygen saturation <85%. In dark-skinned individuals, it may be detectable at an oxygen saturation of 75%.
The types of cyanosis are:
Central cyanosis
Peripheral cyanosis
Due to diminished arterial ox ygen saturation/presence of a bnormal hemoglobin derivati ve.
Due to diminished peripheral blood flow.
Mucous membranes and skin are both affected
Mucous membranes of the or al cavity or those beneath the tongue are spared.
Decreases after O2suppleme ntation
Does not decrease after O2su pplementation
Solution to Question 5:
Casal’s necklace is not associated with an endocrine abnormality. It is a feature of pellagra, which occurs due to the deficiency of niacin.
Option A: Acanthosis nigricans is seen in multiple endocrinopathies like acromegaly, Cushing’s syndrome, polycystic ovary syndrome, and insulin-resistant diabetes mellitus.
Option B: Diffuse hyperpigmentation is seen in Addison’s disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome. Option D: Purple striae are seen in Cushing’s disease.
Solution to Question 6:
Petechiae are defined as skin hemorrhages appearing as minute non-blanching spots that measure less than 2 mm.
A few conditions causing petechiae have been stated below:
Infectious diseases: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, infective endocarditis, meningococcemia, and viral hemorrhagic fevers.
Non-infectious conditions: Vasculitis, thrombocytopenia, leukemia, scurvy, and vitamin K deficiency
Drugs: Anticoagulants (warfarin, heparin), quinine, etc.
Large extravasation of blood in the skin is known as ecchymosis.
Purpura are also non-blanching spots but unlike petechiae, they measure  3 mm in size.
Solution to Question 7:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi (nevus araneus). They are seen in:
Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use
Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease
Thyrotoxicosis
They are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the centre outward.
Solution to Question 8:
The given image shows digital clubbing. Among the given options, aortic dissection is least likely to cause digital clubbing.
Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface.
Causes of clubbing are:
Pulmonary
Bronchogenic carcinoma
Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
Interstitial lung diseases
Cystic fibrosis
Sarcoidosis
Asbestosis
GI
Inflammatory bowel disease (Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease)
Sprue, celiac disease
Neoplasms - esophagus, liver, bowel
Cirrhosis - juvenile and biliary
Chronic active hepatitis
Cardiovascular
Cyanotic congenital heart disease
Subacute bacterial endocarditis
Aortic aneurysm
Arteriovenous fistula
Patent ductus arteriosus with right to left shunt
Atrial myxoma
Endocrine
Grave’s disease (thyroid acropachy)
CNS
Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)
Skin disease
Palmoplantar keratoderma
Fischer-Volavsek syndrome.
Malignancies
Thyroid cancer
Thymus cancer
Hodgkin disease
Disseminated chronic myeloid leukemia.
Note: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) does not cause clubbing. If clubbing is present in a patient with COPD, underlying lung cancer and bronchiectasis must be ruled out.
Solution to Question 9:
The nail change seen in the given image is leukonychia totalis. It is a prominent feature of hypoalbuminemic states. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of liver cirrhosis, which leads to hypoalbuminemia.
Leukonychia is an opaque whitish discoloration of the nail and is seen in the following conditions:
Dietary deficiency: Protein-energy malnutrition, pellagra, zinc deficiency
Drugs: Cytotoxic agents, Steroids, Retinoids, Pilocarpine
Dermatological pathology: Alopecia areata, erythema multiforme, exfoliative dermatitis, and SLE
Systemic diseases: Liver cirrhosis, renal failure, and cardiac failure
Miscellaneous: Trauma, malignancy, and toxins (arsenic, fluoride)
Idiopathic
Note: The leukonychia secondary to arsenic poisoning is termed leukonychia striata or Aldrich–Mees lines.

Solution to Question 10:
Bilateral non-pitting edema in the lower limbs is suggestive of myxedema.
While chronic lymphangitis and acute lymphatic filariasis can also cause non-pitting edema, they usually have a unilateral/localized presentation.
Nephrotic syndrome and heart failure cause bilateral pitting edema. Causes of generalized edema include:
Heart failure
Chronic renal failure
Nephrotic syndrome
Liver cirrhosis
Causes of localized edema include:
Thrombophlebitis
Chronic lymphangitis
Resection of regional lymph nodes
Filariasis
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of water hammer pulse, which is not seen in left-sided heart failure.
Collapsing pulse/Watson’s water hammer pulse is a rapidly rising pulse that collapses suddenly. This is because arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole. It is also called Corrigan's pulse.
The various causes of the collapsing pulse include
Physiologically, it can be present in fever and pregnancy. This is attributed to the combination of increased cardiac output and the reduction in systemic vascular resistance.
Cardiac lesions such as aortic regurgitation, patent ductus arteriosus, systolic hypertension, marked bradycardia, aneurysm of sinus of Valsalva
High-output states such as anemia, cor pulmonale, thyrotoxicosis, arteriovenous fistula, Paget's disease, beriberi, and liver cirrhosis (secondary to chronic alcoholism)
Solution to Question 12:
Orthostatic hypotension or postural hypotension is defined as a sustained drop in systolic BP of
20 mmHg or diastolic BP of 10 mmHg after 3 min of standing.
It can manifest as lightheadedness/dizziness, weakness or tiredness, difficulty thinking/concentrating, blurred vision, and anxiety.
In non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension such as hypovolemia, the drop in the blood pressure is accompanied by a compensatory increase in heart rate of >15 beats/min. In neurogenic causes, there is aggravation or precipitation of orthostatic hypotension by autonomic stressors like a meal, hot bath, or exercise.
Non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension include
Cardiac pump failure - myocardial infarction, myocarditis, aortic stenosis
Hypovolemia - dehydration, diarrhea, hemorrhage
Metabolic - adrenocortical insufficiency, pheochromocytoma
Venous pooling - sepsis, prolonged standing, or recumbency
Medications - alpha-blockers, diuretics, phenothiazines, tricyclic antidepressants Treatment includes removing reversible causes like drugs causing hypotension.
Non-pharmacological interventions include patient education regarding staged moves from supine to upright, raising the head of the bed, and increasing dietary fluid and salt. If these fail, drugs like fludrocortisone and midodrine can be given.
Solution to Question 13:
Winterbottom’s sign is due to the involvement of posterior cervical nodes. It is seen in African trypanosomiasis.
African trypanosomiasis is a vector born disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense/rhodesiense. It is transmitted through the bite of a Tsetse fly.
The clinical syndrome includes hemolymphatic disease with associated Winterbottom's sign and a maculopapular rash primarily involving the trunk. At a later stage, the patient can present with features suggestive of meningoencephalitis.
Solution to Question 14:
In the given options typhoid, Q fever, and leptospirosis are infectious causes of relative bradycardia.
Relative bradycardia, also known as Faget's sign, is observed when patients exhibit a lower heart rate than anticipated in relation to an increase in body temperature. Body temperature is commonly regarded as a factor that independently influences heart rate. It is estimated that for each 1°C (1.8°F) rise in temperature, the heart rate typically increases by approximately 15-20 beats per minute.
While this pulse-temperature dissociation is not highly sensitive or specific for establishing a diagnosis, it can still prove beneficial in resource-limited settings due to its easy accessibility and simplicity.
Infectious causes of relative bradycardia include:
Salmonella typhi
Francisella tularensis
Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
Leptospira interrogans
Legionella pneumophila
Rickettsia spp.
Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus)
Corynebacterium diphtheriae
Plasmodium spp. (malaria)
Noninfectious causes include:
Drug fever
Beta-blocker use
Central nervous system lesions
Malignant lymphoma
Factitious fever
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). Splinter hemorrhages are seen in the nails of these patients.
Subungual splinter hemorrhages are classically identified as dark-red, linear petechiae in the nail bed.
Other peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:
Petechiae: Common but nonspecific finding
Purulent purpura
Osler nodes: Tender subcutaneous nodules usually found on the distal pads of the digits
Janeway lesions: Nontender maculae on the palms and soles
Roth spots: Relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers
Solution to Question 16:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is infective endocarditis.
Tender violaceous subcutaneous nodules in the fingers shown in the image are Osler nodes. They usually occur in the pads of fingers and toes but can also occur on the thenar and hypothenar eminences.
Other lesions that are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis include:
Roth spots: These are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centres.
Janeway lesions: They are nontender, slightly raised haemorrhages on the palms and soles. The image is shown below.

Solution to Question 17:
On examination of the chest wall, the presence of thrills indicates a palpable murmur. Thrills are the palpable vibrations produced by turbulent blood flow causing murmurs.
Palpable S3 and S4 cause a double thrust in the apical impulse.
Palpable right ventricular systole is known as heave which is felt in the left parasternal area.
Solution to Question 18:
The commonly used method to determine the length of a nasogastric tube is the NEX method: the tip of the nose to the ear to the xiphisternum.
The approximate length is 120-125 cm. The markings indicate the traversing of the tube through various parts of the GIT:
40 cm: Cardia of the stomach
50 cm: Body of the stomach
60 cm: Pylorus
70 cm: Duodenum
A nasogastric tube or Ryle's tube is inserted in the sitting position with the neck slightly flexed. The tube is then gently inserted through the nostril and advanced until it reaches 10 cm. The patient is encouraged to swallow, allowing the tube to move down the esophagus with successive swallows until it reaches the measured distance.
Subjective confirmation involves insufflating air through the proximal opening of the NG tube and listening for the sound of air in the left upper quadrant where the stomach is located. Objective confirmation can be obtained through pH measurement, chest or abdominal radiographs, ultrasound, or calorimetric capnometry.
While widely practiced, blind NG tube insertion can lead to complications such as coiling of the tube in the nasopharynx, incorrect placement in the bronchial passage, or even esophageal perforation.
Solution to Question 19:
The most likely diagnosis in the given scenario is hyperglycemia. The symptoms of hyperglycemia include:
Polyuria
Polydipsia
Weight loss
Fatigue
Blurry vision
Frequent superficial infections (vaginitis, fungal skin infections)
Slow healing of skin lesions after minor trauma.
Note: The metabolic derangements occurring in these patients are due to osmotic diuresis and a catabolic state caused by urinary loss of glucose and increased muscle breakdown. Blurred vision results from changes in the water content of the lens.
Solution to Question 20:
The temperature of the water bath for a patient with frostbite should be maintained between 37- 40°C (Option A). Circulating water is preferred for treatment.
In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vasoconstriction. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.
The treatment includes - extraction from cold environment, rapid rewarming, analgesics for pain during thawing, antithrombotics or thrombolytics, cleaning of the injured area with soap or antiseptics, tetanus prophylaxis, monitoring for compartment syndrome and finally, elective late amputation after imaging in severe cases.

A 40-year-old woman was rushed to the ER with chest pain, palpitations, and sweating. On examination, her respiratory rate was 32/min, and carpopedal spasm was noted while measuring BP. Her ECG was normal. Which of the following acid-base disorders is she likely to have?

The arterial blood gas analysis of an unconscious man showed pH- 6.9, HCO3- 13 mEq/L, paCO2- 68 mmHg. The acid-base status of this patient is best described as:

Solution to Question 1:
The most effective extracellular buffer system at physiological pH is the bicarbonate buffer system.
A molecule with a pKa close to the physiological pH (7.4) is considered an effective buffer. Although the pKa of HCO3- is relatively low (6.1), it makes up 92% of the plasma buffering.
This is often attributed to the enormous quantity of HCO3- present in the body and the ability of this system to accept protons and form carbonic acid (H2CO3). This further in the presence of carbonic anhydrase is converted to readily excretable H■O and CO2. It is therefore considered the most efficient extracellular buffering system in the body.
HCO3- + H+	H2CO3 	H■O + CO2
Solution to Question 2:
Flexion of the wrist is not done just before drawing blood for ABG analysis.
During arterial blood gas analysis, the ideal position for drawing arterial blood from the radial artery is to maintain the wrist in extension. This provides stability to the artery and prevents it from slipping away during the puncture. To draw blood for ABG analysis, the skin is pierced at a 45° angle.

Allen's test is done prior to radial cannulation to identify the adequacy of radial and ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand.

The syringe used to draw blood for ABG analysis is rinsed with heparin prior to the procedure. Prior to collecting blood, 0.1 ml heparin is drawn into the syringe and then flushed
out. The residue that lubricates the inner wall of the syringe is sufficient to prevent the blood from clotting.
Solution to Question 3:
Mineralocorticoid deficiency does not cause metabolic alkalosis. Its excess causes metabolic alkalosis.
Causes of metabolic alkalosis:
Loss of hydrogen:
Gastrointestinal loss
Removal of gastric secretions - vomiting or nasogastric suction
Chloride-losing diarrhea
Gastrocolic fistula
Villous adenoma
Antacid therapy, particularly if combined with cation exchange resin
Renal loss
Loop or thiazide diuretics
Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice)
Posthypercapnic states
Hypercalcemia, including milk-alkali syndrome
H+ movement into cells
Hypokalemia Exogenous Alkali:
Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids
Massive blood transfusion
Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome Contraction alkalosis (loss of ECF volume):
Loop or thiazide-type diuretics
Sweat losses in cystic fibrosis
Gastric losses in achlorhydria Miscellaneous:
Bartter's syndrome
Gitelman's syndrome
Solution to Question 4:
The metabolic abnormality patients with bulimia nervosa are least likely to develop is metabolic acidosis. Chronic vomiting, as seen in bulimia nervosa leads to metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis.
Conditions associated with chronic vomiting lead to hypochloremia, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.
Solution to Question 5:
Metabolic alkalosis is associated with potassium depletion, not hyperkalemia.
While hypercalcemia can be a cause of metabolic alkalosis, alkalosis itself can cause a decrease in ionized calcium. The patients can present with tetany and show signs of hypocalcemia, i.e., Trousseau sign and Chvostek's sign.
Conn's syndrome is primary hyperaldosteronism that leads to sodium reabsorption in exchange for hydrogen in the collecting ducts. This causes hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and hydrogen loss in urine and may lead to metabolic alkalosis.
Renin-secreting tumors also lead to an increase in aldosterone levels leading to alkalosis. Causes of metabolic alkalosis:
Loss of hydrogen:
Gastrointestinal loss
Removal of gastric secretions- vomiting or nasogastric suction
Chloride-losing diarrhea
Gastrocolic fistula
Villous adenoma
Antacid therapy, particularly if combined with cation exchange resin
Renal loss
Loop or thiazide diuretics
Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice)
Posthypercapnic states

Solution to Question 7:
The underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.
Interpretation of the ABG:
Step 1: A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis.
Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 40 mEq/L, which in the presence of a high pH indicates metabolic alkalosis.
Step 3: pCO2 is 54 mmHg indicating respiratory acidosis. The increase in pCO2 along with the increase in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.
Step 4: Assessing the compensatory response:
On average, the pCO2 rises 0.75 mmHg for every 1.0 mEq/L increment in the plasma HCO3-
In the above scenario, the plasma HCO3- concentration is increased to 40 mEq/L (The average normal value is considered as 24 mEq/L)
Thus, the HCO3- elevation is 40 – 24 = 16 mEq/L Therefore, pCO2 elevation should be 0.75 × 16 = 12 mmHg
Now, considering that the average value of normal pCO2 is 40 mmHg, the estimated pCO2 measured should be 40 + 12= 52 mmHg.
As pCO2 is higher than the expected estimate, it is a case of metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.
Solution to Question 8:
The patient has low pH and decreased levels of bicarbonate which is indicative of metabolic acidosis. Bicarbonate reabsorption is increased in renal handling of metabolic acidosis.
In response to metabolic acidosis, acidification of urine occurs by the following compensatory mechanisms:
The proximal tubule reabsorbs all the filtered HCO3- (as any loss of HCO3- is equal to the addition of an equimolar amount of H+).
The collecting duct excretes the daily H+ load (loss of H+ is equal to the addition of an equimolar amount of HCO3-) primarily in the form of urinary ammonia.
Solution to Question 9:
The anion gap is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:
Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])
Substituting the given values, AG is 22 mmol/L. Normal AG is 6 to 12 mmol/L with an average of 10 mmol/L.
The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Therefore, there is no real “anion gap” in the plasma.
However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl and HCO3. The value of plasma potassium is omitted from the calculation of the anion gap.
Usually, the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations.
The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall.
The unmeasured anions include albumin, phosphate, sulfate, and other organic anions. The unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium, and potassium.
Solution to Question 10:
The anion gap is increased in ketoacidosis. The ketone bodies act as unmeasured anions and increase the anion gap.
The anion gap is calculated as:
AG = (Na+) – [(Cl-) + (HCO3-)]
The normal anion gap is 6 - 12 mEq/L (optimally <10 mEq/L).
Solution to Question 11:
Renal tubular acidosis causes normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, not high anion gap acidosis.
Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, a few of the anionic proteins (e.g., albumin), phosphates, sulfates, and organic anions are not measured and this is called an anion gap. It is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:
Plasma anion gap = [Na+] ([Cl-]+[HCO3-])
The normal anion gap ranges between 6-12 mEq/L.
Solution to Question 12:
Metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap is a feature of renal tubular acidosis.
Renal tubular acidosis is a form of hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis which occurs when the renal damage primarily affects tubular function without much effect on glomerular function. The bicarbonate loss leading to acidosis is mirrored by an increase in chloride concentration. Hence the unmeasured anions are unaffected and thus, the anion gap remains within normal limits.
The result is a decrease in H+ excretion which is greater than that can be explained by any change in the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). However, if the GFR is significantly depressed eg., renal failure, the retention of fixed acids leads to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
Solution to Question 13:
Metformin toxicity is associated with type B lactic acidosis.
Lactic acidosis is defined as an increase in plasma lactate levels. The various types of lactic acidosis are:
D-lactic acidosis is an unusual form of metabolic acidosis. It occurs due to the formation of D-lactate by gut bacteria. It occurs in patients with:
Short bowel syndrome

Solution to Question 14:
The probable diagnosis is a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) with metabolic alkalosis. Interpretation of the ABG:
Step 1: The pH being 7.4 is within normal limits.
Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 23 mEq/L and again is within normal limits.
At this juncture, we have ruled out options B and C as this particular clinical scenario is not suggestive of a simple acid-base disorder.
Step 3: Calculating the Anion gap:
Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])
= 145-(100+23)
= 22 mEq/L
The presence of a high anion gap indicates that there's indeed an acid-base disorder, thus ruling out option A.
A high anion gap indicates metabolic acidosis. However, HCO3- levels within normal limits suggest that there is also coexisting metabolic alkalosis in this patient.
This can be confirmed by calculating the delta gap. Delta gap = AG - HCO3-
In this scenario: Delta gap = (22-10) - (24-23) = 11 mEq/L
Delta gap is > +6 suggesting the presence of metabolic alkalosis along with HAGMA.
If the delta gap is significantly positive (>+6), metabolic alkalosis is present because the rise in the anion gap is more than the fall in bicarbonate. If the delta gap is significantly negative (<6) then hyperchloremic acidosis is usually present because a rise in the anion gap is less than a fall in bicarbonate.
Alternatively, this can be confirmed by calculating the delta ratio. Delta ratio = the increase in Anion Gap / the decrease in HCO3-
It is used in the presence of a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), to check it is a ‘pure’ HAGMA or if there is coexistant normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) or metabolic alkalosis.
Delta ratio values:
subject: Medicine

question_text:
2 indicates HAGMA
< 1 indicates NAGMA + HAGMA
> 2 indicates HAGMA + Metabolic alkalosis In this scenario,
Delta ratio = 12/1 = 12
Thus, the acid-base disorder for the above scenario is HAGMA with metabolic alkalosis.
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. This leads to a decrease in serum albumin which is an unmeasured anion.
Albumin at physiological pH is the major contributor to the unmeasured anions of the body. Unmeasured anions consume bicarbonate in the body and reduce its levels. This leads to an increase in the anion gap. Therefore, when these unmeasured anions are reduced the anion gap also reduces due to decreased consumption of the bicarbonate.
Nephrotic syndrome causes hypoalbuminemia and thus patients have a reduced anion gap. A fall in serum albumin by 1 g/dL from the normal value (4.5 g/dL) decreases the anion gap by 2.5 mEq/L.
Decreased anion gap (<6 mEq/L) is seen in:
Increase in unmeasured cations
An addition of abnormal cations to the blood, such as:
Lithium (lithium intoxication)
Cationic immunoglobulins (plasma cell dyscrasias)
Reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration (nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or malabsorption)
Bromide intoxication
Hyperviscosity and severe hyperlipidemia, which can lead to an underestimation of sodium and chloride concentrations.
Solution to Question 16:
In renal failure, there is a loss of kidney function due to the damage affecting glomeruli and tubules. This leads to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
Solution to Question 17:
The underlying acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.
Interpretation of the ABG:
Step 1: A pH of 7.1 signifies acidosis.
Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 6 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis.
Step 3: pCO2 is 16 mmHg indicating respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in pCO2 along with the decrease in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.
Step 4: The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula
(Expected PCO2= {[1.5 x HCO3-] +8} ± 2).
Expected PCO2 = {[1.5 x 6] +8} ± 2 = 15 to 19 mmHg
A pCO2 level of 16 mmHg falls within the range given above. Hence, metabolic acidosis is associated with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.
(pCO2 values above or below 15 - 19 mmHg would indicate mixed acid-base disorders) Alternatively:
The other method to calculate the expected compensation is a 1.2 mmHg decrease in pCO2 for every 1 mmol/L decrease in bicarbonate.
The decrease in bicarbonate is 24 - 6 = 18 mEq/L Decrease in pCO2 is 18 x 1.2 = 22
Expected pCO2 = 40 - 22 = 18 mmHg (roughly = 16 mmHg since the standard values are approximations)
This method also indicates primary metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis. However, Winter's formula is more accurate.

The probable reason for the patient's presenting symptoms is respiratory acidosis.
Asthma attack leads to the narrowing of respiratory passages. This leads to reduced O2 inhalation and reduced CO2 exhalation contributing to the rise of pCO2 in the blood, thereby
causing respiratory acidosis. Causes of respiratory acidosis:

Solution to Question 19:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis. Interpretation of the ABG:
Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.
Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.
Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis.
Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:
Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 š  PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)
Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.
The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.
But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.
Solution to Question 20:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute severe asthma. The acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis, partially compensated.
Interpretation of the ABG:
Step 1: pH is decreased. This signifies acidosis. In acidosis, either pCO2 is increased or plasma HCO3- is decreased.
Step 2: In this case, pCO2 is increased by 30 mmHg. This signifies respiratory acidosis.
Step 3: Plasma HCO3- is increased by 26-24 = 2 mEq/L. This signifies compensation is taking place.
In acute conditions, for every 10mmHg rise in pCO2 expected rise in plasma HCO3- is 1mEq/L. In this case, pCO2 has risen by 30 mmHg, so the expected rise in HCO3- is 3 mEq/L.
However, plasma HCO3- has risen only by 2 mEq/L, which implies compensation is only partial.
Solution to Question 21:
The above findings give the diagnosis of respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. Interpretation of the ABG:
Step 1: pH is reduced (7.12), hence acidosis.
Step 2: Since pCO2 is raised (50 mmHg), it is respiratory acidosis.
Step 3: HCO3 is raised (28 mEq/L) suggesting there is metabolic compensation.
Solution to Question 22:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic attack. The patient is likely to have respiratory alkalosis.
Panic attacks are characterized by hyperventilation which leads to a washout of CO2 (reduced PaCO2). This further increases the ratio of bicarbonate concentration to PaCO2 and, thereby, increases the pH level causing alkalosis.
Alkalosis promotes the binding of calcium to albumin and reduces the fraction of ionized calcium in the blood. This leads to hypocalcemia without reducing the total calcium levels. Thus, alkalosis can precipitate tetany and laryngospasm, especially in calcium-deficient patients.
Induction of carpopedal spasm when the BP cuff is inflated 20 mm Hg over the systolic BP for three minutes or more is called Trousseau sign. It is a clinical manifestation of hypocalcemia.
Causes of respiratory alkalosis:
Central nervous system stimulation:
Pain
Anxiety, psychosis
Fever
Cerebrovascular accident
meningitis, encephalitis
Tumor
Trauma
Hypoxemia or tissue hypoxia:
High altitude
Pneumonia, pulmonary edema
Aspiration
Severe anemia
Drugs or hormones:
Pregnancy
Salicylates
Cardiac failure
Stimulation of chest receptors:
Hemothorax
Flail chest
Cardiac failure
Pulmonary embolism
Miscellaneous:
Septicemia
Hepatic failure
Mechanical hyperventilation
Heat exposure
Recovery from metabolic acidosis
Note: While metabolic alkalosis can also cause hypocalcemia, the above scenario of hyperventilation is more suggestive of respiratory alkalosis. Furthermore, hypocalcemic symptoms are more common with respiratory alkalosis.
Solution to Question 23:
In the given illustrated acid-base nomogram, the letters A and D indicate acute respiratory acidosis and acute respiratory alkalosis.
An acid-base nomogram, also known as a Davenport diagram, is a graphical representation of acid-base balance to interpret arterial blood gas (ABG) results. It helps determine the primary acid-base disorder and identify compensatory mechanisms.

The y-axis of the acid-base nomogram represents the arterial bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels, and the x-axis represents the arterial pH values. The shaded areas are the range of values of the normal respiratory and metabolic compensations for primary acid-base disturbances.
Solution to Question 24:
The mechanism for the secondary disorder is hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout.
The given arterial blood gas findings are suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. The compensation is partial because the fall in paCO2 much lower than what is expected for the given HCO3 levels. The fall in paCO2 is inadequate due to hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout. In this case, the secondary disorder is respiratory acidosis.
Hyperventilation causing increased CO2 washout (Option B) would allow for better compensation, with lower paCO2 levels than observed.
The expected paCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula:
For metabolic acidosis, the expected paCO2 = [1 .5 š HCO3-] + 8 ± 2. Substituting the values, expected PaCO2 = (1.5 x 10) +8 ± 2
= 15+8 ±2
= 21 to 25 mmHg
However, the actual PaCO2 is 30 mmHg, which is higher than the expected paCO2 indicating a secondary respiratory acidosis. A possible explanation for this could only be hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout.
Thus, the given ABG findings are suggestive of a mixed acid-base disorder characterized by metabolic acidosis with additional respiratory acidosis.
For example, in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis and pneumonia, the lungs would fail to compensate, and the patient could develop hypoventilation leading to secondary respiratory
acidosis.
Solution to Question 25:
According to the ABG analysis provided, the patient has a mixed acid-base disorder with simultaneous respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
Interpretation of the ABG:
Step 1: A pH of 6.9 signifies acidosis.
Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 13 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis.
Step 3: pCO2 is 68 mmHg indicating co-existing respiratory acidosis. The direction of pCO2 change is the same as that of pH change suggesting that this is a mixed acid-base disorder.
Step 4: The expected compensatory change in pCO2 in the metabolic acidosis calculated using Winter's formula would be:
pCO2 = [1.5xHCO3-] + 8 ± 2 = 26 - 30 mmHg
The actual pCO2 measure is very high (68 mmHg) compared to the estimated range of 26 - 30 mmHg indicating the presence of simultaneous metabolic and respiratory acidosis.
Note- If this was a case of uncompensated acidosis, either the bicarbonate or the pCO2 values would have been within the normal limits.

Solution to Question 1:
Vasopressin acts on the V2 receptor using cAMP as its second messenger.
Vasopressin acts on GPCR using different second messengers to accomplish its various actions as follows:
V1 receptor - vasoconstriction using phospholipase C as its second messenger
V2 receptor - reabsorption of water through aquaporin 2, using cAMP as its second messenger
Vasopressin has a maximum effect on the collecting ducts. It acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to the apical membrane.
Solution to Question 2:
cAMP is the second messenger for the hormone secretin. It regulates fluid and electrolyte secretion and also mediates water and nutrient reabsorption.
Solution to Question 3:
Nitric oxide mediates its action via cyclic GMP or cGMP.
cGMP is the second messenger associated with smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Atrial natriuretic factor (ANF) and NO (nitric oxide) are the only hormones that mediate their action via cGMP.
Note: Recent studies show that NO is a hormone. NO, which functions as a chemical messenger, has similar properties to hormones (which are known as the body's chemical messengers).
Solution to Question 4:
Growth hormone (GH) is the most abundant hormone produced by the pituitary gland.
It is produced by the acidophil cells or somatotropes of the anterior pituitary, which account for 50% of the anterior pituitary cell population.
Option A: Vasopressin is produced in the hypothalamus and only stored in the posterior pituitary. Option C: Corticotrophs account for 10% of the anterior pituitary cell population.
Option D: Thyrotrophs account for 5% of the anterior pituitary cell population.
Solution to Question 5:
Insulin acts on the tyrosine kinase receptor, a cell-surface receptor.
Solution to Question 6:
GH and prolactin are called twin hormones as both are secreted by the acidophil cells of the anterior pituitary. They act on cytokine receptors and show JAK-STAT activity.
Solution to Question 7:
The thyroid hormone is synthesized from tyrosine residues and thus is an amino acid derivative. Insulin, activin and parathyroid hormone are large protein hormones.
Solution to Question 8:
Inhibin is a large protein hormone, not a steroid hormone.
All adrenocortical and reproductive hormones are steroid hormones synthesized from cholesterol precursors except activin and inhibin.
Solution to Question 9:
Insulin is classified as a large protein hormone (>50 amino acid residues) as it is composed of 51 amino acids.
Protein and polypeptide hormones are classified as small peptides (< 50 amino acid residues) and large proteins.
Solution to Question 10:
The action of cAMP is mediated by protein kinases.
cAMP is a second messenger molecule associated with electrolyte secretion and water and nutrient reabsorption. It is synthesized by adenylyl cyclase but it mediates its actions via protein kinases.
Solution to Question 11:
cAMP is synthesized by adenylyl cyclase, but it mediates its actions via protein kinases.
Solution to Question 12:
The binding of epinephrine to its various receptors results in the activation of different types of G-protein subunits, namely Gq, Gi, and Gs.
All catecholamines act via G protein-coupled receptors. This stimulates cAMP production and signaling via protein kinases.
Solution to Question 13:
Kinases are a subclass of transferases that catalyze the transfer of a phosphate group from a donor to an acceptor protein. They are associated with the regulation of many essential cellular processes.

Solution to Question 1:
Hyperglycemia is not a characteristic of GH deficiency. Isolated GH deficiency, especially in children, can lead to a higher propensity to develop hypoglycemia. This is attributed to the relatively unopposed action of insulin.
Isolated GH deficiency in children is associated with the following features:
Short stature
Micropenis
Increased fat
High-pitched voice
High propensity to develop hypoglycemia due to relatively unopposed insulin action.
Solution to Question 2:
Laron-type dwarfism, also known as GH-insensitivity syndrome, is characterized by GH-receptor anomalies.
Laron-type dwarfism is an autosomal recessive disorder. The primary clinical symptom associated with this condition is short stature. Treatment is by subcutaneous injections of insulin-like growth factor 1 (a growth-promoting hormone), often called IGF-1.
Solution to Question 3:
GH is a potent counter-regulatory hormone to insulin and leads to hyperglycemia, thus contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled diabetes.
Side effects of GH administration include:
Dose-related fluid retention
Hyperglycemia
Joint pain and carpal tunnel syndrome
Headache, increased intracranial pressure, hypertension
Tinnitus
Pituitary tumor regrowth
Progression of skin lesions
Acromegaly
Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
Gynecomastia
The actions of GH are:
Induces protein synthesis and nitrogen retention
Impairs glucose tolerance by antagonizing insulin action
Stimulates lipolysis
Promotes sodium, potassium, and water retention
Elevates serum levels of inorganic phosphate
Linear bone growth occurs
Stimulates epiphyseal prechondrocyte differentiation
Solution to Question 4:
The paradoxical response of GH release to TRH is not seen in malnutrition patients.
In normal individuals, GH doesn't respond to TRH stimulation, but paradoxically, the GH levels may increase in response to TRH stimulation in the following conditions:
Acromegaly
Prolactinoma
Anorexia nervosa
The exact mechanism underlying this paradoxical GH response is poorly understood.
Solution to Question 5:
The most common cause of acromegaly is GH secretion from somatotrope adenoma. Causes of acromegaly:
Pituitary - 98%
Somatotrope adenoma - 60% - most common.
Mixed somatotroph-lactotroph adenoma
Other plurihormonal tumors.
Extrapituitary tumor-producing GH: Pancreatic Islet cell tumor
Excess GHRH secretion
Central - hypothalamic hamartoma
Peripheral - bronchial carcinoid
Solution to Question 6:
Impaired glucose tolerance, galactorrhea, and hypertension can be seen in patients with acromegaly.
GH secretion is a part of the counter-regulatory defense mechanism against hypoglycemia. Physiological GH secretion is inhibited by hyperglycemia. In acromegaly or gigantism, GH secretion is autonomous and not suppressed by glucose. Thus, its diagnosis can be confirmed by demonstrating the failure of GH suppression with an oral glucose load (impaired oral glucose tolerance test).
Galactorrhea is due to hyperprolactinemia and hypertension is secondary to increased aldosterone levels in acromegaly. GH leads to increased production of vitamin D3 which results in increased phosphate absorption from the intestine and decreased renal excretion. Hence there is increased serum phosphate level.
Solution to Question 7:
The given scenario and the enlarged hands in the patient, as shown in the image, point towards a diagnosis of acromegaly. Diabetes insipidus is not a feature of acromegaly, but diabetes mellitus can develop in patients with acromegaly.

Solution to Question 8:
The given scenario and the presence of coarse facial features and prognathism, as shown in the image, points towards a diagnosis of acromegaly. An oral glucose tolerance test with GH levels is used to confirm acromegaly.
Solution to Question 9:
The best screening test for acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1
(IGF-1) level. Other options:
Options A and B: Oral glucose challenge test with growth hormone (GH) levels is used for further confirmation of the diagnosis. Increased insulin-like growth factor-1 binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3) levels can also be seen in patients with acromegaly. But they are not typically used as initial screening methods.
Option D: IGF-1 levels are more reliable than random GH levels because GH secretion is pulsatile. IGF-1 levels reflect long-term exposure to GH and provide a more stable indicator of excessive GH production.
Acromegaly is characterized by excessive GH secretion, usually caused by a somatotrope adenoma in the pituitary gland. It can also be due to ectopic GH secretion or hypothalamic tumors.
The clinical presentation of acromegaly includes frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, coarse facial features, mandibular prognathism, widened space between lower incisors and other manifestations such as soft tissue swelling, deepening voice, carpal tunnel syndrome, arthropathy, and acanthosis nigricans.
It can also lead to cardiovascular complications (cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, and hypertension), obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes mellitus, an increased risk of colon polyps, and colonic malignancy.
The primary treatment for acromegaly is surgical resection of GH-secreting adenomas. Somatostatin receptor ligands like octreotide and lanreotide, which suppress GH and IGF-1 levels, are used as adjuvant treatment or when surgery is not possible or unsuccessful. Radiation therapy may be considered for patients who cannot tolerate or do not respond to medical therapy. Other treatment options include GH receptor antagonists like pegvisomant and dopamine agonists like cabergoline.
Solution to Question 10:
Levodopa is not used in the treatment of acromegaly. Studies have proven that it is not as effective as agents like cabergoline.
Medical management of acromegaly includes:
Somatostatin analogs:
Octreotide
Lanreotide
Pasireotide
GH-receptor antagonists:
Pegvisomant
Dopamine agonists:
Bromocriptine
Cabergoline
Solution to Question 11:
This given scenario of infertility, amenorrhea and galactorrhea with elevated prolactin level (normal level is 0-25 ng/ml in a non-pregnant woman) is suggestive of hyperprolactinemia, and bromocriptine does not lead to hyperprolactinemia. It is a dopamine-agonist and hence it inhibits prolactin synthesis.
Dopamine agonists like bromocriptine and cabergoline are used in the treatment of hyperprolactinemia.
Solution to Question 12:
Hypothyroidism predisposes to the development of hyperprolactinemia.
Both enhanced hypothalamic synthesis of TRH and increased pituitary-responsiveness to TRH have been described as the mechanism behind this phenomenon.
Other systemic disorders that predispose to the development of hyperprolactinemia :
Chronic renal failure
Cirrhosis
Pseudocyesis
Epileptic seizures
Solution to Question 13:
The hallmarks of hyperprolactinemia in women are:
Amenorrhea – (Secondary > Primary)
Galactorrhea
Infertility
In men with hyperprolactinemia, diminished libido, infertility, and visual loss (from optic nerve compression) are the usual presenting symptoms.
Solution to Question 14:
TSH should be measured along with the prolactin level to rule out hypothyroidism which can cause hyperprolactinemia.
Note: However, pregnancy (using qualitative HCG) should be ruled out in all women of the reproductive age group with amenorrhea.
Solution to Question 15:
The drug of choice for clinical management of this patient would be bromocriptine.
Bromocriptine is an ergot alkaloid and a short-acting dopamine receptor agonist. Due to its short-term action, it is preferred when pregnancy is desired.
Cabergoline is a long-acting dopamine receptor agonist with high D2 receptor affinity. It effectively suppresses PRL secretion for >14 days after a single oral dose.

Solution to Question 1:
Prolactin-secreting adenoma or prolactinoma is the most common type of functioning pituitary adenoma. Pituitary adenomas are the most common type of pituitary tumor, accounting for one-third of all tumors.
Solution to Question 2:
Non-functioning pituitary adenomas most commonly arise from gonadotropic cells (80%).
Pituitary adenomas are classified as functioning or non-functioning based on the secretion of hormones. Non-functioning adenomas are usually asymptomatic in the initial stages but as the tumor grows larger, mass effect produces clinical manifestations such as:
Headache
Bitemporal hemianopia
Diplopia, ptosis
Compression of pituitary stalk
Hyperprolactinemia initially - reduced dopamine release leads to loss of inhibition of lactotrophs
Hypopituitarism in later stages
Solution to Question 3:
Pituitary adenomas < 10 mm are called microadenomas.
Asymptomatic pituitary tumors can be discovered incidentally on imaging. They must also be suspected in patients with features of hormone hypersecretion or mass effect. In such cases, MRI with contrast is the best investigation to detect the tumor, as shown below.

Levels of pituitary hormones must also be measured to rule out both hypersecretion and hyposecretion.
Solution to Question 4:
Pituitary macroadenomas do not cause pigmentation of mucous membranes as ACTH levels are low.
In this condition, there is destruction of the pituitary gland by mass effect. This leads to panhypopituitarism or reduced levels of all hormones, including ACTH. Excessive pigmentation is only seen in cases of excess ACTH.
The following hormones are deficient in panhypopituitarism:
ACTH - Secondary adrenal insufficiency
TSH - Secondary hypothyroidism
GH - Growth failure and adult hyposomatotropism
FSH, LH - Hypogonadic hypogonadism
Prolactin - Lactation failure
Adiponectin, secreted by fat cells normally increases insulin sensitivity. It is usually suppressed by cortisol. In panhypopituitarism, decreased cortisol levels lead to increased insulin sensitivity.
Solution to Question 5:
Superior quadrantanopia may be seen in patients with prolactinoma > 10 mm in size
(macroadenoma).
In this condition, visual field defects occur due to compression of the optic chiasm. In the initial stages, the pituitary tumor tends to compress the ventral portion of the optic chiasm. This causes a bitemporal (heteronymous) superior field defect. As the tumor grows larger, the entire optic chiasm gets compressed, leading to complete bitemporal hemianopia, as shown below.
Damage to the optic radiation in the temporal lobe would result in homonymous superior quadrantanopia or pie-in-the-sky appearance.
Solution to Question 6:
The diagnosis of a prolactinoma is highly likely when prolactin levels are > 200 g/L.
The normal range of serum prolactin (PRL) is 5-20 g/L. Prolactin levels < 100 g/L can be due to non-functioning pituitary adenomas or non-neoplastic causes of hyperprolactinemia. MRI brain must be done in all patients with hyperprolactinemia.
Prolactinoma are tumors arising from the lactotroph cells of the pituitary gland, they can be classified as microadenoma(<1cm in diameter, usually non invasive ) or macroadenoma(>1cm, locally invasive to adjacent structures). Clinical features include amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea in women, impotence, loss of libido, infertility in men and if tumor extends beyond sella, there can be visual field defects and other mass effects.
Treatment - In asymptomatic patients and those where fertility is not desired, they do not require treatment and can be monitored using regular PRL measurements and MRI. In symptomatic microadenoma cases, oral dopamine agonists (cabergoline and bromocriptine) form the main treatment for hyperprolactinemia and reduction of tumor volume. For macroadenoma, before starting dopamine agonists visual field testing is to be done, and reassess it with MRI changes every 6-12 month intervals until maximum reduction is achieved, in unresponsive cases consider surgery.
Solution to Question 7:
MEN2 syndrome is not associated with pituitary tumors. It is associated with medullary thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma.
The genetic syndromes associated with pituitary tumors include:
MEN1
MEN4
Carney complex tumors
McCune-Albright Syndrome
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario describes a woman presenting with hypopituitarism following
trans-sphenoidal resection. Mineralocorticoid supplementation is not needed postoperatively as it is regulated by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and not by ACTH. Therefore, mineralocorticoid levels would remain intact despite ACTH deficiency.
Thyroid hormone, estradiol, and glucocorticoid supplementation are needed in this patient as their secretion is regulated by anterior pituitary hormones.
Features of hypopituitarism include growth abnormalities in children with a growth hormone deficiency, insufficient levels of gonadotropins leading to menstrual irregularities, infertility in women and reduced sexual function, infertility and loss of secondary sexual characteristics in men. TSH deficiency leads to stunted growth in children and features of hypothyroidism in both children and adults. ACTH deficiency leads to secondary adrenal insufficiency.
Polyuria and polydipsia may be seen and indicate a loss of vasopressin secretion in posterior pituitary lesions.
The following hormones must be replaced post-hypophysectomy:
Trophic hormone defic it

TSH

FSH/LH
Males: TestosteroneFemales: For fertility: menopausal gon adotropins, hCGPost-menopa usal women: Conjugated estr ogen, progesterone
GH

Intranasal desmopressin
Solution to Question 9:
Headache is the most common presenting symptom of craniopharyngioma.
Craniopharyngiomas are benign, suprasellar cystic masses. They have a bimodal distribution, occurring predominantly in children but also between the ages of 55 and 65 years. It can present with the following clinical symptoms:
Headache
Hypopituitarism
Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
Central diabetes insipidus
Bitemporal hemianopia
Raised ICT - vomiting, papilledema, hydrocephalus
Solution to Question 10:
The given MRI showing a suprasellar mass with calcifications is suggestive of a craniopharyngioma. Surgery is not curative in the majority of patients as the tumor is adherent to surrounding structures.
They are benign epithelial cell-containing tumors and are of two types:
Adamantinomatous - calcifications and keratin nodules are seen
Papillary - calcifications are rare
Biopsy reveals machinery or motor-oil-like fluid within the cyst that contains cholesterol
crystals. The treatment of choice is transcranial or transsphenoidal resection. It must be followed by postoperative radiation to prevent recurrence.
Solution to Question 11:
Pituitary apoplexy does not occur in hyperthyroidism. It is a rare endocrine emergency which can occur due to haemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland. It may occur as a result of the following conditions:
Pituitary adenoma (spontaneous)
Sheehan syndrome
Acute shock
Diabetes mellitus
Hypertension
Sickle cell anemia
Solution to Question 12:
Shock is seen in pituitary apoplexy.
Loss of consciousness (Option C) can also be seen but it occurs secondary to adrenal insufficiency and shock. Hence, shock is the most appropriate answer.
Pituitary apoplexy refers to acute hemorrhagic infarction of the pituitary gland. This results in the compression of surrounding structures and hypopituitarism leading to acute adrenal insufficiency. It may be seen spontaneously in a pre-existing pituitary adenoma, post-partum (Sheehan’s syndrome), or be associated with hypertension, diabetes mellitus or sickle cell anemia or shock.
Pituitary apoplexy is an endocrine emergency that can lead to severe hypoglycemia, hypotension, shock, central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage, and death. Acute clinical manifestations commonly encompass intense headaches with signs of meningeal irritation, bilateral visual changes, ophthalmoplegia, and even cardiovascular collapse.
The investigation of choice is MRI.
Patients who do not exhibit overt visual impairment or altered mental status can be managed conservatively with high-dose glucocorticoids. Progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or altered mental status necessitate expeditious surgical decompression.
Solution to Question 13:
Growth hormone (GH) is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome. The hormones are affected in the order of GH  Prolactin  LH and FSH  ACTH  TSH
Sheehan syndrome refers to postpartum pituitary necrosis following severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). During pregnancy, the pituitary gland undergoes hypertrophy with increased blood supply. This makes it susceptible to ischemia and infarction when there is severe hypovolemia.
The clinical presentation depends on the amount of damage to the pituitary.
Mild - can go unnoticed for many years
Moderate - develops over months
Lactation failure
Failure to resume menses
Mild fatigue and anorexia
Severe - endocrine emergency that develops within few days
Hypotension and shock
Severe hypoglycemia
Lactation failure
GH deficiency is very common in Sheehan’s syndrome because somatotrophs are located in the lower and lateral regions of the pituitary gland, and are most likely to be damaged by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary.
Solution to Question 14:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Sheehan syndrome. Corticosteroids must be supplemented first, as life-threatening manifestations may occur due to the sudden onset of adrenal insufficiency. This is followed by the replacement of other deficient pituitary hormones including thyroid hormone and estrogen administered with or without progesterone.

Solution to Question 1:
Oxytocin plays a role in milk ejection. It also helps in initiation or facilitation of labour by stimulating the contraction of uterine smooth muscles.
It stimulates postpartum milk let-down in response to suckling. Prolactin is the hormone responsible for milk production.
Osmoregulation is mediated by hormones such as ADH, aldosterone, etc.
Solution to Question 2:
AVP/Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and oxytocin are stored in Herring bodies at the axon terminals of the posterior pituitary. They are synthesized by two types of magnocellular neurons in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus.
Solution to Question 3:
AVP binds to V2 receptors on the serosal surface (also called basolateral surface) of renal tubular cells.
This interaction activates adenylyl cyclase and leads to the insertion of water channels called aquaporin 2 on the luminal surface of the cell.
Solution to Question 4:
ADH secretion reduces when the plasma osmolality becomes low. ADH causes water reabsorption and dilutes the plasma, thereby causing a reduction in plasma osmolality.
The antidiuretic effect of ADH is mediated via a G protein-coupled V2 receptor that increases intracellular cyclic AMP, thereby inducing translocation of aquaporin 2 (AQP 2) water channels into the apical membrane.
During and after surgery, surgical stress results in the release of ADH.
Solution to Question 5:
A mutation in the gene for aquaporin 2 channel leads to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
The antidiuretic hormone (ADH) binds to V2 receptors in the late distal tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts, and stimulates the movement of an intracellular protein, called aquaporin-2 (AQP-2), to the luminal side of the cell membranes.
Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a condition in which there is the absence of or poor response to anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). This results in reduced permeability of the distal tubules and
collecting ducts to water. This furthermore leads the kidneys to excrete large amounts of dilute urine that clinically manifests as polyuria and polydipsia.
DI can be of four types :
Note: Lithium - used to treat bipolar disorder, can cause acquired diabetes insipidus by decreasing the expression of the AQP2 gene.
Option A : Liddle’s syndrome is due to an inherited gain of function mutation of genes regulating the Na channel in collecting duct ENaC, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.
Option C : Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutation in CFTR gene that serves as a channel in the luminal plasma membranes of epithelial cells and regulates volume and composition of secretions in exocrine glands.
Option D : Bartter syndrome is due to loss-of-function mutations of transporters and ion channels in thick ascending loop of henle, most commonly, Na-K-2Cl transporter.

Low levels of vasopressin lead to the excretion of a large amount of diluted urine. This loss of water from the body leads to hypernatremia.

Central DI is caused by a primary deficiency in AVP secretion which usually results from agenesis or irreversible destruction of the posterior pituitary. It can be differentiated from primary polydipsia with the help of an MRI brain.

The MRI given below shows the posterior pituitary bright spot. The arrow points at the posterior pituitary and the arrowhead at the anterior pituitary.

Nephrogenic DI develops due to resistance to the antidiuretic action of AVP. A 24-hour urine volume >3 liters is suggestive of polyuria. An ADH value >1 pg/ml is suggestive of nephrogenic DI.

Metabolic derangements like hypercalcemia and hypokalemia lead to the production of large amounts of dilute urine by causing nephrogenic DI.
Options C & D: Primary polydipsia is of three types:
Dipsogenic – Due to inappropriate thirst.
Iatrogenic – Due to an increase in fluid intake due to its presumed health benefits.
Psychogenic – Due to psychosis or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario is suggestive of lithium-induced nephrogenic DI. Among the given options thiazide diuretics is the best suited answer.
Thiazides reduce the kidney’s ability to excrete free water by increasing proximal tubular water reabsorption (secondary to volume contraction) and block the ability of DCT to form dilute urine. This effect results in an increase in urine osmolality.
Treatment of diabetes insipidus:
Central and gestational diabetes insipidus:
Desmopressin an ADH analog
Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus:
Adequate water intake along with a low sodium diet
Thiazide diuretics
Potassium-sparing diuretics (triamterene and amiloride): Amiloride is the drug of choice for ithium-induced DI
Prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor (indomethacin)
Psychogenic diabetes insipidus:
Behavioral therapy to reduce fluid consumption
Solution to Question 14:
Fixed specific gravity, in which values remain 1.010 regardless of fluid intake, occurs in chronic glomerulonephritis with severe renal damage.
In chronic kidney disease, as renal function deteriorates, polyuria can be seen due to the impairment of the kidney's ability to concentrate urine.
In diabetes insipidus, although specific gravity is low it is not fixed.
Potomania (beer potomania/beer drinker's potomania/ beer drinker's hyponatremia) is a specific hypo-osmolality syndrome related to massive consumption of beer.
Solution to Question 15:
The features of frequent urination, nocturia, with polyuria(>3L/day), low urine osmolarity(<280 mosm/L), low plasma ADH levels and MRI showing absent pituitary bright spot is suggestive of Pituitary Diabetes Insipidus.

Diabetes Insipidus(DI) :
Treatment:
For Central DI, synthetic analog of ADH Desmopressin(DDAVP) is used.
For Nephrogenic DI, a low sodium diet with thiazide diuretic and/or amiloride and prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor is used.
For primary polydipsia, there are no effective drugs used but for Iatrogenic type patient education is helpful.
Other options:
Option A: In nephrogenic DI, there is polyuria, low urine osmolarity but the ADH levels will be
>1pg/mL.
Option B: In primary polydipsia, there is polyuria, low urine osmolarity, ADH levels will be
<1pg/mL but a pituitary bright spot present.
Option D: In solute loss (mannitol or hypertonic saline infusion), urine osmolality is >300 mOsm/L.

Solution to Question 1:
SIADH does not cause hypernatremia. SIADH is the most common cause of euvolemic hyponatremia.
The excess ADH secreted leads to the gain of water in the body. This stimulates baroreceptors to release atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). ANP leads to the loss of water and salt in the urine, leading to urine sodium level of > 20 mEq/L in these patients. Thus, the level of water reaches a steady state (euvolemia) but the urinary loss of sodium continues to occur, giving rise to hyponatremia.
SIADH is characterized by low levels of uric acid, normal blood pressure, and normal urea and creatinine levels.
SIADH is diagnosed based on the following criteria (Bartter-Schwartz criteria):
Reduced serum osmolality
Urine osmolality > Serum osmolality
Clinical euvolemia
Increased levels of urinary sodium
Absence of other causes of hyponatremia like pituitary, renal, adrenal, thyroid or liver diseases.
Solution to Question 2:
The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) is associated with increased urinary excretion of sodium (urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L), and hyponatremia.
Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with SIADH due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone.
Solution to Question 3:
Primary pulmonary emphysema is not a cause of SIADH. Respiratory causes of SIADH include asthma, pneumothorax and positive-pressure respiration.
Solution to Question 4:
The given scenario is suggestive of SIADH and demeclocycline does not cause this condition. Demeclocycline causes nephrogenic diabetes insipidus and hence is used in the treatment of chronic SIADH.
The following features in the given case point towards the diagnosis of SIADH:
Serum osmolality less than 275 mOsm/Kg
Urine osmolality more than 100 mOsm/Kg
Urine sodium more than 20 mmol/L
Serum sodium level less than 135 mmol/L
Solution to Question 5:
Chromophobe adenoma is a type of pituitary adenoma that causes symptoms of hypogonadism due to pressure effects on the pituitary stalk. It is not a cause of syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH).
Solution to Question 6:
The given scenario is suggestive of cerebral salt wasting. Both SIADH and cerebral salt wasting cause hyponatremia, but polyuria happens in cerebral salt wasting.
Cerebral salt wasting results from hypersecretion of atrial natriuretic peptide. It is seen primarily with central nervous system disorders including brain tumors, head trauma, hydrocephalus, neurosurgery, cerebrovascular accidents, and brain death. It is associated with hyponatremia, polyuria and elevated urinary sodium excretion. Treatment is by restoring intravascular volume with sodium chloride and water.
Clinical parameters to distinguish between SIADH, cerebral salt wasting, and central diabetes insipidus are:

Solution to Question 7:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute symptomatic SIADH and this condition is best treated by the infusion of hypertonic (3%) saline. This mode of treatment also helps in the correction of sodium deficiency that is partly responsible for hyponatremia.
The other form of treatment is to help reduce the concentration of body water by giving an AVP receptor-2 antagonist, conivaptan. Conivaptan blocks the antidiuretic effect of AVP and increases urine output.
DDAVP is a synthetic analog of AVP and should not be used as it will further increase water retention.
Solution to Question 8:
The drug of choice for the treatment of chronic SIADH is tolvaptan.
Vaptans are selective V2 receptor antagonists that act by increasing urinary water excretion by blocking the antidiuretic effect of AVP.
Treatment options for chronic SIADH include:
Restriction of fluid intake to below the level of urine output - This is considered the mainstay of treatment. But it also has certain disadvantages as stated below, and hence adding on a drug like vaptan is necessary in most cases.
Tolvaptan
Demeclocycline
Fludrocortisone
Advantages of vaptans over fluid restriction:
Fluid restriction is usually a burden to the patient, unreliable, impractical, and slow to work.
Increased thirst is a frequently observed characteristic of hyponatremia in SIADH, and is particularly difficult to suppress. Hence, water restriction in SIADH frequently leads to non-compliance in the long run.
Solution to Question 9:
Rapid correction of hyponatremia may result in central pontine myelinolysis.
Central pontine myelinolysis is an osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS), wherein rapid correction of hyponatremia results in water being driven out of the cell which has adapted to a chronic state of hypotonicity, leading to damage to the myelin sheath of these cells.
It is characterized by the acute onset of quadriparesis, ataxia, and abnormal extraocular movements.

Solution to Question 1:
Ophthalmopathy is the specific sign of Graves’ disease.
Glycosaminoglycan deposition, lymphoid infiltrates and fatty infiltration are responsible for ophthalmopathy and dermopathy.
Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder due to the production of TSH-receptor stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) thereby causing hyperthyroidism.
It is characterized by the triad of:
Thyrotoxicosis
Infiltrative ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos)
Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema)
Ophthalmopathy can sometimes precede or follow thyrotoxicosis, accounting for some cases of euthyroid ophthalmopathy.
Solution to Question 2:
The given scenario along with the image is suggestive of thyroid dermopathy. It occurs in <5% of patients with Graves’ disease. Thyroid dermopathy is almost always associated with ophthalmopathy.
Thyroid dermopathy is most frequently observed over the anterolateral parts of the lower leg. Hence, it is termed pretibial myxedema. Skin changes can occur at other sites, particularly after trauma. The typical lesion is a noninflamed, indurated plaque with a deep pink or purple color and orange peel-textured papules.
Thyroid acropachy refers to a form of clubbing rarely observed in Graves’ disease. It is strongly associated with thyroid dermopathy.
Thyroid dermopathy usually does not need any active treatment, but if necessary, treatment includes topical, high-potency glucocorticoid ointment under an occlusive dressing or octreotide can be useful in some cases.
The following image shows thyroid dermopathy and acropachy:

Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the Jod-Basedow phenomenon, likely due to the administration of an iodine-containing contrast agent during CECT.
This phenomenon is characterized by hyperthyroidism due to enhanced thyroid hormone production following the administration of contrast agents and other iodine-containing substances. This occurs in:
Patients with autonomous thyroid nodules
Patients with pre-existing subclinical hypothyroidism (endemic iodine deficiency in hilly areas)
Option B: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is characterized by the transient inhibition of thyroid iodide organification by excess iodine, thereby decreasing thyroid hormone synthesis.
Option C: Basedow disease is another name for Graves' disease.
Option D: Plummer disease is another name for toxic multinodular goitre.

Solution to Question 6:
Silent thyroiditis is not associated with amiodarone therapy. Amiodarone has the following effects on the thyroid gland:
Acute, transient suppression of thyroid function i.e., Wolff-Chaikoff effect
Hypothyroidism in patients susceptible to the inhibitory effects of a high iodine load
Thyrotoxicosis may be caused by Jod-Basedow phenomenon due to the iodine load, in the setting of multinodular goitre or incipient Graves’ disease. It can also be caused by a thyroiditis-like condition.
Painless thyroiditis, or silent thyroiditis, occurs in patients with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease and has a clinical course similar to that of subacute thyroiditis.
The condition can occur in up to 5% of women 3–6 months after pregnancy and is then termed postpartum thyroiditis.
Solution to Question 7:
Type 1 AIT is associated with intrinsic abnormalities of the thyroid gland.
Amiodarone is structurally similar to thyroid hormones and contains 39% iodine by weight. Amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis (AIT) is the most common manifestation of the effects of amiodarone on the thyroid.
Administration of amiodarone should be stopped if possible.
Near-total thyroidectomy rapidly decreases thyroid hormone levels and may be the most effective long-term clinical solution.

Solution to Question 8:
Multinodular goitre (MNG) is more commonly observed in women. It is common in iodine-deficient regions.
Most patients are asymptomatic and euthyroid. Sudden pain may occur due to haemorrhage. TFTs should be performed in all patients to exclude thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism.
The risk of malignancy due to MNG is similar to that due to solitary nodules. Hoarseness, reflecting the involvement of laryngeal nerves implicate malignancy.
Most non-toxic MNGs can be managed conservatively. Levothyroxine if used, should be started at low doses and then increased gradually. Radioiodine therapy is implemented for large goitres as it
decreases goitre size and can ablate regions of autonomy.
Solution to Question 9:
The major difference between toxic and non-toxic multinodular goiter (MNG) is the presence of functional autonomy in toxic MNG.
The pathogenesis of toxic MNG appears to be similar to that of non-toxic MNG. In both types, many nodules are polyclonal whereas others are monoclonal and vary in their clonal origins.
Most patients with non-toxic MNG are asymptomatic and euthyroid. However, patients with toxic MNG have subclinical or mild hyperthyroidism.

Among the options, the female patient with age between 20 and 65 years and no voice abnormalities and nodule size < 4 cm has the least risk for development of thyroid carcinoma.
Risk factors for the development of thyroid carcinoma in patients with thyroid nodules include:

Solution to Question 12:
Thyroid hormone resistance is an autosomal dominant disorder.
It is characterized by elevated thyroid hormone levels and inappropriately elevated or normal TSH levels.
Classic forms of the disease are attributed to the mutation in TR- gene. Patients with this condition are often asymptomatic, as hormone resistance is partial and compensated by the increase in thyroid hormone levels.
In most patients, no treatment is indicated.
Solution to Question 13:
Serum thyroglobulin levels are normal in patients with thyrotoxicosis factitia, as it is caused by the self-administration of thyroid hormone. Its level is elevated in all other types of thyrotoxicosis.
Thyroglobulin (Tg) levels are particularly increased in thyroiditis, implicating destruction of thyroid tissue and release of thyroglobulin.
The primary course of action for determining the thyroglobulin levels, however, is in the clinical follow-up of thyroid cancer patients.
Following total thyroidectomy and radiofrequency ablation, thyroglobulin levels become undetectable. In the absence of anti-Tg antibodies, measurable levels of Tg are indicative of incomplete ablation or recurrent cancer.
Solution to Question 14:
The given scenario is suggestive of De Quervain’s thyroiditis, and it is not autoimmune in origin. It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections.
Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been clinically implicated in this condition. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are generally affected three times more often than men.
Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever. It has three distinct phases:
Thyrotoxic phase
Hypothyroid phase
Recovery phase
Treatment includes large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.
Solution to Question 15:
Graves' disease is not associated with hypothyroidism.
Solution to Question 16:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. The most common cause of this condition is thyroid gland dysgenesis, seen in about 80-85% of cases of neonatal hypothyroidism.
In the remaining cases of neonatal hypothyroidism, it is due to inborn defects in thyroid hormone synthesis and rarely due to TSH receptor antibodies. These developmental abnormalities are twice as common in girls.
Clinical features include:
Prolonged jaundice
Umbilical hernia
Enlarged tongue
Hypotonia
Delayed bone maturation
Permanent neurological damage results if treatment is delayed.
T4 requirements are relatively high during the first year of life. A high circulating T4 level is needed to normalize TSH.
Early treatment with T4 results in normal IQ levels by preventing neurodevelopmental abnormalities.
Solution to Question 17:
Autoimmune hypothyroidism is usually not associated with type II diabetes mellitus.
Genetic risk factors for autoimmune hypothyroidism has been documented with HLA-DR3, HLA-DR4, HLA-DR5. A weak association also exists with CTLA4 gene polymorphism.
This may explain the relationship between autoimmune hypothyroidism and type I diabetes mellitus, Addison's disease, pernicious anemia, and vitiligo.
Less commonly encountered clinical associations include:
Celiac disease
Dermatitis herpetiformis
Chronic active hepatitis
Rheumatoid arthritis
Myasthenia gravis
Systemic lupus erythematosus
Sjogren's syndrome.
