Solution to Question 19:
Hyperthermia is least likely in this patient. Clinical manifestations of myxedema coma include decreased consciousness, seizures and hypothermia.
Myxedema coma is a serious condition with a mortality rate of 20-40%. The clinical outcomes are independent of the detected T4 and TSH levels.
Clinical features of myxedema crisis include:
Impaired cognition, ranging from confusion to somnolence to coma (myxedema coma)
Convulsions and abnormal CNS signs.
Profound hypothermia (can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension.
Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury.
Solution to Question 20:
The presenting symptoms of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain are suggestive of hypothyroidism. An increase in TSH on administration of TRH confirms the lack of stimulus for TSH secretion from the hypothalamus.
Although decreased TSH levels can be seen in hyperthyroidism, clinical features such as lethargy, increased sleep and weight gain are not. This pushes the diagnosis in favor of hypothyroidism.
If the disease was in the pituitary, there would be no increase in TSH secretion on administration of TRH (Option B).
Normally, the thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) is released by the hypothalamus. It stimulates the pituitary gland to release the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which in turn stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4 hormones.

Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical history is typical of a case of hypothyroidism and the diagnosis is myxedema coma, which is a serious complication of hypothyroidism.
Myxedema coma is a part of a larger clinical picture of myxedema crisis. Myxedema crisis refers to severe, life-threatening manifestations of hypothyroidism. It is often precipitated by the administration of sedatives, antidepressants, hypnotics, anaesthetics, or opioids.
Clinical features of myxedema crisis :
Impaired cognition, ranging from confusion to somnolence to coma (myxedema coma).
Convulsions and abnormal CNS signs.
Profound hypothermia (can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension.
Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury
A high mortality rate Other options:
Option A: Without a history of or focus of infection, septic shock is unlikely.
Option B: Cardiogenic shock would present with symptoms of left heart failure i.e. pitting pedal edema, abdominal distension, prominence of neck veins, and dyspnea.
Option D: Hypoglycemia usually presents with sweating, palpitations, and tachycardia

Solution to Question 1:
In Graves' disease, the level of serum TSH is low, free T4 is high and serum T3 is high. In patients with thyrotoxicosis, the radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours is characteristically elevated.
Grave’s disease is characterized by thyrotoxicosis caused by thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSIs) synthesized by lymphocytes in the thyroid gland, bone marrow, and lymph nodes. Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) and thyroglobulin (Tg) antibodies are also seen. This results in excess production of free T3 and free T4 levels and in turn reduces serum TSH levels.
RAIU is used to differentiate Grave’s from other thyroid disorders, here there is diffuse high uptake. Measurement of TRab and TPOs is also done to confirm the diagnosis if the diagnosis clinically is unclear.

Solution to Question 2:
The most common hormone pattern observed in sick euthyroid syndrome (SES) is a decrease in total and unbound T3 levels with normal levels of T4 and TSH. This pattern is called low T3 syndrome.
SES is caused by an acute severe illness in the absence of underlying thyroid disease. T4 to T3 conversion via peripheral deiodination is impaired leading to a fall in T3 corresponding to the severity of illness. There is an adaptive increase in the level of reverse T3 (rT3).
In very sick patients, there can be a dramatic fall in both total T4 and T3 levels. This pattern is called low T4 syndrome and is associated with a poor prognosis.
Solution to Question 3:
An elevated TSH value with low free T4 is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism (Option D). Option A: In subclinical hypothyroidism, free T4 levels remain normal despite elevated TSH. Option B: TSH is low in hyperthyroidism.
Option C: The diagnosis of secondary hypothyroidism is made along with a deficiency of other pituitary hormones. TSH levels may be low, normal, or slightly increased. The elevation in TSH levels can be attributed to the secretion of immunoreactive but biologically inactive forms of TSH. To confirm the diagnosis, it is essential to detect a low level of unbound T4.

Solution to Question 4:
The given image showing localized overactivity (increased uptake) in the left lobe of the thyroid i.e., hot nodule, with suppression of the remainder of the gland, is suggestive of a hypersecreting adenoma.
Other options:
Option B: The likelihood of malignancies like papillary Carcinoma thyroid is low (5%) in the case of a hot nodule.
Option C: Graves disease shows diffusely increased uptake on a thyroid scan.
Option D: Lateral aberrant thyroid presents with swelling of cervical lymph nodes and not thyroid. It is due to skip metastasis from papillary thyroid carcinoma to the ipsilateral cervical lymph nodes.
The thyroid scan appearance in different conditions is shown in the image below:

Diagnostic isotope studies, such as 99mTc-pertechnetate and iodine-123, are becoming less common in thyroid imaging because some warm swellings (5%) which are actually malignant could be mistaken as benign. Isotope scanning is most valuable when assessing a hyperthyroid patient presenting with a nodule or nodularity in the thyroid. It helps to identify overactivity in the gland, which can differentiate between a toxic nodule that suppresses the rest of the gland and a toxic multinodular goitre with multiple areas of increased uptake.
Solution to Question 5:
The given image shows the absence of scalp hair and skin, along with calvarial defects(skull bone defects), suggestive of aplasia cutis congenita. This is commonly associated with carbimazole and methimazole.
These drugs can also cause other defects such as:
Choanal atresia
Tracheoesophageal fistula
Fetal goiter
Solution to Question 6:
Lactating mothers cannot undergo radioiodine therapy. Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications of radioiodine therapy. Patients can safely conceive 6 months after undergoing radioiodine treatment.
Radioiodine therapy in patients with severe ophthalmopathy can be given with caution along with prednisone to prevent exacerbation of ophthalmopathy.
Solution to Question 7:
The patient in the given clinical scenario is in the 1st trimester of pregnancy. Propylthiouracil is used in the 1st trimester of gestation because it has lower teratogenic effects than carbimazole.
Carbimazole and methimazole are associated with teratogenic effects such as
Aplasia cutis congenita
Choanal atresia
Treacheosopageal fistula
Fetal goiter
However, propylthiouracil use is limited to the first trimester due to the risk of hepatotoxicity. It is replaced with carbimazole or methimazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters of the pregnancy.
The lowest effective antithyroid drug dose should be used throughout gestation. This is to maintain the maternal serum-free T4 level in the upper limit of the non-pregnant normal reference range.
Solution to Question 8:
The given scenario is suggestive of thyroid storm and propylthiouracil is the drug of choice in this patient. This is due to its inhibitory action on peripheral T4  T3 conversion.
PTU is administered in large doses (500–1000 mg loading dose and 250 mg every 4h) administered orally / via nasogastric tube / per rectum.
Propranolol is also given to reduce symptoms like tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations.
Solution to Question 9:
The given scenario is suggestive of a non-toxic diffuse goitre. Surgery is rarely indicated in this condition, except for cosmetic reasons, tracheal compression or obstruction of the thoracic inlet.
It is sometimes called simple goitre - because of the absence of nodules, and colloid goitre
- because of the presence of uniform follicles that are filled with colloid. It is most commonly caused by iodine deficiency and is often termed endemic goitre.
Most diffuse goitres are benign and asymptomatic. Examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, non-tender, generally soft gland without palpable nodules. TFTs should be performed in all patients to exclude thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism.
If markedly enlarged, it can cause tracheal/oesophagal compression.
Substernal goitre may obstruct the thoracic inlet leading to a positive Pemberton’s sign i.e., facial congestion on bilateral arm elevation due to venous occlusion.
Solution to Question 10:
Glucocorticoid treatment is not indicated in silent thyroiditis.
The condition is called silent thyroiditis, as it is painless. When it occurs 3-6 months after pregnancy, it is termed postpartum thyroiditis. The condition is observed in up to 5% of women and it is 3 times more common in women with Type 1 diabetes mellitus.
Typically, patients experience a brief phase of thyrotoxicosis lasting 2-4 weeks, followed by hypothyroidism for 4-12 weeks, and then clinical resolution. Often, only one phase is apparent.
In addition to painless goitre, silent thyroiditis can be distinguished from subacute thyroiditis by a normal ESR value and the presence of TPO antibodies.
Severe thyrotoxic symptoms can be managed with a brief course of propranolol, a 20–40 mg dose administered three or four times daily.
Thyroxine replacement may be needed for treating the hypothyroid phase but should be withdrawn after 6–9 months, to enable patient recovery.
Solution to Question 11:
The clinical effects of levothyroxine replacement are slow to appear. Patients may not experience full relief from symptoms until 3–6 months after normal TSH levels are restored.
If there is no residual function, the daily replacement dose of levothyroxine is usually 1.6 g/kg body weight (typically 100–150 g), ideally taken at least 30 minutes before breakfast.
TSH responses are gradual and should be determined 2 months following the initiation of treatment or change in dose. Once the full replacement is achieved and TSH levels are stable, TSH measurement is recommended at annual intervals.
In patients who have developed hypothyroidism following treatment of Graves' disease, lower doses are needed for replacement. This is because there is often underlying autonomous function, necessitating lower replacement doses (typically 75–125 g/d).
Solution to Question 12:
The target TSH level to be maintained in the first trimester of pregnancy is <2.5 mIU/L. For second and third trimester the target is <3.0 mIU/L.
Thyroid function must be evaluated by testing for TSH levels every 4 weeks in the first trimester and less frequently after 20 weeks. The levothyroxine dose may be increased by 50% during pregnancy. Following delivery, doses of thyroxine are usually restored to that of pre-pregnancy levels.
Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario is suggestive of myxedema coma. Hypotonic IV fluids are avoided in the course of treatment of this condition. However, hypertonic saline is used.
Hypotonic fluids may exacerbate water retention and dilutional hyponatremia secondary to impaired renal perfusion and inappropriate vasopressin.
Treatment of myxedema coma includes:
Levothyroxine (T4) can be administered as a single IV bolus of 500 g. Although further doses are strictly not required, it is continued at 50-100 g/day.
An alternative mode of treatment is the IV administration of liothyronine (T3) or via NG tubes ith doses ranging from 10-25 g every 8-12 hours in case T4 to T3 conversion in myxedema is
impaired.
Parenteral hydrocortisone should be administered to treat a condition of impaired adrenal reserve in profound hypothyroidism.
Hypertonic saline or IV glucose may be recommended for treatment.
External warming is indicated only if the temperature is less than 30oC.

Solution to Question 1:
MEN1 is also referred to as Wermer's syndrome.
Solution to Question 2:
Anterior pituitary tumours are associated with MEN1 syndrome, not posterior pituitary tumors.
Solution to Question 3:
The given scenario is suggestive of MEN1 syndrome and gastrinoma is the most common functional enteropancreatic tumor in MEN1 / Wermer's syndrome.
Enteropancreatic tumors in MEN1 syndrome are:
Non-functioning pancreatic tumors (most common overall)
Functioning pancreatic tumors :
Gastrinoma - 50% (most common among functioning pancreatic tumours)
Insulinoma - 30%
Glucagonoma
VIPoma (least common)
Solution to Question 4:
Most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the first and second part of duodenum.
MEN 1 syndrome is characterized by the triad of tumors involving the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary.
Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor in MEN 1 syndrome and if it is associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcers, the condition is called Zollinger Ellison syndrome.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario along with elevated serum C peptide levels points towards a diagnosis of insulinoma in a MEN1 patient. The definitive treatment of choice in this patient is surgery.
Insulinoma is the second most common functioning enteropancreatic tumor in MEN1 syndrome. Investigation of choice is 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels. These parameters are measured when the patient develops hypoglycemic symptoms during a supervised 72-hour fasting period.
The treatment of choice is surgery, ranging from enucleation of a single tumor to pancreatectomy.
Non-surgical management of insulinoma includes frequent consumption of carbohydrate-rich meals, octreotide or diazoxide, which are not always successful.
Selpercatinib, a kinase inhibitor was recently approved by the FDA. It is used to treat tumours with a mutation in the RET gene. These are non-small cell lung cancer, medullary thyroid cancer, and other types of thyroid cancers in patients with a mutation in the RET gene.
Solution to Question 6:
The most frequently observed cutaneous manifestation of MEN1 syndrome is angiofibroma. Cutaneous tumors in MEN1 Syndrome are:
Angiofibroma – 85%
Collagenoma – 70%
Lipoma - 33%

Other imaging tests like MRI and CT might have to be done for screening of conditions like anterior pituitary tumors or adrenal tumors.

question_text:
d
Solution to Question 1:
The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes the following symptoms:
Headache
Profuse sweating
Palpitation (due to tachycardia)
Hypertension is the most predominant sign of pheochromocytoma. Though intermittent hypertension is a classical feature, sustained hypertension is also common.
Solution to Question 2:
Hypercalcemia is seen in patients with pheochromocytoma, not hypocalcemia. This is due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by the tumor.
Solution to Question 3:
Polyuria, not oliguria is seen in patients with pheochromocytoma.
Excess catecholamine levels in this condition can cause polyuria and polydipsia due to hyperglycemia.
Solution to Question 4:
Café au lait spots are seen in neurofibromatosis 1, which is a pheochromocytoma-associated syndrome.
Pheochromocytoma-associated syndromes include the following:
Neurofibromatosis type 1
Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2
Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome
Paraganglioma syndrome
Solution to Question 5:
Malignant pheochromocytoma refers to tumors that have undergone metastasis to lymph nodes or distant sites.
They are histologically and biochemically the same as benign ones. Hence, typical histological criteria like cellular atypia, mitotic spindles, and capsular invasion are insufficient to
confirm malignancy in pheochromocytomas.
Solution to Question 6:
Norepinephrine is exclusively secreted in patients with extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma.
The PNMT (phenylethanolamine-N-methyl transferase) enzyme converts norepinephrine to epinephrine. This enzyme is absent in extra-adrenal sites. Hence, extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas secrete only norepinephrine and cannot secrete epinephrine.
On the other hand, adrenal pheochromocytomas can secrete norepinephrine, epinephrine, and dopamine in varying amounts depending on the PNMT levels in the tumor.
Extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas or catecholamine-secreting paragangliomas are most commonly found in the abdomen. They commonly arise from the organ of Zuckerkandl.
Solution to Question 7:
This clinical scenario with a history of thyroid cancer (likely medullary carcinoma) and the image showing mucosal neuromas points towards MEN2B syndrome. Her current presentation is suggestive of a pheochromocytoma. She is likely to have predominantly elevated levels
of epinephrine and its metabolite, metanephrine.
This is due to the higher expression of the PNMT enzyme associated with the mutations in MEN2 syndromes (both 2A and 2B). The higher levels of epinephrine result in a more symptomatic presentation.
In contrast, low PNMT expression is seen in von-Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome. This leads to a predominant elevation of norepinephrine and normetanephrine levels. It is less symptomatic compared to MEN2 syndrome.
Solution to Question 8:
Biopsy and FNAC should be avoided in patients with pheochromocytoma, as it is a highly vascular tumor.
CT and MRI have similar sensitivity but T2-weighted MRI with gadolinium contrast is the optimal test for diagnosis. MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) scintigraphy can be used to localize the tumor if both CT and MRI are negative.
Genetic testing may be performed as nearly 40% of the tumors are associated with familial syndromes like VHL, neurofibromatosis, and MEN2.
Note: In cases of malignant pheochromocytoma, biopsy may be indicated to confirm adrenal gland metastasis in other sites.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. The measurement of 24-hour urinary fractionated metanephrines has both the highest specificity and sensitivity in the diagnosis of this condition.
Imaging modalities like CT and MRI have a sensitivity of around 98-100% and specificity of 70%.

Solution to Question 10:
Among the given options, the fluorodopa-PET scan is the best method for detecting and localization of tumors associated with pheochromocytoma.
If biochemical testing for pheochromocytoma is positive, an abdominal MRI must be performed first. If MRI is negative or if multiple tumors are suspected, the tumor can be localized by performing one of the following investigations:
68 Ga-DOTATATE PET scan - most sensitive, gold standard
Fluorodopa and 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) PET scans - 97% sensitive
MIBG scintigraphy - least sensitive (94%)
Solution to Question 11:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. The drug of choice to control blood pressure prior to surgery is oral phenoxybenzamine at 0.5–4 mg/kg of body weight. It is a non-specific -blocker and is preferred due to its long action (3-4 days).
Other -blockers like oral prazosin and intravenous phentolamine have a shorter duration of action and can be used to manage paroxysms. IV phentolamine is also used for intra-operative management of BP.
-blockers are usually given for 7 days. Following this, -blockers are started, usually 2-3 days preoperatively. -blockers should never be started first because blockade of vasodilatory peripheral -receptors with unopposed -receptor stimulation can lead to a further elevation in blood pressure. (Mnemonic: A before B)
Solution to Question 12:
Beta-blockers like atenolol should never be used as the initial drug or alone in the management of pheochromocytoma.
They must be given only after adequate alpha blockade has been established. Blocking
beta-receptors may cause unopposed stimulation of alpha-receptors, precipitating a hypertensive crisis.
Option A: Prazosin is an alpha-blocker.
Option C: Nitroprusside can be used in case of hypertensive emergencies.
Option D: Metyrosine inhibits catecholamine synthesis. It can be used when other agents have been ineffective.
Solution to Question 13:
Vinblastine is not included in Averbuch’s chemotherapy protocol for the treatment of malignant pheochromocytoma.

Solution to Question 5:
Cushing’s disease, and all other causes of Cushing's syndrome, can result in a hypercoagulable state. This is due to an increase in procoagulant factors and inhibition of fibrinolysis.
Cushing's disease is a form of Cushing's syndrome caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary tumor. The high ACTH levels stimulate melanocytes and cause skin hyperpigmentation. This is especially seen over friction-prone areas like knuckles and elbows.
The majority of patients with Cushing's syndrome have psychiatric symptoms such as:
Anxiety,
Depression, and
Frank psychosis
Mineralocorticoid action of cortisol may lead to diastolic hypertension, hypokalemia, and edema.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing moon facies with acne and hirsutism are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome. It can be diagnosed with the help of a single midnight
serum cortisol measurement.
Option A: Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test is used for the diagnosis of Addison's disease.
Options C and D: Serum testosterone, abdominal USG, and LH: FSH ratio, are used to confirm a diagnosis of the polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Though PCOS can present with similar features, it is not typically associated with moon facies, purple striae, or hypertension.
Solution to Question 7:
Determination of plasma ACTH levels is not advised as a screening test for a patient with Cushing's syndrome.
Plasma ACTH determination is done to distinguish between ACTH-dependent and independent causes. It is done after the screening or confirmation of Cushing's syndrome.
Solution to Question 8:
Basal plasma ACTH levels are highest in ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors.
Plasma ACTH > 15pg/ml is suggestive of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome due to pituitary or ectopic sources. Basal ACTH in pituitary adenoma can be normal or elevated, whereas in an ectopic source the ACTH production is very high. This occurs because a pituitary adenoma retains some sensitivity to the negative feedback mechanism exerted by cortisol, but ectopic tumors remain unaffected.
Plasma ACTH < 5pg/ml is suggestive of ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome that can be caused by an adrenal adenoma or exogenous administration of glucocorticoids.
Solution to Question 9:
An elevated ACTH level is suggestive of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. The investigation of choice for ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome is MRI brain, to look for the presence of
a pituitary tumour.
If the MRI brain shows a mass it is suggestive of a pituitary mass of >6 mm in size. However, if the MRI brain does not show a mass it suggests a pituitary tumor of <6mm in size or an ectopic ACTH source.

N te: High-dose dexamethasone suppression test and CRH stimulation test are employed t differentiate pituitary from ectopic ACTH syndrome. A definitive cause can be established only by imaging techniques like MRI for pituitary tumors, CT scan of the chest and abdomen for ectopic ACTH sites. Hence MRI is considered the investigation of choice.
Solution to Question 10:
Elevated ACTH levels that do not get suppressed by a high-dose dexamethasone test are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome secondary to an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor. Considering the patient's smoking history and presentation with hemoptysis, it is likely to be a lung tumor.
Ectopic sources of ACTH include small cell lung cancers and pulmonary carcinoid tumors. The most effective treatment strategy is the management of the underlying SCLC or carcinoid.

Solution to Question 12:
Cushing’s syndrome with petrosal: peripheral ACTH ratio > 2 at baseline confirms the presence of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. The treatment of choice is transsphenoidal pituitary surgery. Radiotherapy is used in case of recurrence of tumors.
Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is performed to differentiate pituitary and ectopic sources of ACTH when initial imaging and testing are inconclusive.

Solution to Question 13:
Mitomycin is not used in the treatment of Cushing’s syndrome. The drugs used in its management include:
Metyrapone
Ketoconazole

Solution to Question 14:
Mitotane is used in the management of adrenocortical carcinoma due to its adrenolytic properties.
Mitotane is an insecticide derivative. It is effective in the treatment of benign Cushing's also, but is rarely used due to its side effects.
Solution to Question 15:
Nelson’s syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible.
The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumor or the formation of a new one.
Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of:
Hyperpigmentation
Excessive ACTH secretion
Corticotroph adenoma
Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain is performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol.
The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days.
Option A: Sheehan’s syndrome refers to postpartum hypopituitarism that is caused by ischemic necrosis of the anterior pituitary as a result of severe postpartum hemorrhage.
Option B: Addison's disease occurs due to autoimmune destruction of adrenal glands.
Option C: Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome refers to adrenal apoplexy that is caused by fulminant meningococcemia.
Solution to Question 16:
Malignancy does not cause pseudo-Cushing's syndrome. It may cause ectopic ACTH production, leading to true Cushing’s syndrome.
Pseudo-Cushing’s syndrome refers to functional hypercortisolism caused by chronic activation of the HPA axis. It presents with clinical and biochemical features similar to Cushing’s syndrome, making it difficult to differentiate between them. It may occur secondary to the following conditions:
Severe major depressive disorder
Polycystic ovarian syndrome
Insulin-resistant obesity
Obstructive sleep apnea
Chronic alcoholism
End-stage renal disease
It usually resolves when the underlying condition is treated.

Solution to Question 1:
Primary adrenal insufficiency, also known as Addison’s disease, is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis.
Tuberculous adrenalitis is still a frequent cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in developing countries like India. It is characterized by the loss of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and adrenal androgen secretion.
Glucocorticoid deficiency results in fatigue, lack of energy, weight loss, fever, myalgia, normochromic anemia, and hypoglycemia. Mineralocorticoid deficiency is characterized by nausea, vomiting, low blood pressure, postural hypotension, salt craving, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Adrenal androgen deficiency manifests as a lack of energy, dry itchy skin, loss of libido, and loss of axillary and pubic hair (in women).
Hyperpigmentation is seen in primary adrenal insufficiency due to excess proopiomelanocortin-derived peptides. Hyperpigmentation is not seen in secondary adrenal insufficiency.
The diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency can be made with the short cosyntropin test (cortisol level <450-500nmol/L sampled 30 to 60 minutes after ACTH stimulation is diagnostic of adrenal insufficiency). Plasma ACTH, plasma renin, and serum aldosterone can help differentiate primary from secondary causes. Primary adrenal insufficiency will show elevated ACTH and a compensatory elevation in renin levels due to decreased aldosterone in the body. In secondary adrenal insufficiency, ACTH is low with normal renin and aldosterone.
Treatment includes glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and adrenal androgen replacement. Other options:
Option B: Patients with adrenocortical carcinoma present with features of glucocorticoid and adrenal androgen excess, and not adrenal insufficiency.
Options C and D: Hypernephroma and medullary carcinoma thyroid are not associated with Addison's disease.
Solution to Question 2:
Tuberculosis is the most common cause of adrenal insufficiency in India and other developing countries.
Idiopathic atrophy due to autoimmune conditions is the most common cause in developed countries.
Solution to Question 3:
Elevated ACTH and reduced cortisol levels are seen in primary adrenal insufficiency. It is not a feature of MEN 4 syndrome.
The following syndromes are associated with primary adrenal insufficiency:
Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type 1
Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type 2
Triple-A syndrome
Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome
Kearns-Sayre syndrome
IMAGe syndrome
Solution to Question 4:
The given image showing skin hyperpigmentation in a patient with severe dizziness and a history of autoimmune thyroiditis points to a diagnosis of Addison’s disease. Hyperglycemia is not a feature of this condition. Hypocortisolism leads to hypoglycemia in these patients.
Addison’s disease is primary adrenal insufficiency characterized by the disruption of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen secretion. Primary adrenal insufficiency is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis and coincident autoimmune disease occurring in these patients most frequently includes thyroid autoimmune disease, vitiligo, and premature ovarian failure.

Levothyroxine can precipitate adrenal insufficiency or crisis in undiagnosed patients. In patients with concurrent adrenal insufficiency and hypothyroidism, a course of steroids must be given before giving thyroid replacement.
Solution to Question 5:
Hyponatremia is the most common biochemical abnormality seen at presentation in patients with adrenal insufficiency. It is observed in 80% of the patients at presentation.
Hyponatremia is caused by:
Mineralocorticoid deficiency
Diminished inhibition of ADH release by cortisol, resulting in mild SIADH during secondary adrenal insufficiency
Hyperkalemia is diagnosed in 40% of the patients during initial diagnosis.
Solution to Question 6:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of adrenal insufficiency. The confirmatory test for diagnosis is the ACTH stimulation test or short cosyntropin stimulation test.
Hyponatremia and hyperkalemia are seen. Plasma levels of ACTH, renin and aldosterone are used to differentiate between primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Solution to Question 7:
Pituitary MRI is indicated in secondary adrenal insufficiency which presents with the following parameters:
Low-normal ACTH level
Normal renin level
Normal aldosterone level
The following findings are seen in primary adrenal insufficiency:
High ACTH levels
High renin
Low aldosterone levels
Pituitary MRIs are not required in primary adrenal insufficiency. The fact that a pituitary MRI is done itself gives a hint towards secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Solution to Question 8:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of an adrenal crisis triggered by missed medication. In this patient who is a known case of adrenal insufficiency, IV hydrocortisone is the drug of choice.
However, in patients with newly diagnosed adrenal insufficiency, dexamethasone is used for the treatment of adrenal crisis. This is because dexamethasone is not measured in cortisol assays and would not interfere with the diagnostic tests, whereas hydrocortisone interferes with cortisol assays.
Acute adrenal insufficiency requires the immediate initiation of the following therapeutic strategies:
Rehydration - saline infusion at an initial rate of 1 L/h with continuous cardiac monitoring.
Glucocorticoid replacement - bolus injection of 100 mg hydrocortisone, followed by the maintenance dose of 100–200 mg over 24h.
Mineralocorticoid replacement - initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose has been reduced to <50 mg as higher doses of hydrocortisone have sufficient mineralocorticoid action.
Solution to Question 9:
Hyperkalemia will not improve following administration of dexamethasone. Dexamethasone is a long-acting steroid with glucocorticoid action. It has no effect on hyperkalemia, which is mediated by mineralocorticoids.
Hyponatremia is chiefly due to mineralocorticoid deficiency, however, hypocortisolism causes hyponatremia due to loss of feedback inhibition of ADH resulting in SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion).
Hypocortisolism can also cause postural hypotension as cortisol regulates vascular tone by potentiating the effects of vasoconstrictors. Thus on administration dexamethasone hyponatremia and postural hypotension will improve as dexamethasone has glucocorticoid action but hyperkalemia will not improve.
Dexamethasone is used in patients with newly diagnosed adrenal insufficiency as it does not interfere with serum cortisol measurement.

Solution to Question 10:
A non-functioning pituitary adenoma causes hypopituitarism due to compression of the pituitary stalk. This results in secondary adrenal insufficiency. Hyperpigmentation is not a feature.
This condition is characterized by an alabaster-like paleness due to the lack of ACTH secretion. In primary adrenal insufficiency, hyperpigmentation occurs as a result of elevated ACTH.
Solution to Question 11:
Addison's disease causes patchy hyperpigmentation of the oral mucosa. Hyperpigmentation is also present in areas of increased friction including:
Palmar creases
Dorsal aspect of the foot
Nipples and the axillary region

Solution to Question 12:
Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia is the most common cause of mineralocorticoid excess. It causes primary hyperaldosteronism. Other causes of primary hyperaldosteronism are:
Conn’s syndrome – Unilateral adrenal adenoma
Glucocorticoid-remediable hyperaldosteronism (< 1%) Other causes of mineralocorticoid excess are as follows:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)
Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME)
Adrenocortical carcinoma
Progesterone-induced hypertension
Cushing’s syndrome
Liddle’s syndrome is due to a mutation of ENaC subunits. This results in reduced degradation of ENaC channels, causing prolonged mineralocorticoid action.
Solution to Question 13:
In Conn’s syndrome, even though there is volume expansion, an underlying salt-escape mechanism leads to the absence of pedal edema.
The volume expansion due to hypernatremia leads to right heart dilatation that stimulates the release of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). This leads to compensatory diuresis and lack of edema despite sodium retention.
Features of primary hyperaldosteronism:
Hypokalemia
Hypertension
Metabolic alkalosis
Polyuria (due to ANP)
Polydipsia (consequence of polyuria)
Muscle weakness
Solution to Question 14:
Conn syndrome is a cause of primary hyperaldosteronism that presents with hypertension and low levels of renin.
Elevated aldosterone levels cause negative feedback in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
(RAAS) and results in decreased renin production.
Solution to Question 15:
Hypokalemic hypertension is suggestive of hyperaldosteronism. The screening test of choice is a measurement of plasma renin and aldosterone levels to calculate the aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR).
ARR must be estimated in patients with hypertension and any one of the following features:
Drug resistance
Hypokalemia
Adrenal mass
Onset before 40 years of age
Prior to the determination of ARR, hypokalemia correction must be done. If the patient is
on spironolactone, it must be stopped 4 weeks prior to testing. Other blood pressure medication may be continued.
ARR screen is considered positive when:
ARR > 750 pmol/L : ng/mL per hour
Aldosterone > 450 pmol/L
Option A: ACTH stimulation test is used for the diagnosis of Addison’s disease. It presents with hypotension and hyperkalemia.
Options B and C: If ARR is positive, CT abdomen and adrenal vein sampling are used for confirmation of the diagnosis.
Solution to Question 16:
An elevated aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR) is indicative of
primary hyperaldosteronism. Metyrapone stimulation test is used in the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency, not hyperaldosteronism.
A failure of suppression of aldosterone levels below 140 pmol/L indicates autonomous aldosterone production, which is the hallmark of primary hyperaldosteronism. This principle is used in the following tests:
Saline infusion test - IV administration of 2L of physiological saline over 4 hours
Oral sodium loading test - oral sodium given over 3 days
Fludrocortisone suppression test - given IV over 4 days
These tests may be used to confirm the diagnosis in patients with elevated ARR, but are not necessary in cases of overt hypokalemic hypertension, strongly positive ARR, and high aldosterone.

Solution to Question 1:
Weight loss is a clinical feature of diabetes mellitus, not weight gain.
Diabetes mellitus refers to a group of common metabolic disorders that result in hyperglycemia. It causes the following classical triad of symptoms:
Polyuria - due to osmotic diuresis
Polydipsia - triggered by the resulting hypovolemia
Weight loss - due to catabolic state
Note: Obesity is a risk factor, not a symptom of type 2 diabetes mellitus and plays a role in its pathogenesis. Increase in the adipocyte mass leads to an increase in the level of circulating free fatty acids. Free fatty acids impair glucose utilization in skeletal muscles, promote glucose
production by the liver, and impair beta-cell function.
Solution to Question 2:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 diabetes mellitus. It is an autoimmune disease associated with the following immunologic markers:
Antibodies against zinc transporter (ZnT-8)
Islet cells antibodies (ICA)
Anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies (GAD)
Insulin autoantibodies (IAA)
Solution to Question 3:
The major susceptibility gene for type 1 diabetes mellitus is located in the HLA region of chromosome 6.
Type I diabetes mellitus occurs in genetically susceptible individuals and is usually triggered by infections. The HLA complex is most commonly involved. The common HLA associations include:
Causative - HLA-DQA1*0501 and DQB*0201
Protective - HLA-DQA1*0102, DQB1*0602, DRB1*1501
Other genomic associations of type I diabetes mellitus include the CTLA-4 gene and IL-2 receptor.
Type 2 diabetes mellitus is associated with mutations in the calpain-10 gene on chromosome 2. It results in insulin resistance.
Solution to Question 4:
In type 2 diabetes mellitus increased fasting blood sugar is predominantly due to increased hepatic gluconeogenesis.
In the postprandial period, there is a rise in peripheral blood glucose levels. Due to insulin resistance in type 2 diabetes mellitus, there is reduced peripheral uptake of glucose by insulin-sensitive tissues like the liver and skeletal muscles. This results in reduced glucose
utilization by skeletal muscles as well as reduced glycogenesis in the liver and skeletal muscles. This results in increased postprandial plasma glucose levels.
Increased hepatic glucose output predominantly accounts for increased FPG levels, whereas decreased peripheral glucose utilization results in postprandial hyperglycemia.
Solution to Question 5:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY).
MODY is a monogenic form of diabetes mellitus that is transmitted in an autosomal dominant fashion. It affects young adults < 25 years of age. It occurs due to reduced insulin secretion. Etiological factors of type 1 and 2 diabetes such as insulin resistance, obesity, and antibodies are not associated with this condition.
Stable hyperglycemia is usually seen, hence complications like diabetic ketoacidosis are uncommon. Macrovascular complications like hyperlipidemia or hypertension are not seen. It is treated with sulfonylureas.
Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA) is a form of type 1 diabetes that occurs between 30-50 years of age.
Solution to Question 6:
MODY 3 is the most common form of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY), accounting for two-thirds of all the cases.
MODY is a monogenic form of diabetes mellitus that is transmitted in an autosomal dominant fashion. It affects young adults <25 years of age. There are a total of 11 types of MODY based on mutations involves. Some of the affected genes include:
Types 1,3,5: HNF (Hepatocyte nuclear transcription factor) mutation
Type 2: Glucokinase mutation
Type 4: IPF 1 (Insulin Promotor Factor-1) mutation
These mutations result in impaired glucose-induced insulin secretion resulting in insulinopenia.
Solution to Question 7:
Type 1 diabetes mellitus in an adult is suggestive of latent autoimmune diabetes in adults
(LADA).
LADA is common in thin-built adults between 30-50 years and is associated with autoantibodies. As the progression of the disease is less rapid than in children, clinical features may mimic type 2 diabetes. However, patients usually require insulin treatment within 5 years.
Option A: Patients with latent diabetes become diabetic under stressful conditions. However, upon removal of stress, they become non-diabetic.
Option B: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is a monogenic form of diabetes that occurs < 25 years. There is impaired insulin secretion, but no antibodies.
Option C: Brittle diabetes is seen in children with type 1 DM. It presents with wide fluctuation in blood sugar levels.
Solution to Question 8:
Fragile X syndrome is not associated with diabetes mellitus. Genetic syndromes associated with diabetes include:
Prader-Willi syndrome

Down’s syndrome

Hemochromatosis
Pancreatitis
Neoplasia
Cystic fibrosis
Endocrinopathies causing diabetes:
Acromegaly
Cushing’s syndrome
Glucagonoma
Pheochromocytoma
Hyperthyroidism

Insulin is the best initial drug of choice when HbA1c is > 9% at diagnosis. Insulin is used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes in the following cases:
Inadequate glycemic control with 2 or more oral agents
HbA1c > 9% at diagnosis
In patients with HbA1c < 9%, metformin is the drug of choice.

Solution to Question 14:

Sulfonylureas
Meglitinides: Nateglinide, Repaglinide
The following drugs are not directly responsible for stimulating insulin secretion and hence do not cause hypoglycemia:
Metformin
Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor
Pioglitazone

The antihypertensive drug of choice in diabetes mellitus include angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE-I) or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs).
Solution to Question 17:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI). This adverse effect occurs as a result of dapagliflozin use.
The group of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 or SGLT-2 inhibitors includes drugs like dapagliflozin and canagliflozin. These drugs prevent glucose reabsorption in the renal tubules and cause loss of sodium and glucose.
UTI - due to glucosuria
Dehydration - due to natriuresis and volume loss
Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis - low blood glucose levels due to glucosuria can reduce insulin release
SGLT-2 inhibitors must be temporarily discontinued for 3-4 days before any scheduled surgery to avoid potential risk for diabetic ketoacidosis.

Solution to Question 18:
This clinical scenario describes the sliding scale method. Rapid-acting insulins such as glulisine are used.
Sliding scale refers to the administration of insulin as a bolus dose based on the blood sugar level before the meal. Using this principle, the insulin dose is titrated every time according to
pre-meal glucose levels to determine insulin requirement. Hence, rapid-acting insulin is preferred.
This method requires a fixed carbohydrate intake at every meal. It is used for the short-term management of hospitalized patients, especially when the frequency or quantity of food intake is very variable.
It does not deliver insulin in a physiological manner, hence is not a preferred long-term strategy for glycemic control.
Solution to Question 19:
Afrezza is an inhalational form of insulin that can cause hypoglycemia.
It is a rapid-acting form of insulin that is administered at the beginning of each meal. Peak levels are achieved 12-15 minutes later.
Adverse effects include hypoglycemia, cough, throat pain, or irritation. It may cause acute bronchospasm in patients with asthma, COPD, as well as active smokers. Hence, it is contraindicated in these condition.
Solution to Question 20:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis, which is treated with insulin infusion. Insulin causes an intracellular shift of K+ ions resulting in a decreased extracellular K+ ion concentration. This results in hypokalemia.
Non-diabetic clinical applications of insulin include:
Treatment of hyperkalemia
To determine the functions of the anterior pituitary
To examine the completion of truncal vagotomy
Solution to Question 21:
Dawn phenomenon refers to normal blood glucose levels at 3 am followed by early morning hyperglycemia.
This occurs due to an early morning surge in plasma growth hormone and cortisol levels, which have an insulin-antagonistic action. In normal individuals, this is countered by increased early morning insulin secretion. However, in diabetic patients, insulin secretion is disrupted which results in the unopposed action of growth hormone. Hence, there will be resulting hyperglycemia.
Solution to Question 22:
When a patient needs > 200 units of insulin per day, they are said to have developed insulin resistance.
Some causes of insulin resistance are as follows:
Werner syndrome
Lipodystrophy syndrome
Ataxia-telangiectasia
Polycystic ovarian disease
Insulin resistance can present as non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
Solution to Question 23:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and the first step is to assess the arterial blood gas (ABG) levels. This precedes correction of fluid balance, as assessment of the current status of the patient is necessary before beginning treatment. A baseline pH and electrolyte level must be obtained.
Diabetic ketoacidosis is the most serious complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include dehydration, nausea, vomiting, confusion, drowsiness, and coma in severe cases.
In DKA, the insulin-to-glucagon ratio is decreased which promotes gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and ketone body formation in the liver. Ketone bodies exist as ketoacids at physiological pH which are neutralized by bicarbonate. As bicarbonate stores are depleted, metabolic acidosis ensues. Increased lactic acid production also contributes to the acidosis.
The diagnostic biochemical criteria for DKA includes:
Hyperglycemia (>250 mg/dL)
Venous pH <7.3
Plasma/serum bicarbonate <15-18 mmol/L
Increased anion gap
Ketonemia (beta-hydroxybutyrate [BOHB] >3 mmol/L) and ketonuria Signs of ketoacidosis:
Kussmaul breathing (deep, heavy, non-labored rapid breathing)
Fruity breath odor (acetone)
Prolonged Q-T interva
Diminished neurocognitive function
Coma

Solution to Question 24:
The elevated levels of triglycerides (TG) and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) in diabetes mellitus (DM) are due to decreased activity of lipoprotein lipase (LpL) and increased activity of hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL).
Insulin normally has an inhibitory action on HSL and induces LpL on capillary walls. There is an absolute or relative deficiency of insulin in DM. In DM, the activity of LpL is decreased and HSL is increased.
The increased activity of HSL results in increased mobilisation of fat stores towards lipolysis releasing fatty acids. These fatty acids are partly cleared by the liver, resulting in increased synthesis of VLDL and TG, resulting in dyslipidemia. They can accumulate in the liver, resulting in steatosis (non-alcoholic fatty liver disease).
The reduced activity of LpL prevents the clearing of TG and VLDL in the bloodstream and their levels remain elevated.

Solution to Question 25:
Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL and 2-hour postprandial blood sugar >200 mg/dl can be used as screening tests for diabetes in a primary health center (PHC).
HbA1c estimation is usually unavailable for screening at many PHCs due to low resources. In India, facilities for HbA1c estimation are usually available only at tertiary centers.
Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL can be used for diagnosis only if the patient presents with symptoms of diabetes, hence it is not a useful screening test.

Solution to Question 1:
In diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), serum bicarbonate is usually < 15. Serum HCO3 > 15 meq/L is suggestive of alcoholic ketoacidosis.
DKA is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. It is usually precipitated by absolute or relative insulin deficiency caused by increased metabolic demand (infections) or insulin noncompliance.
The common symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain. The common signs include Kussmaul breathing, fruity odor of the breath, dehydration, tachycardia, hypotension, and delirium.
The diagnosis of DKA is made based on the following parameters:
Hyperglycemia > 250 mg/d
Ketosis or ketones in urine
Metabolic acidosis with pH < 7.3
HCO3 < 15-18 mEq/L
High anion gap due to ketoacids and lactic acidosis
Hyponatremia is seen as a result of hyperglycemia (osmotic shift causes dilutional hyponatremia). Normal sodium levels on admission indicate severe dehydration. Despite a total-body potassium deficit, the serum Potassium at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis and volume depletion.
Solution to Question 2:
The drug of choice for controlling hyperglycemia in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is short-acting insulin, preferably regular insulin.
Intermediate (such as lente insulin and NPH), long-acting insulins, and oral hypoglycemic agents are never used in the initial management of DKA.
The mainstay of treatment is the administration of normal saline followed by infusion of
short-acting insulin. The precipitating event must be identified and treated. Careful monitoring of K+ levels and replacement in the later stages is required, as insulin therapy causes hypokalemia.
Solution to Question 3:
Cerebral edema is the leading cause of mortality in children with diabetic ketoacidosis.
The osmolar gradient generated due to the high blood glucose level results in water shift from the intracellular fluid (ICF) to the extracellular fluid (ECF) space and leads to the contraction of cell volume. Correction with insulin and intravenous fluids can result in a rapid reduction in effective osmolarity, reversal of the fluid shift, and result in cerebral edema.
Complications of diabetic ketoacidosis include:
Cerebral edema – especially in children
Cardiac arrhythmia - due to electrolyte imbalance
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
Venous thrombosis
Acute gastric dilation
Acute kidney injury
Intestinal necrosis
Acute pancreatitis
Mucormycosis
Solution to Question 4:
In diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), severe abdominal pain can mimic acute pancreatitis. Serum lipase is the best test to rule out this condition. It must then be confirmed by imaging (USG or CT abdomen).
Serum amylase is an unreliable indicator as DKA is associated with hyperamylasemia of salivary origin.
Serum and urine trypsinogen may be elevated in early pancreatitis but are not used for diagnosis. Fecal elastase is elevated in chronic pancreatitis.
Solution to Question 5:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). On confirming the diagnosis, IV fluids must be started. If the initial serum potassium < 3.3 meq/L, insulin should be administered only after the correction of hypokalemia.
This is because treatment with insulin and fluids can worsen hypokalemia by the following mechanisms:
Insulin causes the shift of K+ ions into cells
Resolution of the acidosis also promotes K+ entry into cells
Urinary loss of K+ salts of organic acids

Solution to Question 6:
Hypotension and tachycardia are common features of both hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state
(HHS) and diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).
In DKA, insulin deficiency and an increase in counter-regulatory hormones lead to shunting of free fatty acids to form ketone bodies. The ketoacids increase the anion gap and cause low pH. In HHS, there is still some insulin available. Hence, there are no ketones formed, and the patient has normal pH and pCO2.
Solution to Question 7:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS). Kussmaul's breathing is not a feature of HHS.
HHS is commonly seen in older adults suffering from type 2 diabetes mellitus. Patients can present with the following features:
Polyuria
Polydipsia
Lethargy
Altered sensorium, coma
Seizures
Severe dehydration
The following lab values are seen:
Blood glucose of 600-1200 mg/d
Serum osmolality > 350 mOsm/L
Prerenal azotemia due to dehydration
Pseudohyponatremia may be seen due to hyperglycemia
Normal pH and ketones
The mainstay of management is fluid replacement, IV regular insulin, along with potassium replacement.
Heparin can be given prophylactically as volume contraction can increase the risk of venous thrombosis.
Solution to Question 8:
Dyslipidemia commonly occurs as a complication of type 2 diabetes mellitus. The most common pattern is as follows:
Increased triglyceride levels - due to increased glucose and free fatty acids, decreased lipolysis of VLDL.
Decreased HDL levels
Though diabetes does not increase LDL levels, there is increased atherogenicity as the existing LDL molecules are more easily glycated and susceptible to oxidation.
Solution to Question 9:
Dyslipidemia is more commonly associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
It is less common in type 1 and gestational diabetes. Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY)
is not associated with dyslipidemia.
Note: Saroglitazar is a more advanced drug that reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic patients. It acts on PPAR alpha and gamma receptors.
Solution to Question 10:
According to the ADA guidelines, a treatment goal of postprandial plasma glucose < 180 mg/dL must be followed in adults with diabetes.
In younger individuals or those with other cardiovascular risk factors, the target blood pressure is < 130/80 mm Hg. Although not a treatment goal, the ADA also recommends triglyceride levels be maintained at < 150 mg/dl.
Note: Saroglitazar is a more advanced drug that reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic patients. It acts on PPAR alpha and gamma receptors.
Solution to Question 11:
The drug of choice in this diabetic patient with hypertension is losartan.
Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARB) are the first-line drugs in diabetic hypertensives. Among ARBs, the drug of choice is telmisartan (acts on PPAR receptor).
They reduce both macrovascular and microvascular complications and have a nephroprotective effect. However, they are contraindicated in chronic kidney disease as they can cause a further decline in GFR.
Solution to Question 12:
The earliest manifestation of diabetic nephropathy is an increase in the glomerular filtration rate
(GFR).
It occurs as a result of glomerular hyperperfusion and renal hypertrophy. The following sequence of changes are seen in diabetic nephropathy:
Increased GFR
Incipient diabetic nephropathy - microalbuminuria (30–300 mg/day albumin)
Diagnostic marker to detect early diabetic nephropathy
Indicator of long-term cardiovascular disease
Overt diabetic nephropathy - macroalbuminuria ( >300 mg/day albumin)
End-stage renal disease

Solution to Question 13:
Albumin of 30-300 mg/day refers to microalbuminuria. It can be unreliable in the diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy.
It is not required to diagnose nephropathy as it is very variable. Non-albuminuric diabetic nephropathy may occur in some patients and regression of albuminuria may be seen in type 1 diabetics.
Diabetic nephropathy can be diagnosed if the following are satisfied:
Reduced GFR (< 60 mL/min/1.73 m2) with or without persistent albuminuria (> 30 mg/day or urine PCR > 30 mg/g)
Long duration of diabetes or established diabetic retinopathy
Other etiologies are ruled out
Long duration in type 1 diabetes refers to 5 years after diagnosis. On the other hand, patients with type 2 diabetes are exposed to hyperglycemia and prediabetes for a long time even before diagnosis. Hence, at the time of diagnosis, patients with type 2 diabetes are considered to have had the disorder for a duration sufficiently long to produce kidney disease.
However, a clinical diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy can be made in patients with established retinopathy, even if the duration of diabetes is short.
Solution to Question 14:
Pancreatic transplantation can help improve proteinuria at an early stage. Successful pancreatic transplantation can have the following effects:
Prevention of diabetic nephropathy and regression of albuminuria in early stages.
Stabilization and improvement of diabetic neuropathy and retinopathy
Increase in HDL with reduction in LDL and triglycerides
Option B: Strict glycemic control can prevent or revert microalbuminuria.
Option C: The ADA does not suggest restrictions of protein intake in diabetic patients with albuminuria because studies have failed to prove its benefits.
Option D: Microalbuminuria is an indicator of long-term cardiovascular morbidity.
Solution to Question 15:
Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACEI) inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARB) are recommended to reduce the progression of diabetic nephropathy. It has the following effects:
Reduction of albuminuria
Reduces the associated decline in GFR
The mainstay of management of diabetic nephropathy includes control of blood sugar and blood pressure, inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone(RAAS) system, and inhibitors of SGLT2 to halt the progression of the disease.
RAAS inhibitors include ACE inhibitors, ARBs, or direct renin inhibitors.
Solution to Question 16:
The characteristic lesion of diabetic nephropathy is nodular or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis, also called Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules. It is pathognomonic for this condition.
The following image shows Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules.

Other non-specific findings seen on biopsy include:
Glomerular basement membrane (GBM) thickening - highly sensitive
Diffuse glomerulosclerosis - most common pattern, due to diffuse mesangial thickening
Fibrin cap - accumulation of hyaline material within the capillary loop
Capsular drop - accumulation of hyaline material attached to the Bowman's capsule
Armani-Ebstein reaction - collection of glycogen clumps within the renal tubules due to tubular injury
Renal biopsy is done to rule out other causes of renal failure. The indications for renal biopsy in diabetic nephropathy are:
Absence of diabetic retinopathy
Absence of edema
Absence of frothing and proteinuria
Absence of hypertension
Presence of microscopic hematuria or features of nephritic syndrome
Solution to Question 17:
Type IV renal tubular acidosis (RTA) may occur in individuals with diabetes mellitus types 1 and 2.
Type IV RTA occurs due to hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism. Low plasma renin activity is common in diabetic patients due to:
Impaired conversion of prorenin to renin
Volume expansion in diabetic nephropathy suppresses renin release
These individuals have a tendency to develop hyperkalemia and acidemia, which can be exacerbated by the use of ACEI and ARBs. Hence, these drugs should be avoided.
Solution to Question 18:
Patients with type 2 diabetes should undergo a comprehensive ophthalmological examination to screen for diabetic retinopathy at diagnosis, followed by an annual examination of the fundus.
In patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, screening for retinopathy is recommended 3 to 5 years after diagnosis. Annual fundal examination is recommended thereafter.
Solution to Question 19:
Screening for diabetic retinopathy is done at 3-5 years following diagnosis in type 1 diabetes mellitus, whereas, patients with type 2 diabetes must be screened at the time of diagnosis.
As type 2 diabetes mellitus often has a long asymptomatic period of hyperglycemia before clinical diagnosis, these patients are more likely to have complications at the time of diagnosis itself.
Retinopathy develops in nearly 50-80% of patients by 20 years of diagnosis. The presence of diabetic retinopathy often correlates with pathological findings of diabetic nephropathy.
Solution to Question 20:
The most common form of diabetic neuropathy is distal symmetric polyneuropathy. It presents with distal sensory loss and pain in a stocking-and-glove distribution and is a risk factor for foot ulceration.
Autonomic neuropathy is a common complication and results in the following features:
Postural hypotension
Silent myocardial infarction
Hypoglycemia unawareness
Erectile dysfunction
Overflow incontinence
Gastroparesis
Enteropathy with constipation or diarrhea
Mononeuropathy of peripheral (median, ulnar, radial) and cranial (oculomotor) nerves is also seen, as well as mononeuritis multiplex.
Diabetic polyradiculopathy is characterized by severe pain along the distribution of one or more nerve roots.
Solution to Question 21:
Amyotrophy refers to weakness of hip extensors and flexors secondary to polyradiculopathy involving the lumbar plexus and femoral nerve. It is associated with severe pain along the distribution of the nerve roots. It is self-limiting and resolves over 6-12 months.
Strict glycemic control can reduce the incidence and prevent the progression of macular edema, peripheral neuropathy, and macroalbuminuria. However, once developed, they cannot be reversed. Intermittent microalbuminuria with normal GFR can be reversed with strict glycemic control.
Solution to Question 22:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of silent hypoglycemia in a diabetic patient. The most likely cause is autonomic neuropathy.
Hypoglycemia presents with symptoms like palpitation, tremors, and sweating as a result
of sympathetic stimulation. These symptoms are protective and provide advance warning before progression to neuroglucopenia.
However, in autonomic neuropathy, there is a reduced release of counterregulatory hormones like catecholamines. Hence, the classical symptoms of hypoglycemia do not occur and the patient directly presents with features of neuroglucopenia. This is called hypoglycemia unawareness.
The use of beta-blockers can also cause hypoglycemia unawareness.
Solution to Question 23:
In patients with longstanding diabetes mellitus, tight glycaemic control is beneficial
for microvascular complications. However, it has no effect on macrovascular complications like peripheral vascular disease (PVD), myocardial infarction, and stroke.
Good glycemic control improves microvascular complications through primary and secondary prevention. It reduces the incidence of complications as well as stabilizes and prevents further progression in affected individuals. Intermittent microalbuminuria with normal GFR can even be reversed with tight glycemic control.

Solution to Question 24:
Legacy effect or metabolic memory can be observed in relation to glycemic control during early disease in patients with diabetes mellitus.
Intensive glycemic control during the early stages of the disease has a positive effect on long-term microvascular and macrovascular complications (statement 1) even if this intensive glycemic control is not maintained long term. Similarly, uncontrolled blood glucose levels in the early stages causes an increased risk of these complications (statement 5). This phenomenon is called legacy effect and is attributed to metabolic memory.
In patients with longstanding diabetes, intensive glycemic control at later stages can improve microvascular complications but has no effect on macrovascular complications.
Solution to Question 25:
Venous stasis is not a cause of diabetic foot ulcers and gangrene. They are usually caused by a combination of three factors:
Ischemia - secondary to atheroma
Peripheral neuropathy - leads to trophic skin changes
Immunosuppression - due to excess sugar deposition in tissues, predisposing diabetic patients to infection
Common sites of ulcers include:
Great toe
Metatarsophalangeal areas.

The given image showing irregular plaques with yellowish discoloration and telangiectasias are suggestive of necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum.
It is an inflammatory granulomatous disorder of the skin due to collagen degeneration and lipid deposition. It is usually seen in young women with diabetes mellitus.
The lesions usually begin in the pretibial region. It begins as papules that gradually enlarge and darken to form erythematous plaques with irregular margins, atrophic centers, and central ulceration.
Option A: Necrolytic migratory erythema is a feature of glucagonoma. It is a waxing and waning rash that appears as shown below.

Option B: Diabetic dermopathy or shin spots are commonly seen in elderly men. It presents as pigmented pretibial papules as shown below.

Option D: Granuloma annulare presents with small papules arranged in an annular pattern. There is no yellowish discoloration or telangiectasias, as shown below.

Emphysematous appendicitis is not a complication of diabetes mellitus. The potentially fatal infectious complications of diabetes include:

Solution to Question 28:
Among the given options, canagliflozin (Option C) is the most suitable treatment. It is an oral drug belonging to the class SGLT-2 inhibitors and causes weight loss. Although it increases the risk of urogenital infections, it has no risk of pancreatitis or bladder cancer.
Option A: Sitagliptin, a DPP-IV inhibitor, is associated with the risk of acute pancreatitis.
Option B: Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione, can increase the risk of bladder cancer and can cause weight gain and congestive cardiac failure.
Option D: Liraglutide is an injectable GLP-1 receptor agonist. Pancreatitis is a serious adverse effect of this drug. Hence, it is contraindicated in individuals with a history of pancreatitis and should be permanently discontinued if pancreatitis develops.
Solution to Question 29:
Metformin should be stopped in case of elevated creatinine levels (renal insufficiency) > 1.5 mg/dl in men and >1.4 mg/dl in women.
Metformin acts by reducing hepatic glucose production and improves peripheral glucose utilization. Lactic acidosis and Vitamin B12 deficiency are specific adverse effects of metformin. It is not used in patients with a glomerular filtration rate <30 mL/min (moderate renal insufficiency), acidosis, unstable congestive cardiac failure, liver disease, severe hypoxemia, and patients undergoing contrast studies.

Solution to Question 3:
Hypoglycemia is a feature of salt-wasting congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).
It is due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. It results in hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and
hypotension. Males typically present with salt-wasting crises as they often go undiagnosed at birth due to the presence of normal genitalia.
Solution to Question 4:
The drug of choice for the prenatal treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency is dexamethasone, as it readily crosses the placenta.
It is an experimental approach aimed at reducing the virilization of 46XX fetuses by suppressing fetal adrenal steroid and androgen secretion. It may be considered when there is a high risk of CAH due to strong family history. It is effective only when started before 4 weeks of gestation.
Hydrocortisone is given in the children at divided doses of 1–1.5 times the normal cortisol production.
Solution to Question 5:
Ambiguous genitalia, elevated 17-(OH)-progesterone, and hypoglycemia are suggestive of 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The drug of choice is hydrocortisone.
Hydrocortisone acts as a potent glucocorticoid with mineralocorticoid action and thus increases salt absorption from the kidneys as well.
Betamethasone, beclomethasone, and dexamethasone have negligible effects as mineralocorticoids.
Solution to Question 6:
Galactorrhea or pathological production of milk is not associated with lactation, which is a physiological condition.
Galactorrhea is the inappropriate discharge of milk-containing fluid from the breast. It may be unilateral or bilateral. It is associated with acromegaly and hyperprolactinemia.
Treatment is with dopamine agonists like bromocriptine or cabergoline if it is due to hyperprolactinemia.

Aplasia or hypoplasia of olfactory bulb The clinical features include:

It is a medical emergency that presents with polyuria, severe dehydration, gastrointestinal symptoms, and altered consciousness. It can lead to cardiac arrest and coma.

Excess calcium ingestion is not associated with restrictive cardiomyopathy. It results in milk-alkali syndrome, commonly associated with excessive intake of absorbable antacids such as milk or calcium carbonate.
In susceptible individuals, there is a loss of negative feedback, leading to excess calcium absorption when there is excess intake. It results in the following triad of clinical features:
Hypercalcemia
Alkalosis - due to HCO3 reabsorption caused by PTH suppression, natriuresis, and water depletion.
Renal failure - due to damage to renal tubules.
It is reversible once ingestion of antacid is stopped. However, in severe cases, a chronic form called Burnett’s syndrome can develop. It is associated with irreversible renal damage.

Solution to Question 10:
Calcitonin levels are increased in hyperparathyroidism.
Due to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in hyperparathyroidism, there is osteoclast activation. This leads to increased calcium levels in plasma. As a response to this, there is an increase in the level of calcitonin to regulate the high calcium levels.
Calcitonin is secreted by the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland. Its principal effects are to lower serum calcium and phosphate by its action on bone and kidney. In bone, calcitonin inhibits osteoclasts and reduces bone resorption. In the kidney, it inhibits the reabsorption of both calcium and phosphate.
Other options
Option A: In hyperthyroidism, the direct effect of thyroid hormones can lead to bone resorption and mild hypercalcemia. However, hyperparathyroidism is a better answer.
Options B and D: Hypoparathyroidism and Cushing’s syndrome will have low serum calcium and hence, will not have increased calcitonin levels.
Solution to Question 11:
The above x-ray shows a rugger jersey spine which is a distinct feature of hyperparathyroidism. It is associated with elevated ALP.
It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.
Option A: Paget's disease causes cortical thickening, which results in increased opacity on all sides of the vertebral body. These are called picture frame vertebrae.
Option C: Osteopetrosis presents with normal ALP levels. It results in sclerotic endplates of vertebrae that are termed sandwich vertebrae. Though this finding is similar to rugger jersey
spine, it is denser and more sharply defined than rugger jersey spine. In addition, there
is sclerosis of inner margins of vertebral bodies, resulting in a bone within a bone appearance.
Option D: Ankylosing spondylitis produces a bamboo spine appearance due to fusion of vertebral bodies.

Solution to Question 13:
The arrows in this x-ray point to arrow-headed fingers or the spade phalanx sign. It is pathognomonic of acromegaly.
Acromegaly is the result of excessive growth hormone (GH) production, most commonly from a macroadenoma of the pituitary. There is osseous enlargement, presenting with spade-like hands and widening of the terminal phalangeal tufts, giving an arrow-head appearance.
Other features in the hand include:
Widened joint spaces (due to cartilage hypertrophy)
Generalized osteoporosis and cystic changes in the carpal bones
Option A: Hyperparathyroidism causes subperiosteal bone resorption, which is marked along the radial aspect of the middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers.
Option B: Down's syndrome can cause hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger. Option C: Psoriasis causes a pencil-in-cup appearance of the distal phalanx.
Solution to Question 14:
Glucocorticoids have no effect on the serum calcium concentration in primary hyperparathyroidism and normal individuals.
They are effective in the treatment of hypercalcemia when associated with the following conditions:
Malignancy
Vitamin D intoxication
Sarcoidosis
Initial medical management of hypercalcemia involves the following:
Normal saline (200-500 ml/hour): It is the mainstay treatment to correct dehydration, and titrated to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hour
Pamidronate or zoledronate: These are bisphosphonates and are considered as the drug of choice in primary hyperparathyroidis
Cinacalcet: This is a calcimimetic that increases the affinity of the glands to extracellular calcium, thereby decreasing parathyroid hormone secretion
Denosumab: This inhibits RANK-ligand, which acts on osteoclasts
Calcitonin: This is an activated vitamin D analog that may be used to reduce calcium levels. It should be used within the first 24 hours
Forced diuresis refers to aggressive fluid hydration with loop diuretic administration. Although this is an effective method to reduce calcium levels, it requires careful monitoring for adverse effects like fluid overload, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesia. Due to this reason as well as the availability of more effective treatment modalities, forced diuresis is not preferred any longer.
The definitive management of primary hyperparathyroidism is the surgical removal of the parathyroid gland.
Solution to Question 15:
In patients with hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity, glucocorticoids like dexamethasone are the preferred therapy as they decrease 1,25 (OH2) vitamin D (calcitriol) production. This results in reduced intestinal calcium absorption and increased urinary excretion of calcium.
Hydroxychloroquine, chloroquine, and ketoconazole may also decrease calcitriol production and are used occasionally. But the preferred therapy is steroids.
Vitamin D toxicity presents acutely with features of hypercalcemia such as confusion, polyuria, polydipsia, anorexia, vomiting, and muscle weakness. Chronic intoxication may cause nephrocalcinosis, bone demineralization, and pain.
Lab features include elevated 25 (OH) vitamin D, high calcium, and suppressed PTH.
Dexamethasone can also be used in the treatment of hypercalcemia caused by the humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (due to PTHr) and sarcoidosis.
Solution to Question 16:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a hypercalcemic crisis. The next best step in management is saline hydration. Typically 200-500 ml/hour fluids are given to correct dehydration and titrated to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hour.
Hypercalcemic crisis is a medical emergency associated with serum calcium >14 mg/dl. It is often caused by conditions causing an acute rise in calcium levels such as malignancies or lithium overdose.
It presents with oliguria, severe dehydration, gastrointestinal symptoms, and altered consciousness. It can lead to cardiac arrest and coma.
Initial medical management of hypercalcemia involves the following:
Fluids are the mainstay treatment
Bisphosphonates
Cinacalcet
Denosumab
Calcitonin

DiGeorge syndrome

Solution to Question 20:
Hypocalcemia is a feature of secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT).
Hypocalcemia refers to total serum calcium 8.4 mg/dl. The causes include:
Low PTH
Hypoparathyroidis
High PTH (SHPT)
Chronic kidney disease
Vitamin D deficiency
Pseudohypoparathyroidis
Hyperphosphatemia
Loop diuretics, calcitonin, bisphosphonates
Massive blood transfusions
Hyperventilation
Hypomagnesemia - Mg is essential for PTH release
Severe hypermagnesemia - higher Mg levels suppress PTH secretion
Hypocalcemia causes tetany or increased neuromuscular excitability. It can cause paresthesias, cramps, spasms, and seizures. Latent tetany can only be detected by performing Chvostek and Trousseau's signs. A prolonged QT interval is seen on ECG.
Solution to Question 21:
The above image indicates Trousseau's sign or carpopedal spasm classically seen in patients with hypocalcemia.
Trousseau's sign is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position.
Hypocalcemia results in tetany or increased neuromuscular irritability. It leads to paresthesia and tingling of extremities and perioral area. Severe hypocalcemia can cause seizures.
Option A: Chvostek's sign is also seen in hypocalcemia. Tapping the facial nerve in front of the tragus will cause spasms of the facial muscles.
Option C: Tinel's sign is seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It refers to a tingling sensation on tapping over the median nerve.
Option D: Troisier's sign refers to left supraclavicular lymphadenopathy in metastatic abdominal malignancy.
Solution to Question 22:
Etidronate is not used in the management of hypocalcemia. It is a bisphosphonate used in the management of hypercalcemia.
The goal in the management of hypoparathyroidism is to restore the calcium-phosphate balance. The mainstay is calcium and vitamin D supplements. Other underlying conditions must also be treated.
Instead of loop diuretics, thiazides can be administered on a low sodium diet as they enhance urinary calcium reabsorption.
