Solution to Question 1:
Leptin is an adipocyte-derived hormone.
It acts through brain circuits (predominantly in the hypothalamus) to influence appetite, energy expenditure, and neuroendocrine function. High leptin levels reduce appetite and increase energy expenditure.
The arcuate nucleus in the hypothalamus plays an important role in the regulation of appetite.
Solution to Question 2:
In the fasting state, high levels of ghrelin are seen. It is a gut-peptide produced in the stomach and stimulates hunger and appetite.
Solution to Question 3:
This boy is likely to have high levels of -Melanocyte-stimulating hormone (-MSH). It is a hypothalamic peptide that decreases appetite and hence would be increased in the fed state.
Solution to Question 4:
One of the key transcription factors involved in the differentiation of mesenchymal preadipocytes to adipose cells is the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor  (PPAR). It is a nuclear receptor that also binds the thiazolidinedione class of insulin-sensitizing drugs used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.
Note: Saroglitazar has a dual action on PPAR and PPAR■ receptors. It reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic patients.
Solution to Question 5:
Adiponectin levels are reduced in obesity.
It is an abundant adipose-derived protein with the following characteristics:
Its levels are reduced in obesity
It enhances insulin sensitivity and lipid oxidation
Has vascular-protective effects
On the other hand, resistin and RBP4 levels, which are also secreted by adipocytes, may induce insulin resistance.
Solution to Question 6:
The most prominent neuroendocrine abnormality seen in obese individuals with inactivating mutations in the leptin (ob gene) or leptin receptor (db gene) is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
Leptin mutations are responsible for a rare form of obesity that runs in families. These mutations prevent leptin from delivering satiety signals. Hence, the brain perceives starvation despite adequate nutrition. It results in morbid, early-onset obesity.
Mutations in the following genes can cause obesity in humans:
Lep (ob)
LepR (db)
POMC
PC-1
MC4R

Pale skin and red hair
Absence of ACTH
Secondary adrenal insufficiency
Solution to Question 8:
Insulin levels are increased in obesity. It stimulates the synthesis of fatty acids and TAG and decreases the rate of lipolysis. Thyroxine, growth hormone, and adiponectin have lipolytic effects, hence their levels are reduced in obesity.
Hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance are consistent features of obesity. Insulin resistance is more strongly linked to intra-abdominal fat than to fat in other areas.
Adiponectin (Option D) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that is produced by adipocytes. It performs vital functions that are reduced in obesity - like, increasing insulin sensitivity and the inhibition of gluconeogenic enzymes. It also enhances fatty acid oxidation.
Insulin resistance in obesity occurs as a result of the following:
Insulin receptor downregulation
Increased FFA (free fatty acids) and capable of impairing insulin action
Intracellular lipid accumulation
Circulating peptides produced by adipocytes such as TNF-, IL-6, RBP4, and resistin modify insulin action.

Solution to Question 1:
The given clinical scenario describes recurrent hemolysis in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis leading to jaundice. In hemolytic conditions, only the unconjugated/ indirect bilirubin is raised and conjugated/direct bilirubin remains normal i.e. <15% of total bilirubin.
Bilirubin is synthesized from heme which is released primarily from the breakdown of old RBCs. This bilirubin is in its unconjugated form. It enters the circulation and reaches the liver. It is converted to conjugated bilirubin which is then secreted into the biliary tree.
Therefore, in a healthy person, most of the circulating bilirubin is unconjugated/indirect bilirubin. Hence, the normal liver function tests show indirect bilirubin >85% and direct/conjugated bilirubin <15% of the total bilirubin. The normal bilirubin values are as follows:
Total bilirubin levels - 1 to 1.5 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin - <0.3 mg/dL
Solution to Question 2:
The raised direct bilirubin levels indicate conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Among the given options, biliary atresia causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
Biliary atresia is a disorder characterised by destruction or absence of bile ducts in a newborn. It leads to obstruction to the flow of bile thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation.
Option B: Physiological jaundice of the newborn occurs due to immaturity of the newborn's liver. It is not able to conjugate the excess bilirubin produced after birth. It leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
Option C: Breast milk may contain certain factors that inhibit the conjugation of bilirubin leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
Option D: Hemolytic disease of the newborn causes excess production of bilirubin due to hemolysis leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
Solution to Question 3:
The presence of urinary bilirubin and increased total bilirubin indicates conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Among the given options, Dubin Johnson syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
Only conjugated bilirubin can appear in the urine because it is water-soluble and filterable by the kidney. Unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble and bound to albumin, hence it cannot be filtered by the kidney.
Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia:
Increased bilirubin production-
Hemolytic anemias
Hematomas
Impaired bilirubin uptake and conjugation-
Gilbert syndrome
Crigler Najjar syndrome
Drugs - Probenecid, Rifampin
Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia:
Hereditary cholestatic syndromes
Dubin Johnson syndrome
Rotor syndrome
Biliary obstruction
Solution to Question 4:
Probenecid causes impaired hepatic uptake of bilirubin which leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
Amoxicillin-clavulanate, acute hepatitis and stone in the common bile duct are causes that lead to mixed hyperbilirubinemia (both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin elevated) or predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemias.
Levels of conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin are useful in determining pre-hepatic causes of jaundice but are not useful in differentiating between intrahepatic and post-hepatic causes of jaundice.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS). The LFT describes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with normal liver enzyme levels. The given image of microscopic examination of liver biopsy shows an accumulation of dark melanin-like pigment in the hepatocytes which is seen in this condition.
DJS is an autosomal recessive condition causing defective expression of MRP 2 protein which is important for the biliary excretion of conjugated bilirubin. The patient has icterus but is otherwise asymptomatic.
DJS also impairs biliary excretion of various compounds like epinephrine metabolites. The dark melanin-like pigment is derived from these metabolites causing the liver to appear black.
Rotor syndrome is also an autosomal recessive condition causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but it does not present with pigmentation of the liver.
Gilbert and Crigler-Najjar syndromes are characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
Solution to Question 6:
Rotor syndrome occurs due to mutation in OATP (organic anion transport protein) 1B1 and 1B3.
Rotor syndrome is an inherited autosomal recessive disorder with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a benign disorder with mild elevation of bilirubin levels. It is similar to Dubin Johnson syndrome but the liver does not show any black pigmentation. No treatment is required for these patients.
Solution to Question 7:
Serum bilirubin levels are not helpful in differentiating between Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS)
and Rotor's syndrome as both these conditions present with mild elevation of serum bilirubin. These two conditions can be differentiated as follows:

Solution to Question 8:
Kernicterus is seen in Crigler-Najjar syndrome but not in Gilbert syndrome. Gilbert syndrome does not cause a significant elevation in unconjugated bilirubin to cause kernicterus.
Crigler-Najjar syndrome and Gilbert syndrome are both caused by various mutations in the UGT1A1 gene. This leads to decreased activity of bilirubin UDP-glucuronosyltransferase enzyme leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Both are predominantly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
These syndromes present with jaundice in infants. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in these syndromes is not associated with any hemolysis. All the other liver function tests are usually normal.
Crigler Najjar syndrome may lead to kernicterus causing severe brain damage. Liver transplantation is required without which the infant may not survive beyond 1-2 years of age. Whereas, Gilbert syndrome is a benign asymptomatic condition that does not need any intervention.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario with poor feeding and seizures is indicative of kernicterus. This accompanied with unconjugated hyperbilrubinemia is highly suggestive of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1.
No improvement in bilirubin levels following the administration of phenobarbital further supports the diagnosis.
Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace enzyme activity and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally.
Kernicterus occurs because the unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble and hence crosses the blood-brain barrier.
Phenobarbital is an enzyme inducer. Its administration can be used to differentiate between type 1 and type 2 Crigler-Najjar.
Enzyme induction by phenobarbital leads to improved conjugation of bilirubin leading to a reduction in total bilirubin level in type 2 Crigler-Najjar syndrome.
No improvement is seen in type 1 as the enzyme activity is absent and therefore cannot be induced.

Crigler-Najjar type I

Solution to Question 12:
Among the given options, alanine aminotransferase is the most specific indicator of liver cell injury.
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) are indicators of liver cell injury. This is because ALT is found primarily in the liver, whereas, AST is found in the liver, cardiac muscle, skeletal muscle, kidneys, brain, pancreas, etc.
GGT and ALP are enzymes that primarily reflect cholestasis.
Solution to Question 13:
In a patient with acute viral hepatitis, serum transaminases are elevated to >1000 IU/L
The normal levels of serum transaminases are 10-40 IU/L. Marked elevation of serum transaminases >1000 IU/L is seen in conditions with extensive hepatocellular injury. These include:
Viral hepatitis
Ischemic injury to the liver in conditions like acute heart failure
Toxin/drug-induced liver injury
Minor elevations of serum transaminase levels up to 300 IU/L are non-specific and can be found in any liver disease.
Solution to Question 14:
A 4 fold rise of serum ALP (alkaline phosphatase) is suggestive of cholestatic liver disease. However, serum ALP levels cannot differentiate between extrahepatic and intrahepatic cholestasis.
The normal range for serum ALP is considered 40-125 IU/L. Serum alkaline phosphatase is found in the liver, bone, small intestines, and placenta. Hence, a mild increase in ALP, i.e., 1 - 1.5 times normal, can be seen in these conditions:
Following a fatty meal intake - influx of intestinal alkaline phosphatase into the blood. Hence, the patient is advised to fast before the blood sample is collected for the test.
In pregnancy - placental ALP
In children - rapid bone growth
In elderly people over 60 years of age
ALP can be raised even in conditions like metastatic bone disease, inflammatory bowel disease,
Hodgkin's lymphoma, etc. Hence, it needs to be correlated with raised levels of
gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT) and 5' nucleotidase which are more specific for liver disease.
Solution to Question 15:
AST:ALT ratio <1 is seen in NAFLD (nonalcoholic fatty liver disease). The AST:ALT ratio can be interpreted as follows:
Option A: Patients with cirrhosis have only mildly elevated or even normal levels of serum transaminases.
Option B: Absolute levels of aminotransferases are not used for predicting prognosis. This is because there is a poor correlation between the degree of liver cell damage and the levels of aminotransferases.

Solution to Question 16:
Among the given options, penicillin does not lead to elevated gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT)
levels.
GGT is a microsomal enzyme. Hence, drugs that are microsomal enzyme inducers can lead to an increase in GGT levels. However, other liver enzyme levels will be normal. Therefore, an isolated rise in GGT level does not indicate cholestatic liver disease.
Drugs that increase levels of GGT are:
Barbiturates
Carbamazepine
Ethanol
Griseofulvin
Rifampicin
Phenytoin
Solution to Question 17:
Prothrombin time (PT) can help in estimating the levels of factors II, V, VII, and X.
PT evaluates the extrinsic and the common pathway of coagulation. Factor VII is required in the extrinsic pathway and factors II, V, X are required in the common pathway.
Coagulation factors are produced by the liver (except factor VIII) and they have a short half-life. Hence, they indicate the synthetic function of the liver and are very useful in assessing acute hepatic dysfunction. Factor VIII is produced by vascular endothelial cells.
Prolonged PT that is not corrected by vitamin K administration indicates poor prognosis in both acute and chronic liver disease.
Solution to Question 18:
Serum albumin is a marker of chronic liver disease because it is synthesized by the hepatocytes and has a long half-life of 18–20 days. Serum albumin is not a good indicator of acute or mild hepatic dysfunction.
Hypoalbuminemia is more common in chronic liver disorders such as cirrhosis and usually reflects severe liver damage. In hepatitis, albumin levels <3 g/dL should raise the possibility of chronic liver disease.
Prothrombin time is used to assess acute parenchymal liver disease. 5' nucleosidase is elevated in cholestasis. Elevation of ALP (<3 fold) is not specific to liver diseases.
Solution to Question 19:
Chronic liver disease is associated with hypergammaglobulinemia. Chronic liver diseases with hypergammaglobulinemia include autoimmune hepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis, and alcoholic liver disease.
The liver produces all globulins except gamma globulin which are produced by B cells. In chronic liver diseases like liver cirrhosis, there is impaired reticuloendothelial function in hepatic sinusoids. Hence the liver fails to clear the bacterial antigens. This causes an increased production of gamma globulin.

Solution to Question 21:
Liver biopsy can be performed in a patient with splenomegaly via the percutaneous approach.
When the percutaneous approach is not advisable, liver biopsy can be performed via the transjugular approach. In this approach, a cannula is inserted via the jugular vein which is then passed into hepatic veins through which the biopsy sample is taken. Therefore, any bleeding resulting from the procedure will drain into the hepatic veins.
Indications of transjugular liver biopsy:
Percutaneous approach contraindicate
Significant ascites
Prolonged INR
Coagulopathies
Difficulty in accessing the liver via the percutaneous route
Morbid obesity

Solution to Question 1:
Alcoholic liver disease is the most common cause of cirrhosis in India.
The most common cause of cirrhosis worldwide is chronic viral hepatitis - Hepatitis C and B. NASH is expected to overtake it in the near future.
Solution to Question 2:
The minimum amount of ethanol that leads to an increased risk of developing alcoholic liver disease is 28g/day. In women, the minimum is 14g/day.
The risk factors for alcoholic liver disease are:
Quantity of alcohol consumption - The risk of developing alcoholic liver disease increases when alcohol consumption is >14 drinks/ week in men and >7drinks/week in women. A standard drink contains 14g of ethanol which is present in -
120 mL of wine
350ml of beer
45ml of spirits (gin, rum, whiskey, vodka, tequilla)
Gender - Women have increased susceptibility to alcoholic liver disease
Hepatitis C infection - Increases the severity and decreases survival in alcoholic liver disease
Genetics - A variation in patatin-like phospholipase domain-containing protein 3 (PNPLA3)
gene confers an increased risk of progressive liver disease
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. It is usually characterized by an AST: ALT > 2. This is because there is a deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate that is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise and there is a reversal of the AST: ALT ratio.
Prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged due to the deficiency of coagulation factors and, usually, does not respond to the administration of parenteral vitamin K. Platelet counts are often reduced early in the disease, which is reflective of portal hypertension with hypersplenism.
Elevated ALP levels are seen due to enzymatic induction by alcohol and mild cholestasis.
Solution to Question 4:
Zieve's syndrome is not associated with thrombocytosis.
Zieve's syndrome is a rare syndrome occurring due to severe alcoholic hepatitis characterized by a triad of:
Cholestatic jaundice
Hemolytic anemia
Transient hyperlipidemia
It resolves with abstinence from alcohol.
Solution to Question 5:
GGT (Gamma Glutamyl Transferase) is the most specific marker of alcoholism among the given options.
The markers with >60% sensitivity and specificity for heavy alcohol use are gamma-glutamyl transferase (>35 u) and carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT), the combination of the two is likely to be more accurate than one. An isolated elevation in serum GGT or GGT elevation out of proportion to that of other enzymes (such as the ALT and ALP) may be an indicator of alcohol abuse or alcoholic liver disease.
ALT (option A) is usually elevated in acute hepatocellular conditions such as hepatitis. Alanine aminotransferase is predominantly found in the liver, hence a more specific marker of liver injury. A ratio of AST/ALT > 2:1 indicates the possibility of alcoholic liver disease and > 3:1 ratio is highly indicative of this condition. In alcoholic liver disease, ALT levels are often normal.
ALP (option C) is elevated in cholestasis, ■■is also elevated when there is rapid bone growth like in children and adolescents because of bone alkaline phosphatase and in normal pregnancies due to placental alkaline phosphatase.
LDH (option D) elevation is nonspecific.
Solution to Question 6:
C stands for feeling the need to cut down your drinking in the CAGE questionnaire.
The CAGE questionnaire is used for identifying alcohol abuse. It can be expanded as below:
C - Have you ever felt you ought to cut down on your drinking?
A - Have people annoyed you by criticizing your drinking?
G - Have you ever felt guilty or bad about your drinking?
E - Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or get rid of a hangover (eye-opener)?
One 'yes' response raises a suspicion of an alcohol use problem and more than one is a strong indication of abuse or dependence.
Solution to Question 7:
Discriminant function (DF) is calculated using prothrombin time and bilirubin level. It is also known as the Maddrey score and it assesses the severity and mortality risk in alcoholic hepatitis.
DF = 4.6 X (the prolongation of the prothrombin time above control [seconds]) + serum bilirubin
(mg/dL)
DF  32 indicates severe disease and is an indication for starting glucocorticoids.
Solution to Question 8:
Severe alcoholic hepatitis is defined as discriminant function (DF)  32. Severe alcoholic hepatitis is defined as:
Discriminant Function (DF)  32
Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) score  21
Presence of hepatic encephalopathy
Solution to Question 9:
Alcoholic cirrhosis is characterized by mixed micro-and macronodular. If a mixed pattern is not an option, the best choice is micronodular cirrhosis.
Cirrhosis is the late stage of alcoholic liver disease. It is characterised by extensive fibrosis. Alcoholic cirrhosis begins as micronodular cirrhosis. With the cessation of alcohol use, larger nodules may form, resulting in a mixed micronodular and macronodular pattern.
The various conditions in which cirrhosis is seen are listed below:
Macronodular cirrhosis- Parenchymal nodules >3 mm
Micronodular cirrhosis- Parenchymal nodules <3 mm

Micronodular cirrhosis

Solution to Question 10:
SOFA score >2 indicates sepsis and glucocorticoids are avoided in septic patients. Glucocorticoids are indicated in severe alcoholic hepatitis which is defined as:
Discriminant Function (DF)  32
Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) score  21
Glasgow alcoholic hepatitis score  9
Presence of hepatic encephalopathy
Prednisolone is given at a dose of 32 mg orally daily for 4 weeks and then slowly tapered off. Glucocorticoid therapy is avoided in:
Active GI bleeding requiring blood transfusions
Active infection requiring antibiotic treatment
Preexisting chronic renal disease with a serum creatinine level greater than 2 mg/dL
Pancreatitis
Obvious contraindications to glucocorticoid therapy
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe alcoholic hepatitis. Since the patient is a known case of chronic kidney disease, pentoxifylline is used in his treatment.
Severe alcoholic hepatitis is defined by a discriminant function  32. In the given scenario,
DF = 4.6 X (the prolongation of the prothrombin time above control [seconds]) + serum bilirubin
(mg/dL)
= 4.6 x (16-11) + 11 = 34.
Thus, the patient cannot be managed by nutritional support alone.
Pentoxifylline is a TNF alpha inhibitor used either by itself or along with glucocorticoids in the treatment of severe alcoholic hepatitis. It is preferred in patients with kidney diseases and conditions where glucocorticoids are contraindicated.
Glucocorticoid therapy is avoided in:
Active GI bleeding requiring blood transfusions
Active infection requiring antibiotic treatment
Preexisting chronic renal disease with a serum creatinine level greater than 2 mg/dL
Pancreatitis
Obvious contraindications to glucocorticoid therapy
Solution to Question 12:
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with increased levels of serum ferritin.
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is defined as hepatic steatosis in the absence of any secondary cause for fat accumulation. Histologically, this requires fat accumulation in more than 5% of hepatocytes and it can be divided into:
Nonalcoholic fatty liver (NAFL)- steatosis without inflammation
Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) - steatosis with inflammation
NAFLD is strongly associated with obesity and insulin resistance. Its diagnosis requires demonstration of hepatic steatosis and exclusion of significant alcohol consumption and other causes of hepatic fat accumulation.
Solution to Question 13:
The first-line therapy for nondiabetic patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis(NASH) is vitamin E.
Management of NAFLD includes:
Vitamin E - first-line therapy in non-diabetics
Insulin sensitizers- first-line therapy in diabetics
Immunizations for Hepatitis A and B
Weight loss
Abstinence from alcoho
Note: The FDA in 2024 has approved Resmetirom, a thyroid hormone receptor-beta (THR-beta)
agonist for noncirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.

Solution to Question 3:
Fatality due to Hepatitis E is highest in pregnant women. In the general population, hepatitis E can lead to fatal fulminant hepatitis in only 1–2% of cases. However, in pregnant women, this is raised to 20% of cases.
HEV does not have a carrier state and can cause chronic hepatitis only in immunocompromised individuals. Its most common route of spread is feco-oral.
Note - HEV is also known as E-NANB, i.e., Enterically transmitted Non-A Non-B hepatitis virus.It often appears in epidemics; hence, it is also called epidemic NANB.
Solution to Question 4:
Acute viral hepatitis caused by the hepatitis D virus is associated with the highest risk of developing fulminant hepatitis.
However, fulminant hepatitis is most commonly caused by hepatitis E, especially in endemic countries such as India. This is due to the greater prevalence of hepatitis E infections compared to hepatitis D.
Solution to Question 5:
The chance of vertical transmission of hepatitis B from a mother who is HBsAg positive and HBeAg positive is >90%. In contrast, when the mother is HBsAg positive but HBeAg negative or HBsAg positive with Anti Hbe, the risk of vertical transmission is low.
To prevent vertical transmission of HBV, HBsAg positive pregnant women with high HBV DNA titres should receive tenofovir prophylaxis from the 28th week of pregnancy until birth. Infants born to these women are given hepatitis B immunoglobulin along with the first dose of
the hepatitis B vaccine.
The presence of HBeAg indicates active replication of HBV. Therefore, HBeAg is the qualitative marker of infectivity. HBV DNA titre is the quantitative marker of infectivity.

Solution to Question 6:
The first virologic marker to rise in acute hepatitis B is HBsAg i.e., Hepatitis B surface antigen. It is detectable in serum within 1–12 weeks of infection. Usually, HBsAg becomes undetectable 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice. If it persists beyond 6 months, it indicates chronic hepatitis B.
However, very rarely, patients may have an HBsAg negative status even during active infection due to infection with escape mutant HBV. These escape mutants have mutations within the S gene and they are known to be responsible for occult hepatitis B infections.

Solution to Question 7:
The diagnosis of acute hepatitis B in the window period or serological gap can be made by the detection of the anti-HBc antibody.
The window period is the period between the disappearance of HBsAg to anti-HBs seroconversion. During this window period, anti-HBc is the only detectable antibody.
Solution to Question 8:
Increased viral load and negative HBeAg suggest a pre-core mutant variety of hepatitis B
virus. These strains have mutations in the pre-core region of the C gene, leading to a stop codon that prevents HBeAg synthesis. These strains can be detected in the serum by HBV DNA analysis.
Infection with hepatitis B mutants is difficult to treat and causes infections of prolonged duration. They have a higher risk of progressing to liver cirrhosis.

Solution to Question 9:
The given lab findings are most likely to be in patients who had hepatitis B in the remote past i.e., patients in late convalescence period. In such conditions, the patient will have positive IgG
anti-HBc and negative HBsAg.
Solution to Question 10:
The serological marker marked in the image which becomes detectable early in the infection and remains elevated for a long period after recovery from the infection is an anti-HBc antibody.
Anti-HBc is demonstrable in serum within the first 1–2 weeks after the appearance of HBsAg. It precedes detectable levels of anti-HBs by weeks to months.
I M anti-HBcAg antibody is seen early in the infection for about 6 months and indicates a recent infection. IgG anti-HBcAg antibody is seen later, after 6 months, and indicates remote infection.
Solution to Question 11:
The most reliable indicator of recent HBV infection is IgM anti-HBc in serum. However, the first virologic marker to rise in acute hepatitis B is HBsAg i.e. surface antigen.
HBsAg is detectable in serum within 1–12 weeks of infection. Anti-HBc is demonstrable in the serum about 1-2 weeks after this, and may sometimes persist in the serum even longer than an anti-HBs antibody. IgM anti-HBcAg is seen early in the infection and persists for about 6 months. It indicates a recent infection. IgG anti-HBcAg antibody is seen later i.e. after 6 months and indicates remote infection.
HBcAg is not detectable in the serum of patients with HBV infection as it is present intracellularly.
Note: The risk of transmission of HBV from percutaneous routes (eg., needle prick) is about 6-30% and it is about 100 times more infectious than HIV.
Solution to Question 12:
The need for administration of hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin (HBIG) in a previously vaccinated individual can be determined based on anti-HBsAg levels. It is the marker for determining the efficacy of hepatitis B vaccination.
The complete hepatitis B vaccine schedule consists of three intramuscular doses at 0, 1, and 6 months.
Post Exposure Prophylaxis:
The prophylaxis can be done using the hepatitis B vaccine or hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG).
Vaccination status of the exp osed person
Recommended prophylaxis
Unvaccinated
HBIG (0.06 mL/kg) and initi ate hepatitis B vaccine series
Known responder to previous vaccination (anti-HBs titer>1 0 mIU/ml)
No action required
Non-responder to previous v accination (anti-HBs titre <1 0 mIU/ml)
HBIG: 2 doses (1 month apar t) OR HBIG: 1 dose + initiate hepatitis B revaccination.
Solution to Question 13:
I M anti-HBc can be used to differentiate between hepatitis D coinfection and superinfection in patients with HBV infection.
Co-infection:
Simultaneous infection with both HBV and HDV
IgM anti-HBc detectable in co-infection as its presence indicates recent infection Superinfection:
HDV infection of an individual chronically infected with HBV
IgM anti-HBc will not be detectable
IgG anti-HBc will be present
Solution to Question 14:
The given histopathological image shows ground-glass hepatocytes which are a hallmark of chronic hepatitis B infection.

These ground-glass hepatocytes are liver parenchymal cells that have an eosinophilic, granular, and glassy appearance on light microscopy. This appearance is due to the accumulation of HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.
Liver biopsy findings in viral hepatitis:
Virus

Hepatitis A

Hepatitis B

Hepatitis E

Solution to Question 15:
Antiviral therapy is not indicated in acute hepatitis B infection. It is only indicated in chronic hepatitis B.
The majority of acute hepatitis (A, B, and E) infections are self-limiting, resulting in viral elimination and complete healing within 6 months. Hence, they need only supportive management. Only 5% of acute hepatitis infections become chronic.
In acute hepatitis C infection, recovery is rare, and the risk of progression to chronic hepatitis is high(85%). Thus antiviral therapy is started irrespective of the disease stage.
Solution to Question 16:
ALT > 2 times upper limit of normal is an indication for antiviral therapy in chronic hepatitis B infection.
The decision to initiate antiviral therapy is primarily based on the presence or absence
of cirrhosis, and parameters such as HBeAg, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level, and HBV DNA level.
The following are the indications for starting antivirals in chronic hepatitis B:
Patients without cirrhosis
HBeAg + with HBV DNA >20,000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal
HBeAg -ve with HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal
Patients with compensated cirrhosis and an HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL
Patients developing acute liver failure or decompensated cirrhosis Recommended first-line antiviral drugs:
Entecavir
Tenofovir alafenamide
Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate
Pegylated interferon alfa can also be used. Treatment is aimed at HBeAg seroconversion, but most patients may need to continue antiviral therapy indefinitely.
Solution to Question 17:
HBeAg negative and HBV DNA <2000 IU/mL is suggestive of HBV carrier. Serial monitoring of both biochemical and virological parameters is done for such patients.
Indications for starting antiviral therapy in chronic hepatitis B are:
Patients without cirrhosis
HBeAg + with HBV DNA >20,000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal
HBeAg -ve with HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal
Patients with compensated cirrhosis and an HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL
Patients developing acute liver failure or decompensated cirrhosis
Solution to Question 18:
First-line drugs used for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B include entecavir and tenofovir. Second-line drugs for this condition include:
Lamivudine
Adefovir
Telbivudine
Pegylated interferon can also be used in its treatment.
Solution to Question 19:
Surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma is recommended for Asian male HBV carriers over the age of 40 years.
The most common etiological factor for hepatocellular carcinoma in the world is the hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Surveillance programs have been implemented to screen for HCC in high-risk individuals because it is more cost-effective than the treatment of HCC.
Surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is recommended in:
HBV carriers with cirrhosis
Patients with high serum levels of HBV DNA and ongoing liver injury
HBV carriers born in Africa and over the age of 20
Asian male HBV carriers over age 40
Asian female HBV carriers over age 50
HBV carriers with a family history of HCC Note:
The CDC recently updated its guidelines for Hepatitis B screening. The report includes screening for all adults >18 years old using the triple-panel test (HBsAg, Anti-HBs, total anti-HBc) and expanded risk-based testing in certain high-risk populations.
Solution to Question 20:
I M anti-HBe is not one of the markers that are evaluated in a suspected case of acute viral hepatitis.
Investigations done in suspected acute viral hepatitis are:
IgM anti-HAV - to detect acute hepatitis A infection which is the most common cause of acute hepatitis in children
HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc - to detect acute hepatitis B infection, where HbsAg is the first marker to rise and IgM anti-HBcAg is the most reliable marker of acute infection
Anti HCV - to evaluate for acute hepatitis C infection
IgM anti-HEV (rarely)- to detect acute hepatitis E infection which is one of the causes of acute viral hepatitis in adults.
Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of jaundice. The tests that should be done in this patient to rule out acute viral hepatitis include:
Anti-HAV
HBsA
IgM anti-HBc
Anti-HCV
We mainly test for hepatitis A, B, and C. Tests for hepatitis D and E are not used routinely.
Hepatitis D only occurs concurrently with Hepatitis B, either as a co-infection (when it is clinically indistinguishable from HBV infection) or superimposed on chronic HBV infection. In the latter scenario, it presents as a sudden worsening of the patient’s condition. IgM anti-HDV, IgG
anti-HDV, and HDV RNA assays are useful for diagnosis when hepatitis D is suspected.
Hepatitis E is not tested as the majority of patients who acquire hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection spontaneously clear the virus. Acute hepatic failure is more likely in those who are pregnant and in those who are malnourished or have preexisting liver disease. Chronic HEV has been described almost exclusively in immunocompromised hosts (e.g., organ transplantation). The diagnosis of acute HEV is typically based upon the detection of IgM antibodies to HEV. Both false positives and negatives are common with available assays and are thus, not very reliable. Thus, additional serologic testing or HEV RNA testing should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and not be useful as a screening test. [Please note the difference between anti-HBe and anti-HEV]

Solution to Question 22:
HCV screening is not indicated for household contacts of persons with hepatitis C. However, hepatitis B virus screening is recommended in household contacts of HBV-infected persons.
Indications of HCV infection screening:
Persons with a history of using injection drugs
Persons with HIV infection
Long term hemodialysis
Persons with an unexplained elevation of aminotransferases
Recipient of blood or organs from a donor found to be positive for hepatitis C
Children born to women with Hepatitis C
Health care, public safety, and emergency medical personnel following needle injury or mucosal exposure to HCV contaminated blood
Sexual partners of persons with Hepatitis C
Solution to Question 23:
Polyarteritis nodosa is not characteristically associated with hepatitis C infection. However, it is a common extrahepatic manifestation of hepatitis B viral infection.
Solution to Question 24:
While HCV RNA is considered the gold standard for establishing a diagnosis of hepatitis C, it has no role in determining the progression of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis C.
The likelihood of progression of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis C is increased by:
Longer duration of infection - most important determinant
Older age
Obesity - patients with a high body mass index are at an increased risk of developing fibrosis
Diabetes mellitus and insulin resistance
Concomitant liver disorder (eg., alcoholic liver disease, chronic hepatitis B, hemochromatosis)
Concomitant HIV infection.
The best prognostic indicator in chronic hepatitis C is the rate of fibrosis and baseline inflammation seen in liver histology.
Solution to Question 25:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatitis C for which the preferred treatment regimen is velpatasvir 100 mg and sofosbuvir 400 mg.
The goal of treatment is a sustained virologic response (SVR), which is defined as the absence of a virus in the blood (undetectable HCV RNA), 12 weeks after completion of treatment. This can be achieved by the use of pan-genotypic directly acting antiviral drugs, irrespective of the disease stage.
Solution to Question 26:
Sofosbuvir is not an NS5A inhibitor but is an NS5B nucleoside/nucleotide polymerase inhibitor. The directly acting antivirals used in the treatment of Hepatitis C infection include:
Autoimmune Disorders of Hepatobiliary System

Solution to Question 1:
Presence of viral markers is not a part of the simplified scoring system for diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis.
The simplified scoring system includes four variables. They are:
Autoantibodies
Elevated serum IgG level
Typical compatible histologic features
Absence of viral hepatitis markers
The clinical presentation in autoimmune hepatitis is variable and shares features with acute and chronic hepatitis of other aetiologies. They usually present with an insidious onset of non-specific symptoms such as fatigue, anorexia and eventually jaundice. It can then progress to extensive liver necrosis and liver failure.
Autoimmune hepatitis is associated with several autoimmune diseases such as:
Rheumatoid arthritis
Systemic lupus erythematosus
Thyroiditis and Grave's disease
Haemolytic anemia
Solution to Question 2:
Minocycline is associated with the development of drug-induced AIH.
Other drugs associated with AIH include nitrofurantoin, methyldopa, diclofenac, and possibly statins.
Solution to Question 3:
cANCA is not seen in autoimmune hepatitis. It is positive in Wegner's granulomatosis. pANCA is what is seen in autoimmune hepatitis.
There are 2 types of autoimmune hepatitis:
Type I (classic) autoimmune hepatitis is often seen in young women. It is linked to HLA-DR3 or HLA-DR4. It responds well to steroids and has a better prognosis. The autoantibodies that are seen in type I are:
ANA - antinuclear antibodies
ASMA - anti-smooth muscle actin
pANCA - perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic
anti-SLA - anti-soluble liver antigen
Type II autoimmune hepatitis is often seen in children. It is linked to HLA-DRB1 or HLA-DQB1. It usually leads to fibrosis, cirrhosis and liver failure. The autoantibodies that are seen in type II are:
Anti-LKM 1 - anti-liver kidney microsomes
Anti-liver cytosol 1
Solution to Question 4:
Anti LKM 1- Autoimmune hepatitis II
Anti SLA - Autoimmune hepatitis I
Anti LKM 2 - Drug-induced hepatitis
Anti LKM 3 - Chronic hepatitis D
Solution to Question 5:
The mainstay of management in autoimmune hepatitis is glucocorticoid therapy.
Glucocorticoids are started at high doses and tapered down to a low maintenance dose. The dose of glucocorticoids is often reduced by combining with azathioprine.
The benefits of glucocorticoid + azathioprine combination therapy are:
Reduction in the duration of therapy.
Avoid life-threatening complications of steroids (e.g., cushingoid features, hypertension, diabetes, osteoporosis).
Solution to Question 6:
Liver transplant is not contraindicated in refractory autoimmune hepatitis even though the risk of recurrence is high.
The medical management of refractory autoimmune hepatitis include:
High dose glucocorticoids
Glucocorticoids + high dose azathioprine
Addition of cyclosporine, tacrolimus, or mycophenolate mofetil.
Solution to Question 7:
Persistently increased serum bilirubin after 2 weeks of therapy suggests a poor prognosis. Early signs of poor prognosis include:
Failure of serum bilirubin to reduce after 2 weeks of therapy. Early signs of good prognosis include:
An increase in serum albumin.
A decrease in serum bilirubin, globulins and aminotransferases.
Improvement of symptoms.
Histopathologic improvement can often take months to years.
Solution to Question 8:
The most common symptom of primary biliary cholangitis(PBC) is fatigue.
Primary biliary cholangitis(PBC) is a granulomatous autoimmune condition characterized by the destruction of interlobular hepatic bile ducts.
Most patients with PBC are asymptomatic at the time of the diagnosis. Fatigue and pruritus are both common presenting symptoms. However, the most common symptom is fatigue.
Other symptoms and signs are -
Right upper quadrant pain
Hyperpigmentation
Xanthomas and xanthelasma
Jaundice
Hepatosplenomegaly.
Solution to Question 9:
Anti-LKM 2 antibodies are not seen in primary biliary cholangitis. They are seen in drug-induced hepatitis.
The laboratory findings of primary biliary cholangitis include :
Liver function tests
Elevated ALP
Elevated GGT and 5'- nucleotidase
Elevated ALT and AST
Serology -
Antimitochondrial antibodies - positive in ˜5% of patients. These are mostly directed against the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.
Antinuclear antibodies
Elevated HDL, LDL, and ™LDL
Elevated serum IgM
Hyperbilirubinemia is seen once cirrhosis has developed.
Solution to Question 10:
The presence of ascites and variceal bleeding suggest decompensated liver disease and the appropriate treatment is liver transplantation.
The first-line drug in primary biliary cholangitis is ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA). It only slows the rate of progression of the disease. It does not provide any symptomatic benefit or cure the disease.
Obeticholic acid is another drug used in PBC as monotherapy or in combination with UDCA. It is a farnesoid X receptor agonist.
Liver transplantation is considered when there are signs of decompensation or portal hypertension such as ascites, variceal bleeding, encephalopathy, coagulopathy, or malnutrition.
Solution to Question 11:
Florid duct lesion is characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). It is the lymphocytes and plasma cells all centered around bile ducts.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis has the characteristic "onion-skin" concentric fibrosis surrounding the bile ducts.

Solution to Question 12:
Liver biopsy does not establish the diagnosis in primary sclerosing cholangitis. The diagnosis requires imaging with MRCP.
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is a chronic progressive disorder characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of intra and extrahepatic biliary ducts resulting in strictures and cholestasis. The cause is unknown. Most patients have underlying ulcerative colitis. It has an association with HLA DRw52. Patients present with symptoms of cholestasis such as fatigue and pruritus.
The laboratory findings include:
Liver function tests - Elevated ALP and aminotransferases.
Increased serum IgM levels
Positive p-ANCA
MRCP is the investigation of choice. It shows multiple strictures in intra and extrahepatic bile ducts. Liver biopsy reveals a concentric "onion skin" fibrosis. This is however not pathognomic of PSC.
There is no definitive treatment. It involves the administration of UDCA and liver transplantation. PSC can lead to the development of cholangiocarcinoma
The image below shows onion-skin fibrosis in PSC.

question_text:

Solution to Question 1:
In acute liver failure, encephalopathy occurs within 4 weeks of the development of the clinical symptoms.
Acute liver failure is the rapid worsening of the liver function in patients without cirrhosis or any preexisting liver disease. The patient initially suffers from an acute injury to the liver by viruses, drugs, etc. Following this, the function of the liver rapidly worsens and patient
develops coagulopathy and encephalopathy within 4 weeks of the development of jaundice or other clinical symptoms.
Solution to Question 2:
The most common cause of acute liver failure (ALF) in India is a viral infection. Among the viruses, hepatitis E virus is the most common cause of acute liver failure.
In developed countries, acetaminophen overdose is the most common cause of acute liver failure.
Solution to Question 3:
The given scenario is suggestive of Amanita phalloides (wild mushrooms) toxicity causing acute liver failure. Hypoglycemia is seen in acute liver failure and not hyperglycemia. It occurs due to impaired gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.
Features of acute hepatic failure are:
Hepatic encephalopathy and cerebral edema- There are increased levels of ammonia
(neurotoxin) in the body as a result of decreased elimination by the liver.
Coagulopathy- There is a decrease in the synthesis of coagulation factors leading to the elevated prothrombin time and INR.
Increased risk of infections- It occurs as a result of decreased reticuloendothelial activity, decreased synthesis of complements, acute phase reactants, etc.
Renal failure- This is more commonly seen in drug/toxin-induced hepatic failure.
Metabolic complications like hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia.
Solution to Question 4:
Hyperacute liver failure is defined as the development of encephalopathy within 7 days of the appearance of symptoms.
Acute liver failure can be subcategorized into three groups depending on the time interval between the onset of jaundice and encephalopathy.
Hyperacute- encephalopathy develops within 7 days or less than 7 days
Acute- encephalopathy develops between 8-28 days
Subacute- encephalopathy develops between 28 days to 6 months
Patients with hyperacute liver failure are more likely to develop coagulopathy and cerebral edema, but most of the patients will recover without the need for liver transplantation. On the other end, patients with subacute liver failure have less severe coagulopathy and cerebral edema, but most of them will need liver transplantation.
Solution to Question 5:
In a patient with acute liver failure, MELD score and King's College Hospital criteria can be used to assess the prognosis.
Option A: Pitt score is used used to predict mortality in patients having bloodstream infections. Option B: The child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity of cirrhosis.
Option D: Maddrey's Discriminant Function (MDF) score suggests which patients with alcoholic hepatitis may have a poor prognosis and benefit from steroid administration.
Solution to Question 6:
Serum bilirubin is not included in King's College Hospital criteria in acute liver failure due to paracetamol overdose.
The King's College Hospital Criteria is a prognostic tool for patients with acute liver failure (ALF).
The criteria is divided into acetaminophen and non-acetaminophen causes of liver failure. Liver transplantation is indicated in acetaminophen-induced ALF if there is a presence of
Either pH <7.3
Or all of the following
Prothrombin time >100 sec or INR >6.5
Serum creatinine level >3.4 mg/dL (300 mol/L) or anuria
Grade 3-4 encephalopathy
Liver transplantation is indicated in non-acetaminophen causes of ALF if there is a presence of
Either prothrombin time >100 sec or INR >6.7
Or any three of the following
Unfavorable etiology (seronegative hepatitis or drug reaction)
Age <10 or >40 yr
Acute or subacute category (duration of jaundice >7 days)
Serum bilirubin level >17.5 mg/dL (300 mol/L)
Prothrombin time >50 sec or INR >3.5
Solution to Question 7:
Portal vein thrombosis is not an absolute contraindication to liver transplantation. This is because portal vein thrombosis can be overcome by constructing a graft from the donor liver portal vein to the recipient’s superior mesenteric vein.
Absolute contraindications of liver transplantation are:
Uncontrolled extra-hepatobiliary infection or untreated sepsis
Uncorrectable life-limiting congenital anomalies
Active substance or alcohol abuse
Malignancies- Hepatocellular carcinoma with metastatic spread, incurable malignancies outside the liver, cholangiocarcinoma
AIDS
Advanced cardiopulmonary disease
Note: Milan criteria- Patients with primary hepatocellular malignancy can be considered for liver transplantation if there is:
A single lesion 5 cm.
Up to three separate lesions all <3 cm without any evidence of gross vascular invasion, nodal or distant metastases.
Solution to Question 8:
Biliary atresia is the most common indication of liver transplantation in children. Indications of liver transplant in children:
Biliary atresia
Neonatal hepatitis
Congenital hepatic fibrosis
Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency
Wilsons disease
Glycogen storage disorders
Lysosomal storage disorders
The most common indication of liver transplant in an adult is the cirrhotic liver. Cirrhosis may be the consequence of viral hepatitis, autoimmune hepatitis, chronic use of alcohol, or biliary cirrhosis.
Solution to Question 9:
Liver transplant assessment should be considered in a patient with cirrhosis of the liver when he develops spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
Cirrhosis is the most common indication of liver transplantation in adults. However, not all cases of cirrhosis require liver transplantation. It is considered
When the patient either develops the complication of cirrhosis like:
Persistent hepatic encephalopathy
Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis
Portal hypertensive bleeding
Diuretic resistant ascites
Hepatorenal syndrome
Or has a poor liver function
MELD score > 12
Child-Pugh grade C
Solution to Question 10:
Mannitol is not a component of the University of Wisconsin (UW) solution. It is the most commonly used preservation solution during the transplantation of the liver and kidneys. The organ can be stored in this solution for up to 20 hours.
Components of UW solution are:
Lactobionate- Prevents cellular swelling and reperfusion injury
Raffinose and hydroxyethyl starch- Prevents endothelial injury
Glutathione and allopurinol- free radical scavengers
Adenosine- required for regeneration of ATP
Solution to Question 11:
The false statement regarding liver transplantation is option D. Reduced-size liver transplantation involves the resection of a full-size liver to appropriately fit in the abdominal cavity of small adults/adolescents. It is reserved only for urgent transplantation. On the contrary, split LT involves dividing the whole donor liver into a left lateral segment (segments II and III) for a pediatric patient and a right lobe (segments I, IV-VIII) for an adult patient.
Option A: The required graft volume in a living donor transplant is measured by graft weight to recipient weight ratio (GRWR) or ratio of graft volume (GV) to recipient standard liver volume (SLV). The ideal GRWR is >0.8 % or GV/SLV is > 35%. The remnant donor liver mass is kept at >30% for safe regeneration.
Option B: Domino liver transplant involves transplanting a liver from a donor with metabolic disease (eg: familial amyloid polyneuropathy) to a recipient with end-stage liver disease (eg: hepatocellular carcinoma). The donor also receives an LT (healthy donor) and is prioritized over the end-stage liver disease recipient. As a liver with metabolic diseases is structurally and functionally normal, it can prolong the recipient’s life by at least 15-20 years as they will not develop the metabolic disease immediately.
Option C: Extended criteria donors/ECDs (liver grafts extracted from donors after circulatory death) and paired-exchange technique are used to decrease waitlist mortality. However, ECDs have poor graft function due to prolonged hypoxia and are associated with higher infection transmission and biliary complications.
Solution to Question 12:
Auxiliary liver transplantation is beneficial in acute liver failure.
Auxiliary liver transplantation involves implanting a healthy liver graft heterotopically or orthotopically while leaving the whole or part of the native liver intact. The auxiliary partial orthotopic LT (APOLT) technique is used in patients with acute liver failure and metabolic diseases (primary hypercholesterolemia, glycogen storage disorders, organic acidemia, etc). In acute liver failure, this technique helps in native liver regeneration and immunosuppression withdrawal. In children with metabolic liver diseases, this technique helps in future gene therapy.
Options B, C, and D are chronic liver diseases not suitable for auxiliary liver transplantation.
Solution to Question 13:
In a split liver transplant, the left lateral lobe is donated to the pediatric recipient.
Split liver donation: This method is done when the liver from the deceased donor is suitable for transplant in an adult as well as a pediatric recipient. The liver is split into two. The left lateral segment (2 and 3) is donated to the pediatric recipient, left medial and right segments (4, 5, 6, 7, and 8) is donated to the adult recipient.
Solution to Question 14:
In a patient who is on tacrolimus, the addition of fluconazole may lead to toxicity of the tacrolimus.
Tacrolimus and cyclosporine are calcineurin inhibitors and are the common agents used for the immunosuppression following liver transplantation. They are metabolized by the CYP3A enzyme. Fluconazole can inhibit this enzyme and lead to increased levels of tacrolimus and cyclosporine.
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of peritonitis due to hepatic artery thrombosis. Sirolimus is known to cause hepatic artery thrombosis in liver transplant recipients.
Sirolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and prevents T cell activation. It is not used commonly in liver transplant recipients because of the increased frequency of hepatic artery thrombosis in the first month posttransplantation. However, they can be used in patients with calcineurin
inhibitor-related nephrotoxicity.
Solution to Question 16:
Patients with liver transplantation are more likely to develop B cell lymphomas and not T cell lymphoma.
Complications of liver transplantation
Rejection of the transplanted liver
Hepatic artery thrombosis
Posttransplantation lymphoproliferative disorders- It can range from a mild polyclonal proliferation of B cells to B cell lymphomas.
Congestive heart failure and arrhythmias
Increased susceptibility to infections as a result of immunosuppression
Renal dysfunction due to acute tubular necrosis or nephrotoxicity of the tacrolimus and cyclosporine
Seizures are commonly associated with cyclosporine or tacrolimus toxicity.
Solution to Question 17:
The presence of endotheliitis confirms the presence of acute rejection of the liver transplant. Rejection following liver transplantation can be acute or chronic.
Patients usually present with
Malaise
Fever
Right upper quadrant pain Laboratory investigations will show
Elevated levels of serum bilirubin
Aminotransferases
Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidases
Liver biopsy- for confirming the diagnosis and planning the treatment
Liver biopsy of the acute rejection is characterized by the presence of mixed portal cellular infiltrate, bile duct injury, and endothelial inflammation (endotheliitis).
Chronic rejection is characterized by the presence of focal parenchymal necrosis, mononuclear cell infiltration, progressive cholestasis, and fibrosis. In some patients, this process will lead to the loss of intrahepatic bile ducts, which is called vanishing bile duct syndrome.
Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-solid transplant infection most likely due
to cytomegalovirus(CMV). It is the most common cause of post-solid organ transplants in India. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), herpes, and varicella are also known to cause infection post-solid organ transplantation but to a lesser extent.
CMV disease in recipients can present with fever, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, malaise, and arthralgia. They usually present within 1-4 months after transplant. The diagnosis of CMV infection is established by nucleic acid testing (NAT) using the polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
Management includes the use of anti-viral drugs like ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, cidofovir and intravenous immunoglobulins.
Solution to Question 19:
Among the given options, autoimmune hepatitis has the highest chance of recurrence after liver transplantation.
Although some cases of sclerosing cholangitis and primary biliary cirrhosis recur, data for recurrence of autoimmune hepatitis is more supportive.
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency does not recur after liver transplantation.

Solution to Question 1:
The most common mutation seen in hemochromatosis is a cysteine to tyrosine substitution at position 282 (C282Y) in the HFE gene.
HFE mutations are the most common cause of hereditary hemochromatosis and are inherited as an autosomal recessive trait.

Thalassemia minor does not result in iron overload. Secondary hemochromatosis or iron overload is characterized by the deposition of iron in parenchymal cells.

Solution to Question 4:
Serum ferritin > 1000 g/L is the strongest predictor of disease expression among individuals homozygous for the C282Y mutation.
Many patients with C282Y mutations are initially asymptomatic and do not show features of iron overload. In such patients, serum ferritin can indicate whether they are likely to develop the disease as ferritin levels reflect the total iron stores.
As ferritin levels may be high following inflammatory conditions, combined measurement of ferritin and transferrin saturation is done in a practical setting to avoid false positives. It is also repeated once inflammation subsides. If these tests are abnormal, genetic testing for HFE mutations is done.
Solution to Question 5:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. The treatment of choice is the removal of excess iron by phlebotomy.
Phlebotomy is an inexpensive, convenient, and safe method of treatment. In this process, 500 mL of blood is removed 1-2 times weekly which removes 200-250 mg of iron. Weekly phlebotomy should be continued until the serum ferritin level is 100 g/L and every 3 months thereafter. It is contraindicated in severe anemia and hypoproteinemia.
Chelating agents bind to iron to form complexes that get excreted and are the drugs of choice. Drugs such as deferoxamine and deferasirox are commonly used. However, they are less effective
and more expensive than phlebotomy.
Liver transplantation is indicated either in end-stage liver disease or in refractory cases. Supportive management includes avoiding iron-containing substances such as red meat,
multi-vitamin tablets, etc. Alcohol should be completely avoided as it can aggravate the disease.
Solution to Question 6:
In hemochromatosis, removal of excess iron through phlebotomy has no effect on arthropathy and hypogonadism.
Solution to Question 7:
Wilson’s disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene on Chr.13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions:
Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin
Helps excrete free copper in bile.
Thus, an ATP7B deficiency leads to excess deposition of free copper within tissues. It is an autosomal recessive condition. So, siblings of affected children have a 1 in 4 chance.
Intracellular trafficking of ATP7B (Wilson's disease) and ATP7A (Menke's disease) genes are regulated by an adaptor protein encoded by the AP1S1 gene. Mutations in this gene result in a syndrome with features of both Wilson's and Menke's diseases. It is called MEDNIK syndrome:
Mental retardation
Enteropathy
Deafness
Neuropathy
Ichthyosis
Keratodermia.
Solution to Question 8:
Among the given options only statements 1 and 5 are true.
Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings are seen in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological involvement. It initially appears as a crescent in the superior pole of Descemet's membrane and gradually extends inferiorly, eventually becoming circumferential in shape.
KF rings occur due to copper deposition in the descemet's membrane. It is golden-brown to greenish-brown in color and can be best seen by slit-lamp examination.
The image below shows a KF ring :

While it is a characteristic sign of Wilson’s disease (statement 2), it can also be seen in:
Primary biliary cholangitis
Primary sclerosing cholangitis
Cholestasis
KF rings are present in almost 95% of patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms compared to around 65% of those with hepatic presentations (statement 4).
They disappear on treatment with copper-chelating agents like d-penicillamine (while desferrioxamine is an iron chelating agent) and reappear with disease progression (statement 3).
Solution to Question 9:
The presence of the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring in Wilson's disease is most commonly associated with neuropsychiatric manifestations such as dystonia.
In majority of the cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations follow hepatic manifestations. It is due to the deposition of free copper in the basal ganglia (leading to bilateral degeneration and atrophy) and cortex. The features include:
Dysarthria (most common): Irregular word spacing, hypophonic or spastic speech
Dystonia: Vacuous smile i.e mask-like face with an open mouth
Parkinsonism: Bradykinesia, postural instability, rigidity
Subcortical dementia: Slow mental processing, memory loss
Psychiatric symptoms: Loss of emotional control, depression, hyperactivity
Decreased scholastic performance: Deterioration in handwriting, clumsiness
Autonomic symptoms: Excessive sweating and salivation, sexual dysfunction
Wing beating tremors (seen in advanced disease): High amplitude tremor that is prominent with arms abducted, elbows flexed and palms facing downward.

Option B: Acute viral hepatitis presents with positive HbsAg, whereas anti-Hbs IgG indicates past infection. There is tender hepatomegaly with very high levels of transaminases (>1000 IU/L).
Option C: Primary biliary cirrhosis presents with jaundice, severe itching, and pale stools. There are high levels of direct bilirubin, ALP, and positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies.

Solution to Question 12:
The following findings will be seen in a patient with Wilson's disease:
Decreased total serum copper
Decreased serum ceruloplasmin
Increased urinary copper
Normally, >90% of copper exists in bound form and <10% in free form. In Wilson’s disease, despite elevated levels of free copper, the marked reduction in ceruloplasmin results in a net reduction of total serum copper i.e.,
total serum copper =free copper + ceruloplasmin

Solution to Question 13:
This clinical scenario and image showing Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring with sunflower cataract are suggestive of Wilson's disease. The gold standard for diagnosis is the estimation of liver
copper following biopsy.
A copper level of >200 g/g dry liver tissue is diagnostic for Wilson's disease. It is measured using neutron activation analysis or atomic absorption spectrometry.
Sunflower cataract is a rare finding of Wilson’s disease. It occurs due to the deposition of copper in the center of the lens.
Solution to Question 14:
In Wilson’s disease, liver biopsy samples are stained using rubeanic acid to visualize the cytoplasmic copper.
Another stain used for copper is the rhodanine stain. However, copper staining is not reliable for diagnosis and a quantitative copper assay must be performed.
The given image shows the staining of copper by rubeanic acid.

Solution to Question 15:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Wilson's disease with predominantly neurological features. The safest drug that can be initiated for this patient is trientine. This is because D-penicillamine can worsen neurological symptoms and would not be tolerated by this patient.
The copper chelating agents, D-penicillamine and trientine are the first-line drugs in the management of Wilson's disease. D-penicillamine is the recommended drug due to its availability and cost-effectiveness compared to trientine.
However, D-penicillamine can precipitate various adverse effects including aplastic anemia, myasthenia gravis and membranous nephropathy. It can also worsen neurological symptoms. Hence, trientine is administered in those who cannot tolerate D-penicillamine.
Elemental zinc is commonly used as a maintenance therapy along with chelating agents. It can also be used as first-line therapy in pregnancy.
Tetrathiomolybdate is currently under phase 2 clinical trials. It has been identified to be effective in patients with neuropsychiatric manifestations but is not approved for clinical use.
Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment for advanced liver disease.
Solution to Question 16:
Penicillamine should always be co-administered with pyridoxine (25 mg/day) as it is an antagonist to pyridoxine.
Solution to Question 17:
ALT is not a part of Nazer’s prognostic index.
Nazer’s prognostic index is used to establish disease severity in Wilson’s disease patients who present with hepatic decompensation.
Solution to Question 18:
Low serum copper level attributed to the ATP7A gene is due to Menke's disease (Option C).
Menke's disease or Menke-Kinky hair syndrome is an X-linked recessive condition occurring due to a mutation in the ATP7A gene on chromosome X. This causes impaired transport of dietary copper from the small intestine to the liver leading to low levels of copper-containing enzymes. It presents within 3 years of age and is characterized by:
Depigmented kinky hair
Failure to thrive
Neurodegenerative symptoms like loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, epilepsyLoose, wrinkled skin
Multiple fractures
Poor visual acuity
Recurrent infections.
Lab investigations show low serum copper (<65 g/dL) and low ceruloplasmin(<20 mg/dl). The disease is fatal as it has no curative treatment. But, administration of L-histidine and copper chloride injections may be beneficial, if started early.
Aceruloplasminemia is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by tissue iron overload, mental deterioration, microcytic anemia, and low serum iron and copper concentrations.
Option B: Low serum copper and low ceruloplasmin is also seen in Wilson’s disease, but is associated with the gene defect ATP7B on chromosome 13. It is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism with features of hepatolenticular degeneration and Kayser Fleischer ring.
Option A: Dubin Johnson Syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired canalicular excretion of bilirubin due to mutation in MRP-2 protein leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
Option D: Gilbert’s Syndrome is characterized by decreased UDP glucuronyl transferase activity leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which can be autosomal recessive or dominant.

Spider telangiectasias are dilated arterioles with a prominent central arteriole with radiating vessels appearing in the shape of a spider. They are generally seen in the superior vena cava territory. Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after the release of pressure. They occur due to a hyperestrogenic state which is caused by defective estrogen metabolism in liver cirrhosis.

SAAG helps distinguish ascites caused by portal hypertension from other causes of ascites.
Solution to Question 7:
The likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario with serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) >1.1g/dL [calculated as serum albumin level - ascitic fluid albumin level, which in this case is 3-1=2g/dL] and ascitic fluid protein <2.5 g/dL is late Budd Chiari syndrome.
Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) can be used to differentiate between ascites due to portal hypertension and non-portal hypertensive ascites. It represents the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids and correlates with the hepatic venous pressure gradient.
It is given by the formula: SAAG = Serum albumin level - Ascitic fluid albumin level Interpretation of SAAG:
SAAG 1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.
In cases with high-SAAG (1.1), ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology:
2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites as in early Budd-Chiari syndrome.
<2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein as in late Budd-Chiari syndrome
Solution to Question 8:
Refractory ascites is defined as the inability to mobilize ascitic fluid despite:
Compliance with dietary sodium restriction
Administration of maximum doses of diuretics -
400mg of spironolactone per day and
160mg of furosemide per day
Solution to Question 9:
The diagnosis of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis(SBP) is made when the fluid sample has an absolute neutrophil count >250/L.
SBP is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. Infection with E.coli and other gut bacteria is most commonly seen. However, gram-positive bacteria like Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus sp., can also be
found. Abdominal paracentesis is the investigation of choice. It can be managed with antibiotic therapy.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario along with ANC  250 cells/l in ascitic fluid is suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). Daily antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended in patients who have had an episode of SBP to prevent a recurrence.
SBP is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. The most common causative organisms are E.coli and other gut bacteria. The diagnosis of SBP is made when the ascitic fluid has an absolute neutrophil count >250/l.
According to the latest recommendations, weekly antibiotic prophylaxis is no longer recommended. For patients with low protein ascites (<1.5 g/dL [15g/L]) along with either impaired renal function or liver failure, we use prolonged
outpatient trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (one double-strength tablet daily). Alternatives include ciprofloxacin 500 mg per day or norfloxacin 400 mg per day.
For patients on chronic trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole therapy, renal function should be monitored by checking serum electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine every one to six months depending on the stability of patient. If there is worsening renal function,
trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be discontinued.
Solution to Question 11:
The risk of bleeding in a patient with oesophageal varices cannot be predicted based on the number of varices present.
The factors that are used to predict the risk of variceal bleeding are:
Severity of cirrhosis (Child’s class, MELD score)
History of a previous variceal bleed
Location of the varices - varices with a thinner layer of supporting tissue are likely to bleed more
Size of the varices - larger varices have a higher risk of bleeding
Endoscopic appearance of varices - Presence of red wale sign, hematocystic spots, diffuse erythema, and cherry red spots are associated with increased risk of bleeding
Variceal pressure
Solution to Question 12:
Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is not recommended in hepatic encephalopathy as it can aggravate its symptoms.
TIPS creates a low-resistance channel between the hepatic vein and an intrahepatic branch of the portal vein. It uses a percutaneous approach under angiographic guidance. This reduces portal pressure.
It is used in the management of:
Oesophageal varices - in patients who fail medical or endoscopic management and have a poor surgical outcome
Refractory ascites
Gastric varices
Ectopic varices
Portal hypertensive gastropathy
Hepatorenal syndrome
Budd Chiari syndrome

Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing caput-medusae is suggestive of acute esophageal variceal bleeding due to portal hypertension. Upper GI endoscopy is performed within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation in variceal bleeding.
The management of esophageal variceal bleeding involves:
Resuscitation with IV fluids, airway protection, and oxygen
Blood transfusion to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL
Antibiotic prophylaxis with ceftriaxone before endoscopy
An attempt at hemostasis with octreotide or terlipressin or vasopressin
Upper GI endoscopy within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation to confirm the source of the bleed
Endoscopic variceal ligation of sclerotherapy
In case, of failure or rebleeding - TIPS
Nonselective beta-blockers like propranolol and nadolol are used in the prophylaxis of variceal bleeding.

Solution to Question 14:
The given image shows Sengstaken-Blakemore tube. Pressure in the oesophageal balloon should not exceed 45 mm Hg.
It is used for balloon tamponade in variceal hemorrhage when medical therapy fails or is not available. Initially, only the gastric balloon should be inflated, with 200– 250 mL of air, as this will usually control bleeding. The oesophageal balloon is used in continued bleeding, it should be deflated for about 5 minutes every 6 hours to avoid oesophageal mucosal damage.
Endotracheal intubation prior to tube insertion reduces the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

Solution to Question 15:
Gross disorientation with an intact response to pain and voice suggest grade 3 hepatic encephalopathy.
Hepatic encephalopathy is the alteration of mental status and cognitive function occurring in liver failure. This occurs due to the failure of removal of gut-derived neurotoxins like ammonia by liver. These neurotoxins enter the brain leading to the development of symptoms.
Solution to Question 16:
The earliest symptom of hepatic encephalopathy is an alteration in sleep pattern. Other signs and symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy include:
Asterixis also called the flapping tremor
Mood changes and inappropriate behavior
Disorientation and confusion
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy. Antibiotics are unlikely to precipitate hepatic encephalopathy.
The common precipitating factors of hepatic encephalopathy are :
Gastrointestinal bleeding
Infections like SBP or UTIs
Peritoneal tap
Constipation
Renal failure
Hypovolemia
Hypoxia
Drugs - sedatives, antidepressants, diuretics
Hypoglycemia
Hypokalemia
Solution to Question 18:
Rifaximin can be used in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy. It lowers blood ammonia levels.
Treatment of hepatic encephalopathy includes:
Correction of precipitating factors
Lactulose - decreased GI transit time due to cathartic actions leading to increased elimination of ammonia
Rifaximin - lowers the blood ammonia levels
L-ornithine L-aspartate - stimulate the urea cycle, with resulting loss of ammonia

The absence of shock is a part of the diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome.
Hepatorenal syndrome is a progressive renal failure in patients with acute or chronic liver disease.
The diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome include:
Cirrhosis with ascites
Diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI)
Increase in serum creatinine of  0.3mg/dL in 48 hours, OR

Solution to Question 20:
Among the given options, platypnea is most likely to be seen in patients with hepatopulmonary syndrome.
Hepatopulmonary syndrome is characterized by a triad of liver disease, hypoxemia, and intrapulmonary vascular dilatations. Most patients have dyspnea on exertion. The classic clinical manifestations are:
Platypnea - Increase in dyspnea when the patient moves from supine to upright position
Orthodeoxia - Decrease in arterial oxygen tension when the patient moves from supine to upright position
The hypoxemia is due to a ventilation-perfusion mismatch which causes an
increased alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient. The most sensitive test for diagnosis is contrast bubble echocardiography.
Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment of this condition following which the symptoms subside.
Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatorenal syndrome. The best treatment modality for it is liver transplantation.
Hepatorenal syndrome is characterised by a rise in:
AST
ALT
Total bilirubin
Serum creatinine
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN).
Management of hepatorenal syndrome include:
Norepinephrine
Octreotide
Terlipressin
Midodrine
Intravenous albumin
Liver transplantation- definitive treatment
Solution to Question 22:
Chronic Hepatitis B is not a MELD exception.
MELD (Model for End-stage Liver Disease) score is used to prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation. However, there are certain diseases that impair patient survival and are not accounted for in the MELD score. Patients with these diseases are given upgraded MELD points to accurately represent the mortality risk and these conditions are called MELD exceptions.
The MELD exceptions include:-
Portopulmonary hypertension
Hepatocellular carcinoma
Familial amyloid polyneuropathy
Primary hyperoxaluria (necessitating liver-kidney transplantation)
Cystic fibrosis with liver disease
Highly selected cases of hilar cholangiocarcinoma.
Hepatopulmonary syndrome
Hepatic artery thrombosis 7–14 days post-liver transplantation.
Solution to Question 23:
The Child Turcotte Pugh (CTP) score does not include creatinine. The components of the CTP score are:
Albumin
Bilirubin
International normalized ratio (INR)
Ascites
Encephalopathy
The Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD 3.0) is used to prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation and includes:
Female sex
Bilirubin
Albumin
Serum sodium (mEq/L)
INR (International Normalized ratio)
Creatinine
Solution to Question 24:
The given patient belongs to Child-Turcotte-Pugh class B. The score can be calculated as follows:
Serum bilirubin-2.5mg/dl: 2
Serum albumin-3g/dl: 2
Prothrombin time-5 seconds or INR-2: 2 No encephalopathy: 1
Mild ascites: 2
Therefore, the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score is (2+2+2+1+2)= 9 which is included in Class B.
