Solution to Question 1:
Restitution is an epithelial mucosal defense mechanism. It is the process by which healthy surface epithelial cells from the adjoining areas migrate to restore a damaged region of the gastric mucosa.
The gastric mucosa has well-established mucosal defense mechanisms against various assaults like HCl, pepsin, alcohol, etc. These include:
Pre-epithelial defense: A layer of mucous over the surface epithelium. This is secreted by the surface epithelium and contains HCO3- which maintains neutral pH at the cell surface
Epithelial defense: It is constituted by the surface epithelial cells and their intercellular tight junctions that perform the following functions
Act as a physical barrier
Restitution is the migration of healthy cells to damaged areas
Rapid renewal of surface epithelial layer
Generating factors that prevent cellular damage such as heat shock proteins
Sub-epithelial defense:
Rich microvascular bed of the gastric submucosa that provides HCO3- and washes away the toxic metabolites.
Alkaline tide- It is caused by the release of HCO3- into the gastric capillaries by the parietal cells. This HCO3- helps in the quick neutralization of HCl.
Solution to Question 2:
The NSAIDs impair the mucosal defense mechanism primarily by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.
NSAIDs also decrease nitric oxide synthesis and have an irritant effect on the gastric mucosa but inhibition of COX enzymes/ prostaglandin synthesis is the most prominent factor.
Almost all the mucosal defense mechanisms are primarily mediated by prostaglandins synthesized by the gastric mucosal cells. Apart from the prostaglandins, the other factors that play a role in mucosal defense include:
Nitric oxide (NO)- Causes vasodilation thereby increasing the mucosal blood flow.
Several growth factors like EGF, TGF, FGF- Play a role in epithelial regeneration and restitution.
Solution to Question 3:
Concomitant use of glucocorticoids with NSAIDs increases the risk of peptic ulcer disease. Other risks factors for NSAID-induced PUD include:
H pylori infection
Serious or multisystem disease
Alcohol and smoking
Concomitant use of the following drugs with NSAIDs increases the risk of PUD and its complications:
Glucocorticoids
Anticoagulants
Clopidogre
Multiple NSAIDs
PUD may occur even with low doses of NSAIDs. No dose of NSAIDs is considered completely safe.
Solution to Question 4:
Antral predominant gastritis is associated with duodenal ulcers. Antral predominant gastritis is associated with increased acid production by the parietal cells. This subjects the duodenum to increased acid exposure, leading to the formation of duodenal ulcers.
H. pylori infection may result in the following patterns of gastritis:
Non-atrophic pangastritis- mostly asymptomatic and sometimes associated with MALToma.
Corpus predominant gastritis- affects the corpus and causes atrophy. This leads to the loss of acid-producing parietal cells that are primarily found in the corpus. Hence, it is associated with decreased acid production. This is also a predisposing factor for the development of gastric cancer.
Antral predominant gastritis- spares the parietal cells. Hence, it is associated with increased acid production.
Option A: Autoimmune gastritis is caused due to autoantibodies against the parietal cells. It is not associated with H. pylori.
Option C: Granulomatous gastritis is characterized by the presence of granulomas It is associated with Crohn's disease and sarcoidosis.
Solution to Question 5:
Epigastric pain with a burning sensation that usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food suggestive of duodenal ulcer.
The following patterns of pain are usually seen in peptic ulcer disease:
Duodenal Ulcer- Pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Pain may awaken the patient from sleep.
Gastric Ulcer- Pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common.
Perforated ulcer- The bed of the ulcer tunnels through the entire thickness of the gastric wall and opens into the peritoneum. This presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and leads to peritonitis. Radiography shows gas under the diaphragm.
Penetrating ulcer- It is a type of perforation where the ulcer tunnels into an adjacent organ like the pancreas/liver. In this case, the pain is no longer relieved by food or antacids and might radiate to the back.
Many patients with peptic ulcers, especially elderly patients, may not have these symptoms and may directly present with a complication like bleeding or perforation.
Solution to Question 6:
Gastric ulcers are associated with low basal acid production and low stimulated acid production. Gastric acid secretion occurs in two patterns:
Basal acid output- Occurs in a circadian pattern. It is mediated by ACh from the vagus and histamine.
Stimulated acid production- Occurs in response to food. It is mediated by gastrin in addition to other factors.

Solution to Question 7:
H.pylori produces vacuolating exotoxin (Vac A) which causes gastric mucosal injury. Vac A inhibits CD4+ T-cells and disrupts the function of B cells, macrophages & mast cells.
Cag A positive strains of H pylori cause an increased risk of gastric cancer.
Solution to Question 8:
Erythromycin is not effective in H pylori eradication. Note:
Vonoprazan, a potassium-competitive acid blocker, has been recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of peptic acid-related disorders.
Solution to Question 9:
The need for H pylori eradication therapy in patients with GERD on long-term PPIs is not well established and is controversial.
H pylori eradication therapy is offered to patients diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease (PUD) as it greatly decreases the recurrence of ulcers. In addition to this, it should also be offered to patients at increased risk of PUD and gastric cancer such as:
Patients with long-term NSAIDs usage. Eg. Rheumatoid arthritis
Patients taking gastric acid inhibitors for >1 year
Patients with increased exposure to risk factors of gastric cancers. Eg. heavy smokers, exposure to dust, coa
Patients with previous history/family history of gastric neoplasm
Solution to Question 10:
Eradication of H. pylori infection can be determined by a urea breath test. A stool antigen test can also be employed.
Solution to Question 11:
H.pylori increases the risk of gastric MALT lymphoma. H.pylori is protective against the following:
GERD
Barrett's esophagus
Adenocarcinoma of esophagus
Adenocarcinoma of the cardia of the stomach
H. pylori are inversely related to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and its sequelae, which include Barrett's esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma.
H.pylori strains positive for Cag A may be particularly protective against the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma. Thus, colonization with H. pylori, particularly Cag A strains, may be protective against the more severe forms of GERD.
Eradication of H. pylori is associated with mild worsening of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in patients with corpus-dominant or pangastritis. It improves symptoms in those with antral-dominant gastritis.
Solution to Question 12:
GI bleeding is the most common complication of peptic ulcer disease. Other complications:
Perforation- second most common
Gastrocolic fistulas
Gastric outlet obstruction
Rarely malignancy
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical features indicating hypercalcemia and investigations showing renal insufficiency, metabolic alkalosis are suggestive of milk-alkali syndrome. Long-term use of calcium carbonate can lead to this condition.
In susceptible individuals, there is a loss of negative feedback, leading to excess calcium absorption when there is excess intake. It results in the following triad of clinical features:
Hypercalcemia
Alkalosis- due to HCO3 reabsorption caused by PTH suppression, natriuresis, and water depletion
Renal failure- due to damage to renal tubules
It is reversible once ingestion of antacid is stopped. However, in severe cases, a chronic form called Burnett’s syndrome can develop. It is associated with irreversible renal damage.
Solution to Question 14:
The gastric ulcers associated with head trauma are Cushing ulcers. Head trauma leads to vagal stimulation which in turn leads to increased gastric acid production.
Option A: Curling ulcers are seen in severe burns.
Option C: Stress ulcers are seen in conditions like shock, sepsis, etc. They are thought to be caused by local ischemia and splanchnic vasoconstriction.
Option D: Refractory ulcers are those that do not heal even after adequate medical therapy.
Solution to Question 15:
A gastric ulcer is said to be refractory if it fails to heal after 12 weeks. A refractory duodenal ulcer is that which fails to heal after 8 weeks. Management of refractory PUD:
Rule out other diseases or causes
High dose PPI
Surgery
Solution to Question 16:
The given scenario of symptoms not improving with antacids, associated diarrhea, and the unusual location of ulcers are highly suggestive of Zollinger Ellison syndrome.
Zollinger Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a peptic ulcer disease caused by unregulated gastrin release from a neuroendocrine tumor/gastrinoma. About 60% of the tumors are malignant, hence, it is important to identify ZES.
The clinical presentation of ZES is very similar to that of peptic ulcer disease. The features which help in suspecting ZES include:
Unusual locations- the second part of the duodenum and beyond
Refractory to medical therapy
Recurrence after acid-reducing surgery
Presenting with complications like bleeding and perforation
Not associated with H. pylori or NSAID ingestion
Patients of ZES often have associated diarrhea and involvement of the esophagus (esophagitis,
ulceration, or stricture).
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Zollinger Ellison syndrome (ZES). The next appropriate step to evaluate the patients for ZES is by measuring the serum gastrin levels. History of hyperparathyroidism and transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection indicates MEN1 syndrome. ZES is commonly associated with MEN1.
The normal gastrin levels are <150 pg/mL. An increase of >10 times the normal levels is highly suggestive of ZES.
Secretin test is a gastrin provocative test. It is done when the gastrin levels and the acid secretory studies are inconclusive for ZES. It is the most sensitive and specific gastrin provocative test for the diagnosis of gastrinoma.
Endoscopic ultrasound is done to localize the tumor. It is done after the diagnosis of ZES has been established.
Solution to Question 18:
OctreoScan detects gastrinomas using their property of uptake of somatostatin analogues.
OctreoScan detects endocrine tumors that express receptors for somatostatin in conditions such as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) and multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes.
Other modalities used for localizing the tumor in ZES include:
Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)
PET/CT with Ga-DOTATATE is the investigation of choice when available.
Note: PET/CT with Ga-DOTATATE is the gold-standard test for localizing tumors in pheochromocytoma.

Viruses that cause infectious gastritis in immunocompromised individuals include cytomegalovirus and Herpes simplex virus.
Solution to Question 20:
The given peripheral smear findings and serology are suggestive of pernicious anemia. It is usually seen in type A gastritis.
Type A autoimmune gastritis is caused by circulating antibodies against the parietal cells. The destruction of parietal cells leads to the deficiency of intrinsic factor that is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12. The resulting B12 deficiency causes pernicious anemia.
Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical scenario along with her endoscopy findings are suggestive of phlegmonous gastritis. It is caused due to E.coli.
Phlegmonous gastritis is a potentially life-threatening disorder characterized by marked and diffuse acute inflammatory infiltrates of the entire gastric wall accompanied by necrosis. It usually affects the immunocompromised and elderly individuals.
Organisms associated with phlegmonous gastritis are:
E.coli
Streptococci
Staphylococci
Proteus
Haemophilus species
Other uncommon forms of gastritis are:
Eosinophilic gastritis: Presents as intestinal obstruction
Russel’s body gastritis: Pseudotumor on endoscopy
Granulomatous gastritis is seen in Crohn’s disease
Lymphocytic gastritis is seen in celiac disease

Solution to Question 1:
The above scenario is suggestive of steatorrhoea, which is seen in short bowel syndrome.
Steatorrhoea is defined as excess fat in stools (>7g/day) due to poor absorption of lipids. It is characterized by stools are bulky, pale, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush.
Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a malabsorption disorder caused by a lack of functional small intestine. It can lead to the typical features of malabsorption such as abdominal pain, diarrhoea, steatorrhoea, weight loss and anaemia.
Option B: Primary lactase deficiency leads to defective absorption of lactose. It does not affect lipid absorption.
Option C: Pernicious anemia is due to an absence of gastric parietal cell-intrinsic factor which is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12.
Option D: Wilson's disease is associated with increased absorption of copper and is not a part of malabsorption syndrome.
Solution to Question 2:
Yogurt is the least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance. It contains lactobacillus that produces lactase and is generally well tolerated.
Lactase is a brush border enzyme that hydrolyzes lactose into glucose and galactose. In lactase deficiency, patients have great variability in clinical symptoms, depending on both the severity of lactase deficiency and the amount of lactose ingested.
The goal of treatment in patients with isolated lactase deficiency is achieving patient comfort through the elimination of dietary lactose.
Foods that are high in lactose include milk (12 g/cup), ice cream (9 g/cup), and cottage cheese (8 g/cup). Aged cheese has lower lactose content. Most people can tolerate up to 12g of lactose a day
without significant symptoms.
Solution to Question 3:
Rapid small-intestinal transit time increases the symptoms of lactose intolerance. Lactose intolerance can be due to:
Primary lactase deficiency- a genetically determined deficiency or absence of lactase enzyme
Secondary lactase deficiency- due to small intestinal mucosal diseases such as celiac disease Factors affecting symptoms of lactose intolerance:
Amount of lactose in the diet.
Rate of gastric emptying- symptoms are more likely when gastric emptying is rapid
(post-gastrectomy and skimmed milk intake).
Small intestinal transit time- more rapid small intestinal transit time makes symptoms more likely.
Antibiotic use- results in decreased colonic microflora which in turn decreases the production of easily absorbed short-chain fatty acids from non-absorbed lactose. This can worsen the symptoms.
Solution to Question 4:
Small bowel diarrhea is associated with steatorrhea, not large bowel diarrhea. Tenesmus refers to the constant urge to defecate with little or no stool passed.

Solution to Question 6:
The most likely diagnosis is factitious diarrhea.
Factitious diarrhoea is a form of Münchausen's syndrome. In patients with diarrhea, stool osmolality is always >290-300 mOsm/kg H2O. A stool osmolality of <290 mOsm/kg H2O is suggestive of dilution with urine or water to the sample, by the patient. In this case stool osmolality can be lower than plasma osmolality (<250 mOsm/kg) or very high (>400 mOsm/kg) due to purposeful dilution with hypotonic/concentrated solute by the patient to the stool sample.
The stool osmolar gap is used to differentiate between osmotic and secretory diarrhea. A gap of:
<50 suggests secretory diarrhoea
>100 suggests osmotic diarrhoea
Stool osmolar gap = measured osmolality - calculated osmolality

Solution to Question 1:
Persistent diarrhoea after a 48-hour fast is not a diagnostic criteria for IBS.
Solution to Question 2:
The most common pattern in IBS patients is constipation alternating with episodes of diarrhoea. Based on bowel movement patterns, IBS is classified as:
IBS-C: Irritable bowel syndrome-constipation predominant
IBS-D: Irritable bowel syndrome-diarrhoea predominant
IBS-M: Irritable bowel syndrome-mixed
The majority of patients change subtypes over the course of illness.
Note: Abdominal pain is a pre-requisite for the diagnosis of IBS. This means that for the diagnosis of IBS, recurrent abdominal pain must be present.
Solution to Question 3:
The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
Features in favour of IBS:
Abdominal pain that improves/worsens with defecation
Association with stress or emotional symptoms
Small volume of stools Features not in favour of IBS:
Onset of symptoms in old age
Presence of fever and weight loss
Persistent diarrhoea after a 48h fast
Nocturnal diarrhoea
Steatorrhoea
Solution to Question 4:
Decreased colonic motor potentials are not implicated in the pathogenesis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). On the contrary, increased colonic motor potentials are seen.
The pathogenesis of IBS is poorly understood. However, the following have been implicated in its pathogenesis:
Increased colonic motor potentials lead to increased high-amplitude propagating contractions
(HAPCs) which causes diarrhea.
Visceral hypersensitivity leads to exaggerated sensory responses to visceral stimulation by food. This explains the postprandial symptoms in IBS.
CNS dysregulation - dysfunctional activation of the mid-cingulate cortex and prefrontal lobes eads to increased perception of visceral pain.
Abnormal serotonin pathways - serotonin-containing enterochromaffin cells are increased in IBS patients.
Altered gut flora
Solution to Question 5:
Serotonin is associated with irritable bowel syndrome diarrhoea type (IBS-D).
Abnormal serotonin pathways is one of the causes for symptoms in IBS. The serotonin containing enterochromaffin cells are increased in a subset of IBS-D patients. This provides a rationale for the use of serotonin antagonists in the treatment of this condition.
Solution to Question 6:
Mid cingulate cortex and prefrontal lobe are associated with IBS.
Mid cingulate cortex: Modulation of this region is associated with changes in the subjective unpleasantness of pain.
Prefrontal lobe: Dysfunction of this area leads to the increased perception of visceral pain.
Solution to Question 7:
Male gender is not a risk factor for post-infectious IBS.
Post-infectious IBS develops following a gastrointestinal infection with microbes such as Campylobacter, Salmonella and Shigella.
Risk factors for developing post-infectious IBS:
Young age and female gender
Prolonged duration of illness
Toxicity of infecting bacterial strain
Smoking
Depression
Hypochondriasis
Solution to Question 8:
A stool fat test is not recommended in a suspected case of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
IBS is a clinical diagnosis that can be made without performing many tests if the patient presents with typical symptoms. However, it is recommended to perform the following tests in most patients to rule out other conditions:
Complete blood count
Sigmoidoscopic examination
Stool examination for ova and parasites

Solution to Question 9:
Fecal lactoferrin is the marker of IBD that is used to rule out irritable bowel syndrome. Fecal lactoferrin is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation.
Fecal calprotectin is another marker of IBD and it is used to rule out irritable bowel syndrome and bacterial overgrowth. It correlates well with histologic inflammation, predicts relapses, and detects pouchitis.
Option A: Fecal fat is normally digested by pancreatic lipase and absorbed from the jejunum. In disorders of exocrine pancreatic function, fat absorption decreases, resulting in steatorrhea and increased fecal fat.
Options C & D: Fecal trypsin, chymotrypsin are pancreatic enzymes, therefore a decrease in fecal levels below normal suggests a disorder of the exocrine pancreas.
Solution to Question 10:
FODMAPs are poorly absorbed in the small intestine.
FODMAPs stands for Fermentable Oligosaccharides, Disaccharides, Monosaccharides, And Polyols. Foodstuff containing lactose, fructose, and sorbitol are some examples of FODMAPs.
Since FODMAPs are poorly absorbed, they are fermented by gut bacteria in the colon to produce gas and osmotically active carbohydrates. So, a diet low in FODMAPs is recommended to reduce symptoms in IBS patients.
Solution to Question 11:
Lubiprostone is used in the treatment of constipation-predominant IBS.
Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator that promotes the secretion of water and chloride into the bowel and improves bowel movements.
Loperamide, alosetron, and eluxadoline (opioid mu receptor agonist) are used in the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS.
Solution to Question 12:
Paroxetine is most effective in treating constipation. It is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor
(SSRI) that accelerates oro-caecal transit.
Note: Citalopram is an SSRI that is effective in the management of pain in IBS. It blunts perception of rectal distension and reduces the magnitude of gastrocolic reflex.
Solution to Question 13:
Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist used in the treatment of IBS–D.
Options B and C: Tegaserod and lubiprostone are used in the treatment of constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (IBS–C).
Option D: Ondansetron is used in the treatment of nausea and vomiting.
Solution to Question 14:
Ischaemic colitis is a side-effect of alosetron.
Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that is used to reduce diarrhoea in irritable bowel syndrome.
Option A: Lubiprostone is associated with nausea and diarrhea. Option B: Linaclotide is associated with diarrhea.
Option D: Tegaserod is associated with cardiac toxicity.
Solution to Question 15:
The best time to take antispasmodics for postprandial pain is 30 min before meals.
Antispasmodics such as dicyclomine inhibit the gastrocolic reflex and thus reduce pain due to intestinal spasms. It is best taken 30 min before meals so that the effective blood levels are achieved shortly before the anticipated onset of pain.

Solution to Question 1:
The gene associated with Crohn's disease is the NOD2 gene. Št is present on chromosome 16.
Nucleotide-binding oligomeri˜ation domain 2 (NOD2) acts as a cytoplasmic sensor of microbial products. Defective NOD2 gene results in defective innate immunity. When the innate immunity is unable to clear the bacteria, there is an exaggerated response of the immune system (T-cells) resulting in damage to the host tissue.
Option B: JAK2 mutation is associated with polycythemia vera.
Option C: BRAF V600E mutation is associated with melanoma, papillary thyroid cancer, and serous ovarian cancers.
Option D: STAT‚ mutations are associated with the autosomal dominant hyper-ŠgE syndrome.
Solution to Question 2:
Klinefelter syndrome is not commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease (ŠBD).
The genetic disorders associated with ŠBD are:
Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
Šmmunodysregulation polyendocrinopathy enteropathy Ž-linked (Š‰EŽ) syndrome
Turner's syndrome
Hermansky-‰udlak syndrome
Glycogen storage disease
Solution to Question 3:
Appendectomy is protective against ulcerative colitis.
Smoking is also seen to have a protective effect on ulcerative colitis but it is a risk factor for developing Crohn's disease.
Solution to Question 4:
Early-onset ŠBD is due to ŠL-10 receptor dysfunction and ŠL-10 deficiency. They are associated with severe refractory ŠBD in early life.
Solution to Question 5:
Š‰EŽ (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, and Ž-linked) syndrome is caused by mutations in the FOŽ‰‚ gene, which leads to a deficiency of T-regulatory cells, resulting in immune dysfunction.
Š‰EŽ is associated with:
çlcerative colitis-like autoimmune enteropathy
Neonatal type 1 DM
Thyroiditis
Dermatitis
Solution to Question 6:
Campylobacter enteritis should be ruled out before diagnosing a patient with ŠBD.
Campylobacter enteritis can mimic the clinical presentation and biopsy appearance of ulcerative colitis or Crohn’s disease (ŠBD). Hence, it should be ruled out, especially in persons with a history of:
Foreign trave
Significant animal contact
Šmmunodeficiency
Exposure incurring a high risk of transmission.
Št can also cause a relapse of established ulcerative colitis.
A definitive diagnosis of campylobacter infection can be made by culture or real-time ‰CR.
Solution to Question 7:
Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) positivity is a feature of ulcerative colitis.
ASCA (anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody), anti-pancreatic antibody, and anti-flagellin antibody positivity are seen in Crohn's disease.

Solution to Question 8:
The most commonly affected site in Crohn's disease is the terminal ileum.
Other commonly affected sites in Crohn's disease include the small intestine and the
colon. Although it can affect any part of the GŠ tract from mouth to anus, the rectum is usually spared.
On the other hand, the rectum is almost always involved in ulcerative colitis.
Solution to Question 9:
The above specimen of the small bowel shows creeping fat which is a feature of Crohn's disease (CD).
Mesenteric fat is normally seen along the longitudinal axis of the intestine. However, in Crohn's disease, excessive fibrofatty proliferation results in mesenteric fat wrapping around the inflamed bowel. This is called creeping fat.
Strictures and fistulae are the commonly associated complications of long-standing Crohn's disease. Strictures can cause bowel obstruction.
Other gross features seen in Crohn's disease are:
Transmural inflammation- full-thickness inflammation involving all the layers of the bowe
Aphthous ulcers- small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
Longitudinal ulcers- linear or serpiginous deep ulcers
Skip lesions- involvement of discontinuous segments of the bowel with intervening norma mucosa
Cobblestone appearance- deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
The image below shows cobblestone appearance in Crohn's disease.

The clinical presentation along with the endoscopy image showing a cobblestone appearance are suggestive of Crohn's disease (CD).

The above scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as jejunoileitis. This is evidenced by the presence of features of malabsorption such as steatorrhea, chronic diarrhea, and vitamin B12 deficiency anemia.
The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome.
The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.
Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, it is a protective factor in ulcerative colitis.

Solution to Question 15:
Aphthous ulcers seen in Crohn's disease are the earliest radiological signs on small bowel follow-through study.
They are shallow ulcers that are often multiple and separated by normal intervening mucosa. They are also the earliest macroscopic findings of Crohn's disease.
Features on barium small bowel follow-through in Crohn's disease include:
Mucosal ulcers:
Aphthous ulcers initially
Deep ulcers (more than ‚ mm depth)
Longitudinal fissures
Transverse stripes
Severe mucosal ulcers lead to cobblestone appearance

String sign of Kantor: tubular narrowing due to spasm or stricture depending on the chronicity
Rose thorn appearance
‰artial obstruction.
CT and MR enterography have a higher sensitivity for the diagnosis of Crohn’s disease. They may reveal additional features such as:
Fat halo sign - submucosal fat deposition
Comb sign - engorgement of the vasa recta.
Šn gastric Crohn's disease, conical narrowing of the antrum may be seen. This is called Ram’s horn sign.

Solution to Question 16:
The earliest radiological change of ulcerative colitis seen on barium enema is fine mucosal granularity.
Double-contrast barium enema allows for exquisite detail of the colonic mucosa and also allows the bowel proximal to strictures to be assessed. Št is however contraindicated if acute severe colitis is present due to the risk of perforation.

Option A: Collar button ulcers are small deep ulcers in which the button surface corresponds to the eroded ulcer base and the button neck corresponds to the undermined and preserved mucosa. They are also seen in ulcerative colitis.
Option C: String sign represents circumferential inflammation and fibrosis, resulting in long segments of luminal narrowing as shown below. Št is more characteristic of Crohn's disease.

Option D: Ram's horn sign is seen in gastric Crohn's disease.
Solution to Question 17:
‰seudopolyps are seen in ulcerative colitis. They are formed due to alternating inflammation and regeneration of the ulcerated mucosal epithelium in ulcerative colitis.
Other gross findings in ulcerative colitis include:
Continuous mucosal inflammation of the colon most commonly involving the rectum
Fine mucosal granularity
Collar button ulcers
‰seudopolyps.
Rose thorn appearance, skip lesions, and pseudodiverticula are features of Crohn's disease.
Solution to Question 18:

Solution to Question 19:
Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. Št is seen in Crohn’s disease.
Hemorrhage, malignant change, and toxic megacolon are complications of ulcerative colitis.
Note: Stricture formation may be a complication of ulcerative colitis, but it is seen only in š-10% of patients. They are more commonly seen in Crohn's disease.

Solution to Question 1:
The given image shows pyoderma gangrenosum. It is very difficult to treat and often requires IV antibiotics and IV glucocorticoids. Other drugs used in its management include dapsone, cyclosporine, and infliximab.
Pyoderma gangrenosum is a dermatological extraintestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease. It begins as a pustule and progresses to an ulcer with necrotic tissue and exudates. It may occur years before the onset of bowel symptoms and is usually associated with severe disease.
Lesions are commonly found on the dorsal surface of the feet and legs but may occur on the arms, chest, and even the face. It responds poorly to colectomy and may even develop years after the surgery.
Other dermatological manifestations associated with IBD include:
Erythema nodosum
Sweet syndrome (neutrophilic dermatosis)
Perianal skin tags
Psoriasis
Metastatic Crohn's disease (cutaneous granulomas).
Solution to Question 2:
The given urinary crystal is the bipyramidal or envelope-shaped crystals of calcium oxalate dihydrate. Calcium oxalate stones are more commonly associated with Crohn's disease.
In Crohn's disease (especially post small bowel resection), fatty acids are not absorbed because of ileal dysfunction. These fatty acids in the gut lumen bind to calcium. Because of this, the dietary oxalates which normally bind to the calcium are now left unbound. This leads to increased absorption of dietary oxalates leading to hyperoxaluria and oxalate stones.
Note: Celiac disease is also associated with calcium oxalate stones.
Solution to Question 3:
The above image shows a large hemorrhoidal perianal skin tag. These are found in patients with Crohn's disease, especially those with colon involvement.
Solution to Question 4:
The clinical scenario and radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. It is seen in severe ulcerative colitis.
Abdominal radiography in toxic megacolon shows transverse or right colonic dilation >6 cm and loss of haustrations.
Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension or features of sepsis.
Solution to Question 5:
Uveitis is the most common cause of the given symptoms in a patient with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
Uveitis is an ophthalmic manifestation of IBD. It is associated with both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It can develop during remission and is seen even after bowel resection. Prompt intervention with glucocorticoids is required to prevent scarring and visual impairment.
The other common ophthalmic manifestations in IBD are conjunctivitis and episcleritis. Episcleritis, more common in Crohn's, is a benign disorder presenting with mild ocular burning.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of erythema nodosum seen in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
Erythema nodosum is a dermatologic manifestation of IBD. It is seen in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It manifests as tender erythematous nodules on the anterior surface of the lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms.
Option A: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a dermatological manifestation of IBD. It begins as pustular lesions which then ulcerate with necrotic foci and exudation.

Option C: Sweet’s syndrome is acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in ulcerative colitis.

Option D: Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, often seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents as pustules/vesicles which progress to necrotic ulcers.

Solution to Question 7:
The cardiopulmonary manifestations of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) are:
Endocarditis
Myocarditis
Pleuropericarditis
Interstitial lung disease
Both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease have an increased risk of venous and arterial thrombosis.
Solution to Question 8:
The above clinical scenario along with MRCP showing multiple areas of intrahepatic narrowing with alternating areas of normal and dilated segments of bile ducts is suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis. PSC is more common in ulcerative colitis than in Crohn's disease.
Additionally, recurrent episodes of bloody diarrhea with weight loss seen in this patient also point toward a possible diagnosis of ulcerative colitis.
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is an extraintestinal manifestation of IBD characterized by intrahepatic and extrahepatic duct inflammation/fibrosis. Around 50-75% of patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) have inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) whereas, only 5% of IBD cases develop PSC.
Option A: Chronic pancreatitis is associated with a chain of lakes appearance- dilated main duct with clubbing and dilatation of the side branches. Patients can present with steatorrhoea i.e., the passage of offensive-smelling large stools due to fat malabsorption.
The image below shows chain of lakes appearance on MRI:

Option B: Celiac disease may be associated with primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), rather than primary sclerosing cholangitis.
Solution to Question 9:
Arthritis worsens with exacerbation of bowel disease and improves with the treatment of bowel symptoms or surgery.
Ankylosing spondylitis, uveitis, and pyoderma gangrenosum do not correlate with disease activity in the bowel. They may occur during the remission of disease or even after surgery.

The above scenario is suggestive of mild ulcerative colitis. The preferred drug for mild ulcerative colitis (UC) is 5-ASA agents (5-aminosalicylic acid).

Patients with Crohn's disease on infliximab are at increased risk of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) and hepatosplenic T-cell lymphoma (HS-TCL).
Infliximab is the first biologic therapy approved for Crohn's disease. It is an IgG1 antibody against TNF-alpha.

Solution to Question 14:
Ustekinumab has no role in rheumatoid arthritis. It is effective against both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.
It can also be used in the management of plaque psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. It is an IgG1 monoclonal antibody that blocks the activity of IL-12 and IL-23.

Note: Mirikizumab (an IL-23 inhibitor) was recently FDA approved for the treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It reduces stool frequency, rectal bleeding and bowel urgency.
Solution to Question 15:
Glucocorticoids play no role in maintenance therapy in inflammatory bowel disease.
They are used for induction in Crohn's disease and moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. Once clinical remission has been induced, they should be tapered gradually.
Solution to Question 16:
The above scenario is suggestive of pancreatitis. Azathioprine causes pancreatitis in some patients within the first few weeks of therapy. It is completely reversible on discontinuing the drug.
Azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine (purine analogues) also have an increased risk of toxicity as some individuals may lack the enzyme necessary for their metabolism. This may lead to hepatitis, bone marrow suppression, etc. Hence, the patient should be monitored regularly with blood counts and liver function tests.
Solution to Question 17:
Nutritional therapy is used for inducing remission in Crohn's disease.
Dietary antigens may stimulate an immune response. Hence, nutritional therapies like total parenteral nutrition, enteral nutrition (peptide-based preparations), etc. can be used to provide bowel rest in active Crohn's disease. These interventions cannot be used for maintaining remission.
Ulcerative colitis does not respond to dietary intervention. Drugs used in treatment of Crohn’s disease:
Oral budesonide (mainly for mild to moderate)
Oral prednisolone
Methotrexate
Anti TNF alpha

Solution to Question 18:
The treatment of choice in refractory ulcerative colitis (UC) is mucosal proctectomy with ileal pouch–anal anastomosis (IPAA).
As ulcerative colitis is a mucosal disease, the rectal mucosa is dissected and removed down to the dentate line of the anus. The ileum is made into a pouch that serves as neorectum.

Solution to Question 1:
Constipation is not a feature of malabsorption syndrome.
Malabsorption syndrome refers to a spectrum of conditions of various etiologies that arises due to diminished absorption of one or more dietary nutrients.
The general features of malabsorption syndrome are abdominal pain, diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss.
Anemia may be present when there is defective absorption of iron, folate, or vitamin B12. Hypocalcemia and tetany can be seen due to defective absorption of vitamin D.
Solution to Question 2:
D-xylose test is useful for the assessment of intestinal mucosal function.
D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the intestinal mucosa without undergoing enzymatic digestion.
The test is performed by administering 25g of D-xylose orally followed by the collection of urine 5h later. The test is considered abnormal (positive) if urinary D-xylose is <4.5g. A positive
D-xylose test indicates abnormal small intestinal mucosa.
Solution to Question 3:
A urinary D-xylose <4.5g after 5 hours of oral D-xylose (abnormal) can be seen in Crohn’s disease.
D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the small intestinal mucosa without undergoing enzymatic digestion. An abnormal (positive) D-xylose test indicates abnormal small intestinal mucosal absorption.
A positive D-xylose test is seen in:
Celiac disease
Whipple’s disease
Tropical sprue
Short bowel syndrome
Crohn’s disease
The test is of limited clinical value today and mostly has been replaced by small intestinal biopsy.
Solution to Question 4:
A small bowel diverticulum can result in malabsorption.
A small bowel diverticulum is a blind pouch protruding from the small intestine that communicates with the lumen of the gut. It becomes a potential site for bacterial overgrowth which causes malabsorption. The growing gut bacteria depletes vitamin B12 and deconjugates bile acids leading to steatorrhea, diarrhea, and macrocytic anemia.
Anterior colon resection, ulcerative colitis, and sigmoid volvulus affect the large intestine and therefore do not cause malabsorption.
Solution to Question 5:
The most common cause of short bowel syndrome in adults is mesenteric vascular occlusion.
Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a malabsorption disorder caused by a lack of functional small intestine. In adults, the common causes are :
Mesenteric vascular disease (e.g: mesenteric vascular occlusion.)
Primary mucosal and submucosal disease (e.g: Crohn’s disease)
Operations without any preexisting small-intestinal disease (e.g: after trauma)
In children, necrotizing enterocolitis is the most common cause.
Solution to Question 6:
Homocystinuria is not a protein malabsorption disorder. It is a disorder of methionine metabolism that leads to increased homocysteine levels.
Proteins are broken down by pancreatic enzymes and are absorbed as amino acids and peptides. So, protein malabsorption usually occurs only in pancreatic insufficiency. Additionally, there are three rare genetic disorders that lead to protein malabsorption. They are:
Enterokinase deficiency- Defective conversion of the proenzyme trypsinogen to trypsin. It is characterised by:
Diarrhoea
Growth retardation
Hypoproteinemia
Hartnup disease- Defective transport of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids. It is characterised by:
Pellagra-like rash
Neuropsychiatric symptoms
Cystinuria- Defective transport of cystine and other dibasic amino acids. It is characterised by:
Renal calculi
Chronic pancreatitis
Solution to Question 7:
The above findings on Schilling test show reduced absorption of vitamin B12 irrespective of all interventions. This is suggestive of an ileal disease.
Solution to Question 8:
The clinical scenario describes a case of malabsorption syndrome (chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea), a normal xylose test and normal duodenal biopsy with abnormal schilling test points towards pancreatic insufficiency.
A normal xylose test and normal duodenal biopsy rules out small intestinal pathologies like celiac disease (option A) and intestinal lymphangiectasia (option C), presence of steatorrhea rules out ulcerative colitis (option B) as it affects the large bowel which is not the main site of absorption of fat.
Ileal disease is also characterized by normal xylose test, normal duodenal biopsy and steatorrhea and abnormal schilling test but among the given options the most appropriate answer would be pancreatic insufficiency due to chronic pancreatitis.
Pancreatic insufficiency is characterised by the deficiency of exocrine pancreatic enzymes that result in maldigestion and malabsorption.
The features in favor of the diagnosis:
Steatorrhea - a deficiency of pancreatic lipases can lead to undigested fat in stools.
D-xylose test - d-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the intestinal mucosa without undergoing any enzymatic action. Normal d-xylose test denotes intact mucosa.
Schilling test - it is abnormal as pancreatic enzymes are required for the absorption of vitamin B12.

Solution to Question 9:
The image showing retinitis pigmentosa and presence of acanthocytes along with the given clinical features is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.
Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder in which there is defective chylomicron formation. Chylomicrons are required for the absorption and transport of fats and fat-soluble vitamins.
It presents in early childhood with steatorrhoea and diarrhea, hypolipidemia, failure to thrive, ataxia, sensory and motor neuropathies.
Solution to Question 10:
Figure A shows vacuoles (unabsorbed fat) in the cytoplasm of the enterocytes. Figure B shows acanthocytes. These findings are associated with abetalipoproteinemia.
Figure C shows distended macrophages in the lamina propria and periodic acid–Schiff
(PAS)-positive granules as seen in Whipple's disease.
Acanthocytes are abnormal red blood cells with spiked cell membranes due to thorn-like projections. Causes of acanthocytes in peripheral smear are:
Abetalipoproteinemia
Renal disease
Liver disease
Hemolytic anemia

Atypical celiac disease has a positive serology with atypical symptoms.
Serology in celiac disease refers to either anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG) or anti-endomysial antibodies.
Note: Tropical sprue and celiac disease have similar clinical, endoscopic and histologic findings. A diagnosis of tropical sprue must be considered with a negative celiac serology.

Solution to Question 12:
The most common extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease is dermatitis herpetiformis (DH).
DH is characterized by intensely pruritic small papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces of extremities, buttocks, and neck. It can be considered a celiac disease of the skin.
Other extraintestinal manifestations of celiac disease are:
Anemia
Low bone density
Ataxia

Celiac disease is often associated with other conditions such as type 1 diabetes mellitus, autoimmune thyroid disease, IgA deficiency, bird fancier's lung, and Down syndrome.

Solution to Question 13:
The presence of fatigue, chronic diarrhea, weight loss and abdominal distention along with investigations showing features of malabsorption (iron deficiency) lead to the diagnosis of celiac disease or gluten sensitive enteropathy. The single best test for which is checking serum for the presence of IgA tissue transglutaminase (anti-TTG) antibodies (Option D).
Celiac disease is a disorder characterized by an immunological response to gluten causing damage to the proximal intestinal mucosa (villous atrophy) and malabsorption of nutrients.
Symptoms usually begin 6 to 24 months from the introduction of gluten into diet, although most patients go undiagnosed.
The common manifestations are - irritability, abdominal distention, chronic diarrhea, weight loss or muscle wasting and extra-intestinally, the symptoms observed are aphthous ulcers, delayed puberty, iron deficiency anemia and short stature.
Screening for celiac disease is by testing for tissue transglutaminase IgA, endomysial, and deamidated antigliadin antibodies. IgA levels in serum are measured to detect false-negative results because of IgA deficiency.
Small intestinal biopsy shows characteristic villus blunting, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes.
The treatment involves the exclusion of gluten-containing food from diet.
Long term complications observed are osteoporosis, anemia, infertility and malignancy
(enteropathy related-T cell lymphoma is the most common association)
The Marsh classification is used to categorize celiac disease into different types and to quantify severity of disease involvement.
Solution to Question 14:
In this patient with positive serology, a biopsy should be done next, to confirm the diagnosis of celiac disease.
Tissue transglutaminase Ab (tTG-IgA) is the best screening test. IgA endomysial antibodies (EMA)
are most specific.
But a small-intestinal biopsy is required to establish a diagnosis of celiac disease, before starting treatment.
Solution to Question 15:
The above scenario along with the presence of IgA tissue trans-glutaminase antibodies and biopsy showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, lamina propria infiltrates indicate a case of celiac disease. Pancreatic insufficiency is not a complication of celiac disease.
The complications of celiac disease are:
Intestinal lymphomas
Intestinal ulcers- also known as ulcerative jejunoileitis
Collagenous sprue- development of a subepithelial collagen layer
Solution to Question 16:
Rice can be consumed on a gluten-free diet.
The primary management of celiac disease is avoiding gluten in the diet.
Diet avoided (gluten)“BRO W”
Diet Allowed“So M RP”
Barley
Soya bean
Rye
Maize
Oats
Rice

Potato
Solution to Question 17:
Refractory celiac disease is diagnosed when there is no remission of disease despite a strict gluten-free diet for 6-12 months.
Patients are symptomatic and have persistent small intestinal villous atrophy on biopsy. They respond well to steroids.
Solution to Question 18:
The sites involved in the given malabsorption syndromes are as follows:
Disorder

Solution to Question 19:
Tropheryma whipplei is difficult to culture from the biopsy specimen. Hence, it cannot be used for the early diagnosis of Whipple's disease.
Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by the gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with central nervous system & cardiac problems. It mostly affects men and presents with fever, diarrhea weight loss, and arthralgia.
The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows the presence of PAS-positive macrophages in the small intestine and other organs with evidence of disease.
Solution to Question 20:
The most common CNS manifestation associated with Whipple’s disease is progressive dementia. Other important CNS manifestations in Whipple's disease are:
Personality and mood changes
Progressive supranuclear ophthalmoplegia
Focal neurologic presentations
Oculomasticatory myorrhythmia - an unusual combination of rhythmic eye and jaw movements which is pathognomonic of Whipple's disease.
Whipple's disease associated with CNS symptoms has a poor prognosis.
Note: Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with neuroblastoma.
Solution to Question 21:
The most common cardiovascular presentation in Whipple's disease is culture-negative endocarditis.
Other cardiovascular findings include:
Congestive heart failure
Pericarditis
Myocarditis
Solution to Question 22:
The above image shows PAS-positive foamy macrophages present in the lamina propria. This along with the given features suggests Whipple's disease. Cotrimoxazole is used in the maintenance phase of the treatment of Whipple's disease.
Treatment of Whipple's disease:
Induction phase- ceftriaxone or meropenem or penicillin G + streptomycin - 2 weeks
Maintenance phase- trimethoprim / sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) for 1 year. It has high CNS penetration so it is used in maintenance to prevent relapse.

Solution to Question 23:
The history of malabsorptive symptoms, a negative celiac serology, and the biopsy findings are suggestive of tropical sprue.
Improvement in symptoms after folic acid intake is a hallmark of tropical sprue.
Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious aetiology. It is seen in people from the tropics such as India, Southeast Asia and South America.
Tropical sprue and celiac disease have similar clinical, endoscopic and histologic findings. However, a positive celiac serology (anti-tissue transglutaminase and anti-endomysial antibodies) can be used to rule out tropical sprue.
Solution to Question 24:
The treatment of tropical sprue is tetracycline + folic acid.
Because of marked folate deficiency, folic acid is most often given together with broad spectrum antibiotics for up to 6 months.
Solution to Question 25:
Rifaximin is the preferred drug for the management of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth
(SIBO).
The antibiotics are given for around 3 weeks. The other drugs that can be used are :
Tetracyclines
Cephalosporins
Metronidazole
Amoxicillin-Clavulanic acid
Rifaximin is the antibiotic used in hepatic encephalopathy to lower blood ammonia levels.

question_text:
b
Solution to Question 1:
Pancreatic rests are not a differential diagnosis for hypertrophied gastric folds. These usually present as a single lump in the stomach and are formed by ectopic pancreatic tissue.
Thickened gastric folds can represent a local malignant process, inflammatory process, or hormonal response. The differential diagnoses of large gastric folds include:
Menetrier's disease
Zollinger–Ellison syndrome - hypergastrinemia leads to parietal cell hyperplasia and prominent folds
Malignancy- lymphoma, infiltrating gastric cancer
Infections- histoplasmosis, tuberculosis.
Solution to Question 2:
The antrum is usually spared in Menetrier's disease.
Foveolar hyperplasia results in the development of large rugal folds in the body and fundus of the stomach, sparing the antrum. These hypertrophied rugal folds give a cobblestone or cerebriform appearance to the gastric mucosa.
The image given below shows the endoscopic appearance of Menetrier's disease.

Solution to Question 3:
The given case scenario and endoscopy image showing large, rugal gastric folds are suggestive of Menetrier's disease. Among the given options, hematemesis is least likely to occur in this patient.
Large, gastric rugal folds in Menetrier's disease occur due to massive overgrowth of mucous cells (foveolar cells) lining the stomach.
Patients usually present with epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, anorexia, peripheral edema, and weight loss. Occult gastrointestinal bleeding may occur, but overt bleeding is unusual. If overt bleeding is seen, it is usually due to superficial mucosal erosions.
They develop protein-losing gastropathy, leading to hypoproteinemia as a result of increased secretion of gastric mucus. There is also a decrease in the number of parietal cells which leads to decreased acid secretion (hypochlorhydria) in the stomach. They are at an increased risk of developing gastric carcinoma.
Solution to Question 4:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Menetrier's disease. In children, it occurs commonly due to the infection by cytomegalovirus.
The histopathological features of Menetrier's disease include:
Foveolar hyperplasia - hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucosa
Reduction in oxyntic glands, parietal cells, and chief cells
Dilated, tortuous gastric glands
Elongation of pits of gastric glands
Eosinophilic infiltration in lamina propria
The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of Menetrier's disease.

Solution to Question 5:
Overexpression of TGF- (transforming growth factor-alpha) causes Menetrier's disease. This overexpression results in overstimulation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) pathway and increased proliferation of mucous cells, resulting in mucous cell (foveolar) hyperplasia.
Solution to Question 6:
Menetrier's disease is confirmed by endoscopic full-thickness biopsy.
A full-thickness biopsy allows for the visualization of the cells on the surface as well as the pits of the gastric glands. The histopathological specimen shows the following features:
Foveolar hyperplasia - hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucosa
Reduction in oxyntic glands, parietal cells, and chief cells
Dilated, tortuous gastric glands
Elongation of pits of gastric glands
Eosinophilic infiltration in lamina propria
A punch biopsy can only sample the surface of the gastric gland and hence is not preferred. The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of Menetrier's disease.

Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing foveolar hyperplasia are suggestive of Menetrier's disease. The treatment of choice is cetuximab.
Increased epidermal growth factor receptor(EGFR) signaling has been implicated in the pathogenesis of Menetrier's disease. Cetuximab is an EGFR inhibitor, and blocks this signaling pathway and helps in the improvement of the symptoms. Therefore, it is the first line of treatment.
Medical therapy with proton pump inhibitors (lansoprazole) and somatostatin analogues (octreotide) may also be tried to manage symptoms. If the patient continues to have protein loss despite medical therapy, then total gastrectomy is indicated.
The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of Menetrier's disease.

Solution to Question 8:
The most common site for mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma or MALToma is the stomach.
MALToma is a type of extranodal marginal zone lymphoma that most commonly occurs in the stomach and to a lesser extent in the salivary glands, lungs, small intestine, etc. It occurs as a result of the malignant proliferation of B cells in the marginal zone of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT).
Solution to Question 9:
MALToma arises from B lymphocytes present in the marginal zone of the lymphoid tissue. The majority of the cases of MALToma are associated with H. pylori induced chronic gastritis.
This infection results in an increased proliferation of lymphocytes in the mucosa of the stomach causing MALToma. It is initially low grade and if the infection is not treated, it later progresses to high grade.
The patients usually present with non-specific symptoms like epigastric pain and discomfort. It is usually diagnosed in patients around 60 years of age. It is also associated with autoimmune diseases like Sjogren's syndrome and Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario and lymphoepithelial lesions seen in the gastric glands is suggestive of MALToma. The diagnosis is confirmed by immunophenotyping.
Histopathological examination of a MALToma shows the presence of lymphoepithelial lesions. These are caused due to the invasion of gastric glands and crypts by the neoplastic lymphocytes. These lymphocytes are positive for CD19, CD20 and negative for CD5 and CD10. Biopsy or aspiration of the bone marrow is also done to see the bone marrow involvement.
Radiological investigations like CT scans, MRIs, and PET scans are useful in identifying the extent of the tumor and infiltration of the tumor to the adjacent organs.
Note: Cytogenetic testing will be helpful in identifying chromosomal abnormalities. The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of a MALToma.


The below image shows a sample of a MALToma showing positive immunophenotyping for CD20.

Solution to Question 11:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a low-grade gastric MALToma. The treatment of choice for this condition is H. pylori eradication therapy which can be done with the OCM
regimen (omeprazole, clarithromycin and metronidazole).
Immunophenotyping in MALTomas shows positive staining for CD19 and CD20 which is suggestive of a B-cell neoplasm. Negative staining for CD5 and CD10 is seen, suggesting it arises from the marginal zone of lymphoid tissues.
Chronic infection with H. pylori leads to the development of MALTomas. When these lesions are limited to the mucosa, treatment of the infection alone is sufficient to cause regression of the tumour.
In high-grade tumors or the tumors which invade into the adjacent or distant organs, radiotherapy and chemotherapy are required to treat the tumor. Radiotherapy is usually
three-dimensional conformal radiotherapy. The chemotherapeutic agents used in the treatment of MALToma are rituximab, cyclophosphamide, fludarabine, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone. Radical gastrectomy has a limited role and is done when the disease is confined to the stomach.
Solution to Question 12:
The given case scenario is suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia.
Chronic mesenteric ischemia occurs due to atherosclerosis of the celiac or mesenteric arteries. It is common in older women, and they usually have a history of smoking, coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, or peripheral artery disease.
The important clinical features of chronic mesenteric ischemia are:
Postprandial abdominal pain occurs as a result of a mismatch between the increased deman and decreased blood flow to the intestine. This is called intestinal angina
Weight loss- patients avoid eating due to postprandial pain and this leads to significant weight loss
Diarrhea- occurs as a result of decreased absorption
Physical examination may reveal epigastric bruit in almost half of the patients.
The gold standard investigation to diagnose the blockade is mesenteric angiography. Once the disease is confirmed, the patients have to be started with antiplatelets and mesenteric angioplasty and stenting should be performed.
Option A: Acute mesenteric ischemia present with acute abdomen, bloody diarrhea and nausea. Angiography will show occlusion of superior mesenteric artery.
Option C: Wilkie's syndrome occurs due to compression of the third portion of the duodenum by the superior mesenteric artery. It can present similarly, however is associated with vomiting and rapid weight loss. It usually occurs in young, asthenic women.
Option D: Nutcracker syndrome occurs due to compression of the left renal vein, between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery. It presents with varicoceles and hematuria.

question_text:
b
Solution to Question 1:
Takayasu disease is an example of large vessel vasculitis.
Solution to Question 2:
Churg-Strauss syndrome is the most likely diagnosis as it is a granulomatous vasculitis. The vasculitis can be classified as:
Granulomatous vasculitis
Non-granulomatous vasculiti s
Giant cell arteritisTakayasu a rteritisGranulomatosis with p olyangiitisChurg-Strauss syn drome
Polyarteritis nodosaKawasaki diseaseBehcet's diseaseMicr oscopic polyangiitisHenoch-S chonlein purpura
Solution to Question 3:
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis) is the most likely diagnosis as it is associated with cANCA.
Solution to Question 4:
Giant cell arteritis is common in older women (>50 years of age).
Giant cell arteritis is an inflammatory vasculitis of the large vessels, commonly seen in females over 50 years of age. It usually involves the temporal artery.
It is characterized by fever, anemia, and headache. Depending on the artery involved, the patient may have tenderness over the affected artery, scalp pain, tongue and jaw claudication. Untreated patients may develop ischemic optic neuropathy.
Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and normochromic normocytic anemia. It shows good response to glucocorticoid therapy.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical presentation of headache, jaw claudication, and painless visual loss is suggestive of giant cell arteritis. The best investigation for the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis is temporal artery biopsy.
Histopathology shows panarteritis with the presence of mononuclear cells and giant cells. The biopsy may not be positive in all patients due to patchy histologic findings. Since involvement of the vessel may be segmental, positive yield is increased by obtaining a biopsy segment of 3–5 cm together with serial sectioning of biopsy specimens.
Note : According to the 21st edition of Harrison's Medicine, as involvement of the vessel may be segmental, getting a biopsy segment of 3–5 cm together with serial sectioning of biopsy specimens would help to increase a positive yield. And Robbin's 10th edition mentions that an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical presentation of painful, tender, and stiff shoulders with restricted movement points toward a diagnosis of polymyalgia rheumatica, which is closely associated with giant cell arteritis.
Polymyalgia rheumatica is characterized by pain and stiffness (worst in the morning) in the muscles of the neck, shoulder, back, hips, and thigh. On examination, diffuse tenderness is present without localization to any specific structures. Pain restricts the active range of motion but passive range of motion and muscle strength are normal.
ESR and CRP are typically elevated in polymyalgia rheumatica whereas creatine phosphokinase
(CPK) lies within the normal range. It shows a good response to prednisone therapy.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical presentation of headache and symptoms suggestive of polymyalgia rheumatica with raised ESR points towards a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis (GCA), for which the next best step is initiation of steroids (prednisone).
Although temporal artery biopsy is the diagnostic investigation for GCA, it should not delay the initiation of steroids as it helps in reducing symptoms and preventing visual loss. The biopsy findings usually remain positive for at least 1 month after initiation of steroids.
Newer drugs used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis are tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) and abatacept (CTLA4-Ig).
Solution to Question 8:
The most common artery involved in Takayasu arteritis is the subclavian artery.
Patients present with pain, claudication, and weakness of the affected limb. The arterial pulse in the affected limb may be weak or absent.
The order of arteries affected in Takayasu arteritis is subclavian artery > common carotid artery > abdominal aorta > renal artery > aortic arch = vertebral > coeliac axis > iliac > pulmonary > coronary artery.
Solution to Question 9:
The above clinical features with a marked weakening of pulse in the upper extremities and laboratory findings of elevated ESR are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. It is also known as pulseless disease.
Takayasu arteritis is a systemic disease and may present with generalized and vascular symptoms. It commonly affects adolescents or young females. Generalized symptoms like fever, night sweats, weight loss, malaise, arthralgias, and anorexia may occur long before vascular symptoms.
Vascular symptoms depend on the vessel involved:
Arch of the aorta and its branches:
Subclavian artery (most commonly affected) - It leads to weak pulses in the upper extremities. Hence, it is also known as pulseless disease. It may also lead to Raynaud’s phenomenon.
Carotid arteries- It leads to weak pulses, blindness, and neurological deficits.
Aortic arch- It may lead to congestive heart failure.
Abdominal aorta, celiac axis, and superior mesenteric artery - leads to abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting
Iliac vessels - leads to claudication of the legs
Renal arteries - leads to systemic hypertension
Pulmonary artery - leads to pulmonary hypertension
Coronary arteries (least commonly affected) - lead to myocardial infarction Investigations:
Laboratory tests reveal an elevated ESR level, anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels.
Arteriography is done as a confirmatory test.
Treatment includes glucocorticoid therapy, methotrexate, immunotherapy with anti-TNF agents, and surgery.
Solution to Question 10:
Pathergy test can be used for confirming Behcet's disease. It is a nonspecific inflammatory skin reaction to scratch or intradermal saline injection and is a specific manifestation.
The diagnostic criteria in Behcet's syndrome are the presence of recurrent oral ulcerations plus two of the following findings:
Recurrent genital ulcerations
Ocular lesions
Skin lesions
Positive pathergy test
Option A: Foshay test is used in cat-scratch disease. Option B: Tzanck test is used to diagnose herpes infection.
Option D: The cardiolipin antibody test is used to detect antiphospholipid antibodies.
Solution to Question 11:
Recurrent oral and genital ulcerations with a positive pathergy test are suggestive of Behcet's syndrome. It is associated with oral ulcers that are painful and heal without scarring.
Behcet's syndrome usually affects young individuals and is associated with HLA-B51 and anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies.
The clinical features of Behcet's syndrome include:
Oral ulcers - painful, non-scarring
Genital ulcers - painful, scarring
Ocular involvement - scarring and bilateral panuveitis
Skin involvement - folliculitis, acne-like rashes, erythema nodosum, and pyoderma gangrenosum
Arthritis and peripheral vein thrombosis
Solution to Question 12:
Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a medium vessel vasculitis.
Solution to Question 13:
The most probable diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa.
The image shows the gangrene of the fingers. The presence of myalgia, the involvement of cutaneous vessels (gangrene with palpable peripheral pulses), renal vessels causing hypertension and serology negative for ANCA make polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) the most probable diagnosis.
Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN.
The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:
Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, and livedo reticularis
Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation Other options:
Takayasu arteritis- It is a large vessel vasculitis. Also known as pulseless disease as it may be associated with weak upper extremity pulses.
Microscopic polyangiitis- It is a small vessel vasculitis. It is positive for p-ANCA. Presentation is similar to granulomatosis with polyangiitis but without upper airway involvement.
Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis- It is frequently associated with hepatitis C. Circulating cryoglubulins and rheumatoid factor can be found in blood. Most common clinical manifestations are cutaneous vasculitis, peripheral neuropathy, glomerulonephritis and arthritis.
Solution to Question 14:
Pulmonary arteries are characteristically spared in polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). PAN mainly involves renal and visceral arteries.
Histopathology of the involved arteries usually shows the following findings:
Transmural necrotizing vasculitis of the arteries and adjacent veins. Venules are spared.
Renal arteries - arteritis without glomerulonephritis
Fibrinoid necrosis
Absence of granuloma and eosinophilia
Solution to Question 15:
One-third of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) cases are associated with Hepatitis B. Other options:
Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa is a systemic vasculitis which is associated with necrotizing inflammation of small and medium-sized muscular arteries.
Option B: Patients show hypergammaglobulinemia.
Option C: PAN is rarely associated with ANCA positivity. There is no serological test for PAN. Most patients exhibit an elevated leukocyte count with a predominance of neutrophils.
PAN is usually seen in young adults, characterized by rapidly accelerating hypertension, abdominal pain, bloody stools, myalgias, and peripheral neuropathy.
Arterial inflammation is segmental, necrotizing, and transmural, leading to aneurysms and thrombosis.
The involved vessels are typically found at arterial bifurcations, spreading to veins but sparing venules. The most commonly affected organs are the kidney, heart, liver, and gastrointestinal tract, in that order. Pulmonary arteries are not involved. Inadequate blood flow leads to ischemia, ulcers, infarcts, atrophy, or hemorrhage.
Diagnosis relies on histopathological findings from organ biopsies or the demonstration of aneurysms in small to medium-sized arteries of the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature.
Untreated PAN has an extremely poor prognosis, with a 5-year survival rate of only 10 to 20%. Common causes of death include gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel infarcts and perforation, as well as cardiovascular issues. Timely treatment is vital for improved outcomes.
Combining prednisone and cyclophosphamide has shown significant benefits in survival rates. Glucocorticoids alone may be sufficient for milder cases. In PAN cases associated with hepatitis B or C, antiviral therapy is combined with glucocorticoids and plasma exchange. Managing hypertension effectively can help reduce vascular complications. Despite successful treatment, relapses occur in approximately 10-20% of patients.
A histopathological image of PAN showing necrotizing transmural inflammation is given below:

The image below shows aneurysms in renal vasculature:

Solution to Question 16:
The most common cause of vasculitis in children in India is Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease has a higher incidence in children in the Indian subcontinent.
The most common vasculitis worldwide is Henoch-Schonlein purpura, whereas in the Indian subcontinent and other Asian countries the most common vasculitis is Kawasaki disease.

Solution to Question 1:
Ischemic optic neuropathy associated with giant cell arteritis (large vessel vasculitis) can present as visual loss.
Small vessel vasculitis is the inflammation of arterioles, capillaries, or venules. It starts with nonspecific symptoms like fever, fatigue, and arthralgia. Since it mainly affects the small vessels and capillaries present in the lungs, kidney, and skin, the majority of the patients will have:
Hemoptysis
Glomerulonephritis (hematuria, proteinuria)
Palpable purpura
Solution to Question 2:
The structure most commonly involved in cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis is postcapillary venules.
Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis is defined as vasculitis which is limited to the small vessels of the skin. There is no systemic vasculitis and glomerulonephritis. It most commonly affects postcapillary venules.
It is characterized by the presence of leukocytoclasis (presence of neutrophil debris in and around the blood vessels).
Solution to Question 3:
The presence of cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy are suggestive of small-vessel vasculitis. Investigating for ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) should be the next step to aid in diagnosis.
