Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario with cANCA positivity is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It is characterized by the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (occasional hemoptysis), and kidneys (red cell casts).
It is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis of the small vessels that mainly affects:
Upper respiratory tract- presenting with sinusitis, otitis media, and nasal septal perforation.
Lower respiratory tract- presenting with hemoptysis.
Kidney (glomerulonephritis)- presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension.
Apart from these organs, the disease can also affect the eye and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules. Laboratory investigations show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and ANCA positivity.
Options A and C: In Goodpasture's syndrome and microscopic polyangiitis, the symptoms of upper respiratory tract involvement are very rare.
Option D: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is commonly seen in children. It presents with palpable purpura, joint pain, abdominal pain, and glomerulonephritis.
Solution to Question 7:
Abatacept is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.
Important drugs used in the management of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis) are:
Cyclophosphamide
Rituximab (anti CD20 antibody)
Glucocorticoids
Methotrexate
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario showing saddle nose deformity along with hemoptysis, and proteinuria is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).
Involvement of upper respiratory tract in granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests as:
Paranasal sinusitis, serous otitis media
Nasal ulcers, purulent or bloody nasal discharge
Nasal perforation leading to the destruction of septum and saddle nose deformity
Subglottic tracheal stenosis
Solution to Question 9:
Wegener's granulomatosis is associated with necrotizing vasculitis.
Wegener's granulomatosis predominantly affects the small blood vessels of the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys. Lung involvement will show multiple, bilateral cavitating nodules and pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray.
The radiograph below shows cavitating nodules in a patient with granulomatosis with polyangiitis
(Wegener's granulomatosis).

Renal involvement initially appears as focal or segmental glomerulonephritis on biopsy. If left untreated, it can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Patients with Wegener's granulomatosis have an increased incidence of venous thrombosis, like deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy. This finding is commonly seen in the tissues obtained from lungs, skin, upper airways, and rarely kidneys.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical presentation along with pANCA positivity and biopsy findings of leukocytoclastic (neutrophil infiltration) vasculitis point towards a diagnosis of microscopic polyangiitis. It is associated with fibrinoid necrosis.
Microscopic polyangiitis, also known as hypersensitivity vasculitis, causes segmental fibrinoid necrosis of small arterioles and venules. It is associated with neutrophil infiltration, and hence also called leukocytoclastic vasculitis.
Histopathology of the affected tissue will show necrotizing vasculitis of arterioles, venules, and capillaries without any granulomas. It is caused by ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) and is not mediated by the immune complex. It primarily affects the kidneys and lungs.
Solution to Question 11:
Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are associated with necrotizing vasculitis. Hence, this feature is not useful to distinguish between them.
Solution to Question 12:
A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia is seen in Churg–Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis).
It is a necrotizing vasculitis of the small-to-medium-sized vessels and in order to be diagnosed with Churg-Strauss, a patient should have evidence of asthma, peripheral blood and tissue eosinophilia (>1000 cells/L), extravascular granuloma formation and clinical features consistent with vasculitis.
Common presenting symptoms of this condition are lower respiratory tract symptoms such as severe attacks of asthma, upper respiratory tract symptoms such as allergic rhinitis, sinusitis, and nasal polyps, mono neuritis multiplex (a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerves) which presents with a complaint of pain, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas and skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules.
Renal involvement is less common and less severe than other small vessel vasculitis. P-ANCA antibodies are present in Churg Strauss syndrome.
Severe attacks of asthma
Mononeuritis multiplex: a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerves. Patients will complain of pain, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas.
Skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules.
Glucocorticoids show effective responses in these patients. Other drugs that have been tried are mepolizumab and rituximab.
For fulminant multisystem disease, daily cyclophosphamide with prednisolone followed by azathioprine or methotrexate is used.
Option A: Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis presents with palpable purpura, arthralgia, neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis. It is most commonly associated with Hepatitis C.
Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can also present with mononeuritis multiplex and skin lesions, but they do not have eosinophilia, it has predominant neutrophilia.
Option D: Giant cell arteritis manifests with the cardinal symptom of headache localized to the temporal region. Common symptoms include headache, polymyalgia rheumatica , jaw claudication, fever, and decrease in body weight. Laboratory results show increased ESR, CRP levels, normochromic or mildly hypochromic anemia.
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario of asthma, mononeuritis multiplex, and pANCA positivity is suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). It affects small to medium-sized arteries.
Laboratory investigations will show peripheral blood eosinophilia. Some patients may be positive for pANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies). Histopathology will show the presence
of necrotizing vasculitis, tissue eosinophilia, and extravascular granulomas. Histopathology of ANCA associated vasculitides can be remembered as:
Microscopic polyangiitis: necrotizing vasculitis
Wegener's granulomatosis: necrotizing vasculitis with granulomas
Churg Strauss syndrome: necrotizing vasculitis with extravascular granulomas and eosinophilia
Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical presentation of palpable purpura, colicky abdominal pain, and arthritis, point towards a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP) also known as IgA vasculitis.
It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by:
Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy.
Arthralgia- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints.
Abdominal pain
Glomerulonephritis: proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, RBC casts in urine.
The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected organs by immunofluorescence.
Option B: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is characterized by a triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.
Option C: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by fever of at least 2 weeks duration associated with arthritis, evanescent erythematous rash, hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, and serositis.
Option D: Patients with IgA nephropathy or Berger's disease present with gross hematuria, often associated with a preceding or ongoing viral infection of the upper respiratory tract (synpharyngitic presentation).
Solution to Question 15:
Cryoglobulinemia is associated with hepatitis C infection.
Following Hepatitis C infection, there is an aberrant immune response leading to an immune complex formation containing hepatitis C antigens, polyclonal IgG specific to Hepatitis C, and monoclonal IgM rheumatoid factor, which triggers an inflammatory cascade results in Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis.
Cryoglobulins are the immunoglobulins that precipitate at temperatures less than 37°C, the presence of these cryoglobulins in serum leads to Cryoglobulinemia, which is characterized by cutaneous vasculitis, palpable purpura, arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis.
Important conditions associated with cryoglobulinemia are:
Hepatitis C
Multiple myeloma
Connective tissue disorders
Lymphoproliferative disorders
Crystal Arthropathies

Solution to Question 1:
In gout, the crystals are negatively birefringent on polarized light microscopy of the joint aspirate.
Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males.
It usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. Acute gout presents with a joint that is red, hot, swollen, and extremely tender on examination. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most frequently involved joint.
Synovial fluid analysis of joint aspirate is diagnostic and shows the following features:
Increased leukocyte count with a neutrophilic predominance
Negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid
Antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide and ethambutol cause hyperuricemia by inhibiting uric acid excretion in the kidney.
Monosodium urate crystals as seen on polarized light microscopy:

Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical presentation and polarised microscopy showing negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals point towards a diagnosis of gout. In gout, the negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals are due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals.
Monosodium urate crystals in gout:

Option A: Calcium apatite crystals can accumulate in areas of tissue damage, hypercalcemia, or hyperparathyroid states.
Option C: Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals that are seen in pseudogout.
Calcium pyrophosphate crystals seen in pseudogout:

Option D: Ammonium urate crystals can cause urinary bladder stones which are radiolucent but may develop a calcific coating making it visible on X-rays.
Solution to Question 3:
Calcium apatite crystals cannot be identified using polarized light microscopy. Polarized light microscopy can identify crystals such as:
Monosodium urate
Calcium pyrophosphate
Calcium oxalate
Solution to Question 4:
The given scenario of multiple painful swelling of ankles and toes that responded to NSAIDs is suggestive of gout. High-dose salicylates (>3g/day) do not precipitate gout.
Although high-dose salicylates inhibit both the secretion and reabsorption of urate, the inhibition of reabsorption is more than the inhibition of secretion, and therefore the net effect is uricosuric.
On the other hand, low-dose salicylates (<2 to 3g/day) are associated with uric acid retention. They inhibit renal tubular secretion of uric acid resulting in hyperuricemia and may precipitate gout.
Aspirin is not used to treat acute attacks of gout due to its uric acid retention property. However, low-dose aspirin used for cardiovascular prophylaxis need not be discontinued during the treatment of a gout flare.
Solution to Question 5:
The given X-ray of a patient with chronic gout shows Martel's sign.
Martel's sign also known as the G sign, or rat-bite erosion, refers to the punched-out lytic lesion and overhanging margin of the new bone along the edge of erosion seen in chronic tophaceous gout.
Option A: Podagra is the inflammation of the base of the great toe (metatarsophalangeal joint) during flares of gout. It is not a radiological sign.
Option C: Chopart's fracture is a fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints. Option D: March fracture is fracture neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal.
X-ray showing Martel's sign:

Solution to Question 6:
The characteristic finding depicted in the given ultrasound image of a patient with chronic gout is the double contour sign.
Double contour sign is characterized by an echogenic line on the outer surface of the joint cartilage, due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals on the surface of articular cartilage. It is seen in chronic gout.
Option A: Double wall sign also known as Rigler's sign is an abdominal radiograph finding seen in pneumoperitoneum. Here both the inner and outer walls of the bowel are visible.

Option B: Double density sign on chest X-ray PA view is seen due to left atrial enlargement. Here, the right border of the left atrium becomes laterally displaced and convex producing this appearance.

Option D: Double barrel sign is a USG finding seen in common bile duct (CBD) obstruction causing dilatation of CBD and its lumen size becomes comparable to portal vein giving the appearance of a double-barrel.

Solution to Question 7:
The given scenario is suggestive of an acute attack of gout. Allopurinol is used in the management of chronic gout.
Urate-lowering drugs such as allopurinol, probenecid, and lesinurad are not initiated during acute attacks.
The treatment options for an acute attack of gout include:
NSAIDs: Indomethacin, naproxen, ibuprofen, and diclofenac are highly effective
Colchicine: It acts by inhibiting neutrophil migration and reduces inflammation. It is used orally and is most effective if given early in an attack.
Glucocorticoids: Systemic glucocorticoids may be used in polyarticular involvement. If the disease is limited to one joint, intraarticular triamcinolone may be given.
Solution to Question 8:
Allopurinol is the best agent for the long-term treatment of chronic or recurrent gout. Hypouricemic drugs that can be used for definitive treatment of chronic gout include:
Xanthine oxidase inhibitors- allopurinol, febuxostat
Uricosuric agents- probenecid, lesinurad
Recombinant uricases- rasburicase and pegloticase
Solution to Question 9:
Losartan is the drug of choice for the management of hypertension in a patient with gout because of its uricosuric action.
Thiazides (hydrochlorothiazide, metolazone) and loop diuretics (furosemide) cause reduced excretion of uric acid from the renal tubules and result in hyperuricemia. Therefore they are not preferred for management of hypertension in patients with gout.
Solution to Question 10:
The knee joint is most commonly affected in calcium pyrophosphate (CPPD) disease or pseudogout. Other sites include the wrist, shoulder, ankle, elbow, and hands.
Acute CPPD arthropathy is commonly seen in the elderly and may be associated with conditions such as primary hyperparathyroidism, hypothyroidism, and hemochromatosis.
ray of the affected joint may reveal chondrocalcinosis, which represents calcium deposition in articular cartilage. Polarised light microscopy of the joint aspirate demonstrates positively birefringent rhomboid crystals, as shown below:

The most common cause of secondary Sjögren’s syndrome is rheumatoid arthritis.
Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic autoimmune disorder that affects the lacrimal and salivary glands. It also affects other organ systems, such as lungs, kidneys, and nervous system. It is seen in association with:

Arthralgia or arthritis - most common manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads t Jaccoud's arthropathy. Jaccoud's arthropathy is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy characterized by the ulnar deviation of the second to 5th fingers with metacarpophalangeal joint subluxation.
Raynaud's phenomenon

The presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B indicate extra glandular involvement and poor prognosis.
Note: Anti-Ro and anti-La in SLE indicate a good prognosis, due to decreased risk of nephritis and vasculitis.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Sjogren's syndrome. In this condition, glomerular lesions are extremely rare.
Defects of tubular function, including renal tubular acidosis, uricosuria, and phosphaturia, are often seen and are associated histologically with tubulointerstitial nephritis.
Lacrimal and salivary glands are the major targets of this disease, while the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts and the vagina may also be involved. The characteristic decrease in tears and saliva (sicca syndrome) is the result of lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary glands. The infiltrate contains predominantly activated CD4+ helper T cells and some B cells, including plasma cells.
Antibodies detected are:
Rheumatoid factor - seen in 75% of patients, whether or not coexisting rheumatoid arthritis is present
Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs)
SS-A (Ro) - associated with early disease onset, longer disease duration, and extra-glandular manifestations, such as cutaneous vasculitis and nephritis
SS-B (La)
These patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas. About 60% of patients have another accompanying autoimmune disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis, and these patients also have the symptoms and signs of that disorder.
Biopsy of the lip (to examine minor salivary glands) is essential for the diagnosis of Sjögren's syndrome.
The image shows an enlargement of the salivary gland with intense lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltration with ductal epithelial hyperplasia in the salivary gland.

Note: Mikulicz syndrome is characterized by lacrimal and salivary gland enlargement from any cause, including sarcoidosis, lymphomas, and other tumors.
Solution to Question 6:
The given image is suggestive of microstomia. The findings of skin thickening, microstomia, positive ANA, and immunofluorescence showing nucleolar pattern point towards a diagnosis of systemic sclerosis. The most common extracutaneous manifestation of systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is Raynaud's phenomenon.
Raynaud's phenomenon is characterized by episodes of reversible vasoconstriction in the fingers and toes on exposure to cold. Rarely, it affects the lips, tip of the nose, and earlobes. These episodes classically occur in the following sequence:
Affected part turning pale due to vasoconstriction.
Blue due to ischemia, often associated with numbness or pain.
As blood flow returns, the area turns red with a burning sensation.

Solution to Question 7:
The above clinical scenario suggests that the patient has Raynaud phenomenon, which is associated with the risk of developing scleroderma in later stages of life.
Raynaud phenomenon is manifested as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, causing pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis. It is seen in virtually all patients with systemic sclerosis or scleroderma and precedes other symptoms in 70% of cases.
The image shows features of Raynaud's phenomenon.

Systemic sclerosis is characterized by progressive fibrosis involving the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and other tissues. Fibrosis may be the result of the activation of fibroblasts by cytokines produced by T cells.
Focal, and sometimes diffuse, subcutaneous calcifications may develop, especially in patients with CREST syndrome. The most ominous manifestation is malignant hypertension.
Solution to Question 8:
Primary Raynaud's phenomenon is not associated with tissue necrosis and ulcers.

Solution to Question 9:
The most common histological pattern of interstitial lung disease in systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP). It commonly affects the lower lobes and is characterised by ground-glass opacities.
Note: Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) is the most common type of ILD in rheumatoid arthritis.
Solution to Question 10:
Drugs implicated in systemic sclerosis-like illness are:
Bleomycin
Pentazocine
Cocaine
L-tryptophan-containing dietary supplements
Chemicals implicated in systemic sclerosis-like illness are:
Heavy metals
Polyvinyl chloride (PVC)
Toluene
Trichloroethylene
Cyclophosphamide and bosentan are used in the treatment of systemic sclerosis (SSc). Cyclophosphamide reduces the progression of ILD associated with SSc. Bosentan reduces the risk of new ulcers in Raynaud's phenomenon associated with SSc.
Solution to Question 11:
The presence of digital ulcers, Raynaud's phenomenon, and GERD are suggestive of systemic sclerosis (scleroderma). Antinuclear antibody (ANA) is the preferred screening test as it is the most sensitive test for both limited and diffuse variants of systemic sclerosis.
Option B: Anti centromere antibody is the most specific test for CREST syndrome.
Option C: Anti topoisomerase I (Scl-70) is the most specific test for diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.
Option D: Anti-cardiolipin antibody is seen in SLE and APLA syndrome.
Solution to Question 12:
The given scenario of skin thickening in the hands and fingers (sclerodactyly), Raynaud's phenomenon, heartburn (GERD), and occasional arthralgia is suggestive of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc). The presence of anticentromere antibody (ACA) will confirm the diagnosis of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.
Antinuclear antibody (ANA) is positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
Solution to Question 13:
The presence of skin thickening over the trunk and proximal parts of the limbs along with positive anti-topoisomerase I antibodies is suggestive of diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc).
Critical limb ischemia is commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc).
Solution to Question 14:
Esophageal dysmotility is more commonly seen in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc)
compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.
Systemic sclerosis is divided into two based on the patterns of involvement - diffuse and limited.
Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis is characteristically associated with CREST syndrome, which includes calcinosis cutis, Raynaud’s phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly and telangiectasia.
Skin involvement, interstitial lung disease (Option C), myopathy (Option B), and scleroderma renal crisis (Option D) are more common in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc) than limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.
The incidence of ischemic digital ulcers, CREST features, and primary biliary cirrhosis is more in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. The frequency of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is equal in both types.
Solution to Question 15:
Renal failure is not a component of CREST syndrome.
CREST syndrome is seen in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) and consists of the following:
Calcinosis cutis
Raynaud’s phenomenon
Esophageal dysmotility
Sclerodactyly
Telangiectasia

Solution to Question 16:
Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody is associated with scleroderma renal crisis.
Scleroderma renal crisis is scleroderma with accelerated hypertension, acute kidney injury and renal failure. The antibodies associated with it are:
Anti-RNA polymerase III
Topoisomerase I
U3-RNP

Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scleroderma renal crisis. The drug of choice is ACE inhibitors.
Scleroderma renal crisis is a medical emergency characterized by acute onset malignant hypertension and kidney failure, usually in the absence of previous evidence of significant kidney disease. The use of steroids is associated with an increased risk of scleroderma renal crisis.
Clinical features of scleroderma renal crisis are:
Accelerated hypertension - headache, vomiting, blurring of vision, hypertensive retinopathy, and hypertensive encephalopathy.
Acute kidney injury - oliguria, mild proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, renal failure.
Pulmonary edema, congestive heart failure.
Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes), thrombocytopenia.
In patients with persistent hypertension, the addition of angiotensin II receptor blockers, calcium channel blockers, and direct renin inhibitors should be considered.

Solution to Question 1:
Sarcoidosis most commonly affects the lungs.
Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. It commonly involves the lungs, skin, liver, and eyes.
Solution to Question 2:
The given condition is lupus pernio which is a cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis.
Lupus pernio is a chronic inflammatory skin lesion, which is diagnostic for a chronic form of sarcoidosis. It involves the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks and often is purple in color.
Other options:
Option A: Acne rosacea is a skin disorder with onset in middle■aged adults (30–50 years old) and involves the convexities of the face.
Option C: Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in dermatomyositis.
Option D: Malar rash or butterfly rash is classically seen in SLE.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical features along with examination findings of lupus vulgaris is suggestive of tuberculosis. The next best investigation is AFB smear microscopy of the sputum sample.
Lupus vulgaris is a manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis. It has a characteristic slow enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical features along with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and non-caseating granuloma are suggestive of sarcoidosis. The most common ocular manifestation in sarcoidosis is anterior uveitis.
Anterior uveitis presents with photophobia, blurry vision, and lacrimation. Other ocular manifestations include retinitis, pars planitis, and dry eyes.
Solution to Question 5:
The most common cranial nerve to be involved in sarcoidosis is the facial nerve leading to facial palsy.
Neurosarcoidosis frequently manifests as follows:
Cranial nerve involvement- optic neuritis (CN II), extraocular muscles involvement (CN III, IV, VI) and facial palsy (CN VII)
Space occupying lesions
Diabetes insipidus - due to anterior hypothalamus involvement
Basilar meningitis
Solution to Question 6:
Parotid enlargement is not a feature of Lofgren's syndrome. Lofgren’s syndrome is an acute form of sarcoidosis that has a good prognosis, with most of the patients experiencing disease resolution within 2 years.
It is characterized by:
Arthritis
Erythema nodosum
Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Heerfordt–Waldenström syndrome also known as uveoparotid fever is a variant of sarcoidosis characterized by:
Fever
Parotid enlargement
Facial palsy
Anterior uveitis
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical features along with a short QT interval points towards hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemia in a patient with sarcoidosis is due to the increased production of vitamin D by the non-caseating granulomas.
Hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria are seen in some patients with sarcoidosis. The increased production of vitamin D (1,25-dihydoxyvitamin D) results in increased intestinal absorption of calcium, leading to hypercalcemia.
Vitamin D supplementation and increased sun exposure in patients with sarcoidosis can precipitate hypercalcemia.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sarcoidosis, in which the histopathological examination of lesions does not show Masson bodies. Masson bodies are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue seen in cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.
The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis, irrespective of the organ involved, is the
non-caseating granuloma. Two other microscopic features are sometimes seen in the granulomas:
Schaumann bodies- inclusion bodies with concentric rings of calcification
Asteroid bodies- stellate inclusions in the giant cells
Solution to Question 9:
The most common abnormality of liver function in sarcoidosis is the elevation of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels.
Sarcoidosis of the liver presents as a granulomatous disease that causes intrahepatic cholestasis. As the disease advances it leads to elevated liver enzymes followed by elevated bilirubin levels.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario and examination findings of erythema nodosum are suggestive of sarcoidosis. CD4/CD8 ratio in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid, not blood, is used for diagnosis of sarcoidosis.
Erythema nodosum is inflammation of the subcutaneous fat (panniculitis) seen in sarcoidosis. The investigations used in the diagnosis of sarcoidosis include:
Serum ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) levels - elevated
BAL- lymphocytosis and increased CD4/CD8 ratio. A ratio of >3.5 in BAL is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
PET-CT scan - to identify areas of granulomatous disease
Gallium scan shows the following signs:
Panda sign- due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis
Lambda sign- due to bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes which resembles lambda
()
Biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas in a patient with features of sarcoidosis confirms the diagnosis.
The image given below shows the Panda sign:

Solution to Question 11:
According to the Scadding scoring system, the presence of pulmonary infiltrates alone represents grade III.
The Scadding scoring system is used to grade lung involvement in sarcoidosis. It is based on the chest radiograph findings:
Grade I: Hilar lymphadenopathy, often with right paratracheal involvement. No pulmonary infiltrates.
Grade II: Hilar lymphadenopathy + pulmonary infiltrates
Grade III: Pulmonary infiltrates only
Grade IV: Fibrosis
Sarcoidosis predominantly involves the upper lobes of the lungs.
Solution to Question 12:
Garland triad does not involve left paratracheal lymph nodes.
Garland triad also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign is a lymph node enlargement pattern in sarcoidosis that involves:
Right paratracheal nodes (1)
Right hilar nodes (2)
Left hilar nodes (3)

Solution to Question 13:
The first-line drug for sarcoidosis with multiple organ involvement is prednisolone. Management of sarcoidosis:
Asymptomatic patients- monitored for disease progression
Localized/ limited cutaneous and ocular lesions- treated using topical steroids
Multisystem involvement:
Systemic steroids
Other drugs like hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and infliximab are considered when the steroids are ineffective or not tolerated

Diabetes is associated with a mild elevation of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels. Significant elevation of ACE levels is seen in:
Sarcoidosis
Silicosis
Leprosy
Gaucher’s disease
Hyperthyroidism
Disseminated granulomatous infections such as miliary tuberculosis

Solution to Question 1:
The most common inflammatory myopathy seen in elderly patients (>50 years) is inclusion body myositis.
Inclusion body myositis is a type of inflammatory myopathy. It is characterized by progressive, asymmetric muscle weakness most commonly involving the wrist, finger flexors, and quadriceps. Muscles of the face and neck may also be involved, presenting as dysphagia.
Inclusion body myositis is named so because of the presence of inclusion bodies containing amyloid-like protein seen on microscopy.
Solution to Question 2:
The given history of progressive and predominantly asymmetric muscle weakness is most likely suggestive of inclusion body myositis.
Inclusion body myositis is a type of inflammatory myopathy. It is seen in people older than 50 years of age. It is characterized by progressive, asymmetric muscle weakness most commonly involving the wrist, finger flexors, and quadriceps. Muscles of the face and neck might also be involved, leading to dysphagia.
Polymyositis, dermatomyositis, and necrotizing myopathy have predominantly symmetric muscle involvement.
Solution to Question 3:
Patients with inclusion body myositis are generally resistant to immunosuppressive therapies.
Solution to Question 4:
Ocular muscles are unlikely to be involved as they are spared in inflammatory myopathy. They are not involved even in advanced, untreated cases.
The pattern of muscle involvement in various inflammatory myopathies is:
Proximal muscles are most commonly involved in dermatomyositis and polymyositis, causing difficulty in getting up from a chair, brushing hair, etc.
Proximal and distal muscles are involved in inclusion body myositis, such as wrist, finger flexors, and quadriceps.
Pharyngeal and neck-flexor muscles are often involved in all forms of inflammatory myopathy, causing dysphagia or difficulty in holding up the head. Respiratory muscles may also be affected in advanced cases.
Solution to Question 5:
Inflammatory myopathy most frequently associated with other autoimmune diseases is polymyositis.
Solution to Question 6:
The presence of Gottron's papules is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis. They are erythematous to violaceous papules that occur symmetrically over the extensor aspects of metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints.
Gottron's sign, on the other hand, is erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles.
V sign is confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest. Shawl sign is the confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms.
All these signs are present in dermatomyositis, but Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash are pathognomonic.
Solution to Question 7:
The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash. The given clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with the characteristic heliotrope rash and history of an internal malignancy point towards a diagnosis of dermatomyositis.
Classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:
Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
V sign- confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
Shawl sign- confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
Gottron’s papules- erythematous papules and plaques over the extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
Gottron's sign- erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles
Mechanic’s hands- rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
Scalp erythema and hair loss
Facial rash- confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
Nail fold changes
Flagellate erythema- linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
Poikiloderma- mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
Cutaneous calcinosis- accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin Facial rash in dermatomyositis-

Eyelid erythema/ heliotrope rash in dermatomyositis-

V- sign in dermatomyositis-

Shawl sign in dermatomyositis-

Flagellate erythema in dermatomyositis-

Gottron papules in dermatomyositis-

Poikilodermatous changes in dermatomyositis-

Solution to Question 8:
An erythematous rash helps in differentiating between the two conditions as it is seen only in dermatomyositis.
Option A: Elevated levels of creatine kinase are seen in all the inflammatory myopathies.
Options B and D: The involvement of proximal muscles more than the distal muscles and interstitial lung disease is seen in both polymyositis and dermatomyositis.
Solution to Question 9:
This patient should be screened for malignancy as dermatomyositis is often associated with underlying malignancies.
The most common cancer associated with dermatomyositis is ovarian cancer. Other malignancies that are commonly associated with dermatomyositis are:
Breast cancer
Melanoma
Colon cancer
Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma
Solution to Question 10:
The given scenario is suggestive of an inflammatory myositis for which the initial investigation of choice is creatine kinase (CK).
Creatine kinase is a marker of muscle breakdown. It is increased in dermatomyositis and polymyositis. However, it may be normal in inclusion body myositis.
The most specific investigation for inflammatory myositis is a muscle biopsy.
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario and findings of Gottron papules (image) are suggestive of dermatomyositis. Positive titers of Anti-Jo-1 (antisynthetase) antibodies are associated with interstitial lung disease, arthritis, and mechanic's hands in patients with dermatomyositis.
Other autoantibodies seen in dermatomyositis are:
Anti-Mi-2 - highly specific to dermatomyositis
Anti-SRP (anti-signal recognition protein) - associated with severe myositis
Anti–PM-Scl - associated with overlapping myositis and scleroderma
Anti-p155/140 or anti-transcription intermediary factor (TIF)-1 - seen in cancer-associated myositis
Anti-MDA5 (anti-CADM 140) - associated with rapidly progressive lung disease and cutaneous ulcer
Solution to Question 12:
Anti-155/140 antibody is strongly associated with dermatomyositis with malignancy.
Adenocarcinomas of the cervix, lung, ovaries, and pancreas account for the majority of cancers associated with inflammatory myopathies.

The clinical presentation and muscle biopsy finding of perimysial inflammation and perifascicular atrophy makes dermatomyositis the most likely diagnosis.

Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical scenario having features of both systemic sclerosis and dermatomyositis points towards a diagnosis of overlap syndrome. The presence of anti-PM/Scl antibodies is diagnostic of overlap syndrome.
Anti-PM/Scl is a specific antinuclear antibody directed against a nucleolar-protein complex.
Overlap syndrome also known as mixed connective tissue disease usually involves a combination of three connective tissue diseases:
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
Progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS)
Polymyositis (PM) or dermatomyositis (DM)
Solution to Question 15:
The most probable diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is fibromyalgia.
Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness accompanied by other non-specific somatic symptoms like fatigue and sleep disturbance, for >three months.
It is more common in females. On examination, they have tenderness in multiple soft tissue anatomical locations. Laboratory findings are normal.
Patients with fibromyalgia may have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue, like chronic headaches, chronic fatigue syndrome, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/ painful bladder syndrome, and pelvic pain syndromes.
Options A and B: Polymyositis and dermatomyositis have positive laboratory findings such as specific antibodies and radiological findings of multiorgan involvement (ex: interstitial lung disease in polymyositis).
Option C: Although the given clinical scenario closely resembles clinical depression, the examination findings showing tenderness and pain sensitivity favor the diagnosis of fibromyalgia.
Solution to Question 16:
Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) studies done on fibromyalgia patients show hypoperfusion of the thalamus.
Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. It is more common in females.
Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue, including chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/ painful bladder syndrome, and pelvic pain syndromes.
N n-pharmacological treatment strategies for fibromyalgia include physical conditioning and aerobic exercise. Opioid analgesics should be avoided in fibromyalgia as they are not effective and are associated with opioid-induced hyperalgesia that can worsen both the symptoms and function.

Solution to Question 1:
Seronegative spondyloarthritides are associated with HLA-B27.
The spondyloarthritides are a group of overlapping disorders that share certain clinical features and genetic associations (HLA-B27). These disorders include:
Psoriatic arthritis
Ankylosing spondylitis
Reactive arthritis
Enteropathic arthritis
Juvenile onset spondyloarthritis
Undifferentiated spondyloarthritis
Usually, rheumatoid factor (RF) assay is negative in spondyloarthritides. Hence, they are also referred to as seronegative arthritis.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical features along with the classical bamboo-spine appearance on X-ray point towards a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis (AS). In ankylosing spondylitis, the symptoms improve with activity.
Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is an inflammatory disorder that affects the axial skeleton primarily, and may also involve peripheral joints. It is strongly associated with HLA-B27. It usually presents in the mid-twenties.
It presents with lower back pain that improves with activity and worsens with rest or inactivity. Early morning stiffness is a characteristic feature. It is associated with elevated serum IgA levels. NSAIDs are the first line of pharmacological therapy.
It is also associated with extra-articular manifestations like uveitis, interstitial lung disease, aortic regurgitation, etc.
NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for ankylosing spondylitis.
Solution to Question 3:
The key cytokines involved in the pathogenesis of ankylosing spondylitis are TNF- and IL-17. IL-23 also plays a role in pathogenesis.
Solution to Question 4:
The earliest joint to be involved in ankylosing spondylitis is the sacroiliac joint.
Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is an inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the axial skeleton. It is more common in males, usually presenting between 20-30 years of age.
Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and peripheral arthritis can occur as extra-intestinal manifestations of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). They are more common in Crohn's disease than in ulcerative colitis.
Solution to Question 5:
Ankylosing spondylitis is related to the HLA-B27 haplotype. This haplotype is not associated with Behcet's disease. It is associated with HLA B51.
Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease that mainly affects the spine and sacroiliac joint. Individuals who inherit this class I HLA allele (HLA-B27) have a 100–200 fold greater chance (odds ratio or relative risk) of developing the disease compared with those who do not carry HLA-B27. Many autoimmune diseases are associated with different class II HLA alleles.
Solution to Question 6:
The test performed is modified Schober’s test. This test is done in patients with suspected ankylosing spondylitis.
It is used to detect reduced flexion of the spine. The test involves marking two points- at the lumbosacral junction and 10 cm above it. The patient is then asked to bend forward with knees fully extended and the distance between the two points is measured.
This distance normally increases by 2 cm. An increase of <2 cm indicates reduced flexion. In the image given below the distance increases by 5cm which is normal.

Option A: Gaenslen's test is used to detect primary chronic inflammation of the sacroiliac joint. Option B: Thomas test is used to detect fixed flexion deformity of the hip.
Option C: Adam's forward bending test is performed on a patient to differentiate structural from non-structural scoliosis.
Solution to Question 7:
The most common extraarticular manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is anterior uveitis.
It usually presents with unilateral pain, photophobia and increased lacrimation. It is also associated with other spondyloarthritides like reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis and enteropathic arthritis.
Other extra-articular manifestations of AS include:
GIT: ileitis, colitis, inflammatory bowel disease
Cardiovascular: increased risk of IHD, aortic insufficiency, heart block
Respiratory: upper lobe fibrosis
Neurological: cauda equina syndrome
Skin: acne fulminans, hidradenitis suppurativa
Solution to Question 8:
Ankylosing spondylitis predominantly involves the upper lobe of the lung leading to pulmonary fibrosis.
Rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, and asbestosis predominantly involve the lower lobes of the lungs.
Solution to Question 9:
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are the first line of pharmacological therapy for ankylosing spondylitis (AS).
Management of ankylosing spondylitis includes:
First-line management:
Physiotherapy to maintain posture and range of motion.
NSAIDs- reduce pain and tenderness, increase mobility, and slow down the disease progression.
TNF  inhibitors- in patients who do not respond to NSAID therapy. It is not used in all patients because of side effects like reactivation of TB, hypersensitivity reactions, pancytopenia,
drug-induced psoriasis, etc.
Anti-IL-17 antibodies- in patients with failed anti-TNF therapy.
Surgery- improves mobility in patients with severe arthritis and joint stiffness.
Solution to Question 10:
Secukinumab is an anti-IL-17 monoclonal antibody used in patients with ankylosing spondylitis who are not responding to NSAIDs and anti-TNF therapy.
Management of ankylosing spondylitis includes:
First-line management:
Physiotherapy to maintain posture and range of motion.
NSAIDs- reduce pain and tenderness, increase mobility, and slow down the disease progression.
TNF  inhibitors- in patients who do not respond to NSAID therapy. It is not used in all patients because of side effects like reactivation of TB, hypersensitivity reactions, pancytopenia,
drug-induced psoriasis, etc.
Anti-IL-17 antibodies- in patients with failed anti-TNF therapy.
Surgery- improves mobility in patients with severe arthritis and joint stiffness.
Option A: Ustekinumab is an anti-IL-12/23 monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of psoriasis.
Options C and D: Infliximab and adalimumab are anti-TNF- monoclonal antibodies used in the treatment of ankylosing spondylitis.
Solution to Question 11:
The given scenario describes an acute arthritis following an infection which is also associated with urethritis and generalized malaise. These features are suggestive of reactive arthritis.
Reactive arthritis also known as Reiter's syndrome is a seronegative spondyloarthritis that occurs as a consequence of a recent enteric or urogenital infection. It is associated with HLA B27. It is also associated with extra-articular manifestations such as:
Urogenital- urethritis, prostatitis, cervicitis
Ocular- conjuctivitis, anterior uveitis
Mucocutaneous- oral ulcers, keratoderma blennorrhagica, circinate balanitis In some patients it presents as a triad of:
Arthritis
Urethritis
Conjunctivitis
Solution to Question 12:
The given scenario of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis is suggestive of reactive arthritis. It is not caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
Disseminated gonococcal infection causes gonococcal arthritis. It comprises localized septic arthritis and arthritis-dermatitis syndrome.
Reactive arthritis is usually caused due to LPS (lipopolysaccharide) component of the
gram-negative organisms or cross-reactivity with synovial antigens. The common causative organisms include:
Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
Salmonella
Shigella
Yersinia
Campylobacter
Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario of acute arthritis following a recent infection and additive
pattern (involvement of new joints within few days) and examination finding of keratoderma blennorrhagica (image) are suggestive of reactive arthritis.
Keratoderma blennorrhagica is a mucocutaneous manifestation of reactive arthritis. It presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions or crusting on the palms and soles.
Other mucocutaneous manifestations of reactive arthritis include:
Oral ulcers - superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic
Circinate balanitis - consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis
Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical image showing dactylitis, nail changes and telescoping of toes is suggestive of psoriatic arthritis.
Clinical features of psoriatic arthritis include:
Psoriatic nail changes- yellowing and hypertrophy
Dactylitis- inflammation of the toes
Telescoping (shortening) of toes due to osteolysis
Severe deformity- suggestive of arthritis mutilans
Enthesitis- heel pain at the sites of ligament or tendon attachment
Psoriatic arthritis of the hands commonly involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints
(PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of
the hands:

Solution to Question 15:
Juvenile onset spondyloarthritis (JSpA) would not be considered as a differential diagnosis as it has no associated extra-articular manifestations like uveitis, lung involvement, etc.
It is a seronegative spondyloarthritis with onset between 7-16 years of age. It usually presents as asymmetric arthritis predominantly involving the lower extremities.
Solution to Question 16:
Psoriasis is not a part of SAPHO syndrome. The SAPHO syndrome is characterized by:
Synovitis- arthritis
Acne- acne conglobata
Pustulosis- palmoplantar pustulosis, hidradenitis suppurativa
Hyperostosis- sternoclavicular and spinal hyperostosis
Osteitis- sterile osteomyelitis
Solution to Question 17:
Uveitis is a rare manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Ocular manifestation in RA includes scleritis, episcleritis, and keratoconjunctivitis.
Uveitis is a common ocular manifestation of seronegative arthritis e.g. Reiter's syndrome, ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JRA).

Solution to Question 1:
Type III hypersensitivity reaction (immune complex deposition) is seen in systemic lupus erythematosus.
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune condition in which autoantibodies are directed against a part of the nucleus such as double-stranded DNA, histone, ribonuclear proteins, etc. The presence of these autoantibodies leads to the deposition of immune complexes and activation of the complement system.
Solution to Question 2:
C1q complement deficiency is a risk factor for the development of systemic lupus erythematosus
(SLE).
Risk factors for SLE are:
Genetic
Genetic defects resulting in C1q, C2, C4 complement deficiencies
Presence of HLA DR3
Mutation in the TREX1 gene
Environmental
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection
Oral contraceptive pills/ hormone replacement therapy
Smoking
Prolonged exposure to silica
Solution to Question 3:
Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) are required for the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus. ANAs are autoantibodies that bind to the contents of the cell nucleus. They are present in >
•5% of patients with SLE. A positive antinuclear antibody ( ANA ) test with a titer of at least 1:™0 is the obligatory entry criterion along with the additive criteria in š clinical and 3 immunologic domains. If a total of >10 points achieved, it is indicative of SLE according to 201• EULAR/ACR Classification Criteria for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
Most sensitive antibody for SLE: ANA
Most specific antibody for SLE: Anti smith > Anti dsDNA
ANA may also be positive in the other options but it is not a criterion for diagnosis of these conditions.
The following antibodies are specific for their respective autoimmune conditions.
Scleroderma (option A): Anti-topoisomerase I(Scl-š0) and anti-centromere antibodies highly specific for Systemic sclerosis.
Rheumatoid arthritis (option C): RF and anti-CCP antibodies
Sjogren syndrome (option D): Anti-Ro, Anti-La
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The best screening test in this condition is to evaluate for the presence of antinuclear antibodies (ANAs).
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario of oral ulcers, photosensitive rash, and arthralgia is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-Sm antibodies are most specific for SLE and hence their presence is diagnostic of this condition.
Solution to Question 6:
Butterfly rash or malar rash in a patient with SLE is not associated with an increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma.
It is the most common type of acute skin rash seen in SLE. It is a photosensitive, erythematous, and scaly rash that is prominent over the cheeks and the nose. It spares the nasolabial folds.
Common causes of malar rash are as follows:
Erysipelas
Cellulitis
Systemic lupus erythematosus
Rosacea
Pellagra
Dermatomyositis
Solution to Question 7:
The most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE is pleuritis, with or without pleural effusion. The most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are:
Musculoskeletal- arthritis and arthralgia
Skin- photosensitivity
Kidneys- proteinuria
Neurologic- cognitive impairment
Cardiac- pericarditis
Pulmonary- pleuritis
Hematologic- anemia
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario along with elevated hemidiaphragm and no evidence of ILD on chest CT is suggestive of shrinking lung syndrome (SLS), which is a rare complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
It is characterized by dyspnea and episodes of pleuritic chest pain. These symptoms occur in the absence of pleural or parenchymal involvement.
PFT shows decreased lung volume with a restrictive pattern, and DLCO is often reduced. Radiological investigations show an elevated hemidiaphragm with no evidence of ILD.
The following X-ray shows shrinking lung syndrome.

Pulmonary manifestations seen in SLE are:
Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion- most common pulmonary manifestation.
Lupus pneumonitis - It is the inflammation of the lung tissue (pneumonitis) due to SLE (lupus).
Interstitial lung fibrosis
Shrinking lung syndrome
Intra-alveolar hemorrhage
Solution to Question 9:
The most common neurological manifestation seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus
(SLE) is cognitive impairment.
It can manifest as impaired memory and reasoning. Other common neurological manifestations in SLE are psychosis, depression, and seizures.
The most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are:
Musculoskeletal- arthritis and arthralgia
Skin- photosensitivity
Kidneys- proteinuria
Neurologic- cognitive impairment
Cardiac- pericarditis
Pulmonary- pleuritis
Hematologic- anemia
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of depression in a patient with SLE. It is associated with anti-ribosomal P antibodies.
Antiribosomal P antibody is associated with psychosis or depression in SLE.
Solution to Question 11:
Pericarditis is the most common cardiac manifestation seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus.
Other cardiac manifestations include:
Myocarditis
Libman-Sacks endocarditis.
Patients with SLE are at an increased risk for myocardial infarction, usually due to accelerated atherosclerosis.
The most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are:
Musculoskeletal- arthritis and arthralgia
Skin- photosensitivity
Kidneys- proteinuria
Neurologic- cognitive impairment
Cardiac- pericarditis
Pulmonary- pleuritis
Hematologic- anemia
Solution to Question 12:
Non-erosive arthritis is a common feature of arthritis in SLE. Features of arthritis in SLE are:
Symmetrical and polyarticular arthritis
A predilection for the small joints of the hand (the proximal interphalangeal and carpal joints)
Non-erosive and deforming arthritis (reducible)
In contrast to rheumatoid arthritis which is characterized by erosive, deforming joint involvement, SLE has non-erosive and deforming arthritis (reduciable).
Solution to Question 13:
Wire loop appearance without glomerular proliferation is seen in diffuse lupus nephritis (Class IV).
The capillaries are thickened due to the subendothelial deposits and appear as wire loops. It is the most common and most severe form of lupus nephritis.

Renal involvement is common in patients with SLE. The majority of the patients will present with
Proteinuria, nephrotic syndrome
Microscopic hematuria, hypertension
Urinary casts
Abnormal renal function tests- elevated serum creatinine
Low C3 and C4 levels
Solution to Question 14:
The most common cause of death in patients with SLE after 10 years of disease is accelerated atherosclerosis.
The leading causes of death in the first 10 years of the disease are infections and renal failure; subsequently, Cardiovascular events become increasingly frequent causes of mortality.
Solution to Question 15:
Hydroxychloroquine is recommended for all patients with SLE. It decreases the symptoms, reduces flares and organ damage.
Important drugs used in the management of SLE are:
NSAIDs- used for a shorter period to reduce pain and fever. They are not used in all patients because of the increased risk of atherosclerosis and renal injury.
Hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine- should be used in all patients with SLE
Glucocorticoids
topical glucocorticoids- in mild skin lesions
systemic steroids- in severe skin lesions and organ involvements.
Immunosuppressive agents- used in combination with glucocorticoids in severe skin lesions and organ involvement. They help to reduce the dose and toxicity of glucocorticoids. Important agents are:
Methotrexate
Azathioprine
Mycophenolate mofetil and cyclophosphamide- immunosuppressive agents of choice in renal involvement.
Biologic drugs- like belimumab and rituximab are used when there is no response to conventional drugs.
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lupus nephritis. Belimumab is a BAFF inhibitor used in patients with lupus nephritis who do not show response to initial therapy with steroids.
Belimumab is a human monoclonal antibody that inhibits the soluble form of a B cell survival factor (known as BLyS or BAFF) which promotes the formation of memory B cells and autoantibodies. Belimumab inhibits this factor and therefore is used in the management of SLE.
It is used in combination with either cyclophosphamide or MMF in patients with lupus nephritis who do not show response to initial therapy with steroids.
CD20 is an antigen present on the B cells. Rituximab is an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody that is used in patients who are resistant to the standard therapies.
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario with positive ANA and anti-histone antibodies point towards a diagnosis of drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Hydralazine which is a vasodilator is associated with the development of drug-induced lupus erythematosus.
Drug-induced lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune condition caused due to exposure to certain medications. It completely resolves after the causative drug is discontinued. Important drugs associated with this condition are:
Sulfonamides
Hydralazine
Isoniazid
Infliximab
Procainamide
Propylthiouracil
ACE inhibitors
Thiazides
TNF-alpha antagonists

Solution to Question 20:
Thrombocytosis is not associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). On the contrary, thrombocytopenia is seen.
APS is an autoantibody-mediated condition that is characterized by arterial thrombosis, venous thrombosis, and recurrent fetal loss. These autoantibodies bind to the phospholipids present on the endothelial cells and activate coagulation and thrombus formation.
Important manifestations of venous thrombosis are:
Deep vein thrombosis of legs
Pulmonary embolism
Livedo reticularis
Cerebral venous thrombosis
Important manifestations of arterial thrombosis are:
Stroke, transient ischemic attacks
Retinal artery thrombosis
Myocardial ischemia
Libman-Sacks endocarditis- due to the vegetations formed by platelet fibrin microthrombi
Leg ulcers, gangrene of the digits Important obstetric manifestations are:
Preeclampsia
Recurrent fetal loss
Premature birth
Important hematological abnormalities are:
Thrombocytopenia- occurs due to increased platelet aggregation and thrombus formation
Coombs positive hemolytic anemia- seen when autoantibodies attack red blood cells
Thrombotic microangiopathic syndromes- thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical history of >3 spontaneous abortions at <10 weeks of gestational age along with a history of deep vein thrombosis suggests a diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). Anti beta-2 microglobulin is not useful in diagnosing this condition.
For the diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome, high titers of one or more of the following three antibodies should be demonstrated along with at least one clinical symptom of thrombosis or pregnancy complications:
Lupus anticoagulant (LA) - most specific
Anticardiolipin (aCL) antibodies - most sensitive
Anti-beta-2 glycoprotein antibodies
Solution to Question 22:
The given findings of positive Moses' sign with elevated D-dimer, lupus anticoagulant, and
anti-cardiolipin antibodies are suggestive of antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). Glucocorticoids are not useful in the general management of APS, they are used only in the treatment of catastrophic APS.
Squeezing of the relaxed calf muscles from side to side is painful as the thrombosed deep veins in the calf are always tender. This test is known as Moses’ sign.
The clinical manifestations in APS occur due to the activation of coagulation and thrombus formation. Therefore, anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents are the mainstays in the treatment. Important drugs used are:
Warfarin- is an anticoagulant that inhibits vitamin K dependant epoxidase.
Low molecular weight heparins (LMWH)- warfarin cannot be used in pregnancy due to its teratogenicity. In these situations, LMWH is used for anticoagulation.
Aspirin- is an antiplatelet agent.
Hydroxychloroquine- is an immunomodulatory agent that can be used to prevent recurrent thrombosis.
Statins
Note: The only condition where corticosteroids are beneficial is catastrophic APS. It is a
life-threatening rapidly progressive thromboembolic disease involving simultaneously three or more organs. It is seen in very few patients.

Solution to Question 1:
Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with HLA DR4.
Solution to Question 2:
The atlantoaxial joint (C1 & C2) is the most commonly affected part of the spine in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
The joints in rheumatoid arthritis are bilaterally and symmetrically involved. The commonly affected joints are:
Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints
Wrists
Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints
Metatarsophalangeal joints (MTP) joints
Atlantoaxial joint
There is relative sparing of the DIP joint in rheumatoid arthritis. The involvement of DIP joints should direct suspicion towards osteoarthritis.
Solution to Question 3:
The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively.
Solution to Question 4:
The given image shows a swan-neck deformity seen in a patient with established rheumatoid arthritis(RA). Swan-neck deformity is hyperextension at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.
Some of the other small joint deformities of the hand in a patient with RA include:
Boutonnie■re deformity with flexion at the PIP joint and hyperextension at the DIP joint.
Z-line deformity with hyperextension at the DIP joint and subluxation of the 1st metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint.
Solution to Question 5:
The above image shows flexion at the PIP joint and extension in the DIP joints which is known as boutonniere deformity which is seen in rheumatoid arthritis(RA).
If the patient gives a history of pain/stiffness in the joints in the early hours of the day which usually decreases as the day progresses suggesting inflammatory arthritis and if it presents with predominant involvement of smaller joints, it is most likely a case of RA(option A).
It occurs due to the accumulation of inflammatory mediators which on increased joint mobility are flushed out due to increased blood supply.
Pain and stiffness in osteoarthritis (Option B) usually increase as the day progresses due to an increase in the activity of the joint. They typically present with nodules around the distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden nodes) and proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard nodes).
Solution to Question 6:
The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis(RA) is subcutaneous nodules.
The nodules are generally benign, non-tender, and firm, and occur in areas subjected to repeated trauma such as the forearm, sacral prominences, and Achilles tendon. They can also occur in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum.
Patients who have a history of cigarette smoking had early onset arthritic manifestations and tested positive for RA factor or ACPA are more likely to develop extra-articular manifestations. Other common extra-articular manifestations include secondary Sjogren's syndrome, interstitial lung disease, pulmonary nodules, and anemia. FELTY’S syndrome is a triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular RA.
Solution to Question 7:
The most common cardiac valvular lesion seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis is mitral regurgitation.
Solution to Question 8:
Hepatomegaly is not seen in Felty syndrome.
Felty syndrome is defined by the clinical triad of:
Neutropenia
Splenomegaly
Rheumatoid arthritis
It occurs in the late stages of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
Other syndromes associated with rheumatoid arthritis are:
Caplan’s syndrome- characterized by both rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis. It is associated with development of multiple peripheral basilar nodules in the lungs.
Secondary Sjogren’s syndrome- development of keratoconjunctivitis sicca or xerostomia in association with connective tissue disorder.
Solution to Question 9:
The most common histopathologic type of lymphoma seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis is diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL).
The risk of developing lymphoma increases if the patient has Felty’s syndrome or high levels of disease activity.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with hypoandrogenism.
It is characterized by low levels of serum testosterone, LH, and DHEA. The conditions associated with rheumatoid arthritis are:
Cardiovascular disease, congestive heart failure
Osteoporosis - hip fractures are more likely to occur
Ocular - keratoconjunctivitis sicca, episcleritis, scleritis, keratitis
Secondary Sjogren's syndrome
Hypoandrogenism in men and postmenopausal women
Solution to Question 11:
Low glucose (<60 mg/dL) is seen in the pleural effusion fluid of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
RA causes exudative pleural effusion and fulfills the Light’s criteria. High LDH and RA factor are found in the pleural fluid of RA patients. Less commonly, patients with RA may have a cholesterol
effusion. It is sterile and has a milky or opaque appearance. The milky appearance is due to the presence of cholesterol crystals and an elevated cholesterol level.
Light’s criteria is used to distinguish between exudative and transudative pleural effusions. An exudative pleural effusion satisfies at least one of the following criteria:
Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH > 0.6
Pleural fluid LDH more than 2/3rds upper limit of normal for serum

Articular erosions on X-ray is seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), but not in SLE.
Juxta-articular osteoporosis, swelling of PIP joint, and ulnar deviation can be seen in both SLE and RA.
Jaccoud arthropathy is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy characterized by the ulnar deviation of the second to 5th fingers with metacarpophalangeal joint subluxation seen in SLE.
The give X-ray shows Jaccoud's arthropathy:

Solution to Question 13:
The most common cause of death in patients with rheumatoid arthritis is cardiovascular disease.
Solution to Question 14:
The most appropriate marker to diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibody as it is the most specific marker for RA.
Anti-CCP, ESR, and CRP values correlate with the disease activity.
Rheumatoid factor can occur in other autoimmune diseases as well as in chronic infections. Therefore it is not considered specific.
Solution to Question 15:
Methotrexate which is a DMARD is the drug of choice for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis
(RA).
A combination regimen is used when there is a failure to achieve adequate improvement with methotrexate only.
Methotrexate in low doses causes adenosine release and suppresses joint inflammation. However, in high doses, it causes inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).
Solution to Question 16:
For further management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with worsening disease activity, the preferred therapy is a step-up to oral triple therapy with methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine. The addition of leflunomide or a biological (anti - TNF) to methotrexate is another alternative.
Ideally, the approach to a patient with early RA is aggressive. Methotrexate is always the first DMARD that the patient is started on, and if an adequate response is not observed within 3-6 months, a step up in therapy is made by adding on drugs.
For assessment of progression, composite indices like Disease Activity Score - 28 (DAS-28) can used.
Other options:
Option A: Changing the route of administration of methotrexate from oral to parenteral is not a part of step up
Option C: Priority is given to minimising the duration the patient is on steroids.
Option D: Anti -TNF agents (adalimumab, etanercept) are not recommended as a monotherapy, and are reserved for treatment in combination with DMARDs. This is due to the fact that the efficacy of monotherapy is lesser than that of DMARDs, and the adverse effects include increased risk of serious infections, re-activation of latent TB and opportunistic fungal infections. They are reserved for cases where there is a lack of response with the first line agents.
Solution to Question 17:
The Janus kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is tofacitinib.
Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are Janus kinase inhibitors used as monotherapy or combination therapy in rheumatoid arthritis.
Option A: Anakinra is an IL-1 antagonist. Option B: Tocilizumab is an IL-6 antagonist.
Option C: Abatacept acts by inhibiting co-stimulation of T cells.
Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Leflunomide should not be prescribed in pregnancy as it is a category X drug.
DMARDs classified as Category X in pregnancy (contraindicated in pregnancy) are:
Methotrexate
Leflunomide
Solution to Question 19:
IgM isotype is the rheumatoid factor (RF) most commonly measured in laboratories.
IgM RF has been found in 75–80% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis. IgG and IgA isotypes of RF have also been identified.
However, RF is not specific for rheumatoid arthritis and can also be found in the following conditions:
Primary Sjögren’s syndrome
Systemic lupus erythematosus
Subacute bacterial endocarditis
Hepatitis B and C
Solution to Question 20:
Iritis is seen in all the above conditions except rheumatoid arthritis. Iritis or iridocyclitis is also known as anterior uveitis.
Anterior uveitis is seen in:
Ankylosing spondylitis
Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis
Psoriasis
Reactive arthritis
Systemic lupus erythematosus
Leprosy
Posterior uveitis is seen in:
Vogt-Koyanagi Harada syndrome
Diseases like toxoplasmosis, cysticercosis, coccidioidomycosis, toxocariasis, histoplasmosis
Infections- Candida, Pneumocystis carinii, Cryptococcus, Aspergillus, and Cytomegalovirus
Cat-scratch disease, Whipple’s disease, and brucellosis Both anterior and posterior uveitis is seen in:
Sarcoidosis
Behcet's disease
Inflammatory bowel disease
Herpes infections, Syphilis, Lyme disease, TB, onchocerciasis Intermediate uveitis/pars planitis is seen in multiple sclerosis.
