Solution to Question 1:
Idiosyncratic or intrinsic asthma does not present in childhood. It typically shows a later onset of disease (adult-onset asthma).
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of aspirin-sensitivity asthma. It is closely associated with nasal polyps.
Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), also known as Samter’s triad or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It is a chronic medical condition that consists of:
Intrinsic asthma
Recurrent sinus disease with nasal polyps
Sensitivity to aspirin and other NSAIDs
It has normal serum IgE levels and a negative skin test for inhaled allergens.
Solution to Question 3:
The best way to diagnose bronchial asthma is by the demonstration of reversible obstruction of the airways. Following the administration of an inhaled beta 2 agonist, a 12% and 200 ml increase in the FEV1 demonstrates the reversibility of airway obstruction.
Options A and B: Chest X-ray and skin test for inhaled allergens are not diagnostic of bronchial asthma.
Option C: FEV1 values are measured to calculate FEV1/FVC ratio to diagnose any obstructive pathology and not specifically for asthma alone.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario of dyspnea, tachycardia along with the ABG analysis suggestive of respiratory alkalosis and chest-Xray showing hyperinflated lungs is pointing to a diagnosis
of acute severe asthma. A history of cough with fever is indicating a probable respiratory infection to have triggered the asthma exacerbation.
Features of acute severe asthma vs asthma with impending respiratory failure:
Note: The X-ray is not showing the features of ARDS and pneumothorax, hence they are ruled out as the right options.
Acute severe asthma
Asthma with impending respi ratory failure
Dyspneic, speaks in words
Mute patient
Agitated patient
Silent / confused patient
Heart rate > 120 /min, tachyc ardia
Relative bradycardia
Pulsus paradoxus present
Pulsus paradoxus absent (du e to respiratory muscle fatigu e)
Accessory muscles of respirat ion used
Paradoxical breathing is seen
Loud wheeze throughout the respiration
Silent chest
Peak expiratory flow rate < 4 0 ml/min
Peak expiratory flow rate < 2 5 ml/min
Respiratory alkalosis
Respiratory acidosis
Hyperventilation leading to l ow or normal PaCO2
Normal or rising PaCO2
Solution to Question 5:
Roflumilast is a phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitor used in the treatment of COPD, not asthma. Drugs used in the treatment of bronchial asthma
Bronchodilators
Beta-2 sympathomimetics: Salmeterol, formoterol
Methylxanthines: Theophylline, aminophylline
Anticholinergics: Ipratropium bromide, tiotropium bromide Anti-inflammatory
Corticosteroids (inhalational): Beclomethasone, budesonide, fluticasone
Corticosteroids (systemic): Prednisolone, hydrocortisone
Mast cell stabilizers: Sodium cromoglycate, ketotifen
Leukotriene antagonists: Montelukast, zafirlukast
Anti-IgE: Omalizumab
Anti-IL5: Mepolizumab, reslizumab
Anti-IL4 receptor: Dupilumab
Solution to Question 6:
Ketotifen is an example of a mast cell stabilizer, not leukotriene modifiers.
Leukotriene modifiers are a group of agents used for mild persistent asthma. They block
LT1-receptors thus causing reduced eosinophilic inflammation and causing bronchodilator. They include montelukast, zafirlukast, and zileuton.
Leukotriene modifiers are less effective than inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) in controlling asthma. They are used as add-on therapy in some patients whose asthma is not controlled with low doses of ICS.
Churg–Strauss syndrome (CSS) is a rare granulomatous small vessel vasculitis, that affects the heart, kidneys, peripheral nerves, etc. It occurs against a background of long-standing asthma and marked peripheral eosinophilia. Several cases of CSS are associated with the use of montelukast and zafirlukast.
Solution to Question 7:
The treatment of choice for type II brittle asthma is subcutaneous adrenaline.
Brittle asthma is a type of severe asthma where patients have very serious and often, life-threatening attacks despite appropriate therapy. It is of two types:
Type 1
Type 2
A persistent pattern of variab ility in PEFR (peak expirator y flow rate) readings
Generally normal or near-nor mal PEFR readings but few u npredictable exacerbations o ccur without an obvious trigg er
Oral steroids, infusion of bro nchodilators, and dietary excl usion of allergens may be hel pful
Respond only to subcutaneou s epinephrine
Solution to Question 8:
The treatment options for asthma do not include IL-1 antagonists (anakinra). Anakinra is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.
Cytokines mediating airway inflammation in asthma: IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, TGF-, and chemokines.
Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE. It is available for the treatment of children 6 years of age with documented allergen-induced asthma that is inadequately controlled by inhaled corticosteroids.
The new treatment options for asthma under clinical trial are:
Mepolizumab: anti–IL-5 antibody
Benralizumab: anti–IL-5 receptor antibody
Dupilumab: anti–IL-4 receptor antibody
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe asthma with impending respiratory failure. The best step in the management is immediate endotracheal intubation.
Features of asthma with impending respiratory failure are:
Mute or confused patient
Paradoxical breathin
Silent chest on auscultation
Relative bradycardia
Peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) <25ml/min
Arterial blood gas analysis shows respiratory acidosis.
Option A: Hyperbaric oxygen is given in CO poisoning and high altitude pulmonary edema. Option B: MDI with salbutamol and corticosteroids is only useful for acute severe asthma. Option D: Intravenous magnesium sulfate is not routinely used.
Solution to Question 10:
The rise in post-bronchodilator FEV1>12% is a feature of asthma, not COPD. It suggests reversible airflow obstruction.
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a chronic respiratory disease characterized by the presence of airflow obstruction that is partially reversible.
Cigarette smoking is the most common cause of COPD. Cigarette smoke exposure affects large airways, small airways, and alveoli:
Changes in large airways cause cough and sputum
Changes in small airways (2mm) and alveoli are responsible for physiologic alterations
The major site of increased resistance in most individuals with COPD is in airways 2 mm diameter.
Characteristic cellular changes include goblet cell metaplasia. Goblet cells are mucus-secreting cells that replace surfactant-secreting Club cells.
Nonuniform ventilation and ventilation-perfusion mismatching are characteristic of COPD.
Solution to Question 11:
Reid index is increased in chronic bronchitis.
Reid index is the ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the bronchial wall.

Solution to Question 12:
Clubbing is not a sign of COPD. Its presence should trigger the investigation of the causes of clubbing, particularly lung cancer.
Signs of COPD:
Signs of respiratory distress
Tripod posture - facilitates the use of accessory muscles of respiration
Pursed lip breathing - seen in emphysema
Central cyanosis
Signs of cachexia
Severe weight loss
Bitemporal wastin
Signs of hypercapnia (type 2 respiratory failure) - more common in chronic bronchitis
Barrel-shaped chest - increase in the anteroposterior diameter
Enlarged lung volumes
Positive Hoover's sign - paradoxical inward movement of the chest during inspiration
Early inspiratory coarse crackles
Normal vesicular breath sounds of reduced-intensity with bilaterally prolonged expiration
Blue bloaters - cyanotic (blue) and edematous (bloaters), chronic bronchitis predominant features
Pink puffers - thin, non-cyanotic (pink) at rest, and severely dyspneic (puffers), emphysema predominant features
Causes of clubbing:
Pulmonary
Bronchogenic carcinoma
Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
Chronic interstitial pneumonitis
Cystic fibrosis
Sarcoidosis
Gastrointestinal
Inflammatory bowel disease
Sprue
Neoplasms - esophagus, liver, bowel
Cardiovascular
Cyanotic congenital heart disease
Subacute bacterial endocarditis

Solution to Question 15:
The clinical picture is highly suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease(COPD). An increase in the residual volume is a feature of COPD.
COPD is defined as a chronic respiratory disease characterized by the presence of airflow obstruction that is partially reversible.
COPD is the clinical expression of abnormalities of airways and/or alveoli and includes:
Emphysema is defined pathologically as the abnormal and permanent dilation of airways distal to the terminal bronchiole, along with the destruction of their walls.
Chronic bronchitis is defined clinically as the presence of persistent cough with sputum production on most of the days for 3 months in 2 consecutive years.
Small airways diseases are conditions affecting airways of 2 mm, resulting in inflammation and narrowing of the same.
Solution to Question 16:
Body plethysmography is the best investigation to measure lung volume in an emphysematous patient with bullous lesions as seen on the X-ray.
To measure absolute lung volumes, two techniques are used:
Body plethysmography: It is used to measure the volume of any gas containing space in the thorax including bullae. It is accurate in both obstructive and restrictive diseases.
Inert gas dilution technique: It is used to measure the volume of regions that are well ventilated which excludes trapped gas or bullae. It is accurate in restrictive diseases only.
The amount of gas trapped in bullae can be measured by subtracting lung volumes measured by inert gas dilution technique from lung volume measured by body plethysmography.
Fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FENO) is a non-invasive test used in the diagnosis and monitoring of bronchial asthma. NO levels are increased in asthmatics and related to the eosinophilic inflammation in the airways.
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical diagnosis is suggestive of COPD and the underlying pathological change is likely to be emphysema. It is associated with a decreased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO).
Emphysema is defined pathologically as the abnormal and permanent dilation of airways distal to the terminal bronchiole, along with the destruction of their walls. This leads to hyperinflation due to air trapping and impaired diffusion of gases.
Pulmonary function tests in COPD:
TLC: Normal or increased
FEV1: Decreased (<80% predicted)
FVC: Decreased
FEV1/FVC: Decreased
DLCO: Decreased
Diseases associated with lowered DLCO:
Emphysema
Interstitial Lung disease
Primary pulmonary hypertension
Note - Bronchial asthma is associated with an increased DLCO.

Solution to Question 20:
Glucocorticoids are used during an exacerbation of COPD. They hasten recovery and reduce the chances of future exacerbations.
Exacerbations are episodes of increased dyspnoea and cough, with a change in the amount and character of sputum. They are often triggered by an infection with one-third of cases having a viral etiology. They may or may not have other signs of illness such as fever, myalgias, and sore
throat. In severe cases, they may present with pneumonia and congestive heart failure.
Note: While oral glucocorticoids are contraindicated in long-term treatment due to side effects, they are used for acute exacerbation of COPD.
Solution to Question 21:
Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) should be the first mode of ventilation used in COPD patients with acute respiratory failure provided there are no absolute contraindications.
This approach improves gas exchange, reduces work of breathing and the need for intubation, decreases hospitalization duration and enhances overall survival outcomes.
Invasive positive pressure ventilation is only considered after failure of NIPPV, resulting in severe respiratory distress, life threatening hypoxemia, severe hypercarbia and/or acidosis, markedly impaired mental status, respiratory arrest or hemodynamic instability (Option B).
Apart from NIPPV, short-acting inhaled beta 2 agonists (albuterol, salbutamol) with or without short-acting anticholinergics (ipratropium) and Long-acting anticholinergics (tiotropium) are recommended as the initial bronchodilators. Maintenance therapy with long-acting beta 2 agonists (formoterol) must be started as soon as possible.
Systemic corticosteroids are useful in the treatment of acute exacerbations of COPD as they reduce airway inflammation and improve lung function over time. However, the effects are not immediate. NIPPV on the other hand provides immediate relief to the patient and reduces the work of breathing. Therefore, it would not be the best choice in this case. (Option C)
Antibiotics can also be considered, as they reduce duration of hospitalisation. Treatment is given for 5 days.
Permissive hypercapnia refers to a ventilation strategy where tidal volume is reduced in order to avoid hyperinflation-associated lung trauma. It is not preferred at the initial presentation. It is only permitted once invasive PPV is started following NIPPV failure (Option D)
An exacerbation of COPD is defined as an event characterized by dyspnea and/or cough and sputum that worsen over < 14 days. Exacerbations of COPD are often associated with increased local and systemic inflammation caused by airway infection, pollution, or other insults to the lungs.
Solution to Question 22:
The given clinical scenario along with the ABG and X-ray findings is suggestive of acute exacerbation of COPD with respiratory failure. The best initial step of management is low-flow humidified oxygen.
Oxygen supplementation is a crucial component of acute therapy. Administering O2 should target a SpO2- 88-92% or PaO2- 60-70 mmHg. This helps to minimize the risk of worsening hypercapnia with excess supplemental oxygen.
The given ABG shows respiratory acidosis as PaCO2 >45 mmHg, and pH<7.35. In respiratory acidosis, a trial of non-invasive ventilation is given. Hence, low-flow humidified oxygen is the first step in management.
Option B: High flow oxygen causes dryness, crusting epistaxis, and damages the lung hence not used.
Option C: Salbutamol and budesonide nebulization are not effective as initial management in exacerbation of COPD with respiratory failure.
Option D: Methylxanthines are not recommended in the management of acute exacerbations due to their side effect profiles.
Solution to Question 23:
Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation (NIPPV) is contraindicated in cardiovascular instability. NIPPV can impede venous filling of the heart, decrease cardiac output, and worsen/precipitate hypotension. Moreover, in unstable states with impending cardiovascular collapse, invasive ventilation is preferred.
Indications of NIPPV:
Apnea - central and obstructive
Central hypoventilation syndrome
Neuromuscular and chest wall disorders
Respiratory failure - PaCO2 >45 mmH Contraindications of NIPPV:
Cardiovascular instability
Impaired mental status or inability to cooperate
Copious secretions or the inability to clear secretions
Craniofacial abnormalities
Trauma precluding effective fitting of the mask
Solution to Question 24:
Oral glucocorticoids are not used in the long-term treatment of COPD because of an unfavorable benefit/risk ratio.
Chronic use of glucocorticoids is associated with significant side effects, including osteoporosis, weight gain, cataracts, glucose intolerance, and increased risk of infection.
Treatment of COPD:
Smoking cessation
Anticholinergic agents- Ipratropium bromide
Beta Agonists- Long-acting inhaled  agonists, such as salmeterol or formoterol are commonly used.
Methylxanthines- theophylline produces improvements in expiratory flow rates and vital capacity.
Phosphodiesterase inhibitors - roflumilast is used when FEV1<50%.
Antibiotics- macrolides like azithromycin reduce exacerbations when used over one year
N-acetylcysteine has been used in patients with COPD for both its mucolytic and antioxidant properties
Oxygen therapy
Non-pharmacologic therapies:
Lung volume reduction surgery
Lung transplantation
Pneumonia

Solution to Question 1:
Legionella pneumonia presents as both typical and atypical pneumonia.
Pneumonia is an infection of the lung parenchyma. Pneumonia that develops outside the hospital setting is commonly referred to as community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). There are two types of community-acquired pneumonia.
Typical Pneumonia
Atypical Pneumonia
Solution to Question 2:
Home split air-conditioning units do not use water to cool the air, so they are not a risk factor for legionella transmission.
The following are the risk factors for transmission of legionella:
Contamination of water supplies in large facilities such as hospitals, hotels, apartment buildings
Contaminated water sources such as hot tubs, birthing pools, fountains, whirlpools
Water using machinery- cooling towers, evaporative condensers, humidifiers
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by legionella. Clinical features of Legionnaire's disease:
High-grade-fever( >104 F)
Cough with scanty sputum
Extrapulmonary manifestations involve
gastrointestinal- diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
neurological- most common-confusion, headache, encephalopathy
Relative bradycardia
Occurrence of illness in an environment in which water supply is at risk of contamination
Failure to respond to beta-lactams and aminoglycoside antibiotics Investigations:
On gram-staining of the sputum, numerous neutrophils with no organisms
Hyponatremia
Elevated liver enzymes
Solution to Question 4:
A urinary antigen detection test is recommended for the diagnosis of Legionella pneumonia. The sensitivity (70%) and specificity (99%) of the test are high.
The test can detect antigen even after the initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy. Urinary antigen detection test can also be used for Streptococcus pneumonia but is not used due to the availability of better alternatives.
Other investigations for Legionella:
DFA (direct fluorescent antibody)- is highly specific but not sensitive
Culture- Gold standard, BCYE media is used
DNA detection with PCR
Treatment: Drugs of choice are azithromycin and respiratory fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin,
moxifloxacin).
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario along with chest X-ray and lab values is suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. The blood investigations show decreased hemoglobin, elevated LDH, and elevated unconjugated bilirubin suggestive of hemolytic anemia.
Mycoplasma is the most common bacteria causing atypical pneumonia and the second most common cause of pneumonia.
Clinical Presentation:
Pulmonary manifestations:
URTI- tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis
Pneumonia( seen in only 10% patients)
Extrapulmonary manifestations:
Cold agglutinin disease( IgM mediated autoimmune hemolytic anemia)
Erythema multiforme or Steven Johnson syndrome
Arthralgia with adenopathy
Guillain Barre Syndrome
Myocarditis
Pericarditis
Encephalitis
Bullous myringitis
Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery.
Azithromycin is the drug of choice. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.
Solution to Question 6:
Cefotaxime is not the drug of choice for the treatment of Mycoplasma pneumonia. Cefotaxime is a cell-wall synthesis inhibitor, hence it is not effective on M.pnemoniae as they lack a cell wall.
Investigations:
PCR of respiratory secretions
Chest X-ray shows-
Patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery
Diffuse peribronchial and perivascular interstitial infiltrates
Airspace consolidation
Reticulonodular opacification
HRCT shows- areas of ground-glass attenuation
On PPLO agar (Dienes method) shows- fried-egg appearance.
The diagnosis is made by serology/PCR. Azithromycin is the drug of choice for management. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray are suggestive of lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae.
Klebsiella pneumonia is associated mostly with alcoholics and shows upper lobe involvement. The patients present with red-currant jelly sputum.
Chest X-ray shows:
Cavitation
Pneumatocele (also seen in S. aureus)
Bulging fissure sign: Classically seen in Klebsiella pneumonia. It represents expansive lobar consolidation causing fissural bulging; or displacement of copious amounts of inflammatory exudates within the affected parenchyma. It is seen in any space-occupying process in the lung such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and lung tumors.

Solution to Question 8:
The most likely causative agent of pneumonia in an infant with X-ray showing pneumatoceles
(air-filled cysts within lung parenchyma) is Staphylococcus aureus.
In newborns and infants, S. aureus is a significant cause of severe respiratory tract infections, presenting with dyspnea, fever, and respiratory failure. Community-acquired infections are often preceded by viral infections, most commonly influenza. Among adults, nosocomial S. aureus pulmonary infections are frequently observed in intubated patients within intensive care units.
S. aureus often causes necrotizing pneumonitis that may be associated with complications such as pneumothorax and empyema.
Pneumatocoele can also be caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, E. coli, group A streptococci, Klebsiella pneumoniae, etc. However, Staphylococcus aureus is most commonly implicated.
Other options:
Option A: Klebsiella pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. Patients present with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum. Classic chest X-ray findings include upper lobe consolidation, classically on the right side, cavitation, and bulging fissure sign.
The following image shows bulging fissure sign:

Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia. Patients with pneumococcal pneumonia present with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. On examination, the involved lobes are dull to percussion, bronchial breath sounds, and crackles are heard on auscultation.
The following image shows right lower lobe consolidation:

Option C: Mycoplasma pneumoniae causes atypical pneumonia. Patients present with dry cough, fever, chills, malaise, and upper respiratory tract symptoms. On auscultation, wheezes or rales are heard. Chest X-ray shows peribronchial pneumonia with prominent bronchial markings, interstitial infiltration, and atelectasis.
The below chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery:

Solution to Question 9:
The best biomarker for lobar pneumonia is procalcitonin.
The most commonly used biomarkers of severe inflammation are C-reactive protein (CRP) and procalcitonin (PCT). Levels of these acute phase reactants increase in the presence of bacterial pathogens. PCT testing distinguishes between bacterial (mostly lobar pneumonia) and viral infection to decide the need for antibacterial therapy or discontinuation of treatment.
CRP, fibrinogen, and serum amyloid A are other acute phase reactants.
Solution to Question 10:
Among the options, systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg (Option D) is not a component of CURB-65. CURB65 includes blood pressure, systolic 90 mmHg or diastolic 60 mmHg.
CURB-65 criteria is used to assess the severity of illness in a case community-acquired pneumonia. It includes confusion (C), urea >7 mmol/L (U), respiratory rate 30/min (R), blood pressure systolic 90 mmHg or diastolic 60 mmHg (B) and an age of 65 years.
Pneumonia severity index (PSI) is another index to assess the severity of illness and the risk of mortality in the case of pneumonia. It includes 20 variables and depending on the score, patients are assigned into one of the 5 classes.
Class, I, II, III - at low risk of death and can be treated on an outpatient basis Class IV & V require hospitalization
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia and the patient belongs to a CURB-65 score of 3. The patient can be best managed by a combination of azithromycin and ceftriaxone in an ICU setting. After culture sensitivity, specific management is done.
Solution to Question 12:
The Empiric treatment of choice for ICU in patients with suspected CA-MRSA is:
-lactam (e.g., ceftriaxone) + Fluoroquinolone/Azithromycin PLUS
Linezolid / Vancomycin with or without Clindamycin to cover CA-MRSA
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia due to aspiration. The drug of choice is clindamycin as anaerobes are implicated.
Anaerobes play a significant role only when an episode of aspiration has occurred days to weeks before presentation for pneumonia. The combination of an unprotected airway (e.g., in patients with alcohol or drug overdose or a seizure disorder) and significant gingivitis constitutes the major risk factor.
Anaerobic pneumonia is often complicated by abscess formation and significant empyemas or parapneumonic effusions.
Solution to Question 14:
The most likely diagnosis in a case of pneumonia in a HIV positive patient, along with the presence of fever, and non-productive cough with radiographic findings of diffuse interstitial infiltrates and symmetric perihilar involvement is Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). A characteristic feature of PCP is retrosternal chest pain, which worsens on inspiration and is described as sharp or burning.
It is important to note that even though the incidence of PCP is the highest at CD4+ counts of
<200/L (80%), it can be seen in patients with higher counts. Other options:
Option D: Tuberculosis (TB) should be considered as a possibility in cases of pneumonia in people living with HIV. However, the absence of hilar lymph node involvement, non-productive cough, and no extrapulmonary (pleural, pericardial, lymphatic) features are not consistent with tuberculosis.
TB can occur at any stage of HIV infection. In the early stages, pulmonary TB appears typically with upper-lobe infiltrates and cavitation. In advanced HIV infection, with CD4+ T-cell count below 200/L, TB presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, minimal cavitation, pleural effusion,
and lymphadenopathy. Extrapulmonary TB is fairly common in HIV, with it being documented in 40-60% of cases.

Option A: Staphylococcal pneumonia most commonly presents with a productive cough, and radiologically presents with pneumatoceles (cavitations)

Option B: Patients with pneumococcal pneumonia also present with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. Imaging usually shows lobar involvement.

Solution to Question 15:
Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole combination (commonly known as cotrimoxazole) is the first-line drug for both prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii infections in immunocompromised patients.
Cotrimoxazole acts by causing a sequential block of folate metabolism. CD4+ T cell counts below 200 cells/L are an indication to start prophylaxis.
Solution to Question 16:
Aerosolised pentamidine is not used in the treatment of PCP. It is used in PCP prophylaxis. Diagnosis of PCP:
Histopathological staining of induced sputum examination
Bronchoscopy with BAL (most sensitive)
Elevated LDH
Treatment and Prophylaxis:
Drug of choice- trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)
IV pentamidine- treatment of choice for severe disease in the patient unable to tolerate TMP-SMX
Glucocorticoids- indicated if PaO2 <70 mmHg or with an A–a gradient >35 mmHg
Other drugs used- dapsone/pyrimethamine + leucovorin, clindamycin/primaquine, and atovaquone
Aerosolised pentamidine is an alternative used in PCP prophylaxis.
Prophylaxis is indicated when CD4+ T cell count <200/uL ( CD4 cell %<15), recent oropharyngeal candidiasis, and prior PCP infection.
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray and gram-staining is suggestive of Nocardiosis. The drug of choice is cotrimoxazole.
Nocardia is a gram-positive and acid-fast bacteria. Nocardia pneumonia has a sub-acute presentation with mostly cough with thick sputum and fever. Generally, hemoptysis is uncommon. Chest radiography shows nodular infiltrations involving bilateral lung fields.
Extrapulmonary manifestations are common, the brain is the most commonly involved organ. It is associated with dense bilateral infiltrates with cavitating nodules and subacute brain abscesses.
The drug of choice is cotrimoxazole. Severe disease is treated with a combination of cotrimoxazole, amikacin, and ceftriaxone, or imipenem.
Note: Mnemonic SNAP:
Sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim (Cotrimoxazole) is the drug of choice for Nocardia. For Actinomyces, Penicillins are the drugs of choice.
Solution to Question 18:
Azithromycin is the drug of choice for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) in an OPD setup.
Outpatient management of CAP:
For previously healthy patients who have not taken antibiotics within the past 3 months:
A macrolide – Azithromycin, 500 mg orally as a first dose and then 250 mg orally daily for 4 days, or 500 mg orally daily for 3 days, or
Clarithromycin, 500 mg orally twice a day; or
Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day
For patients with such comorbid medical conditions as chronic heart, lung, liver, or kidney disease, diabetes mellitus, alcoholism, malignancy, asplenia, immunosuppressant conditions or use of immunosuppressive drugs or use of antibiotics within the previous 3 months:
A respiratory fluoroquinolone (moxifloxacin, 400 mg orally daily; gemifloxacin, 320 mg orally daily; levofloxacin, 750 mg orally daily) or
A macrolide (as above) plus a beta-lactam (amoxicillin, 1 g orally three times a day; amoxicillin-clavulanate, 2 g orally twice a day; cefuroxime, 500 mg orally twice a day).
In regions with a high rate (> 25%) of infection with high level (MIC  16 mcg/mL) macrolide-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae, consider the use of alternative agents listed in (2) for patients with comorbidities.
Other options: Vancomycin, Ceftriaxone, and Streptomycin are administered parenterally, and hence, not appropriate for outpatient management.
Solution to Question 19:
Among the given options, Acinetobacter species is the most commonly isolated organism in cases of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). VAP develops in a mechanically ventilated patient >48 hours after endotracheal intubation.
The organisms causing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) significantly vary from one hospital to another. However, the organisms that frequently cause VAP in hospital settings are Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Acinetobacter sp., Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, and gram-negative rods (Enterobacter species, K. pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli).
Three factors distinguish nosocomial pneumonia from community-acquired pneumonia:
Different infectious agent
Different antibiotic susceptibility patterns, specifically, a higher incidence of drug resistance
Poorer underlying health status of patients putting them at risk for more severe infections
Within 48 hours of admission, 75% of seriously ill hospitalized patients have their upper airway colonized with organisms from the hospital environment. Impaired cellular and mechanical defense mechanisms in the lungs of hospitalized patients raise the risk of infection after aspiration has occurred.
VAP patients may be infected with Acinetobacter species and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia. Anaerobic organisms (Bacteroides, anaerobic streptococci, Fusobacterium) may also cause pneumonia in the hospitalized patient.
Solution to Question 20:
Pleural Fluid Protein >4 gm/dL is not an indication of tube thoracostomy.
Parapneumonic effusion is pleural effusion associated with bacterial pneumonia, lung abscess, or bronchiectasis. When it worsens, it can result in the collection of frank pus in the pleural space. This is known as empyema.
Risk factors include diabetes, immunosuppression, alcoholism, cancer, and poor dental hygiene. Investigations:
Chest X-ray:
Loculations or encystments (complicated parapneumonic effusion)
Intrapleural air-fluid level (bronchopulmonary fistula)
Parenchymal infiltrations (underlying pneumonia)
Ultrasound: Shows echogenic pleural fluid with septations and helps in characterizing the effusion
Pleural fluid analysis:
Exudative neutrophilic effusion
Low pH <7.2, low glucose <60 mg/dL, high LDH >1000 IU/L in complicated parapneumonic effusion
CECT: Split pleura sign seen in empyema Treatment:
Antibiotics: Tailored according to the microorganism
Therapeutic thoracocentesis
Tube thoracostomy is indicated if:
Pleural fluid pH <7.2
Frank pus
Microorganism isolated in Gram stain or culture of pleural fluid

Solution to Question 1:
The most common interstitial lung disease (ILD) is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
ILD refers to the remodeling of interstitial space, the region between the epithelium and endothelium. The main pathology is fibrosis, mediated by TGF-ß and platelet-derived growth factor.

Solution to Question 2:
The above HRCT shows a honeycomb appearance of lung parenchyma due to interstitial fibrosis in a restrictive lung disorder that is suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). Inspiratory coarse crackles are not a feature of interstitial lung disease.
Auscultating a patient with ILD will reveal bilateral basal end-inspiratory fine crackles also called velcro crackles or rales.
Patients with interstitial lung disease usually present with a non-productive cough and breathlessness on exertion. Clubbing may be seen on examination, especially in advanced cases.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario along with the HRCT findings are suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). FEV1/FVC ratio >0.7 and decreased DLCO are likely to be seen in the PFT. A history of swollen joints and early morning stiffness hints at rheumatoid arthritis. It is associated with the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern of ILD.
In ILD, restrictive pattern is seen on pulmonary function test, which is characterized by:
Decreased total lung capacity (TLC)
Decreased forced vital capacity (FVC)
Decreased residual volumes (RV)
Decreased DLCO (diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide)
FEV1/FVC ratio - normal or increased, >0.7
Solution to Question 4:
Ground-glass opacities on HRCT are not a characteristic finding in UIP.
Honeycombing, loss of lung architecture, traction bronchiectasis, and basilar subpleural reticular opacities are seen in UIP pattern of ILD on HRCT.
Solution to Question 5:
Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) is also known as Hamman–Rich syndrome.
AIP is a rare, idiopathic, fulminant interstitial lung disease (ILD) that is similar in presentation to ARDS. It is often preceded by a viral upper respiratory tract infection.
Histologically, it shows diffuse alveolar damage. HRCT shows bilateral patchy, ground-glass opacities. Lung biopsy shows diffuse alveolar damage with hyaline formation.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing sclerodactyly suggestive of scleroderma along with the HRCT findings point to a diagnosis of non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP). It is characterized by homogeneous interstitial involvement.
NSIP is often associated with connective tissue disease but can also be drug-induced. The common drugs implicated in NSIP are:
Bleomycin
Busulfan
Methotrexate
Amiodarone
It usually affects middle-aged woman who have never smoked. There is uniformity of interstitial involvement across the biopsy section, and this may be predominantly cellular or fibrosing. HRCT shows homogenous involvement with symmetrical ground-glass opacities.
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) responds to steroids. Other treatment modalities include cytotoxic drugs like azathioprine or cyclophosphamide and also biologics like rituximab.
Solution to Question 7:
Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is not related to smoking.
It is usually seen in young females with tuberous sclerosis. LAM can lead to pneumothorax or chylous effusions.
Pulmonary function testing usually reveals an obstructive or mixed obstructive-restrictive pattern. HRCT shows thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma.
The smoking-related ILDs are:
DIP - Desquamating interstitial pneumonia.
RB-ILD - Respiratory bronchiolitis associated ILD.
LCH - Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
Solution to Question 8:
The given scenario is suggestive of pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). It is a smoking-related ILD that typically affects young adults. Smoking cessation leads to improvement in the condition.
The specific immunohistochemical markers for LCH are CD1a and langerin (CD207). On electron microscopy, the presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is characteristic (as shown below).

HRCT shows bilateral irregularly shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe. There is a risk of spontaneous pneumothorax in this condition due to cyst rupture.
Solution to Question 9:
Chunky, gelatinous, PAS-positive sputum is a feature of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP).
PAP is a condition characterized by the accumulation of surfactants in alveoli and terminal airways. It can be due to impaired clearance or abnormal production of surfactants.
PAP can be of three forms:
Primary (most common): There is impaired GM-CSF-dependent surfactant clearance by the alveolar macrophages. It can be due to:
Autoantibodies against GM-CSF (acquired/idiopathic/autoimmune PAP)
Mutation in GM-CSF receptors (hereditary PAP)
Secondary: There is a reduction in the number or ability of alveolar macrophages that causes impaired surfactant clearance. It can be due to:
Silicosis
Immunodeficiency disorders
Hematopoietic disorders and malignancies
Congenital: It affects neonates and children. There is abnormal surfactant production due to mutation in the genes coding for:
Surfactant protein B
Surfactant protein C
ATP binding cassette protein member 3
About 30% of patients are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients can have persistent dry cough, progressive dyspnea, and pleuritic chest pain
ray shows bilateral, diffuse opacities and HRCT shows a crazy-paving pattern (as shown below). The treatment is whole lung lavage.

Solution to Question 10:
Farmer’s lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused due to exposure to mouldy hay, which contains thermophilic actinomycetes, principally Thermopolyspora polyspora.
Solution to Question 11:
The given X-ray shows irregular opacities, which appear to be pleural thickenings i.e., pleural plaques. The sign along with a history of working in the cement industry suggests a diagnosis of asbestosis.
Workers of the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first.
The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis-related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques calcify resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on the X-ray. This is the “holly leaf sign”.
Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years). They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes.
Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
The image below shows thick plueral plaques.

Solution to Question 12:
Workers in the roofing industry are exposed to asbestos. Lung cancer (of all histologic types) is the most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure.
Smoking along with asbestos exposure multiplies the risk to a great extent. Cough and hemoptysis are common presentations.
Pleural mesothelioma is the most specific cancer associated with asbestos exposure, but not the most common. Smoking does not seem to be associated with mesothelioma. Pleuritic chest pain or a mass on the radiographic image are common presentations.
Solution to Question 13:
Silicosis is a common concern for people working in granite mining industries.
Silica is found in rock, granite, slate, and sandstone. People working in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, glass and cement manufacturing, and quarrying are exposed to silica. The active molecule that causes silicosis is free silica or crystalline silica (quartz).
Silicosis can present as:
Acute silicosis - due to heavy exposure in closed spaces and they manifest within 2 years.
Chronic silicosis (simple silicosis) - due to long-term (10 to 30 years), less intense exposure.
Complicated silicosis- simple silicosis may progress to complicated silicosis that presents with chronic cough and progressive dyspnoea on exertion.
Note: Silicosis is the most common pnemoconiosis in the world.
Solution to Question 14:
A history of working in the sandblasting industry for about a year without PPE suggests a heavy exposure to silica. This along with the CT finding of bilateral nodules, interstitial fibrosis, and crazy pavement pattern suggests a diagnosis of acute silicosis.
Acute silicosis is seen rarely. It manifests within 2 years of heavy exposure. Common presentations are dyspnoea and hypoxemia.
The X-ray may show diffuse miliary infiltrates or consolidation. HRCT may also show bilateral centrilobular nodules and ground-glass opacification. Bronchoalveolar lavage yields a
PAS-positive milky white fluid.
Solution to Question 15:
In this scenario, the man works in the stone cutting industry, indicating exposure to silica. He is expected to have less intense, long term exposure owing to a few but substandard measures to control exposure to silica. Such individuals are more likely to develop simple silicosis. These patients are asymptomatic, and HRCT shows small round opacities in the upper lobes.
This can progress to complicated silicosis. Here, the nodules coalesce and form masses leading to impairment of lung function. They present with chronic cough and progressive dyspnoea on exertion. This may progress further to cause progressive massive fibrosis.
PFT shows a mixed obstructive and restrictive pattern. Calcification of hilar lymph nodes is seen in a few cases, called eggshell calcification. This is depicted in the image below.

Option A: A crazy pavement pattern is seen with acute silicosis.
Option C: Thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma are seen in pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis (LAM).
Option D: Pleural plaques are seen in patients suffering from asbestosis.
Solution to Question 16:
Silicosis is associated with an increased incidence of tuberculosis.
Silica causes pulmonary alveolar macrophage dysfunction and hence, patients with silicosis have a higher risk of developing lung infections from organisms like M. Tuberculosis, atypical mycobacteria and fungi.
Radiographic imaging of silicotuberculosis shows cavitation.
Solution to Question 17:
Caplan's syndrome also called rheumatoid pneumoconiosis, is a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis.
It manifests as pneumoconiotic nodules along with features of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis. Caplan syndrome was first described in coal miners and later in patients with silicosis too.
Option C: Hilar adenopathy, polyarthritis, and erythema nodosum are characteristic of Lofgren syndrome.
Option D: Arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis are characteristic of Reiter syndrome.
Solution to Question 18:
The above characteristic pattern of symptoms is called Monday fever or Monday chest tightness and is due to byssinosis.
Byssinosis is seen commonly in cotton factory workers due to cotton dust exposure. It is also caused due to flax, hemp, and jute dust.
It is due to occupational hypersensitivity reaction with symptoms occurring (or recurring) on the first day of the workweek and diminishing by the weekend due to development of tolerance.
Solution to Question 19:
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) pattern of ILD is the most common pulmonary manifestation in systemic sclerosis.
The CT scan of NSIP shows ground-glass opacities. It responds to steroids given along with azathioprine or cyclophosphamide.
Other connective tissue diseases associated with ILD:
Rheumatoid arthritis
Sjögren syndrome
Dermatopolymyositis
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
Solution to Question 20:
The given clinical scenario and the microscopic image showing abundant black-colored pigment within the macrophages of lung parenchyma is characteristic of pulmonary anthracosis/coal worker's pneumoconiosis. It may give rise to centrilobular emphysema.
The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages. They accumulate in the connective tissue along lymphatics or in lymphoid tissue along the bronchi or the hilum, which causes the blackening of the tissues. Aggregates of carbon dust are present as coal macules or nodules which consist of carbon-laden macrophages.
It is commonly seen in people who work in environments where there is high air pollution with carbon particles, such as coal mines. It is usually benign and less than 10% of the cases develop progressive massive fibrosis which may lead to pulmonary dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale. Coal workers may also develop emphysema or chronic bronchitis, independent of smoking.
Unlike asbestosis, this condition does not predispose to cancer.

question_text:
a
Solution to Question 1:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis. HRCT is the investigation of choice - most specific.
Bronchiectasis is a suppurative lung disease with abnormal and irreversible dilatation of the bronchi. It is an end-stage condition of various diseases (infections, congenital or autoimmune disorders) that result in the destruction of the bronchial wall and its surrounding supporting tissues.
Ried’s classification divides bronchiectasis into 3 types based on the phenotype of the affected bronchi:
Cylindrical or tubular (most common)
Saccular or varicose
Cystic
Traction bronchiectasis is a type of bronchiectasis seen in conditions causing extensive pulmonary fibrosis (tuberculosis, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis). The mechanical traction due to fibrosis pulls apart the adjacent bronchi, making them distorted and abnormally dilated. There is no destruction of the bronchial wall.
Clinically, they have a chronic productive cough, clubbing, crackles, and rhonchi.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario and the CT showing signet ring sign is suggestive of bronchiectasis which can be due to cystic fibrosis.
A history of repeated chest infections is an indication of cystic fibrosis and a major risk factor for the development of bronchiectasis.
Solution to Question 3:
Lung cancer is not a known complication of bronchiectasis.
Complications of bronchiectasis include:
Massive hemoptysis
Empyema and lung abscess
Respiratory failure
Pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale
Secondary amyloidosis (AA type)
Chronic and recurrent infections lead to secondary amyloidosis (AA type) and involve the kidneys.
Solution to Question 4:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis secondary to a non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection. Mucolytic dornase is recommended routinely in cystic fibrosis (CF)-related bronchiectasis but not in non-CF bronchiectasis.
Macrolides (azithromycin or clarithromycin) combined with rifampicin and ethambutol are used in the treatment of non-CF bronchiectasis.
Treatment of bronchiectasis:
Antibiotic therapy: This is used to treat exacerbations and is given for 10-14 days. Commonly administered antibiotics include:
Amoxicillin or clarithromycin: First-line drugs
Ciprofloxacin: For Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Airway clearance:
Postural drainage: This is done by gravity-assisted positioning of the patient and chest hysiotherapy.
Mucolytic treatment: only in cystic fibrosis patients
Normal or hypertonic saline (3%) nebulization
Humidified air inhalation
Drugs like N-acetylcysteine or carbocysteine
Others:
Inhaled bronchodilators like long-acting 2 agonists and anticholinergics
Long-term oxygen therapy: In patients with chronic respiratory failure
Pulmonary rehabilitation
Adequate hydration
Resection of a focal area of suppuration, lung transplantation: In refractory cases
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. Abnormalities in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein (CFTR) gene lead to defective chloride transport and not calcium transport.
Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting the epithelial cells of various exocrine glands of the body. It is caused by mutations in the gene coding for CFTR protein. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.
The most prominent clinical features of cystic fibrosis are chronic respiratory diseases (fever,
productive cough, recurrent lung infections) and pancreatic insufficiency (steatorrhea).
Male patients with cystic fibrosis usually have infertility due to congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in azoospermia.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In these patients, sperm count is most likely to be decreased.
Male patients with cystic fibrosis usually have infertility due to congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in obstructive azoospermia.
Option A: Sweat chloride levels are elevated (60 mEq/L) due to abnormalities in the CFTR protein leading to defective chloride transport.
Option B: Serum bicarbonate levels are increased due to excessive loss of salt in the sweat resulting in hypochloremic alkalosis.
Option D: Immunoreactive trypsinogen levels are increased due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Measurement of these levels is a diagnostic screening test in newborns.
Solution to Question 7:
DNA analysis is used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis in patients with equivocal (one normal and one abnormal value) or frankly normal sweat chloride values.
The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:
Presence of
Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
Positive newborn screening or
A sibling with cystic fibrosis
Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by
Two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or
Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference Option A: 72-hour fecal fat is not used in the diagnosis of CF.
Option B: Measuring the levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen is a screening test in newborns.
Option D: Trans epithelial nasal potential difference measurement can be used as an adjunct to sweat test, but it has limited availability and is predominantly used as a research tool.
Solution to Question 8:
Male infertility is typical in Kartagener syndrome, but not a component of the triad. Kartagener’s syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad of:
Situs inversus
Chronic sinusitis
Bronchiectasis
Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.
As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen, its absence, will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality.
Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).
Solution to Question 9:
Kartagener’s syndrome is a type of primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad of
Situs inversus
Chronic sinusitis
Bronchiectasis
Infertility in Kartagener’s syndrome is due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function), not azoospermia (complete absence of spermatozoa in ejaculate).
Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis. As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen, its absence will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality.
Approximately half of the patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia have Kartagener syndrome.

The most common cause of lung abscess is aspirated oropharyngeal secretion.
Lung abscess represents necrosis and cavitation of the lung following microbial infection. They are broadly divided into two categories:
Primary lung abscesses: usually arise from aspiration, often caused principally by anaerobic bacteria (most common)
Secondary lung abscesses: arise in the setting of an underlying condition, such as a
ost-obstructive process (e.g., a bronchial foreign body or tumor) or a systemic process (e.g., HIV infection or another immunocompromising condition)

The right lung is affected more commonly than the left because the right mainstem bronchus is less angulated.
In secondary abscesses, the location of the abscess may vary with the underlying cause.

The patients usually present with complaints of fever, cough with sputum production, and chest pain. Patients with putrid lung abscesses may report foul-smelling sputum. Patients with chronic lung abscesses usually have a history of night sweats, fatigue, and anemia.

Solution to Question 16:
The most common presentation of inhalation anthrax is hemorrhagic mediastinitis, which is seen in 38% of the patients.
Inhalational anthrax also known as wool sorter’s disease is caused by Bacillus anthracis. Infection usually occurs among workers handling contaminated animal wool, hair, and skin in textile and tanning industries.
Patients present with malaise, fever, cough, shortness of breath & headache. B. anthracis spores are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages and transported to mediastinal lymph nodes. Hemorrhagic necrosis of the thoracic lymph nodes draining the lung results in hemorrhagic mediastinitis. Pulmonary infiltrates, mediastinal widening, and pleural effusion are other findings.
Treatment of inhalation anthrax includes a combination of intravenous ciprofloxacin and clindamycin for at least 14 days, antitoxins (Raxibacumab, Obiltoxaximab), anthrax immunoglobulins and steroids (if associated meningitis is present).
Prophylaxis with ciprofloxacin (500mg twice daily for 2 months) is recommended for anyone at high risk of inhalational exposure to anthrax spores.
Solution to Question 17:
Central bronchiectasis is a typical feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), not distal bronchiectasis.
ABPA is an eosinophilic pulmonary disorder caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonization of airways by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma (~2.5% of patients) or cystic fibrosis (up to 15%). In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction can lead to
bronchiectasis, fibrosis, and respiratory compromise. While central bronchiectasis is characteristic, some patients can develop chronic cavitary lesions.
With the development of ABPA, asthma or cystic fibrosis typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts. The presence of hyperattenuating mucus in the airways is highly specific.
ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:
Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml
Positive skin prick test or IgE levels against A. fumigatus extract Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies
Eosinophilia >500 cells/L
Treatment - The use of systemic glucocorticoids is indicated for ABPA, but the course should be tapered by 3-6 months. Antifungal agents like itraconazole, voriconazole, and newer azoles can be used for over 4 months to control disease activity. Monoclonal antibodies against IgE, IL-4, and IL-5 receptors can be used for severe refractory cases.
Solution to Question 18:
The culture of Aspergillus fumigatus from sputum is not a diagnostic criterion for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). The sensitivity of sputum culture in ABPA is low.
ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:
Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml.
Positive skin prick test or IgE levels against A. fumigatus extract.
Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies.
Eosinophilia >500 cells/L.
Solution to Question 19:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of aspergillosis. Fungal hyphae of Aspergillus species are narrow, septate, and have branching at 45o.
Yeast forms of Aspergillus are not seen in infected tissue.
Exposure to the high number of conidia that are found in construction sites, hay barns, moldy barks, and composts is a risk factor.
Clinical features:
Most of the patients are asymptomatic
Fever
Cough
Chest discomfort
Trivial hemoptysis
Shortness of breath
Halo sign-on HRCT refers to a localized ground glass appearance representing an area of hemorrhagic infarction surrounding a nodule. It is seen in invasive aspergillosis, a distinct entity where there is a direct invasion of hyphae into the lung tissue.
The air crescent sign describes the crescent of air that can be seen in invasive aspergillosis. It usually heralds recovery and is the result of increased granulocyte activity.
Monod sign refers to the gas that surrounds a mycetoma (most commonly an aspergilloma) in a pre-existing pulmonary cavity.

Solution to Question 1:
Reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of obstructive lung disease.
Forced vital capacity (FVC) is the volume of expired air recorded when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and as completely as possible. The volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume 1 (FEV1).
Given below is a graphical representation of FEV and FEV1:

FVC is reduced in both obstructive and restrictive lung diseases. In obstructive diseases, the slope of FVC is steady, therefore the FEV1 value is low and the FEV1/FVC ratio decreases. In restrictive diseases, the airflow is fast in the beginning leading to a higher value of FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio increases.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is characterized by an increased residual volume.
According to Uptodate, decreased vital capacity and increased total lung capacity is indicative of hyperinflation seen in COPD. FVC can be used a proxy for VC in normal individuals but in COPD FVC is less than VC due to air trapping, airflow limitation, and small airway collapse.

MMFR is the average expiratory flow rate during the middle 50% of the vital capacity i.e., forced expiratory flow rate between 25 and 75% of the vital capacity.
This is the most sensitive measurement of early airflow obstruction, particularly in small airways.

The given clinical scenario along with the honeycomb pattern of lung parenchyma due to interstitial fibrosis is suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). The alveolar-arterial gradient (PAO2-PaO2) is increased in ILD. It is a restrictive lung disease.
In ILD, the alveolar-capillary bed is damaged and thus there is a decrease in diffusion capacity. Therefore, while the PAO2 (Alveolar O2) remains normal, the PaO2 (arterial) decreases, and the alveolar-arterial difference increases.

Diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is decreased in patients with emphysema.
DLCO measures the ability of the lungs to transfer gas from inhaled air in the alveoli to the red blood cells in pulmonary capillaries.
In general, the DLCO is used to identify the cause of dyspnea or hypoxemia. It is also used
to monitor disease progression in interstitial lung disease, and identify pulmonary hypertension in patients at risk, such as those with systemic sclerosis.

Solution to Question 10:
The likely diagnosis is tracheal stenosis. The flow-volume loop shows flattened inspiratory and expiratory curves, suggestive of fixed upper-airway obstruction.

A normal flow-volume loop begins on the X-axis (Volume axis): at the start of the test, both flow and volume are equal to zero. After the starting point, the curve rapidly mounts to a peak: Peak expiratory flow (PEF).
Then, the PEF the curve descends (=the flow decreases) as more air is expired. A normal,
non-pathological F/V loop will descend in a straight or a convex line from the top (PEF) to the bottom (FVC).
The forced inspiration that follows the forced expiration has roughly the same morphology, but the PIF (Peak Inspiratory Flow) is not as distinct as PEF.

Asthma, emphysema, and endobronchial neoplasms present with obstructive flow patterns.

Solution to Question 1:
Patients with brain stem injury develop type 2 respiratory failure. It is characterized by low pO2 and high pCO2.
Acute respiratory failure refers to acute impairment in gas exchange between the lungs and the blood causing hypoxia with or without hypercapnia.
Solution to Question 2:
The features of respiratory failure in the perioperative period of this patient is most likely due to lung atelectasis. Type 3 respiratory failure is most likely to be present in him.
Type 3 respiratory failure is also known as perioperative respiratory failure.
After general anesthesia, there is a decrease in functional residual capacity due to a reduction in muscular tone. This leads to airway closure and the collapse of the dependent lung units.
Atelectasis can be treated by frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright positioning, and control of incisional and abdominal pain. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cardiogenic shock. He is likely to develop type 4 respiratory failure, not type 2.
Patients in cardiogenic shock often have respiratory distress secondary to acute pulmonary edema (batwing appearance on x-ray). This increases the requirement of oxygen delivery to the respiratory muscles from <5% to up to 40% of cardiac output.
Hypoperfusion and increased oxygen requirement lead to inadequate perfusion of respiratory muscles which causes type 4 respiratory failure.
Intubation and mechanical ventilation are the treatment of choice.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray finding is suggestive of ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) secondary to acute pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis gives rise to inflammatory processes and endothelial damage that results in ARDS.
CXR features in ARDS:

Pneumonia

Indirect lung injury:

Moderate ARDS is characterized by PaO2/FiO2: 101 - 200 mmHg. PaO2/FiO2: 200 - 300 mm/Hg is classified as mild ARDS.
Diagnostic criteria in ARDS—Berlin definition:(requires each of the following criteria to be present to diagnose ARDS)
Onset - Acute: Respiratory symptoms must have begun < 1 week of a known clinical insult
Bilateral alveolar or interstitial infiltrates: on a chest X-ray image or CT scan
Respiratory failure must not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. Objective assessment e.g Echo should be done in cases of no known cause.
Impairment of oxygenation: The severity of hypoxemia defines the severity of ARDS.

Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ARDS secondary to drowning. The ventilator setting recommended is low tidal volume and high PEEP.
Drowning causes direct lung injury. The aspiration of water into the lungs damages the surfactant. This disrupts the alveolar-capillary membrane and leads to alveolar edema, resulting in ARDS.
The ventilator settings recommended in ARDS are:
Low tidal volume: To avoid barotrauma due to overdistention of the alveoli.
High PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure): This prevents the collapse of alveoli at the end of the expiration and improves oxygenation.

The high-risk population is individuals whose age is 60 years and who have a smoking history of
10 pack-years.
Low dose CT scans are shown to detect more lung nodules and cancers than the standard CXR in selected high-risk populations. Also, up to 85% of cancers thus detected are classified as stage I. Early staged cancers are considered potentially curable with surgical resection.
Here, the aim is to reduce medical radiation exposure as much as possible, low dose CT is effective in screening for lung cancer, and is thus preferred.

superior sulcus tumor. This affects the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.
It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.
Regional spread can cause
Tracheal obstruction
Esophageal compression with dysphagia
Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)

Solution to Question 8:
Adenocarcinomas with EGFR mutation are exquisitely sensitive to tyrosine kinase inhibitors of the EGFR signal pathway such as gefitinib and erlotinib.
Option A: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF.
Option B: Paclitaxel- a taxane, is a plant alkaloid and chemotherapeutic agent.
Option C: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor effective in the treatment of CML and GIST.
Solution to Question 9:
In the given clinical scenario the patient has features of Cushing's syndrome, secondary to
small-cell lung cancer. This occurs due to ectopic ACTH production. It can also seen in pulmonary carcinoids.
Most effective management is treating underlying SCLC or carcinoid.
Solution to Question 10:
The primary cause of his symptoms is ectopic secretion of PTH related peptide. Lung cancers are associated with several paraneoplastic syndromes. Squamous cell lung cancer is associated with hypercalcemia due to ectopic PTH related peptide. Hypercalcemia may present as vomiting,
abdominal pain, constipation, increased frequency of urination, kidney stones, bone pain and shortened QT interval.
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). It is associated with hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.
TLS is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It is usually seen within 1-5 days of receiving chemotherapy. It has also been observed with the administration of glucocorticoids, letrozole, tamoxifen, rituximab and gemtuzumab. Rarely, spontaneous necrosis of malignancies causes TLS.
Clinical features:
Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy
Pruritus, renal colicky pain, oliguria
Muscle cramps, carpopedal spasm, tetany Biochemical findings:
Hyperuricemia
Hyperkalemia
Hypocalcemia
Hyperphosphatemia
Due to these biochemical changes, there is an increased risk of arrhythmias, acidosis, and acute kidney injury.
Solution to Question 12:
Sodium bicarbonate is not recommended in the treatment of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS).
Urinary alkalinization by sodium bicarbonate decreases the solubility of xanthine, hypoxanthine, and calcium phosphate. This potentially increases the risk of intratubular crystallization.
Management of TLS includes:
Aggressive hydration
Allopurino
Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase
Febuxostat - non-purine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor
Solution to Question 13:
Patients with ipsilateral mediastinal node metastases are suitable candidates for curative resection.
In patients with NSCLC, the following are contraindications to potentially curative resection:
Extra-thoracic metastases
Vocal cord involvement
Superior vena cava syndrome
Involvement of the main pulmonary artery
Cardiac tamponade
Phrenic nerve paralysis
Malignant pleural effusion
Tumor within 2 cm of the carina
Metastasis to the contralateral lung
Metastases to supraclavicular lymph nodes
Contralateral mediastinal node metastases

She reported that he even dozed off while driving yesterday and nearly caused an accident. He is being treated for hypertension, gastro-oesophageal reflux, and type 2 diabetes. What else would be the ideal therapy for his symptoms?

Solution to Question 1:
Sleep apnea is defined as a temporary pause in breathing during sleep lasting at least 10 seconds. Sleep apneas can be further divided into:
Obstructive apneas - Sleep apnea with persistent respiratory effort.
Central apneas - Sleep apnea with an absence of respiratory effort.
The gold standard for the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS) is an overnight polysomnogram (PSG).
Solution to Question 2:
Arterial blood gases are not part of polysomnography. However, they are usually measured to rule out alveolar hypoventilation secondary to lung disease or chest wall abnormalities.
An overnight polysomnogram is a multi-parametric test and is the gold standard for the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea. It includes:
EEG
Eye movements (EOG)
Muscle activity or skeletal muscle activation (EMG)
ECG
Respiratory airflow and respiratory effort indicators
Peripheral pulse oximetry
Sleep latency
Sleep efficiency
Arousal index

Other sleep disorders diagnosed by polysomnography:
Narcolepsy
Idiopathic hypersomnia
Periodic limb movement disorder
REM behavior disorder
Parasomnias
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central sleep apnea (CSA), and it is caused by increased sensitivity to pCO2. Thus changes in pCO2 levels during sleep lead to an unstable breathing pattern that manifests as hyperventilation alternating with apnea. Crescendo-decrescendo breathing pattern known as Cheyne-Stokes respiration is seen.
Risk factors for CSA:
Heart failure
Opioid medications
Hypoxia (e.g., breathing at high altitude)
Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) at high pressures seems to induce central apnea; this condition is referred to as complex sleep apnea.
Solution to Question 4:
Strychnine is not a risk factor as it does not cause respiratory depression. It is a CNS stimulant. Only drugs that cause respiratory centre depression are risk factors for the development of central
sleep apnea.
Option A: Opioids depress the respiratory centre in a dose-dependent manner. Option C: Barbiturates cause respiratory depression in high doses.
Option D: Gelsemium is an ergot-type alkaloid and is a CNS depressant. Often used in homoeopathy, in large doses, paralysis and death from respiratory failure can occur.

The pink shaded area shows an apneic period without any respiratory efforts.
Solution to Question 5:
The breathing pattern shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes respiration. It
is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing, followed by a gradual decrease that results in a temporary stop in breathing called apnea.
It is caused by an increased sensitivity of the respiratory center to arterial PCO2. There is an apneic phase, during which arterial PO2 falls and arterial PCO2 rises. These changes in the arterial blood gas content stimulate the respiratory center, resulting in hyperventilation and hypocapnia, followed by recurrence of apnea. It is present in 40% of patients with advanced HF and usually is associated with low cardiac output.

Solution to Question 6:
The most probable diagnosis of this patient is obesity hypoventilation syndrome.
Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) or Pickwickian syndrome is defined as the presence of awake alveolar hypoventilation in an obese individual which cannot be attributed to other conditions associated with alveolar hypoventilation.
Patients with OHS are obese and give a history of daytime hypersomnolence, loud snoring, choking during sleep, fatigue, impaired concentration, and memory. On examination usually, there is a small oropharynx and a thick neck.
OHS may be associated with the following findings:
Elevated serum bicarbonate (>27 mE˜/L)
Hypercapnia (PaCO2 >45 mmHg)
Hypoxemia (PaO2 <70 mmHg)
Polycythemia
Options A and D: In obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea, the awake ABG values are usually normal.
Option B: There are no ABG changes in narcolepsy.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome
(OSAHS). The ideal therapy is continuous positive airway pressure therapy (CPAP).
Option A: Supplemental oxygenation can improve oxygen saturation but there is little evidence that it improves OSAHS symptoms.
Option B: Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is the most common surgery done in OSAHS but it is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.
Option D: Unilateral neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve through a surgically implanted device is a recently tested therapy for OSAHS. It can be used as an alternative in selected patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.
Solution to Question 8:
Syndrome Z is defined as a combination of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome with metabolic syndrome. LDL more than 100 mg/dL is not a criterion for the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome.
Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed based on The NCEP: ATP III Criteria. Three or more of the following must be present :
Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level 150 mg/dL or specific medication
Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively, or specific medication
Hypertension: blood pressure 130 mmHg systolic or 85 mmHg diastolic or specific medication
Fasting plasma glucose level 100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 iabetes

Solution to Question 1:
Urine samples should be analyzed within 2-4 hours after collection to avoid cell lysis and precipitation of solutes. If urine analysis is not possible in the given time, then the sample can be stored at 4-8 oC for a maximum of 12 hours.
Urine samples can be collected using the following techniques:
Midstream sample during spontaneous voiding
Fresh specimen from an indwelling catheter
Suprapubic needle aspiration of the bladder, especially in infants

Chemical content

The normal color of urine is pale straw due to the presence of urochrome.

Solution to Question 4:
Isosthenuria is defined as a urine specific gravity of 1.010, which is similar to that of plasma. The normal specific gravity of urine is around 1.020 to 1.030.
Specific gravity and osmolality are measures of the concentration or relative density of urine.
Specific gravity: The weight of a solution relative to that of equal amounts of water. It is measured by refractometry or using reagent strips.
Osmolality: The gold standard for relative density. It is defined as the number of osmoles of solute per kilogram of solvent. It is measured directly with an osmometer.
Isosthenuria means that the kidney is neither concentrating nor diluting the urine. This is seen in chronic renal failure (CRF) and acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

Solution to Question 5:
The given image shows reddish discoloration of the urine sample. A negative urine dipstick indicates absence of RBCs and is suggestive of porphyria.
A urine dipstick test is the first step to be done in a patient with high coloured urine to help identify true hematuria. A positive dipstick test identifies heme that is present in red blood cells, haemoglobin or myoglobin. A negative dipstick test implies that the reddish discolouration is due to pigments from certain food items (beetroot), drugs or porphyrias.

Solution to Question 6:
Hematuria is defined as the presence of 2-5 RBCs / high-powered field (HPF). It is considered significant or persistent in the presence of one of the following:
RBCs > 3 / HPF on 3 or more occasions
RBCs > 100 / HPF on 1 occasion
Gross hematuria
Solution to Question 7:
Acanthocytes are a subtype of dysmorphic red blood cells with protruding blebs that are seen in glomerular disease.
The 40-5-1 rule can be used to identify glomerular diseases based on urinalysis:
Dysmorphic RBCs - 40% (can range from 10-80%)
Acanthocytes - 5% (can range from 2-5%)
Even a single RBC cast
Hematuria can be either due to systemic or renal causes. Renal causes can be further subdivided into glomerular and non-glomerular causes as given below:
Glomerular
Non-glomerular

Solution to Question 9:
Nephrotic-range or heavy proteinuria refers to excretion of > 3.5 g/day or > 1000 mg/m2/day in children.
Normally, the following mechanisms prevent proteinuria:
The glomerular basement membrane acts as a barrier to prevent the loss of negatively charged and large proteins.
Reabsorption of small proteins in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT).
The various types of proteinuria are:
Glomerular - increased filtration of proteins due to disruption of basement membrane
Tubular - damage to tubules prevents protein reabsorption in the PCT
Overflow - excess production of low molecular weight proteins such as light chains
Postrenal - infections or stones can lead to secretion of IgA and IgG by the urinary tract

Solution to Question 10:
Non-glomerular proteinuria is characterized by the presence of N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG).
This form of proteinuria occurs as a result of tubular injury. N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG) is a lysosomal enzyme present in the proximal tubular cells and is released into the urine following any injury to the tubules.
˜ow-molecular-weight proteins such as 2-microglobulin are normally reabsorbed in the PCT. When there is tubular injury, the proportion of these proteins in urine increases. This lowers the albumin: 2-microglobulin ratio in urine.
In glomerular proteinuria, there is increased filtration of macromolecules like albumin across the glomerular capillary wall. NAG is absent as there is no tubular injury.
