Solution to Question 11:
The image shows a hexagonal crystal, suggesting cystine stones. These stones are a recurrent feature in patients with cystinuria.
Crystals in urine are usually associated with kidney stones. Crystals form in the urine depends upon a variety of factors including:
The degree of concentration of constituent molecules
The urine pH
The presence of inhibitors of crystallization
Calcium oxalate and uric acid crystals can sometimes be found in normal urine that has been left to stand, due to crystal formation ex vivo.
Solution to Question 12:
The sites of formation of casts are the collecting ducts and DCTs (distal convoluted tubules).
Casts are cylindrical structures formed by the aggregation of Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein or uromodulin. This protein is secreted in the thick ascending loop of Henle. They assume the shape and size of the lumen in which they are formed. Several factors favour cast formation, such as urine stasis, low pH and high concentration. Casts are the only elements in urine sediments that are specifically of renal origin.
Solution to Question 13:
Muddy-brown granular casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis, a type of intrinsic renal failure. ATN can occur secondary to nephrotoxicity or hypovolemia.
Solution to Question 14:
Broad casts are associated with a poor prognosis.
They refer to wider waxy casts that are seen in advanced chronic kidney disease. It implies dilation of the tubules.

Solution to Question 7:
Uremic syndrome cannot be eliminated by removing urea alone. It is a complex condition occurring due to the accumulation of multiple toxins.
The pathophysiology of uremic syndrome involves the following:
Accumulation of toxins (uremia) - urea, creatinine, other products of protein metabolism like urates, hippurates, polyamines, indoles.
Loss of kidney function leading to fluid and electrolyte imbalance and hormone dysregulation.
Progressive systemic inflammation with vascular and nutritional impairment.
Clinical features secondary to loss of kidney function tend to develop in parallel with declining GFR. However the features of uremia and, hence, uremic syndrome, usually occur only in stage 5 or ESRD.

Solution to Question 9:
Sickle cell anemia is not a feature of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
Common causes of anemia in CKD include:
Erythropoietin deficiency
Diminished red blood cell surviva
Bleeding diathesis
Iron deficiency
Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency
Hyperparathyroidism (due to bone marrow fibrosis)
Hemoglobinopathy
Solution to Question 10:
Hyperthyroidism is not a feature of chronic renal failure.
Option A: Peripheral neuropathy can occur secondary to uremia.
Options C and D: In chronic renal failure, calcitriol (vitamin D3) production is decreased, leading to metabolic bone disease, which in turn leads to low serum calcium levels, secondary hyperparathyroidism, and osteomalacia.
Solution to Question 11:
The most common neurological disorder seen in patients with CKD is peripheral neuropathy. The various neuromuscular manifestations of CKD include:
Memory and concentration impairment
Dialysis dementia - due to aluminum intoxication
Restless leg syndrome
Peripheral neuropathy
Hiccups
Cramps
Uremic encephalopathy
Confusion and lethargy
Tremors
Myoclonus
Asterixis
Seizures
Coma
Solution to Question 12:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of restless legs syndrome (RLS) or Willis-Ekbom disease. Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is not the most common cause of this condition.
RLS is a neurological sleep disorder that can be primary or secondary. The primary form is more common. It shows autosomal dominant inheritance in most cases, but can be idiopathic.
Secondary RLS is associated with the following:
Iron deficiency
Pregnancy - most common movement disorder
Peripheral neuropathy
Diabetes mellitus
CKD
Parkinson's disease
Multiple sclerosis
It is characterized by an uncontrollable, restless urge to move the legs. It tends to worsen during periods of inactivity and at evening or night. It is accompanied by crawling, tingling or burning sensations. These symptoms show partial or complete improvement with movement. This cycle may continue for a while and result in insomnia.
Primary RLS is managed by improving sleep hygiene and dopamine agonists (pramipexole or ropinirole) if symptoms persist. Iron supplements can also be given. In secondary RLS, the underlying cause must be treated.
Solution to Question 13:
The most likely cause of convulsions in a patient with CKD is water intoxication. Volume overload in these patients as well as damage to the blood-brain barrier by uremic toxins causes cerebral edema and seizures.
Solution to Question 14:
Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients at every stage of CKD.
Solution to Question 15:
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with elevated levels of fibrinogen.
CKD is a pro-inflammatory state characterized by altered levels of acute-phase reactants (APR)
Elevated levels of positive APR like CRP and fibrinogen (associated with high ESR).
Reduced levels of negative APR like albumin and fetuin.
Solution to Question 16:
High anion gap metabolic acidosis is the predominant electrolyte abnormality in a patient with advanced CKD. In advanced CKD, impaired renal functioning causes decreased urinary excretion of acids. These retained organic acids result in a high anion gap.
In early CKD, potassium retention is associated with bicarbonate loss. This gives rise to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap in early CKD.
The following electrolyte abnormalities are seen in CKD:
Hyperkalemia
Hypocalcemia
Hyperphosphatemia
Hyperuricemia
Hypermagnesemia
Hypokalemia is uncommon in CKD and usually reflects markedly reduced dietary potassium intake, especially in association with excessive diuretic therapy or concurrent GI losses.
Solution to Question 17:
Of the given options, hyperkalemia is the most life-threatening complication of chronic kidney disease (CKD) as it can result in cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death.
CKD is staged based on declining glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and albuminuria. The various clinical manifestations occur due to loss of kidney function and accumulation of various uremic toxins (urea, creatinine, and other products of protein metabolism).
Complications of declining kidney function include:
Volume overload
Hyperkalemia
Metabolic acidosis
Hyperphosphatemia
Mineral and bone disorders
Hypertension
Anemia
Dyslipidemia
Solution to Question 18:
Serum estrogen levels are low in CKD patients. This leads to menstrual abnormalities and infertility.
Option A: Plasma levels of insulin are elevated in CKD patients due to impaired clearance by the affected kidneys. Hence, insulin dose must be reduced in these patients.
Option B: Elevated parathyroid hormone levels in CKD are secondary to derangements in the homeostasis of calcium, phosphate, and vitamin D.
Option D: FGF-23 (fibroblast growth factor) is part of a family of phosphatonins that promotes renal phosphate excretion. The levels of this hormone increase early in the course of CKD.
Solution to Question 19:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (MI) in a patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD). A serial rise in cardiac troponin levels over 3-6 hours following presentation is needed to make a diagnosis. An interval of 1-hour is not considered sufficient.
Minor chronic elevations in serum troponins are commonly observed in patients with CKD even in the absence of cardiovascular disease. Hence, a single elevated troponin value in such patients cannot be used to diagnose MI.
CK-MB is far less sensitive and specific than troponins. Hence, it is not preferred.
Solution to Question 20:
Microalbuminuria is the most sensitive and earliest finding of diabetic nephropathy. It refers to urine albumin of 30–300 mg/24-hour urine. It is seen in the stage of incipient diabetic kidney disease.
However, microalbuminuria is a very variable finding and is not required to diagnose nephropathy. Non-albuminuric diabetic nephropathy may occur in some patients and regression of albuminuria may be seen in type 1 diabetics.
Diabetic nephropathy can be diagnosed if the following are satisfied:
Reduced GFR (< 60 mL/min/1.73 m2) with or without persistent albuminuria (> 30 mg/day or urine PCR > 30 mg/g)
Long duration of diabetes or established diabetic retinopathy
Other etiologies are ruled out

Solution to Question 21:
Hypertensive nephropathy is unlikely in this patient as it usually presents with shrunken kidneys.
Longstanding CKD due to most causes results in bilaterally small kidneys. Causes of CKD with normal size kidneys are:
Diabetic nephropathy (kidney size may be increased at the onset)
Amyloidosis
HIV nephropathy
Solution to Question 22:
According to the ESC 2018 guidelines, the target blood pressure in hypertensive patients with CKD is < 140/ 80 mm Hg regardless of age.
Solution to Question 23:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) and hyperphosphatemia in a patient with CKD. Sevelamer is the best initial treatment for this patient. It is a phosphate binder that reduces the absorption of phosphate from the gastrointestinal tract.
Other phosphate binders that can be used include:
Calcium containing
Calcium acetate
Calcium carbonate
Non-calcium containing
Sevelamer
Lanthanum
Calcitriol and cinacalcet are used to decrease PTH levels in secondary hyperparathyroidism. However, they also cause increased serum phosphate levels. Hence, they should not be given as initial treatment in patients with hyperphosphatemia.
Bisphosphonates like pamidronate are used in the treatment of primary hyperparathyroidism.
Solution to Question 24:
Anemia in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is primarily due to decreased erythropoietin production. Hence, human recombinant erythropoietin (EPO) such as darbepoetin is the most appropriate treatment and is considered the mainstay.
However, an optimal response to treatment with EPO occurs only when iron stores are adequate. Hence, iron supplements (oral or IV) must be given first to ensure the effectiveness of EPO therapy.
Other treatment options for anemia in CKD are:
Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation
Blood transfusion - in severe anemia and failure to EPO therapy
Solution to Question 25:
Diclofenac should not be used in a patient with CKD as it is nephrotoxic.
Renal blood flow is regulated by prostaglandin E2. Aspirin, diclofenac and other NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase. This decreases prostaglandin E2 concentration, thereby causing a reduction in blood flow and GFR.
Nephrotoxic drugs include the following:
NSAIDs
Antifungals (amphotericin B)
Antibiotics
Aminoglycosides
Vancomycin
Cephalosporins
Sulfonamides
Streptomycin
Antivirals
Acyclovir
Foscarnet
Chemotherapy drugs
Methotrexate
Platins
Immunosuppressants (cyclosporine)
Solution to Question 26:
In CKD patients with diabetes, the dose of insulin must be reduced.
In CKD patients, the plasma levels of insulin are elevated due to diminished renal degradation of insulin by the impaired kidney. This impaired renal clearance of insulin can lead to hypoglycemia. Hence, the dose of insulin must be reduced to prevent this.

Solution to Question 1:
A rise in creatinine 1.5 times the baseline value within 7 days is diagnostic of acute kidney injury
(AKI).
AKI is an abrupt decrease in kidney function within hours to days. According to the KDIGO definition, it is defined as any of the following:
Increase in serum creatinine by 0.3 mg/dL within 48 hours OR
Increase in serum creatinine to 1.5 times the baseline within 7 days OR
Urine volume <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours.
Solution to Question 2:

Solution to Question 3:
Anuria is defined as urine output less than 100 mL/day. Oliguria is defined as urine output less than 400 mL/day.
Acute kidney injury (AKI) can have varied clinical features depending on the etiology. The history and physical examination in AKI aims mainly at:
Finding the etiology
Identifying the occurrence of any complications The following clinical features may be seen:
Oliguria or anuria
Gross hematuria
Renal colic pain (in renal stones)
Loss of skin turgor, dry mouth, hypotension, tachycardia (in hypovolemia)
Prostatomegaly and/or a pelvic mass (in post-renal obstruction)
Dysuria, fever with chills and rigors, increased frequency of micturition, renal angle tenderness
(in pyelonephritis)
Edema, hypertension (volume overload)
Encephalopathy, seizures, platelet dysfunction (uremia)
Solution to Question 4:
NSAIDs, Rhabdomyolysis and ACE inhibitors cause prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI).
The use of NSAIDs causes reduced production of vasodilatory prostaglandins. This leads to decreased renal perfusion and glomerular capillary pressure. NSAIDs can also lead to acute interstitial nephritis, a cause of renal AKI. However, this is relatively uncommon.
ACE inhibitors cause inhibition of efferent arteriole vasoconstriction, leading to reduced renal perfusion.
Rhabdomyolysis causes AKI by both prerenal mechanisms (due to volume sequestration) and ATN
(due to precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules).
Nephrotoxins like myeloma light chains, snake venom, myoglobin (due to rhabdomyolysis) cause acute tubular necrosis (ATN). This leads to renal or intrinsic AKI.

Solution to Question 5:
This clinical scenario and CT scan showing papillary calcifications are highly suggestive of chronic kidney disease caused by analgesic nephropathy.
This condition is more common in females secondary to excessive prolonged use of a combination of analgesics. The mechanism of injury is medullary hypoxia leading to papillary necrosis and finally causes chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis.
Patients can remain asymptomatic for a long time. Sloughing or obstruction of papillae can cause abdominal pain and hematuria. It increases the risk of urothelial malignancies. The following CT findings can be seen:
Papillary calcifications
Small kidneys
Irregular contour
Note: NSAID-induced nephropathy causes acute interstitial nephritis. It is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. The features include non-oliguric AKI, fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) < 1, and hyperkalemia. It is seen within a few days of use and is reversible.

Solution to Question 7:
This clinical scenario and urine/ plasma creatinine ratio of <20 is suggestive of renal AKI due to rhabdomyolysis-induced acute tubular necrosis.
Rhabdomyolysis is a serious complication of crush injuries. It leads to muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury by the following mechanisms:
Direct toxic effect of myoglobin and heme on the PCT
Tubular obstruction by precipitation of pigmented casts
Renal vasoconstriction can cause FeNa < 1 (unlike other renal causes of AKI)

Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rhabdomyolysis. Hypocalcemia is seen in this condition.
The causes of rhabdomyolysis include:
Hypothyroidism (precipitated by exertion, alcohol, infection)
Crush injury
Electric shock
Prolonged seizures
Malignant hyperthermia
Exertion
Drugs like fibrates, statins
Polymyositis / Dermatomyositis
McArdle's disease (GSD-5) causes recurrent rhabdomyolysis.
Patients often present with muscle pain and high-colored urine. The following features are seen:
High serum CK (> 5 times normal)
High serum myoglobin
High serum LDH
Hyperkalemia
Hypermagnesemia
Hyperphosphatemia
Hypocalcemia
Hyperuricemia
Once AKI develops, high serum creatinine and urea
The treatment includes administration of large amounts of IV fluids (5-6 liters), alkalization of urine, and hemodialysis.
Solution to Question 9:
Bence-Jones proteins on urine analysis are suggestive of multiple myeloma. It causes acute kidney injury (AKI) by the following mechanisms:
Hypercalcemia - leads to intense renal vasoconstriction and reduced perfusion
Myeloma light chains - cause direct tubular toxicity.
Solution to Question 10:
Non-oliguric renal failure may be seen in the following conditions:
Acute interstitial nephritis
Acute tubular necrosis (aminoglycoside toxicity, contrast-induced nephropathy)
All the causes of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) cause non-oliguric AKI except acyclovir (oliguric AKI).
The difference in urine output between oliguric and non-oliguric AKI may be due to variations in GFR or in the rate of tubular reabsorption. Non-oliguric forms may be associated with less severe injury.
Other options: Prerenal causes such as congestive heart failure cause oliguric AKI. In post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, oliguria occurs as a result of decreased GFR.
Solution to Question 11:
Electrical burns result in rhabdomyolysis. It presents with hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis.
Muscle breakdown in rhabdomyolysis leads to hyperkalemia which causes arrhythmias. It also causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the increase in H+ ions and liberation of organic anions.
Solution to Question 12:
In acute renal failure, metabolic acidosis occurs due to decreased excretion of ammonium. This impairs the excretion of H+ ions as NH4 ions.
Normally, H+ are excreted via the kidney in combination with ammonia which acts as a urinary buffer.
In AKI, there is a decreased capacity of tubules to secrete ammonia. Due to reduced amounts of ammonia, the production of NH4 is impaired. Hence, H+ ions cannot be excreted, which leads to metabolic acidosis.
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario shows >0.5 mg/dL increase in S.creatinine levels, which is indicative of contrast-induced nephropathy for which obesity is not a risk factor.
Contrast-induced nephropathy is defined as a 25% or 0.5 mg/dL increase from the baseline value of serum creatinine within 48-72 hours of intravenous contrast administration. It occurs due to tubular damage and as a result, the patient develops non-oliguric transient nephropathy.
Risk factors for contrast medium-induced nephropathy:
Patient-related:
eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intra-arterial administration
eGFR < 45 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intravenous administration
Patient conditions that increase the risk:
Diabetic nephropathy
Dehydration
Congestive heart failure (NYHA grade 3–4) and low LVEF
Recent myocardial infarction (<24 h)
Intra-aortic balloon pump
Peri-procedural hypotension
Low hematocrit leve
Age over 70
Concurrent administration of nephrotoxic drugs
Known or suspected acute renal failure Procedure-related:
Intra-arterial administration of contrast medium
High-osmolality agents
Large doses of contrast medium
Multiple contrast medium administrations within a few days Side effects of iodinated contrast material include:
Idiosyncratic anaphylactoid reaction - patient develops bronchospasm and hypotension
Dose-dependent side effect – contrast-induced nephropathy seen especially with the use of high osmolar agents
Prevention of contrast-induced nephropathy:
IV fluids (isotonic saline or sodium bicarbonate) started 1 hour before and continued for at least 3-6 hours after the procedure
Low volume low osmolar contrast should be used
N-acetyl cysteine may be given prior to contrast exposure
Solution to Question 14:
Dialysis-requiring AKI is uncommon in contrast-induced nephropathy.
Contrast-induced AKI is generally associated with the use of high osmolar contrasts such as:
Iodinated contrast agents
High-dose gadolinium
Mechanism of contrast-induced injury includes:
Medullary ischemia and hypoxia: By inducing intense vasoconstriction
Toxic tubular damage: By direct injury
It usually develops within 24-48 hrs. Serum creatinine peaks by 3-5 days and normalizes by 7-10 days. It manifests mainly as a non-oliguric renal failure and has an excellent prognosis.
Contrast-induced AKI can be prevented by:
Use of iso-osmolar or non-ionic contrast agents (least toxic)
Administering minimum required quantity of contrast
Pre- and post-hydration (IV normal saline 1 mL/kg/h x 12 h prior and post-exposure)
N-acetyl cysteine may be given prior to contrast exposure.
Solution to Question 15:
Acid phosphatase is not a marker of kidney injury. The various markers of kidney injury are as follows:
IL-18
Cystatin C
NGAL (neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin)
KIM-1 (kidney injury molecule-1)
LFABP (liver fatty acid-binding protein)
NHE3 (sodium hydrogen exchanger 3)
NAG (N-acetyl glucosaminidase)
Alanine aminopeptidase
Osteopontin
ALP
Solution to Question 16:
Isotonic crystalloids like 0.9% NaCl are preferred for the correction of hypovolemia in pre-renal AKI.
Management of AKI:
AKI care bundle:
Nephrotoxic drugs should be avoided and the dosage of other drugs must be adjusted according to kidney function
Creatinine levels and urine output must be closely monitored
Hemodynamic management:
If hypovolemic - fluid replenishment using isotonic crystalloids (normal saline)
If euvolemic - fluid intake = urine output + additional ~500 mL
If hypervolemic - diuretics are administered. If the response is unsatisfactory, dialysis is required.
Management of complications:
Pulmonary edema - Treated with diuretics, non-invasive ventilation, and dialysis if refractory
Metabolic acidosis - Treated when pH <7.2 with oral or IV sodium bicarbonate
Hyperkalemia - Treated by restriction of dietary potassium, administration of sodium polystyrene sulfonate, insulin, glucose, inhaled -agonist, and calcium gluconate
Options A and B: Hydroxyethyl starch solutions and dextrans increase the risk of severe AKI and are contraindicated.
Option D: Ringer's lactate is preferred only when a large volume of fluids is required.
Solution to Question 17:
Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) is a modality of dialysis that involves hemodialysis and hemofiltration. It is the preferred option in AKI patients with severe hypotension.
It is preferred in the following cases:
Acute renal failure complicated by hemodynamic instability or heart failure
Severe volume overload unresponsive to diuretic therapy
Brain edema
Hypercatabolism state
Acute or chronic liver failure as a renal support measure
It is an extracorporeal blood purification therapy intended to substitute for impaired renal function over an extended period of time, aimed at being applied for 24 hours a day. There is no rapid shift of volume and osmolarity with this process as in intermittent hemodialysis.
The other types of dialysis are:
Intermittent hemodialysis - may be done in hemodynamically stable patients with AKI
Peritoneal dialysis - used when hemodialysis is not available.
Solution to Question 18:
Hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, is seen in tumor lysis syndrome (TLS).
TLS is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by the rapid destruction of a large number of tumor cells. The release of calcium phosphate from lysed cells contributes to hyperphosphatemia and subsequent reciprocal depression in serum calcium levels. The consumption of ionized calcium during the formation of calcium phosphate crystals leads to hypocalcemia.
TLS is commonly observed after initiation of chemotherapy in hematologic malignancies characterized by high cell turnover rates, such as Burkitt's lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
The destruction of neoplastic cells results in the release of nucleic acids, which are broken down into uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia. The acidic environment in the renal tubules can cause uric acid to precipitate, leading to acute renal failure. Potassium is released in large quantities during tumor cell lysis leading to hyperkalemia.
TLS is diagnosed using the Cairo-Bishop criteria which includes both laboratory and clinical criteria.
Prevention is the mainstay of the management of TLS, which involves includes allopurinol, which inhibits the production of uric acid, and aggressive hydration to promote urine flow. Urinary alkalization is not recommended. Febuxostat, a selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, can be used as an alternative.
In severe cases or when renal failure is present, rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase, is used for treatment. Rasburicase rapidly lowers uric acid levels by converting it into a highly soluble compound called allantoin. Renal replacement therapy is often required and should be considered in case of acute renal failure.
Renal Replacement Therapy

Asterixis

Which of the following is the most commonly used therapeutic modality for patients with end-stage renal disease?
Hemodialysis

Solution to Question 1:
Dialysis is not indicated in patients who initially present with hyperkalemia. It is indicated in the case of refractory hyperkalemia that has failed to respond to other modalities of treatment.
Indications for dialysis can be remembered using the mnemonic AEIOU:
Acidosis - metabolic acidosis that is refractory to medical treatment.
Electrolyte abnormality - refractory hyperkalemia and hypercalcemia.
Intoxication - barbiturates, alcohol, and lithium.
Overload - hypervolemia and pulmonary edema.
Uncontrolled hypertension (and)
Uremia - encephalopathy, pericarditis, asterixis, seizures, intractable nausea and vomiting, and bleeding diathesis.
Solution to Question 2:
The most common therapeutic modality for patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is hemodialysis.
The various modalities of renal replacement therapy include the following:
Dialysis:
Acute intermittent hemodialysis
Continuous renal replacement therapy - includes hemodialysis and ultrafiltration techniques
Peritoneal dialysis
CAPD - Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis
CCPD - Continuous cycling peritoneal dialysis
NIPD - Nocturnal intermittent peritoneal dialysis
Renal transplan
Solution to Question 3:
In hemodialysis, the dialyzer is made up of biocompatible membranes derived from polysulfone. Cellulose is bio-incompatible and is no longer used.
Hemodialysis is based on the principle of solute diffusion using an artificial semi-permeable membrane. Smaller molecules (urea) diffuse faster and are cleared more efficiently than larger molecules (creatinine). There are three components to this system:
Dialyzer - a chamber that contains compartments for blood and dialysate solution, separated by a semipermeable membrane.
Dialysate - a solution that helps in the removal of metabolic waste products. Bicarbonate is used as a buffer to correct acidosis in CKD patients.
Blood delivery system - consists of the vascular access and extracorporeal circuit.
The dialyzers used during a session of dialysis are reprocessed and reused for the next dialysis sessions. The reprocessors used for dialyzers are:
Glutaraldehyde
Formaldehyde
Peracetic acid-hydrogen peroxide
The following image depicts hemodialysis.

Solution to Question 4:
The most common complication of arteriovenous (AV) grafts is stenosis, not infections.
In order to perform hemodialysis, vascular or hemodialysis access must first be established. The preferred site is the forearm. The following types of vascular access may be used for hemodialysis:
AV fistulas:
Fistula refers to the anastomosis of an artery and an adequately large vein (either side-to-side or end-to-side).
This causes arterialization of the vein, thereby causing venous wall thickening and increasing venous diameter.
Fistulas need 4-6 weeks to mature before they can be used.
The access of choice is radiocephalic AV fistula (Brescia-Cimino fistula).
Fistulas have higher long-term patency rates than grafts.
Thrombosis is a common complication.
The following image depicts a radiocephalic fistula.

AV grafts:
The artery and vein are connected by a prosthetic graft such as PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene).
The advantage is that it can be performed with smaller veins.
Complications include stenosis (most common), due to intimal hyperplasia at anastomosis between graft and vein, and infections.
Central venous catheter:
Tunneled catheters are used for long-term IV access. As they tunnel through the skin before entering the vein, they have a lower risk of infection.
Solution to Question 5:
During hemodialysis, heparinized blood flows through the dialyzer at a rate of 250–450 mL/min. On the other hand, the dialysate flows in the opposite counter-current direction at 500–800 mL/min.
Solution to Question 6:
The adequacy of dialysis is determined by the urea reduction ratio. It is defined as the fractional reduction in blood urea nitrogen per hemodialysis session. It is calculated as (Co - C) / Co, where:
Co - predialysis serum urea C - postdialysis serum urea
The target urea reduction ratio is 65–70%.
Solution to Question 7:
Acetate is used as a buffer in the dialysate solution. It is the most common cause of dialysis-induced hypotension because of its vasodilatory and cardio-depressive effects.
For this reason, acetate is less commonly used these days and has been largely replaced by bicarbonate.
Solution to Question 8:
Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis, particularly among patients with diabetes mellitus.
Solution to Question 9:
Cooling, not warming, the dialysate before dialysis must be done to prevent hypotension during dialysis.
Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis. The mechanism is not fully understood and occurs due to multiple factors. However, the following precautions have been shown to frequently prevent this complication:
Careful calculation of the dry weight and adjustment of the filtration rate accordingly.
Ultrafiltration modeling such that more fluid is removed during the beginning than the end of he procedure.
Avoiding rapid fluid removal and maintaining the rate < 13 mL/kg/hour.
Avoiding heavy meals during dialysis.
Cooling of the dialysate during the dialysis.
Solution to Question 10:
The given scenario is suggestive of the dialysis disequilibrium syndrome or the reverse urea effect. It is an acute complication that occurs especially in patients undergoing dialysis for the first time.
During dialysis, urea in blood vessels is rapidly removed as compared to that in the interstitium. This decreases the osmolality of blood. This results in a fluid shift from the blood vessels into the interstitium and brain parenchyma, causing cerebral edema.
In order to prevent this, the rate of flow of dialysate must be adjusted to avoid the rapid removal of solutes.

IgE-mediated immediate hypersensitivity reaction that can lead to shock and death.
Bio-incompatible cellulose-containing membranes are commonly associated with hemodialysis-associated anaphylaxis.

Type A reaction

Occur after hours.

Carpal tunnel syndrome in the setting of chronic dialysis is suggestive of dialysis-associated amyloidosis. It occurs due to the deposition of amyloid ß-2 in tissues.
This condition is seen in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis or continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD). Amyloid deposition can lead to the following complications:
Destructive osteoarthropathies - carpal tunnel syndrome, flexor tenosynovitis
Subchondral bone cysts and pathologic fractures
Paraplegia - due to deposits along paravertebral ligaments and intervertebral discs
Visceral involvement - GI tract, heart, tongue
Management involves providing symptomatic relief by means of analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, physical and occupational therapy, and surgical procedures. Renal transplantation is the treatment of choice.
Solution to Question 14:
Renal osteodystrophy does not show improvement with dialysis.
Failure of renal function leads to decreased renal vitamin D production. The resulting hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, in turn, lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism. This can be corrected only by vitamin D and calcium supplementation.
Other manifestations of renal dysfunction and uremia show improvement with regular dialysis sessions.
Solution to Question 15:
Cardiovascular disease due to accelerated atherosclerosis is the major cause of death in patients with ESRD on chronic dialysis.
Cardiovascular mortality is higher in dialysis patients compared to patients after transplantation.
Solution to Question 16:
In peritoneal dialysis, 1.5–3 L of dialysis fluid is infused into the peritoneal cavity.
In this process, the peritoneum itself acts as a semipermeable membrane. A peritoneal catheter is used to infuse the fluid into the cavity. It is allowed to dwell for a set period of time usually 2–4 hours to allow for the removal of metabolic waste products. The dialysis fluid contains osmotically active agents such as glucose or icodextrin.
The following image shows the process of peritoneal dialysis.

Peritonitis

Weight gain

Solution to Question 19:
The most common cause of death in renal transplant recipients is cardiovascular causes. It occurs in > 50% of patients.
Other complications in recipients include:
Infections
Most common - CMV.
Most specific - BK (polyoma) virus
Most common fungal - pneumocystis.
Malignancy - most commonly of skin and lip
Donors can develop long-term complications related to premature failure of the single remaining kidney including:
Hypertension
Proteinuria
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
ABO and HLA mismatch are relative, not absolute contraindications due to the availability of desensitization procedures. The absolute contraindications for transplantation are as follows:
Recipient
Donor

Active substance abuse/ unco ntrolled psychiatric condition
Uncontrolled psychiatric con dition or suicidality
Treatment nonadherence
Age < 18 or lack of mental ca pacity
Reversible renal failure
Solution to Question 20:
Cyclosporine, azathioprine, prednisolone constitute the prophylactic maintenance therapy used after renal transplant.
Immunosuppressive therapy is given to reduce the risk of transplant rejection reactions. The following regimen is commonly followed:
Induction therapy:
Given at the time of transplant to reduce the risk of early acute rejection.
The preferred treatment is anti-lymphocyte serum and alemtuzumab.
Maintenance therapy:
Given to all kidney transplant patients except when the donor and recipient are identical twins.
The most common combination used is :
cyclosporine, azathioprine, and prednisolone (also known as triple therapy).
Belatacept is a co-stimulatory blocking antibody approved by the FDA for maintenance therapy. Rejection reactions can be hyperacute, acute, or chronic. Treatment of rejection is as follows:
First episode - IV prednisolone for 3 days
Failure to respond to prednisone or second episode - anti-thymocyte globulin
Solution to Question 21:
The most common opportunistic infection occurring 1-6 months after renal transplant is Cytomegalovirus (CMV).
Pneumocystis carinii is rare these days due to universal prophylaxis for 6-12 months following transplantation.

Solution to Question 22:
Alport syndrome does not recur in the transplanted kidney. This is because it occurs due to an inherited defect in type 4 collagen in the glomerular basement membrane. This defect is absent in the transplanted kidney.
Diabetic nephropathy, membranous glomerulonephritis, and lupus nephritis can recur in the transplanted kidney.
Solution to Question 23:
Patients with diabetic nephropathy have the highest risk of disease recurrence after renal transplant. Nearly 52% of transplant recipients have histological evidence of diabetic kidney disease/mesangial sclerosis at 10 years after transplantation.
The recurrence rates of the other conditions are as follows:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis: 20-48%
Membranous glomerulonephritis: 10-45%
Lupus nephritis: 2-11%

The average life expectancy of a living-donor graft is around 14 years and that of a deceased-donor graft is around 10 years.

Solution to Question 1:
Cardiovascular complications are the most common cause of mortality in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Infections are the second most common cause.
ADPKD is usually clinically silent. Many cases remain asymptomatic until the fifth decade of life and are diagnosed incidentally. PKD-1 mutations cause more severe disease than PKD-2 mutations. The following clinical features may be seen in symptomatic patients:
Abdominal mass
Back or flank pain
Recurrent UTIs - Renal cyst infections by Gram-negative bacteria are common
Nephrolithiasis - most commonly uric acid stones
Hematuria
Cardiac:
Hypertension - early feature
Left ventricular hypertrophy
Mitral valve prolapse, valvular insufficiency
Extra-renal:
Intracranial aneurysms
Hepatic cysts
As the cysts grow they compress on the surrounding normal tissue which leads to a progressive reduction in the GFR. Eventually, it leads to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) by the fifth decade of life.
Solution to Question 2:
This clinical scenario with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and multiple renal cysts is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The PKD-1 mutation has a higher risk of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) than PKD-2.
ADPKD is a disorder which is characterized by progressive bilateral formation of renal cysts. It is caused by the following mutations:
PKD1 gene on chromosome 16 (85%) - codes for polycystin-1
PKD2 gene on chromosome 4 (15%) - codes for polycystin-2
Polycystins are transmembrane proteins that are present on the primary cilia of the tubular cells. The mutated proteins in ADPKD alter the normal functioning and triggers cell growth and cyst formation.
Though cysts are formed only in 5% of the tubules of the kidney, they compress surrounding renal tissue due to their enormous growth. This results in loss of renal function.
Solution to Question 3:
In patients with ADPKD, cysts in the lungs are very rare.
There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients.
The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include:
Hepatic cysts (50-70%) - most common
Seminal vesicle cysts (40%) - can result in infertility
Arachnoid membrane cysts (8%) - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdura hematoma
Pancreatic cysts (7-36%)
Splenic cysts
Solution to Question 4:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) with lymph node metastases. The sarcomatoid type of RCC is commonly associated with ADPKD.
Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is a relatively rare complication of ADPKD. There does not seem to be an increased frequency of RCC in these patients compared to the general population. However, when it occurs, it tends to be bilateral, multicentric and of sarcomatoid type.
Solution to Question 5:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). These patients usually have impaired renal function. Hence, contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) would usually be avoided due to the risk of contrast nephrotoxicity.
The following investigations are done in patients with ADPKD:
USG abdomen - for screening and diagnosis
Non-contrast CT abdomen - more sensitive and picks up cysts of smaller size
MR-angiography of brain - pre-symptomatic screening for intracerebral aneurysms
Solution to Question 6:
Between 40-59 years of age, the presence of 2 cysts in each kidney is needed to diagnose ADPKD. This condition is diagnosed based on the USG findings using the Ravine’s criteria:
Age (in years)
Imaging findings

Solution to Question 7:
This clinical scenario and USG showing a cystic appearance of the kidney is suggestive of asymptomatic autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Surgical decompression is not a routine procedure performed in these patients. It may be required only in cases of very large cysts causing persistent pain and infected cysts.
The management includes the following:
Analgesics
Increased fluid intake
Prevents renal stone formation
Reduces growth of cysts by suppressing ADH release
ACE inhibitors and ARBs
Blood pressure contro
Slowing of cyst growth
Tolvaptan (V2 receptor antagonist)
Reduce pain and slow the decline in renal function
Renal transplant
Definitive management
Pre-transplant nephrectomy may be required in patients with very large polycystic kidneys
Solution to Question 8:
A PKHD1 mutation in the deceased infant is suggestive of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD). As the woman has signs of oligohydramnios, it is likely that this fetus also has ARPKD. Severe cases of ARPKD can be diagnosed in-utero with a USG. Prenatal testing can also be done.
ARPKD is a hereditary renal disease of childhood caused by a mutation in the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 6. It codes for fibrocystin/ polyductin (FPC), a membrane protein present in the cells of the cortical and medullary collecting ducts.
Affected fetuses show greatly enlarged kidneys and reduced fetal urine production. This leads to oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia. About 30% of neonates die soon after birth due to respiratory insufficiency. Most deaths occur < 1 month of life. Others develop chronic kidney disease and hypertension in early childhood.
Solution to Question 9:
Hepatic cysts are not a typical feature of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD).
They occur only in rare cases.
ARPKD is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. These patients commonly have the following findings:
Hypertension
Chronic renal insufficiency
Congenital hepatic fibrosis
Biliary dysgenesis with periportal fibrosis is seen
Can lead to portal hypertension
Caroli’s disease - dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts
Note: Caroli's disease is also associated with medullary sponge kidney.
Solution to Question 10:
The gene mutations causing the following cystic disorders are:
Medullary cystic kidney disease-1 (MCKD-1) - MUC1
Medullary cystic kidney disease-2 (MCKD-2) - UMOD
Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) - PKHD1
Adolescent nephronophthisis - NPHP 1-20
Medullary cystic kidney disease (MCKD) is an autosomal dominant disorder. It presents with a late-onset, slowly progressive renal failure. Renal cysts are not common but can be seen occasionally. Medullary cystic kidney diseases are of two types, MCKD1 and MCKD2.
MCKD1 is due to a defect in the mucin 1 (MUC1) gene. The mutated gene codes for a large protein fragment that has a toxic effect on the tubules. It is not associated with elevated uric acid levels and gout.
MCKD2 is due to a defect in the UMOD gene, which codes for the protein uromodulin. It is associated with hyperuricemia and gout.
Solution to Question 11:
Nephronophthisis is an autosomal recessive renal cystic disease.
It belongs to a category of conditions called ciliopathies. It occurs due to an underlying defect in the primary cilia of the tubular epithelial cells. The cilia play an important role in cell signaling and maintenance of cell growth, proliferation, and secretion.
Other ciliopathies include autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease, and medullary cystic kidney disease.
Solution to Question 12:
The most common inherited cause of kidney failure in childhood is nephronophthisis.
Nephronophthisis (NPHP) refers to a group of related, but genetically distinct, autosomal recessive disorders. Mutations are seen in the NPHP genes 1-20. These genes code for nephrocystins which are expressed on the kidney tubules.
NPHP is classified into infantile, juvenile, and adolescent forms. The juvenile form is the most common form. Common features include tubulointerstitial fibrosis, renal cysts, and chronic kidney disease.
Solution to Question 13:
Joubert’s syndrome is defined by the presence of juvenile nephronophthisis (NPHP) and multiple neurologic findings.
A few examples of multiorgan syndromes associated with nephronophthisis are:
Senior-Loken syndrome: NPHP with retinitis pigmentosa
Joubert syndrome: NPHP with multiple neurologic findings
Bardet-Biedl syndrome: NPHP with truncal obesity, cognitive impairment, retinal dystrophy, and polydactyly
Solution to Question 14:
The given image shows a paintbrush or bouquet of flowers appearance on intravenous pyelography (IVP). It occurs in medullary sponge kidney (MSK).
MSK is a sporadic benign condition that is often diagnosed incidentally. It is a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of the medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts. It is characterized by medullary cysts that are of variable size. It is associated with distal RTA which leads to hypercalciuria. The hypercalciuria leads to a tendency to form calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones. The patients can also have recurrent UTIs and hematuria.
CT urography has largely replaced intravenous pyelography as the investigation of choice.

subject: Medicine

question_text:
b
Solution to Question 1:
In renal tubular acidosis (RTA), there is normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
RTA refers to a group of disorders in which there is impaired tubular transport of H+ and/or HCO3- despite relatively well-preserved renal function. There are 4 types:
Type I - impaired H+ secretion (distal), leading to decreased HCO3- production
Type II - impaired HCO3- reabsorption (proximal)
Type III - carbonic anhydrase deficiency causing defects in the transport of both H+ and HCO3- (mixed)
Type IV - hypoaldosteronism (hyperkalemic)
The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal.
Solution to Question 2:
The most common type of renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is the type 4 or hyperkalemic type.
Solution to Question 3:
Type 4 renal tubular acidosis can be a congenital or acquired disorder.
It is caused by conditions that result in hypoaldosteronism or hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism including:
Diabetic nephropathy - most common
Tubulointerstitial disease
Addison's disease
Obstructive uropathy
Drugs like NSAIDs, ACEI, ARBs can increase the risk
Psuedohypoaldosteronism type 1 (due to aldosterone resistance)
Psuedohypoaldosteronism type 2/ gordons syndrome (due to defects in Na-Cl cotransporter)
Congenital isolated hypoaldosteronism (due to enzyme deficiency)
Solution to Question 4:
Hyperkalemia is a characteristic feature of type 4 RTA or generalized distal RTA. It commonly occurs in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
In CKD patients, renal dysfunction results in hyperkalemia only when the GFR is severely impaired (stage 5). Hyperkalemia in the earlier stages of CKD is suggestive of type 4 RTA.
In CKD, volume overload leads to low levels of renin and, hence, aldosterone. This leads to Na+ loss and K+ retention in the distal tubule. The resultant hyperkalemia causes impaired NH3 synthesis in the proximal tubule. Hence, H+ cannot be excreted as NH4+ ions. Retained H+ ions lead to reduced HCO3- production and acidosis.
Solution to Question 5:
Urinary pH will be > 5.5 after acid loading in RTA type 1.
In this condition, there is a defect in H+ secretion by the distal tubules. Hence, there is a failure of urine acidification. H+ combines with NH3 to form NH■■ and thus in RTA type 1, NH4+ excretion is reduced. In the acid loading test, acidosis is induced by the administration of NH4Cl (releases H+). In normal individuals, this results in increased excretion of H+, leading to acidic urine (pH < 5.5). However, this fails to occur in RTA type 1.
Impaired secretion of H+ leads to potassium wasting and hypokalemia (via the H+/K+ATPase antiporter). The resulting metabolic acidosis causes bone demineralization and resorption.
Solution to Question 6:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 RTA. In this condition, calcium phosphate and oxalate stones are formed in the distal convoluting tubules (DCT).
In this condition, there is a defect in H+ secretion by the distal tubules. This leads to:
Normal anion gap metabolic acidosi
Urinary pH > 5.5
Hypokalemia
Impaired H+ secretion causes K+ wasting
It improves following alkalinization therapy with NaHCO3
Acidemia leads to hypercalcemia and then hypercalciuria. There is also hypocitraturia as acidemia induces increased cell citrate utilization. Normally, citrate in the urine binds to calcium and increases its solubility. In the absence of citrate in the urine, calcium begins to precipitate.
This leads to nephrocalcinosis and calcium phosphate and oxalate stones.
Solution to Question 7:
Hypertonia is not a feature of Lowe's syndrome or oculo-cerebro-renal syndrome. The following clinical features are seen in this condition:
Hypotonia
Cataract
Glaucoma
Intellectual disability
Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) type 2
Solution to Question 8:
Dent's disease is an inherited cause of type 2 RTA. A proximal renal tubular defect is seen in this condition, not a distal tubular defect.
It is an X-linked recessive condition. It is caused by inactivating mutations in CLCN5, a chloride transporter expressed in endosomes of the proximal tubule. The resulting dysfunction of the proximal convoluted tubule and failure of reabsorption of substances leads to:
Hypercalciuria
Hypophosphatemia
Recurrent kidney stone
Solution to Question 9:
Medullary sponge kidney is a cause of RTA type 1, not type 2. The causes of RTA type 2 include:
Amyloidosi
Wilson's disease
Galactosemia
Hereditary fructose intolerance
Cystinosi
Lowe syndrome
Drugs - tenofovir, acetazolamide, topiramate The causes of RTA type 1 include:
Familial defect
Autoimmune conditions - SLE, Sjogren syndrome
Drugs - amphotericin, lithium, aminoglycosides, ifosfamide
Medullary sponge kidney
Solution to Question 10:
Renal stones are not a feature of type 2 or proximal RTA. This is because high levels of citrate in the urine bind with calcium and prevent stone formation.
In this condition, the cells of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) fail to reabsorb HCO3-. In the initial stages, this HCO3- loss leads to a urine pH > 5.5. However, as the body's HCO3- stores are depleted, the urinary pH falls to < 5.5 as the secretion of H+ in the DCT remains intact.
Hence, the minimum urinary pH is < 5.5.
It can be caused by Lowe's syndrome but a majority of type 2 RTA cases are associated with Fanconi's syndrome. This syndrome is characterized by a generalized defect of reabsorption of various substances at the PCT. This leads to loss of HCO3-, glucose, amino acids, phosphate, citrate, and calcium in the urine. Loss of phosphate leads to vitamin-D resistant hypophosphatemic rickets /osteomalacia.
Note: An exception is Dent's disease, a genetic cause of RTA type 2 in which renal stones are present.
Solution to Question 11:
Pathological fractures and a bone-in-bone appearance point towards a diagnosis of osteopetrosis. The lab values are significant for hypokalemia with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. These findings are suggestive of renal tubular acidosis (RTA) type 3.
Type 3 or mixed RTA is a rare condition that usually occurs in neonates and infants. It is due to an autosomal recessive, inherited carbonic anhydrase-2 (CA-2) deficiency. This results in features of both distal and proximal RTA with:
Failure to reabsorb HCO3 at PCT
Failure to excrete H+ at DCT
This results in the following findings:
Normal anion gap metabolic acidosi
Hypokalemia
Urinary pH > 5.5
Positive urine anion gap
As CA-2 is widely expressed, mutations of this gene result in a condition called marble brain disease or Guibaud-Vainsel syndrome. It presents with multiple clinical findings including:
Cerebral calcification
Mental retardation
Mixed RTA (Type 3 RTA)
Osteopetrosi
Solution to Question 12:
The clinical scenario with hypertension and metabolic alkalosis is suggestive of Liddle's syndrome.
It is an autosomal dominant condition due to a gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene. This gene codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. This leads to increased sodium retention and results in a state of pseudo-hyperaldosteronism. The following findings are seen:
Hypertension
Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosi
Normal-low aldosterone
Low renin
Treatment is with diuretics that directly block the ENaC channels, like amiloride and triamterene. Spironolactone is not effective as it is an aldosterone-receptor antagonist.
Solution to Question 13:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Bartter syndrome. It occurs due to a defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel in the thick ascending loop of Henle.
A defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel impairs the transport functions of the thick ascending loop of Henle. It results in the following features:
Polyuria and polydipsia
Natriuresis with high aldosterone (due to RAAS activation)
Hypokalemia
Metabolic alkalosi
Hypomagnesemia
Hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria
The clinical features of this condition are similar to the effects of loop diuretics. These drugs also act on the Na+/K+/Cl- channel. Hence, response to loop diuretics may be blunted. Treatment is with potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone and amiloride. NSAID's like indomethacin are second line drugs however they can reduce renal function.
Option A: Defect in the proximal tubule results in Fanconi's syndrome. These patients have acidosis, with glycosuria, generalized aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia.
Option B: Defect in the Na+/Cl- cotransporter in distal convoluted tubule (DCT) results in Gitelman syndrome. These patients also present with hypokalemic alkalosis
and hypomagnesemia. However, they also develop, hypocalciuria, and chondrocalcinosis.
Option D: Increased activation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) channels results in Liddle syndrome. This causes increased reabsorption of Na+ exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension.
Solution to Question 14:
Chvostek's sign (spasm of facial muscles on tapping the facial nerve) indicates tetany. In this patient with hypercalcemia, it is likely due to hypomagnesemia. These clinical features are suggestive of Gitelman syndrome.
This condition occurs due to a mutation of Na+/Cl- cotransporter in the distal collecting tubule
(DCT). The resulting impairment of the tubular transport leads to the following features:
Mild natriuresis with normal-low BP
Increased renin and aldosterone
Hypokalemia
Metabolic alkalosi
Hypercalcemia and hypocalciuria
Hypomagnesemia
The clinical features of this condition are similar to the effects of thiazide diuretics. These drugs also act on the Na+/Cl- cotransporter. Hence, response to thiazide diuretics may be blunted.
Treatment is with potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone and amiloride.
Option A: Bartter syndrome affects the Na+/K+/Cl- channels. It causes hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria.
Option C: Liddle syndrome causes increased activation of ENaC channels. It results in hypokalemia and hypertension.
Option D: Fanconi's syndrome occurs due to a defect in proximal tubular function. It results in metabolic acidosis.

Solution to Question 5:
This clinical scenario and image showing schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) in a woman are suggestive of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Blood transfusion is not preferred in TTP as it can aggravate the condition.
TTP is a type of thrombotic microangiopathy that occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies against the ADAMTS13 metalloprotease, which is responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor multimers. In the absence of this protein, vWF multimers aggregate and form thrombi. It presents with a classical pentad of clinical features:
Fever
Thrombocytopenia
Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
Renal failure
Neurological manifestations
It is treated with plasmapheresis and rituximab.
Solution to Question 6:
The most common cause of clinically significant renal artery stenosis is atherosclerosis.
Renal artery stenosis is a relatively common finding in older patients with chronic essential hypertension. However, it is considered clinically significant only when renovascular hypertension develops. It occurs in the case of:
> 70% stenosis in both renal arteries
> 50% stenosis with post stenotic dilatation The causes of renal artery stenosis are:
Atherosclerosis (most common) - common in older patients with cardiovascular risk factors
Fibromuscular dysplasia – more common in young, white females and is usually bilatera
Less common causes include:
Thromboemboli
External compression by tumors
Systemic vasculitis
Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
Transplant renal artery stenosis
Infrarenal aortic aneurysms and dissections
The investigation of choice for renal artery stenosis is renal angiography.
Solution to Question 7:
This clinical scenario and the string of beads appearance on CT angiography is characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common peripheral (limb) arteries affected are the iliac arteries.
Fibromuscular dysplasia is a segmental, non-atheromatous, dysplastic type of angiopathy that predominantly affects females. The most common subtype is medial fibroplasia. It is one of the major causes of renovascular hypertension. The most common sites of involvement in decreasing order of frequency are as follows:
Renal arteries
Carotid arteries
Peripheral (limb) arteries - most commonly iliac arteries
On angiography, a string of beads appearance is seen as shown below.

Solution to Question 8:
Atheroembolic kidney disease is associated with decreased complement levels.
Atheroembolic kidney disease is more frequent in males with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and ischemic heart disease. Most clinical atheroembolic events follow angiographic procedures, often of the coronary vessels.
It is associated with aortic aneurysms and renal artery stenosis. Systemic embolic manifestations such as fever, abdominal pain, and weight loss are also present, although cutaneous manifestations are more common like livedo reticularis and localized toe gangrene.
The lab findings include:
Rising serum creatinine
Transient eosinophilia
Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate
Hypocomplementemia
Definitive diagnosis depends on kidney biopsy which demonstrates microvessel occlusion with cholesterol crystals that leave a cleft in the vessel as shown below.

Solution to Question 9:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of renal artery stenosis. Renal intra-arterial angiography is the gold standard for diagnosis.In a patient with hypertension and increased creatinine,
an ultrasound of the abdomen must be performed first to visualize the renal size and morphology to look for a unilateral shrunken kidney and thereby renal artery stenosis.
Option A: MR angiography is less preferred as gadolinium contrast can lead to nephrogenic fibrosis, particularly in patients with reduced kidney function.
Option C: CT scan with image reconstruction provides an excellent image but also carries a risk of contrast nephropathy.
Option D: Renal arterial doppler ultrasound measures renal artery velocities and can predict hemodynamically important lesions. However, it is not the gold standard test. Duplex
ultrasonography is used as a screening investigation.
Solution to Question 10:
ACE inhibitors must be avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis (RAS).
In renal artery stenosis, blood flow to the kidney is reduced, thereby reducing blood flow to the afferent arterioles. Hence, constriction of efferent arterioles is needed to maintain hydrostatic pressure within the glomerulus in order to maintain GFR.
ACEIs and ARBs inhibit efferent renal arteriolar vasoconstriction. In bilateral RAS, this causes a decline in the GFR within a few days of starting the drug.
Note: Bilateral renal artery stenosis has been classically considered as an absolute contraindication to the use of ACE inhibitors. However, new studies show that they may be used in some cases with careful monitoring.

Solution to Question 1:
The "a" wave in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is a positive wave, which corresponds to right atrial contraction.
The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:
a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

Solution to Question 2:
The c-wave in a JVP waveform represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
JVP measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:
a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

Solution to Question 3:
The given waveform shows a cannon ‘a’ wave seen in ventricular tachycardia. It occurs since atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve in ventricular tachycardia.
JVP measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure.
Note: Giant/prominent a-waves occur during every beat while cannon a-waves result from arrhythmias, therefore, are usually intermittent. The ECG is helpful to look for rhythm disturbances that are associated with cannon a-waves whereas echocardiography can be used to assess structural defects (of right atrium) that are associated with giant a-waves.

Solution to Question 4:
Hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention (Beck’s triad) are the three principal features of cardiac tamponade. The typical JVP finding here is absent y-descent.
JVP shows a prominent x (early systolic) descent and an absent y (early diastolic) descent because of the ventricle's limited or absent early diastolic filling. JVP is almost always elevated in cardiac tamponade and may be associated with venous distention in the forehead and scalp.
There may be reductions in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, and electrical alternans of the P, QRS, or T waves in cardiac tamponade.
Note: Alternation of QRS complexes, usually in a 2:1 ratio, on ECG is called electrical alternans. It is caused by the movement of the heart in the pericardial space. Electrical alternans is also seen in patients with myocardial ischemia, acute pulmonary embolism, and tachyarrhythmias.

Solution to Question 5:
The y-descent in jugular venous pulse (JVP) corresponds to the fall in right atrial pressure after the tricuspid valve opening in the early diastolic phase of the right ventricle. Y-descent is attenuated or absent in cardiac tamponade because of resistance to ventricular filling in the early diastole.
Other options:
Options B and C: Restrictive cardiomyopathy and constrictive pericarditis can have deep y descent due to rapid filling of the right ventricle during early diastole.
Option D: In patients with tricuspid regurgitation, increased blood flow to the right atria through the incompetent tricuspid valve during ventricular systole results in a prominent v wave. When the tricuspid valve opens during ventricular diastole, this increased blood in the right atria enters rapidly into the right ventricle during early diastole resulting in deep y-descent.
Solution to Question 6:
Orthostatic hypotension is defined as a reduction in systolic blood pressure of at least 20
mmHg or diastolic blood pressure of at least 10 mmHg within 3 min of standing or head-up tilt on a tilt table.
On standing, blood is displaced to the lower extremities, causing a drop in the venous return to the heart. This drop leads to a decrease in cardiac output and stimulation of compensatory mechanisms which trigger a reflex increase in sympathetic (vasoconstrictor) outflow. Orthostatic hypotension is a manifestation of sympathetic (autonomic) failure.
Symptoms include light-headedness, dizziness, and presyncope (near-faintness) in response to sudden postural change.
Solution to Question 7:
Pulsus bisferiens is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, not pulsus paradoxus.
Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic pressure by > 10 mmHg with inspiration. It is an exaggeration of the normal response. It is seen in the following conditions:
Cardiac tamponade
Massive pulmonary embolism
Hemorrhagic shock
Obstructive lung disease
Tension pneumothorax
Solution to Question 8:
Pulsus alternans (characterized by alternating strong and weak beats) is seen in left ventricular dysfunction.
Pulsus bisferiens is a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. It is seen in the following conditions:
Advanced aortic regurgitation (AR)
Aortic stenosis (AS) with AR
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Solution to Question 9:
Water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan’s pulse, is characterized by a sharp rise and a rapid fall-off and is seen in aortic regurgitation (AR) due to the fact that arterial pressure falls rapidly in late systole and early diastole.
In AR, the pulse pressure is widened due to systolic hypertension and decreased diastolic pressure. The diastolic pressure is measured at Korotkoff phase IV. In certain patients with AR or a combination of aortic stenosis (AS) and AR, the carotid arterial pulse may exhibit a bisferiens pattern, characterized by two systolic waves separated by a trough.
The apical impulse is heaving and displaced inferiorly. A diastolic thrill may be palpable along the left sternal border.
A2 is usually absent in AR. An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic AR. It is best heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge.

Severe AS (Option A) would show pulsus parvus et tardus, characterized by the carotid pulse rising slowly to a delayed peak.
Chronic mitral regurgitation (Option D) shows a sharp, low volume upstroke due to reduced cardiac output and acute mitral regurgitation demonstrates narrow pulse pressure.
Solution to Question 10:
Rheumatic mitral stenosis is associated with loud S1.
The greater the distance the valve travels to close, the louder is the sound. Increased left atrial pressures in rheumatic mitral stenosis force the mobile portion of the mitral valve leaflets far apart such that they are forced closed from a relatively far distance, resulting in a loud S1. In calcific mitral stenosis, leaflet mobility is poor, and they are not separated by a large distance, resulting in a soft S1.
Loud S1 is heard in the following:
Short PR intervals
Early stages of mitral stenosis as long as the valves are pliable
Atrial myxoma
High output states
Tachycardia
Soft S1 is heard in the following:
Mitral regurgitation
Aortic regurgitation
Long PR intervals
Calcified Mitral stenosis
Left ventricular contractile dysfunction
Beta-receptor blockers
ericardial effusion, obesity, COPD- due to decreased conduction through the chest wall
Solution to Question 11:
Reversed (or paradoxical) splitting refers to the situation when P2 is heard before A2. This is seen in the following:
LBBB
HOCM
Right ventricular pacing
Severe AS
Acute myocardial ischemia
Solution to Question 12:
Loud S1 is heard in mild mitral stenosis (MS).
The intensity of S1 depends on the distance over which the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve moves, leaflet mobility, LV contractility, and PR interval. It is independent of the severity of MS.
Loud S1 is seen in early rheumatic MS, short PR interval, and hyperdynamic circulatory states.
S1 becomes soft in case of calcified leaflets, long PR interval, associated aortic regurgitation and LV dysfunction.
Solution to Question 13:
A wide split of S2 is not seen in the left bundle branch block (LBBB), however paradoxical splitting is seen.
S2 is normally heard as A2-P2. This split is exaggerated in conditions that cause early aortic valve closure or delayed pulmonary valve closure.
Option A: In atrial septal defect (ASD), left ventricle (LV) ejection time decreases due to the shunting of the blood from the left atrium (LA) to the right atrium leading to early aortic valve closure.
Option B: In mitral regurgitation (MR), due to the regurgitation of blood from the LV to the LA, the LV ejection time decreases leading to early aortic valve closure.
Option C: In pulmonary stenosis (PS), the delayed closure of pulmonary valves leads to the splitting of S2.
Wide splitting of S2 is also heard in RBBB and LV pacing.
Solution to Question 14:
Fixed wide splitting of S2 is seen in atrial septal defect (ASD).
The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of inspiration/expiration.
Solution to Question 15:
S4 is heard during the ventricular-filling phase.
S3 and S4 are diastolic sounds that are low pitched, and best heard with the bell of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex in the left lateral decubitus position.
The presence of an S3 and S4 heart sound is called a summation gallop and sounds like a galloping horse.

Solution to Question 16:
In a patient with a right bundle branch block (RBBB), there's a widely split S1 which increases with inspiration.
S1 is normally heard as a single sound. Any delay in the closure of the tricuspid valve or early closure of the mitral valve produces a split in S1. During inspiration, venous return to the right
atrium increases. Therefore, the atria take a longer time to empty into the ventricles delaying the closure of the tricuspid valve. This increases the split in S1 during inspiration. In a patient with an RBBB, the tricuspid valve closure is further delayed leading to a wide split in S1.
Solution to Question 17:
The probable diagnosis of the above scenario is Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS).
EDS is a group of clinically and genetically heterogeneous connective tissue disorders. Typical presenting features include joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility. EDS type 6 is also characterized by scoliosis. Gorlin’s sign refers to the ability of patients
of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of their tongue.
Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is a frequent finding in patients with EDS. An early systolic click which may be followed by a late systolic murmur is the auscultatory finding heard in MVP.
Solution to Question 18:
The ejection click is a systolic sound.
Ejection clicks are high-pitched sounds that occur at the moment of the maximal opening of the aortic or pulmonary valves. They are heard just after the first heart sound.
Ejection clicks occur in:
Non-calcific aortic or pulmonary stenosis
Aortic or pulmonary root dilatation
Congenital bicuspid aortic or pulmonary valves
Nonejection clicks, which occur after the onset of the carotid upstroke, are related to the mitral valve prolapse.
Solution to Question 19:
A murmur occurring between S1 and S2 is a systolic murmur. Pulmonary regurgitation produces a diastolic murmur.
The causes of systolic murmurs are as follows:
Mid-systolic- aortic stenosis, pulmonic stenosis, ASD, HOCM.
Holosystolic/pansystolic- mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, VSD.
Late systolic- mitral valve prolapse.
The causes of diastolic murmurs are as follows:
Early diastolic- aortic regurgitation, pulmonic regurgitation.
Mid/late diastolic- mitral stenosis, tricuspid stenosis, Austin-Flint. The causes of continuous murmurs are as follows:
atent ductus arteriosus (machinery or Gibson's murmur).
Venous hum
AV fistula
Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm
Solution to Question 20:
A mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation and an opening snap is typically seen in mitral stenosis.
The presystolic accentuation is due to the atrial contraction forcing blood through the stenosed mitral valve. The presystolic accentuation disappears in atrial fibrillation.
Option A: Mitral regurgitation presents with a holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex with radiation to the left axilla.
Option B: Mitral valve prolapse presents with an early systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur is heard.
Option C: Aortic stenosis presents with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo ejection systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border, with radiation of the murmur to the carotid arteries.
Solution to Question 21:
The above image shows the Valsalva maneuver. The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
(HCM) increases in intensity while performing the Valsalva maneuver.
The murmurs produced by TR (tricuspid regurgitation), AS (aortic stenosis), and MR (mitral regurgitation) decrease in intensity while performing the Valsalva maneuver.
Note: Valsalva maneuver decreases the intensity of all murmurs except MVP (mitral valve prolapse) and HCM.
Solution to Question 22:
The above image shows a sustained handgrip maneuver. The murmur of aortic stenosis decreases in intensity during sustained handgrip.
Maneuvers like sustained handgrip, simultaneous inflation of blood pressure cuffs above the systolic in both upper limbs, and infusion of vasopressors increase the systemic vascular resistance (afterload). Since increasing afterload will prevent blood from flowing in a normal forward path, it will increase any murmurs that are due to backward flowing blood and decresase the ones due to forward blood flow.
Murmurs that increase in intensity on sustained handgrip:
Mitral regurgitation
Ventricular septal defect
Aortic regurgitation
Murmurs that decrease in intensity on sustained handgrip:
Aortic stenosis
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Solution to Question 23:
The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) increases with standing, as there is a reduction in preload. In conditions of reduced preload, there is lesser end diastolic volume in the left ventricle, leading to a narrower outflow tract, and a louder murmur is heard.
The murmur heard in HOCM is a mid-systolic murmur, which is loudest along the left sternal border. It increases in conditions of decreased preload and afterload (standing, valsalva, vagal maneuvers) or conditions of increased contractility (inotropic stimulation) and decreases when preload and afterload are increased (squatting, vasopressors).
Most murmurs decrease in intensity with reduced preload and afterload except HOCM and mitral valve prolapse (MVP).
Solution to Question 24:
The murmur described above is a continuous murmur.
A continuous murmur is produced when there is a pressure gradient between the cardiac chambers or the blood vessels throughout the systole and diastole. Continous murmurs are characterised by the flow of blood in the same direction and through the same channel during systole and diastole. These murmurs begin in systole, envelope the second heart sound (S2), and continue through some portion of diastole.
Conditions producing a continuous murmur:
atent ductus arteriosus
Venous hum
AV fistula
Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm
Ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation does not produce a continuous murmur. It produces a systolic-diastolic murmur as the blood flows through different channels during systole and diastole. These murmurs do not envelope S2.
Solution to Question 25:
The Gallavardin effect refers to the phenomenon of the transmission of the mid-systolic murmur of aortic stenosis to the apex where it becomes higher pitched.
Solution to Question 26:
A holosystolic murmur that is best heard over the lower left sternal border and radiating to the epigastrium most likely arises from tricuspid regurgitation.
Solution to Question 27:
Still’s murmur refers to the benign grade 2 mid-systolic murmur heard at mid or lower left sternal border in normal children and adolescents. Louder in hyperdynamic states(fever, anxiety).
The anatomic basis for the murmur has not been definitively determined. It is best heard in a supine position.
Solution to Question 28:
Graham Steell murmur is the early to mid-diastolic murmur heard in pulmonary regurgitation.
It is best heard in 2nd left intercostal space and radiates along left sternal border. It can increase with inspiration.
Solution to Question 29:
Carey Coombs murmur is heard in mitral valvulitis.
It is a mid-diastolic murmur heard during an episode of acute rheumatic fever causing mitral valvulitis.
It is produced due to the flow of blood through an edematous mitral valve and dissipates with the resolution of the acute attack.
Solution to Question 30:
Austin-Flint murmur is a low-pitched mid to late diastolic murmur of chronic severe AR.
It results from the turbulence at the mitral inflow area from the mixture of regurgitant and forward blood flow. It is best heard at the apex.
Austin-Flint murmur is often confused with the murmur of mitral stenosis. This can be differentiated based on the following:

Murmur becomes shorter an d softer.Mechanism- Fall in t he diastolic pressure gradient between the aorta and left ve ntricle.
Murmur remains constant or increases in intensity.Mecha nism- Reflex increase in cardi ac output and mitral valve flo w.
Solution to Question 31:
The clinical scenario of transient loss of consciousness in this patient is suggestive of syncope. Hence, an ECG must be done to rule out cardiac causes for syncope like - arrhythmias (atrial fibrillation, sinus node dysfunction, supra ventricular tachycardias) or a structural cardiac abnormality.
A CT would only be required if a seizure or transient ischemic attack (TIA) is suspected. However, in this case - the episode only lasted for a few seconds, the patient has no history of similar episodes in the past and there are no lasting neurological deficits after the episode. Therefore, option B is incorrect.
Syncope is a transient loss of consciousness caused by global cerebral hypoperfusion. It can be due to multiple causes, but is broadly divided into - neurally mediated syncope, orthostatic hypotension and cardiac syncope.
The initial workup for a case of syncope includes:
Detailed history of the episode and past history of similar episodes
hysical examination mainly to check BP in standing and supine positions to
rule out orthostatic hypotension.
A resting ECG to look for cardiac arrhythmia
Option B: If the ECG is normal, no further tests are needed. If the ECG is suggestive of cardiac arrhythmia, then further tests including continuous ECG monitoring and electrophysiological studies may be done.
Option C: Tilt-table testing is done in patients with recurrent syncopal attacks who are suspected to have vasovagal syncope. Psychiatric evaluation is done in patients with recurrent unexplained syncopal attacks.
Option D: Vestibular neuritis is associated with vertigo, where the patients typically complain of dizziness and a sense of spinning of the head.

Solution to Question 1:
The T wave in ECG is due to ventricular repolarisation.
Solution to Question 2:
The normal duration of the PR interval is 0.12-0.2 seconds (3 to 5 small boxes).
PR interval is said to be prolonged if it is > 0.2 seconds and short if it is < 0.12 seconds.
It is measured from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. It represents the time from the start of atrial depolarization to the start of ventricular depolarization.

Solution to Question 3:
The normal duration of the QRS interval is normally 0.1-0.11 seconds (less than 3 small boxes). QRS interval represents the duration of ventricular depolarization. When the QRS complex is >

Bundle branch blocks (RBBB or LBBB)
Depolarizations originating in the ventricles
