Solution to Question 4:
As all the waves (P, QRS, T) are negative in the given ECG, it should be lead aVR. All the depolarisations waves (P, QRS, T) move away from lead aVR in the normal sinus.
Depolarisation wave moving towards the positive pole of the lead (or active electrode) produces a positive deflection in the ECG and depolarization moving away from the positive pole of the lead produces a negative deflection in the ECG.
The lead aVR provides information from the right upper side of the heart.

Solution to Question 5:
In a normal ECG, a biphasic P wave is seen in lead V1 only.
Lead V1 is a chest lead. So, it records potentials in the horizontal plane. The P wave in lead V1 consists of:
Positive component reflecting right atrial depolarization (due to anteriorly oriented vector)
Negative component reflecting left atrial depolarization (due to posteriorly oriented vector)

Solution to Question 6:
With the cardiac axis at +‹0 degrees, lead aVF would show the maximum R wave.
The cardiac axis represents the mean QRS axis (direction of mean depolarization vector). The normal adult QRS axis is directed downward and to the left, which is between
-30 degrees and +100 degrees.
The position of lead aVF is at +‹0 degrees. If the cardiac axis is also at +‹0 degrees, it would be in the same direction as lead aVF and hence aVF would show maximum R wave amplitude.
If the mean axis is:
More negative than –30 degrees: left axis deviation
More positive than +‹0 to +100 degrees: right axis deviation
Lies between -‹0 to +1˜0 degrees: extreme axis deviation

Solution to Question 7:
Pseudo P pulmonale refers to tall peaked P waves seen in hypokalemia. P-pulmonale refers to P waves taller than >2.5mm in an ECG lead.

Hypocalcemia (Option C) prolongs the QT interval. Hypercalcemia (Option D) shortens the QT interval.
Solution to Question 8:
Prolonged QT interval with flat T waves is seen in hypokalemia.
Hypokalemia prolongs ventricular repolarization. The ECG changes seen are as follows:
Flattening of T wave
ST-segment depression
Prolongation of QT interval
The appearance of U wave

Solution to Question 9:
The P waves in the given ECG are broad and notched. This is the P mitrale pattern which is seen in left atrial enlargement.
This patient has likely developed mitral stenosis (heard as a mid-diastolic murmur) secondary to his rheumatic heart disease. Mitral valve stenosis and atrial inflammation in rheumatic carditis lead to left atrial dilation.
The features of P mitrale are:
lead II: broad (>2.5mm) notched P waves
Lead V1: Biphasic wave with a prominent negative terminal component (representing delayed depolarization of the LA)
P pulmonale is seen in right atrial enlargement.

Option A: The rabbit ear pattern is seen in the right bundle branch block. The ECG of RBBB below shows the rSR' pattern of the QRS complex (rabbit ear) in leads V1-V2 and slurred S wave in lead V6.

Option D: Sawtooth pattern in ECG is seen in atrial flutter (shown below).

Solution to Question 10:
In the given ECG, a peaked P wave can be seen. This is called P pulmonale and it is seen in cases of right atrial enlargement. The patient is showing features of heart failure possibly as a consequence of dysfunction caused by the overload.
Signs of heart failure in this patient:
Bilateral pitting edema in lower extremities (systemic congestion)
Worsening dyspnea due to increased PCWP causing pulmonary hypertension and pulmonary edema (pulmonary congestion)
The features of P pulmonale include:
The amplitude of the P wave is >2.5mm on Lead II
Prominent positive wave in the biphasic P wave of lead V1

Solution to Question 11:
The given ECG shows deep S-waves in V6 and large R-waves in V1. This is suggestive of right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH).
Diagnostic criteria for RVH:
Dominant R wave in V1 (R/S ratio > 1).
Dominant S wave in V5 or V6 (R/S ratio < 1).
Right ventricular strain pattern - ST depression/T wave inversion in the right precordial (V1-4)
and inferior leads (II, III, aVF)
Right axis deviation of +110° or more.
For left ventricular hypertrophy, Sokolow Lyon criteria are commonly used.
It is based on the presence of tall left precordial R waves and deep right precordial S waves (S wave in V1 + [R wave in V5 or V6] >35 mm).

Solution to Question 12:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block
(LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:
Wide QRS complex- QRS 120 ms
Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) MI can have the following ECG changes:
ST-segment elevation- zone of injury
T wave depression
Deep Q waves- late sign to develop
New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)

Solution to Question 13:
The given ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior chest leads suggestive of myocardial infarction.
Features of MI on ECG:
ST-segment elevation: Zone of injury
T wave inversions
Deep Q waves: late sign to develop
New left bundle branch block (LBBB)
Option A: Atrial flutter shows a sawtooth wave pattern. Option B: WPW syndrome shows delta waves.
Option D: Ventricular tachycardia has wide QRS complex and increased heart rate.
Solution to Question 14:
The given ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4 which is suggestive of acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction (MI). ST depression in the leads III and aVF signifies an old inferior wall infarction.
Solution to Question 15:
The ECG shows ST elevations in leads I, aVL, and V1-V6. This is suggestive of extensive anterior wall MI.
Solution to Question 16:
The ECG is suggestive of lateral wall MI and possible posterior wall MI.
ST-elevation is present in the high lateral leads (I and aVL) and in V5 and V6.
Reciprocal ST depression is seen in the inferior leads (III and aVF) with associated ST depression in V1, V2, and V3 (which could represent posterior wall MI).
This pattern is consistent with an acute infarction localized to the superior portion of the lateral wall of the left ventricle (high lateral STEMI).
Solution to Question 17:
The given ECG is of posterior wall MI.
The ECG findings in posterior wall MI include,
Reciprocal ST depressions in leads V1 to V3. Posterior wall ischemia is indirectly recognized in this way
Tall and broad R waves (>30ms) in V2 and V3
Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2
Upright terminal portions of the T waves in V2 and V3
Solution to Question 18:
Prolonged QT interval is not a feature of hyperkalemia, it is a feature of hypokalemia.

Solution to Question 19:
The above scenario is suggestive of hypercalcemia due to ectopic production of PTH-related peptides. It is mostly associated with squamous-cell lung cancer (SCC). ECG is likely to show a decreased QT interval.
Hypocalcemia shows increased QT interval.
Solution to Question 20:
QT interval of 0.55s suggests QT prolongation. It is not seen in digitalis toxicity. Rather, a QT shortening with characteristic “scooping” of the ST–T-wave complex, called a digitalis effect, is seen.
The ECG changes seen in digitalis toxicity are as follows:
Prolonged PR interval
ST-segment depression
Short QT interval
QT interval represents the time taken for the ventricles to depolarize and repolarize. It is prolonged in the following:
Hypocalcemia
Hypokalemia
Congenital long QT syndromes such as Romano-Ward syndrome
Hypothermia
Drugs: Class IA and Class III antiarrhythmics
Intracranial bleeds: particularly SAH
Solution to Question 21:
Osborn waves are seen in hypothermia.
Osborn waves can also be seen in severe hypothyroidism (Option A), but even in those cases, hypothermia is the reason for the appearance of Osborn waves. Therefore, hypothermia is the better answer here.
It consists of an abrupt ascent right at the J point (the junctional point between the QRS complex and the ST segment) and then an equally sudden plunge back to the baseline. It is also called the J wave. This is because systemic hypothermia prolongs repolarisation.

Osborn wave can also be seen in:
Hypercalcemia
Brain injury
Subarachnoid hemorrhage
Vasospastic angina
Cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation
Idiopathic ventricular fibrillation
Solution to Question 22:
Right axis deviation is seen in left-sided pneumothorax.
The ECG changes seen in left-sided pneumothorax are as follows:
Reduced R wave amplitude
Inversion of T wave in precordial leads
Amplitude changes in QRS complex
Right axis deviation

Solution to Question 1:
The above ECG strip shows normal sinus rhythm.
The features in this ECG that suggest this diagnosis are as follows:
The QRS complexes are narrow (<120 ms or 3 small squares) which implies that the impulse is supraventricular and is conducted via the normal conduction pathway.

Each QRS complex is preceded by a P wave. This means that all the atrial depolarizations that arise in the sinus node are conducted to the ventricles.

The PR interval is constant for all the impulses and is normal (<200 ms) in duration.

The RR interval is constant which implies a regular rhythm.

Solution to Question 2:
Premature ventricular beats are a type of ventricular tachycardias, not supraventricular tachycardias.
Tachycardia is defined as a heart rate of >100 beats/min. It can be classified based on the site of origin of the cardiac impulse as follows:
Supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) originate above the ventricles, that is, in the sinoatria node, atria, or the atrioventricular node. Supraventricular tachycardias include:
Tachycardias originating from the atrium:
Sinus tachycardia- from the SA node
Focal atrial tachycardia
Multifocal atrial tachycardia
Atrial flutter
Atrial fibrillation
Tachycardias originating from the AV node:
Junctional tachycardia- automaticity within AV Node
AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT)
Tachycardia associated with accessory atrioventricular pathways: atrioventricular reentry tachycardia (AVRT)
Ventricular tachycardias originate from the ectopic foci or the reentry pathways in the ventricles. Ventricular tachycardias include:
Premature ventricular beats
Ventricular tachycardia (VT)
Monomorphic VT- Very rapid monomorphic VT is also known as ventricular flutter
Polymorphic VT- associated with Torsades de pointes
Ventricular fibrillation

Solution to Question 3:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT).
Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology:
Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat
Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT.
The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease.
Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG.
Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like:
Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch
Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT
The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:


Solution to Question 4:
The most common supraventricular arrhythmia is sinus tachycardia. It can either be physiological or pathological. Physiological sinus tachycardia is seen in exercise, fever, anemia, hyperthyroidism, etc.
Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias are those supraventricular tachycardias that occur with sudden onset and termination, they are non-sustained arrhythmias (lasts < 30 seconds). They include AVNRT, AVRT, and atrial tachycardias.
The most common sustained (lasts > 30 seconds) arrhythmia is atrial fibrillation.
Junctional tachycardia originates from ectopic foci in the AV node. It is an uncommon tachycardia.
Solution to Question 5:
ECG showing tachyarrhythmia with a narrow QRS complex suggests a supraventricular tachycardia. An irregular RR interval is seen with the following supraventricular tachycardias:
Atrial fibrillation
Multifocal atrial tachycardia
Atrial flutter/ atrial tachycardia with variable block
The ECG below shows atrial fibrillation. Note the narrow QRS complexes and irregular RR intervals. Disappearacne of P-wave is another feature.

Solution to Question 6:
The ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves. This is suggestive of atrial fibrillation.
Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a supraventricular tachycardia caused by ectopic foci or small reentry circuits within the atria. It has an atrial rate of 400-600/min and a ventricular rate of
subject: Medicine

question_text:
160/min.
Risk factors for developing AF include:
Age- usually above 60 years of age
Underlying heart disease
Hypertension
Diabetes mellitus
Obesity
Sleep apnea
Post-cardiac surgery
Inflammatory pericarditis
Acute precipitating factors for AF include:
Hyperthyroidism
Acute alcohol intoxication
Acute illness like myocardial infarction and pulmonary embolism

Solution to Question 7:
The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered
in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease. Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:
In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:
Flecainide
Propafenone
Disopyramide
In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period:
Amiodarone
Dofetilide
Sotalo
Ibutilide

Solution to Question 8:
A patient of atrial fibrillation usually has an irregular heart rate of >100/ min but this patient presents with a regular slow heart rate. The most likely cause of slow regular heart rate in chronic AF is digitalis toxicity. Symptoms such as nausea, anorexia are also suggestive of digitalis toxicity.
Digitalis lowers the AV nodal conduction by stimulating the vagal nerve endings leading to increased vagal tone. Hence digitalis toxicity can cause AV nodal block. This leads to a junctional escape rhythm taking over the ventricles causing slow and regular heart rate.
Digitalis toxicity can also lead to a variety of arrhythmias as it increases the intracellular calcium levels increasing the risk of tachyarrhythmias.
Solution to Question 9:
The given ECG is suggestive of atrial flutter.
The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes, hence it is supraventricular tachycardia. The RR intervals are regular and the normal P waves are replaced by sawtooth-shaped waves, known as flutter waves.
In atrial flutter, the ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio. The commonest AV ratio is 2:1. In the above ECG, the rhythm is atrial flutter 4:1 block with an atrial rate of about 270 and a ventricular rate of 68/min.
The image below shows sawtooth shaped waves in atrial flutter.

Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pulmonary disease and the ECG showing different p wave morphologies are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia.
Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) occurs due to impulses arising from multiple abnormal foci in the atria. This leads to supraventricular tachycardia with p waves and QRS complexes of different morphologies. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness.
Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. Calcium-channel blockers and radiofrequency ablation of the AV node are the other treatment modalities.
The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals, hence it can be atrial fibrillation or multifocal atrial tachycardia. The next step is to look at the p waves. Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image). Whereas, in atrial fibrillation, there would be no distinct p waves seen.

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias are tachycardias that occur with sudden onset and termination, they are not sustained arrhythmias. They include

Atrial tachycardia
Whereas, atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia among supraventricular tachycardias.

Adenosine is the preferred drug in stable paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).
Treatment of PSVT:
In hemodynamically unstable patients, QRS-synchronous DC cardioversion should be done. In hemodynamically stable patients,
Mechanical measures: These maneuvers result in an acute increase in the vagal tone which decreases AV conduction and terminates the arrhythmia. They include the following:
Valsalva maneuver
Lowering the head between the knees
Coughing
Splashing cold water on the face
Breath-holding
Carotid sinus massage
Pharmacologic therapy:
Adenosine- it is the first-line agent. It blocks conduction across the AV node and terminates the SVT. It is given as a 6-18 mg bolus
Calcium channel blockers- verapamil and diltiazem
Beta-blockers- esmolol, propranolol, and metoprolo
IV Procainamide- it is administered if the tachycardia is being mediated through an accessory pathway. It facilitates the AV conduction and therefore causes an initial increase in rate. Therefore, it is given after administering calcium channel blockers or beta-blockers.

Solution to Question 13:
The given ECG showing narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with absent P wave is suggestive of paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The next best step in the management of a patient with unstable vitals (systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg) is synchronized cardioversion.
Synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice in unstable PSVT patients, in which shocks are delivered with the defibrillator/monitor in synchronized mode with an initial energy level of 100J. Synchronization times the delivery so that it is given at the peak of the QRS complex.
If the shock occurs in the ST segment or the T wave (unsynchronized), it can precipitate a more serious arrhythmia such as ventricular fibrillation.

The next step in the management of PSVT in a hemodynamically stable (systolic blood pressure >90 mm Hg) patient is vagotonic maneuvres such as carotid sinus massage or Valsalva maneuver.
Carotid sinus massage can be considered in the absence of carotid bruits and no history of stroke. If vagal maneuvers fail or cannot be performed, intravenous adenosine can be used.
Non-DHP calcium channel blockers and beta blockers are second-line pharmacological agents in the management of PSVT. They can cause hypotension before and after terminating the arrhythmia.
If the patient is hemodynamically unstable (systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg or mean arterial pressure <65 mm Hg), immediate QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is necessary.

Solution to Question 16:
Retrograde conduction via accessory pathways does not cause preexcitation.
Accessory pathways (APs) are abnormal conduction pathways connecting the atrium and ventricle. They can conduct impulses in the following ways:
Antegrade conduction:
Occurs from the atria to the ventricle
The impulses from atria reach the ventricles faster via the accessory pathway as compared to the normal AV nodal pathway as they bypass the AV nodal delay.
This leads to an earlier excitation of the ventricles known as the preexcitation of the ventricles and thus a wide QRS complex.
Examples- WPW syndrome and antidromic AVRT Retrograde conduction:
Occurs from the ventricle to the atria.
The impulses reach the ventricles via the normal AV nodal pathway but re-enter the atria through the accessory pathway.
Ventricular depolarization is normal, there is no preexcitation and thus a narrow QRS complex. It causes supraventricular tachycardia as the impulses re-enter the atria via the accessory pathway.
Examples- concealed accessory pathways (can cause SVTs) and orthodromic AVRT.
Solution to Question 17:
The most common reentrant tachycardia caused by an accessory pathway is orthodromic AV reentry.
Accessory pathways (APs) are abnormal conduction pathways connecting the atrium and ventricle. They can conduct impulses in the following ways:
Antegrade conduction:
Occurs from the atria to the ventricle
The impulses from atria reach the ventricles faster via the accessory pathway as compared to the normal AV nodal pathway as they bypass the AV nodal delay.
This leads to an earlier excitation of the ventricles known as the preexcitation of the ventricles and thus a wide QRS complex.
Examples- WPW syndrome and antidromic AVRT Retrograde conduction:
Occurs from the ventricle to the atria.
The impulses reach the ventricles via the normal AV nodal pathway but re-enter the atria through the accessory pathway.
Ventricular depolarization is normal, there is no preexcitation and thus a narrow
QRS complex. It causes supraventricular tachycardia as the impulses re-enter the atria via the accessory pathway.
Examples- concealed accessory pathways (can cause SVTs) and orthodromic AVRT.
AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT) is not caused by an accessory pathway. It involves tissues with different conduction speeds within the AV node or just adjacent to the AV node, known as the fast pathway and the slow pathway. This is known as dual AV nodal physiology.
Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient with WPW syndrome with atrial fibrillation.
Rate-slowing drugs such as non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg, verapamil, diltiazem), beta-blockers, and digoxin are contraindicated in these patients. They increase the refractoriness of the AV node with minimal or no effect on the accessory pathway. This can lead to faster ventricular rates, increasing the risk of ventricular fibrillation.
The ECG below shows a short PR interval (<120 ms) and delta waves in WPW syndrome.

Solution to Question 20:
The given ECG is suggestive of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Its prevalence decreases with age.
The classic ECG features in WPW are as follows:
A shortened PR interval (typically <120 ms)
A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
A widened QRS complex (total duration >0.12 seconds)
ST-segment–T wave (repolarization) changes, generally directed opposite the major delta wave and QRS complex, reflecting altered depolarization

Solution to Question 21:
The ECG shows the presence of delta waves (preexcitation wave), wide QRS, and short PR interval which are classically seen in Wolff Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome. In this patient, catheter ablation is the best for long-term management.
Patients with preexcitation who have symptoms of arrhythmia are at risk for developing AF and sudden death if they have an accessory pathway that allows rapid antegrade conduction (preexcitation & tachyarrhythmias are features of WPW syndrome due to the abnormal accessory pathway).
Complications of catheter ablation are rare but include AV block, cardiac tamponade, thromboembolic events, and hematoma at the access site.
Solution to Question 22:
Sick sinus syndrome is frequently seen in patients with concomitant atrial fibrillation.
Sick sinus syndrome (or sinus node dysfunction) is a group of abnormal heart rhythms. It is a disorder of the sinoatrial node caused by impaired pacemaker function and impulse transmission. This leads to a combination of abnormal rhythms, including atrial bradyarrhythmias, atrial tachyarrhythmias, and sometimes a pattern of alternating bradycardia and tachycardia, known as tachy-brady syndrome. These irregular rhythms can cause symptoms such as palpitations, decreased tissue perfusion, subsequent fatigue, lightheadedness, pre-syncope, and syncope.
The management of sick sinus syndrome includes identifying and correcting reversible factors, as an initial step.
Some examples of reversible causes of Sinus Node Dysfunction include,
Hypothyroidism
Sleep apnea
Anti-hypertensive medications eg. Beta-blockers
Anti-arrhythmic medications eg. Amiodarone, Procainamide
Ambulatory ECG monitoring is required to diagnose as the symptoms are nonspecific. Treatment involves permanent pacing.
Other options:
Option A: The course of sinus node dysfunction is usually a slow progression over decades. In the early stages, most patients are asymptomatic.
Option B: It occurs most commonly in elderly patients due to the gradual loss of SA node function.
Option D: Beta-blockers are contraindicated in this condition.

Solution to Question 1:
The above ECG shows a pattern of premature ventricular contractions, one premature beat after one normal beat. This is seen in ventricular bigeminy.
Premature ventricular contractions/beats (PVC) are single ventricular beats that occur earlier than the next normal supraventricular beat. They originate from abnormal foci in the ventricular tissue:
Unifocal PVCs arise from a single focus and hence have the same QRS morphology
Multifocal PVCs arise from multiple foci and therefore have different QRS morphologie
They are not preceded by a P wave as they do not originate in the atria. They show wide QRS complexes (>0.12 ms) on the ECG because they are conducted via normal myocardial tissue instead of the Purkinje system.
Ventricular bigeminy refers to a pair of normal and premature ventricular contractions, whereas ventricular trigeminy refers to a premature beat that occurs after two normal beats. Quadrigeminy is when a premature beat follows three normal beats.
Few other terms associated with premature ventricular contractions:
Two successive PVCs are known as a couplet
Three successive PVCs are known as a triplet.
The given ECG shows ventricular bigeminy with premature beats circled in red and normal ventricular contractions circled in green.

Solution to Question 2:
The ECG feature of ventricular tachycardia seen in the given image is a fusion beat. It occurs when a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex.
Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is defined as  3 consecutive premature ventricular contractions at a rate of >100/min. It is characterized by:
Wide QRS complex
AV dissociation- Atrial activity independent of ventricular activity, seen on the ECG as every p wave not followed by QRS complex
Fusion beats- occur when a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex
Capture beats occur when the SA node transiently ‘captures’ the ventricles, that is, ventricles are depolarized by the impulses from the SA node producing a QRS complex of normal duration.
The given ECG shows a fusion beat (red arrow), and a capture beat (green arrow) can also be seen:

The given image shows capture beats in VT:

Option C: Polymorphic QRS, that is, continuously changing QRS morphology is seen in polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
Option D: Triphasic QRS (eg. RSR pattern on V1) is seen in supraventricular tachycardias with the wide QRS complex.
Solution to Question 3:
The rate of the given ECG is around 188 BPM ( >100 BPM) and it shows wide QRS complexes (
 0.12 s) with abnormal morphology (red arrows) and absence of P waves which suggests a diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia.

Ventricular fibrillation (Option B) would not show discreet QRS complexes, and hence is not the answer in this case.

Solution to Question 4:
The clinical scenario describes a man with history of coronary artery disease developing syncope. The ECG shows wide QRS complex (> 0.12 s) tachycardia with a single QRS morphology suggestive of monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). The most appropriate treatment of VT in a hemodynamically unstable (systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg) patient is DC cardioversion.
VT can be casued by structural heart disease, scar-related reentry, cardiomyopathies, or abnormalities in the conduction pathways. VT is said to be sustained if it lasts for at least 30 seconds or requires intervention for termination.
Rapid VT can lead to hypotension and syncope, especially in patients with ventricular dysfunction. Patients with normal cardiac function may tolerate sustained VT, presenting with palpitations. Monomorphic VT associated with structural heart disease can progress to ventricular fibrillation (VF) and sudden cardiac arrest.
QRS synchronous electrical cardioversion is performed for unstable patients. Intravenous amiodarone is the preferred drug for stable VT associated with heart disease.
After restoring sinus rhythm, further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying heart disease. Treatment options include antiarrhythmic medications, catheter ablation, or implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) for recurrent or high-risk VT. ICDs are commonly used for secondary prevention of sudden death in patients with sustained VT and structural heart disease.
Solution to Question 5:
Carotid sinus massage will be effective only in supraventricular tachycardias but not in ventricular tachycardias. This is because it acts by increasing the AV node block which does not play any role in the pathogenesis of ventricular tachycardia.
Hence, AV node blocking maneuvers (carotid sinus massage, valsalva) and drugs (adenosine) are not used in the management of VT.
Solution to Question 6:
Accelerated idioventricular rhythm is the most common arrhythmia associated with myocardial reperfusion, most commonly in the first 2 days after presentation.
Idioventricular rhythm is defined as  3 consecutive premature ventricular contractions with a heart rate of <50 bpm. If the heart rate is 60-100 bpm, it is known as accelerated idioventricular rhythm, and if it is more than 100 bpm it is known as ventricular tachycardia. It may be the result of an abnormal focus in the ventricle that generates an impulse faster than the sinus node and therefore assumes control.
Other causes of AIVR include:
Buerger disease
Congenital heart disease
Dilated cardiomyopathy
Myocarditi
Drugs: Digoxin toxicity, cocaine toxicity, and various anesthesia agent
Electrolyte abnormality
Postresuscitation
Episodes of AIVR have not been found to affect prognosis in acute MI and usually do not require intervention. If AIVR is accompanied by hemodynamic compromise, treatment with atropine or atrial pacing will often suppress the rhythm.
Solution to Question 7:
An automated implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) is a device placed in the chest or abdomen to detect arrhythmias and perform cardioversion, defibrillation, and pace the heart.
It is contraindicated in patients experiencing tachyarrhythmias with reversible or transient causes such as acute MI.
It is used in:
Brugada syndrome- refers to a sodium channelopathy with a high risk of arrhythmias that can lead to sudden cardiac death.
Ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia.
Cardiac resynchronization therapy for prevention of sudden cardiac death in heart failure.
High-risk situations of sudden cardiac death in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Solution to Question 8:
Sudden cardiac death is defined as unexpected non-traumatic death in clinically well or stable patients who die within 1 hour after onset of symptoms.
The causative rhythm in most cases is ventricular fibrillation, which is usually preceded by ventricular tachycardia except in the setting of acute ischemia or infarction.
Solution to Question 9:
The given ECG is suggestive of ventricular fibrillation.
The features in the above ECG that support the diagnosis are:
Disordered electrical ventricular activation with no identifiable QRS complexe
No identifiable P-waves, no PR interval
Possible mechanisms of ventricular fibrillation include spiral wave reentry and multiple circulating reentry wavefronts.
The ECG features suggestive of ventricular tachycardia are as follows:
Wide QRS complex with abnormal morphology (marked with red arrows in image below)

Solution to Question 10:
The given ECG finding shows torsades de pointes, which can occur due to
hypomagnesemia (Crohn's disease causes chronic diarrhea which can cause excess GI loss of magnesium).
Torsades de pointes means twisting of points, it implies twisting of the QRS complexes around the isoelectric line of the ECG. It is a form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that is seen in patients with a prolonged QT interval.
A prolonged QT interval usually results from prolonged ventricular repolarization (lengthening of T wave). A premature ventricular contraction falling in the elongated T wave can initiate torsades de pointes.
The features of torsades de pointes are:
Polymorphic QRS complexes that change in amplitude
Cycle length giving an appearance of oscillations around the baseline
QT prolongation

Solution to Question 11:
The given ECG showing a wide QRS complex tachycardia with waxing and waning QRS amplitude points to the diagnosis of torsades des pointes. As the patient is hemodynamically stable, intravenous MgSO4 is the treatment of choice.
Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) has a continually changing QRS morphology. Polymorphic VT that occurs in individuals with congenital or acquired prolongation of QT interval is referred to as torsades des pointes. Patients present with near-syncope, syncope, or cardiac arrest.
IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and the prevention of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades des pointes.
If magnesium alone is ineffective, isoproterenol infusion or pacing, to a rate of 100-120 depolarization/minute usually suppresses VT recurrences.
If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

Solution to Question 12:
The bundle of Kent is the accessory pathway of conduction between the atria and ventricle in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. It conducts impulses faster than the AV nodal pathway
and avoids AV nodal delay, leading to shortened PR interval. QRS is prolonged because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.
Solution to Question 13:
The major feature of Brugada syndrome is transient or concealed ST-segment elevation in V1 to V3.
Brugada syndrome is a rare syndrome characterized by ST-segment elevation and negative T waves in more than 1 anterior precordial leads ( V1- V3 ). It is associated with mutations involving cardiac sodium channels. The patients have episodes of polymorphic VT which may lead to syncope or cardiac arrest.
It shows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects males more than females. The episodes of VT may occur either in sleep or maybe provoked by febrile illness or sodium channel-blocking drugs (Class I antiarrhythmics) like ajmaline, flecainide, and procainamide.
The episodes of VT can be suppressed using quinidine or catheter ablation. ICD can be used in individuals who have been resuscitated from cardiac arrest.
Solution to Question 14:
Brugada syndrome is associated with right bundle branch block. It is an inherited disease that predisposes patients to potentially life threatening arrythmias.
The ECG below is depictive of Brugada syndrome with concave ST segments and negative T waves
(to be seen in more than one anterior precordial leads, i.e., V1-V3)

Solution to Question 15:
Romano-Ward syndrome is a congenital long QT syndrome without deafness.
Romano-Ward syndrome is associated with specific genetic mutations affecting membrane potassium and sodium channels. The inheritance pattern may be autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant.
The preferred drugs for managing this condition are the beta-blockers. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) implantation can also be done.

Solution to Question 18:
This patient has symptoms and ECG findings suggestive of Mobitz type I or Wenckebach block.
In the given ECG PR segment progressively increases in each successive cycle, until a P wave of the series fails to produce a QRS complex (dropped QRS). In this example, for every 5 'P' waves, there are only 4 'QRS' complexes; hence, this is a 5:4 Wenckebach block.
Solution to Question 19:
The absence of a constant relationship between the P wave and the QRS complex (P-QRS dissociation) is a feature of complete heart block. It is not seen in Mobitz type II second-degree heart block.
The PR interval remains constant in Mobitz type II second-degree heart block but few p waves are not followed by QRS complex. It occurs due to a block in the bundle of His. The atrial rate is more than the ventricular rate.
Solution to Question 20:
The given ECG shows a constant PR interval in each successive cycle followed by a dropped QRS (P wave fails to produce a QRS complex). This pattern is suggestive of Mobitz type II block.
Mobitz type II block is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses.
The dropped QRS is marked in the image below:

Note: Bradyarrhythmias that cause syncope include those due to severe sinus node dysfunction and AV block( Mobitz type II block, complete AV block). Syncope due to bradycardia or asystole is referred to as Stokes-Adams attack.
Solution to Question 21:
The above ECG shows a complete heart block.
Features in the ECG supporting the diagnosis of complete heart block:
PP interval is constant
RR interval is constant
P waves more in number than QRS complexe
There is no relation between P waves and the QRS complexes.
For a second-degree heart block, the QRS complex should be preceded by the P wave, whereas in a third-degree heart block, the QRS complex is independent of the P wave.

Solution to Question 22:
QRS > 0.12s points towards a wide QRS complex. The left anterior fascicular block does not cause a wide QRS complex.
Fascicular blocks do not prolong the QRS interval. They only lead to axis deviation.
Left anterior fascicular block: left axis deviation
Left posterior fascicular block: right axis deviation
Wide QRS complexes ( 0.12 seconds) are seen in the following:
Ventricular tachycardia
Ventricular premature contraction
Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
Bundle branch blocks (complete blocks- QRS interval  0.12 seconds, incomplete blocks- QRS interval between 0.10–0.12 seconds)
Hyperkalemia
Solution to Question 23:
The symptoms of weakness, paresthesia, and dyspnea along with the given ECG showing depression of the ST segment, a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave (flattening or inversion), and an increase in the amplitude of U waves (at the end of the T wave) are characteristic of hypokalemia.
In the given ECG, leads V1-V6 exhibit T wave inversion. U waves are well appreciated in leads V2-V5.

Hypokalemia leads to dynamic ECG changes. The image given shows the sequence of changes observed:

Hypokalemia is defined as plasma K+ concentration of <3.5meq/L. It can also cause premature atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
Other options:
Option B: Hyperkalemia causes tall peaked T waves with a shortened QT interval. There is a progressive lengthening of the PR interval and QRS duration with an increase in potassium levels, eventually leading to the disappearance of the P wave; and widening of the QRS complex to a sine wave pattern.

Option C: Hypocalcemia causes prolongation of the QT interval. There is a lengthening of the ST segment, while the T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered.
Option D: Hypercalcemia causes shortening of the QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment duration.

Solution to Question 1:
The most common cause of valvular heart disease in developing countries is rheumatic fever. This is mainly due to the repeated infections with rheumatogenic streptococci and inadequate coverage of antibiotics. It mainly affects the mitral valve.
In developed countries, degenerative or inflammatory processes are the most common cause of valvular heart diseases.
Solution to Question 2:
The size of the mitral orifice in a normal adult is 4-6 sq cm.
Depending on the area of mitral valve opening (MVA), mitral stenosis can be classified as:
Progressive MS - MVA > 1.5 sq cm
Severe MS - MVA  1.5 sq cm
Very severe MS -  1 sq cm
Solution to Question 3:
Left ventricular hypertrophy is not seen in mitral stenosis. On the contrary, right ventricle hypertrophy is seen.
Mechanism of mitral stenosis (MS):
In a normal mitral valve, there is no obstruction to the flow of blood from the left atrium(LA) to the left ventricle. Therefore a small LA pressure is sufficient to empty the blood into the ventricle.
When the MVA is <~2 sq cm, blood flows from the left atrium to the left ventricle, propelled by a mildly elevated atrial pressure. Hence, patients are usually asymptomatic and may develop dyspnea only when the heart rate increases, as seen in exertion, excitement, fever, etc. All these conditions:
Increase the rate of blood flow across the mitral orifice, resulting in further elevation of the LA pressure
Decrease the diastolic filling time, resulting in a reduction in cardiac output The image below explains the mechanism of mitral stenosis.

Mid-systolic click is least likely to be heard in a patient with mitral stenosis. It is seen in a patient with mitral valve prolapse.

Solution to Question 5:
The given image is of mitral stenosis showing fish mouth or buttonhole appearance.
Solution to Question 6:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral stenosis. The more severe the thickening, the earlier the opening snap occurs in diastole. Hence, the decreased interval between A2 and opening snap (OS) indicates increased severity of the stenosis.
The auscultatory findings which are suggestive of increased severity of murmur are:
Decreased interval between A2 and OS
Increased duration of the diastolic murmur
Loud S1 is seen in the initial stages of MS when the mitral leaflets are flexible. When there is further thickening and calcification of the leaflets, they become immobile, and the amplitude of S1 decreases.
Increased severity of the stenosis increases the left atrial pressure. This increase in left atrial pressure can increase pulmonary artery pressure which leads to loud P2 on auscultation.
Solution to Question 7:
Left atrium (LA) is the first cardiac chamber to get enlarged in mitral stenosis (MS). It is due to the pressure overload of LA. It can be appreciated on the lateral and left anterior oblique views.
Other radiographic changes seen in MS are straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac silhouette, posterior displacement of the esophagus by an enlarged LA, and Kerley B lines due to distention of interlobular septae and lymphatics with edema.
Severe MS causing pulmonary hypertension leads to enlargement of the pulmonary artery, right ventricle, and right atrium. Left ventricle remains unaffected in isolated MS.
Solution to Question 8:
Mitral valvotomy is indicated in symptomatic (NYHA Functional Class II-IV) patients with mitral stenosis (MS) with orifice < 1.5 cm2 in normal-sized adults or <1 cm2/m2 body surface area.
Treatment of mitral stenosis:
Administration of warfarin in patients with MS who develop atrial fibrillation.
Surgical treatment includes:
Mitral valvotomy: It is done in symptomatic patients whose mitral orifice is less than 1.5 cm2. This can be either percutaneous mitral valvotomy or open surgical valvotomy.
Mitral valve replacement: This is done in patients whose mitral valve is severely distorted.
Solution to Question 9:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral valve prolapse.
It is caused due to the myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve. It may be associated with Marfan's syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. It is more common in females of the age group of 15- 30 years.
Most patients are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with symptoms such as palpitations, syncope due to arrhythmias (premature ventricular contractions, ventricular tachycardia, and atrial fibrillation), non-specific chest pain, and dyspnea
Auscultation reveals mid-systolic clicks. If there is associated mitral regurgitation, a systolic murmur might also be heard. The duration of the murmur of MVP decreases on squatting and increases on standing. Whereas the duration of the murmur of MR increases on squatting and decreases on standing.
Solution to Question 10:
Carvallo’s sign refers to the increase in the intensity of systolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation with inspiration.
During inspiration, the venous return to the heart increases due to the negative intrathoracic pressure. This increases the leak from the right ventricle to the right atrium making the murmur louder.
In general, the right-sided heart murmurs increase in intensity with inspiration and decrease in intensity with expiration, while the opposite is true for left-sided heart murmurs. Pulmonic ejection sound is the only right-sided acoustic event that decreases in intensity with inspiration.
Solution to Question 11:
The severity of mitral regurgitation (MR) can be assessed by the wide splitting of the S2. Due to severe regurgitation of blood, the pressure in the left ventricle falls rapidly, leading to the early closure of the aortic valve.
Clinical findings that indicate the severity of MR is:
Reduced cardiac output
Palpable systolic thrill
Palpable S3
Wide splitting of S2
N te: The intensity of murmur does not always correlate with the severity of the murmur. Intensity may be diminished in severe MR caused by LV dysfunction, acute MI and periprosthetic
valve regugitation.
Solution to Question 12:
The most likely diagnosis is aortic stenosis.
Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused due to the calcification of the normal aortic valve, calcification of congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease.
Three cardinal clinical features of aortic stenosis are:
Exertional dyspnea - this occurs due to the left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading t elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.
Angina pectoris - it occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and reduction of O2 delivery.
Syncope - it occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.
Solution to Question 13:
The phonocardiogram given above is of an ejection systolic murmur, which is seen in aortic stenosis. It is also heard in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur, etc.
Clinical findings in aortic stenosis:
Pulse - slow rising and late peaking pulse which is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. A carotid thrill may also be palpated over these arteries.
Apical impulse - A double apical impulse may be recognized, and in the later stages, it may be displaced laterally.
Auscultation findings in aortic stenosis:
Early systolic ejection sound - heard in early stages, disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid
Paradoxical splitting of S2 - With worsening of stenosis, delayed closure of the aortic valve ccurs. This leads to narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, leads to paradoxical splitting of S2.
S4 and S3 - heard in severe cases
Ejection systolic murmur - starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2. It radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver.
The image below shows phonocardiograms of normal and abnormal heart sounds.

Solution to Question 14:
The above features point to a diagnosis of aortic stenosis. Wide splitting of S2 is not a feature of severe aortic stenosis. On the contrary, there might be single S2 or paradoxical splitting of S2.
Features of severe aortic stenosis are:
Pulsus parvus et tardus
Palpable carotid thrill
Louder and late peaking of systolic murmur
Single S2 or paradoxical splitting of S2
Presence of S3 and S4 heart sounds
Signs of right and left ventricular failure
Left ventricular hypertrophy
Solution to Question 15:
Acute myocardial infarction is not associated with aortic regurgitation.
Aortic regurgitation is the backflow of the blood from the aorta to the left ventricle.
It may be caused either due to the defect in the valve or defect in the aortic root (dilation of the aortic annulus).
Conditions that affect valves are:
Congenital
Endocarditis
Rheumatic fever
Myxomatous (prolapse)
Traumatic
Syphilis
Ankylosing spondylitis
Conditions that affect aortic root are:
Aortic dissection
Cystic medial degeneration
Marfan syndrome
Bicuspid aortic valve
Hypertension

The image below explains the mechanism of aortic regurgitation.

Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical features are suggestive of aortic regurgitation. An early diastolic murmur is a high-pitched decrescendo diastolic murmur.
Auscultatory findings in AR are:
Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
Diminished or absent A2
S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign f impaired LV function.
Early diastolic murmur -
High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur
Best heard in the left third intercostal space
Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration
Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity
Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.
Solution to Question 18:
Regurgitant volume >60mL/ beat is the criteria for severe aortic regurgitation, in transthoracic doppler echocardiography (TTE).
Doppler echocardiography can be used to assess the severity of aortic regurgitation. According to this, AR is considered to be severe when:
Central jet width is more than 65% of left ventricular outflow tract
Vena contracta width >6mm
Regurgitant fraction >50%
Regurgitant volume >60mL/beat
Effective regurgitant orifice >0.3cm2
Solution to Question 19:
The treatment of choice in symptomatic acute severe AR is aortic valve replacement (AVR).
Treatment of aortic regurgitation:
In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. The symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output can be managed by diuretics and vasodilators.
In severe AR, surgery (AVR) is indicated in the following conditions:
The patient is symptomatic.
The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

Distended neck veins with prominent c-v waves
Hepatomegaly with systolic pulsations
Positive hepatojugular reflex - the distension of the jugular vein when firm pressure is applied ver the liver
Blowing holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal margin

Solution to Question 1:
The mitral valve is the most common valve affected in infective endocarditis.
Infective endocarditis is the infection of the endocardial layer of the heart. It may involve the endocardial layer over the heart valves, mural endocardium, or septum. However, it can also affect intracardiac devices.

Note: Infection of the arteriovenous shunts and the arterio-arterial shunt is called infective endarteritis and not infective endocarditis.
Solution to Question 2:
Roth's spots are not the cardiac manifestation of infective endocarditis (IE). They are the immunological phenomenon seen in patients with infective endocarditis.
Symptoms of infective endocarditis can be broadly divided into cardiac and non-cardiac manifestations. Non-cardiac manifestations of infective endocarditis are further divided into immunologic and vascular phenomena.
Cardiac manifestations of IE:
Presence of new regurgitant murmurs
Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction
Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae- caused due to the extension of infection beyond the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue
Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess.
Embolization of coronary arteries
Non-cardiac manifestations of IE:
Immunological phenomena (mnemonic ROGeR):
Osler's nodes- small, tender, red papules that are present on the distal finger and toe pads.
Roth's spots- white-centered retinal hemorrhages
Immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis
Positivity for rheumatoid factor
Vascular phenomena:
Janeway lesions- these are faint, red, macular, painless lesions, commonly present on the thenar and hypothenar eminences.
Major arterial emboli
Septic pulmonary infarct
Mycotic aneurysm
Intracranial hemorrhages
Conjunctival hemorrhages
Splenic abscess
Cerebral abscess
The image below shows Roth spot on the retina.

Solution to Question 3:
Positive echocardiogram not meeting major criteria was earlier a minor criterion but is now removed.
Solution to Question 4:
According to modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800 is included in the major criteria.
Solution to Question 5:
The above scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. The skin lesions shown in the image are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous, or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles.

Another skin finding that can be found in patients with infective endocarditis is Osler's nodes. In contrast to Janeway lesions, these are small, tender, red papules which are present on the distal finger and toe pads.

Option D. According to the Modified Duke 2023 Criteria for infective endocarditis, when a typical organism is suspected, two separate culture sets are required, one aerobic and one anaerobic.
If an atypical organism is suspected, three or more separate culture sets are used.
According to the new Duke’s criteria, there is no specific timing to draw blood for blood culture.
Solution to Question 8:
Patient developing endocarditis 2 years after prosthetic valve surgery suggests late-onset endocarditis. In such cases, the most common causative organism is streptococci.
Solution to Question 9:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. Staphylococcus aureus is most likely to be positive in cultures as it is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers.
Endocarditis in injection drug users is mostly right-sided and involves the tricuspid valve.
Solution to Question 10:
The most common cause of culture-negative infective endocarditis is the prior use of antibiotics.
Some proportion of patients with endocarditis have negative blood cultures. The important causes are:
Prior antibiotic use (most common cause)
IE due to fastidious organisms or unusual pathogens or fungi such as:
Streptococci (Granulicatella and Abiotrophia species)
HACEK organisms
Coxiella burnetii
Bartonella species
Brucella
Tropheryma whipplei
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical features and laboratory investigations are suggestive of infective endocarditis caused due to Streptococcus gallolyticus. In this condition, a colonoscopy should be performed.
Streptococcus gallolyticus originates from the gastrointestinal tract and is associated with polyps and colon cancer. Hence, the presence of this organism in the vegetation of infective endocarditis should warrant a gastrointestinal investigation.
Solution to Question 12:
For a patient with low suspicion of IE, transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) will be done as an initial investigation.
Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is preferred as the initial investigation in all high-risk patients and/or in patients where a high clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis (IE) exists.
TEE is also preferred over TTE for evaluating:
Vegetations < 2mm in diameter
Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE)
Detection of myocardial abscess
Detection of valve perforation
Detection of intracardiac fistulae
Detection of vegetations in a patient with a cardiovascular implantable electronic device (CIED)
Solution to Question 13:
Atrial septal defect (ASD) is associated with a very low incidence of IE. In ASD, the velocity of the shunt blood is low due to the decreased pressure gradient between the two atria. This low velocity of the blood does not usually damage the lining endocardium.
Unrepaired VSD is the most frequent congenital heart disease lesion associated with IE, followed by ventricular outflow tract obstructive lesions, such as with tetralogy of Fallot.

Solution to Question 14:
Antibiotic prophylaxis is not required in patients undergoing genitourinary or gastrointestinal procedures even if they have a high-risk cardiac lesion for developing infecting endocarditis (e.g., prosthetic valve).
Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for patients who are undergoing dental procedures, invasive respiratory tract procedures, and procedures on the infected skin.
Solution to Question 15:
Routine antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis is not recommended for patients with previous coronary artery bypass graft surgery. They do not have a long-term risk of infection.
High-risk cardiac lesions, for which endocarditis prophylaxis is advised before dental procedures are:
Prosthetic heart valves
Prior endocarditis
Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits
Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the 6 months after repair
Incompletely repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects adjacent to prosthetic material
Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation
Antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely recommended for patients with acquired valvular heart diseases.
Standard regimen: Amoxicillin 2g per orally is given 1-hour prior to surgery. In patients with penicillin allergy, clarithromycin, and azithromycin 500mg per orally can be given.

The treatment for infective endocarditis with streptococci consists of penicillin with gentamicin for 2 weeks.
Penicillin G (2-3mU IV Q4h) or Ceftriaxone (2g single dose daily) can be given as a monotherapy for 4 weeks.

Solution to Question 17:
The first-line agents used in the management of Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC) infections are trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole), meropenem, minocycline, and ceftazidime (3rd generation cephalosporin).
Other options:
Option A: Burkholderia species are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides and polymyxins. Option C: Tigecycline is less effective in the case of Burkholderia infections.
Option D: Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporins have the same mechanism of action and compete for the same binding site. Hence, it is not a rational drug combination.
BCC is a group of bacteria known for causing severe respiratory distress and septicemia, particularly in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). BCC organisms are also found in ICU patients and individuals with chronic granulomatous disease, leading to lung disease. BCC colonization in CF patients prior to lung transplantation increases the risk of death during the early transplant period.
Solution to Question 18:
Acute rheumatic fever is caused due to infection with group A streptococcus (GAS), which is Streptococcus pyogenes. It usually follows a streptococcal sore throat or scarlet fever. Other groups of streptococci do not cause acute rheumatic fever.
The pathogenesis of the development of ARF is based on the concept of molecular mimicry. The antibodies which are produced against M protein and N-acetyl glucosamine of group A streptococci, bind to and damage the human endothelial cells.
It mainly affects children between 5-14 years of age. Patients have various rheumatologic, cardiac, and neurological manifestations. Modified Jone's criteria is used for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever.
The main aim of treatment of rheumatic fever is to relieve symptoms, prevent inflammation and prevent further infections by group A streptoccus by the use of penicillins.
Solution to Question 19:
The most common clinical feature of acute rheumatic fever is carditis followed by polyarthritis.
Solution to Question 20:
Choreiform movements in Sydenham’s chorea is mainly seen in the head & upper limbs.
Sydenham chorea is characterized by the presence of involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements of the hands, arms, shoulders, feet, legs, face, and trunk. The movements may be generalized or restricted to one side of the body.
It follows a long latent period (more than 6 months) and therefore can occur alone without any other clinical manifestations.

Solution to Question 21:
Subcutaneous nodules are commonly present in hands, feet, elbows, and occiput.
They are firm, painless, and freely movable subcutaneous nodules, present over the bony prominences of hands, feet, elbow, and occiput. They are a delayed manifestation of rheumatic fever and are usually associated with carditis.
Solution to Question 22:
ESR 60 mm and polyarthralgia are a part of minor criteria for the low-risk population among the given options.
The major and minor criteria for arthritis differ in low risk and medium to high-risk populations.
For low-risk populations, polyarthritis is a major criterion and polyarthralgia is a minor criterion.
In the medium to high-risk populations, polyarthritis, polyarthralgia, monoarthritis are major criteria and monoarthralgia is a minor criterion.
Solution to Question 23:
In rheumatic fever, joint pain is usually asymmetric. Characteristic features of arthritis of acute rheumatic fever are:
Migratory- the pain moves from one joint to another over a period of hours
Involvement of large joints – most commonly knees, ankle, hips & elbows
Asymmetric
Highly responsive to salicylates
Solution to Question 24:
The above clinical features are suggestive of rheumatic fever and the skin finding shown in the image is erythema marginatum. It generally occurs in patients with carditis.
Erythema marginatum is a pink, non-pruritic rash that generally occurs on the upper part of the arms or trunk but not on the face. It extends from the centre with an irregular serpiginous border. As the size of the rash increases, the center of the rash returns to normal, while the borders remain pink. Hence it is named erythema marginatum.
The rash may also become more prominent after a hot shower.
Solution to Question 25:
Evidence of preceding streptococcal infection for making diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever (ARF)
is not required in the presence of chorea.
Chorea is frequently a late finding of ARF. When chorea appears, major findings, minor findings and findings of preceding streptococcal infection would have been disappeared.
Solution to Question 26:
Characteristic initial valvular manifestation in acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is mitral regurgitation.
Damage of the valves leads to mitral regurgitation in the early stages. With repeated episodes of rheumatic fever, there is thickening, calcification, and stenosis of the affected valve.
Mitral regurgitation is the most common cardiac lesion in ARF, while mitral stenosis is the most common lesion in rheumatic heart disease.
Other cardiac manifestations of acute rheumatic fever include myocardial inflammation that can also affect electrical conduction pathways, leading to P-R interval prolongation (first-degree atrioventricular block or rarely higher-level block) and softening of the first heart sound.
Solution to Question 27:
The prevalence of rheumatic valvular heart disease peaks between 25-40 years.
Acute rheumatic fever is mainly a disease of children and is common between 5–14 years of age and rare in a person aged more 30 years. In contrast to this, rheumatic valvular heart disease is common between 25-40 years.
Solution to Question 28:
The drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea is sodium valproate.
Sydenham's chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements which mainly affect the head and upper limbs. In the tongue, it is visible as the characteristic darting movements.
Medications used to treat Sydenham chorea are:
Mild cases: managed by providing a calm environment
Severe cases: dopamine antagonists like haloperidol, pimozide, or antiepileptic medications like sodium valproate (preferred due to no extrapyramidal side effects) and carbamazepine
Since Sydenham chorea is thought to be an immune-mediated disorder, steroids are effective in the treatment of severe or refractory cases.
Solution to Question 29:
This patient has a rheumatic fever without carditis. He should be given prophylaxis till 21 years of age as the duration of secondary prophylaxis is 5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer).
Secondary prophylaxis is given for patients with acute rheumatic fever (ARF). These patients are at a higher risk of developing a further episode of ARF after a group A streptococcal infection.
Hence they should receive long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrent infections. The antibiotics that can be given for secondary prophylaxis are:
Benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units) given every 4 weeks (Best antibiotic)
Oral penicillin V (250 mg) given twice daily (less effective than benzathine penicillin G)
Erythromycin (250 mg) twice daily (For patients allergic to penicillin)

Solution to Question 1:
Low potassium increases blood pressure and hence is not recommended in the dietary modifications. On the contrary, potassium supplementation lowers the BP significantly in hypertensives. It is given preferably by dietary modifications unless contraindicated.
Solution to Question 2:
According to European guidelines for hypertension 2018, systolic blood pressure between 130-139 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure between 85-89 mmHg is classified as high normal.
Solution to Question 3:
SBP 140 mm Hg and DBP <90 mmHg is called isolated systolic hypertension. White-coat hypertension is characterized by:
The office blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg on 3 separate office visits
2 blood pressure measurements taken outside the office are <140/90 mm Hg, frequently using home blood pressure monitoring; and
There is no evidence of hypertensive target organ damage.
Solution to Question 4:
Carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity (PWV) is the gold standard for measuring large artery stiffness due to hypertension.
Long-standing hypertension can lead to structural and functional changes in arteries and target organs like the heart, brain, arteries, and kidneys. This is called hypertension mediated organ damage (HMOD).

In patients above 65 years of age, the desired goal of systolic blood pressure is between 130-139 while the desired diastolic range remains the same.
This goal is in accordance with the European Society of Cardiology guidelines (2018).

Solution to Question 7:
In this patient with no markers of cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated end-organ damage (HMOD), and normal renal function, immediate pharmacological treatment is recommended when the blood pressure (BP) is 140/90 mmHg according to the AHA and ESH on the management of hypertension.
Guidelines for Hypertension Management:
Adults 18–79 y with SBP 140 mm Hg or DBP 90 mm Hg
Adults 80 y with SBP 160 mm Hg but 140 mm Hg can be considered.
In frail patients, individualize treatment.
In patients with CVD, especially CAD, SBP 130 mm Hg, or DBP 80 mm Hg. Treatment BP targets:
Adults 18–79 y, primary SBP/DBP goal <140/90 mm Hg; if treatment well tolerated target SBP/DBP <130/80 mm Hg but not SBP <120 mm Hg or DBP <70 mm Hg. For adults with isolated systolic hypertension, target SBP lowering, albeit cautiously.
In adults 80 y, target SBP/DBP <140/90 mm Hg, if well tolerated AHA Hypertension grading:

The preferred treatment in hypertensive patients with chronic kidney disease is a combination of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) with calcium channel blockers (CCBs) or diuretics (ACEi/ARBs + CCBs/diuretics).
Solution to Question 9:
Metoprolol, when added with verapamil, leads to bradycardia with AV block.
Verapamil and  blockers have additive effect on inhibiting SA node and AV conduction, and the combination should be avoided to prevent severe bradycardia and conduction block.
These agents can also have additive effect on decreasing left ventricular function which could seriously impair cardiac output in a patient with heart failure.

The above coronary angiogram shows partial occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery. Beta-blockers like atenolol in combination with ACE inhibitors or ARBs or calcium channe blockers or diuretics are preferred for the management of hypertension in patients with coronary artery disease.
Other indications for beta-blockers are:
Congestive heart failure due to systolic dysfunction
Post myocardial infarction
Sinus tachycardia
Ventricular arrhythmias

Solution to Question 11:
The most likely etiology is pheochromocytoma. Patients commonly present with a classical triad of palpitation, headache and profuse sweating. The presence of this triad in association with hypertension and elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis.
Solution to Question 12:
Hypertension with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis is seen in Liddle's syndrome.
Liddle's syndrome (pseudo aldosteronism) is an autosomal dominant condition that is caused due to the increased activation of ENaC channels. This causes increased reabsorption of Na+ exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension, and there is also a loss of H+ ion with K+, leading to metabolic alkalosis. It is associated with low renin and low aldosterone levels.
Solution to Question 13:
Hypertensive emergencies are situations in which grade 3 hypertension (BP>180/110 mmHg) is associated with acute hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD).
Treatment of hypertensive emergency depends on the type of end-organ damage present (as shown in the table below). It is treated with rapidly acting intravenous antihypertensive agents.
In hypertensive encephalopathy, the initial goal of therapy is to immediately reduce mean arterial blood (MAP) pressure by no more than 25%. Rapid reduction of blood pressure may lead to reduced cerebral blood flow and result in cerebral infarction.
The table below shows the treatment of various hypertensive emergencies with intravenous drug therapy.

Solution to Question 14:
Patient 3 suffers from hypertensive urgency as BP > 180/110 mmHg and end-organ damage is not seen.
Target organ damage is absent in hypertensive urgency but is present in a hypertensive emergency.
Severe hypertension (grade 3) is generally defined as blood pressure 180/110 mmHg. Hypertensive emergency, hypertensive urgency, and malignant hypertension are all forms of severe hypertension.
Option A: Patient 1 suffers from hypertension. Since BP <180/110 mmHg it is not a hypertensive crisis (urgency or emergency).
Option B: Patient 2 has a BP > 180/110 mmHg along with symptoms of hypertensive encephalopathy. This is an example of a hypertensive emergency as there is severe hypertension with signs or symptoms of hypertensive-mediated organ damage (HMOD).
Option D: Patient 4 has a BP > 180/110 mm Hg along with papilledema. This is a case of severe hypertension associated with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages, papilloedema) which is suggestive of malignant hypertension. Microangiopathy, DIC, and encephalopathy may also be present. Fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles and small arteries is seen. The prognosis is very poor if untreated.
Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) or acute hypertensive encephalopathy is a rare complication in patients with an acute rise in blood pressure. Due to the acute rise, there is increased cerebral perfusion and edema of the brain. Clinically it is recognized by alteration in mental status, nausea, headache, visual disturbance, seizure, or development of focal neurological deficits.
Solution to Question 15:
The above scenario points towards the diagnosis of malignant hypertension. The drug which is east useful in the management is furosemide(diuretic).
Volume depletion is common in patients with malignant hypertension, and the administration of a diuretic together with a hypertensive agent can lead to an extreme drop in blood pressure.
Diuretics are generally not recommended for the rapid reduction of blood pressure in patients with hypertensive crises. They are used only in conditions of volume overload such as acute pulmonary edema.
Solution to Question 16:
The most important risk factor for the development of hypertension is obesity.
Hypertension is defined as repeated office systolic blood pressure of  140 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure of  90 mm Hg.
Primary/essential hypertension is the leading cause of hypertension in adults. It is caused due to the interaction of genetic factors with various other factors such as diet, sedentary lifestyle, etc. In some people, hypertension may result from renal, endocrine, or adrenal disorders (secondary hypertension).
Risk factors of hypertension can be divided into modifiable and non-modifiable: Non-modifiable risk factors are:
Age- risk increases with age
Sex- in young and middle-aged adults, the risk is higher in males
Genetic factors- mutation in the genes which encode the components of the
renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, atrial natriuretic peptide, and alpha adducin
Ethnicity
Modifiable risk factors are:
Obesity (most important)
High alcohol intake
High salt intake
Sedentary lifestyle
Stress
Dyslipidemia
Diet low in potassium and calcium

Solution to Question 1:
The left anterior descending (anterior interventricular) coronary artery is most commonly involved in coronary artery disease (CAD) or coronary heart disease or ischemic heart disease.
The regions affected are the anterior wall of the left ventricle near the apex and the anterior portion of the ventricular septum.
CAD is caused by plaque buildup in the walls of the coronary arteries that narrow over time and can partially or totally block the blood flow causing myocardial ischemia and subsequently infarction.
The image below shows coronary circulation.

Solution to Question 2:
Subendocardium is the region of the myocardium most vulnerable to ischemic damage.
The myocardium is perfused from the epicardium to the endocardium. This results in the subendocardium being the least perfused region making it most vulnerable to ischemic damage.
A narrow zone of the myocardium immediately beneath the endocardium is spared from necrosis because it can be oxygenated by diffusion from the ventricle.

Solution to Question 3:
The above scenario is suggestive of Wellens syndrome. It is alternatively known as anterior, descending, T-wave syndrome. The ECG pattern of Wellens syndrome is relatively common in patients who exhibit symptoms consistent with unstable angina.
ECG in the pain-free interval is characterized by deeply inverted or biphasic T waves in precordial leads and with minimal or no ST elevations. Cardiac enzymes are normal or mildly elevated.
These patients are at high risk for impending large anterior wall acute myocardial infarction.
The ECG below shows biphasic T waves in leads V2 and V3 and inverted T waves in leads V4 and V5 in Wellens syndrome.

Option A: Broken heart syndrome is another name for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.
Option C: Barlow syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse. Option D: Brugada syndrome is a genetic cardiac rhythm disorder.
Solution to Question 4:
The levels of cardiac markers remain unchanged in stable and unstable angina as there is no necrosis of cardiac myocytes.
The clinical presentations of ischemic heart disease can be broadly classified into:
Chronic coronary syndrome (CCS) - this includes
Stable angina - this is an episodic angina that occurs with predictable severity, frequency, and threshold of precipitation by stressors, and is relieved by rest and nitrates
Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) - this includes
Unstable angina - this is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of an ACS with no elevation of biomarkers
Myocardial infarction - it is the necrosis and death of a portion of the myocardium due to prolonged ischemia. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in this condition

When a patient with angina is asked to localize the sensation, he or she typically places a hand over the sternum, sometimes with a clenched fist, to indicate a squeezing, central, substernal discomfort. This is called Levine’s sign.
Option A: Mayne's sign- Drop of at least 15 mmHg in the diastolic blood pressure on raising the arm. It occurs in patients with aortic regurgitation (not reliable).
Option C: Frank’s sign- Diagonal crease in the ear lobe indicative of cardiovascular diseases and/or diabetes.
Option D: Friedreich's sign- Exaggerated drop in JVP seen in constrictive pericarditis.

Squeezing, central, substernal discomfort

Typically lasts 2 to 5 min
Can radiate occasionally to neck, jaw, epigastrium, shoulders, left arm.
Angina is rarely localized below the umbilicus or above the mandible. Myocardial ischemic discomfort does not radiate to the trapezius muscles, that radiation pattern is more typical of pericarditis.
