Solution to Question 7:
The above scenario is suggestive of STEMI with bradycardia which is a feature of inferior wall myocardial infarction. Up to one-half with inferior infarction show evidence of parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and/or hypotension).
Many patients have a normal pulse rate and blood pressure within the first hour of STEMI.
About one-fourth of patients with anterior infarction have manifestations of sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity (tachycardia and/or hypertension).
Solution to Question 8:
A transient midsystolic or late systolic apical murmur due to mitral regurgitation secondary to dysfunction of the mitral valve apparatus (papillary muscle dysfunction, LV dilation) may be present in STEMI.
Solution to Question 9:
Myoglobin is the earliest to rise in acute MI followed by troponin, CK-MB and then LDH.
Serum myoglobin and heart-type fatty acid-binding protein are smaller molecules that diffuse through interstitial ■uids more rapidly after cell death than the larger CK and troponin molecules. They become abnormal as early as 30 minutes after myocardial injury. Neither molecule is specific to myocardial tissue. Myoglobin levels are not tested in routine practice.
Solution to Question 10:
The most preferred cardiac biomarker for myocardial injury/acute MI amongst the given options is cardiac troponin-I.
Cardiac troponin-I, CK-MB, and myoglobin are significantly more specific for acute-MI than cardiac troponin-T.
The cardiac troponins are particularly valuable when there is clinical suspicion of a small MI that may be below the detection limit for CK-MB measurement. They have replaced CK-MB as the biomarker of choice for diagnosing myocardial infarction.
Cardiac troponins:
Most specific cardiac biomarker for myocardial injury/acute MI
Elevations are useful for short & long-term prognoses in MI
Elevations correlate with the estimation of infarct size and risk of death
Newer highly sensitive assays for troponins become positive within the first 3 hours after onset of chest pain in MI
Solution to Question 11:
Troponins are not elevated in patients suffering from angina. Troponins are elevated in the case of myocardial necrosis (seen in MI) whereas angina is associated with myocardial insufficiency/ischemia.
Conditions associated with an elevation in cardiac troponins:
MI
Myocarditis
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
Myocardial contusion
Cardioversion/defibrillation
LV strain from CHF
Hypertensive crisis
RV strain from PE
Renal disease
Sepsis
Solution to Question 12:
Troponin(serial) is the preferred biomarker for diagnosing reinfarction.
Serial troponin levels are used to detect reinfarction, an acute MI that occurs within 28 days of an incident or recurrent MI.
In case of suspected reinfarction, an immediate measurement of cardiac troponin followed by a second sample after 3-6 hours. 20 percent rise in the second sample suggests reinfarction.
Solution to Question 13:
In myocardial injury, the LDH-1 fraction increases, and the ratio of LDH-1 to LDH-2 becomes
>1 in the plasma. This is called flipped LDH pattern.
Normally, the LDH-2 fraction is greater than the LDH-1 fraction in the plasma, and therefore, the ratio of LDH-1 to LDH-2 is normally <1.

Solution to Question 15:
Treadmill exercise testing (treadmill test) may be safely performed in patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.
Absolute contraindications to exercise testing:
Acute myocardial infarction (within 2 days)
High-risk unstable angina
Uncontrolled cardiac arrhythmia with hemodynamic compromise
Active endocarditis
Symptomatic severe aortic stenosis
Decompensated heart failure
Acute pulmonary embolism or pulmonary infarction
Acute myocarditis or pericarditis
Severe pulmonary hypertension
Aortic dissection
Relative Contraindications to exercise testing:

Moderate aortic stenosis with uncertain relation to symptoms
Tachyarrhythmias with uncontrolled ventricular rates
Acquired complete heart block
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with severe resting gradient
Mental impairment with limited ability to cooperate
Solution to Question 16:
Phenylephrine, an alpha-receptor agonist, cannot be used for a patient undergoing stress echocardiography as it causes vasoconstriction.
Dobutamine (preferred agent) and vasodilators (dipyridamole, adenosine, regadenoson) are used for pharmacological stress echocardiography.
Pharmacologic stress testing is used in those who cannot exercise because of pulmonary veno-occlusive disease, musculoskeletal disease, or exertional dyspnea.
Stress echocardiography can be done using either exercise (e.g.: treadmill test or bicycle test) or pharmacologic agents.
Solution to Question 17:
A failure to increase systolic blood pressure by 10 mm Hg, or a sustained decrease in systolic blood pressure of 10 mm Hg or more, is suggestive of multivessel (or left main) CAD.
Other abnormalities on exercise testing that are suggestive of multivessel CAD include:
Early-onset of ischemic ST-segment depression
ST-segment depression of 2 mm (0.2mV) involving 5 or more leads, or persisting 5 minutes into recovery
Exercise-induced ST-segment elevation is also consistent with multivessel CAD
Recent evidence suggests that ST-segment elevation of 1 mm in lead aVR may be a significant predictor of left main coronary artery disease, proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery disease, or at least multivessel CAD
An exercise tolerance/treadmill test involves walking in place on a treadmill while monitoring the electrical activity of your heart. Throughout the test, the speed and incline of the treadmill increase. The results show how well your heart responds to the stress of different levels of exercise.
Solution to Question 18:
Myocardial perfusion imaging is done with either thallium-201 or technetium-99m labeled compounds (e.g., technetium-99m sestamibi).
Solution to Question 19:
Modalities for the determination of myocardial viability include:
Thallium-201 imaging
MRI
Dobutamine echocardiography
PET scan (investigation of choice)
The investigation of choice for assessing the ventricular function is cardiac MRI.
Solution to Question 20:
WHO Rose questionnaire is used for the assessment of angina.
Option B: International prostate symptom score (IPSS) questionnaire is used for BPH. Option C: The CAGE questionnaire is used to check for signs of possible alcohol dependency.
Option D: The youth tobacco survey (YTS) questionnaire is used to study the prevalence of use of tobacco products amongst youth.
Solution to Question 21:
During acute myocardial infarction, the ECG evolves through 3 stages:
T-wave peaking and T-wave inversion:
Peaked T-wave aka hyperacute T-wave- first ECG change (occurs within minutes)
If the blood flow is restored or the oxygen demands of the heart are met, the T waves will revert to norma
If myocardial cell death has occurred, T wave inversions appear (over days) and persist for months to years.
A nonspecific finding and is indicative only of ischemia and not diagnostic of infarction
ST-segment elevation occurs over minutes to hours (after T-wave peaking)
The appearance of new pathologic Q-waves:
Occurs over hours to days (after ST-segment elevation) and is indicative of an evolving MI
The persistence of pathological Q-waves indicates irreversible myocardial cell death

Solution to Question 22:
Measurement of troponin is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours.

Troponin T/I:
Highly specific for MI
Troponin I is more important than troponin T.
Troponins will remain elevated longer than creatine kinase (CK), for up to 14 days.
This makes troponins a superior marker for diagnosing MI in the recent past (late diagnosis).
Reinfarction: It is now clear that cardiac troponin (cTn) increases rapidly, even if it is from an abnormal baseline in patients with reinfarction.
Sometimes cTn concentration is elevated, but stable or decreasing at the time of suspected reinfarction. In this case, the diagnosis of reinfarction requires a 20% or greater increase in the cTn measurement
Creatine kinase (CK):
Less sensitive and specific than troponins
When cTn is available, CK-MB should not be used for the initial diagnosis of acute MI Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):
Normally, LDH2>LDH1; but, in MI, LDH1>LDH2. This is called flipping of the LDH ratio.
Current recommendations suggest that LDH no longer has a role in the diagnosis of MI. Myoglobin:
Earliest enzyme to increase after MI.
Not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle.
Heart-type fatty acid-binding protein (H-FABP), which mainly exists in cardiomyocytes, has recently emerged as a potential biomarker, which was found to be sensitive for the early diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction. H-FABP as an early marker and cTnI as a late marker would be the ideal combination to cover the complete diagnostic window for AMI
Solution to Question 23:
There is no ST-segment elevation in unstable angina.
Differential diagnosis of ST-segment elevation (Mnemonic-ELEVATION):
Electrolytes(Hypercalcemia, Hyperkalemia)
Left bundle branch block
Early(Benign) repolarization, Embolism(Acute pulmonary)
Ventricular hypertrophy
Arrhythmia(Brugada syndrome), Aneurysm of LV, Aortic dissection, Antiarrhythmic drugs(Class 1c)
Tako-tsubo syndrome, Tumor invading left ventricle, Trauma to ventricles
Infarction(MI), Inflammation(Myocarditis, Pericarditis)
Osborn J waves (Hypothermia or hypercalcemia)
Non-atherosclerotic vasospasm(Prinzmetal's angina)

Solution to Question 1:
The above scenario in which rest pain is associated with ST-segment elevation and transient coronary vasospasm is suggestive of Prinzmetal's angina. The drug of choice is a calcium channel blocker.
Prinzmetal variant angina (PVA) is a clinical syndrome in which chest pain occurs without the usual precipitating factors. It usually results from coronary vasoconstriction (vasospasm) and tends to involve the right coronary artery.
It is a supply ischemia and usually causes transmural ischemia (subendocardial in classic angina pectoris).
It often affects women under 50 years of age. It characteristically occurs in the early morning, awakening patients from sleep, and may be associated with arrhythmias or conduction defects.
The clinical diagnosis of PVA is made by the detection of transient ST-segment elevation with rest pain. Coronary angiography demonstrates transient coronary spasm which is the diagnostic hallmark of PVA.
Nitrates and calcium channel blockers both can be used in alleviating symptoms in Prinzmetal's angina. However due to the development of nitrate tolerance in some individuals, they are less preferred and calcium channel blockers such as verapamil, diltiazem are used as first-line agents.
Solution to Question 2:
Streptokinase is given in a dose of 1.5 million units IV given over 1 hour for treatment of MI.
Fibrinolytic therapy should ideally be initiated within 30 min of presentation. The fibrinolytic agents that have been approved for IV use in patients with STEMI are:
Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)
Streptokinase
Tenecteplase (TNK)
Reteplase (rPA)
Adverse effects of streptokinase:
Transient hypotension
Allergic reactions
Hemorrhage
Solution to Question 3:
Streptokinase has the lowest clot selectivity among the fibrinolytic agents. Fibrinolytic agent with:
Least fibrin specificity– streptokinase
Most fibrin specificity – tenecteplase
Solution to Question 4:
Tenecteplase is given as a single bolus dose (based on body weight) which reduces the rate of medication errors (common with IV infusions).
Tenecteplase and reteplase are referred to as bolus fibrinolytics as their administration does not require prolonged intravenous infusion.
Solution to Question 5:
Prolonged cardiopulmonary resuscitation is a relative contraindication for fibrinolytic therapy.
Contraindications for the use of fibrinolytic agents
Absolute contraindications
Relative contraindications
History of hemorrhagic strok e at any time
Current use of anticoagulants
(INR 2)
Non-hemorrhagic stroke or o ther cerebrovascular events within the past year
Recent (<2 weeks) invasive or surgical procedure
Marked hypertension (SBP>1 80mmHg and/or a DBP>110 mmHg) at any time during th e acute presentation
Prolonged (>10 min) cardiop ulmonary resuscitation
Suspicion of aortic dissection
Known bleeding diathesis
Contraindications for the use of fibrinolytic agents
Contraindications for the use of fibrinolytic agents
Active internal bleeding (excl uding menses)
Pregnancy
Hemorrhagic ophthalmic con dition (e.g., hemorrhagic dia betic retinopathy)
Active peptic ulcer disease
History of severe hypertensio n that is currently adequately controlled
Solution to Question 6:
Trimetazidine is an antianginal drug.
It is a PFox (partial fatty acid oxidation) inhibitor. It inhibits the beta-oxidation of fatty acids and thus enhances glucose oxidation. This results in decreased oxygen consumption in ATP synthesis as beta-oxidation consumes more oxygen.
Option A: Thyroxine increases the heart rate, which can increase the myocardial oxygen demand and can precipitate angina.
Option B: Sumatriptan and other triptans cause coronary vasospasm. They are therefore contraindicated in patients with CAD.
Option C: Dipyridamole can produce coronary steal phenomenon and can worsen angina.
Solution to Question 7:
Verapamil and -blockers have additive effects on inhibiting SA node and AV conduction, the combination should be avoided to prevent severe bradycardia and conduction block. These agents can also have additive effects on decreasing left ventricular function which could seriously impair cardiac output in a patient with heart failure.
Diltiazem can be combined with beta-blockers in patients with normal ventricular function and no conduction disturbances.
Amlodipine and -blockers have complementary actions on coronary blood supply and myocardial oxygen demands. Whereas the former decreases blood pressure and dilates coronary arteries, the latter slows the heart rate and decreases contractility.
Solution to Question 8:
The predominant mechanism of action of ranolazine is inhibition of the late sodium current in myocardial cells.
Ranolazine is useful for patients with chronic angina despite standard medical therapy. It is administered at a dose of 500-1000 mg twice daily.
Contraindications:
Hepatic impairment
QT prolongation
Drugs inhibiting CYP3A metabolic system- ketoconazole, diltiazem, verapamil, macrolide antibiotics, HIV protease inhibitors, and large quantities of grapefruit juice
Solution to Question 9:
Clopidogrel should be stopped 5-7 days prior to surgery to avoid the risk of increased surgical bleeding.
Solution to Question 10:
Beta-blockers are the only antianginal agents that have been demonstrated to prolong life in patients with coronary disease (post-myocardial infarction).
Note: B-blockers and spironolactone have been demonstrated to improve survival in individuals with heart failure.
Solution to Question 11:
In this 60 yr old patient with post-myocardial infarction (Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease patient), high-intensity statins should be given irrespective of cholesterol levels. So atorvastatin 80mg is the treatment plan in the given case scenario.
Examples of high-intensity statins include high-dose atorvastatin 40–80 mg/day and rosuvastatin 20–40 mg/day.
Note: Fenofibrate is not advocated unless TG is more than 500 mg/dl. It can be administered along with a moderate-intensity statin.

Solution to Question 12:
The above scenario is suggestive of NSTEMI. Antiplatelet and anticoagulation therapies and coronary intervention are mainstays of treatment.
A distinction in acute coronary syndrome between patients with and without ST-segment elevation at presentation is essential to determine the need for reperfusion therapy. Fibrinolytic therapy is harmful in acute coronary syndrome without ST-segment elevation, unlike with
ST-segment elevation, where acute reperfusion saves lives.
Solution to Question 13:
Sirolimus and paclitaxel are a part of first-generation drug-eluting stents that carry a relatively higher risk of restenosis and late stent thrombosis than second-generation drug-eluting stents.
Second-generation drug-eluting stents use newer agents such as everolimus, biolimus, and zotarolimus. These second-generation drug-eluting stents are more effective with fewer complications like stent thrombosis than first-generation stents.
An antiproliferative agent is attached to the stent by the use of a thin polymer coating. This antiproliferative drug elutes from the stent over a 1 to 3 month period after implantation.
Solution to Question 14:
The patient described above is categorized as a high-risk patient due to his history of PCI 3 months ago. The next best course of action for this patient is immediate revascularization with PCI.
Revascularization with PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) is indicated in high-risk patients who have one or more of the following:
New ST-segment depression
Diabetes mellitus
Renal dysfunction - eGFR <60mL/min per 1.73m2
Ejection fraction <40%
Early postinfarction angina
PCI within the past 6 months
Prior CABG
Refractory angina
Symptoms of congestive heart failure
Hemodynamic instability
Recurrent angina at rest/low-level activity despite treatment
Elevated troponin T or troponin I
Sustained VT or VF
Solution to Question 15:
The treatment of choice in patients with acute STEMI with cardiogenic shock is revascularization with PCI.
The 2013 ACCF/AHA guidelines for the treatment of cardiogenic shock in patients with acute MI are:
Emergency revascularization with PCI or CABG is recommended in suitable patients irrespective of the time delay from MI onset.
In the absence of contraindications, fibrinolytic therapy should be administered to patients with STEMI and cardiogenic shock who are unsuitable candidates for either PCI or CABG.
Routine use of Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump counterpulsation (IABP) is not recommended for cardiogenic shock (based on IABP-SHOCK II trial). IABP can be useful for those patients with cardiogenic shock after STEMI who do not quickly stabilize with pharmacological therapy or have mechanical complications (eg, acute mitral regurgitation or rupture of the ventricular septum).
Alternative left ventricular assist devices for circulatory support may be considered in patients with refractory cardiogenic shock.
Solution to Question 16:
The above scenario is suggestive of a non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS).
Immediate intervention is the administration of aspirin.
Aspirin is the first drug given in acute coronary syndromes. An initial dose of 325 mg to be chewed and swallowed is given. If oral administration is not feasible, it should be given as a rectal suppository.
The following protocol must be followed in the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome:
Stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation
Administration of O2
Treatment of sustained ventricular arrhythmia rapidly according to ACLS protocols
Give aspirin 325 mg
History and examination, assess cardiac biomarkers
Give three sublingual nitroglycerin tablets each 5 min apart. Add IV nitroglycerin for the persistence of symptoms.
Treat left heart failure if present with an after-load reducing agent or loop diuretic
Give beta-blockers
Give morphine for the persistence of anxiety and discomfort related to MI
In patients with STEMI - Reperfusion with PCI or fibrinolysis (if PCI is unavailable within 120 min) followed by antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy. In patients with NSTEMI - antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy are indicated.
Solution to Question 17:
The above ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF suggestive of an inferior-wall MI. In the given scenario, the most likely reason for the patient to have shock is right ventricular infarction.
The diagnosis of right ventricular MI is suspected in patients with inferior-wall MI, clear lung fields (no added sounds on auscultation), and shock. It can also be confirmed by the use of right-sided electrocardiogram (ECG) leads.
In patients with presumed right ventricular shock, intravenous (IV) fluid replacement is indicated if jugular (central) venous pressure is not elevated.
Options A, B, and D: No added sounds on auscultation clearly rule out mitral regurgitation, septa defect (pansystolic murmur is heard), and decreased ejection fraction from the left ventricle (leads to pulmonary congestion and added sounds), as the cause of shock in this patient.
Solution to Question 18:
The echocardiogram shows pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade (swinging heart sign). The likely diagnosis in the above scenario is myocardial rupture post-MI. It usually occurs 3-5 days postinfarction and commonly involves the anterior wall.
This condition usually results in immediate death. It is common in older women.
Incomplete or gradual rupture may be sealed off by the pericardium creating a pseudoaneurysm.
Immediate pericardiocentesis should be done to relieve the symptoms of shock due to tamponade. Early surgical repair is the definitive treatment.
Solution to Question 19:
Dressler syndrome commonly occurs 1-12 weeks after MI, not 2-7 days. However, it can recur over months.
Dressler syndrome is a post-myocardial infarction syndrome that presents as pleuritic chest pain, fever, and sometimes a pleuritic rub and effusion. The ECG findings include PR segment depression or ST-segment elevation. It is an autoimmune phenomenon occurring due to
immune-complex deposition in the pericardium and lung pleura. The first-line therapy consists of aspirin.
Note: NSAIDs and corticosteroids impair the infarct healing and predispose the patients to myocardial rupture. Therefore these drugs must be avoided in the early postinfarction period.
Solution to Question 20:
The above image showing left ventriculography with contrast is suggestive of a left ventricular aneurysm. Anterior transmural infarcts are involved in causing aneurysms as a post-MI complication.
Patients with anterior transmural infarcts are at the greatest risk for:
Free-wall rupture
Expansion
Mural thrombi
Aneurysm
Posterior transmural infarcts are more likely to be complicated by:
Conduction blocks
Right ventricular involvement, or both
Solution to Question 21:
The door-to-balloon time for a patient arriving in a hospital that is not equipped to perform a PCI and is then transported to a hospital where PCI can be performed is 120 min.
The door-to-balloon time is the time interval between the first medical contact and PCI.
It is 90 min or less for a patient arriving in a hospital equipped with PCI (ACC/AHA guidelines and MoHFW, India guidelines).
In patients who cannot receive PCI within 120 min of first medical contact, fibrinolysis is given. Fibrinolysis is only considered if the patient presents within 12 hours of symptom onset.
Note: The European society of cardiology (ESC) recommends 60 min target time for patients presenting in a PCI-centre and 90 min maximum target time for PCI-mediated reperfusion.
Solution to Question 22:
PCI related MI is defined as elevation of cTn > 5 times normal in the presence of symptoms of MI, ECG changes, angiographic findings or imaging abnormality.
The imaging abnormality could be a new loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality. If the baseline cTn values are elevated but stable or falling, a rise in cTn >20 % defined PCI related MI.
CABG related MI is defined as elevation of cTn > 10 times the normal baseline values in the presence of new pathologic Q waves, angiographic findings or imaging abnormality.
Solution to Question 23:
Based on the given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with sudden onset of chest pain, with ECG findings of ST depression in the anterior chest leads and T wave inversion, the most likely diagnosis is a non-ST-segment elevation-acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS). The most appropriate line of management in this patient would be to administer aspirin with heparin.
Percutaneous coronary intervention is indicated after coronary angiography in high-risk patients. Fibrinolytic therapy is not indicated in patients with NSTE-ACS.
Arrhythmia prophylaxis is generally not routinely recommended in all patients with NSTE-ACS. Acute coronary syndrome is classified into 2 groups:
ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
NSTE-ACS
NSTE-ACS further includes:
NSTEMI (myocyte necrosis present and cardiac troponins elevated)
Unstable Angina (myocyte necrosis absent and cardiac troponins not elevated) The diagnosis of NSTE-ACS is based on the following:
Severe chest discomfort with at least one of 3 features:
Occurring at rest or minimal exertion and lasting for more than 10 minutes
Recent onset
Crescendo pattern
ECG showing:
ST segment depression
T wave inversion
Elevated cardiac troponins in case of NSTEMI. Management of NSTE-ACS:
To provide relief of pain and discomfort, initial treatment includes bed rest, nitrates, beta blockers, and inhaled oxygen (only if arterial O2 saturation <90%).
Antithrombotic therapy consisting of antiplatelet and anticoagulant drugs:
Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT): Aspirin (162-325 mg) AND one ADP receptor inhibitor
(Ticagrelor, clopidogrel or prasugrel)
Anticoagulation: Enoxaparin, unfractionated heparin, fondaparinux or bivalirudin
An early invasive strategy including diagnostic coronary angiography (within 2–72 hours of presentation) followed by revascularization (percutaneous coronary intervention/ coronary artery bypass grafting) is indicated for stabilized patients who are at high risk of coronary events (Based on TIMI, GRACE or HEART score).
Cardiomyopathy and Myocarditis

Solution to Question 1:
The most common mutations in HCM are those affecting the myosin heavy chain.
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant disease. In the majority of cases it is due to missense mutations in the following two sarcolemmal protein genes:
Myosin binding protein C (MYBC)
Beta myosin heavy chain (MYH7)
Option B: Alpha-tropomyosin mutation is seen in HCM but is not common.
Options C and D: Mutations in cardiac troponin C and titin are associated with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario of exercise intolerance (syncope) in the patient and family history of sudden cardiac death in his elder brother at a young age is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Mitral regurgitation with posteriorly directed regurgitant jet is usually seen on echocardiogram in HCM. ECG and echocardiogram are used to confirm the diagnosis of HCM.
HCM is characterized by myofiber disarray in the heart, resulting in a hypertrophic myocardium. The hypertrophy leads to the following pathophysiological changes in HCM:
Diastolic dysfunction - presenting as exercise intolerance
Systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve
The hypertrophied muscles result in a narrow outflow tract
This leads to the production of a high-velocity jet pulling the mitral leaflets towards the septum posteriorly
SAM leads to mitral regurgitation
Dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction Echocardiography features of HCM are as follows:
Left ventricular wall thickness >15 mm
Hypertrophied heart more confined to the interventricular septum resulting in banana-shaped ventricular cavity
Solution to Question 3:
Squatting increases the preload and afterload thereby decreasing the outflow obstruction and intensity of murmur in HCM.
In HCM left ventricular size is small, thus the approximation of the interventricular septum with the mitral valve increases. The following mechanisms further increase this approximation and increase blood outflow obstruction and intensity of murmur:
A decrease in left ventricular cavity volume or pressure (decreased preload)
A decrease in systemic vascular resistance and/or arterial pressure (decreased afterload)
Increase in left ventricular contractility
The image below shows a cross-section of a heart with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Note: All murmurs increase in intensity on squatting except that of HOCM and MVP.

Murmur intensity decreased

obstruction)

(preload = obstruction)

Solution to Question 4:
Atrial fibrillation in HCM is not associated with increased HCM-related mortality. It frequently accounts for unexpected hospital admissions, lost productivity, and impaired quality of life.
Among HCM patients, the greatest risk for sudden cardiac death is seen in patients who have sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT). These patients must undergo placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) for secondary prevention.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Digoxin should be avoided as it may increase contractility and worsen obstruction.
Drugs that can lead to possible aggravation of outflow tract obstruction and thus contraindicated in HCM are:
Digoxin
Inotropes
Nitrates
ACE inhibitors
Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg- nifedipine, amlodipine)
Beta-blockers and verapamil are first-line agents in the treatment of HCM. Disopyramide and amiodarone are the preferred antiarrhythmic agents.
Solution to Question 6:
Symptomatic atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common sustained arrhythmia in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). It frequently accounts for unexpected hospital admissions, lost productivity, and impaired quality of life.
Treatment of atrial fibrillation in HCM:
Amiodarone - drug of choice
Disopyramide
Radiofrequency ablation for medically refractory cases
Anticoagulation to prevent embolic events
Note: A sustained arrhythmia is one that lasts for >30 seconds.
Solution to Question 7:
Participation in competitive sports is not recommended for patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
The following general measures are advised for patients with HCM:
Patients are advised against engaging in competitive athletics or vigorous physical activities
Maintaining low to moderate levels of exercise as a part of a healthy lifestyle has been proven to be beneficia
Adequate hydration at all times
Note: Non-contact sports are those sports wherein the participants are physically separated with almost no physical contact (ex: tennis, badminton) between them. Contact sports involve some form of physical contact between the participants (ex: wrestling, boxing)
Solution to Question 8:
The presence of giant T wave inversions and spade-like deformity on left ventriculography points to a diagnosis of apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is also called Yamaguchi syndrome. It is characterized by hypertrophy of the myocardium, predominantly in the left ventricular apex. It was first described in the Japanese population and is uncommon in other populations.
The symptoms are milder and the risk of sudden cardiac death is lower than in the traditional septal form of HCM.
The image below shows the ace of spades appearance on left ventriculography:

The image below shows the ace of spades appearance on echocardiography with massive hypertrophy of the apex and relative sparing of the base:

Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario of sudden heart failure in a previously healthy person under a stressful situation is suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. It is a transient myocardial stunning from microcirculation spams due to a catecholamine surge during stress. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. The patients can present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain.
ECHO reveals apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart, resembling a Takotsubo (pot for catching octopus). The ECG changes can mimic myocardial infarction but changes extend beyond a particular coronary arterial territory. Coronary angiography, therefore, may be needed to rule out coronary occlusion. (Option B)
It is a self-limiting disorder resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good.
The image below shows left ventriculography during systole showing apical ballooning resembling a Takotsubo pot.

Other options:
Option A: Infective cardiomyopathy: The most common causes of infective myocarditis are viral infections and the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, which is associated with Chagas' disease. Acute viral myocarditis often presents with symptoms and signs of heart failure, although it can also manifest as chest pain and show electrocardiogram (ECG) changes resembling pericarditis or acute myocardial infarction. In Chagas' disease, specific features include abnormalities in the conduction system, particularly dysfunction of the sinus node and AV node, as well as the right bundle branch block.
Option C: Dilated cardiomyopathy: It is the most common cardiomyopathy and is predominantly characterised by systolic dysfunction. Though it may present acutely, it progresses chronically.
The familial form is due to mutations in TTN gene which encode the sarcomeric protein titin. Other etiologocal agents include alcohol, infective myocarditis, doxorubicin, hemochromatosis and sarcoidosis.
Option D: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most common genetic cardiovascular disorder and is a prominent cause of sudden death before the age of 35 years. Family history is commonly present, a sarcomere mutation is present in ~50% of patients. Sudden death can be due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation. Risk factors for sudden death in this disease include young age, nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, failure of blood pressure to increase during exercise, recent (within 6 months) syncope, ventricular wall thickness >3 cm, and possibly the severity of LV outflow obstruction.
Solution to Question 10:
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is the probable diagnosis when the observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match ECG changes.
Myocardial stunning is a state where certain segments of the myocardium (usually corresponding to an area of major coronary occlusion) show forms of contractile abnormality (dysfunction) on echocardiography.
In Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, while the ECG changes mimic a myocardial infarction(MI), the left ventricular dysfunction extends well beyond the distribution of a specific coronary artery. Thus, the myocardial stunning pattern might not fully match the ECG. Ventriculography shows apica dilation with basal contraction.
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy occurs typically in older women and is associated with a sudden increase in emotional or physical stress, presenting with hypotension, chest pain with ECG changes of acute MI, and pulmonary edema. Its also known as apical ballooning syndrome or acute stress-induced cardiomyopathy.
Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by diastolic dysfunction with reduced contractility and ejection fraction, most commonly seen in amyloidosis, and enlarged ventricles on imaging with low-voltage ECG complexes.
Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is a type of familial dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), having defects in desmosomal proteins, affecting the ventricles showing thin ventricular walls on Echo, epsilon waves, and low voltage ECG complexes.
Option D: Pericardial tamponade is characterized by hypotension, muffled heart sounds and increased jugular venous pressure with muffled heart sounds with total electrical alternans and sinus tachycardia in ECG.

The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency. It is endemic dilated cardiomyopathy that affects children and women of childbearing age in some areas in China.

Selenium

Phosphate
Magnesium

Active myocarditis is defined as an inflammatory infiltrate of the myocardium with necrosis and/or degeneration of adjacent myocytes not typical of the ischemic damage associated with coronary artery disease.
Borderline myocarditis is the term used when the inflammatory infiltrate is too sparse or myocyte injury is not demonstrated.

The most common noninfective cause of myocarditis is sarcoidosis.

The given clinical scenario of a young patient with a history of sudden collapse following physical activity along with ECG findings of V5, V6 inversion, and prominent inverted T-waves, and 2D echocardiography showing the systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet point toward a diagnosis of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HCM).
In HCM, clinical examination may reveal pulsus bisferiens and an ejection systolic murmur that increases on standing.
Beta-blockers and implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICD) are used in the management.
HCM is a leading cause of sudden death in young. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern with variable penetrance. HCM is characterized by the thickening of the septal myocardium below the aortic valve leading to obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.

Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of heart failure. The brain natriuretic peptide
(BNP) can be used to confirm this.
Natriuretic peptides are protein molecules that are secreted by the ventricular myocytes in response to volume or pressure overload. Ventricular musculature releases pre-proBNP which is cleaved into active BNP and inert NT-proBNP.
BNP causes natriuresis, vasodilatation, and diuresis that leads to improved myocardial relaxation. These peptides also counteract the actions of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Measurement of both BNP and inert NT-proBNP levels can be used in the diagnosis of heart failure and to determine the prognosis.

Flash pulmonary edema

It falsely increases in:
Advanced age
Renal impairment
Female patients

Solution to Question 6:
ACE inhibitors + beta-blockers are the treatment of choice in patients with heart failure with an ejection fraction of <40% after euvolemic status is achieved using diuretics.
The first-line drugs used in congestive heart failure with reduced ejection fraction are ACE inhibitors + diuretics. Once the euvolemic status is achieved, ACE inhibitors + beta-blockers are the drugs of choice.
Beta-blockers that improve survival in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction are carvedilol, metoprolol, and bisoprolol.
Solution to Question 7:
Sacubitril/Valsartan, an angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI), is used in patients with chronic symptomatic HFrEF to reduce morbidity and mortality (class I recommendation).
Sacubitril (neprilysin inhibitor) is approved in combination with valsartan (ARB), in a ratio of 1:1. The combination is approved for use in chronic heart failure.
Sacubitril is a prodrug that is activated to sacubitrilat. It inhibits the enzyme neprilysin (neutral endopeptidase), which is responsible for the degradation of atrial and brain natriuretic peptides (reduction of blood volume). Thus, it increases the levels of atrial and brain natriuretic peptides and lowers blood pressure.
Solution to Question 8:
Omecamtiv mecarbil is the selective myosin activator. It activates cardiac myosin and prolongs systole without increasing oxygen consumption of the heart.
Solution to Question 9:
Ivabradine is an inhibitor of If current in the sinoatrial node. It reduces the heart rate without decreasing the force of contraction.
It is used in patients with chronic HFrEF with a sinus rhythm and a resting heart rate 70 bpm who are either on a maximum tolerated beta-blocker dose or have a contraindication for
beta-blockers. The concurrent treatment should include ACE inhibitor ( or ARB ) and aldosterone receptor antagonist.
Option A: Omapatrilat is a dual neprilysin inhibitor+ ACE inhibitor.
Option C: Nesiritide belongs to the intravenous vasodilators class and is a recombinant human brain natriuretic peptide (BNP).
Option D: Levosimendan belongs to the positive inotropes class and is a combined calcium sensitizer and PDE3 inhibitor.

Option A: Levosimendan belongs to the positive inotropes class and is a combined calcium sensitizer and PDE3 inhibitor.

Solution to Question 13:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with symptomatic heart failure and K+ levels of 5.5 mg%. She requires a diuretic for symptom control. Furosemide can be given safely as it causes hypokalemia.
Other options:
Option A: Digoxin is not used as a first-line drug in the management of symptomatic heart failure.
Options B and C: Spironolactone (K+ sparing diuretic) and enalapril (ACE inhibitor) can cause hyperkalemia.
The first step in managing acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) is addressing the factors that caused the decompensation. They include nonadherence to medications, dietary indiscretion, medication use that exacerbates heart failure, coronary ischemia, arrhythmias, valvular heart disease, infection, and pulmonary thromboembolism.
Volume management is crucial in ADHF. Intravenous loop diuretics are used to relieve congestion. The effectiveness of diuretic therapy can be assessed by changes in weight, improvement in symptoms, and clinical examination findings. Natriuretic peptide levels can also help assess the adequacy of therapy and predict risk.
Cardiorenal syndrome, characterized by the interplay between heart and kidney dysfunction, is a common complication of ADHF. Diuretic therapy should be carefully managed to avoid worsening renal function in patients with elevated right-sided filling pressures. In cases of severe low cardiac output, inotropic therapy or mechanical circulatory support may be necessary to preserve or improve renal function temporarily.
Vasodilators like nitroglycerin, sodium nitroprusside, and nesiritide (recombinant BNP) are used to reduce filling pressures and systemic vascular resistance.
Inotropic therapy with drugs like dopamine and milrinone is used to increase myocardial contractility and improve cardiac output in patients with low-output ADHF. Dopamine has
dose-dependent effects on different receptors, while milrinone is a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor.
Solution to Question 14:
The above X-ray showing batwing appearance along with the given symptoms and reduced LVEF is suggestive of acute decompensated heart failure with pulmonary edema. Digoxin has no role in the management of this condition.
The management of acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema consists of:
Oxygen therapy and positive pressure ventilation
Reduction of preload:
Diuretics: Furosemide is the diuretic of choice
Nitrates: sublingual nitroglycerin is the first-line therapy. If pulmonary edema persists, IV nitroglycerin is administered.
Morphine: It is a transient venodilator that reduces preload, thereby reducing dyspnea and anxiety.
ACE inhibitors: They reduce both preload and afterload and are recommended for hypertensive patients.
Nesiritide: It is an IV recombinant BNP which is a potent vasodilator with diuretic properties.
Inotropic and inodilators:
Dopamine, dobutamine-inotropic agents.
Milrinone- stimulates myocardial contractility and promotes peripheral vasodilatation.
Intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation- or LV assist devices are used in cardiogenic shock and end-organ failure.

Solution to Question 1:
Clinically, acute pericarditis is of <6 weeks duration.
Pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardial sac. This inflammation can lead to excessive secretion of the pericardial fluid leading to pericardial effusion. When the accumulation of fluid causes obstruction to the inflow of blood into the ventricles, it is called cardiac tamponade.
Clinically, pericarditis is classified as:
Acute - < 6 weeks
Subacute - 6 weeks to 6 months
Chronic - > 6 months
Solution to Question 2:
In this patient, Low-grade fever, chest pain that got relieved on leaning forward, and characteristic auscultatory findings are suggestive of acute pericarditis. The grating sound heard on auscultation is a pericardial friction rub.
Features of the pericardial rub:
Superficial scratchy/leathery/grating sound caused due to friction between the visceral and parietal pericardium
Best heard at end-expiration with the patient sitting and leaning forward
Very high-pitched sound best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope, at the lower left sternal border
Consists of three components corresponding to atrial systole, ventricular systole, and early ventricular diastole
Pathognomonic of acute pericarditis
Solution to Question 3:
The above scenario is suggestive of acute pericarditis. PR-segment depressions are seen early in acute pericarditis.
The ECG changes in acute pericarditis evolve through 4 stages -
Stage 1 - Generalized ST-segment elevation with upward concavity with reciprocal depressions only in aVR and V1 and PR segment depression.
Stage 2 - The ST segments return to normal
Stage 3 - Diffuse T-wave inversion
Stage 4 - ECG returns to normal in weeks or months ECG in acute pericarditis vs acute MI:
Cardiac biomarkers are grossly elevated in acute-MI, whereas in acute pericarditis the elevation if present is only mild and indicative of epi-myocarditis causing myocyte necrosis.

Solution to Question 4:
A patch of dullness with increased vocal fremitus beneath the angle of the left scapula due to the compression of the base of the lung by the pericardial fluid is called Ewart’s sign. It is seen in pericardial effusion.
Acute pericarditis is frequently associated with pericardial effusion.
Option A: Auenbrugger’s sign is the bulging of the epigastrium in severe pericardial effusion.
Option B: Moschcowitz’s sign is the abrupt transition in percussion from the lungs to the right heart border seen in pericardial effusion.

Solution to Question 5:
Pulsus paradoxus is not part of Beck’s triad. Pulsus paradoxus is seen in cardiac tamponade. However, it is not a part of Beck's triad.
Beck’s triad is seen in cardiac tamponade and it includes:
Hypotension
Soft or absent heart sounds
Jugular venous distension
Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space significant enough to cause an obstruction to the inflow of blood to the ventricles. This reduces cardiac output and arterial pressure causing hypotension.
This also causes a greater than the normal reduction in the systolic arterial blood pressure producing pulsus paradoxus. Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration.
Other causes of pulsus paradoxus include:
Massive pulmonary embolism
Tension pneumothorax
Severe obstructive lung disease
Hemorrhagic shock
The echocardiography clip below shows the swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade.

Solution to Question 6:
The differentiating feature between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax is breath sounds. The breath sounds are absent in tension pneumothorax while they are present in cardiac tamponade.
The presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad) suggest a cardiac tamponade. These features can also be seen in tension pneumothorax. Other clinical features pointing towards tension pneumothorax are absent breath sounds, hyper resonance to percussion, and shift of the mediastinum to the contralateral side.
Heart sounds can be muffled by structures between the stethoscope and the heart, eg, adipose tissue deposition (obesity), fluid accumulation (pericardial effusion, pleural effusion), gas accumulation (pneumothorax, subcutaneous emphysema), soft tissue masses can lead to attenuation of heart sounds.
Solution to Question 7:
The patient with cardiac tamponade is asked to breathe normally to elicit pulsus paradoxus.
In a patient with cardiac tamponade, both ventricles share an incompressible pericardial covering due to the fluid. As the right ventricle enlarges during inspiration, the interventricular septum bulges into the left ventricle, reducing the left ventricular volume.
This results in reduced stroke volume and hence reduced systolic arterial pressure.
As a result, there is a greater than normal (more than 10 mmHg) fall in systolic arterial blood pressure during inspiration, producing pulsus paradoxus.
This cannot be elicited if the patient is holding his/her breath, taking long or shallow breaths.
Pulsus paradoxus is also seen with effusive constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy and right ventricular myocardial infarction.

The given clinical scenario with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated JVP (Beck's triad) suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. The JVP finding most likely to be seen
is prominent x descent and absent y descent.

Note: JVP in constrictive pericarditis is characterized by prominent x and y descents.

Electrical alternans is the beat-to-beat alternation in the ECG waveform. In cardiac tamponade, this is caused by the periodic swinging motion of the heart in a large pericardial effusion.

Solution to Question 11:
The presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and absence of heart sounds (Beck's triad) are suggestive of cardiac tamponade. An urgent pericardial tap needs to be done to relieve the tension on the heart chambers.
Although these features could be seen in tension pneumothorax as well, the presence of adequate bilateral air entry excludes this diagnosis.
Pericardiocentesis, also known as pericardial tap, can be performed with sub-xiphoid, parasternal, or apical approaches. The most common approach is a sub-xiphoid approach under echocardiographic guidance.
Option A: Rapid blood transfusion is needed in massive blood loss indicated by hypotension. Although this patient presents with hypotension, it is most likely a result of cardiac tamponade. Although blood transfusion is indicated, it will be effective only when the pericardial tap decompresses the pericardium.
Option C: Intercostal tube drainage is done in tension pneumothorax. The presence of adequate air entry bilaterally excludes this diagnosis.
Option D: The fixation of femur fracture and femoral artery is not a priority here. The inability to palpate pulses distal to the fracture could be a result of hypotension. This needs to be explored only if the patient fails to improve after the pericardial tap and blood transfusion.
Solution to Question 12:
A rise or a lack of fall in JVP with inspiration is known as Kussmaul's sign. It is not seen in cardiac tamponade.
Normally, in inspiration due to the negative intrathoracic pressure and increased intrathoracic volume, the capacity of the right heart increases and the JVP falls. In conditions where the myocardium or pericardium is poorly compliant, it does not allow the right heart chambers to accommodate more blood and this fall is not seen. In fact, due to an increase in venous return during inspiration, the JVP might rise. This is called Kussmaul's sign.
This is seen in:
Restrictive cardiomyopathy
Constrictive pericarditis
Massive pulmonary embolism
Right ventricular infarcts
Advanced cases of left ventricular systolic failure
Kussmaul’s sign is not seen in patients with cardiac tamponade because even though the increase in pericardial pressure exerts an inward force compressing the entire heart during inspiration, the increase in negative intrathoracic pressure is still transmitted to the right side of the heart. This allows for an increase in blood flow to the right atrium. Therefore, the JVP falls as seen in normal conditions.

Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario of a young male developing respiratory distress with hypotension, subcutaneous emphysema, and unilaterally absent air entry is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The immediate next step, in this case, would be needle decompression at the fifth intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line (as the patient is an adult).
In children, the second intercostal space in the midclavicular line is chosen as the site for needle decompression.
Needle decompression turns a tension pneumothorax into an open pneumothorax. It has to be followed by tube thoracostomy. An intercostal chest drain (ICD) tube is inserted in the triangle of safety, just anterior to the midaxillary line on the side of the lung injury. The site of insertion is the same in both children and adults.
The triangle of safety is bounded by the lateral border of the pectoralis major anteriorly, the anterior border of the latissimus dorsi posteriorly, and the fifth intercostal space inferiorly, with the apex below the axilla. This provides a safe landmark for the insertion of an ICD with minimal risk of tissue injury.

Tension pneumothorax is a condition where air accumulates in the pleural space due to a one-way valve air leak, leading to the collapse of the affected lung. This can cause a mediastinal shift, compression of the opposite lung, and decreased venous return, resulting in obstructive shock. It commonly occurs during positive-pressure mechanical ventilation, but can also happen after chest trauma, subclavian/internal jugular venous catheter insertion, or chest wall defects. The diagnosis is clinical, and immediate treatment is necessary without waiting for radiological confirmation.
Tension pneumothorax is characterized by chest pain, tachypnoea, tachycardia, hypotension, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, absent breath sounds on the affected side, cyanosis, and neck vein distention. Patients can also develop subcutaneous emphysema as a complication secondary to the pneumothorax.

Solution to Question 1:
Pulmonary hypertension is a pathological hemodynamic condition characterized by a mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAP) >20mmHg assessed by right heart catheterization.
Pulmonary hypertension could be a complication of cardiac or pulmonary disease or a primary disorder of small pulmonary arteries. Right heart catheterization is the gold standard investigation in diagnosing pulmonary hypertension.
Note: The threshold for diagnosing pulmonary hypertension has been revised from >25 mmHg to >20 mmHg to enable earlier detection.
Solution to Question 2:
Bone morphogenetic protein receptor 2 (BMPR2) mutation is the most commonly implicated gene in hereditary pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
The BMPR2 receptor is involved in the regulation of growth, differentiation, and apoptosis of pulmonary artery endothelial and smooth muscle cells. Due to the mutation, there is enhanced proliferation and reduced apoptosis of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells leading to pulmonary hypertension.

Solution to Question 5:
In the given scenario, a mitral valve area of 1 sq cm suggests severe mitral stenosis. This leads to elevated LA pressure and subsequently pulmonary hypertension. Due to pulmonary hypertension, there is compensatory RV hypertrophy (right ventricular-pulmonary hypertension coupling) and secondary TR. The next step should be to confirm pulmonary hypertension. Right heart catheterization is the gold standard test for diagnosing pulmonary hypertension.
Option A: Cardiac MRI is considered the gold standard for assessing RV function. In the case of pulmonary hypertension, it is used for serial follow-ups due to its non-invasive nature.
Options B and D: CT angiography and ventilation/perfusion scan are done when pulmonary hypertension is suspected to be due to pulmonary embolism, coagulation disorders, or past history of thrombosis (chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension) which should be followed by right heart catheterization.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension. Vasodilator therapy would be beneficial in this patient. Endothelin receptor antagonists, PDE-5 inhibitors, and prostacyclins are examples of vasodilators.
Option A: Since pulmonary arterial hypertension is a vascular disorder, bronchodilation is not beneficial.
Option C: Nitric oxide is a vasodilator and inhibitors of nitric oxide would worsen the disease in pulmonary arterial hypertension.
Option D: Immunosuppressants are not useful in pulmonary arterial hypertension.
Solution to Question 7:
ACE inhibitors are not used in pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Solution to Question 1:
Aortic aneurysms caused by spondyloarthropathies are most commonly seen in the ascending aorta.
An aneurysm is a pathologic dilation of a segment of a blood vessel. An aortic aneurysm occurs when the structural components of the aortic wall, that is, elastin and collagen, are damaged. This may occur either due to degradation or abnormal synthesis of these components.

Solution to Question 2:
The most common pathology associated with ascending aortic aneurysm is medial degeneration.
Medial degeneration (cystic medial necrosis) describes the degenerative process of the tunica media of the aorta. There is degeneration of collagen and elastic fibers in the media and loss of medial cells that are replaced by multiple clefts of mucoid material, such as proteoglycans.
It is seen in the following conditions and is associated with the corresponding mutations:
Marfan’s syndrome- fibrillin 1
Loeys-Dietz syndrome- TGFBR1, TGFBR2
Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV - type III procollagen
Familial thoracic aortic aneurysm syndromes- genes associated with actin and myosin eg. ACTA2, MHC11
Congenital bicuspid aortic valves
Turner’s syndrom
Hypertension
Solution to Question 3:
The X-ray shows a widening of the mediastinum with trachea displaced to the right and dilatation of the ascending thoracic aorta (red arrow) i.e. ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm. In the case of Marfan's syndrome, ascending aortic aneurysm of 4-5 cm is taken up for operative repair. This is because of a higher rate of expansion of the aneurysm in these patients.
Management of thoracic aortic aneurysm:
Beta-blockers and angiotensin receptor antagonists reduce the rate of expansion, especially in Marfan's syndrome.
Operative treatment is indicated in:
All symptomatic cases
Ascending aortic aneurysm -  5.5 cm in diameter or growth rate of >0.5 cm/year
Descending aortic aneurysm - > 6 cm in diameter or growth rate of >1 cm/year
Marfan's syndrome - 4-5 cm in diameter
Solution to Question 4:
Operative repair of the aneurysm is the next best step in management in this case. Operative repair is indicated for both symptomatic or asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms if they are
 5.5 cm in diameter.
Abdominal aortic aneurysms are mostly asymptomatic and are detected as incidental findings on investigations for other complaints. Sometimes, they present with pain and pulsatile abdominal mass. Rupture of aneurysm presents with acute pain and hypotension.
Management of abdominal aortic aneurysms:
Statins- atherosclerosis is the most common pathology associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. Hence, statins are prescribed to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
Asymptomatic aneurysms <5.5 cm in diameter- serial abdominal ultrasound to monitor th rate of expansion of the aneurysm.
Operative repair is indicated for:
Aneurysm of any size associated with symptoms
Rapidly growing aneurysms
Aneurysms 5.5 cm in diameter
Note: Medical management with beta-blockers though helps in BP control, it is not effective in reducing the rate of growth of abdominal aortic aneurysms.

Solution to Question 5:
Blood cultures may indicate the etiology of the aneurysm. They are often positive in patients with mycotic aneurysms.
A mycotic aneurysm is a rare condition that develops as a result of staphylococcal, streptococcal, salmonella or other bacterial or fungal infections of the aorta. The term mycotic aneurysm is usually a misnomer as the causative pathogen is usually bacteria rather than fungi.
These aneurysms are usually saccular. These organisms may involve every major artery, but aortic involvement predominates.

The third trimester of pregnancy is a predisposing factor for aortic dissection, not second. Predisposition to aortic dissection increases when there are factors associated with:
Medial degeneration- seen in:
Syndromes affecting the connective tissue- Marfan's, Ehlers Danlos syndrom
Vasculitis- Takayasu's arteritis, giant cell arteritis
Increased stress on the aortic wall- seen in:
Hypertension
Third trimester of pregnancy
Other conditions with increased incidence include:
Bicuspid aortic valv
Coarctation of aorta
Aortic trauma
Cocaine us
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing double-lumen of the aorta are suggestive of aortic dissection. Isolated use of a direct vasodilator such as hydralazine is contraindicated in acute dissection.
It is because these agents can increase hydraulic shear and worsen the dissection by causing vasodilation without reducing the left ventricular ejection force that continues to weaken the arterial wall.
Medical therapy for aortic dissection includes beta-blockers and sodium nitroprusside to reduce cardiac contractility and blood pressure. The heart rate is reduced to around 60 bpm and the SBP is lowered to  120mmHg.
CCBs like verapamil and diltiazem may be used IV if nitroprusside or beta-blockers cannot be employed. Parenteral angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor such as enalaprilat may be considered.
Solution to Question 8:
Image D depicts Stanford type A aortic dissection. The classification schemes for aortic dissection are:
Stanford classification
Type A - dissection involves the ascending aorta with or without the involvement of other parts of the aorta
Type B - dissection is limited to the arch and/or descending aorta without the involvement of ascending aorta
DeBakey classification
Type I - dissection involves ascending to descending aorta
Type II - dissection is limited to the ascending aorta or transverse aorta without descending aorta
Type III - intimal tear is located in the descending aorta with distal propagation of the dissection

Hence, if the ascending aorta is involved, it is Stanford type A and DeBakey type I or II. If only the aortic arch or the descending aorta is involved, it is Stanford type B and DeBakey type III.
From a management standpoint, the classification of aortic dissections into type A or B is more practical and useful, since DeBakey types I and II are managed in a similar manner.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario describes intermittent claudication. It is the most common symptom of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The most appropriate advice for this patient is antiplatelet therapy with aspirin.
PAD occurs due to atherosclerotic plaques causing stenosis and occlusion of blood flow. The symptoms of inadequate blood flow exacerbate during increased physical activity.
The following advice is given to patients with PAD:
Lifestyle modification- regular exercise, discontinue smoking
Statins to treat hypercholesterolemia
Reducing the risk of cardiovascular events:
Controlling hypertension- angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, beta-blockers
Antiplatelet therapy- aspirin, clopidogrel
Revascularization procedures (catheter-based or surgical)- For patients not improving with medical therapy
Endovascular interventions- percutaneous transluminal balloon angioplasty (PTA), stent placement, atherectomy
Surgical- aortobifemoral bypass using Dacron grafts, axillofemoral bypass, femoro-femoral bypass
Antiplatelet therapy and warfarin is not preferred because of the high risk of bleeding.
Intravenous heparin is used to treat acute limb ischemia which most often occurs due to thromboembolic events. Acute limb ischemia presents with loss of pulses distal to the occlusion, cyanosis, or pallor. These symptoms do not subside on taking rest. Hence, this patient has intermittent claudication and not acute limb ischemia.

Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Raynaud’s phenomenon. Clonidine is avoided in Raynaud’s phenomenon as it worsens the condition.
Clonidine acts on central alpha-2 adrenoreceptor in CNS and reduces sympathetic outflow. This causes decreased blood pressure and perfusion that can exacerbate Raynaud's phenomenon or any PVD.
Drugs that can be used for the treatment of Raynaud’s phenomenon: Primary Raynaud's:
Dihydropyridine CCBs- nifedipine, isradipine, felodipine, and amlodipin
Diltiazem
Prazosin, doxazosin, and terazosin Secondary Raynaud's:
Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors- sildenafil and tadalafil
Digital sympathectomy is helpful in some patients who are unresponsive to medical therapy.

Solution to Question 1:
Pulmonary infarction as suggested by CT is typically due to a small pulmonary embolism.
Pulmonary infarction occurs when small thrombi lodge in the segmental and subsegmental vessels. These patients most often have pleuritic chest pain as the site where the thrombus lodges are near the innervation of pleural nerves.
Massive pulmonary emboli and saddle emboli that occlude the main pulmonary artery
cause hypotension and shock as opposed to infarction. These are caused by larger-sized emboli that lodge more proximally in the pulmonary circulation.
Pulmonary embolism is classified based on the degree of reduction of pulmonary vascular blood flow and associated hemodynamic disturbances:
Massive: Hypotension lasting for >15 minutes or BP maintained with inotropes.
Submassive: No hypotension, but features of cardiac injury present.
Non-massive: No hypotension or features of cardiac injury.
CT findings associated with pulmonary infarction include a feeding vessel or vessel sign as shown below. It depicts a distinct vessel feeding directly to a lesion, usually of hematogenous origin.
However, it is not specific for pulmonary infarction.

Solution to Question 2:
Enlarged right descending pulmonary artery on a chest X-ray in pulmonary embolism is called Palla’s sign.
The black pleura sign is seen in alveolar pulmonary microlithiasis. It refers to the shadow of the pleura between the extensive alveolar calcification and the adjacent rib cage.
Solution to Question 3:
The sign described is called McConnell’s sign.
It demonstrates right ventricular dysfunction as akinesia of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion at the right ventricular apex. It is the best-known indirect sign of pulmonary embolism on transthoracic echocardiography.
Moses' (Bancroft's), Homan’s, and Lowenberg’s signs are seen in venous thrombosis. They're not specific to pulmonary embolism.
Solution to Question 4:
NGAL (Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin) is a kidney injury marker and not a cardiac injury marker.
The following are biomarkers of cardiac injury in pulmonary embolism:
Plasma brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)
Heart-type fatty acid binding protein
Troponins.
Serum troponin and plasma heart-type fatty acid-binding protein levels increase because of right ventricular microinfarction. Myocardial stretch causes the release of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) or NT-proBNP.
Solution to Question 5:
All of the conditions mentioned above have raised D-dimer levels. D-dimer is a fibrin degradation product.
Plasma D-dimer levels commonly rise in DVT and pulmonary embolism due to the breakdown of fibrin by plasmin. D-dimer is more sensitive to pulmonary embolism than DVT. The sensitivity of D-dimer levels in the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism is > 95% but it is is not specific for pulmonary embolism.
Normal D-dimer rules out pulmonary embolism in low and intermediate-risk patients. Patients with a high risk of PE should undergo a CT pulmonary angiogram to effectively rule out PE.
Conditions which have raised D-dimer levels include:
Myocardial infarction
Pneumonia
Sepsi
Cancer
Postoperative state
Pregnancy- second and third trimester
Solution to Question 6:
The above scenario is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). IVC filters increase the rate of recurrence of DVT (by providing a nidus for clot formation) even though they usually prevent pulmonary embolism (over the short term).
The two principal indications for insertion of an IVC filter are:
Active bleeding (prevents the use of anticoagulation)
Recurrent venous thrombosis despite intensive anticoagulation
Prevention of recurrent PE in patients with right heart failure who are not candidates for fibrinolysis and prophylaxis of extremely high-risk patients are some other indications for filter placement.
Patients impaired by dyspnea due to chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension should be considered for pulmonary thromboendarterectomy.
Solution to Question 7:
CT pulmonary angiography should be performed as it is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE).
Option A: Most patients with acute PE have normal echocardiograms. However, echocardiography is a very useful diagnostic tool for detecting conditions that may mimic PE, such as acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.
Option C: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, used mostly for patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast or in whom the CT results are inconclusive.
Option D: MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. It is used when neither CT angiography nor
ventilation-perfusion scan can be done.

A patient with Well's score of 1.5 has a low probability of pulmonary embolism. The initial investigation should be the measurement of D-dimer levels.
In a patient with a high probability of pulmonary embolism, the initial investigation is CT pulmonary angiography.

Solution to Question 10:
For fibrinolysis (thrombolytic therapy) in massive pulmonary embolism, the only widely accepted indication is persistent hypotension or shock. It is defined as SBP <90mmHg or a decrease in SBP by 40 mmHg from baseline for >15 minutes.
Alteplase or recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), streptokinase, and urokinase are approved for the treatment of PE. tPA is the most commonly used fibrinolytic, but it is not superior to other agents.
Pulmonary embolism is classified based on the degree of reduction of pulmonary vascular blood flow and associated hemodynamic disturbances:
Massive: Hypotension lasting for >15 minutes or BP maintained with inotropes.
Submassive: No hypotension, but features of cardiac injury present.
Non-massive: No hypotension or features of cardiac injury. Contraindications for thrombolysis:
Haemorrhagic stroke
Ischemic stroke in the last 6 month
CNS tumour
Major surgery/trauma in the last 3 week
Active bleeding
Bleeding diathesis.

Solution to Question 12:
Betrixaban is a new oral, once-daily factor Xa inhibitor approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for extended-duration prophylaxis of VTE in acute medically ill patients.
In patients with no obvious risk factors for VTE, early ambulation with or without mechanical methods (pneumatic compression stockings or venous foot pump) should be advised.
In patients with one risk factor for VTE with no risk of bleeding, LMWH is preferred. In presence of renal failure/cost issues, unfractionated heparin is used. In the case of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, fondaparinux is preferred.
In patients with multiple risk factors, increasing the dose of anticoagulants or using a mechanical device is advised. For patients with risk factors and a high risk of bleeding or contraindication for anticoagulation, mechanical methods are recommended.
Solution to Question 13:
May-Thurner syndrome (MTS) is caused when the left iliac vein is compressed by the right iliac artery against the fifth lumbar vertebra. It is also called iliocaval venous compression syndrome, iliac vein compression syndrome, Cockett's syndrome, and venous spur.
Most patients have a partial obstruction and are asymptomatic. It can however progress to symptomatic extensive deep vein thrombosis (DVT). It is a cause of recurrent DVT affecting the left leg.
Solution to Question 14:
The above scenario is suggestive of pulmonary embolism. ECG shows the S1Q3T3 sign (i.e, an S wave in lead I, a Q wave in lead III, and an inverted T wave in lead III) that is relatively specific but insensitive. The most common sign of pulmonary embolism is tachypnea.
Most common symptom of pulmonary embolism is dyspnea. Most common ECG abnormality in pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia.Most common preliminary investigation used is

Solution to Question 15:
Surgical pulmonary embolectomy is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient.
This patient is suffering from a massive pulmonary embolism. In such cases, thrombolytic therapy is given once diagnosis is made using CT pulmonary angiography or bedside ECHO.
But, since this patient underwent a large open abdominal operation (bariatric surgery), thrombolysis is contraindicated due to the increased risk of life-threatening bleeding. Therefore, surgical embolectomy must be done. The main pulmonary arteries are incised, and fresh clots are removed.
Contraindications for thrombolysis:
Haemorrhagic stroke
Ischemic stroke in the last 6 month
CNS tumour
Major surgery/trauma in the last 3 week
Active bleeding
Bleeding diathesis.
Solution to Question 16:
This patient had suboptimal anticoagulation management. The best approach would be to reinstitute heparin and continue warfarin.
The patient had unprovoked PE from lower limb DVT. She was started on warfarin bridged with heparin initially.
Warfarin & parenteral anticoagulation need to be overlapped for at least 5 days, independent of the INR achieved during these 5 days in patients with acute venous thromboembolism.
Warfarin inhibits protein C, protein S (which is part of the fibrinolytic pathway) in addition to factors II, VII, IX, X. Protein C has a short half-life (4-6 hours) and thus decreases early. Since protein C is antithrombotic, decreased levels of protein C by warfarin renders the patient hypercoagulable during the first few days of treatment before factor II with a long half-life (36 hours) decreases and protects the patient from thrombosis.
Thus warfarin creates a prothrombotic state in the first 5 days putting the patient at risk of progression of thrombosis unless a parenteral anticoagulant is given overlapping warfarin for these days.
Solution to Question 17:
This patient is most probably suffering from antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) as her lupus anticoagulant is strongly positive. In such patients, the initial anticoagulation is with unfractionated heparin and is monitored by anti-Xa tests.
Due to the presence of lupus anticoagulant, the lab measurement of aPTT will show erroneously prolonged aPTT. Therefore, even though there is an apparently prolonged aPTT, the patient is at increased risk of thrombosis and not bleeding, and hence patients with APS should be anticoagulated.
Anti Xa tests are not influenced by APS. So, the patient can be monitored for the adequacy of anticoagulation with UFH by monitoring anti-Xa.
Option A: The patient’s aPTT is already prolonged due to lupus anticoagulant, so we cannot monitor the patient with aPTT after starting unfractionated heparin.
Option C: Warfarin in the first few days of therapy, causes a decrease in Protein C & S levels, causing a prothrombotic state. Hence, a heparin bridge is necessary for APS which is already a pro-thrombotic state.
Option D: Argatroban is a direct thrombin inhibitor used in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia(HIT) to prevent thrombosis and also to increase platelet levels. Therapy is monitored with aPTT.
Note: Lupus anticoagulant may function as an inhibitor in vitro by binding to the reagent phospholipid and blocking the phospholipid-dependent reactions of the intrinsic pathway. The net effect is a prolongation of the aPTT.
Solution to Question 18:
The risk of developing pulmonary embolism in this patient is high (Option B) according to the three-tiered Well’s clinical risk assessment score.
Calculation of Well's score:
Clinical signs of DVT = 3; - swelling of legs, pain on palpation (Moses sign)
No alternative diagnosis = 3
Heart rate is <100 BPM = 0; - 70 BPM
Surgery in previous 4 weeks = 1.5; - hip replacement surgery 1 week ago
No previous pulmonary embolism = 0
No Hemoptysis = 0
No malignancy = 0; - no significant weight lo Total score = 7.5
Risk stratification:
High risk = > 6.0
Moderate risk = 2.0 to 6.0
Low risk = <2.0 (in patients with low risk, to further confirm the risk - pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (PERC) may be referred)
Note: There is no other alternative diagnosis which is more likely in this condition, where there is a clear clinical presentation of a deep vein thrombosis, with the associated risk factors of a recent surgery and immobilization. Hence, 3 points can be added to the score.

Solution to Question 1:
The given patient has slurred speech and a positive Babinski sign, which is suggestive of an upper motor neuron lesion (UMN lesion). Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes are a feature of UMN lesions.
The distal muscle groups are affected more than the proximal muscles and the axial muscles are spared (as the anterior corticospinal tracts supplying the axial muscles have bilateral representation) in UMN lesions. Axial muscles are involved when the lesion is severe or bilateral.
Hypertonia in the form of spasticity is seen in the upper motor neuron lesions. Fasciculations and hypotonia are features of lower motor neuron lesions.

Solution to Question 3:
Jaw jerk is brisk in pseudobulbar palsy.
Bilateral corticobulbar lesions produce pseudobulbar palsy. This condition is characterized by dysarthria, dysphagia, dysphonia, emotional lability, bilateral facial weakness, and brisk jaw jerk.
Damage to lower motor neurons of the cranial nerves in the brainstem is called bulbar palsy. Depressed jaw jerk is seen in bulbar palsy.
Pseudobulbar palsy is analogous to UMN lesions exhibiting hyperreflexia. Bulbar palsy is analogous to LMN lesions exhibiting hyporeflexia.
