Solution to Question 5:
Aspirin and other NSAIDs can be continued in a patient who is scheduled to undergo a lumbar puncture (LP). These drugs have not shown an increased risk of developing spinal hematomas. Hence an LP can be performed in patients receiving these drugs.
Options A and B: Abciximab and eptifibatide are Gp IIb/ IIIa inhibitors. Platelet aggregation remains abnormal following the discontinuation of these drugs. LP, spinal and epidural procedures must be avoided until the platelet function is normal.
Option D: Rivaroxaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor. LP should be avoided in patients receiving this drug due to the risk of developing epidural or spinal hematomas. Other factor Xa inhibitors, namely, fondaparinux and apixaban must also be held prior to LP, spinal and epidural procedures.
Solution to Question 6:
The given image shows xanthochromatic CSF on centrifugation. This is unlikely with a traumatic tap. A traumatic tap has clear supernatant following CSF centrifugation.
Xanthochromia refers to the yellowish appearance of CSF. In a lumbar puncture, a traumatic tap can be confused with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as both show blood in the drawn CSF sample. In such situations, centrifugation of the sample distinguishes the two.
Clear supernatant following CSF centrifugation supports a traumatic tap.
Xanthochromatic supernatant suggests SAH.
Xanthochromatic supernatant may be present in the following conditions:
In Liver disease, due to elevated bilirubin levels.
When CSF protein concentration is elevated.
In subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), RBCs are present in the CSF long enough for them to undergo lysis. This releases hemoglobin which is converted to bilirubin, thus staining the CSF yellow.
Solution to Question 7:
The use of a 22 gauge needle (or smaller) can reduce the incidence of post-dural headache after lumbar puncture.
Effective strategies that reduce the incidence of PDPH include:
Use of small-diameter needle (22-gauge or smaller)
Use of atraumatic needle (Sprotte and others)
Replacement of stylet prior to removal of the needle
Insertion of a needle with bevel oriented in a cephalad to caudad direction (when using a stranded needle)
Ineffective strategies:
Bed rest (up to 4h) following LP
Supplemental fluids
Minimizing the volume of spinal fluid removed
Immediate mobilization following LP
The customary practice of remaining in a recumbent position post-LP is unnecessary. Studies have shown no benefit in terms of reducing the incidence of headaches.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical features are suggestive of cerebellar ataxia, hence the lesion is most likely to be seen in the cerebellum. Cerebellar ataxia can be caused due to an acute vascular event such as infarction or hemorrhage.
Wide stepping gait, a broad-based unstable gait is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction. Few other notable gait abnormalities are:
Short stepped gait- parkinsonism
Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion
High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease
Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness A few of the cerebellar signs include:
Dysdiadokinesia / dysmetria
Ataxia
Nystagmus
Intention tremor
Speech - slurred or scanning
Hypotonia
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute paraparesis. This is caused most commonly by an intraspinal lesion. A negative Babinski reflex and flaccidity are suggestive of a lower motor neuron lesion. Hence, the most appropriate among the given investigations for acute paraparesis with LMN signs is a spinal MRI.
Spinal causes of acute onset paraparesis include:
Injury to the spinal cord
Thrombosis of anterior vertebral artery
Hematomyelia
Prolapsed intervertebral disc
Solution to Question 10:
Ruling out glycemic extremes is the first step in the evaluation of this patient who is in a coma as most of the causes of coma are metabolic in origin and with appropriate treatment are completely reversible.
In this elderly patient, with no other relevant history, the most likely cause of coma is diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state, or even hypoglycemia (which may present with hypertension).
Other options :
The patient presents with tachycardia which is not a sign of raised intracranial pressure(bradycardia, altered respiratory pattern, raised systolic blood pressure) and hence starting iv mannitol (option 3) to reduce intracranial pressure or doing a CT (option 4) to rule out intracranial space-occupying lesion is not required.
The patient is a known case of hypertension which may cause hypertensive encephalopathy due to cerebral edema and would present with a similar history and signs of raised intracranial pressure giving antihypertensive (option 2) medications would treat the condition but it is not the first step as metabolic causes are more common and have to be addressed first.
Coma is defined as a deep sleep-like state from which the patient cannot be aroused.Coma could be due to:
Metabolic and toxic encephalopathies, where brain imaging will be norma
Meningitis syndromes
Diseases with prominent focal signs like stroke, or hemorrhage
Urgent intervention is needed to prevent further brain damage. It is done by providing supplemental oxygen, intravenous thiamine (at least 100 mg), and intravenous 50% dextrose in water (25 g) empirically. It is crucial to measure baseline serum glucose levels before administering glucose.
The initial examination includes evaluating the general appearance,vitals, breath sounds, response to stimulation, pupil size and responsiveness, and any abnormal posturing or movements. In trauma cases, the neck should be stabilized until ruling out cervical spine fracture. Airway protection and intravenous access is necessary.
Immediate therapeutic intervention should be done for hypotension, significant hypertension, bradycardia, arrhythmias affecting blood pressure or marked hyperthermia. Signs of meningeal irritation or fever indicate the need for urgent lumbar puncture. Fundus examination for papilledema and a CT scan of the brain should be performed prior to lumbar puncture in comatose patients.
Solution to Question 11:
Brain injury is the most common cause of autonomic storm and typically follows severe head trauma and postresuscitation anoxic-ischemic brain injury.
An autonomic storm is an acute state of sustained sympathetic surge which can cause alterations in BP and heart rate, body temperature, respiration, and sweating.
Other causes include:
Spinal cord injury
Drugs and toxins (phenylpropanolamine, cocaine, amphetamines, and TCA's; tetanus; and less often, botulinum toxin)
Autonomic neuropathy
Chemodectomas (e.g., pheochromocytoma).
Guillain-Barré syndrome can produce a moderate autonomic storm.
Solution to Question 12:
The GCS-P score allows a minimum score of 1.
The Glasgow coma scale – pupils score (GCS-P) was described in response to the wish for a single index combining the coma scale with pupillary reactivity as a reflection of brainstem function. Its possible values range from 1 to 15, reflecting an extended range of severity, and may be particularly useful in relating to prognosis.
The GCS-P is calculated by subtracting the pupil reactivity score (PRS) from the Glasgow coma scale (GCS) total score:
GCS-P = GCS - PRS
The minimum score in GCS is 3.

The GCS score of the patient described is 8 (E3 V3 M2). In the case elaborated above, the score allotted is :
Eye-opening to speech—3
Inappropriate words—3
Extensor response of the upper limb in response to painful stimuli—2
Patients scoring a GCS of 3 or 4 have an 85% chance of dying or remaining vegetative.
However, scores >11 indicate only a 5–10% likelihood of death or vegetative state and an 85% chance of moderate disability or good recovery.

The GCS score is E2VNTM3. In this case:

In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as 'not testable/NT'. Earlier in intubated patients, the V score was denoted as VT. According to the current update, the V score should be VNT.

Solution to Question 16:
Constricted pupils would rule out brain death.
Brain death is the irreversible cessation of all cerebral function with the preservation of cardiac activity and maintenance of respiratory and somatic function by artificial means.
In brain death, the pupils are usually midsized or maybe dilated. However, constricted pupils are not seen.
The diagnosis of brain death should be confirmed with the following clinical findings:
Absent brain-originating motor response, including response to pain stimulus above the neck or other brain-originating movements (eg, seizures, decerebrate or decorticate posturing)
Unresponsiveness to any stimuli
Brainstem damage, as evidenced by dilated or mid-sized pupils without light reaction
Absent corneal, gag, and oculovestibular reflexes
Absent sucking or rooting reflexes
Absent cough with tracheal suctioning
Apnea, indicating medullary destruction
The heart rate should be invariant and does not accelerate to atropine
Solution to Question 17:
To declare brain death, apnea is confirmed if no respiratory effort has been observed in the presence of arterial pCO2 levels of 60 mmHg (apnea test is positive).
Destruction of the medulla leads to complete and irreversible apnea. Demonstration that apnea is due to medullary damage requires that the PCO2 be high enough to stimulate respiration during a test of spontaneous breathing.
An apnea test is conducted to confirm that there is no respiratory effort in the presence of a sufficiently elevated arterial PCO2. Apnea testing can be done safely by the use of preoxygenation with 100% oxygen prior to and following removal of the ventilator. CO2 tension increases
~0.3–0.4 kPa/min (2–3 mmHg/min) during apnea.
Solution to Question 18:
Clinical criteria for brain death does not include absent spinal cord reflexes. Deep tendon reflexes/spinal cord reflexes may be present in brain death as the spinal cord is intact.
Criteria for brain death:
Coma - Deep, unresponsiveness to noxious stimuli
Absence of brainstem reflexes - Pupillary, oculocephalic, corneal, gag reflex, etc.
Apnea - Absence of spontaneous respiration at arterial pCO2 tension of at least 50–60mm Hg

Solution to Question 1:
Beta waves are seen on the EEG of an adult recorded with eyes open. The frequency of these waves on an EEG is >13 Hz.
Solution to Question 2:
In a normal adult awake patient lying quietly with his eyes closed, alpha waves are predominantly seen intermixed with a variable generalized beta activity.
This alpha rhythm is attenuated when the eyes are opened.

Solution to Question 3:
Jacksonian march is a feature seen in focal seizures, not generalized epilepsy.
In Jacksonian march, the abnormal motor movements begin in a very restricted region such as the fingers and gradually progress to include a larger portion of the extremity. It represents the spread of the seizure activity over a progressively larger region of the motor cortex.

Solution to Question 4:
The given scenario is suggestive of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME). Myoclonic seizures are the predominant feature of JME and are now classified under both focal onset and generalized onset seizures.
Generalized seizures arise at some point in the brain but immediately and rapidly engage neuronal networks in both cerebral hemispheres.
Focal seizures arise from a neuronal network either discretely localized within one brain region or more broadly distributed but still within a cerebral hemisphere.
Myoclonic seizures are characterized by:
Preserved consciousness
Preserved postural contro
Lack of postictal confusion
JME is an epilepsy syndrome that has familial inheritance and begins in adolescence. It most commonly occurs in the morning and is provoked by sleep deprivation. JME is usually associated with GTCS and sometimes with absence seizures. EEG shows a typical 4-6 Hz polyspike and wave pattern. Treatment includes administration of sodium valproate.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
ILAE-International League Against Epilepsy Classification:

Solution to Question 5:
The ictal cry is seen in generalized, tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS). Jacksonian march, Todd's paralysis, and Epilepsia partialis continua are features of focal seizures.
Jacksonian march is a feature seen in focal seizures wherein the abnormal motor movements begin in a very restricted region such as the fingers and gradually progress to include a larger portion of the extremity. It represents the spread of seizure activity over a progressively larger region of the motor cortex.
Todd’s paralysis is a transient focal temporary paralysis usually persisting for a few minutes to hours (maximum up to 48 hours) in the postictal phase.
Epilepsia partialis continua refer to continued focal seizures for hours or days. It is often refractory to medical therapy.
Tonic contraction of the muscles of expiration and the larynx at the onset of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure will produce a loud moan or ictal cry.
Solution to Question 6:
The given history is most consistent with atonic seizures. Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control and there is no postictal confusion.
Options A and D: Absence seizures usually present as blank stares or unresponsiveness for a few seconds. Postural control is not lost during absence seizures.
Option C: The girl regains consciousness immediately and has no associated complaints like sweating, fatigue, or tachycardia. She also resumes her activity after the episodes. Also, there is no precipitating factor that points towards syncope. Hence it is unlikely to be syncope.
Solution to Question 7:
Sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion is seen in absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds.
EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern (as shown below). Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and seizures.

Option A: Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control.
Option B: Myoclonic seizures have preserved consciousness. They involve a sudden brief jerking movement involving the entire body or a part of it.
Option D: Generalised tonic-clonic seizures are characterized by post-ictal confusion.
Solution to Question 8:
The scenario is suggestive of post-ictal confusion which is seen in generalized tonic-clonic seizures.
It is not seen in absence seizures, atonic seizures or myoclonic seizures.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myoclonic seizures. Post-ictal paralysis is not seen in these seizures.
Myoclonic seizures are characterized by preserved consciousness (rarely very short loss of consciousness), preserved postural control, Lack of postictal confusion.
Myoclonic seizures usually coexist with other forms of generalized seizures but are the predominant feature of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME). The EEG shows bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow wave discharges.
JME or Janz's syndrome is an epilepsy syndrome that has familial inheritance and begins in adolescence. It most commonly occurs in the morning and is provoked by sleep deprivation. JME is usually associated with GTCS and sometimes with absence seizures. EEG shows a typical 4-6 Hz polyspike and wave pattern. Treatment includes administration of sodium valproate.
Solution to Question 10:
EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. This is seen in absence seizures.
Absence seizures are characterized by a sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control that lasts only a few seconds. However, there is no post-ictal confusion.
Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and also the seizures. Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures.

Solution to Question 11:
The first-line agents in the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS) are Valproate, levetiracetam, and lamotrigine.
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario describes Jacksonian march followed by Todd’s palsy. These are characteristics of a focal seizure. Among the given drugs, the first-line drug for focal seizures is
carbamazepine.
Solution to Question 13:
Levetiracetam is not the first-line agent for the treatment of typical absence seizures. First-line drugs for:
Typical absence seizures: Ethosuximide (drug of choice), valproate, and lamotrigine
Atypical absence seizures: Valproate
Solution to Question 14:
Lamotrigine is a first-line drug in the treatment of both generalized tonic-clonic and focal seizures.
Solution to Question 15:
Valproate is the drug of choice in generalized epilepsy syndrome having mixed seizures. It is particularly effective in absence, myoclonic and atonic seizures.
Valproate is usually first given alone (monotherapy) and if ineffective, another drug such as amotrigine may be added.
In generalized epilepsy, drugs such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, and oxcarbazepine can increase the number of seizures. They can also provoke new seizure types - myoclonic or absence seizures. Hence, they are avoided.
Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures and is not used for GTCS.
Solution to Question 16:
With seizures occurring for 1 hour, this patient is suffering from status epilepticus. A second dose of lorazepam can be given to control this patient's seizures if there is no response after 5 minutes of administration of the first dose.
Status epilepticus refers to continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness in the inter-ictal period. For practical purposes, it is defined as any one of the following:
Continuing seizures >5 minutes or
No regaining of consciousness between 2 seizures. Management of status epilepticus:

Solution to Question 17:
In the given clinical scenario of a girl on antiepileptics for 6 months with no further seizures, no family history, normal EEG, neurological examination, and intelligence, antiepileptics should be continued for another 18 months since she’s already taken for 6 months (minimum 2 years) to prevent seizure recurrence.
Anti-epileptic drugs withdrawal is considered only when an adult patient has been seizure-free for
2 years along with the following criteria:
Normal CNS examination including intelligence
Normal EEG and normal M˜I
Single seizure type
No family history of epilepsy.
It is preferable to reduce the dose of the drug gradually over 2–3 months. Other options:
Option A: Sudden cessation of drug therapy may cause recurrence of seizure hence not advised.
Option B: The patient has a seizure-free interval of only 6 months and therefore, is not yet eligible for considering medication withdrawal.
Option D: Life-long treatment is not necessary in this case as the patient meets all the above-mentioned criteria for drug withdrawal after 2 years.
Note: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), the most common idiopathic generalized epilepsy syndrome is known to have a high risk of seizure recurrence, and hence antiepileptics are continued lifelong in a majority of patients.
Solution to Question 18:
Weight gain, alopecia, and thrombocytopenia are the side effects of valproate use. Adverse effects of Sodium Valproate (mnemonic: VALP˜OATE)
Vomiting
Alopecia
Liver toxicity
Pancreatitis
˜ash
Obesity
Anorexia
Teratogenicity (most common: spina bifida), thrombocytopenia, tremors
Edema
The first-line agents for treating GTCS are valproate, leviteracetam, and lamotrigine.
Solution to Question 19:
Café au lait is a neurocutaneous marker seen in neurofibromatosis, not a component of West syndrome.
The triad of West syndrome is:
Infantile spasms (also called Salaam spells)
Developmental regression
Hypsarrhythmia (abnormal EEG) West syndrome is treated with:
ACTH injections
Vigabatrin if associated with tuberous sclerosis
Solution to Question 20:
The given scenario is of infantile spasms, developmental regression and the EEG showing hypsarrhythmia is suggestive of West syndrome. The drug of choice for this condition is ACTH.
West syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in infancy. It is characterized by a triad of
Infantile spasm (also called salaam spells) is a convulsive disease characterized by brief, symmetric axial muscle contraction (neck, trunk, and/or extremities).
Developmental regression
Hypsarrhythmia (Himalayan wave pattern) on EEG: Characterized by a high-voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes
Treatment of West syndrome includes:
ACTH
Vigabatrin if associated with tuberous sclerosis
Solution to Question 21:
The given image shows a Shagreen patch, which is a typical feature of tuberous
sclerosis. Vigabatrin is effective in the control of seizures in patients with tuberous sclerosis.
Tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease) is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in either the TSC1 or the TSC2 gene. The clinical features seen are as follows:
Seizures
Intellectual disability
Adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas)
Shagreen patch
Hypomelanotic macules
Periungual fibromas
˜enal angiomyolipomas
Cardiac rhabdomyomas.
A Shagreen patch is an irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin-colored plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region.
Solution to Question 22:
The given clinical scenario of focal seizure with impaired consciousness which along with hippocampal sclerosis is suggestive of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy.
The following image shows left hippocampal sclerosis:

Solution to Question 23:
Seizures of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy are not controlled with carbamazepine. The condition is refractory to anticonvulsant therapy but responds well to surgical intervention.
Solution to Question 24:
Oxcarbazepine is known to worsen myoclonic seizures and is therefore contraindicated in it.
Drugs like carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine and phenytoin can worsen the myoclonic, absence, tonic and atonic seizures and are therefore avoided.
Solution to Question 25:
EEG showing <3Hz spike and wave discharge is a characteristic feature of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in childhood. It may occur due to various reasons such as developmental anomalies, mutations, trauma, infections, etc. It is characterized by a typical triad of
Multiple seizure types
Intellectual disability
Typical <3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG
Treatment includes administration of anti-epileptic drugs such as lamotrigine and sodium valproate. It is frequently refractory to medical therapy and usually has a poor prognosis.
Note: EEG with symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern is seen in typical absence seizure.
Solution to Question 26:
Glucocerebrosidase infusions are not the treatment for Lafora's disease. There is no approved treatment for Lafora body disease.
The mainstay of management is anti-epileptic drugs, valproate in particular; however, other AEDs such as topiramate, ethosuximide, and phenobarbital can be used to control seizures. Most recently, perampanel, a new AMPA receptor antagonist AED, is shown to be effective.
Lafora body disease is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disease and has an adolescent onset. It is associated with polyglucosan intracellular inclusion bodies. It is characterized by:
Progressive myoclonus
Epileptic seizures
Dementia
Ataxia.
Diagnosis is by DNA sequencing. Death usually occurs within 10 years of the onset of the disease.
Solution to Question 27:
The given scenario is suggestive of a gelastic seizure.
This condition is also known as gelastic epilepsy, and is a rare type of seizure that involves a sudden burst of energy, usually in the form of laughing or crying. It is seen when the seizure focus is within the left prefrontal cortex. Gelastic seizures have been associated classically with hypothalamic hamartomas.
Option A: Kluver Bucy syndrome is characterized by hypersexuality, placidity, a tendency to explore the environment with the mouth, inability to recognize the emotional significance of visual stimuli, and constantly shifting attention, called hypermetamorphosis.
Option B: Witzelsucht is a tendency to joke and make puns.
Option C: Pseudobulbar affect is defined by involuntary, sudden, and frequent episodes of laughing or crying that are generally out of proportion or inappropriate to the situation.
Solution to Question 28:
The given clinical scenario reveals multiple types of seizures such as atonic seizures (sudden falls), absence seizures (blank stares and unresponsive), and generalized tonic-clonic seizures in this patient. This is a characteristic feature of Lenox-Gastaut syndrome.
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in childhood. It may occur due to various reasons such as developmental anomalies, mutations, trauma, infections, etc.
It is characterized by a typical triad of
Multiple seizure types
Intellectual disability
Typical <3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG
Treatment includes administration of anti-epileptic drugs such as lamotrigine and sodium valproate. It is frequently refractory to medical therapy and usually has a poor prognosis.

question_text:

Solution to Question 1:
A decrease in the cerebral blood flow below 20 mL/100 g/min causes reversible ischemia.
If this state is prolonged for several hours to days, it can lead to infarction. A decrease in CBF to 0 causes the death of the brain tissue within 4–10 min.
Normal cerebral blood flow (CBF) in an adult brain at rest is 50–55 mL/100 g/min.
Solution to Question 2:
This patient with mitral stenosis and acute onset weakness of the left arm is most likely to have had an embolic stroke, which is a type of ischemic stroke. Embolic strokes tend to occur suddenly with maximum neurologic deficit present at onset.
Mitral stenosis is known to cause atrial fibrillation and is a common cause of cardioembolic stroke.
Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours. This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina or cochlea. Most TIAs last for less than 1 hour to a few minutes.
There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA.
Solution to Question 3:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a transient ischemic attack. The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by the ABCD2 score.
CHADS2-VASc score is used to determine the risk of stroke in a patient with atrial fibrillation.
CURB-65 is a scoring system used to predict mortality in patients with community-acquired pneumonia.
APACHE II is a scoring system used to predict ICU mortality.
Solution to Question 4:
The given scenario along with the ECG findings are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. The risk of stroke in this condition is determined by CHA2DS2-VASC score.
The ECG show irregular QRS complexes of normal morphology and absent P waves.
Solution to Question 5:
Lacunar infarcts, also called small vessel stroke, refer to infarction following atherothrombotic or lipohyalinotic occlusion of small penetrating arteries in the brain. These penetrating arteries arise from the stem of the middle cerebral artery, circle of Willis, and basilar and vertebral arteries.
The principal risk factors are hypertension and old age. The image below shows two lacunar infarctions on a CT.

Solution to Question 6:
Crural monoplegia with urinary incontinence is not caused by a lacunar stroke. It is caused by the occlusion of A2 segment of the anterior cerebral artery. Crural monoplegia refers to a monoplegia of the lower limbs.
The types of lacunar syndromes are as follows:
Pure motor hemiparesis - infarct in the posterior limb of the internal capsule
Pure sensory stroke - infarct in the thalamus
Ataxic hemiparesis - infarct in the pons or internal capsule
Dysarthria and clumsy hand syndrome - infarction in the pons or internal capsule.

The ACA is divided into two segments:
The pre-communal (A1) circle of Willis, or stem, which connects the internal carotid artery to the anterior communicating artery
The post-communal (A2) segment distal to the anterior communicating artery

Solution to Question 7:
The given scenario where the patient is unable to perform learned skilled movements is suggestive of apraxia. The lesion is likely to be in the dominant parietal lobe as apraxia is a feature of a lesion in this area.
The features of dominant parietal lobe lesions are as follows:
Apraxia - inability to perform learned skilled movements
Acalculia - difficulty performing simple mathematical tasks
Alexia - inability to recognize or read written words or letters
Agnosia - inability to recognize and identify objects, persons, or sounds
Dysphasia - language disorder marked by deficiency in the generation of speech and its comprehension
Contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia
Gerstmann syndrome (acalculia, dysgraphia, finger agnosia, right-left confusion) Features of non-dominant parietal lobe lesions include:
Spatial disorientation
Constructional apraxia
Contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia
Contralateral hemineglect.
Solution to Question 8:
Neglect is not a feature of temporal lobe lesion. It is a feature of a non-dominant parietal lobe lesion.
Features of dominant temporal lobe lesions:
Complex hallucinations - visual, auditory or olfactory
Memory impairment
Complex partial seizures
Wernicke’s aphasia
Contralateral superior quadrantanopia Features of non-dominant temporal lobe lesions:
Poor non-verbal memory
Loss of musical skills
Complex hallucinations
Contralateral superior quadrantanopia.
Solution to Question 9:
Antisocial behavior, urinary incontinence, and impaired memory in this patient are suggestive of frontal lobe involvement.
Features of frontal lobe lesions:
Disinhibition
Lack of initiative
Antisocial behavior
Impaired memory
Incontinence
Grasp reflexes
Anosmia.
Solution to Question 10:
Paracentral lobule (PCL) is the continuation of the precentral and postcentral gyri of the superolateral surface into the medial surface of cerebral hemisphere. It controls the motor and sensory innervations of the contralateral lower extremity. It is also responsible for cortical control of micturition and defecation.
The anterior two-thirds of PCL belong to Brodmann area 4, it reflects the primary motor cortex for the muscles of contralateral leg, foot, and perineum,it is functionally important in control of bladder and anal sphincters. Therefore, it's called the cortical center of defecation and micturition.
The posterior third of the PCL contains 3,2 and 1, it reflects the primary somatosensory representation of the leg and foot.
The A2 segment of the anterior cerebral artery supplies the paracentral lobule. Lesions in the paracentral lobule lead to:
Weakness and loss of sensation in contralateral lower limb
Urinary incontinence
Fecal incontinence.
Solution to Question 11:
Lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus cause Wernicke’s or Fluent aphasia due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense (area no 22).
Broca's (Option B) or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.
Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia (Option C). This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.
Conduction aphasia (Option D) is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.
Solution to Question 12:
Prosopagnosia, also called face blindness, is the inability to recognize faces including one's own image. This occurs due to occipitotemporal lobe damage, seen in posterior cerebral artery (PCA) strokes involving cortical branch occlusion.
It is not seen in anterior cerebral artery strokes.
The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies parts of the frontal lobe, corpus callosum, paracentral lobule, and other deeper structures.
Signs and symptoms of ACA occlusion and structures involved:
Urinary incontinence, fecal incontinence
Paratonic rigidity
Abulia (Akinetic mutism), lack of spontaneity, slowness
Gait impairment
Paralysis of contralateral foot and leg
Paresis of the contralateral arm
Cortical sensory loss over the contralateral lower limb
Dyspraxia of left limbs, tactile aphasia in left limbs.
Solution to Question 13:
Hemiplegia is most commonly associated with infarction of the area of distribution of middle cerebral artery.
Middle cerebral artery supplies the motor cortex responsible for sending the output to the motor neurons. Infarction in this territory leads to hemiplegia.
Infarction of area of distribution of vertebral, anterior spinal and posterior cerebral arteries can also lead to hemiplegia.


Solution to Question 14:
Aphasia is not a feature of right middle cerebral artery infarct (MCA).
Aphasia occurs when there is damage to the dominant hemisphere, i.e., left hemisphere. The dominant hemisphere contains the language network which includes Broca’s area, Wernicke’s area, their interconnections and connections with frontal, parietal and temporal areas.
The MCA originates from the internal carotid artery. The stem of the MCA is referred to as the M1 segment. It gives rise to cortical and penetrating/lenticulostriate branches.
MCA stem occlusion leads to :
Contralateral hemiplegia
Hemianesthesia
Homonymous hemianopia
Global aphasia (dominant hemisphere)
Anosognosia, constructional apraxia, neglect (non-dominant hemisphere)
Occlusion of the lenticulostriate branches of MCA (lacunar stroke) may affect the genu of the internal capsule. This can lead to dysarthria with contralateral clumsy hand (fine motor weakness).
Solution to Question 15:
The given scenario is suggestive of homonymous right superior quadrantanopia (pie in the sky appearance) and sensory aphasia. These are seen in occlusion of the inferior division of the opposite side middle cerebral artery (MCA).
Parts of the middle cerebral artery:
The MCA originates from the internal carotid artery. The stem of the MCA is referred to as the M1 segment.
In the Sylvian fissure, the MCA divides into superior and inferior divisions. These branches are referred to as the M2 segments of the MCA.
Occlusion of the following sites and their effects are given below:
MCA stem (M1) - leads to contralateral hemiplegia, hemianesthesia and homonymous hemianopia amongst other features
Superior division of MCA (M2) on the dominant side - leads to motor aphasia (Broca's) and facio-brachial weakness
Inferior division of MCA (M2) on the dominant side - leads to sensory aphasia (Wernicke's) and contralateral superior quadrantanopia
The following image of coronal section of cerebral hemisphere shows the segments of MCA:

Solution to Question 16:
The presence of Wernicke’s aphasia without motor involvement suggests an infarct in the MCA territory of the left (dominant) hemisphere.
Wernicke’s area is located in the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere (mostly the left side). This area is supplied by the inferior division of MCA.
MCA divides into superior and inferior divisions in the Sylvian fissure. These branches are referred to as the M2 segments of MCA.
The superior division - supplies the frontal and the superior parietal cortex.
The inferior division - supplies the inferior parietal and temporal cortex.
An infarct in the territory of the inferior division of MCA in the dominant hemisphere causes Wernicke’s aphasia without weakness. As the frontal cortex (containing the motor area) is supplied by the superior division and is not affected, weakness is not observed.
An infarct in the inferior division of MCA of the non-dominant hemisphere (mostly the right side) causes hemineglect without weakness.
Solution to Question 17:
Aphasia (dominant hemisphere), constructional apraxia and neglect (non-dominant hemisphere) are seen in MCA stem occlusion. These features are absent in anterior choroidal artery occlusion.
Features common to both MCA and anterior choroidal artery occlusion include:
Contralateral hemiplegia
Hemianaesthesia
Homonymous hemianopia.
Solution to Question 18:
The given scenario is suggestive of pontine haemorrhage. Clinical features of pontine haemorrhage are:
Deep coma
Quadriparesis and multiple cranial nerve dysfunction
Decerebrate rigidity
Pin-point pupils
Hyperpnea, hyperpyrexia, severe hypertension, and hyperhidrosis
Option A: The presence of hyperpyrexia and pin-point pupils rule out the possibility of spinal cord trauma.
Option B: Morphine poisoning is a differential diagnosis for pin-point pupils. But it leads to slower respiratory rate, not tachypnea.
Option D: In ponto-medullary laceration, medullary involvement would cause respiratory depression, leading to apnea. But here tachypnea is noted.
Solution to Question 19:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient. Intravenous thrombolysis(alteplase 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period i.e., within 3-4.5 hours of symptom onset.
Aspirin + clopidogrel(Option B) is used in secondary prevention of stroke and also to prevent stroke following TIA.
Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) refer to episodes of stroke symptoms that have a brief duration, the standard definition of duration is <24 h, but most TIAs last <1 hr. TIAs may arise from emboli to the brain or from in situ thrombosis of an intracranial vessel. With a TIA, the occluded blood vessel reopens and neurologic function is restored. If a relevant brain infarction is identified on brain imaging, the clinical entity is now classified as stroke regardless of the duration of symptoms.
The risk of stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is approximately 10-15% in the first three months, majorly in the first two days. A reliable estimation of this risk can be obtained using the ABCD2 score.
Other options:
Option A: If CT is normal it only rules out hemorrhagic stroke and changes of ischemic stroke usually take time to appear on NCCT.
Option D: BP control is done when BP exceeds 220/120 mmHg, if there is malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg and thrombolytic therapy is anticipated.
Solution to Question 20:
A sustained blood pressure > 185/110 mmHg and recent myocardial infarction are contraindications for initiating thrombolysis in ischemic stroke.
Solution to Question 21:
IV thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke has been proven to be beneficial up to 4.5 hours after the onset of symptoms according to European Cooperative Acute Stroke Study (ECASS) III.
According to MoHFW (India), thrombolysis is to be carried out within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.
IV tPA should be administered to all eligible acute stroke patients within 3 hours of last known normal and to a more selective group of eligible acute stroke patients (based on ECASS III exclusion criteria) within 4.5 hours of last known normal.
Solution to Question 22:
Neglect is a feature of stroke that need not be treated. Although neglect indicates a poor prognosis, most patients recover without any treatment in 1-6 months.
Dysphagia(Option A) poses a high risk of aspiration and hence can't be left untreated. Spasticity(Option B) can be treated with baclofen, tizanidine. Untreated, it creates a psychosocial impact on the patient. Fever(Option C) is deleterious in stroke patients and must be treated.
Neglect can arise from injury to cortical-limbic-reticular network, that directs attention and integrates the localization and identification of a stimulus. Neglect is associated with poor scores and slower recovery, but severe neglect is rare beyond 6 months. Recovery is rapid in the first 2 weeks, regardless of the side of stroke. By 3 months, patients might have some residual visual neglect. The choice of an intervention depends on the mechanism of neglect, the patient can be treated for an underaroused right hemisphere which has difficulty processing sensory inputs.
Neurogenic dysphagia is an important cause of pulmonary infection in any patient with stroke, motor neuron disease, even transient dysphagia can lead to malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration pneumonia, and airway obstruction with asphyxia, it increases the risk of death and institutionalization. Early placement of nasogastric tube to feed patients after stroke has improved nutrition and reduced deaths.
Spasticity is seen in less than 20% of stroke patients. Patients with bilateral weakness from hypoxic injury are likely to have signs of spasticity. Exaggerated cutaneous and autonomic reflexes and involuntary spasms are disabling problems associated with spasticity. Physical modalities like slow stretching movements and daily passive exercises will reduce symptoms of spasticity and risk of contractures. Baclofen, tizanidine, and clonidine are used in reducing clonus and extensor spasms.
Solution to Question 23:
The presence of headache and paraparesis in this patient with a history of oral contraceptive use is suggestive of cerebral venous thrombosis.
Cerebral venous thrombosis is commonly seen in hypercoagulable states such as:
Oral contraceptive pill use
Pregnancy and puerperium
Inflammatory bowel disease
Dehydration
Intracranial infections. It presents with:
Headache (most common)
Seizures
Intracranial Hypertension
Focal neurological Deficits
Altered Mental status
MR venography is used for diagnosis.
The below image shows the empty delta sign seen on CECT or MRI with contrast in patients with sagittal sinus thrombosis.

Solution to Question 24:
IV heparin is the drug of choice in cerebral venous thrombosis. It prevents further thrombosis and reduces venous hypertension and ischemia.
Anticoagulation is often continued indefinitely if thrombophilia is diagnosed.
If there is no underlying hypercoagulable state, treatment with vitamin K antagonists (VKAs) for 3–6 months may be initiated and then converted to aspirin, depending on the degree of resolution of the venous sinus thrombus.
Treatment of CVT:
Acute treatment - IV Heparin or LMWH
Maintenance therapy:
Warfarin for at least 3 months
In pregnant women with a history of CVT - anticoagulation with LMWH throughout pregnancy and till 8 weeks postpartum.
Solution to Question 25:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Moyamoya disease and Dawson's fingers is not a finding in this condition.
Dawson fingers are a radiographic feature typically seen in multiple sclerosis (MS)
The picture below demonstrates Dawson fingers.

Moyamoya disease is an occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries. It has a bimodal age distribution and is seen in the first and fourth decades:
Childhood moyamoya is characterized by ischemic manifestations
Adult moyamoya is characterized by hemorrhagic manifestations The first symptom is a stroke or recurrent TIA.
Treatment is by surgical bypass of extracranial carotid arteries to the dura or middle cerebral artery. This may prevent stroke and haemorrhage.
The below image shows the MR angiography findings in a patient with Moyamoya disease.

Note: As this is a chronic condition, the lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion. This is seen as a 'puff of smoke' (moyamoya in Japanese) on X-ray angiography.
Solution to Question 26:
Age > 60 years is not a component of the CHADS2-VASc score. Age > 75years and age group 65-75 yrs are the two age criteria considered in the score.
The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients who have atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation therapy is given when the score is 2. Patients with a score of 1 may also be considered for anticoagulation therapy.
Anticoagulation therapy is given for all the patients of AF having mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or a history of stroke.

Solution to Question 1:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Gerstmann syndrome. It is commonly associated with damage to the left (dominant) inferior parietal lobule.
Gerstmann syndrome consists of:
Acalculia - impairment of simple arithmetic
Dysgraphia - impaired writing
Finger anomia - an inability to name individual finger
Right-left confusion - an inability to tell whether a hand, foot, or arm of the patient or examiner is on the right or left side of the body
Option B: Anton syndrome also known as visual anosognosia occurs due to bilateral infarction in the distal PCAs. It produces cortical blindness and the patients are unaware of the blindness or may even deny it.
Option C: Millard-Gubler syndrome occurs due to ventral pontine injury. It causes functional loss of the 6th and 7th cranial nerves and corticospinal tract. This presents as diplopia, ipsilateral facial palsy, ipsilateral loss of corneal reflex, contralateral hemiparesis.
Option D: Dejerine-Roussy syndrome is associated with hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected region. It is also known as thalamic pain syndrome.
Solution to Question 2:
Hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected regions is classically seen in Dejerine-Roussy syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome.
Dejerine- Roussy syndrome occurs due to occlusion of the thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches arising from the P1 segment resulting in contralateral hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected regions.
The P1 segment of the posterior cerebral artery extends from the basilar bifurcation to the junction with the posterior communicating artery.
This pain responds poorly to analgesics. Anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine or gabapentin or tricyclic antidepressants may be beneficial.
Solution to Question 3:
The given scenario is suggestive of Anton's syndrome. It occurs due to bilateral infarction in the distal posterior cerebral artery (P2 segment) and is associated with the following features:
Cortical blindness with preserved pupillary light reaction
Visual anosognosia - denial of loss of vision
Confabulation in the setting of obvious visual lo
Option D: Riddoch phenomenon is a condition where cortical blindness is associated with the perception of only moving targets.
Solution to Question 4:
The persistence of visual image even after shifting gaze is called palinopsia. It is seen in Balint’s syndrome.
Balint’s syndrome results due to low flow in the watershed areas between distal PCA and MCA territories. It is characterized by the following:
Palinopsia - persistence of a visual image despite gazing at another scene
Asimultagnosia - difficulty to focus on more than one item in the visual field
Optic ataxia - Inability to reach accurately under visual guidance
Ocular apraxia - Inability to direct gaze accurately to a new target
Claude's syndrome is a distinctive brainstem syndrome characterized by ipsilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral hemiataxia. It is due to an intrinsic or extrinsic lesion in the midbrain.
Note: While some authors use the term simultanagnosia, others use asimultanagnosia instead. A few authors also use these two terminologies interchangeably.
Solution to Question 5:
Opsoclonus is not seen in Balint's syndrome. The features of Balint’s syndrome are:
Optic ataxia - the inability to guide the arm to reach a certain object in the visual field
Simultanagnosia - the inability to perceive more than one object at a time. In other words, it i the inability to recognize multiple elements in a visual presentation, one object or some element of a scene can be appreciated but not the display as a whole.
Ocular apraxia - the inability to control voluntary purposeful eye movement
Palinopsia - the persistence of a visual image even after the stimulus has been removed
Note: While some authors use the term simultanagnosia, others use asimultanagnosia instead. A few authors also use these two terminologies interchangeably.
Solution to Question 6:
Ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiplegia is seen in Weber’s syndrome.
Weber’s syndrome occurs due to infarction in the distribution of the penetrating branches of the PCA. It affects the cerebral peduncle, especially medially, and damages III cranial nerve and the pyramidal fibers. It results in contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral oculomotor palsy.
Claude's syndrome is a distinctive brainstem syndrome characterized by ipsilateral third cranial nerve palsy with contralateral hemiataxia. This is due to an intrinsic or extrinsic lesion in the midbrain.
Solution to Question 7:
Ipsilateral paralysis of the lower face is not seen in Weber's syndrome. However, there is contralateral paralysis of the lower face.
Weber syndrome is caused by infarction in the distribution of the penetrating branches of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA). It affects the cerebral peduncle, especially medially, with damage to the fascicle of cranial nerve III and the pyramidal fibers.
The resultant clinical findings are contralateral hemiplegia of the face, arm, and leg secondary to corticospinal and corticobulbar tract involvement, and ipsilateral oculomotor paresis including a dilated pupil.

Solution to Question 8:
The presence of convergence-retraction nystagmus and loss of upgaze is seen in Parinaud's syndrome. It is caused by a lesion in the dorsal midbrain.
The following tetrad of symptoms are seen:
Loss of upgaze
Light-near dissociation
Convergence-retraction nystagmu
Lid retraction
Convergence■retraction nystagmus is irregular, jerky nystagmus in which both eyeballs rhythmically converge and retract into the orbit, particularly on attempting an upward gaze.
Nothnagel syndrome is associated with oculomotor palsy and contralateral limb ataxia. Underlying structures involved are the superior cerebellar peduncle and tectum of the midbrain.
Solution to Question 9:
Ipsilateral abducens and facial nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia are seen in Millard–Gubler syndrome.
In this syndrome, there is a ventral pontine injury (lesion in abducens fascicle) that causes lateral rectus palsy.

Lateral gaze palsy is a feature of Foville’s Syndrome which is a result of dorsal pontine injury.
Millard-Gubler syndrome occurs due to ventral pontine injury. Lateral gaze palsy does not occur in this condition because the abducens fascicle is injured rather than the nucleus.

Solution to Question 11:
Thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) causes lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome.
PICA is a branch of the fourth part of the vertebral artery, which is a branch of the first part of subclavian artery.

Solution to Question 12:
Thrombosis of the vertebral artery is most commonly implicated in Wallenberg syndrome.
Wallenberg syndrome, also called lateral medullary syndrome, is due to occlusion of the ipsilateral vertebral artery in most cases. In the remainder, posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion is responsible.
Wallenberg / lateral medullary syndrome affects the following structures:
Descending tract and nucleus of cranial nerve V - Ipsilateral impaired sensation over half of the face
IX and X cranial nerves - Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex
Nucleus of tractus solitarius - Ipsilateral loss of taste
Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
Spinocerebellar tract - Ipsilateral ataxia
Descending sympathetic tract - Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
Lateral spinothalamic tract - Contralateral impaired pain and thermal sensation over half of the body.
Solution to Question 13:
The pyramidal tracts are not affected in Wallenberg syndrome and therefore hemiplegia is not seen.
Wallenberg / lateral medullary syndrome affects the following structures:
Descending tract and nucleus of CN V - I/L impaired sensation over half of face
IX and X CN - I/L paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex
Nucleus of Tractus Solitarius – I/L loss of taste
Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
Spinocerebellar tract – I/L ataxia
Descending sympathetic tract – I/L Horner’s syndrome
Lateral spinothalamic tract – C/L impaired pain and thermal sensation over half of the body.
Solution to Question 14:
Horner’s syndrome is not a feature of medial medullary syndrome.
Medial medullary syndrome occurs due to the occlusion of the vertebral artery or a branch of the vertebral or basilar artery. The features of medial medullary syndrome are
CN XII - Ipsilateral paralysis of the tongue
Pyramidal tract - Contralateral hemiplegia
Medial lemniscus - Impaired tactile and proprioception over the contralateral half of the body
Horner’s syndrome occurs due to a lesion involving the sympathetic fibres. It is seen in lateral medullary syndrome.
Solution to Question 15:
The most common site for intracerebral hypertensive hemorrhage is the putamen.
The most common type of intracranial haemorrhage is an intraparenchymal i.e., intracerebral haemorrhage. It is most often caused by a hypertensive bleed.
Most common sites of intracerebral hypertensive bleed:
Putamen (basal ganglia)
Thalamu
Cerebellum
Pons.
Solution to Question 16:
Raised ICT is not associated with paraparesis. Manifestations of raised ICT include:
Hypertension
Bradycardia
Respiratory depression
Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy
Seizure
Paraparesis is usually caused by a spinal lesion such as thoracic myelopathy and neoplasms causing compression of the spinal cord.
Rare intracranial causes of paraparesis are:
Parasagittal meningioma
Occlusion of unpaired anterior cerebral artery
Cerebral venous thrombosis affecting the sagittal sinus.
Solution to Question 17:
Bradycardia is a component of Cushing's triad.
Cushing’s triad is characteristically seen in raised ICT. Its components are as follows:
Hypertension
Bradycardia
Respiratory depression.
Solution to Question 18:
The given scenario is suggestive of non-traumatic subarachnoid haemorrhage. The most common cause for this condition is the rupture of a berry aneurysm, also known as a saccular aneurysm.
CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.
Most unruptured intracranial aneurysms are completely asymptomatic. Prodromal symptoms occasionally suggest the site of the enlarging unruptured aneurysm. For example, cranial nerve III palsy with loss of ipsilateral light reflex and focal pain above or behind the eye suggests an expanding aneurysm at the junction of the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid
artery.
Ruptured aneurysms cause an excruciating thunderclap headache followed by a transient loss of consciousness.
Non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice for SAH. LP shows xanthochromatic CSF. Treatment involves clipping or coiling the aneurysm to eliminate the risk of rebleeding.
Solution to Question 19:
Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery will most likely compress the oculomotor
nerve. This is because the posterior communicating artery is anatomically located very close to the oculomotor nerve.
Patients with an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery can present with symptoms of oculomotor nerve palsy such as:
Unilateral ptosis (LPS)
Outward eye deviation (MR)
Dilated pupil.
The nerves controlling the pupils are located very superficially and these are always affected due to the mass effect of the aneurysm. Therefore the pupil sparing third nerve palsies are unlikely to be due to an aneurysm.
Pupil-sparing oculomotor nerve palsy is often assumed to be caused by ischemic injuries such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus.
Expanding unruptured aneurysms can occasionally lead to prodromal symptoms which suggest the location of the aneurysm.
Solution to Question 20:
The size and site of aneurysm are important in predicting the risk of rupture. Aneurysms with the following features have a greater risk of rupture:
Size >7 mm in diameter
Located at the top of the basilar artery (i.e origin of the posterior cerebral artery)
Located near the origin of the posterior communicating artery.
The most common location of Berry aneurysm is the anterior communicating artery.
Solution to Question 21:
The given image is suggestive of a subdural hematoma and it most commonly results from injury to the bridging dural veins.
Subdural hematoma refers to the haemorrhage between the dura and arachnoid mater. The image of the CT scan reveals a hyperdense crescentic lesion. Mass effect with midline displacement can also be seen.
Causes of SDH are:
Trauma
Anticoagulant
Antiplatelet
Alcohol abuse
Shaken baby syndrome.
Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice. Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhage are:
Typically unilateral
Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain
Not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflection
Chronic subdural hemorrhage: Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT
Acute subdural hemorrhage: Hyperdense collections on CT
Solution to Question 22:
The given CT image is suggestive of extradural haemorrhage (EDH). In this condition, blood accumulates between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater.
The typical presentation is an initial loss of consciousness following trauma, a complete transient recovery (lucid interval), and a rapid progression of neurological deterioration.
This condition is treated by rapid surgical evacuation and ligation or cautery of the damaged vessel.
Solution to Question 23:
In extradural hemorrhage (EDH), CT brain does not show a crescentric opacity. It shows a lentiform opacity.
Solution to Question 24:
This patient's clinical features of sudden-onset headache with neck stiffness, nausea, and vomiting with no neurological deficits is suggestive of a diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage. The presence of blood in the Sylvian fissure confirms this diagnosis.
Trauma is the most common cause. However, spontaneous sub-arachnoid bleeding occurs most often due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm. Most of them are found in the anterior circulation, mostly on the circle of Willis. The three most common locations are:
Terminal ICA
MCA bifurcation
Top of the basilar artery.
A non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice. LP shows xanthochromatic CSF. Treatment involves clipping or coiling the aneurysm to eliminate the risk of rebleeding.
Solution to Question 25:
The clinical scenario describes a 53 year old patient admitted in view of a cerebrovascular accident developing neurologic deterioration (drowsy with minimal response) on the second day, and CT brain showing significant edema of MCA territory with midline shift. The next line of management is decompressive surgery.
Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day after the stroke and can last for around 10 days.
Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the cerebellum.
Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and experience deterioration  48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy. Hypodensity on head CT within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving  one-third of the MCA territory, early midline shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours  80 mL are predictors of severe cerebral edema.
Solution to Question 26:
The scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and the treatment of choice for this condition is surgical clipping.
CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.
SAH can present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.
Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, by preventing ischemic injury.
Option A: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis. Meningitis does not show hyper-attenuated subarachnoid space.
Option B: IV Tenecteplase is used for ischemic stroke without bleeding complications.

Solution to Question 1:
Peripheral neuropathies can impair sensory, motor, or autonomic function, either singly or in combination.
Peripheral nerves are composed of sensory, motor, and autonomic elements. Peripheral neuropathies are classified into those that primarily affect the
Cell body - neuronopathy or ganglionopathy
Myelin - myelinopathy
Axon - axonopathy
Solution to Question 2:
Disorders of autonomic function (dysautonomia) is usually considered in patients with:
Unexplained orthostatic hypotension (OH)
Syncope
Sleep dysfunction
Altered sweating (hyperhidrosis or hypohidrosis)
Impotence
Constipation or other GI symptoms like bloating, nausea, vomiting of old food, diarrhea.
Bladder disorders such as urinary frequency, hesitancy, or incontinence.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario of macrocytic anemia and a vegetarian diet is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. This typically leads to large fiber neuropathy which presents with loss of proprioception and vibration.
Smaller-diameter myelinated and unmyelinated fibers transmit pain and temperature sensation. Hence, small fiber neuropathies present as temperature loss or burning or stabbing pain.
Solution to Question 4:
Sjogren’s syndrome does not cause small fiber neuropathy. It causes preferential large fiber sensory neuropathy.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario suggests symmetric proximal and distal weakness with sensory loss. This pattern is characteristic of acquired immune demyelinating polyneuropathies.
It consists of:
Acute form - Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy [AIDP] also known as Guillain-Barré syndrome [GBS]
Chronic form - Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy [CIDP]
Option B: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a multiple degenerative motor neuron disease. It leads to muscle weakness and disability in the absence of sensory symptoms and signs.
Option C: Mononeuropathy multiplex refers to multiple compressive mononeuropathies. It presents as asymmetric subacute or acute sensory and motor symptoms and signs.
Option D: Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus presents with asymmetric weakness.
Solution to Question 6:
Hereditary motor neuropathy does not present with asymmetric distal weakness without sensory loss. It presents with symmetric distal weakness without sensory loss.
Solution to Question 7:
Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy.
Other examples of rare hereditary neuropathies are Friedreich’s ataxia, familial amyloid polyneuropathy and Tangier disease.
Solution to Question 8:
In hyperthyroidism, excessive thyroxine causes sympathetic autonomic overactivity, not neuropathy.
Hypothyroidism can be associated with peripheral neuropathy, most typically carpal tunnel syndrome. Treatment is the correction of hypothyroidism.
Solution to Question 9:
The given case scenario is suggestive of burning feet syndrome, seen in HSAN 1.
There are five types of hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathies (HSAN I–V), of which the most important are HSAN I and HSAN III.
HSAN I has an autosomal dominant inheritance. It presents in adolescence or adulthood as a distal small-fiber neuropathy. It causes burning feet syndrome in which patients present with:
Burning sensation of feet, especially at night
Sensory loss
Foot ulcers.
Option B: Dejerine Roussy syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome usually occurs after a stroke. The patient experiences burning pain over affected areas of the body.
Option C: HSAN III or Riley Day syndrome presents in childhood. It presents with labile BP, decreased tearing, hyperhidrosis, reduced sensitivity to pain, and areflexia.
Option D: Charcot Marie Tooth disease is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. It is a hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN) which presents with motor weakness and skeletal deformities.
Solution to Question 10:
Distal symmetric sensory and sensorimotor polyneuropathy (DSPN) is the most common form of diabetic neuropathy and is seen in approximately one-third of patients with DM.
Other neuropathies seen in diabetes mellitus are:
The most common mononeuropathies are median neuropathy at the wrist and ulnar neuropathy at the elbow
Diabetic autonomic neuropathy is typically seen in combination with DSPN
Cranial neuropathy (third nerve palsy is the most common) and diabetic neuropathic cachexia The Michigan diabetic neuropathy score is a screening tool used to assess diabetic neuropathy.
Solution to Question 11:
Duloxetine is a selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the first-line drugs used in the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy.
Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:
First-line:
Lidoderm 5% patch
Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
Gabapentin, Pregabalin
Duloxetine
Second-line:
Carbamazepine
Phenytoin
Venlafaxine
Tramado
Third-line:
Mexiletine
Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.
Solution to Question 12:
Lead poisoning does not cause sensorimotor neuropathy. It causes symptoms and signs of primarily motor neuropathy. The most common presentation of lead poisoning is encephalopathy.
The sensation is generally preserved but the autonomic nervous system can be affected in lead poisoning.
Solution to Question 13:
Isoniazid (INH), which is a first-line anti-tuberculosis drug, inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase, resulting in pyridoxine deficiency and neuropathy. Prophylactic administration of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) 10 mg/day can prevent neuropathy from developing.
10 mg daily suffices for prophylaxis but patients with evidence of vitamin B6 deficiency may require up to 50 mg daily.
Current WHO guidelines recommend routine substitution of pyridoxine to patients who are at risk of peripheral neuropathy, e.g., malnutrition, chronic alcohol dependence, diabetics, HIV.
However, pyridoxine excess (acute intoxication or long-term use of large doses) is also found to cause peripheral neuropathy.
Solution to Question 14:
The image shows Mee’s lines, transverse white striae of the fingernails. This along with history is suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning probably due to a contaminated water source. Arsenic poisoning causes toxic sensorimotor polyneuropathy.
The neuropathy manifests 5–10 days after ingestion of arsenic and progresses for several weeks, mimicking Guillain–Barre's Syndrome.
Solution to Question 15:
The given image showing thickening of tissues in the temporal and orbital regions with coarse overlying skin suggests a diagnosis of plexiform neurofibroma.
Plexiform neurofibroma represents an uncommon variant (30%) of neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1). Plexiform neurofibromas are usually evident at birth and result from a diffuse thickening of nerve trunks and surrounding tissues that are usually located in the orbital or temporal region of the face. The skin overlying it may be coarse and associated with hyperpigmentation.
Plexiform neurofibromas may produce an overgrowth of an extremity and a deformity of the corresponding bone.
NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:
Six or more café-au-lait macules >5mm in prepubertal and >15mm in postpuberta
Axillary or inguinal freckling
Two or more iris lisch nodules
Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma
A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones with or without pseudoarthrosis.
Optic gliomas
A first-degree relative with NF-1

Solution to Question 1:
Campylobacter jejuni is one of the most common risk factors for GBS. Infections that may trigger GBS are:
Campylobacter jejuni
Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
Epstein Barr virus
Mycoplasma
Varicella zoster virus
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), dengue, or influenza, Zika, hepatitis
Less commonly vaccinations, surgical procedures, and trauma have been reported to trigger the development of GBS.
Solution to Question 2:
IgG isotype of autoantibody is involved in the pathogenesis of GBS.
IgM isotype autoantibodies are known to play a role in some types of chronic immune neuropathies.
Solution to Question 3:
Autoantibodies in GBS due to Campylobacter jejuni infection are directed most commonly against GM1 gangliosidase.
Solution to Question 4:
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common type of GBS.
There are several types of Guillain–Barre syndrome, which are recognized by electrodiagnostic studies and pathological distinctions. These include:
Demyelinating
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) - most common
Axona
Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN)
Acute motor–sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN)
Regional GBS syndromes
Miller–Fisher syndrome (MFS)
Pure sensory forms
Ophthalmoplegia with anti-GQ1b antibodies as part of severe motor-sensory GBS
GBS with severe bulbar and facial paralysis
Acute pandysautonomia
Solution to Question 5:
The acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN) subtype of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) is more common in pediatric age groups.

Solution to Question 6:
In AMAN, the complement along with IgG is deposited at the nodes of Ranvier of large motor axons.
In AIDP, complement deposits along the outer surface of the Schwann cell.
Solution to Question 7:
Bladder dysfunction is not usually severe and does not appear early in the course of Guillain-Barre Syndrome(GBS). If bladder dysfunction is a prominent feature and comes early in the course, diagnostic possibilities other than GBS should be considered.
GBS is an acute demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy. It is an autoimmune disorder triggered by infections like:
Campylobacter jejuni
Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
Epstein Barr virus
Mycoplasma
Varicella zoster virus
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), dengue, or influenza
It manifests as a rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis, with or without sensory disturbance. The usual pattern is ascending paralysis. Proximal and distal muscles are equally involved. The lower cranial nerves are frequently affected, causing bulbar weakness.
Solution to Question 8:
Loss of proprioception is severe in Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS).
GBS affects the large sensory fibers, leading to attenuation or loss of deep tendon reflexes and loss of proprioception.
Cutaneous sensory deficits (e.g., loss of pain and temperature sensation) are usually relatively mild.
Solution to Question 9:
The given scenario is suggestive of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). Protein levels are elevated

1000mg/dl) in the CSF of a patient with this condition.
The CSF cell counts are usually normal. Albuminocytologic dissociation, which is an elevation in CSF protein without an elevation in white blood cells, is characteristic in GBS.
Causes of albuminocytologic dissociation are:
Guillain-Barre Syndrome
Spinal cord tumours
Solution to Question 10:
Subclavian steal syndrome does not present with autonomic dysfunction.
Option A: Polyneuropathy is seen in sporadic and familial amyloidosis. In some cases, autonomic insufficiency presents before distal painful polyneuropathy accompanied by sensory loss
Option B: Guillain-Barré syndrome is associated with autonomic instability. This can present with BP fluctuations, arrhythmias, and GI disturbances.
Option C: Botulinum toxin binds presynaptically to cholinergic nerve terminals. After uptake into the cytoplasm, it blocks ACh release. Thus, patients with botulism present with motor paralysis and autonomic disturbances.
Solution to Question 11:
The given scenario is suggestive of Guillian-Barre syndrome (GBS). Postural hypotension is a common autonomic disturbance seen in this condition.
Autonomic involvement is common and may occur even in patients whose GBS is otherwise mild. The usual autonomic manifestations are:
Loss of vasomotor control with wide fluctuation in blood pressure, postural hypotension
Cardiac dysrhythmias
Solution to Question 12:
Weakness is not seen in the triad of Miller-Fisher syndrome (MFS).
Miller Fisher syndrome is a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome(GBS). Like Guillain-Barré syndrome, symptoms may be preceded by a viral illness. It classically presents as a triad of:
Ataxia
Areflexia
Ophthalmoplegia
The condition is usually not associated with weakness, and even if present, is very mild. It is strongly associated with antibodies to the ganglioside GQ1b.
The prognosis in Miller Fisher syndrome is usually good with recovery beginning within 2 to 4 weeks of the symptom onset, and completing by 6 months. Some individuals are left with residual deficits. Relapses are rare.
Treatment for Miller Fisher syndrome is identical to treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome: intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis and supportive care.
Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario is suggestive of Guillain-Barre syndrome(GBS) probably as a result of COVID-19. IV Immunoglobulin is the recommended initial therapy for patients with GBS.
High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) and plasmapheresis are both equally effective in GBS and can be used as the initial therapy. However, IVIg is often the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record. It is administered as five daily infusions for a total dose of 2 g/kg body weight. Glucocorticoids have not been found to be effective in GBS.
Solution to Question 14:
Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) should be suspected when GBS deteriorates >9 weeks after onset or relapses at least three times.
Onset is usually gradual over a few months or longer, but in a few cases, the initial attack is indistinguishable from that of GBS.
CIDP is distinguished from GBS by its chronic course. In other respects, this neuropathy shares many features with the common demyelinating form of GBS, including elevated CSF protein levels and the electrodiagnostic studies findings of acquired demyelination.
Solution to Question 15:
Hepatitis A infection is not associated with CIDP. Diseases associated with CIDP are:
Hepatitis B
Hepatitis C
Lymphoma
HIV
Diabetic mellitus
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
Pregnancy
Paraneoplastic syndrome
Inflammatory bowel disease
Amyloidosis

Solution to Question 19:
NSAIDs are not used in the treatment of CIDP.
The treatment of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) includes high-dose IV immunoglobulin, plasmapheresis, and glucocorticoids.
Initial therapy is usually with IV immunoglobulin. If all the first-line agents fail, immunosuppressants are attempted either alone or as an adjunctive treatment.
Solution to Question 20:
The given scenario is suggestive of multiple myeloma and the pattern of polyneuropathy seen in this condition is sensorimotor type.
Multiple myeloma-associated polyneuropathies occur in ~5% of patients with the commonly encountered type of multiple myeloma.
Myeloma with osteosclerotic features, although representing only 3% of all myelomas, is associated with polyneuropathy in one-half of cases.
Polyneuropathy generally does not reverse even with successful suppression of the myeloma.
Solution to Question 21:
Most common pattern of peripheral neuropathy in polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is mononeuritis multiplex (multifocal motor-sensory neuropathy). It is asymmetric, due to ischemic lesions of nerve trunks and roots.
Some cases present as a distal, symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy. Small- to medium-sized arteries of the vasa nervorum, particularly the epineural vessels, are affected in PAN, resulting in a widespread ischemic neuropathy.
Combination therapy with glucocorticoids and rituximab is increasingly recommended as the standard initial treatment, particularly for ANCA-associated vasculitis.
