question_text:
c
Solution to Question 1:
The sensory loss just below the circumferential level of the umbilicus corresponds to the lesion at the T10 spinal cord segment. It indicates the involvement of the cord adjacent to T7-T8 vertebral
bodies.
The spinal cord has 31 segments, but they do not always correspond to the same vertebral body.
The first seven pairs of cervical spinal nerves exit above the same-numbered vertebral bodies. All the subsequent nerves exit below the same-numbered vertebral bodies. This is because of the presence of eight cervical spinal cord segments but only seven cervical vertebrae.
The lower spinal nerves take an increasingly downward course to exit via intervertebral foramina.

Solution to Question 2:
Quadriplegia and weakness of the diaphragm (manifesting as difficulty in breathing) are associated with spinal cord lesion at the level of C1-C4 spinal segments.
Diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve arising from C3 - C5.
The uppermost level of weakness and reflex loss with lesions:
At C5-C6 : Bicep
At C7: Finger, wrist extensors, and tricep
At C8 : Finger and wrist flexion
Note: Horner’s syndrome (characterized by miosis, ptosis, and facial hypohidrosis) may accompany a cervical cord lesion at any level.
Solution to Question 3:
The Beevor’s sign localizes the spinal cord injury at T10-T12.
Beevor’s sign is the abnormal upward movement of the umbilicus on abdominal wall contraction in the supine position. This is because a lesion in the T10-T12 level of the spinal cord paralyzes the lower abdominal muscles but the upper abdominal muscles are normally resulting in the upward movement of the umbilicus.

Solution to Question 4:
Lesions at L2 – L4 spinal nerve roots do not cause paralysis of the knee flexors. The paralysis of the flexion at the knee occurs due to the lesion at L5 – S1.
Solution to Question 5:
The clinical features of the conus medullaris syndrome include:
Bilateral saddle anesthesia
Bladder and bowel dysfunction
Impotence
Absence of bulbocavernosus (S2-S4) and anal reflexes (S4-S5)
The conus medullaris is the tapered caudal termination of the spinal cord, comprising all the sacral and single coccygeal segments. Damage at this level of the cord, often occurs due to injuries to the lumbar vertebra, result in conus medullaris syndrome. Muscle strength is largely preserved in this condition.
Solution to Question 6:
Early loss of bladder control is a feature of the conus medullaris syndrome.
It is characterized by urinary retention and atonic anal sphincter, which cause overflow urinary incontinence and fecal incontinence, respectively.
Option A: In the cauda equina syndrome, there is relative sparing of bladder control. Options C and D: Bladder dysfunction is uncommon in Guillian–Barre syndrome and ALS.
Solution to Question 7:
This is a case of cauda equina syndrome (CES).
CES signifies an injury of multiple lumbosacral nerve roots within the spinal canal distal to the termination of the spinal cord at L1-L2. It is commonly due to a ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disk, lumbosacral spine fracture, hematoma within the spinal canal, compressive tumor, or other mass lesions.
Low back pain, weakness, and areflexia in the legs, saddle anesthesia, or loss of bladder function may occur.
Treatment options include surgical decompression, sometimes urgently in an attempt to restore or preserve motor or sphincter function, or radiotherapy for metastatic tumors.
Solution to Question 8:
Symmetric weakness of lower limbs helps in a diagnosis of conus medullaris syndrome. There is an asymmetric motor loss in cauda equina syndrome.
Mass lesions in the lower spinal canal often produce a mixed clinical picture with elements of both cauda equina and conus medullaris syndromes.
Solution to Question 9:
The Brown–Sequard syndrome presents with contralateral loss of pain sensation.
Lateral hemisection of the spinal cord produces the Brown–Séquard syndrome (also known as the hemicord syndrome). Knife or bullet injuries and demyelination are the most common causes
of this condition. Clinical features include:
Ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract involvement)
Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column involvement)
Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract involvement) one or two levels below the lesion
Ipsilateral segmental signs like radicular pain, muscle atrophy, or loss of a deep tendon reflex
Solution to Question 10:
Proprioception is the type of sensation lost on the same side (ipsilateral) in Brown–Sequard syndrome. This is due to a lesion of the posterior column.
The sensations of crude touch, pain and temperature are lost on the opposite side, due to the lesions of anterior column or spinothalamic tract.
Solution to Question 11:
The given scenario is suggestive of cape distribution of sensory deficit is seen in central cord syndrome.
This condition affects the cervical cord producing arm weakness > leg weakness. A dissociated sensory loss i.e. loss of pain and temperature with preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sensations is seen over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution).
It results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells and the decussating spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. These decussating fibers carry crude touch, pain, and temperature sensations.
Spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors are the main causes.

Option A: In Brown–Sequard Syndrome, ipsilateral weakness and loss of joint position and vibratory sense, with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense, one or two levels below the lesion is seen.
Option C: Anterior spinal artery syndrome is caused due to an ASA infarct. It typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion.
Option D: In foramen magnum syndrome, compressive lesions near the foramen magnum may produce weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. This is referred to as 'around the clock' pattern.
Solution to Question 12:
The MRI shows a syrinx located at C6–C7 in the cervical spine which is suggestive of syringomyelia. Suspended distribution of sensory deficit is a feature of this condition.
Syringomyelia is a developmental cavity of the cervical cord that may enlarge and produce progressive myelopathy or may remain asymptomatic.
It presents as a central cord syndrome with unilateral sensory loss in the hands initially. There is a loss of pain and temperature sensation with the sparing of touch and vibration. The sensory deficit has a distribution that is 'suspended' over the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms (cape distribution) or in the hands. Areflexic weakness is seen in the upper limbs.
Extension of the syrinx into the grey matter of the cord causes muscle wasting in the lower neck, shoulders, arms, and hands with asymmetric or absent reflexes in the arms. Extension of the syrinx into the medulla (syringobulbia) causes palatal or vocal cord paralysis, dysarthria, horizontal or vertical nystagmus, episodic dizziness or vertigo, and tongue weakness with atrophy.
Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario is suggestive of an 'around-the-clock' pattern of weakness, which is seen in foramen magnum syndrome.
Around the clock pattern of weakness is described as a sequential weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. The weakness may begin in any of the limbs.
The lesions in the foramen magnum area interrupt decussating pyramidal tract fibers destined for the legs, resulting in weakness of the legs. There is typically suboccipital pain spreading to the neck and shoulders in foramen magnum syndrome.
Solution to Question 14:
Anterior spinal artery thrombosis does not lead to loss of vibration sense. Vibration sense is carried by the posterior column.
Anterior spinal artery syndrome or anterior cord syndrome is the result of occlusion or diminished flow in the anterior spinal artery. There is bilateral tissue destruction at several contiguous levels that spares the posterior columns.
All spinal cord functions (motor, sensory, and autonomic) are lost below the level of the lesion, except vibration and position sensation.
Solution to Question 15:
The early feature of dysautonomia that can occur in this patient is spastic bladder.
Dysautonomia due to brain and spinal cord disease above the level of the lumbar spine result first in increased urinary frequency and small bladder volume. Eventually, incontinence occurs. These features are suggestive of an upper motor neuron lesion, i.e., spastic bladder.
On the other hand, dysautonomia due to peripheral nervous system (PNS) disease of autonomic nerve fibers results in large bladder volumes, increased urinary frequency, and overflow incontinence. These are features suggestive of a lower motor neuron lesion, i.e., flaccid bladder.
Postvoidal residual volume helps to distinguish between upper and lower motor neuron bladder dysfunction in the early stages of dysautonomia.
Solution to Question 16:
Syringobulbia is a condition that affects the brainstem, not the spinal cord. It is a neurological disorder characterized by a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) which affects the brainstem (medulla).
The following autonomic disorders are associated with spinal cord involvement:
Syringomyelia
Multiple sclerosis and neuromyelitis optica
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
Traumatic quadriplegia
Subacute combined degeneration
Tetanu
Stiff-person syndrome
Spinal cord tumor
Solution to Question 17:
Sacral sparing is not a feature of extramedullary tumors, it is seen in intramedullary tumors. Differences between extramedullary and intramedullary syndromes are:
Extramedullary tumors lie outside the cord and compress the spinal cord or its vascular supply. Intramedullary tumors arise within the substance of the cord.
The spinothalamic tract has a laminated configuration with the sacral fibers outermost, and hence, there is an early sacral sensory loss in extramedullary tumors.
Extramedullary
Intramedullary
Radicular pain
Poorly localized burning pain
Early sacral sensory loss
Sacral sparing
Incontinence due to the supe rficial location of the corresp onding sensory and motor fib ers in the spinothalamic and corticospinal tracts
Corticospinal tract signs appe ar later
Solution to Question 18:
Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) is due to the deficiency of vitamin B12. Pernicious anemia, partial gastrectomy, and Diphyllobothrium latum infestation can lead to this condition. High consumption of refined rice leads to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.
The most severely affected regions in SACD are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels.
Clinical features include:
Signs of both peripheral nerve and spinal cord involvement
Paresthesias in the hands or feet > Weakness and unsteadiness of gait
Loss of vibration or joint position sense in the leg
Mental slowing, depression, confusion, delusions, and hallucination
SACD is treated by a replacement regimen of intramuscular daily injections of 1000 g of vitamin B12 for the first week, followed by weekly 1000 g injections for 1 month, and monthly injections thereafter.

question_text:
a
Solution to Question 1:
Myasthenia gravis is associated with a decrease in synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction.
Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular (myoneural) junction.
Solution to Question 2:
In myasthenia gravis, damage to muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase is not a mechanism by which anti-AChR antibodies reduce the number of available AChRs at the neuromuscular junction.
The anti-AChR antibodies reduce the number of available AChRs at the neuromuscular junction using three distinct mechanisms:
Accelerated turnover of AChRs
Damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane mediated by antibodies and complement
Blockade of the active site of the AChR
Patients whose sera test negative for both AChR and MuSK antibodies possess antibodies specific to another protein at the neuromuscular junction called low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4). LRP4 plays a functional role in the clustering of AChRs.
Anti-MuSK antibodies are directed against muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSK), a protein involved in AChR clustering at the neuromuscular junction.
Solution to Question 3:
Remissions may occur spontaneously but are usually not complete or permanent. The cardinal clinical features of myasthenia gravis include:
Women are affected by myasthenia gravis more frequently than men, in a ratio of ~3:2.
Weakness and fatigability of muscles - Weakness may increase upon repeated use or later in the day. It may improve with rest or sleep.
Diplopia and ptosis - They are common initial clinical complaints. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and the extraocular muscles, are typically involved early in the course of myasthenia gravis.
Limb weakness - It is often proximal and may be asymmetric.
Deep tendon reflexes - They are preserved despite muscle weakness.
Solution to Question 4:
The given scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis (MG). Myoid cells in the thymus serve as the source of autoantigens in this condition.
The muscle-like cells within the thymus called myoid cells, express AChRs on their surface. These cells are known to serve as a source of autoantigen and trigger autoimmune reactions within the thymus gland. This stimulates the production of autoantibodies, thus causing myasthenia gravis.
The thymus is abnormal in ~75% of patients with AChR antibody-positive MG. In these cases, the thymus is hyperplastic. 10% of the patients show symptoms of thymoma.
Solution to Question 5:
Thymoma is associated with hypogammaglobulinemia, not hypergammaglobulinemia. Thymoma with hypogammaglobulinemia is also called Good’s syndrome.
The following conditions are associated with thymomas:
Myasthenia gravis (30%)
Pure red cell aplasia (5-8%)
Hypogammaglobulinemia (~5%)
Polymyositis
SLE
Thyroiditis
Sjogren's syndrome
Ulcerative colitis
Addison's disease
Pernicious anemia
Scleroderma
Panhypopituitarism
Aplastic anemia
Limbic encephalitis
Solution to Question 6:
Absent deep tendon reflex is not a feature of myasthenia gravis (MG).
MG usually occurs in young females. Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which worsens on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. Snarling expression on smiling (facial weakness), nasal timbre of speech (weakness of palate and tongue), and difficulty swallowing may be seen. Bulbar weakness and respiratory depression are seen more frequently in MuSK antibody–positive MG.
MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR. This autoimmune response against the AChR seems to be mediated by the thymus. The myoid (muscle-like) cells present in the thymus express AChRs on their surface and are postulated to provide the autoantigen which triggers this autoimmune reaction. Thymic hyperplasia is seen in 65% of the patients, and thymomas are seen in 10% of the patients.
The tests which are used to confirm the diagnosis of MG include:
Anti-AChR antibody immunoassay: 85% of myasthenic patients have detectable anti-AChR antibodies, but only 50% of patients with weakness limited to ocular muscles. The presence of anti-AChR antibodies is highly suggestive of MG, but a negative test does not exclude the disease. Antibodies to MuSK and LRP4 are found in some patients
Recurrent nerve stimulation test: MG shows a decremental response > 10%, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) shows an incremental response
Block and jitter response on single-fiber electromyography
Positive edrophonium test: improvement of ptosis on the administration of anticholinesterase such as edrophonium
Positive ice-pack test: improvement of ptosis on the application of ice-pack on the affected eye
The first line of medical management in MG is anticholinesterase drugs. Pyridostigmine 30–60 mg three to four times daily is the most commonly used drug.
Patients are evaluated for associated thymic abnormalities using a CT chest. Thymectomy is considered in patients with thymoma and in generalized MG patients with anti-AChR antibodies.
Immunotherapy therapy can be initiated in patients with poor control on pyridostigmine after thymectomy. Glucocorticoids, cyclosporine, or tacrolimus are generally effective within 1-3 months. Azathioprine and mycophenolate mofetil may take several months to show beneficial effects and are used for the long-term management of MG. Rituximab has shown effectiveness in patients with MuSK antibodies. Intravenous eculizumab, which binds to terminal complement component 5, is also effective.
Myasthenic crisis is the life-threatening exacerbation of MG leading to respiratory failure. Treatment for myasthenic crisis should take place in intensive care units. It is important to rule out excessive anticholinesterase medication as a cause of deterioration by temporarily discontinuing these drugs. Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) are beneficial
in hastening recovery.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis and ptosis is the most common ocular feature of the disease.
Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction most commonly caused by anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. The disorder is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles where the weakness increases during repeated use and may improve following rest.
Ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints due to early involvement of the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs). Of them, Ptosis is a more common manifestation than diplopia. Ptosis in myasthenia gravis is insidious, bilateral, and frequently asymmetrical.
Investigations of myasthenia gravis include:
Ice pack test -This tests for a transient improvement of the ptotic eyelid on placing an ice pack for 2 minutes, as the cold inhibits the breakdown of acetylcholine by acetylcholinesterase.
Tensilon (Edrophonium) test - This tests for a transient improvement in the weakness on administration of a short-acting anticholinesterase such as edrophonium.
Antibody testing - for Acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies, MuSK protein antibodies helps support a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.
Solution to Question 8:
The pupils are always spared in myasthenia gravis (MG), differentiating it from other disorders marked by similar ocular symptoms (e.g. botulism)
If weakness remains restricted to the extraocular muscles for 3 years, it is likely that it will not become generalized. These patients are said to have ocular MG.
Ptosis and/or diplopia are the initial symptoms of MG in up to 85% of patients. The ptosis may increase with sustained upward gaze or by holding up the opposite eyelid with the examiner's finger (curtain sign).
Cogan lid twitch is characteristic of MG. It refers to a brief overshoot twitch of the lid when the patient is made to gaze upwards after a period of downgaze.
RNS studies (repetitive nerve stimulation) and anti-AChR antibodies are often negative.
Single-fiber EMG (SFEMG) testing may be required for confirming the diagnosis in seronegative patients.
Solution to Question 9:
Dysferlin deficiency is not associated with congenital myasthenic syndrome (CMS). CMS is an uncommon cause of neuromuscular junction failure in newborns. In CMS, the immune system is unaffected.
The common syndromes associated with CMS are as follows:
Slow-channel congenital myasthenic syndrome (SCCMS)
Fast-channel congenital myasthenic syndrome (FCCMS)
Primary acetylcholine receptor deficiency
Endplate acetylcholinesterase deficiency
Solution to Question 10:
The given scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). Incremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation is a feature of this condition.
LEMS is a neuromuscular junction disorder associated with the reduced acetylcholine (Ach)
release from the presynaptic nerve terminals, despite normal ACh vesicle numbers.
Antibodies directed against the P/Q voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC) interfere with the normal calcium flux required for the release of acetylcholine.
Approximately 50% of LEMS cases are associated with malignancy, mainly small cell lung cancer
(SCLC).
Most patients with LEMS present with symptoms as slowly progressive proximal muscle weakness. In LEMS, the weakness improves for a while after exertion. Diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes help differentiate between LEMS and myasthenia gravis.
An increase in the compound muscle action potential (CAMP) amplitude >100% after exercise or with high-frequency repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) is considered to be of diagnostic significance.
Solution to Question 11:
Single-fiber electromyography has the highest sensitivity for the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. The tests used in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis are:
Testing for autoantibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR-Ab) should be performed on all patients (most specific).
If the AChR-Abs test negative, an assay for antibodies against muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSK) should be performed.
Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) simultaneously records action potentials of two muscle fibers innervated by the same motor axon. The variability in time of the second action potential relative to the first is called "jitter" and this is increased in myasthenia gravis.
Repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) is considered abnormal if there is a decremental response of
>10%.
The edrophonium ("Tensilon") test should be used for diagnosis only in those patients with obvious ptosis or ophthalmoparesis and is not confirmatory. This test is not used routinely.
Electrophysiological (RNS/SFEMG) tests are used to diagnose patients affected with seronegative myasthenia gravis.
Solution to Question 12:
Pyridostigmine is the first-line drug of choice in the treatment of symptomatic myasthenia gravis. Treatment for myasthenia gravis involves:
Symptomatic treatment: Anticholinesterase agents – Pyridostigmine is the initial therapy of choice.
Chronic immunomodulating therapy: Glucocorticoids (prednisone) and immunosuppressive drugs (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine) implemented in patients significantly symptomatic on pyridostigmine.
Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange—Used to tide over severe illness (myasthenic crisis) and as 'bridge' therapy before surgery, or starting chronic mmunomodulating treatment.
Surgical approach: Thymectomy
Solution to Question 13:
Thymectomy is indicated in most AChR-Ab positive patients with generalized myasthenia gravis
Thymectomy is recommended for all patients aged <60 years with non-thymomatous, acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibody-associated generalized myasthenia gravis.
Significant improvement in symptoms is expected within one year after thymectomy. It is indicated in all patients with thymoma if resection is feasible, regardless of the subtype of myasthenia gravis.
Solution to Question 14:
Daptomycin can be safely administered to treat the patient's MRSA infection. This is because it is not known to unmask or worsen the symptoms of myasthenia gravis.
Drugs that may unmask or worsen myasthenia gravis include:
Anesthetic agents: Neuromuscular-blocking agents
Antibiotics:
Aminoglycosides (eg., gentamicin, neomycin, tobramycin)
Clindamycin
Fluoroquinolones (eg., ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, norfloxacin)
Ketolides (eg., telithromycin)
Vancomycin
Cardiovascular drugs:
Beta-blockers (eg., atenolol, labetalol, metoprolol, propranolol)
Procainamide
Quinidine
Other drugs:
Botulinum toxin
Chloroquine
Hydroxychloroquine
Magnesium
Penicillamine
Quinine
Solution to Question 15:
Patients with myasthenia gravis are resistant to neuromuscular blockade with
depolarizing NMBAs (e.g., succinylcholine), possibly because they have a decreased number of acetylcholine receptors.
Local anesthetics and inhalation anesthetics are usually well-tolerated in myasthenia gravis with occasional exacerbations.
Solution to Question 16:
Pyridostigmine is an anticholinesterase agent that does not alter the disease process of myasthenia gravis.
Anticholinesterase agents improve muscle contractions by allowing released acetylcholine to accumulate and act on the receptors over a large area and also have the additional direct depolarizing effect on the motor endplate.
They do not alter the disease process but provide symptomatic relief. The underlying disease process continues and ultimately it may not be possible to restore muscle strength with anticholinesterase agents alone. It is due to the reduction of the receptors by the antibodies.
Drugs like prednisone, mycophenolate mofetil, and azathioprine are immunosuppressive agents that reduce the antibody titers and can modify the disease process.

question_text:
b
Solution to Question 1:
Demyelinating disorders do not include biochemical abnormalities of myelin. Disorders occuring due to biochemical abnormalities of myelin are called dysmyelinating disorders.
Multiple sclerosis is the most common immune-mediated, inflammatory demyelinating disorder. It commonly presents in adulthood.
Solution to Question 2:
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system. It is characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (scarring), and neuronal loss.
The peripheral nervous system is spared in MS.
The course of the disease may be relapsing-remitting or progressive. The clinical course of manifestation can be variable ranging from a benign condition to a rapidly evolving and incapacitating disease.
Solution to Question 3:
HLA-DRB1 is a risk factor for the development of multiple sclerosis, not HLA-B27. Risk factors supporting the course of development of multiple sclerosis include:
Cigarette smoking
Vitamin D deficiency
Family history, HLA-DRB1
Exposure to Epstein-Barr virus (Human Herpesvirus 4) after early childhood
Solution to Question 4:
In multiple sclerosis, the slowing of conduction is due to the loss of the myelin sheath.
Under normal circumstances, nerve conduction in myelinated axons occurs in a saltatory manner
i.e from one node of Ranvier to another. But, when demyelination sets in, the nerve impulse are unable to travel as fast due to not being saltatory. This produces either a conduction block or delay.
Lesions due to multiple sclerosis begin with perivenular cuffing by inflammatory mononuclear cells. Myelin-specific autoantibodies cause degeneration of myelin sheaths. As lesions evolve, prominent astrocytic proliferation (gliosis) is observed.
Demyelination is the hallmark in the pathology of multiple sclerosis. But, it is not solely a disease affecting the myelin sheath. Partial or total axonal destruction (neuronal loss) can also occur.
Solution to Question 5:
The autoantibodies in multiple sclerosis are directed against both myelin basic protein (MBP) and myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG).
Solution to Question 6:
Remyelination of axons in the central nervous system leads to the formation of shadow plaques.
Shadow plaques develop due to the partial remyelination of the naked axons by surviving oligodendrocytes or those that differentiate from precursor cells.
Solution to Question 7:
An electric shock-like sensation radiating down the back into the legs is called Lhermitte's sign. It is associated with multiple sclerosis.
It is induced typically by flexion or other movements of the neck. Lhermitte’s sign can also occur simultaneously with other disorders of the cervical spinal cord like cervical spondylosis.
Option A: Uhthoff ’s phenomenon refers to the unilateral visual blurring that may occur during a hot shower or with physical exercise. It is an exacerbation of the symptoms of multiple sclerosis due to heat.
Option C: Stransky's sign is a clinical sign in which vigorous abduction followed by the sudden release of the little toe causes an extensor plantar reflex. It is seen in pyramidal tract lesions.
Option D: Cornell's sign is a clinical sign in which scratching along the inner side of the extensor hallucis longus tendon elicits an extensor plantar reflex. It is seen in pyramidal tract lesions.
Solution to Question 8:
The MRI image shows Dawson's fingers.
Dawson's fingers are demyelinating plaques through the corpus callosum, arranged at right angles along medullary veins (callososeptal location). They are a characteristic feature of multiple sclerosis and presents as T2 hyperintensities.
MRI is the imaging of choice in a patient with multiple sclerosis due to its high sensitivity.
Option A: Black hole lesions are multiple sclerosis plaques indicative of the chronic stage when they display T1 hypointense signals. They signify axonal destruction and irreversible damage.
Option B: The molar tooth sign refers to the appearance of the midbrain in an axial section in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles gives the midbrain the appearance of a molar or wisdom tooth. It is seen in Joubert syndrome.
Option C: Tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome.
Solution to Question 9:
The given scenario and the MRI finding of Dawson's fingers are suggestive of multiple sclerosis. Revised McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. It takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves the assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.
The Kurtzke expanded disability status scale (EDSS) and functional status (FS) score are widely used measures of neurologic impairment, which are performed following the confirmed diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.
Solution to Question 10:
The Expanded disability status scale (EDSS) gives a measure of neurological impairment in multiple sclerosis.
EDSS scores <3.5: The patient walks normally, shows no disability
EDSS scores >5.5: Progressive disease, gait impairment, and occupational disability EDSS scores =10.0: Death due to multiple sclerosis
Solution to Question 11:
Glucocorticoids are used in the clinical management of either first attacks or acute exacerbations.
Intravenous methylprednisolone administration at a dose of 500–1000 mg/day for 3-5 days, followed by a course of oral prednisolone beginning at a dose of 60–80 mg/day and gradually tapered over 2 weeks is given.
These medications reduce the severity and shorten the duration of attacks. Disease-modifying therapies for relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis are:
IFN--1a
IFN--1b
Glatiramer acetate
Natalizumab
Fingolimod
Dimethyl fumarate
Teriflunomide
Mitoxantrone
Alemtuzumab
Solution to Question 12:
Marburg’s variant is an acute form of multiple sclerosis, typically with no remissions.
It is a fulminant demyelinating process that in some cases progresses, leading to death within 1–2 years. Marburg’s variant does not seem to be associated with infection or vaccination.
Clinical management by high-dose glucocorticoids, plasma exchange, and cyclophosphamide have been tried, with uncertain benefit.
Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario is suggestive of neuromyelitis optica, which is also known as Devic's disease.
It is an aggressive inflammatory demyelinating disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of optic neuritis and myelitis. Attacks of Optic neuritis can be bilateral or unilateral and myelitis can be severe and involve three or more contiguous vertebral segments.
Core clinical characteristics are:
Optic neuritis
Acute myelitis
Area postrema syndrome: episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting
Acute brainstem syndrome
Symptomatic narcolepsy or acute diencephalic clinical syndrome with NMOSD*-typica diencephalic MRI lesions
Symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMOSD*-typical brain lesions
Option A: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is a demyelinating condition most frequently associated with an antecedent infection
Option C: Riddoch syndrome is the ability to consciously perceive the stimulus in a blind field. It is seen when there is a lesion in the occipital lobe.
Option D: Acute fulminant multiple sclerosis is an acute episode of multiple sclerosis, known as Marburg’s variant
*NMOSD stands for neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder.
Solution to Question 14:
Acute attacks of neuromyelitis optica are managed by high-dose glucocorticoids or plasma exchange.
Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses include:
Mycophenolate mofeti
Rituximab
Glucocorticoids + azathioprine
Solution to Question 15:
Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is associated with measles infection, measles vaccination, rubella infection, and rubella vaccination.
ADEM is a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that typically presents as
a monophasic disorder associated with multifocal neurological symptoms and encephalopathy. It may be :
Post-infectious (95%) - associated infections are with varicella, measles, rubella, mumps, influenza, EBV, HHV-6, HIV, other viruses, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
Post-vaccination (5%) - presently it is most often associated with measles (most common), mumps, and rubella vaccination.
Solution to Question 16:
Seizures are common in ADEM.
ADEM results from a cross-reactive immune response to the infectious agent (most commonly measles virus) or vaccine which then triggers an inflammatory demyelinating response.
Autoantibodies to MBP and to other myelin antigens have been detected in the CSF of some patients with ADEM.
In ADEM due to chickenpox, cerebellar involvement is often conspicuous. Initial treatment is with high-dose glucocorticoids.
Solution to Question 17:
Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease.
It is a rare, X-linked recessive disorder characterized by central nervous system dysmyelination.
The proteolipid protein gene (PLP1) is affected, leading to the failure of axon myelination by oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system.
Clinical Features:
Nystagmus
Developmental delay
Psychomotor delay
Seizure
Stridor
Feeding difficulties
Ataxia
Hypotonia progressing to spasticity.
The degree of dysmyelination is correlated with the severity of the clinical manifestations.
Genetic analysis can confirm the diagnosis. MRI shows a lack of myelination and MR spectroscopy reveals aberrant N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) and choline concentrations that reflect axonal and myelination abnormalities.
Unlike other demyelinating leukodystrophies such as metachromatic leukodystrophy and adrenoleukodystrophy, where myelin is formed but subsequently destroyed, PMD shows a failure of myelin formation.

Tension-type headache is a chronic head-pain syndrome characterized by bilateral, tight,

Solution to Question 5:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of cluster headache. Patients with cluster headaches are more often smokers with a higher than average alcohol consumption.
Cluster headache causes severe, unilateral periorbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. Occasionally features of Horner's syndrome may be seen. The pain, though severe, is characteristically brief (30–90 minutes). There are 1-8 attacks/day lasting for 15min-3 hours.
Solution to Question 6:
Repetitive brief, unilateral, stabbing headaches associated with lacrimation and rhinorrhea suggest a diagnosis of cluster headaches. Indomethacin is not used for the prophylaxis of these headaches.
The drug of choice used in the prophylaxis of cluster headaches is verapamil. Steroids and lithium can also be used.
Solution to Question 7:

The most common negative visual aura is scotoma.
The classic migraine is associated with an aura. The aura can be:
Visual (most common):
Zigzag lines
Tunnel vision
Scotoma
Transient visual loss
Sensory:
Tingling sensation of hands, which spreads proximally
Solution to Question 8:
Multiple unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea, vomiting and photophobia suggests a diagnosis of migraine. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) is a vasoactive neuropeptide associated with this condition. It is present at vascular terminations of the trigeminal nerve and within the trigeminal nucleus.
CGRP antagonists approved for migraine prevention are:
Erenumab
Fremanezumab
Galcanezumab
Eptinezumab

Note:
The FDA has recently approved Atogepant, a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in adults. The recommended dosage is 10 mg, 30 mg, or 60 mg orally once daily. In severe renal impairment or end-stage renal disease it is 10 mg once daily.

Solution to Question 10:
The most efficacious triptans for moderate to severe acute migraines are rizatriptan and eletriptan.
Oral dosage forms of triptans are the most convenient to use. Still, they may not be practical in patients experiencing migraine-associated nausea and vomiting, for whom injectable and nasal
spray formulations are helpful.
Standard treatment comprises a 6-mg subcutaneous dose of sumatriptan. All triptans have similar pharmacologic properties but vary slightly in terms of clinical efficacy. Rizatriptan and eletriptan are the most efficacious of the triptans currently available.
Solution to Question 11:
Sumatriptan is used in the treatment of an acute attack of migraine not in prophylaxis. It can be given by oral, subcutaneous, intravenous or intranasal routes.
Drugs used in the prophylaxis of migraine:
Beta-blockers- propranolol
Calcium channel blocker- flunarizine (verapamil, nimodipine has no role)
Antidepressants- amitriptyline, venlafaxine (SSRIs like fluoxetine are not used)
Anticonvulsants- valproate, topiramate

Solution to Question 12:
Taking ergot alkaloids in the past one week is not a contraindication for sumatriptan. However, they shouldn't be given together as doing so could result in excessive blood vessel narrowing.
Ergots constrict arteries and triptans narrow normal heart arteries by up to 20%. For this reason, ergots should not be taken with triptans on the same day.
Sumatriptan is a 5HT1B/1D receptor agonist used in an acute migraine attack. It is contraindicated in the following conditions:
Cerebrovascular disease
Coronary artery disease
Option B- Sumatriptan is the safest triptan in pregnancy, but its use is recommended only if the benefits outweigh the risks, and if all first line options do not provide relief.

Solution to Question 15:
Nummular headache is not a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia. It is characterized by small circumscribed areas of continuous pain on the head.
Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia is characterized by pain along the distribution of trigeminal nerve (unilateral) and cranial autonomic symptoms. This is due to increased parasympathetic flow and decreased sympathetic flow.
Solution to Question 16:
The cutaneous trigger is not seen in cluster headache. It is seen in short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT).
Solution to Question 17:
Paroxysmal hemicrania could be the likely diagnosis since it responds to indomethacin.
It is characterized by frequent unilateral, severe, short-lasting, and frequent episodes of headache. They have marked autonomic features ipsilateral to the pain.
Indomethacin (25–75 mg t.i.d) can completely suppress attacks of paroxysmal hemicrania. It is also effective in:
Hemicrania continuum
Primary sexual / exercise headache
Tension-type headache
Solution to Question 18:
Short attacks of stabbing pain are common to both SUNCT and trigeminal neuralgia.
SUNCT has autonomic symptoms such as lacrimation, nasal congestion, conjunctival injection, and salivation. Trigeminal neuralgia does not have autonomic symptoms.
Solution to Question 19:
Trigeminal neuralgia is associated with superficial pain and not deep-seated pain.
It is more common (~ 60% of cases) in females (Option A) over 50 years and is characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain. This most commonly involves the second and/or third divisions (Option B) of the trigeminal nerve territory. Bilateral or early-onset pain is associated with multiple sclerosis. Unilateral trigeminal nerve compression can be due to the superior cerebellar artery.
Pain is repetitive, severe, and brief and can be triggered by touch, cold, wind, or eating. Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux). No signs of sensory loss are present (Option D)
The drug of choice is carbamazepine.
Note: It is important to note that trigeminal neuralgia and trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia (TAC) are different entities. TAC is a group of primary headaches that include - cluster headaches, paroxysmal hemicrania, short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)/short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic symptoms (SUNA), and hemicrania continua.

Cerebral venous thrombosis
Hypertensive crisis

Solution to Question 1:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain at the level of superior colliculus is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, also known as paralysis agitans.
Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease, there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.
Bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.
Other options:
Option B: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is not due to damage to the substantia nigra.
Option C: Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is due to atrophy of the entorhinal cortex, located in the medial temporal lobe.
Option D: Huntington’s chorea is an autosomal dominant disorder of movement and cognition primarily involving the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen).

Solution to Question 2:
The most common form of monogenic familial PD is PARK8, caused by mutations in the leucine-rich repeat kinase-2 (LRRK2) gene.
Familial forms of parkinsonism (designated PARK1 through PARK13) have been associated with causative mutations in a number of nuclear genes. A few of these are:
The LRRK2 gene mutation causes autosomal dominant PD (PARK8). In this condition, Middle to late-onset PD is seen, which resembles typical PD and is responsive to levodopa.
Mutations in alpha-synuclein (PARK 1 and PARK4) cause rare forms of familial PD and constitute the major component of Lewy bodies in sporadic PD.
Parkin-associated PD (PARK 2) & PINK1-associated PD (PARK6) are autosomal recessive seen in young-onset PD.
Mutation in the glucocerebrosidase gene (GBA) gene of Gauchers represents the most important risk factor for the development of Parkinson's disease. Patients with PD who are GBA mutation carriers have a younger age at onset.
Solution to Question 3:
Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes are not a feature of Parkinson's disease. Cardinal motor features in PD include:
Resting tremors
Bradykinesia
Rigidity
Gait disturbance / postural instability
Mnemonic: TRAP - Tremors + Rigidity + Akinesia + Postural instability
Other motor features include:
Micrographia
Masked facies (hypomimia)
Reduced eye blinking
Soft voice (hypophonia)
Dysphagia
Non-motor features are:
Anosmia
Sensory disturbance (pain)
Mood Disorders (depression)
Sleep disturbances (rapid eye movement behavior disorder)
Autonomic:
GI disturbances
Genitourinary disturbances
Sexual dysfunction
Orthostatic hypotension
Cognitive impairment
Parkinson’s disease(PD) is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder after Alzheimer's disease. UK Brain Bank criteria is used for the diagnosis of PD.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease and Lewy bodies seen in Parkinson's disease do not contain tau protein. They contain the protein -synuclein.
Pathologic hallmarks of Parkinson's disease include:
Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc)
Reduced striatal dopamine
Intracytoplasmic proteinaceous inclusions called Lewy bodies, which contain the protein
-synuclein
Solution to Question 5:
The frequency of resting tremors in Parkinson’s disease is 4–6 Hz.
More than 70 percent of patients with Parkinson's disease have tremors as the presenting feature. The classic parkinsonian tremor begins as a low-frequency, pill-rolling motion of the fingers, progressing to forearm pronation/supination and elbow flexion/extension. Other features of the tremors are:
Typically asymmetric
Occurs at rest
Becomes less prominent with voluntary movement
Frequency of various types of tremors: Physiological tremor (12 Hz ) > Essential tremor (8–10 Hz) > Resting tremor in PD (4–6 Hz ).

Mood disorders:

Anxiety - second most common psychiatric disturbance
Abulia/apathy
Sleep disorders - insomnia, daytime sleepiness with sleep attacks, restless leg syndrome
Autonomic dysfunction

Benztropine is a centrally acting anticholinergic. It has been used for controlling tremors in drug-induced Parkinson's. Side effects include urinary dysfunction, glaucoma, and cognitive impairment.

Solution to Question 13:
The clinical features of the patient are suggestive of a severe 'off' episode. The rescue agent for the treatment of severe 'off' episodes is apomorphine.
Levodopa-induced motor complications consist of fluctuations in motor response ('on' episodes when the drug is working and 'off' episodes when parkinsonian features return) and involuntary movements are known as dyskinesias which typically complicate 'on' periods.
Apomorphine is a non-ergot dopamine agonist. It has efficacy comparable to levodopa, but it must be administered parenterally (intravenous or subcutaneous) and has a very short half-life and
duration of activity (45 min).
Solution to Question 14:
Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor known to have some disease-modifying action in Parkinson's disease. Studies have shown that selegiline significantly delayed the time until the emergence of disability necessitating the introduction of levodopa in untreated PD patients.
MAO-B inhibitors include:
Selegiline
Rasagiline (more potent)
Cheese effect: inhibition of MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of tyramine in the gut, leading to a potentially fatal hypertensive reaction called the 'cheese effect'. It can be precipitated by tyramine-rich foods such as cheese, aged meat, and red wine.
Selegiline and rasagiline do not functionally inhibit MAO-A isoform and are not associated with cheese effect in doses typically used in clinical practice.

Solution to Question 16:
Levodopa-induced motor complications are more likely to occur in females.
The complications include transient, stereotypic, rhythmic movements that predominantly involve the lower extremities. It is seen in younger individuals with severe disease and also with higher doses of levodopa.
Solution to Question 17:
The given scenario is suggestive of compulsive shopping. Pathological gambling, hypersexuality, and compulsive eating and shopping are the adverse effects of dopamine agonists. Levodopa can also cause these effects, but to a lesser extent than dopamine agonists.

The target site for deep brain stimulation in Parkinson’s disease is the subthalamic nucleus (STN)
and globus pallidus internus (GPi).
It helps improve tremors and reduce both 'off' time and dyskinesia. It does not improve features that fail to respond to levodopa. It does not prevent the development or progression of
non-dopaminergic features such as freezing, falling, and dementia.
Solution to Question 19:
Progressive supranuclear palsy is an example of Parkinson's plus syndrome.
Parkinson's plus syndrome or atypical parkinsonism refers to a group of conditions that present with parkinsonism (rigidity and bradykinesia) but are different from PD due to underlying differences in clinical manifestations and pathology. They may have degeneration of the striatum, globus pallidus, cerebellum, and brainstem as well as the SNc. These include multiple system atrophy (MSA), progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), and corticobasal syndrome (CBS).
PSP is often misdiagnosed as Parkinson’s disease (PD). The substantia nigra is damaged in both diseases and this accounts for the overlapping symptoms which are observed. In PSP, impairment of cognitive functions occurs before the motor or ocular signs and this serves as an important distinguishing feature.
Immunohistochemistry broadly classifies them into two subtypes: synucleopathies and tauopathies.
Solution to Question 20:
Early speech and gait impairment are seen in atypical parkinsonism. Features of atypical parkinsonism include:
Early speech and gait impairment
Absence of rest tremor
No motor asymmetry
Poor or no response to levodopa
Aggressive clinical course
Symptoms of severe early autonomic involvement
Early severe dementia also points towards atypical parkinsonism
Solution to Question 21:
Parkinsonism, cerebellar features, and the 'hot cross bun' sign on MRI suggest multiple system atrophy (MSA).
MSA manifests as a combination of parkinsonian, cerebellar, and autonomic features. Based on predominant clinical features it is further divided into :
MSA-P:
Predominantly parkinsonian features are seen
T2 weighted MRI demonstrates hyperintense putaminal rim
MSA-C:
Predominantly cerebellar features are seen
MRI shows cerebellar and brainstem atrophy causing pontine hot cross bun sign
Solution to Question 22:
Orthostatic hypotension is not a core clinical feature of Lewy body dementia (LBD) as per DSM-5.
LBD also known as dementia with Lewy bodies is the second most type of progressive dementia after Alzheimer’s disease. Protein deposits, called Lewy bodies, deposit in nerve cells in the brain region involved in thinking, memory, and movement (motor control)
Core features of LBD as per DSM-5 are fluctuating cognition, attention, alertness, recurrent visual hallucination, and Parkinsonian symptoms. Suggestive features are REM sleep behavior disorder and severe neuroleptic sensitivity.
Orthostatic hypotension, erectile dysfunction, and constipation are other features of LBD.
Treatment of LBD includes rivastigmine and donepezil which may improve cognition, and reduce hallucinosis and delusion. Pimavanserin may be used to treat psychosis.
Solution to Question 23:
An elderly male with a history of features of Parkinsonism nonresponsive to levodopa should raise suspicion for Parkinson plus syndromes which include progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP).
Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), also known as the Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome, is a tauopathy and is considered a neurodegenerative disease with no current efficacious treatment. It is characterized by decreased cognition, abnormal eye movements (supranuclear vertical gaze palsy), postural instability and falls, as well as parkinsonian features and speech disturbances.
The atrophy of the midbrain results in hummingbird sign of the brainstem (in the sagittal plane). The preserved pons form the body of the bird, and the atrophic midbrain, the head, with beak extending anteriorly towards the optic chiasm. Midbrain atrophy is best confirmed with the reduction in the midbrain to pons ratio.
Mickey mouse appearance, which is the reduction of anteroposterior midline midbrain diameter, at the level of the superior colliculi is seen on axial imaging.
The following image shows the hummingbird sign:

According to a recent imaging study data, the insula and frontal cortex seem to be involved in the development of anxiety in adults with Parkinson's disease.
Solution to Question 24:
Rapid, semi-purposeful, graceful, dance-like, involuntary movements are seen in chorea.
Sydenham's chorea (also called St. Vitus's dance) is a type of chorea that is typically seen in childhood (5-15 years) with prior exposure to group A streptococcal infection and is thought to be autoimmune in nature. It is characterized by the acute onset of choreiform movements and behavioral disturbances and is self-limiting.

Solution to Question 25:
Unilateral wild, flinging movements are called hemiballismus and is seen due to a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus. The most common cause of hemiballismus is stroke.
Solution to Question 26:
The most common acute drug-induced movement disorder is dystonia.
Drug-induced movement disorders are primarily associated with drugs that block dopamine receptors(neuroleptics) or central dopaminergic transmission. Neuroleptics are the commonest cause of this condition. Drug-induced movement disorders are classified as:
Acute: Dystonia is the most common acute hyperkinetic drug reaction; generalized in children, focal in adults.
Subacute: Akathisia is the commonest reaction in this category
Tardive syndromes: Develop after months to years of initiation of the drug.
Tardive dyskinesia is the most common. Choreiform movements affecting the mouth, lips, and tongue are seen. In severe cases, trunks, limbs, and respiratory muscles may also be affected.
In one third, TD remits within 3 months of stopping the drug and improvement occur over several years.
Solution to Question 27:
The most common movement disorder is essential tremor.
It can present in childhood but dramatically increases in prevalence over the age of 70 years. Essential tremor is characterized by a high-frequency tremor 6-10 Hz that predominantly affects the upper extremities.
The tremor is characteristically improved by alcohol and worsened by stress.

Beta-blockers: propranolol, atenolo

In severe and drug-resistant cases, surgical treatment involves targeting the ventral intermediate
(VIM) nucleus of the thalamus.

Solution to Question 30:
Westphal akinetic variant has the worst prognosis.
Huntington's disease shows an autosomal dominant inheritance. It is a trinucleotide repeat expansion disease with multiple CAG repeats (>40 repeats) in the coding region of the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4p. It demonstrates genetic anticipation with earlier onset if inherited from the father.
It presents in the second to third decade of life with cognitive impairment as an early feature. The dominant cognitive feature of HD is executive dysfunction. Additionally, dementia is seen later as the disease progresses.
Decreased acetylcholine leads to dementia. Decreased GABA and increased dopamine lead to chorea. Treatment consists of haloperidol, tetrabenazine (Dopamine depletor).
The following image shows MRI showing dilated ventricles (ex vacuo ventriculomegaly)- due to atrophy of caudate and putamen:

MRI showing atrophy of caudate and putamen

Solution to Question 31:
Sydenham's chorea was originally called St. Vitus's dance.
Sydenham's chorea is more common in females. It is typically seen in childhood (5-1 5 years) with prior exposure to group A streptococcal infection and is thought to be autoimmune in nature.
It is characterized by the acute onset of choreiform movements and behavioral disturbances.
It is self limited.Treatment is generally restricted to those with severe chorea.The chorea generally responds to dopamine-blocking agents, valproic acid, and carbamazepine.
Solution to Question 32:
In restless leg syndrome (RLS), symptoms begin or worsen with rest. It is also called as Willis-Ekbom disease.
The four core symptoms required for the diagnosis of RLS are:
An urge to move the legs
Usually caused or accompanied by an unpleasant sensation in the legs (creepy-crawly feeling, paresthesia, or burning)
Symptoms that begin or worsen with rest and partial or complete relief by movement
Worsening during the evening or night
Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during rest periods, especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated
with burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. In idiopathic cases, dopaminergic
hypofunction is postulated.
In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.
FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome:
Gabapentin
Ropinirole
Pramipexole
Rotigotine
A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.
Non-pharmacological treatments that can be used in restless leg syndrome are:
Avoiding alcohol at bedtime
Massaging affected legs
Hot baths
Applying hot or cold to the affected area
Engaging in moderate exercises

b
Solution to Question 1:
Lower motor neuron lesions are associated with fasciculations.
Solution to Question 2:
Bulbar paralysis refers to LMN palsy of cranial nerves 9 to 12. It is seen due to disease processes affecting primarily the motor nuclei of the cranial nerves.
The manifestations of bulbar palsy include paralysis of tongue, muscles of swallowing, and facial muscles. There is difficulty handling secretions and maintaining an airway.
Causes of bulbar palsy include:
GBS
Polio
Syringobulbia
Solution to Question 3:
Primary lateral sclerosis is a progressive isolated upper motor neuron disorder. The spectrum of motor neuron disease includes:
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS):
It is the most common form of motor neuron disease
Includes upper and lower motor neuron pathology (UMN +LMN)
Primary lateral sclerosis:
It is a progressive isolated upper motor neuron disorder (UMN)
Some patients develop lower motor neuron signs later in their clinical course, at which point the disease is called upper motor neuron-onset ALS
Progressive muscular atrophy:
It is a progressive isolated lower motor neuron disorder (LMN)
Some patients develop upper motor neuron signs later in their clinical course, at which point the disease is called lower motor neuron-onset ALS
Progressive bulbar palsy:
It is a progressive upper and lower motor neuron (UMN +LMN) disorder of cranial muscles
This condition may occasionally stay isolated to the bulbar segment, but more commonly, upper and lower motor neuron signs and symptoms spread to involve other segments. This is then referred to as bulbar-onset ALS
Solution to Question 4:
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) involves the anterior horn cells and corticospinal tract. ALS is the most common form of progressive motor neuron disease.
The pathologic hallmark of motor neuron degenerative disorders is the death of lower motor neurons and upper, or corticospinal, motor neurons. LMN consist of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and their brainstem homologs innervating bulbar muscles. UMN originate in layer five of the motor cortex and descend via the pyramidal tract to synapse with lower motor neurons, either directly or indirectly via interneurons.
Although at its onset, ALS may cause selective loss of function of only upper or lower motor neurons, it ultimately causes progressive loss of both categories of motor neurons.
Solution to Question 5:
The most likely diagnosis is amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
The clinical hallmark of ALS is the presence of signs and symptoms of both upper and lower motor neuron (UMN + LMN) dysfunction. The signs of UMN dysfunction include spasticity and brisk jaw jerk, while the signs of LMN dysfunction include atrophy and weakness of limbs.
Conventional MRI is usually normal in ALS and is used to exclude other possible causes although increased signal in the corticospinal tracts on T2-weighted MRI is supportive of the diagnosis of ALS.
Solution to Question 6:
The given scenario with both UMN (positive Babinski sign) and LMN (absent reflexes and wasting of muscles) signs are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). It is also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, after the famous New York Yankee baseball player who was affected with the disorder.
ALS was first described by Charcot in the 19th century and is also referred to as Charcot's disease.
Option A: Kennedy disease is a gradually progressive neuromuscular disorder characterised by wasting of proximal and bulbar muscles. It is caused by a mutation in the androgen receptor gene.
Option C: Pelizaeus–Merzbacher disease is an inherited leukodystrophy characterized by problems with coordination, motor skills, and learning.
Option D: Charcot-Marie-tooth disease encompasses a group of hereditary sensory and motor neuropathies.
Solution to Question 7:
The given scenario is suggestive of familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. This condition is linked to mutations of the gene encoding copper-zinc (Cu, Zn) superoxide dismutase type 1
(SOD1). Familial ALS accounts for about 10% of all ALS cases.
Option B: Mutations in the NADPH oxidase genes cause chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). Option C: Hereditary deficiency of myeloperoxidase (MPO) predisposes to immune deficiency. Option D: Glutathione peroxidase deficiency leads to hemolytic anemia.
Solution to Question 8:
Orthostatic hypotension is not a feature seen in classical ALS. Autonomic symptoms are not classically seen in ALS, although a few cases with autonomic insufficiency have been reported and these are classified separately as ALS-plus syndromes.
Option A: The split-hand syndrome describes a frequent pattern of weakness and atrophy in ALS that predominantly involves the median and ulnar-innervated lateral (thenar) hand intrinsic muscles with relative sparing of the medial (hypothenar) muscles.
Option C: There is a well-established link between ALS and frontotemporal executive dysfunction
(dementia) that may precede or follow the onset of upper and/or lower motor neuron dysfunction
Option D: Dropped head syndrome is an important clinical sign in ALS caused by severe neck extensor weakness (LMN), which leads to an inability to maintain level head position.
Solution to Question 9:
The patient with bowel and bladder dysfunction is unlikely to have ALS as these findings are not seen in ALS. Even in the late stages of the ALS, sensory & bowel & bladder functions are preserved.
Fasciculations, muscle cramps, weakness, atrophy, and bulbar palsy are LMN features seen in ALS.
Spasticity, increased reflexes, flexor spasms, and pseudobulbar palsy are UMN features in ALS.
A frequent bulbar UMN symptom seen in ALS is the pseudobulbar affect. This is manifested as inappropriate laughing, crying, or yawning. The observed affect is often mood incongruent or may be triggered by stimuli that would not have elicited such a response prior to the development of pseudobulbar affect.
Solution to Question 10:
The diagnosis of ALS is based on clinical criteria that include the presence of upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron signs, the progression of the disease, and the absence of an alternative explanation.
There is no single diagnostic test that can confirm or entirely exclude the diagnosis of motor neuron disease in general and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) in particular.
The revised El Escorial criteria and, more recently, the newer Awaji criteria are being used for the diagnosis of ALS.
Practically, the diagnosis is made when it is suggested by the history and physical examination, supported by electrodiagnostic studies (EMG & NCS), and not excluded by neuroimaging (MRI) and laboratory studies (CSF, blood, and urine analysis). Increased signal in the corticospinal tracts on T2-weighted MRI, if seen, is supportive of the diagnosis of ALS
Muscle biopsy is not a routine part of the diagnostic evaluation of ALS but should be performed if there is clinical suspicion of inflammatory myopathy.
Genetic testing is not a routine part of the diagnostic evaluation in ALS except in cases where familial ALS (10%) is suspected.
Solution to Question 11:
Among the given options, riluzole is the only known drug to have any impact on survival in ALS. It can slow ALS progression to a modest degree. It is a neuroprotective drug that blocks glutamatergic neurotransmission in the CNS.
Edaravone is a newer drug that is a free radical scavenger. It is thought to reduce oxidative stress, which has been implicated in the pathogenesis of ALS. Edaravone was found to slow functional deterioration in some patients with ALS. It is recommended as an adjunct to riluzole for all patients with ALS.

Solution to Question 1:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the involvement of the posterior column.
Posterior column carries proprioception which is essential for coordination of motor movements. Loss of this leads to the development of a stomping gait. This is seen in cases of vitamin B12 deficiency leading to subacute combined degeneration, tabes dorsalis or diabetic neuropathy.
Solution to Question 2:
Intention tremor is a feature of cerebellar ataxia, not resting tremor. Cerebellar ataxia is characterized by the following symptoms:
Gait impairment
Unclear speech or scanning speech
Blurred vision due to nystagmus
Dysdiadochokinesis
Intention tremors - tremor on goal-oriented movements
Bilateral and symmetric involvement suggests the following etiologies:
Genetic - SCA gene mutations
Metabolic - Vitamin B1 or B12 deficiency
Immune - Antigliadin antibody syndrome
Toxic - Phenytoin, amiodarone, alcoho
Focal, unilateral symptoms with headache, impaired level of consciousness, ipsilateral cranial nerve palsies and contralateral weakness suggest a space-occupying cerebellar lesion.
Solution to Question 3:
The given case scenario is suggestive of paraneoplastic cerebellar ataxia, which is most likely to be caused by small cell lung cancer here.
Paraneoplastic syndromes causing cerebellar ataxia are associated with various antibodies:
Sometimes, paraneoplastic ataxias may be the only presenting symptom of the underlying cancer. In paraneoplastic cerebellar ataxias, serum anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) antibodies may be elevated, affecting speech and gait.
Cancer
Antibody seen
Breast and ovarian cancer s
Anti-Yo antibody
Small-cell lung cancer

Hodgkin's disease
Anti-Tr antibodies
Solution to Question 4:
Friedreich's ataxia is the most common form of inherited ataxia (autosomal recessive), comprising one-half of all hereditary ataxias.
Friedrich's ataxia has autosomal recessive inheritance and presents before 25 years of age. The median age of death is 35 years. Women have a significantly better prognosis than men.
Friedrich's ataxia presents with clinical features such as dysarthria, progressive staggering gait, frequent falls and titubation. Other neurological symptoms include nystagmus, loss of fast
saccadic movements, loss of vibratory and proprioceptive sensation, and ataxia or trunk and limb movements. The lower extremities are more severely involved than the upper ones.
Cardiac involvement occurs in 90% of patients. It presents with cardiomegaly, symmetric hypertrophy, and conduction defects. Musculoskeletal deformities are common and include progressive scoliosis, pes cavus, and pes equinovarus.
Solution to Question 5:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Friedrich's ataxia, in which the dorsal root ganglion cells are involved first.
The primary sites of pathology are the spinal cord, dorsal root ganglion cells, and the peripheral nerves.
Spinal cord tracts are involved, and degeneration occurs predominantly in the spinocerebellar tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and posterior columns. Degeneration of cranial nerves (glossopharyngeal, vagus, hypoglossal) and deep cerebellar nuclei can occur. Peripheral nerves are also involved, and there's a loss of large myelinated fibers. Cerebellar atrophy is also seen.
Cardiac changes occur due to myocyte hypertrophy, fibrosis, and degeneration of cardiac ganglia. Note: Friedrich's ataxia may also be associated with vitamin E deficiency.
Solution to Question 6:
The given case scenario and smear showing macroovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils, is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency. Myopathy is not a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency.
Vitamin B12 deficiency may produce the following neurological manifestations:
Loss of vibration sense and proprioception
Paresthesia - upper limb paresthesias occur before lower limbs are affected.
Unsteady gait - due to sensory ataxia
Peripheral neuropathy
Optic neuropathy
Psychiatric manifestations such as:
Irritated behavior
Severe dementia
Frank psychosis
Solution to Question 7:
The given case scenario is suggestive of subacute combined degeneration (SACD) due to vitamin B12 deficiency.
SACD presents with the following features:
Loss of vibration sense and proprioception
Paresthesia - upper limb paresthesias occur before lower limbs are affected.
Unsteady gait - due to sensory ataxia
Loss of deep tendon reflexes
Peripheral neuropathy
Optic neuropathy - can present as blurring of vision
Psychiatric manifestations such as:
Irritated behavior
Severe dementia
Frank psychosis
MRI spine shows myelopathy and areas of demyelination. Myelopathy of SACD tends to be diffuse rather than focal.
Treatment is replacement therapy is with 1000 g of intramuscular vitamin B12 repeated at regular intervals or by oral vitamin B12.
Solution to Question 8:
The given case scenario is suggestive of tabes dorsalis. It presents with loss of reflexes in lower limbs, not hyperreflexia.
Tabes dorsalis (or syphilitic myelopathy) is a slow degeneration and demyelination of the neural tracts. It is seen in tertiary syphilis. It primarily involves the dorsal columns of the spinal cord and dorsal roots.
It presents with the following clinical features:
Loss of reflexes in lower limbs
Romberg's sign
Bilateral Argyll Robertson pupils - accommodation reflex present, pupillary reflex absent
Loss of position sense and vibration
Stabbing/pricking pain in the legs - this is fleeting or repetitive
Ataxia of the legs and gait disturbances
Paresthesias
Bladder disturbances
Acute abdominal pain with vomiting - visceral crisis Note: Diabetic polyradiculopathy may simulate tabes.
Solution to Question 9:
Ataxia-telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive condition presenting in the first decade of life.
It is associated with a high incidence of recurrent pulmonary infections, lymphomas, Hodgkin's disease, breast cancer, and acute T cell leukemias.
Histology shows loss of Purkinje cells, granules, and basket cells in the cerebellar cortex. There is a loss of neurons in the deep cerebellar nuclei, inferior olives of the medulla, and anterior horn and dorsal root of the spinal cord.
Clinical features of ataxia-telangiectasia include:
Progressive telangiectatic lesions
Oculomotor apraxia
Truncal and limb ataxia
Dysarthria
Extensor plantar reflexes
Myoclonic jerks
Areflexia
Distal sensory deficits
Nystagmus
Cellular and humoral immunodeficiency (absent/ill-developed thymus)
Solution to Question 10:
The given case scenario describes an elderly woman with urinary incontinence, dementia (cognitive decline), and a history of multiple falls (suggestive of a gait abnormality or ataxia). These form the classical triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).
Both frontotemporal dementia (Option B) and Parkinson’s disease (Option C) are common causes of dementia associated with falls, but urinary incontinence is not commonly appreciated. NPH is, therefore, the most likely diagnosis.
Normal pressure hydrocephalus refers to a disproportionate enlargement of the ventricles compared to the degree of cortical atrophy. It is a communicating hydrocephalus caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Out of the classical triad of symptoms, most patients present with one or two. Hence, neuroimaging showing dilated ventricles is essential, as well as an L- dopa challenge test to rule out parkinson’s disease is recommended.

Solution to Question 1:
The cranial nerves III, IV, V, and VI are affected by cavernous sinus syndrome.
The cavernous sinus syndrome is a condition caused by any pathology involving the cavernous sinus. The oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV) and trigeminal (V) nerves pass in relation to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. The abducent (VI) nerve passes through the cavernous sinus.
Patients with this condition usually present with the following features:
Orbital or facial pain
Orbital swelling and chemosis due to occlusion of the ophthalmic veins
Fever
Oculomotor neuropathy (III, IV, and VI)
Trigeminal neuropathy (V)
Causes of cavernous sinus syndrome include:
Cavernous sinus thrombosis - most common
Carotid artery aneurysm
Carotid-cavernous fistula
Tumors such as meningioma.

Solution to Question 2:
Tic douloureux is another term for trigeminal neuralgia.
Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by frequent paroxysms of severe pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin. It is sometimes seen in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.
Middle-aged and elderly females are primarily affected. The pain usually lasts for a short time
(seconds to minutes) but be may intense enough that the patient winces, hence the term 'tic'.
A characteristic feature is the presence of trigger zones, typically on the face, lips, or tongue. Patients usually report excruciating pain during activities such as washing the face or brushing the teeth. However, no signs of sensory loss can be demonstrated.
Solution to Question 3:
The high frequency of trigeminal neuralgia in patients with multiple sclerosis occurs due to the involvement of oligodendrocyte-derived myelin covering the beginning of the nerve.
Multiple sclerosis is a disorder of oligodendrocyte myelin. It should be ruled out when trigeminal neuralgia is bilateral or develops in a young adult. In such cases, the cause is a demyelinating plaque near the root entry zone of the fifth cranial nerve in the pons. In these patients, a facial sensory loss is also often found in association.
Solution to Question 4:
The superior cerebellar artery most often compresses the trigeminal nerve as it emerges from the brainstem. This causes lancinating pain in the distribution of the nerve which is known
as trigeminal neuralgia.
Though trigeminal neuralgia can be diagnosed by the clinical features, MRI is recommended to define the underlying cause. In cases refractory to medical management, it also helps to plan for surgical decompression.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia and the drug of choice is carbamazepine.
Oxcarbazepine is an alternative to carbamazepine that has less bone marrow toxicity and is equally efficacious.
Other drugs used are lamotrigine, gabapentin and baclofen.
Solution to Question 6:
Maximal weakness occurs within 48 hours as a rule in Bells' palsy.
Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion of the facial nerve.
Clinical presentation of Bell’s palsy:
Pain behind the ear (may precede paralysis and last for 1-2 days)
Bell's phenomenon
Asymmetrical face
Hyperacusis (due to stapedial paralysis)
Loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani).
MRI may reveal swelling and uniform enhancement of the geniculate ganglion and facial nerve.
Approximately 80% of patients recover within a few weeks or months. The presence of incomplete paralysis in the first week is the most favorable prognostic sign. Recurrence may be seen in some cases.
Solution to Question 7:
Herpes simplex virus is most commonly implicated in causing Bell’s palsy. Varicella-zoster virus is the second most common cause.
Solution to Question 8:
Bell’s phenomenon refers to a normal phenomenon that becomes evident in facial paralysis. The eyeballs roll up and outwards on attempting to close the eyes.
It is also known as the palpebral oculogyric reflex. It is a normal protective reflex resulting in the elevation of globes while blinking to protect the eyes from injury. It also serves to provide a wiper blade-like cleansing function of the cornea by the eyelid.
However, it occurs behind the closed eyelids in healthy individuals. It becomes noticeable in Bell's palsy as the eyelids fail to close completely.
The image below shows a patient with evident Bell’s phenomenon.

Solution to Question 9:
Acyclovir may be considered as add-on therapy for patients with severe Bell's palsy as 400mg five times daily for 10 days. Monotherapy is not recommended.
Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. Randomized trials found no added benefit of the antiviral agents valacyclovir and acyclovir when compared to glucocorticoids alone.
The use of paper tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep prevents corneal drying.
For patients with permanent paralysis, cosmetic surgical procedures have been used to restore a relatively symmetric appearance to the face.
Solution to Question 10:
The features are suggestive of lower motor neuron (LMN) type of facial palsy.
In the image, the absence of wrinkling over the right side of the forehead and incomplete closure of the right eyelid is characteristic of LMN type of facial palsy.
In upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, the upper part of the face is spared due to bilateral UMN innervation.

Solution to Question 11:
Patient 1 has left UMN facial nerve palsy and patient 2 has right LMN facial nerve palsy.
In an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, wrinkling on the forehead and eyelid closure remains intact. In this lesion, the contralateral side of the face is affected. The first-order neurons from
the left cerebral hemisphere cross over (left to right) at the cortical level and relay in
the right facial nerve nucleus in the pons. From here the second-order neurons (right facial nerve) descend and supply the right side of the face.
Hence, a left UMN lesion causes paralysis of the lower half of the face on the right side. In facial palsy, the angle of the mouth deviates towards the normal side. In this patient, since the mouth deviates towards the left, the right facial nerve is affected.
In lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions, there is an absence of wrinkling on the forehead and incomplete closure of the eyelid on the ipsilateral side of the face.
