Solution to Question 14:
Facial synkinesis occurs due to anomalous regeneration of facial nerve fibers.
Following facial nerve injury , the recovering nerve fibers may aberrantly regenerate and supply other muscles. This results in involuntary muscular movements in the face during voluntary facial movements.
Some examples include:
Retraction of the mouth on closure of the eyelids:
Seen when fibers originally connected with the orbicularis oculi aberrantly innervate the orbicularis oris
'Crocodile tears' also known as Bogorad syndrome:
It refers to anomalous tearing occurring with activity of the facial muscles, such as eating.
Due to aberrant innervation of the lacrimal gland.
Note: Frey's syndrome is an aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and the great auricular nerve, resulting in gustatory sweating.
Solution to Question 15:
Hemifacial spasms are painless irregular contractions occurring on one side of the face.
They commonly occur as sequelae to Bell's palsy. It can also be seen in irritative lesions of the facial nerve such as acoustic neuroma and basilar aneurysm.
Treatment is with carbamazepine or gabapentin. In resistant cases, baclofen may be tried. Local injection of botulinum toxin and surgical decompression are alternative options.
Solution to Question 16:
Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome is a rare disease characterised by the following triad:
Recurrent facial nerve palsy
Facial edema (particularly labial)
Plication of tongue or fissured tongue

Facial paralysis along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna is seen
in Ramsay-Hunt syndrome. It occurs due to herpes zoster infection and is also called herpes zoster oticus.
Congenital facial weakness combined with abnormal ocular abduction is seen in Moebius syndrome. Patients may present with bilateral concurrent facial nerve paralysis.
Solution to Question 17:
The clinical features are suggestive of glossopharyngeal neuralgia which is associated with cardiac symptoms such as bradycardia, asystole, hypotension, and fainting.
It involves the glossopharyngeal (IX) and sometimes portions of the vagus (X) nerve. The condition resembles trigeminal neuralgia but is less common. There is no demonstrable sensory or motor deficit.
It can result from vascular compression, multiple sclerosis or tumors.
The drug of choice is carbamazepine. If unsuccessful, surgical procedures are indicated:
Microvascular decompression (if vascular compression is evident)
Rhizotomy of glossopharyngeal and vagal fibers in the jugular bulb

Solution to Question 1:
The clinical features are suggestive of neonatal meningitis and Escherichia coli is the most common cause of this condition.
The causes of neonatal meningitis in decreasing order of frequency are:
Escherichia coli
Group B Streptococci
Listeria monocytogenes
Empirical treatment of neonatal meningitis is with ampicillin + 3rd generation cephalosporins.
Solution to Question 2:
The most common cause of meningitis in patients aged 2-50 years is Streptococcus pneumoniae. The common causes of meningitis in this age group include:
Streptococcus pneumoniae

Solution to Question 3:
The clinical features are suggestive of acute bacterial meningitis. This condition is most likely caused by Staphylococcus aureus in a patient with an Ommaya reservoir.
An Ommaya reservoir is an intraventricular catheter system used for the delivery of drugs into the cerebrospinal fluid. S. aureus and coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) are important causes of meningitis that occurs following invasive neuro-surgical procedures, or as a complication of the use of Ommaya reservoirs. S aureus is a more common cause than CoNS.
Solution to Question 4:
The sign being elicited here is Kernig's sign and this along with the given clinical features are suggestive of acute bacterial meningitis. Empirical treatment with cefepime, vancomycin and ampicillin is recommended for patients on immunomodulatory drugs as they are at risk for Listeria infection.
Risk factors for Listeria meningitis include:
Age>50
Diabetes
Chronic illness
Malignancy
Immunosuppressive therapy
Solution to Question 5:
The clinical features are suggestive of meningococcal meningitis and the drug of choice is a third-generation cephalosporin such as ceftriaxone. Chloramphenicol is used in patients with penicillin allergy.
It is caused by Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative, oxidase-positive, catalase-positive diplococci. Outbreaks usually occur in mass gatherings such as in army camps or hostel dorms.
The risk of infection is increased in patients with terminal complement deficiency, hypogammaglobulinemia and hyposplenism. This is because opsonization by complement is a major mechanism by which the bacteria is cleared from the blood.
Characteristic clinical findings include:
Maculopapular or purpuric rash
Shock due to capillary leak
Bilateral adrenal hemorrhage (Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome) Rifampicin, ciprofloxacin and cephalosporins can be used to treat carriers.
Solution to Question 6:
Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime is the drug of choice for empirical treatment of meningococcal meningitis. However, Penicillin G remains the antibiotic of choice for susceptible strains.
Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated in patients with suspected bacterial meningitis before the results of CSF Gram stain and culture are known.
S. pneumoniae and N. meningitidis are the most common etiologic organisms of community-acquired bacterial meningitis. Due to the emergence of penicillin-resistant and cephalosporin-resistant S. pneumoniae, empirical therapy of community-acquired suspected bacterial meningitis should include a combination of:
Dexamethasone
Third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or cefepime)
Vancomycin
Acyclovir - HSV encephalitis is the main differential
Doxycycline - during tick season.
Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime provides better coverage for susceptible S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae and group B streptococci and good coverage for N. meningitidis. Cefepime is a broad-spectrum fourth-generation cephalosporin with activity similar to that of cefotaxime or ceftriaxone against S. pneumoniae and N. meningitidis with additional greater activity against Enterobacter species and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Solution to Question 7:
Ciprofloxacin is used for chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis for close contacts. Ceftriaxone and rifampicin are also used.
Antibiotic chemoprophylaxis among close contacts of a patient with invasive meningococcal disease is recommended to prevent secondary cases.
Rifampin - was earlier used widely, but is not optimal due to the high risk of adverse events, emerging resistance, and the need for compliance for four doses.
Ciprofloxacin - widely used as a single oral dose, but it cannot be given in pregnancy and those elow 18 years of age.
Ceftriaxone - can be given in pregnancy and all ages as a single IM or IV dose. However, reduced susceptibility of isolates to ceftriaxone has occasionally been reported.

Solution to Question 8:
The features and imaging findings are suggestive of tuberculous meningitis. CSF analysis would likely show lymphocytosis, low glucose and high protein.
If the CSF is allowed to stand, a 'spider’s web clot' or 'cobweb' coagulam may form due to the high level of protein.
Solution to Question 9:
The given symptoms cluster of fever, vomiting, and neck stiffness is suggestive of meningitis. A CSF analysis showing increased opening pressure, lymphocytic pleocytosis, mildly increased protein, and normal glucose is suggestive of viral meningitis. Among the given options, Coxsackie (Option D) is the only viral cause of meningitis.
Other options:
Option A: Tuberculous meningitis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis with low glucose. Option B: Bacterial meningitis shows neutrophilic pleocytosis with low glucose.
Option C: Fungal meningitis shows lymphocytic/neutrophilic pleocytosis with low glucose.
Solution to Question 10:
The clinical hallmark of HSV encephalitis has been the acute onset of fever and focal neurologic symptoms and signs, especially in the temporal lobe.
Investigation of choice includes HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR.
The image below is a coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes.

Solution to Question 11:
The clinical features are suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis and the CSF analysis would likely show 100 RBC/microliter. HSV encephalitis is associated with hemorrhagic necrosis of inferomedial temporal and frontal lobe resulting in significant number of RBCs in the CSF.
It is caused by both HSV 1 and HSV 2. Patients present with fever, headache, seizures, personality, and behavioral changes.
CSF analysis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, moderately elevated protein levels and normal glucose concentration. EEG shows periodic lateralized spike-wave discharges.
The drug of choice for the condition is acyclovir.
Solution to Question 12:
The clinical features and EEG point towards a diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-•akob disease (C•D). The EEG shows periodic biphasic or triphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes.
C•D is a spongiform encephalopathy caused by a prion. It presents as rapidly progressive dementia and is fatal within 1 year of onset of symptoms.
Patients present with myoclonus, akinetic mutism, cerebellar or visual disturbances and pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction (hypokinesia). Insomnia, apathy and other behavioral abnormalities may be seen.
Four types of Creutzfeldt-•akob disease have been described:
Sporadic (sC•D): Accounts for 85-˜0% of cases
MRI shows cortical ribbon sign
Variant (vC•D): mad cow disease, Kuru
MRI shows hockey stick sign
Familial (fC•D): 10% of cases (these individuals carry a PRPc mutation)
Iatrogenic
CSF analysis shows a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. Management is mainly supportive.
Note: Hepatic encephalopathy will show a triphasic wave pattern (negative-positive-negative wave). They are also seen in Hashimoto encephalopathy and CO2 narcosis.

Solution to Question 1:
Hemolytic anemia is not a hypoproliferative anemia.
Anemia can be defined as hemoglobin of < 13 g/dl in men and < 12 g/dl in women. Based on the mechanism of reduction of hemoglobin, anemia can be classified as:
Hypoproliferative anemias - due to impaired production of RBCs
Hemolytic anemias and hemoglobinopathies - due to increased destruction of RBCs
Anemia due to blood loss
Hypoproliferative anemias are characterized by an abnormally low reticulocyte response (reticulocyte index <2–2.5) to reduced RBC production. They include:
Iron-deficiency anemia
Anemia of chronic disease (inflammation, renal disease, or malignancies)
Thalassemia
Sideroblastic anemia
Aplastic anemia
Megaloblastic macrocytic anemias (folate and vitamin B12 deficiency)
Non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemias (alcohol use)
Solution to Question 2:
The corrected reticulocyte count (CRC) of this patient is 3. CRC = Reticulocyte % x (Actual Hb / Normal Hb) Plugging in the values given in the question,
CRC = 9% x 5/15 = 3%
Alternatively, CRC can be calculated using hematocrit (PCV) as follows: CRC = Reticulocyte % x (Actual PCV / Normal PCV)
For these calculations, take normal Hb as 15g/dL and normal PCV as 45%.
The patient's hemoglobin level (5 g/dL) is significantly lower than the normal hemoglobin level (15 g/dL). To obtain an accurate assessment of reticulocyte production relative to the reduced number of circulating red blood cells, a correction factor has to be applied. CRC accounts for the anemia and provides a more precise estimate of the reticulocyte count.
When polychromatophilic macrocytes (prematurely released reticulocytes/shift cells) are observed in the peripheral blood smear, a second correction is applied to account for the longer life of reticulocytes to yield reticulocyte production index (RPI).
In the classification of anemia, the patient's reticulocyte count is compared to the expected reticulocyte response. Reticulocytes can be identified by staining their ribosomal RNA with a supravital dye, resulting in the formation of blue or black punctate spots. They can be quantified manually or by using fluorescent dyes. The presence of reticulocytes indicates active red cell production.
The premature release of reticulocytes is typically associated with increased EPO stimulation. In hemolytic anemia, red cell production can increase six to seven times. If the RPI < 2 in a patient with anemia, a defect in erythroid marrow proliferation or maturation has to be suspected.
Solution to Question 3:
Red cell distribution width (RDW) measures the range of red blood cell volumes and provides an assessment of their variability (anisocytosis).
The normal range of RDW is 11-14%. In the presence of uneven cell size (anisocytosis), the RDW increases to 15-18%.
RDW has clinical utility in two main scenarios:
In cases of microcytic anemia (low MCV), it helps differentiate between iron deficiency and thalassemia. Thalassemia is characterized by uniformly small red blood cells with a normal RDW, while iron deficiency leads to greater size variability and an increased RDW.
A high RDW can indicate dimorphic anemia caused by chronic atrophic gastritis. Vitamin B12 malabsorption results in macrocytic anemia and blood loss leads to iron deficiency (microcytic anemia).
Solution to Question 4:
The black arrows in the given image denote target cells or codocytes. They are RBCs with a dense center (hyperchromic bull's eye) surrounded by an area of pallor. They are not a feature of renal disease (Patient D).
Target cells are seen in the following conditions:
Thalassemia
Iron deficiency anemia
Liver disease
Post-splenectomy
Hemoglobin C disease
As artifacts in improperly prepared slides
Solution to Question 5:
The small, dense RBCs with absent central pallor seen in the given peripheral smear are called spherocytes. They appear due to decreased membrane surface area and are seen in the following conditions:
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Hereditary spherocytosis
Clostridial sepsis
Snake bites
Solution to Question 6:
The given peripheral smear shows teardrop cells or dacrocytes. They are not seen in sideroblastic anemia.
Teardrop cells are seen in the following conditions:
Myelofibrosis
Myelodysplastic syndromes
Hemolytic anemia
Thalassemia
Severe iron deficiency
Solution to Question 7:
The given image shows Howell-Jolly bodies. They are remnants of RBC nuclei that occur in conditions with either defective production (dysplasia) or destruction of RBCs. They are observed in the following conditions:
Sickle cell disease (postsplenectomy)
Hyposplenism
Megaloblastic anemia
Dyshematopoesis
Hemolytic anemia
Thalassemia presents with microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, and target cells.
Lead poisoning presents with basophilic stippling or punctate basophilia on peripheral smears. These are RNA fragments seen as numerous basophilic granules dispersed in the cytoplasm of RBCs, as shown below.

Solution to Question 8:
Iron absorption takes place in the duodenum. In sleeve gastrectomy, a portion of the stomach is resected but the duodenum remains intact. Hence, the surface area of iron absorption is not affected.

Dietary iron is efficiently absorbed in its heme form. Non-heme iron is less efficiently absorbed mainly because of interference by phosphates, tannins, oxalates, and other food constituents. Acidic pH enhances iron absorption by promoting the conversion of ferric to ferrous iron by the enzyme ferrireductase.

The following are malabsorptive procedures that reduce the duodenal surface area and hence, reduce iron absorption:
Biliopancreatic diversion
Roux-en-Y gastric bypass
Duodenal switch
Solution to Question 9:
Tea contains tannins, which inhibit iron absorption. Hence, it should not be taken with iron supplements. Iron absorption is also reduced by:
Calcium supplements and antacids
Milk and dairy products
Proton pump inhibitors
Grapefruit and kiwi are acid-containing citrus fruits that create an acidic pH and hence, increase iron absorption.
Broccoli contains ascorbic acid that also enhances iron absorption.
Solution to Question 10:
The earliest sign of iron deficiency is a decrease in serum ferritin levels. This is called the state of negative iron balance.
Iron deficiency anemia develops in 3 stages:
Stage of negative iron balance - decrease in iron stores with normal serum iron and RBC morphology
Stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis - decrease in serum iron levels with normal RBC morphology
Stage of iron deficiency anemia - fall in hemoglobin with microcytic hypochromic RBCs
Solution to Question 11:
TIBC (total iron-binding capacity) does not decrease during the stage of a negative iron balance of iron deficiency anemia.
The progression to iron deficiency develops in 3 stages:
Stage of negative iron balance - Decrease in iron stores with normal serum iron and RBC morphology
Stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis - Decrease in serum iron levels with normal RBC morphology
Stage of iron deficiency anemia - Microcytic hypochromic RBCs

Solution to Question 12:
Tingling and numbness of the lower extremities are suggestive of peripheral neuropathy. It is a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency, not iron deficiency.
Iron-deficiency anemia is associated with the following findings:
Smooth tongue - due to loss of papillae
Cheilosis - fissuring at corners of mouth
Brittle nails

Solution to Question 13:
Image 4 shows dense RBCs with loss of central pallor or spherocytes. They are seen in autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and hereditary spherocytosis, not iron deficiency anemia.

The peripheral blood smear in iron deficiency anemia shows:
Microcytic hypochromic cells
Target cells
Pencil-shaped or cigar-shaped cells
Poikilocytosis- variations in the shape of RBCs
Anisocytosis- variations in the size of RBCs.
Solution to Question 14:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of iron deficiency anemia due to the following findings:
Low MCV (N: 87-96 fL)
Low MCH (N: 27-33 pg)
Elevated RDW
High TIBC
Option A: Anemia of chronic disease is associated with low TIBC.
Options B and D: Anemia due to B12 and folate deficiency presents with a high MCV
(macrocytosis).
Solution to Question 15:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of anemia of chronic disease. The chief mediator of this condition is hepcidin.
Anemia of chronic disease is associated with chronic inflammatory states such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic infections, and malignancies.
Hepcidin is a positive acute-phase reactant (ARP) that increases in chronic inflammatory states. It binds with ferroportin which results in both reduced iron intake in the gut and reduced iron transfer from macrophages to erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. Hence, hepcidin is
a negative regulator of iron balance.
Solution to Question 16:
Normocytic normochromic anemia is seen in chronic kidney disease (CKD).
It is also seen in the following conditions:
RBC membrane disorders - hereditary spherocytosis, elliptocytosis
RBC enzyme disorders - G6PD deficiency, Pyruvate kinase deficiency
Parvovirus B19 infection
Anemia of chronic disease - can also present as microcytic anemia
Solution to Question 17:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of anemia of chronic disease due to the following findings:
Low MCV (N: 87-96 fl)
Low TIBC (N: 300-360g/dL)
Elevated ferritin level (N: 50-200 g/L)
Normal transferrin saturation (N: 25-50%)
Solution to Question 18:
Anemia of CKD is a form of hypoproliferative anemia presenting with decreased reticulocytes.
It mainly occurs due to a failure of erythropoietin production by the diseased kidney and a reduction in the survival of RBCs. Also, patients with CKD maintained on chronic hemodialysis
may develop iron deficiency from blood loss through the dialysis procedure. The following features are seen:
Normocytic and normochromic RBCs
Decreased reticulocytes
Serum iron, transferrin saturation, TIBC are usually normal or low
Decreased serum ferritin
The degree of anemia usually correlates with the severity of the renal failure. Note: Anaemia in CKD is not the same as anaemia of chronic disease.
Solution to Question 19:
Inherited forms of sideroblastic anemia are usually X-linked. Rarely, autosomal recessive forms may also occur.
linked sideroblastic anemia results from the deficient activity of the erythroid form of ALA-synthase (ALA-synthase 2) and is associated with ineffective erythropoiesis
Solution to Question 20:
High serum iron levels are seen in patients with sideroblastic anemia. Sideroblastic anemia presents with the following features:
Serum iron level - high/norma
Transferrin saturation - high
Serum ferritin levels - high
TIBC - low/norma
Peripheral smear - dimorphic population (both microcytes and macrocytes).
Bone marrow study - marked erythroid hyperplasia.
The iron profile of sideroblastic anemia is opposite to that of iron deficiency anemia.
Solution to Question 21:
The given image shows ringed sideroblasts, which are erythroid precursors in the marrow. In these cells, iron deposits in the mitochondria form a ring around the nucleus and are stained by Prussian blue.
The mature red blood cell counterparts of ringed sideroblasts in the circulation are called siderocytes. These cells have iron-containing basophilic granules called Pappenheimer bodies, as
shown below.

Ringed sideroblasts and Pappenheimer bodies are pathognomonic of sideroblastic anemia.
Solution to Question 22:
Chloramphenicol is known to cause sideroblastic anemia. The agents known to cause sideroblastic anemia are:
Isoniazid
Chloramphenico

Excessive alcoho

Question 1:
The peripheral blood smear of a patient is given below. All of the following can cause this except:

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Solution to Question 1:
The given image shows hypersegmented neutrophils (> 5 nuclear lobes), which are seen in megaloblastic anemia. Chronic alcoholism causes non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia.
Megaloblastic anemia is a form of macrocytic anemia with impaired nucleic acid metabolism and defective erythropoiesis. The causes include vitamin B12 deficiency, folate deficiency, and orotic aciduria. Nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation giving the appearance of hypersegmented neutrophils. Peripheral smear findings include:
Oval macrocytes
Anisocytosis
Hypersegmented neutrophils
Other features of ineffective erythropoiesis seen in megaloblastic anemias include:
Howell-Jolly bodies are nuclear remnants in red cells. They are usually single, round, dark purple-red in color and peripheral in location, as shown below.

Basophilic stippling refers to blue granules of various sizes dispersed throughout the cytoplasm of the red cell. They represent ribosomal precipitates.
Cabot rings are red cell inclusions appearing as fine, purple filamentous loops or figure-of-eight forms, as shown below. They are presumed to be remnants of mitotic spindles.

Solution to Question 2:
Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) infection does not affect the absorption of cobalamin or vitamin B12. Small amounts of blood loss during the attachment of hookworms to the intestinal mucosa can cause iron-deficiency anemia.
Vitamin B12-intrinsic factor (IF) complex is absorbed in the ileum. Tropical sprue, Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) infection and Crohn's disease affect the ileum leading to defective absorption of vitamin B12.
Solution to Question 3:
Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in cyanocobalamin or vitamin B12 deficiency, not conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia due to ineffective erythropoiesis. This leads to the formation of nucleated RBCs in the marrow, which undergo early lysis. This leads to increased unconjugated bilirubin in the plasma.

Solution to Question 4:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of folate deficiency.
It is associated with the following clinical and laboratory findings:
Raised MCV (normal: 80-100 fL) - macrocytosis
Normal MCHC (normal: 33-36 g/dl)
Increased MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin)
Elevated RDW (red cell distribution width)
Decreased reticulocyte count - due to destruction of abnormal erythroid precursors
Elevated homocysteine
Normal MMA (methyl malonic acid)
In vitamin B12 deficiency, elevated homocysteine and elevated MMA levels are seen.
Peripheral neuropathy is a feature of B12 deficiency, not folate deficiency. In this patient, it may be due to diabetic neuropathy.

Temafloxacin is not associated with megaloblastic anemia. Megaloblastic anemia is associated with the following drugs:
Anticonvulsant drugs - phenytoin, primidone, barbiturates

Folate antagonists - trimethoprim, methotrexate, pyrimethamine, pentamidine, cotrimoxazole
Temafloxacin is a fluoroquinolone with severe adverse effects like hemolytic anemia and allergic reactions. It was withdrawn from the market and is no longer used.
Solution to Question 6:
This patient likely has folate deficiency secondary to the use of an anti-folate anti-convulsant drug. Lamotrigine has no effect on folate metabolism and does not cause its deficiency.
The following anticonvulsants have anti-folate properties:
Phenytoin

Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic macrocytic anemia which results in the following findings in RBCs:
Anemia (low Hb = 10g/dl)
Macrocytic (high MCV = 110 fl)
Hyperchromic (high MCH = 40 pg)
Solution to Question 7:
This clinical scenario refers to Schilling's test done for the determination of the cause of B12 deficiency. Improvement of urinary B12 excretion > 10% after antibiotic administration is suggestive of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO).
Solution to Question 8:
Megaloblastic anemia that is responsive to treatment with uridine is suggestive of orotic aciduria.
Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism in children. It occurs due to a defect in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway causing a failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. It manifests in early childhood with anemia and failure to thrive.
Solution to Question 9:
This clinical scenario in a patient with a history of autoimmune thyroiditis is suspicious for pernicious anemia. It is an autoimmune cause of B12 deficiency. Antibodies against gastrin are not seen in these patients. The following autoantibodies are seen:
Type I or blocking antibodies - prevent the combination of IF and cobalamin
Type II or binding antibodies - prevent attachment of IF to the ileal mucosa
Anti-parietal cell antibodies - target the gastric proton pump located in these cells
This leads to the deficiency of the intrinsic factor of Castle (IF) and hydrochloric acid produced by the parietal cells. The resulting atrophic gastritis causes high gastrin and low pepsinogen
levels. Lack of IF further causes vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia.
Solution to Question 10:
Gastric biopsy in pernicious anemia shows loss of glandular elements, not hypertrophy.
This is an autoimmune condition that occurs in genetically susceptible individuals. One of the common triggers of the disease process is Helicobacter pylori infection. Gastric biopsy findings in pernicious anemia include the following:
Atrophy of all layers of the body and fundus
Loss of glandular elements
Absence of parietal and chief cells and replacement by mucus cells
Mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate (excess of CD4 cells against gastric H+/K+-ATPase)
Intestinal metaplasia
Antral mucosa is usually well preserved.
Solution to Question 11:
Patients with pernicious anemia have an increased risk of intestinal-type of gastric adenocarcinoma and gastric carcinoid tumors. These patients must undergo regular endoscopic screening for these conditions.
The presumed mechanism is prolonged achlorhydria due to parietal cell loss. This leads to hypergastrinemia and cellular hyperplasia.
Solution to Question 12:
Reduced nutritional intake is the most common cause of folate deficiency.
Solution to Question 13:
Dietary folates are absorbed from the duodenum and jejunum in the form of monoglutamates. Vitamin B12 absorption takes place in the terminal ileum.
Solution to Question 14:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of dorsal column involvement of the spinal cord due to underlying vitamin B12 deficiency.
Vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (SACD). It affects the following structures:
Dorsal column - sensory loss, paresthesias, incontinence, sensory ataxia (positive Romberg sign with eyes closed)
Lateral column - spasticity and paraplegias in later stages
Folate deficiency is typically not associated with neurological manifestations. In patients with combined deficiency of B12 and folate, B12 deficiency must always be corrected first. This is because the administration of folate supplements may improve hematologic abnormalities but worsens neurological manifestations.
Treatment of cobalamin deficiency is as follows:
Replenishment of body stores: Six 1000-g IM injections of hydroxocobalamin given at 3- to 7-day intervals.
Maintenance therapy: 1000 g hydroxocobalamin IM once every 3 months Treatment of folate deficiency is as follows:

Option C: Thiamine deficiency causes Wernicke's syndrome with ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and nystagmus. As this is due to cerebellar damage, Romberg's sign would be positive even with eyes open.
Option D: Pyridoxine deficiency causes pellagra like syndrome with features of dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia.
Solution to Question 15:
Usage of phenytoin leads to folate deficiency and megaloblastic anemia. Hence, folic acid must be supplemented.
Solution to Question 16:
The recommended prophylactic dose of folic acid in women who have had a previous fetus with a neural tube defect is 4-5 mg daily, pre-conceptionally, and during the first trimester of pregnancy. Following the first trimester, these patients are then switched to 400 g of folic acid for the remainder of the pregnancy.
This high dose of folic acid (4-5 mg) should be initiated at least one to three months before pregnancy and should be continued for 12 weeks after pregnancy. The patient can be prescribed 1 mg tablet of folic acid and advised to take them 4- 5 times a day or they can be recommended 5mg tablets/capsules once daily.
Prophylactic folic acid with 400 g daily, pre-conceptionally, and throughout pregnancy is indicated in all pregnant women to prevent megaloblastic anemia and reduce the incidence of neural tube defects.
Solution to Question 17:
Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome (IGS) is an autosomal recessive disorder.
IGS occurs due to mutations in either the cubulin (CUBN) or amnionless (AMN) genes. They form the cubam receptor responsible for the absorption of the Cbl-IF complex. Hence, this condition leads to congenital cobalamin malabsorption. It is the most common cause of megaloblastic anemia due to B12 deficiency in infancy in Western countries.
Affected children present with lethargy, failure to thrive, and neurological symptoms like hypotonia, developmental delay, and movement disorders. Non-specific proteinuria with normal renal function is seen in 90% of patients.

Solution to Question 2:
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a hemolytic anemia due to an intracorpuscular defect.
It is caused due to an acquired somatic mutation leading to deficiency of membrane protective factors CD59 and CD55. This makes the RBC extremely sensitive to complement activation and causes intravascular hemolysis.
The other conditions occur due to extracorpuscular defects.
Option A: In autoimmune hemolytic anemia, RBCs are coated with autoantibodies. This triggers phagocytosis in the reticuloendothelial system leading to extravascular hemolysis.
Option C: Familial hemolytic uremic syndrome (atypical HUS) is an inherited abnormality with excessive complement activation leading to episodic and excessive production of membrane attack complex destroying normal RBCs.
Option D: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is non-immune hemolysis resulting from intravascular red blood cell fragmentation due to abnormalities in the microvasculature.
Solution to Question 3:
Deficiency of CD55 and CD59 is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).
It is due to an acquired mutation in the X-linked phosphatidylinositol class A PIG-A gene (Option A) causing a deficiency of GPI anchor proteins. GPI is a glycolipid that anchors membrane protective factors such as CD59 and CD55 to the membrane. The deficiency of CD55 and CD59 makes the RBC sensitive to complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis(Option B). The anemia is usually normo-macrocytic (Option D).
Hemolysis tends to occur at night due to a slight decrease in blood pH during sleep, which triggers complement activity (nocturnal hemoglobinuria). PNH is characterized by hemolytic anemia, pancytopenia, and venous thrombosis.
PNH is diagnosed using flow cytometry. The drugs of choice for treatment are Eculizumab or Ravulizumab which work against complement C5. Supportive management of PNH includes folic acid and iron supplementation. Bone marrow transplantation is another option for the treatment of this condition.
Solution to Question 4:
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a type of hemolytic anemia associated with pancytopenia and venous thrombosis.
In PNH, there is complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis. Bone marrow dysfunction also occurs, resulting in pancytopenia. Transformation to aplastic anemia or acute myeloid leukemia (AML) may rarely occur.
PNH is also associated with venous thrombosis (cerebral, renal, hepatic). This is the most common cause of death in PNH.
Option A: Shwachman-Diamond syndrome is inherited aplastic anemia with neutropenia with pancreatic insufficiency and malabsorption.
Options B and C: Pyruvate kinase and G6PD deficiency are inherited RBC enzyme disorders causing extravascular hemolytic anemias. They do not affect other cell lines and are not associated with venous thrombosis.
Solution to Question 5:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of intravascular hemolysis due to paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). The gold standard for diagnosis is flow cytometry.
Flow cytometry is performed with fluorescently labeled monoclonal antibodies that bind to GPI-anchored proteins (CD59, CD55). Most tests also use FLuorescent AERolysin (FLAER), a reagent that directly binds the GPI anchor. Absence of CD59 and CD55 are diagnostic of PNH.
Other investigations in PNH include:
Ham test (acidified serum lysis) - lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation.
Bone marrow biopsy:
Hypercellularity with erythroid hyperplasia is seen in classical presentations.
Patients who develop pancytopenia will have hypocellular bone marrow.
Imaging - to evaluate venous thrombosis.
Option B and D: Eosin-5-maleimide-binding and acidified glycerol lysis tests are done in hereditary spherocytosis.
Solution to Question 6:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). C5 complement inhibitors like eculizumab and ravalizumab are the drugs of choice in PNH.
Management of PNH involves the following:
C5 complement inhibitors prevent the formation of membrane attack complex and complement-mediated lysis.
Bone marrow transplant is useful for patients with severe pancytopenia
Supportive measures:
Transfusion of filtered RBCs
Folic acid, and iron supplementation
Anticoagulants in case of venous thrombosis
Solution to Question 7:
The peripheral smear shows hyperchromic RBCs with loss of central pallor or spherocytes. These findings are suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. The eosin-5-maleimide test is the most specific investigation for this condition.
It is a flow cytometric test based on the interaction between the dye eosin-5-maleimide and band 3 protein.
Other investigations that can be performed in this condition are:
Acidified glycerol lysis test: Spherocytes from patients with hereditary spherocytosis lyse more quickly than normal red blood cells when incubated in a phosphate buffered hypotonic solution with added glycerol. It has greater sensitivity and specificity than the osmotic fragility test.
Osmotic fragility test: Detects hemolysis by measuring the fraction of total hemoglobin released from red cells when suspended in progressively more dilute salt concentrations.
Note: NESTROFT (Naked eye single tube red-cell osmotic fragility test) is a highly sensitive test used as a screening test for thalassemia.
Solution to Question 8:
Cholecystectomy at the time of splenectomy is indicated in patients with hereditary spherocytosis (HS) only if they have symptomatic cholelithiasis at the time of surgery. It is usually carried out via a laparoscopic approach.
Penicillin prophylaxis after splenectomy is controversial. Routine penicillin prophylaxis is not mandatory for adults. It is recommended up to age of five and for at least one year following splenectomy.
Guidelines for the timing of splenectomy in HS:
Mild cases - avoid splenectomy.
Moderate cases - delay until puberty
Severe cases - at 4–6 years of age
Solution to Question 9:
The given peripheral smear shows oval, elongated, rod, or cigar-shaped RBCs suggestive of elliptocytosis. The hereditary form is most commonly associated with the spectrin genes.
The following proteins are implicated in hereditary elliptocytosis (HE):
-Spectrin (SPTA1 gene) - 65%
-Spectrin (SPTB gene) - 30%
Band 4.1
The treatment of choice is splenectomy, preferably after 5 years of age.
Solution to Question 10:
G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder. Male children of an affected man are not affected as they receive only the paternal Y chromosome. However, the mutation can be passed on to female children, who are typically carriers of the disease.
G6PD deficiency is the most common enzymatic disorder of RBCs. G6PD enzyme is involved in the generation of NADPH and protects RBCs from oxidative injury. Hence, patients with G6PD deficiency have episodes of acute hemolysis in the setting of oxidant injury from medications, acute infections, and certain foods (fava beans/broad beans).
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. This is suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen results in the formation of characteristic bite cells or degmacytes or blister cells (as shown in the image).
A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria.
Drugs that carry the risk of clinical hemolysis in persons with G6PD deficiency: Note: Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole.

Solution to Question 12:
The above peripheral smear shows basophilic stippling. It is characteristic of 5' nucleotidase deficiency.
Pyrimidine 5'-nucleotidase (P5'N-1) deficiency is the third most common enzyme abnormality causing hereditary hemolytic anemia. It is an autosomal recessive trait.
The hallmark of this enzyme deficiency is the presence of pronounced basophilic stippling and accumulation of pyrimidine nucleotides (RNA remnants) within erythrocytes.
Cabot rings may also be seen. They are thin, threadlike, red to violet rings or figure-of-8 shaped inclusions in red blood cells. They are remnants of the mitotic spindle and are seen in conditions causing dyserythropoiesis.
Basophilic stippling is also seen in the following conditions:
Lead toxicity
Sideroblastic anemia
Severe thalassemia
Conditions with impaired cell division
Solution to Question 13:
The antibody involved in warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is IgG, which causes extravascular hemolysis.
IgG is called a warm antibody, as it binds to target proteins at 37 oC. On the other hand, cold antibodies or IgM are reactive at 4 to 30oC.
In AIHA, autoantibodies against RBC antigens are produced which coat the RBC membrane. The Fc portion of the antibody is recognized by the Fc receptor on macrophages causing phagocytosis. RBC destruction takes place in extravascular sites where macrophages are abundant.
Solution to Question 14:
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is commonly associated with CLL (chronic lymphocytic leukemia). It is not a typical feature of CML (chronic myeloid leukemia).
AIHA can develop secondary to several autoimmune and infectious causes, as well as drugs. Drug-induced hemolytic anemia can occur by the following mechanisms:

options: This immune complex acti vates the complement system and destroys nearby RBCs (i nnocent bystanders) SulfonamidesQuinineQuinidi nePhenothiazines Some drugs trigger the produ ction ofautoantibodies Methyldopa Solution to Question 15: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) and hereditary spherocytosis are not Coomb's positive conditions. The following are Coombs-positive hemolytic anemias: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) Warm AIHA Cold agglutinin disease Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) Drug-induced hemolytic anemia  In PCH, the direct Coomb's test will be positive for complement only. This condition is characterized by the presence of the Donath-Landsteiner antibody. It is a unique antibody with anti-P specificity at 4°C. Hence, it binds to the RBC at 4°C. However, it causes complement-mediated lysis at 37°C. Interpretation of direct Coomb's test results: Condition Agglutination wit h anti- IgG anti- C3 Warm AIHA + + Drug-induced + + PCH - + Cold agglutinin disease (IgM) - + PNH - - Solution to Question 16: Donath Landsteiner antibody is specific for paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH). PCH is a rare form of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. The mechanism of this antibody includes: Binding to RBCs at 4°C Complement-mediated lysis at 37°C This condition presents with intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Blood transfusion is required in severe anemia. It is a self-limiting condition. The differences between PCH and PNH are given below: Condition Paroxysmal nocturnal hemog lobinuria (PNH) Paroxysmal cold hemoglobin uria (PCH) Onset Chronic with acute exacerbat ions Acute Pathogene sis Complement-mediateddestru ction of CD59/55(–) RBCs Immune lysisof normal red c ells Diagnosis Flow cytometry to display a C D55/CD59(–) red cell populat ion Test forDonath-Landsteinera ntibody Triggers Infections, alcohol, exercise, stress, or medications Triggered by viral infection Solution to Question 17: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) is not seen in prosthetic heart valves. It is associated with macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia. MAHA refers to cell fragmentation that occurs in microcirculation. Microvascular lesions lead to luminal narrowing due to the deposition of fibrin and platelets. These produce shear stress that mechanically injures passing red cells. Hence, it is a type of non-immune hemolysis (Coombs-negative). On peripheral blood smear, schistocytes are seen. Common causes of MAHA include: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura Hemolytic uremic syndrome Disseminated intravascular coagulation Vasculitis Malignant hypertension APLA syndrome Drug-induced hemolysis Eclampsia Solution to Question 18: The best prognosis in atypical HUS is seen in membrane cofactor protein (MCP) gene mutation. Familial HUS or atypical HUS (aHUS) is the only inherited cause of extracorpuscular hemolytic anemia. It can occur due to mutations in any one of several genes encoding complement regulatory proteins. Mutations in the following genes are seen: Membrane cofactor protein - best prognosis Complement factor B - worst prognosis Complement factor H - most common Complement factor I - least common In these patients, infection or other triggers cause complement activation through the alternative pathway. This causes hemolysis and damage to endothelial cells in the kidney. It is usually self-limited. The standard treatment is plasma exchange. Eculizumab has recently been shown to be beneficial in atypical HUS. Solution to Question 19: Deferoxamine has poor oral bioavailability and is administered parenterally (SC/IV). Oral formulations of both deferiprone and deferasirox are available. The adverse effects of iron chelators include: Deferiprone - neutropenia, and agranulocytosis. Deferasirox - transaminitis and mild, asymptomatic rise in serum creatinine Deferoxamine - occasional cataracts, deafness, and local skin reactions, but is usually well-tolerated Solution to Question 20: Naked eye single tube red-cell osmotic fragility test (NESTROFT) is the most sensitive test to detect thalassemia in the population. Hence, it is an effective screening test. The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. It is performed as follows: Mix EDTA blood and 0.36% buffered saline solution. Shake the tube and leave it at room temperature for 30 minutes. Shake the tube again and immediately hold the tube in front of a piece of paper with text. The image below shows a positive NESTROF test (test tube marked as T1) as the line is not visible through the test tube. The test tube marked as C shows the control (Please note that a negative NESTROF test would show visible lines similar to the appearance of the control). NESTROFT Inference Reason Lines visible (negative) Normal Hemolysis has occurred Lines not seen (positive) Thalasse mia Stable RBC, unable to lyse  The following tests are specific and used to confirm the diagnosis of thalassemia: Hemoglobin electrophoresis High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) Genetic testing Note: Eosin 5' maleimide (EMA) flow cytometry is the most specific test for the diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis. Solution to Question 21: This clinical scenario is consistent with -thalassemia minor. The diagnosis can be established by hemoglobin electrophoresis. This condition presents with the following features: Microcytes (N: 80-96 fL) Hypochromic (N: 27-33 pg) Mild anemia Target cells Normal iron profile Hemoglobin electrophoresis findings are as follows: 4% of HbA2 5% of HbF Solution to Question 22: Acute pain crisis is not associated with sickle cell trait. Acute pain crisis is classicaly seen in sickle cell disease. Manifestations of sickle cell trait include: Often asymptomatic. Hyposthenuria Painless hematuria - due to papillary necrosis Recurrent UTIs Risk of renal medullary carcinoma - rare Increased risk of CKD Sloughing of papillae with urethral obstruction is very rare Anemia and painful crises are rare. Solution to Question 23: Acute pain crisis is the most common clinical presentation of sickle cell anemia. These are intermittent episodes of vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal structures. This results in ischemia resulting in acute pain and tenderness, fever, tachycardia, and anxiety. The management includes vigorous hydration, evaluation for underlying causes, and aggressive analgesia. Other manifestations of sickle cell anemia include: Hand-foot syndrome - painful infarcts of the digits and dactylitis Priapism - infarction of the penile venous outflow tracts Chronic lower leg ulcers - ischemia and superinfection in the distal circulation Splenic sequestration crisis - life-threatening complication due to acute venous obstruction that requires emergency transfusion and/or splenectomy Aplastic crisis - commonly secondary to parvovirus B19 infection Acute chest syndrome - sickling within the lung, producing pain and temporary pulmonary dysfunction. Treatment may include lifelong transfusion support, using partial exchange transfusion Stroke - common in children Myeloproliferative Disorders and Aplastic Anemia Question 1: According to WHO 2022 classification, which of the following is not a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm? Solution to Question 1:
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a lymphoid neoplasm. It is not a myeloproliferative neoplasm.
Myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN) are a group of disorders that cause an increased number of red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets. According to 5th edition WHO classification (2022), myeloproliferative neoplasms consist of the following:
Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
Polycythemia vera (PV)
Primary myelofibrosis (PMF)
Essential thrombocythemia
Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML)
Chronic neutrophilic leukemia (CNL)
Chronic eosinophilic leukemia
Myeloproliferative neoplasm, not otherwise specified
Solution to Question 2:
The most common myeloproliferative neoplasm is polycythemia vera.
It is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder that is characterized by uncontrolled proliferation of the red blood cells in the body. It is also frequently associated with an increase in white blood cells and platelets.
Solution to Question 3:
This patient has increased Hb and normal WBCs and platelets. The next step is to measure RBC mass to evaluate for polycythemia.
A person has to be evaluated for polycythemia if there is:
Increased hemoglobin: >16.5 g/dL in men or >16.0 g/dL in women, (or)
Increased hematocrit: >49 percent in men or >48 percent in women
This condition is due to either a true increase in the number of RBCs (absolute polycythemia) or an apparent increase due to a decrease in the plasma volume (relative polycythemia). Both of these conditions can be differentiated by measuring RBC mass (amount of total blood volume that is occupied by RBCs).
In patients with absolute polycythemia, erythropoietin (EPO) levels must be measured.
Primary polycythemia - low or normal EPO levels
Secondary polycythemia - elevated EPO levels
Solution to Question 4:
Polycythemia vera is associated with low or normal erythropoietin (EPO) levels.
Polycythemia refers to an increase in the number of red blood cells (RBC) in the body. It is classified as:
Autonomous production of erythropoietin occurs in renal cell carcinoma (RCC), hepatocellular carcinoma, cerebellar hemangioblastoma.
Relative (spurious) polycythemia refers to an apparent increase in RBC or hemoglobin count due to a decrease in the plasma volume. It is commonly seen in dehydration.
Primarypolycythemia (polycy themia vera)
Secondarypolycythemia

Solution to Question 5:
The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation. JAK2 mutations can be found in the following neoplasms:
Polycythemia vera
Essential thrombocythemia
Primary myelofibrosis
Solution to Question 6:
Generalized pruritus seen in polycythemia vera (PV) is a consequence of the activation of mast cells by JAK 2 mutation.
Other options:
Option A: The risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with erythrocytosis, not the degree of thrombocytosis.
Option C: In polycythemia vera, there is an increased risk of H.pylori infection.
Option D: Thrombosis is the major cause of mortality in polycythemia vera. The incidence of acute leukemia in patients not exposed to chemotherapy or radiation therapy is low.
PV is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which red cells, granulocytes & platelets accumulate in the absence of a physiological stimulus. The most common mutation seen in PV is he JAK2 mutation.
Clinical features of polycythemia vera are:
Thrombosis is the most common manifestation and is the major cause of mortality. Uncontrolled erythrocytosis causes increased viscosity of the blood causing thrombosis of the vessels. Patients may present with stroke, transient ischemic attacks, myocardial infarction, and Budd-Chiari syndrome.
Aquagenic pruritis is generalized itching following a warm bath or a shower due to increased mast cells and histamine.
Erythromelalgia is erythema and pain in the fingers, hands, and feet due to increased platele stickiness.
Splenomegaly due to increased destruction of RBCs in the spleen
Gout is due to the excessive proliferation of the marrow cells leading to elevated uric acid levels.
Solution to Question 7:
Low WBC count is not a feature of polycythemia vera. It is associated with an elevated WBC count.
Common laboratory findings of polycythemia vera are:
Elevated hemoglobin concentration, hematocrit levels, and RBC coun
Elevated WBCs and platelet counts
Low to normal erythropoietin levels
Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase
Solution to Question 8:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera. In these
patients, ruxolitinib, a Janus-kinase inhibitor is used to provide symptomatic relief. The treatment of polycythemia vera is as follows:
Therapeutic phlebotomy - definitive treatmen
Anticoagulants - in patients with thrombosis
Symptomatic relief:
Ruxolitinib
Hydroxyurea
Interferon-alpha
PUVA therapy
Solution to Question 9:
Enlargement of the spleen > 8 cm below the costal margin or weight > 1000 g is called massive splenomegaly. It is not a feature of essential thrombocythemia (ET), as it causes only mild splenomegaly.
The causes of massive splenomegaly include:
Chronic myeloid leukemia
Primary myelofibrosis
Polycythemia vera
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
Lymphoma
Hairy cell leukemia
Gaucher's disease
Sarcoidosis
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

The majority of the patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally. Some patients may present with thrombotic events or rarely, hemorrhages. The following findings are seen:
Peripheral smear - abnormally large platelets
Bone marrow biopsy - increased number of megakaryocytes, with hyperlobulated nuclei
Solution to Question 10:
The first-line drug for cytoreductive therapy in patients with essential thrombocythemia is hydroxyurea.
Treatment of essential thrombocythemia is as follows:
No symptoms or risk of thrombosis:
Observation alone
Low dose aspirin may be considered
High risk of thrombosis (cardiovascular risk factors, prior history of thrombosis)
Low dose aspirin
Cytoreduction with hydroxyurea, busulfan, or interferon-alpha
Solution to Question 11:
The image shows the deposition of numerous collagen fibers in the bone marrow, which indicates marrow fibrosis. These clinical findings and history of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration are diagnostic of primary myelofibrosis.
In this condition, the neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells results in increased and abnormal proliferation of the megakaryocytes. These megakaryocytes release excessive amounts of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-. Increased growth factors lead to the deposition of collagen in the bone marrow which eventually leads to fibrosis.
The clinical features include:
Early phase:
Thrombocytosis (large, abnormal platelets) and leukocytosis
Hypercellularity of bone marrow
Late phase:
Pancytopenia
Hypocellularity and fibrosis of bone marrow (dry tap)
Teardrop-shaped RBCs and leukoerythroblastosis (premature release of nucleated erythroid and early granulocytes into blood)
Hepatosplenomegaly - due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
Solution to Question 12:
Fanconi anemia results in pancytopenia with hypocellular bone marrow. Hence, it is not likely in this patient.
Causes of pancytopenia with hypocellular bone marrow include:
Inherited aplastic anemia
Fanconi anemia
Dyskeratosis congenita
Shwachman-Diamond syndrome
Acquired aplastic anemia
Causes of pancytopenia with hypercellular bone marrow include:
Primary bone marrow disorders
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)
Myelodysplastic syndrome
Myelofibrosis
Systemic diseases
Megaloblastic anemia
Alcoholism
Sarcoidosis
Tuberculosis
Brucellosis
Solution to Question 13:
The most likely diagnosis is dyskeratosis congenita. This condition is characterized by pancytopenia along with the clinical triad of:
Reticular skin pigmentation
Nail dystrophy
Oral leukoplakia

Option A: Fanconi anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by pancytopenia, congenital anomalies, and an increased risk of malignancies.
Option B: Shwachman-Diamond syndrome presents with bone marrow failure and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.
Option C: Diamond-Blackfan syndrome presents with low RBC counts due to congenital erythroid aplasia.
Note: Fanconi anemia is different from Fanconi syndrome. Fanconi syndrome is a disorder of renal tubular function (type 2 RTA) that results in increased excretion of glucose, amino acids, bicarbonates, and phosphates.
Solution to Question 14:
Herpes simplex infection is not a cause of acquired aplastic anemia. Secondary causes of acquired aplastic anemia include:
Radiation
Toxins - Benzene
Drugs
Chemotherapy drugs (including cyclophosphamide)
Sulfonamides

Solution to Question 15:
The clinical and laboratory findings, as well as bone marrow hypocellularity are diagnostic of aplastic anemia. In this young patient, the best method of management is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
Aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia and resulting bleeding manifestations, anemia, and frequent infections. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypocellularity with fatty infiltration of the bone marrow. The management is as follows:
Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation - best method of management in young patients
Antithymocyte globulin with cyclosporine - elderly patients and patients without HLA-matched donors
Eltrombopag - a thrombopoietin analog used as add-on therapy
Solution to Question 16:
The most common cytogenetic abnormality seen in myelodysplastic neoplasm is the 5q deletion.
Myelodysplastic syndromes/neoplasm (MDS) are a group of disorders in which abnormal stem cells produce increased numbers of immature blood cells. These immature cells are defective and die prematurely resulting in lower numbers of mature blood cells. It is characterized
by pancytopenia and a high risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
The cytogenetic abnormalities identified in this condition include:
subject: Medicine

question_text:
th edition WHO Classification of MDS (2022):
MDS with defining genetic abnormalities:
MDS with a low blast and isolated 5q deletion (MDS-5q): <5% blasts in the bone marrow or
<2% blasts in the peripheral blood.
MDS with a low blast and SF3B1 mutation (MDS-SF3B1): Detection of 15% ring sideroblasts may substitute for SF3B1 mutation.
MDS with biallelic TP53 inactivation (MDS-biTP53): <20% blasts in the bone marrow or peripheral blood.
MDS, morphologically defined:
MDS with low blasts: <5% blasts in the bone marrow or <2% blasts in the peripheral blood.
MDS-hypoplastic: 25% bone marrow cellularity
MDS with increased blasts (IB):
MDS-IB1: 5–9% of blasts in bone marrow or 2–4% in peripheral blood
MDS-IB2:10-19% of blasts in bone marrow or 5-19% in peripheral blood or Auer rods
MDS-fibrosis: 5-19% of blasts in bone marrow or 2–19% in peripheral blood
Childhood myelodysplastic neoplasm:
Childhood MDS with low blasts:<5% blasts in the bone marrow or <2% blasts in the peripheral blood
Childhood MDS with increased blasts: 5-19% blasts in the bone marrow or 2-19% blasts in the peripheral blood.
Solution to Question 17:
Lenalidomide is the drug of choice in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) associated with 5q deletion.
It is a thalidomide derivative with the following benefits in these patients:
Patients achieve transfusion independence
Normal or near-normal hemoglobin levels
Normalization of cytogenetics Adverse effects include:
Myelosuppression (worsening thrombocytopenia and neutropenia, necessitating blood coun monitoring)
Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism
However, hematopoietic stem cell transplant remains the definitive treatment.

Solution to Question 1:
The average lifespan of platelets in circulation is 7–10 days.
Thrombopoietin (TPO) is the regulator of platelet production. A reduction in platelet and megakaryocyte mass increases the level of TPO, which then stimulates platelet production.
The shelf life of donor platelets is 5 days. It is stored on a special agitator at 20-24 °C. The half-life of transfused platelets is 3-5 days.
Solution to Question 2:
Hemarthrosis is highly suggestive of a coagulation disorder, not a platelet disorder. Bleeding diathesis can occur due to:
Platelet disorders - mucocutaneous bleeding like petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses, epistaxis, menorrhagia, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeds
Coagulation disorders - hemarthrosis, muscle hematomas, and bleeding into soft tissues
Disorders of the vessel wall (Henoch-Schönlein purpura, scurvy) - purpura and ecchymosis

Solution to Question 3:
Bernard Soulier syndrome is a disorder of platelet adhesion. It occurs due to an inherited defect in the GPIb-IX complex.

Solution to Question 4:
Thrombocytopenia is a feature of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.
It is an X-linked recessive condition caused by mutations in the WASP gene. It affects T-cells and platelets and presents with the following features:
Eczema
Thrombocytopenia - along with decreased platelet size, impaired platelet aggregation response
Immunodeficiency - low IgM, high IgE, defective regulatory T cells causing recurrent bacterial infections.
Option A: Platelet storage pool disorder is a disorder of defective platelet granule formation.
Option C: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a type of small vessel vasculitis in children and young adults.

Solution to Question 5:
Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in drug-induced thrombocytopenia. Common drugs that cause this are quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds.
Drug-dependent antibody binding can only be demonstrated in the presence of the drug in the laboratory assays. The thrombocytopenia normally occurs within 21 days of initial exposure and usually gets resolved after 7-10 days once the drug is stopped.
Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in:
Drug-induced thrombocytopenia

Idiopathic/ immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

It presents with features of mucocutaneous bleeding. CBC shows isolated thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear does not reveal any hemolysis.

Solution to Question 7:
This scenario is suggestive of acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura. Bleeding into the joints is seen in coagulation disorders and is not a manifestation of this condition.
Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder in which there is an immune-mediated destruction of platelets. It can be acute or chronic.
Acute ITP is common in children and is usually preceded by viral infection. It presents with mucocutaneous bleeding (epistaxis, petechiae, ecchymosis). Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever and jaundice are absent. The following laboratory features are seen:
Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000 / L)
Bleeding time - prolonged
PT/aPTT/INR - normal
Bone marrow - normal/increased megakaryocytes
Peripheral smear - normal
This condition resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases. Treatment is as follows:
Platelet count < 30,000 with risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or concomitant bleeding disorders): Oral glucocorticoids or IVIG
Severe bleeding symptoms: IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG
Life-threatening bleeding (like intracranial hemorrhage): platelet transfusion + IV methylprednisolone + IVIG
Solution to Question 8:
This clinical scenario in an adult patient is suggestive of chronic ITP (idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura). She does not require platelet transfusion. It is recommended only for patients with severe bleeding manifestations (intracranial/ gastrointestinal) or platelet count < 5000 L.
Chronic ITP can either be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE or infections like HIV and hepatitis C. Depending on the clinical features, the management is as follows:

Solution to Question 9:
Splenectomy is the treatment of choice in a case of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) relapse after first line therapy with glucocorticoids. The relapse usually occurs once they are tapered. Vaccination against encapsulated organisms (pneumococcus, meningococcus, H. influenzae) is advised before splenectomy is performed.
It is important to note that in some patients ITP resolves by itself, and observation along with intermittent IV immunoglobulins and anti - Rh(D) administration or administration of a
thrombopoietin receptor agonist (eltrombopag, romiplostim) can be a viable option before splenectomy is considered.
The treatment of ITP is as follows:
ITP is an acquired disorder characterized by the immune-mediated destruction of platelets and possibly inhibition of platelet release from the megakaryocyte. Secondary causes of ITP include systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), HIV-AIDS, and Hepatitis C.
ITP usually presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, very low platelet count, and normal peripheral blood cells. Patients typically exhibit ecchymoses and petechiae or they may incidentally discover thrombocytopenia during a routine complete blood count. Rarely,
life-threatening bleeding may occur. The presence of wet purpura (blood blisters in the mouth) and retinal hemorrhages can serve as warning signs of potentially life-threatening bleeding.

Solution to Question 10:
Abciximab can cause a drop in platelet count within 24 hours of initial exposure. Hence, these patients must be monitored for thrombocytopenia. This is due to naturally-occurring antibodies that cross-react with the drug bound to the platelets.
Thrombocytopenia due to other drugs typically occurs several days after exposure (average 21 days) and resolves in 7-10 days after drug withdrawal. Drug-induced thrombocytopenia can occur due to the following mechanisms:
Bone marrow suppression - chemotherapeutic drugs
Drug dependent antibodies that react with platelet surface antigens - quinine and sulfonamides
Naturally occurring antibodies that cross-react with drugs bound to the platelets - platelet Gp IIb/IIIa inhibitors
Some of the drugs that cause thrombocytopenia are:
Antibiotics - ampicillin, cephalosporins, piperacillin, vancomycine
Analgesics - ibuprofen, acetaminophen
Anti-epileptics - phenytoin, carbamazepine
Heparin
Amiodarone
Solution to Question 11:
Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is not associated with bleeding. On the contrary, it is associated with an increased risk of thrombosis.
This condition occurs due to the production of antibodies against the heparin-PF4 complex (platelet factor 4, a platelet-specific protein). These antibodies can activate platelets and result in thrombosis. It is seen 5-14 days after exposure to heparin.
These antibodies can be detected using ELISA or serotonin release assay. This condition is managed by discontinuing heparin and using alternative anticoagulants.
Solution to Question 12:
Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) such as enoxaparin cannot be used in the treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). This is because HIT antibodies (against
anti-PF4-heparin complex) may cross-react with LMWH.
HIT can occur following exposure to unfractionated heparin and less commonly with LMWH. The treatment of HIT is as follows:
Discontinue heparin
Anticoagulation with non-heparin anticoagulants even in the absence of thrombosis, since there is a high risk of thrombosis.
Direct thrombin inhibitors: Argatroban, lepirudin, bivalirudin
Danaparoid (heparinoid)
Solution to Question 13:
This scenario is suggestive of pseudothrombocytopenia. It is seen in blood samples collected with EDTA as the anticoagulant.
EDTA causes a reduction in the calcium content of the collected blood sample. This triggers in vitro platelet clumping and agglutination by antibodies (usually IgG), as shown below:

When a low platelet count is obtained with an EDTA sample, the peripheral blood smear should be evaluated. The platelet count must also be determined in blood collected in sodium citrate or heparin collection tubes or fresh fingerstick blood sample.
Solution to Question 14:
The ristocetin aggregation test is abnormal (no aggregation) in patients with Bernard-Soulier (BS)
syndrome.
It is an inherited disorder of platelet function or qualitative platelet disorder due to deficiency of the Gp Ib-IX receptor. This is the platelet membrane receptor for the von Willebrand factor (vWF). The binding of the vWF to the GpIb-IX-V complex on the platelet membrane is essential for platelet adhesion to the vessel wall.
This condition presents with mild thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear shows large platelets.
Platelet aggregation tests are performed to measure platelet activation and aggregation in vitro. Various platelet agonists like ADP, epinephrine, collagen, and ristocetin can be used to perform these tests. In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the following responses are seen:
With ristocetin - No response/no aggregation, as ristocetin specifically binds to the platelet membrane via the Gp Ib-IXa receptor
With ADP or epinephrine - Normal response, as Gp IIb-IIIa receptor is not involved in this process
Solution to Question 15:
Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.
vWD occurs due to deficient or abnormal von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is synthesized by endothelial cells and megakaryocytes (gene located on chromosome 12p). It is then stored in endothelial storage vesicles, Weibel-Palade bodies. Metalloprotease ADAMTS13 cleaves ultra-large multimers of VWF which are responsible for platelet adhesion.
The functions of vWF and the corresponding symptoms include:
Adhesion of the platelets to the exposed subendothelium - symptoms of both platelet and bleeding disorders
Prolongs the half-life of factor VIII by binding to it in circulation - hemophilia A like symptoms
(rare)
Solution to Question 16:
Autosomal hemophilia is also called type 2N von Willebrand disease (vWD), as the clinical presentation is similar to hemophilia.
The types of vWD are:
In pseudo vWD, the vWF is normal. However, platelets have an increased affinity for vWF. It presents similar to vWD 2B with thrombocytopenia.

Solution to Question 17:
Heyde’s syndrome is aortic stenosis with gastrointestinal bleeding, due to angiodysplasia of the gastrointestinal tract.
The shear stress on blood passing through the stenotic aortic valve produces a change in the von Willebrand factor making it susceptible to serum proteases. Hence, large multimer forms are lost,
leading to an acquired type 2 von Willebrand disease (vWD). The condition is reversed with the replacement of the aortic valve.
Other causes of acquired vWD include:
Multiple myeloma
Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
Polycythemia vera
Systemic lupus erythematosus
Solution to Question 18:
Bleeding time is increased in von Willebrand disease (vWD). It is a combination of a platelet adhesion defect with factor VIII deficiency.
The laboratory findings in vWD include:
Platelet count is normal (except type 2B)
Bleeding time is prolonged
Ristocetin aggregation is abnormal
Other platelet aggregation tests are normal
Prothrombin time (PT) is normal
aPTT is prolonged
VWF activity is decreased
Factor VIII activity is decreased
Solution to Question 19:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of von Willebrand's disease. The preferred first-line treatment is desmopressin (DDAVP).
This drug acts on endothelial V2 receptors causing the release of VWF and factor VIII from endothelial stores. DDAVP can be given intravenously or by an intranasal spray. The side effects include tachyphylaxis and hyponatremia.
VWF concentrate and factor VIII concentrate are reserved for patients with severe disease or prior to major procedures. Antifibrinolytic therapy (tranexamic acid or -aminocaproic acid) may be used for the prevention and treatment of mucosal bleeding.
Solution to Question 20:
Thrombocytopenia is not seen in Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia.
Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia is a primary defect of platelet function (aggregation). It occurs due to congenital absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor. It presents as superficial mucocutaneous bleeding with normal platelet count and single isolated platelets without clumping on peripheral smear. The levels of vWF are normal.
Normally, release of ADP causes platelets to change shape and bind to fibrinogen through the GpIIb/IIIa receptor. In Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, absence of the receptor causes abnormal aggregation (absent or reduced) on adding ADP. However, aggregation in response to ristocetin is normal, as it is dependent on GpIb and vWF.
Secondary platelet dysfunction can be seen in the following conditions:
Uremia
Paraproteinemia
Myeloproliferative disorders
Solution to Question 21:
Pagoclone is an anxiolytic medication. It is not an antiplatelet drug.
The thienopyridine drugs are ADP receptor or P2Y12 antagonists that inhibit ADP mediated platelet aggregation. They include the following drugs:
Clopidogrel - commonly used
Ticagrelor - reversible drug with a shorter t1/2, does not require activation, may cause mild, self-limited dyspnea
Prasugrel - 10 times more potent than clopidogrel, rapid onset of action, better absorption, more predictable
Ticlopidine
Clopidogrel and prasugrel are prodrugs that require activation by cytochrome P450
enzymes. CYP2C19 polymorphisms can cause reduced platelet inhibition with clopidogrel and increased risk of cardiovascular events.

Combined autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)
is called Evans syndrome.

The severity of the bleeding symptoms is out of proportion to the moderately decreased platelet count.
Option D: Rosenthal syndrome or hemophilia C refers to factor XI deficiency.
Solution to Question 23:
The most common side effect of aspirin is gastrointestinal symptoms. The use of enteric-coated aspirin does not reduce these side effects.
Aspirin irreversibly acetylates and inhibits platelet cyclooxygenase (COX)-1, which causes reduced synthesis of thromboxane A2. At high doses, it also inhibits COX-2, which results in the
anti-inflammatory effects of aspirin.
The major GI side effects include dyspepsia, erosive gastritis, peptic ulcers with bleeding and perforation. The overall risk of major bleeding with aspirin is 1–3% per year, which increases 2-3 fold if there is concurrent use of other antiplatelet drugs or anticoagulants. The risk of bleeding can be reduced by eradication of Helicobacter pylori infection and giving proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).
Aspirin sensitivity refers to bronchospasm or urticaria/angioedema seen immediately after administration of aspirin. It is also called Samter's triad (asthma, recurrent nasal polyps, aspirin sensitivity). In patients with aspirin resistance, there is failure of aspirin to produce its normal platelet inhibitory functions.
Solution to Question 24:
Dipyridamole increases extracellular adenosine levels.
It is an antiplatelet drug that increases levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP) in platelets by:
Blocking the reuptake of adenosine and increasing extracellular adenosine levels
Inhibiting phosphodiesterase-mediated cAMP degradation
This increase in cyclic AMP reduces intracellular levels of calcium. This inhibits platelet activation and aggregation.

Dipyridamole is a weak antiplatelet used in combination with aspirin for the prevention of stroke in patients with TIA.
Side effects include gastrointestinal and vasodilatory complaints (headache, flushing, dizziness, hypotension). Due to it's vasodilatory effects, it is contraindicated in patients with symptomatic coronary artery disease.

Solution to Question 26:
Plasmapheresis is the mainstay of the treatment of patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).
The best response to this therapy is seen in patients with ADAMTS13 autoantibodies. Plasmapheresis is continued until the resolution of platelet count and signs of hemolysis for at least 2 days.
Option A: The first line of treatment of autoimmune hemolytic anemia is glucocorticoids. The second line includes rituximab and splenectomy.
Option B: Treatment of disseminated intravascular coagulation is primarily supportive with measures to treat the underlying cause.
Option D: Treatment of HUS is primarily supportive. Dialysis is usually required. In some varients of HUS plasma infusion/exchange can be effective by replasing the complement-regulatory proteins.
Solution to Question 27:
Large vessel arterial or venous thromboemboli are not seen in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). This condition is associated with microvascular thrombosis.
TTP occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies against the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. In this condition, the vWF molecules persist causing pathogenic platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes localized platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits at various sites.
It presents with the following pentad of clinical features:
Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia - mechanical shearing of RBCs as they pass through platelet rich-microthrombi
Thrombocytopenia - deposition of platelets in microthrombi
Renal failure - microthrombi in the renal vasculature
Neurologic findings - headache, confusion, transient focal neurologic deficits
Fever
Solution to Question 28:
In patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), the PT and aPTT are normal, as consumptive coagulopathy is not seen.
TTP and HUS are thrombotic microangiopathies with overlapping clinical features. TTP can be primary (ADAMTS13 deficiency) or secondary (associated with infections like HIV and drugs like quinine).
Note: In disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), thrombocytopenia and microangiopathy are seen. It is associated with consumption of clotting factors and fibrinogen resulting in prolonged PT and aPTT.
Solution to Question 29:
Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of venous thrombosis. Venous thrombosis typically manifests as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary thromboembolism.
Hypercoagulable states or thrombophilias can be inherited or acquired:
Inherited causes in decreasing order of prevalence are as follows:
Factor V Leiden mutation
Prothrombin mutation
Protein C deficiency
Protein S deficiency
Antithrombin III deficiency
Acquired causes include:
Surgery
Malignancy
Antiphospholipid syndrome
Trauma
Pregnancy
Long-haul travel
Obesity
Oral contraceptives/hormone replacement
Myeloproliferative disorders
Polycythemia vera

Bernard Soulier syndrome, Glanzman thrombasthenia, and Chediak-Higashi syndrome are inherited as autosomal recessive traits.

Excellent clinical outcomes

Drugs:

Solution to Question 3:
This clinical scenario of congenital neutropenia is suggestive of Kostmann syndrome. It is associated with an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
Kostmann syndrome occurs due to mutations in the G-CSF receptor and neutrophil elastase. This causes bone marrow failure specifically in the myeloid lineage. It presents in young children as recurrent bacterial infections (such as otitis media, cellulitis) and oral ulcers.
Option A: Bloom syndrome occurs due to defects in DNA repair. It is not associated with neutropenia but has a higher risk of AML.
Option C: Diamond-Blackfan syndrome refers to congenital erythroid aplasia. It is also associated with a higher risk of AML.
Option D: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is due to defective phagolysosome formation. It is not associated with neutropenia.
Solution to Question 4:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a chloroma. It is commonly associated with the M2 subtype of acute myeloid leukemia, also called AML with maturation.
Chloroma is also called myeloid sarcoma, extramedullary myeloid tumor, or granulocytic sarcoma. It is an extramedullary tumor mass consisting of myeloid blasts, with or without maturation. It is called chloroma due to the peculiar green color, caused by myeloperoxidase. The sites affected include orbit (most common), skull, oral cavity, paranasal sinuses, sternum, ribs, vertebrae, and pelvis.

Infiltration of the gingivae, skin, soft tissues or meninges with leukemic blasts is characteristic of the monocytic subtypes and those with 11q23 chromosomal abnormalities.
Less commonly, infiltration is also seen in acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AML-M4).
