Solution to Question 8:
The cutoff value of blast cells for the diagnosis of AML is 20% according to the WHO classification. This classification is based on the clinical features, cytogenetic and molecular abnormalities in addition to morphology. This is in contrast to the previously used
French-American-British (FAB) classification which was based on only morphology of myeloid precursors.
The major changes in the WHO classification in contrast to FAB classification are:
Blast cutoff for diagnosis of AML is 20% (30% in FAB classification)
Specific chromosomal rearrangements such as t (8;21), inv(16), t(16;16) and t (15;17) can define AML even with < 20% blasts
Immunophenotyping (flow cytometry) is used to differentiate AML from ALL and to identify some subtypes of AML
Myeloid dysplasia with blasts between 20-30% can benefit from therapy for myelodysplastic syndrome (decitabine, 5-azacytidine, cedazuridine)

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML).
According to the WHO criteria, the diagnosis of AML requires any one of the following:
Blast cell count 20% either in the peripheral blood or bone marrow
Presence of any one of the following cytogenetic abnormalities:
t(15;17)
t(8;21)
Inversion 16 or t(16;16)
t(9;22)
NPM1 mutation (Nucleophosmin mutation)
CEBPA mutation

t(15,17) is associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).

The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing blast cells with peroxidase granules are suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Peroxidase granules are dark blue-stained granules seen in the cytoplasm on peroxidase staining.
Myeloperoxidase cytochemical activity is negative in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and blast crisis.
Solution to Question 13:
Young age of onset is associated with a good prognosis in patients with AML. Family history does not affect the prognosis.
P	r prognosis is seen in the following cases:
Advancing age (usually defined as > 60 years)
Previous hematologic disorders - myeloproliferative neoplasms and myelodysplastic syndrome
Longstanding cytopenias >3 months before diagnosis
Therapy-related AML (chemotherapy for other cancers)
Chromosomal aberrations with poor outcomes
Solution to Question 14:
Pelger-Huet anomaly is not a feature of myeloblasts. Auer rods and Phi bodies are considered pathognomonic of AML.
Myeloblasts have the following characteristics as shown in the following image:
Large, uniform population of cells
Prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow in the image)
Primary cytoplasmic granules
Auer rods - needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by fusion of lysosomes (black arrow)
Phi-bodies - fusiform or spindle-shaped rods similar to Auer rods that require special stains for hydroperoxidases
Pseudo-Chediak-Higashi syndrome - Giant lysosomes forming intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

Pelger-Huet anomaly refers to neutrophils with bilobed nuclei that occur as a benign, inherited condition. Pseudo-Pelger-Huet anomaly refers to an acquired defect seen in CML, myelodysplastic syndrome.
Note: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with abnormal lysosomal trafficking (LYST gene). Presents with oculocutaneous albinism and immunodeficiency.
Solution to Question 15:
This clinical presentation with painful edematous plaques is suggestive of febrile neutrophilic dermatosis or Sweet syndrome. It is not associated with aplastic anemia. It is associated with the following conditions:
Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) - most common
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
Solid malignancies of the genitourinary tract
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
Drugs - all-trans-retinoic acid, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF)
Idiopathic Sweet syndrome - common in women following respiratory tract infection This condition presents with the following triad:
Fever
Neutrophilia
Dense dermal infiltrate of neutrophils:
Pinkish-red to reddish-brown edematous painful plaques
Occur over the head, neck, extremities
Solution to Question 16:
The most commonly used complete remission induction regimen in patients with AML is cytarabine and an anthracycline (e.g., daunorubicin, idarubicin).
The treatment of AML is as follows:
Induction chemotherapy with a 7+3 regimen:
Cytarabine - continuous intravenous infusion for 7 days
IV daunorubicin on days 1,2,3
Side effects include neutropenia, sepsis
Post-remission therapy:
High dose cytarabine
Allogenic hematopoeitic stem cell transplant
Novel agents include gemtuzumab ozogamicin, a CD33 monoclonal antibody.
Solution to Question 17:
The presence of blast cells with numerous Auer rods, MPO (myeloperoxidase) positive cells,
and t(15:17) is diagnostic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). The preferred treatment regimen is arsenic trioxide and all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA).

APL is characterized by t(15; 17) translocation resulting in the PML-RAR-alpha fusion gene (promyelocyte-retinoic acid receptor alpha). It is a highly curable subtype of leukemia. The treatment is as follows:
Induction therapy:
ATRA + anthracycline (daunorubicin or idarubicin) or cytarabine (OR)
ATRA + arsenic trioxide
Consolidation therapy:
Post remission anthracycline-based chemotherapy
Solution to Question 18:
The clinical scenario describes a patient of APL (acute promyelocytic leukemia) developing fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates while on medical treatment. This is suggestive of APL differentiation syndrome, an adverse effect of all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA). The management involves glucocorticoids like dexamethasone.
Along with glucocorticoids, the other management of APL differentiation syndrome includes chemotherapy for cytoreduction and supportive measures. In severe cases, temporary discontinuation of ATRA is necessary.
ATRA is an oral drug that induces the differentiation of leukemic cells bearing the t(15;17) chromosomal translocation. While ATRA reduces the incidence of DIC associated with cytarabine and daunorubicin used earlier in APL, it can cause APL differentiation syndrome due to the adhesion of differentiated neoplastic cells to the pulmonary vasculature endothelium.
In low-risk APL patients with a low leukocyte count at presentation, a combination of ATRA and arsenic trioxide (ATO) has been found to be superior and is the current standard of care.
Solution to Question 19:
In the case of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), allogeneic stem cell transplants are the treatment of choice. His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is blood type O positive would be the best choice.
Other options:
Option A: An identical twin brother would not be the donor of choice. The therapeutic benefit of stem cell transplant in hematological malignancies is due to the graft-versus-leukemia (GvL).
Donor T lymphocytes attack malignant hematopoietic stem cells of the recipient that remain after high-dose chemotherapy. Despite having a low rate of graft versus host disease (GvHD), stem cells from an identical twin do not have a desirable degree of GvL effect, leading to higher rates of recurrence post-transplant.
Option B: Autologous (umbilical cord transplant) is not recommended as higher rates of relapse have been reported.
Option D: An HLA identical sibling is preferred over an unrelated HLA identical donor because there is a greater chance of matching for minor histocompatibility complex (mHC). This reduces the risk of GvHD. ABO compatibility is also important to consider, but a minor ABO mismatch (Rh mismatch) doesn't have any impact on hemolysis, graft-versus-host disease, or survival.
Solution to Question 20:
The highest incidence of T-ALL (T-cell acute lymphoblastic lymphoma) is at 10-19 years (adolescence) when the thymus reaches the maximum size.
On the other hand, B-ALL which is more common has a peak incidence at 3 years (1-10 years). At this age, the number of normal bone marrow pre-B cells (the cell of origin) is at its greatest.

Associated with GATA1 mutations.
Seen in 10% of neonates, resolves in first 3 months of life
Require close follow-up as 20-30% may develop AML by 3 years of life

Solution to Question 1:
Bone pain is the most common symptom in multiple myeloma.
Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy in which there is an increased proliferation of monoclonal plasma cells. There is an increased production of monoclonal paraprotein (M protein).
Clinical features of multiple myeloma:
Bone pain (most common):
Due to proliferation of tumor cells, activation of osteoclasts that destroy bone, and suppression f osteoblasts that form new bone.
Persistent localized pain in a patient with myeloma usually signifies a pathological fracture.
Fever due to recurrent bacterial infections (second most common)
Acute kidney injury due to:
Hypercalcemia (most common)
Amyloid deposits
Hyperuricemia
Recurrent infections
Infiltration of the kidney by myeloma cells
Normocytic-normochromic anemia due to:
Replacement of normal marrow by expanding tumor cells
Inhibition of hematopoiesis by factors made by the tumor
Reduced production of erythropoietin by the kidney
Myeloma defining events (MDE) include the presence of one or more features such as hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia and lytic bone lesions.
Solution to Question 2:
There is decreased anion gap in multiple myeloma due to the M protein. Anion gap in the serum is calculated as Na■ – (Cl– +HCO3–).
The M protein is cationic, resulting in the retention of chloride causing decreased anion gap.
Only 1% of patients with monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) go on to develop multiple myeloma. Hyperviscosity symptoms in multiple myeloma occurs due to excessive production of M proteins, usually of IgG3 or IgA subtype. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (IgM myeloma) is the most common cause for hyperviscosity syndrome due to excess IgM paraprotein in these cases.
Radioisotopic bone scanning is less useful in diagnosis because the bone lesions are lytic in nature and are rarely associated with osteoblastic new bone formation.
Solution to Question 3:
In this scenario, the patient has increased M protein (>30g/l), bone marrow clonal plasma cells >10%, and evidence of end-organ damage (fatiguability and back pain). The most likely diagnosis is multiple myeloma.
Diagnostic criteria for plasma cell disorders:
Note: Solitary plasmacytoma of bone has only a single area of bone destruction due to clonal plasma cells, no M protein, bone marrow appears normal, and no end-organ damage.
Plasma cell leukemia is an aggressive plasma cell proliferative disorder with >20% abnormal plasma cells in the peripheral blood.

Solution to Question 4:
Hypercalcemia is the most common cause of renal failure in multiple myeloma.
The second most common cause of renal failure in multiple myeloma is light chain cast nephropathy. The most common type of myeloma causing renal failure is light chain myeloma.
Mechanisms involved in acute kidney injury are:
Hypercalcemia
Amyloid deposits
Hyperuricemia
Recurrent infections
Infiltration of the kidney by myeloma cells
Tubular damage by excretion of light chains (Fanconi's syndrome)
Solution to Question 5:
In this patient with hypokalemia and urine pH of 5.1, type 2 renal tubular acidosis (adult Fanconi’s syndrome) is the likely diagnosis. It is commonly associated with multiple myeloma.
Normally, light chains are filtered, reabsorbed in the proximal tubules, and catabolized. In multiple myeloma, there is an increased amount of light chains and the tubular cells are overloaded.
This leads to proximal tubular damage either directly from light chain toxic effects or indirectly from the release of intracellular lysosomal enzymes.
Clinical features of renal tubular acidosis type 2:
Metabolic acidosis
Urine pH <5.3
Proteinuria (only light chains)
Glycosuria
Aminoaciduria
Alport's syndrome is characterised by hematuria, hearing loss and eye abnormalities.
Solution to Question 6:
The immunophenotype of tumor cells in multiple myeloma is CD38 and CD138.
Multiple myeloma is derived from plasma cells in which B cell markers (CD19, CD20) are lost.
Immunophenotype of tumor cells in lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma / Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia is CD19, CD20, surface IgM+, CD38. A lymphoplasmacytic cell retains B cell markers and carries plasma cell markers.
Solution to Question 7:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient most likely has multiple myeloma as there
are pathological fractures and elevated M protein. Serum M protein is likely to constitute IgG. The serum M component is IgG in 53% of patients, IgA in 25%, and IgD in 1%.
Serum IgM is elevated in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia (lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma).
Solution to Question 8:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has normal SPEP and clonal plasmacytosis. The most likely diagnosis is non-secretory myeloma.
Non-secretory myeloma is characterised by the absence of M protein in the serum or urine. Bone marrow clonal plasmacytosis > 10% and myeloma defining symptoms.
Option A: In multiple myeloma, SPEP demonstrates a sharp peak (church spire or M band) in the gamma globulin region, as shown below.

Option B: Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia) also demonstrates a localized peak (M band) in the gamma globulin region. Immunofixation is required to identify the type of immunoglobulin.
Option C: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) does not present with myeloma-defining symptoms. Clonal bone marrow cells will be less than 10%
Solution to Question 9:
Serum 2-microglobulin levels are the best modality to predict the median survival period.
Albumin levels alone cannot be used to predict the median survival period. It is used in combination with 2-microglobulin for risk stratification.
Patients with 2-microglobulin levels <3.5 mg/L and albumin levels > 3.5 g/dl have a median survival period of 5 years. Those with levels >3.5 mg/L and albumin < 3.5 g/dl have a survival period of fewer than 2 years.
Durie-Salmon staging is unable to predict outcomes with newer agents. Hence it is no longer used. Factors associated with poor prognosis:
Plasma cell labeling index
Chromosomal aberrations
Circulating plasma cells
Performance status
Highly elevated LDH
Extramedullary disease
De novo plasma cell leukemia

Solution to Question 11:
In the above clinical scenario, hypercalcemia along with the skull demonstrating typical 'punched out' lesions is characteristic of multiple myeloma. Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR are consistent with multiple myeloma.
Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone
and hypercalcemia. Signs and symptoms:
Bone pain is the most common symptom
Pathologic fractures
Recurrent bacterial infections
Renal failure
Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker f bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray. The lesions are purely osteolytic with little or no osteoblastic activity. Hence alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is normal. The most common site of lytic lesion in multiple myeloma is the vertebral column.
Electrophoresis: M spikes
Urinalysis: Bence Jones proteinuria
Bone marrow biopsy: Plasma cells
Solution to Question 12:
In the above clinical scenario, the symptoms and bone marrow biopsy are characteristic of multiple myeloma. Lenalidomide + bortezomib + dexamethasone is the treatment of choice in this condition.
This combination achieves close to a 100% response. Hence it is one of the preferred induction regimens in transplant-eligible multiple myeloma patients.
Other pharmacological agents are used as second-line and have a 90% response
rate. Chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation prolongs overall survival. The image below shows a bone marrow biopsy with an increased number of plasma cells.

Solution to Question 13:
Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor.
It has a rapid response and is effective in poor-prognosis myeloma. Side effects include neuropathy (both peripheral and autonomic). Subcutaneous and weekly administration can reduce neuropathic side effects.
Other proteasome inhibitors include carfilzomib (second-generation) and ixazomib, an oral proteasome inhibitor, used in relapsed disease.
Option A: Lenalidomide is an immunomodulatory analogue of thalidomide. Option B: Rituximab is an anti-CD-20 monoclonal antibody.
Option C: Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating chemotherapeutic agent.
Solution to Question 14:
In the above clinical scenario, the hyperviscosity symptoms and rouleaux formation on peripherals smear point to a diagnosis of Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia. It does not cause lytic bone lesions.
Waldenstrom's macroglöbulinemia is a B-cell malignancy affecting lymphoplasmacytoid and plasma cells. It is characterized by high levels of circulating IgM antibodies.
Clinical features include:
Hyperviscosity symptoms
Recurrent infections
Epistaxis
Visual disturbances
Peripheral neuropathy - due to myelin-associated glycoprotein causing demyelination.
Lymphadenopathy
Hepatosplenomegaly
Ophthalmoscopic examination may reveal vascular segmentation and dilation of the retinal veins.
Investigations:
Bone marrow shows >10% infiltration with lymphoplasmacytic cells
Serum M component is >30 g/L (3 g/dL). The size of the IgM paraprotein results in little renal excretion, and only 20% of patients excrete light chains.
The image below shows rouleaux formation.

Solution to Question 15:
The biopsy showing amyloid deposits stained by congo red, along with family history points to a diagnosis of familial amyloidosis (AF). It is most commonly due to the mutation of the transthyretin gene (TTR).
Amyloidosis is a group of protein misfolding disorders characterized by the accumulation of abnormal proteins called amyloid fibrils in various organs.
Solution to Question 16:
The patient has non-specific symptoms, which along with macroglossia and raccoon eyes are suggestive of amyloidosis.
Clinical features include:
Fatigue
Weight loss
Nephrotic range proteinuria due to renal amyloidosis and is associated with hypoalbuminemia
Cutaneous ecchymoses around the eyes are called the 'raccoon-eye' sign. Due to easy bruising as a result of amyloid deposits or deficiency of clotting factor X.
Solution to Question 17:
The kidneys are the most frequently involved organ in amyloidosis and are affected in 70–80% of patients.
The heart is the second most commonly affected organ (50–60% of patients).
The spleen is frequently involved, and there may be functional hyposplenism in the absence of significant splenomegaly.
Liver involvement causes cholestasis.
Macroglossia, a pathognomonic sign of AL amyloidosis is seen in only 10% of patients.
Solution to Question 18:
Cardiac disease is the leading cause of death from primary amyloidosis.

Solution to Question 1:
Exposure to a high dose of ionizing radiation is the only known risk factor for developing chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). This may be in the form of radiation therapy for malignancy or other conditions and nuclear accidents. It is dose-dependent and low-dose radiation exposure is not a risk factor.
There are no familial associations, infections, or toxins associated with the development of CML.
Solution to Question 2:
Philadelphia chromosome is a balanced translocation between the long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22. It is present in the majority of patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
In a balanced translocation, a part of one chromosome is shifted to another chromosome and vice versa. In this case, the ABL gene present in chromosome 9 is translocated next to the BCR gene (breakpoint cluster region) on chromosome 22. It leads to the formation of shortened chromosome 22, which has been named the Philadelphia chromosome after the place of discovery.

Solution to Question 3:
Splenomegaly is the most common physical examination finding in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
The majority of the patients with CML are asymptomatic. They are often incidentally diagnosed during routine blood tests when they have elevated white blood cells count. In later stages, the following clinical features develop:
Anemia - easy fatigability, exercise intolerance
Increased number of WBCs and platelets - hyperviscosity, leading to MI and stroke
Increased cell metabolism - night sweats, weight loss, and hyperuricemia (gout)
Splenomegaly - abdominal pain, early satiety
Hepatomegaly, lymphadenopathy, skin or subcutaneous lesions
Solution to Question 4:
Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is increased in polycythemia vera and leukemoid reactions.
The biochemical abnormalities in CML include:
Low LAP score
High levels of:
Vitamin B12
Uric acid
Lactic dehydrogenase
Lysozyme
Note: Leukemoid reaction refers to extreme elevations in WBC > 50,000/mm3 due to reactive causes outside the marrow. This includes severe infection, trauma, Down's syndrome.
Solution to Question 5:
Myelocytes will be predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear of the patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
The clinical hallmark of CML is the uncontrolled production of mature and maturing granulocytes. All of the stages of development of granulocytes can be noted on the peripheral smear in varying numbers:
Myeloblast - large cells with a round or oval nucleus, cytoplasm is dark and has no granules
Myelocyte - nucleus is oval and is eccentrically placed.
Metamyelocyte - nucleus is like a kidney bean-shaped
Band forms - nucleus is in the shape of C or U.
Segmented neutrophils- nucleus has 2-5 lobes.
All the cells except the myeloblast have a granular cytoplasm. Due to the varied appearance of the cells, it is called garden party appearance or college girl's appearance.

Solution to Question 6:
The image shows a left-shift with a predominance of segmented neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes that is suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Marrow blasts are usually < 5% in the majority of CML patients.

In CML, the following bone marrow findings are noted:
Markedly hypercellularity - due to increased granulocytic precursors
Myeloid: erythroid ratio (M/E ratio) is significantly increased
Megakaryocytes - normal or increased
Erythroid precursors - usually decreased
Sea blue histiocytes - macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm.
Bone marrow fibrosis may occur due to the deposition of reticulin.
Pseudo-Gaucher cells - macrophages with wrinkled tissue paper appearance, as shown below. Due to the increased turnover of the cells, there is an increased accumulation of glucocerebroside within the macrophages.

Solution to Question 7:
The initial treatment of choice in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is tyrosine kinase inhibitors. These include imatinib, nilotinib, dasatinib, bosutinib, and ponatinib.
Allogeneic stem cell transplant is considered in patients who are negative for Philadelphia chromosome, or who are non-responsive to the tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
Solution to Question 8:
Ponatinib is effective in patients with CML with T315I mutations. It is a third-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor.
The T315I mutation in BCR-ABL clones is specifically resistant to therapy with imatinib, dasatinib, nilotinib, and bosutinib but is sensitive to the third-generation agent ponatinib. It is also used in the treatment of accelerated and blast phases.
Solution to Question 9:
Hasford scoring system can be used to assess prognosis in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia
(CML).
The prognosis of CML can be assessed by:
Sokal score which is based on:
Age
Spleen size
Platelet count
Percentage of blast cells in the blood
Hasford score - Similar to Sokal score, but additionally uses the percentage of eosinophils and basophils in the blood
Option A: Rai and Binet staging system is used for staging chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
Option B: Ann Arbor staging system is used in Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas. Option D: Matutes scoring system is used for the diagnosis of CLL by flow cytometry.
Solution to Question 10:
A blast count  20% in peripheral blood is indicative of a blast crisis, not the accelerated phase of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
CML can be divided into three phases:
Chronic stable phase - Blasts < 10% in peripheral blood and bone marrow
Accelerated phase - any of the following:
Blasts comprising 10-19% of white blood cells (WBCs) in peripheral blood and/or bone marrow
Peripheral blood basophils 20%
Thrombocytopenia or thrombocytosis not responsive to therapy
Additional cytogenetic abnormalities in Philadelphia chromosome cells
Blast crisis:
Blasts  20% of peripheral blood WBCs or bone marrow
Extramedullary blast proliferation
Majority of the patients present in the chronic stable phase. Without effective treatment, CML in the chronic phase will eventually move into an accelerated phase at first and then into the blast phase.

The classical immunophenotypic feature seen in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is CD19+, CD20+, CD21+,CD22+, CD23+, CD5+. It is significant for coexpression of the B cell marker CD19 with the T cell marker CD5.
Mantle cell lymphoma has the same immunophenotype but with absent CD23.

Solution to Question 12:
The smear shows small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and the presence of a smudge cell. The most probable diagnosis is chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). Patients with CLL may have autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA).

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia/ small lymphocytic lymphoma refers to the monoclonal proliferation of mature B lymphocytes. It is more common in men than women. Increasing age and family history are important risk factors. CLL is one of the few leukemias not linked to radiation exposure.
The majority of the patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed during routine blood tests. Some patients may have painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Increased B cells may
produce autoantibodies leading to autoimmune complications like autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia (ITP).
Solution to Question 13:
Expectant management is the treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). This is because there is no clear survival benefit with chemotherapy in asymptomatic patients.
Chemotherapy and monoclonal antibodies are used in the presence of the following features:
Progressive marrow failure - worsening anemia, thrombocytopenia
Progressive splenomegaly
Progressive lymphadenopathy
Presence of constitutional symptoms like weight loss, fever, night sweats
Important drugs used in the management of CLL are fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, bendamustine, and rituximab.
Solution to Question 14:
Richter's syndrome is the transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) to aggressive lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL). It has a poor prognosis.
Patients develop the following features:
Fever, and weight loss
Rapidly enlarging lymph nodes
Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase
Lymphomas

Solution to Question 1:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma
(NHL) in adults and children over the age of 15 years, worldwide, and in India. Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common NHL in children under the age of 15 years.
Solution to Question 2:
Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is the etiological factor for primary effusion lymphoma, not Epstein-Barr virus.
Lymphoid malignancies associated with Epstein-Barr virus include:
Burkitt's lymphoma
Post-organ transplant lymphoma
Primary diffuse large B cell lymphoma of the CNS
Hodgkin's disease
Extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma, nasal type
Primary effusion lymphoma is a variant of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma that presents with pleural effusions, usually without apparent tumor mass lesions. It is most common in the setting
of immune deficiency disease, especially AIDS.
Solution to Question 3:
Burkitt lymphoma is a fast-growing, high-grade type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL).
NHL was earlier classified on the basis of its morphology and clinical behaviour. However, this classification is not currently used. Based on the clinical behavior, NHL is classified as:
Low grade - CLL/SLL (small lymphocytic lymphoma), follicular lymphoma
Intermediate grade - mantle cell and marginal cell lymphoma
High grade - diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), Burkitt's lymphoma
The most aggressive NHL is DLBCL, whereas the most rapidly progressive tumor is Burkitt's lymphoma. Most pediatric NHLs are high-grade and aggressive.
Solution to Question 4:
The gastrointestinal tract is the most common extranodal site in patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL). The stomach is most commonly involved, followed by the small intestine.
The skin is the second-most common site. Mycosis fungoides is a mature T-cell (CD4+) NHL with skin involvement with eventual visceral and nodal spread. When malignant T-cells in the skin enter circulation, it is called Sezary syndrome. It presents as erythroderma (diffuse erythema and scaling). Histologically, there are Sézary-Lutzner cells (with cerebriform nuclei) and Pautrier microabscesses in epidermis.
CNS is the most common extranodal site in patients with HIV infection. Primary CNS lymphoma
(histologically, DLBCL) is one of the AIDS-defining malignancies.
Solution to Question 5:
The prognosis of patients with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma is best assessed using the international Prognostic Index (IPI). It consists of 5 clinical risk factors for poor prognosis:
Age >60 years
Elevated levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
Performance status  2 (ECOG) or 70 (Karnofsky)
Ann Arbor stage III or IV
>1 site of extranodal involvement
Option A: Ann Arbor staging is used for anatomic staging to develop a treatment plan for Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Option B: Rai and Binet score is used for staging of CLL.
Option D: Hasford scoring is used to assess the prognosis of CML.

Solution to Question 7:
Translocations seen in Burkitt's lymphoma are t (8;14), t (2;8) and t (8;22).
Solution to Question 8:
This clinical scenario and the presence of centrocytes and centroblasts on biopsy are suggestive of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping will be positive for CD19, CD79a, CD20, CD10, CD23, Bcl-2.
Follicular lymphoma presents at a median age of 59 years with no sex predilection. The patients most commonly develop painless generalized lymphadenopathy. Systemic symptoms are absent. A lymph node biopsy is usually adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Characteristic features following lymph node biopsy include:
The normal nodal architecture is effaced by nodular expansions of tumour cells
Centrocytes - small lymphocytes with cleaved nuclei
Centroblasts - larger cells with vesicular chromatin and prominent nucleoli
Solution to Question 9:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) commonly (>50%) presents with extranodal involvement at diagnosis, with the most common sites being the GI tract and bone marrow.
DLBCL is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is a high-grade aggressive tumour. It is associated with BCL-6 chromosomal rearrangements and t(14;18). It is commonly associated with CNS lymphoma, pleural effusion lymphoma, and intravascular lymphoma. It is considered
an AIDS-defining malignancy.
AIDS-defining malignancies include:
Kaposi sarcoma
Primary central nervous system lymphoma (DLBCL)
Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
Invasive cervical cancer
Solution to Question 10:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of the endemic type of Burkitt's lymphoma. In this condition, the tumor cells are CD21+.
Burkitt's lymphoma is an aggressive condition and is the most common NHL in children. This condition is endemic in African countries and is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. It is associated with c-myc dysregulation, especially in cases in bone marrow involvement.
Patients require aggressive management with high-dose chemotherapy.
Solution to Question 11:
The given image shows the characteristic starry sky appearance of Burkitt's lymphoma. The reactive macrophages (labelled as A) represent the stars in starry sky appearance. On the other hand, the homogenous tumour cells (labelled as B) represent the sky.
The neoplastic cells are homogeneous, medium-sized B cells with a high growth fraction. These cells are positive for CD19, CD10, BCL-6 & CD43.
Reactive macrophages are scattered throughout the tumour. Their pale cytoplasm in a background of blue-staining tumour cells gives the tumor a so-called starry sky appearance. Reactive leukocytes and macrophages are not stained by special stains. They are positive for CD14, CD40, CD11b & CD64.
The growth fraction of these lymphomas is very high, with frequent mitotic figures. The fraction of Ki-67+ (MIB-1+) stained cells is nearly 100%.
Solution to Question 12:
Sjogren's syndrome is implicated in salivary gland MALToma.
MALT lymphomas are commonly associated with an underlying autoimmune or inflammatory process such as:
Sjogren’s syndrome - salivary gland
Hashimoto’s thyroiditis - thyroid
Helicobacter pylori gastritis - gastric (most common)
Celiac disease - small intestine
The most common translocation associated with MALToma is (11,18). It has a good prognosis.
Solution to Question 13:
Hairy cell leukemia arises from a late, activated memory B cell exhibiting post-germinal center features.
Mycosis fungoides and anaplastic large cell lymphoma (also called null cell lymphoma) are both T-cell lymphomas.
Solution to Question 14:
The given peripheral smear shows tumor cells with multilobulated nuclei called cloverleaf or flower cells. This is characteristic of adult T-Cell leukemia/lymphoma.
This condition occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to one year following diagnosis. It is characterized by the following clinical features:
Skin lesions
Generalized lymphadenopathy
Hepatosplenomegaly
Peripheral blood lymphocytosis,
Hypercalcemia
Solution to Question 15:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy cell leukemia (HCL).
In this condition, most patients present with symptoms related to cytopenias or splenomegaly. On bone marrow aspiration, a dry tap is obtained due to HCL-induced marrow fibrosis and the interlocking cell borders of hairy cells (distinct from myelofibrosis).
Tumor cells share certain characteristics of memory B cells. CD11c, CD25, CD103, CD123 is the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic of this condition. Pan-B markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22 may also be positive.
Note: Splenic marginal zone lymphoma involves both white and red pulp of the spleen, whereas hairy cell leukemia is limited to the red pulp. All non-Hodgkin's lymphomas involve white pulp of spleen except:
Hairy cell leukemia
Hepatosplenic lymphoma
Solution to Question 16:
Annexin A1 on immunophenotyping of bone marrow specimens is the best method to differentiate hairy cell leukemia from other B-cell malignancies. It has 100% sensitivity and specificity.
Hairy cells on Wright-stained peripheral blood smear are an important diagnostic finding. Typical hairy cells are mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with elongated (hairy) projections. Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies called ribosome-lamellar complexes can also be seen in 50% of cases. However, these can be seen in other B-cell disorders also.
Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain is an important tool and is positive in 95% of cases of hairy cell leukemia. However, it is not pathognomonic.
The following pattern of bone marrow involvement is near to pathognomonic for hairy cell leukemia (>99%):
Diffuse infiltration of tumor cells with honeycomb appearance.
Individual cells have a fried egg appearance such that the nucleus of each hairy cell is surrounded by a halo of cytoplasm, as shown below.

Solution to Question 17:
Hairy cell leukemia is associated with infections of Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare. This is possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia. Among them, infection with Mycobacterium kansasii is common.
Solution to Question 18:
The given image shows mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with elongated (hairy) projections, which are TRAP-positive. This clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy cell leukemia. The drug of choice is cladribine.
Hairy cell leukemia is responsive to chemotherapy with interferon , pentostatin, and cladribine. However, cladribine is the preferred drug of choice due to complete remission in the majority of patients, and higher rates of long-term disease-free survival. It is administered daily for 7 days by continuous intravenous infusion.
Chemotherapy-refractory patients have responded to vemurafenib, a BRAF inhibitor. Splenectomy is often associated with prolonged remission.
Solution to Question 19:
The most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma in India is the mixed cellularity classical Hodgkin's lymphoma. In contrast, nodular sclerosis is most commonly seen in western countries.
The most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma in:
Developed/ western countries - nodular sclerosing
Children - mixed cellularity
Females - nodular sclerosis (but Hodgkin's lymphoma is more common in males overall)
HIV-associated - mixed cellularity
EBV-associated - lymphocyte-depleted

Solution to Question 21:
Supraclavicular or cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common clinical presentation of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
The clinical features of Hodgkin's lymphoma are as follows:
Asymptomatic lymphadenopathy (non-tender with a rubbery consistency) is the most common presentation.
Most common - cervical or supraclavicular
Second-most common presentation - mediastinal mass
Hepatosplenomegaly in some cases
Pel-Ebstein fever:
Refers to recurrent febrile and afebrile intervals, each phase lasting for days to weeks
More common in older patients with mixed-cellularity Hodgkin’s lymphoma in an abdominal site
Alcohol-induced pain is a rare, unusual presentation
Solution to Question 22:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Hodgkin's lymphoma. The paraneoplastic syndrome associated with this condition is subacute cerebellar degeneration.
Other paraneoplastic syndromes associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma include:
Minimal change disease (nephrotic syndrome)
Vanishing bile duct syndrome
Cholangitis
Alcohol-induced pain - pain typically occurs within a few minutes after the ingestion of even a small amount of alcohol and is localized to areas involved by HL
Option A: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion is associated with small cell lung carcinoma of the lungs.
Option B: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is associated with small cell lung carcinoma of the lungs.
Option D: Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) is associated with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas and lungs.

Solution to Question 24:
PET-CT is the most reliable technique for staging Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Reed-Sternberg cells on histology, point to a clinical diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma. However, they are not specific for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Reed-Sternberg cells can also be seen in the following conditions:
Infectious mononucleosis
Solid tissue cancers
Large cell non-Hodgkin's lymphomas (most common in immunoblastic type)
Classical Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with positive test results for CD15 and CD30. Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with CD20 positive cells.
The central nervous system (CNS) is an uncommon site of extranodal disease in Hodgkin's lymphoma. Lung, liver, bone, and bone marrow are the most common extranodal sites for the disease.
Solution to Question 25:
In this scenario of Hodgkin's lymphoma, the patient presented with B symptoms (fever, night sweats, and weight loss) and shows lymph node involvement on both sides of the diaphragm are involved (supraclavicular and inguinal). According to Ann Arbor Staging, this patient is categorized as stage IIIB.

Solution to Question 26:
In this patient with advanced-stage Hodgkin's lymphoma, his age, gender, and absolute lymphocyte count all indicate poor prognosis.
Unfavourable or poor prognostic factors for advanced-stage HL (stages III and IV) include:
Age > 45 years
Male gender
Haemoglobin (Hb) < 10.5 g/dL
Serum albumin <4 g/dL
White blood cell (WBC) count 15,000/ µL
Absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) < 600/ µL
Unfavourable or poor prognostic factors for early Hodgkin's lymphoma (stages I and II) include:
Large mediastinal lymphadenopathy
Involvement of 4 or more sites
Age >45
ESR > 30 mm/hr
B symptoms - unexplained fever, night sweats or unexplained weight loss
The selection of initial treatment for Hodgkin's lymphoma is usually based on presenting stage and prognostic factors.
Solution to Question 27:
The patient's age (> 45 years) and presence of B symptoms indicate an unfavourable prognosis. The treatment of choice in early-stage Hodgkin's lymphoma (stage I and II) with an unfavourable prognosis is ABVD regimen along with field radiation. ABVD is a combination of doxorubicin (adriamycin), bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine.
The treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma is as follows:
Early Hodgkin's lymphoma (favourable and unfavourable) - ABVD regimen + limited field radiation
Advanced Hodgkin's lymphoma - extended course of chemotherapy with ABVD regimen. The side effects of this treatment include:
Doxorubicin - dilated cardiomyopathy
Bleomycin- interstitial lung disease
Vinblastine - SIADH, Peripheral neuropathy
Radiation - hypothyroidism, Lhermitte's syndrome, infertility
Note: R-CHOP regimen is used in the treatment of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is composed of rituximab + cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine (oncovin) and prednisone.

Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is the etiological agent for lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma/ Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.

and Burkitt's lymphoma.

Gastric MALToma/extranodal marginal cell lymphoma - induced by Helicobacter pylori infection
Intestinal T-cell lymphomas/enteropathy-associated T cell lymphoma - induced by gluten-sensitive enteropathy
Anaplastic large cell lymphoma in scar tissue - can occur following breast implants

Solution to Question 2:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation is associated with prolonged PT and prolonged aPTT. Conditions with prolonged aPTT can be classified on the basis of the bleeding symptoms:
No bleeding symptoms: deficiency of Factor XII, prekallikrein, HMW kininogen, lupus anticoagulant
Mild bleeding symptoms: Factor XI deficiency
Severe bleeding symptoms: Hemophilia, von Willebrand diseas
Lupus anticoagulant is an antiphospholipid antibody that interferes with aPTT test and causes its prolongation. It is corrected by adding excess phospholipid.
The clinical manifestation of lupus anticoagulant is thrombosis. Confirmatory tests are dilute Russell's viper venom test and kaolin clotting time.

Fibrinogen (factor I)

Factor IX
Factor X
Factor XI
Factor VIII is produced in the endothelial cells and factor XIII A-subunit is produced in the bon marrow.

Acquired deficiencies of plasma coagulation factors are more frequent than congenital disorders. The most common acquired disorders include:
Hemorrhagic diathesis of liver diseas
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
Vitamin K deficiency.
H mophilia A is the most common inherited disorder of coagulation. Hemophilia A is mor common than Hemophilia B.

Solution to Question 6:
Recurrent hemarthrosis is the most common bleeding manifestation of severe
hemophilia. Hemophilia is said to be severe when the residual activity of factor VIII is <1%.
H mophilia is an X-linked recessive hemorrhagic disorder and is caused by mutations in either the F8 gene (hemophilia A or classic hemophilia) or the F9 gene (hemophilia B). Clinically, it is impossible to distinguish between hemophilia A and hemophilia B as they present with similar symptoms. It can be classified based on residual activity of FVIII or FIX as severe (<1%), moderate (1–5%), or mild (6–30% )
H mophilia presents early in life- bleeding after circumcision or when beginning to walk or crawl. Clinical features:
Acute hemarthrosis:
Local pain, swelling
Erythema
Muscle contractures due to fixed positioning.
Chronic hemarthrosis:
Synovial thickening
Synovitis (due to intraarticular blood)
The most common joint affected is the knee. One joint is affected more than the other. This is called the target joint. Muscle hematomas can lead to compartment syndromes.
H maturia is common but self-limited. Life-threatening bleeds such as bleeding into oropharyngeal spaces, CNS, and retroperitoneum can occur.
Treatment: Without treatment, severe hemophilia may limit life expectancy. Factor replacement for hemophilia has been the mainstay of therapy.
FVIII dose (IU) = Target FVIII levels – FVIII baseline levels × body weight (kg) × 0.5 unit/kg .
FIX dose (IU) = Target FIX levels – FIX baseline levels × body weight (kg) × 1 unit/kg
The FVIII half-life of 8–12 h requires injections twice a day to maintain therapeutic levels, whereas the FIX half-life is longer, ~24 h so that once-a-day injection is sufficient.

H mophilia A has decreased factor VIII activity and hemophilia B has decreased factor IX activity. Note: Prolonged bleeding time, normal PT, prolonged aPTT is seen in von Willebrand disease.

Acquired hemophilia A occurs predominantly in older adults (median age- 60 years). It occasionally occurs in pregnant or postpartum women.
It is an acquired immune-mediated disease characterized by autoantibodies against clotting factor
VIII. It is associated with an underlying disease in 50% of patients. They include:
Malignancies - lymphomas, prostate cancer
Dermatologic diseases - pemphigoid

One unit of factor VIII/kg body weight increases the plasma levels of factor VIII levels by 2%. Therefore, for a rise in 1 % in the plasma, half unit/ kg will be required, that is 0.5 units/kg.
It is used in the treatment of hemophilia. One unit of FVIII is the amount of FVIII in 1 mL of plasma.
The dose required for replacement is calculated as :
Factor VIII dose = (Target factor VIII levels - baseline factor VIII levels) x bodyweight x 0.5 units/ kg
Factor IX (IU) = (Target FIX levels – FIX baseline levels) x bodyweight (kg) x 1 unit/kg
Cryoprecipitate is used when factor concentrates are not available. Each bag of cryoprecipitate contains 80 IU of Factor VIII.

Solution to Question 11:
Bethesda assay is the best test for the confirmation of factor VIII inhibitors.
The formation of inhibitor/ alloantibodies to FVIII or FIX is the major complication of hemophilia treatment. When this happens, patients do not respond to factor replacement at therapeutic doses.
aPTT measurement is done on a mixed sample. It is used to determine the presence of factor VIII inhibitors. aPTT is estimated using a 1:1 mix of patient's plasma and normal plasma. It is interpreted as:
In hemophilia, aPTT is corrected with a 1:1 mix.
In patients with inhibitors, aPTT with 1:1 mix is abnormally prolonged (inhibitor neutralizes th normal factors).
Bethesda assay is based on the same principle but is superior because it helps to quantify the type and specificity of the inhibitor.

Solution to Question 12:
In disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC), fibrinogen levels are decreased due to increased bleeding.
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acquired syndrome characterized by the widespread activation of blood clotting factors within blood vessels, resulting in a loss of clotting control. The primary mechanism of DIC involves the uncontrolled generation of thrombin through multiple pathways which leads to sustained coagulation activation, the formation of fibrin, and the consumption of clotting factors and platelets.
Infections are the most frequent cause of DIC. Laboratory investigations in DIC:
Decreased platelet count
Prolonged PT/TT
Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
Decreased fibrinogen
Elevated fibrin degradation products (D-dimers)
Peripheral smear: microangiopathic hemolytic anemia in DIC with schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells)
The treatment involves platelet transfusion when platelet counts are below 10,000-20,000/L. Replacement of fibrinogen and coagulation factors is with fresh frozen plasma (FFP) along with cryoprecipitate or fibrinogen concentrate.
In cases of low-grade DIC associated with solid tumors or acute promyelocytic leukemia low doses of continuous-infusion heparin has been effective.
Solution to Question 13:
Acute pancreatitis can cause disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) not chronic pancreatitis.
Common causes of DIC:
Sepsis- gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, viral, mycotic, parasitic, rickettsial
Acute pancreatitis
Trauma, burns
Malignancies- acute promyelocytic leukemia, adenocarcinoma of pancreas and prostat
Obstetric- abruptio placentae, amniotic fluid embolism, and septic abortion
Snakebit

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a condition characterized by widespread intravascular fibrin formation. The central mechanism is the uncontrolled generation of thrombin by exposure of blood to pathologic levels of tissue factor.

Solution to Question 16:
This patient presents with petechiae, and abdominal distension with schistocytes and thrombocytopenia. This in child most likely has Kasabach-Merritt syndrome (secondary DIC). His abdominal mass is likely to be a hepatic hemangioma.
Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is a life-threatening complication that occurs in patients with giant hemangiomas. It is most commonly seen in infants.
Clinical features:
Enlarged abdomen
Hepatomegaly or jaundic
Petechiae, bruising, and frank bleeding
Painful lesions
Anemia
It is characterized by profound thrombocytopenia and consumptive coagulopathy leading to a DIC-like picture.
Other options:
Option A: Neuroblastomas are tumors of the sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla that are derived from primordial neural crest cells. It is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood and the most frequently diagnosed tumor in infancy. Brain tumors are the most common solid tumors in childhood. They present as a flank mass that crosses the midline.
Option B: Hepatoblastoma is the most common childhood liver tumor. Histologically it is composed of small polygonal embryonal cells forming trabeculae, acini, or papillary structures in the developing liver.
Option C: Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor in children and is the second most common malignant abdominal tumor in children. The clinical presentation usually involves an asymptomatic unilateral abdominal mass, hypertension, abdominal pain, and gross painless hematuria. Constitutional symptoms of fever, anorexia, and weight loss can also be present at the time of diagnosis.
Solution to Question 17:
Spontaneous bleeding is not seen in protein C deficiency. It is characterised by an increased tendency for thrombus formation.
Protein C deficiency is a rare genetic disorder. It predisposes to the following thrombotic complications:
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT):
Adults with a mild form of the disease at higher risk of developing venous thromboembolism.
Purpura fulminans:
Severe form of DIC
Thrombosis of extensive areas of the skin
Affects predominantly young children following viral or bacterial infection.
Warfarin-induced skin necrosis:
Rare complication seen in patients with congenital or acquired deficiencies of protein C or S.
Thrombosis of the skin leads to well-demarcated erythematous lesions with central necrosis on the thighs, buttocks, breasts, or toes(shown below).

Solution to Question 18:
The anticoagulant effect of heparin can be monitored using anti-factor Xa level and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). aPTT is prolonged as heparin inhibits intrinsic pathway factors.
Prothrombin time and INR are used to monitor the anticoagulant effect of warfarin (inhibits vitamin K dependent factor II, VII, IX, X. Factor VII has the shortest half-life).
No monitoring is required with the use of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and fondaparinux.
Solution to Question 19:
Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) has a lower risk of bleeding than heparin.
In contrast to heparin which requires monitoring by aPTT and anti-factorXa, laboratory monitoring is not required for LMWH. It is also associated with lower risk of heparin induced thrombocytopenia.
Examples of LMWH:
Dalteparin
Enoxaparin
Tinzaparin
Nadroparin
Protamine sulphate is the only clinically approved antidote for unfractionated heparin. Protamine sulphate is only partially effective against low molecular weight heparin.

Apixaban and edoxaban are a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC) that inhibits factor Xa. Abciximab is an antiplatelet drug that inhibits Gp IIb-IIIa receptor.
Solution to Question 21:
Serotonin release assay is the most specific test for the diagnosis of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).
HIT is commonly diagnosed clinically by means of 4T scoring (Thrombocytopenia, Timing of platelet count fall, Thrombosis, Other causes for Thrombocytopenia).
Serotonin release assay is performed by quantifying serotonin release.
Platelets loaded with labeled serotonin are exposed to patient serum in the absence or presence of varying concentrations of heparin. If the patient serum contains the HIT antibody, heparin addition induces platelet activation and serotonin release.
Enzyme-linked assays such as platelet activation assay and heparin-PF-4 complex antibody assay are sensitive but not specific for HIT.

In the above clinical scenario, the patient requires direct thrombin inhibitors for the treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Argatroban is safe in renal disease.

Argatroban - hepatic clearance, approved for the treatment of HIT
Lepirudin - renal clearance, contraindicated in renal diseas
Bivalirudin- renal clearance, contraindicated in renal disease, shortest half-lif
Fondaparinux is a factor Xa inhibitor. It is contraindicated in renal disease because it has renal clearance.
Solution to Question 23:
Patients on warfarin who present with severe bleeding are treated with both IV infusion of vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma regardless of the INR.
Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that blocks the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase.
This inhibits factors II, VII, IX, and X, proteins C and S. This can cause an initial procoagulant state.
Since the anticoagulant action of warfarin takes 2-3 days, patients require concomitant treatment (bridging therapy) with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant (heparin, LMWH or fondaparinux) for at least 5 days.
Warfarin has a narrow therapeutic window, hence all patients on warfarin should have their INR determined every 3–4 weeks. The most common side effect of warfarin is bleeding.

Solution to Question 1:
The hemoglobin tetramer is highly soluble in the plasma. However, individual globin chains are insoluble. Unpaired globin precipitates can form inclusions that damage the cell and trigger apoptosis.
Each hemoglobin molecule consists of a tetramer of globin polypeptide chains. This includes a pair of -like chains and a pair of -like chains. Each globin chain enfolds a single heme moiety. Heme consists of a protoporphyrin IX ring complexed with a single iron atom in the ferrous state (Fe2+). Each heme moiety can bind one O2 molecule.
The common forms of hemoglobin include:
HbA (22): Major adult hemoglobin
HbF (22): Fetal hemoglobin
HbA2 (22): Minor adult hemoglobin
Solution to Question 2:
Patients with -thalassemia are susceptible to infection with Plasmodium vivax.
Thalassemia provides natural protection against infection with the more lethal Plasmodium falciparum. There is no conclusive evidence on the relationship between alpha thalassemia and P. malariae or P. ovale infection.
Conditions protective against Plasmodium falciparum include:
Sickle cell trait
Hemoglobin C
Hemoglobin SC

Solution to Question 4:
The features of multiple episodes of acute severe pain in fingers and toes with spontaneous resolution are suggestive of dactylitis (hand-foot syndrome), which usually occurs in sickle cell anemia.
The sickled RBCs have a sticking tendency towards the endothelium of the small venules. These abnormalities provoke unpredictable episodes of vaso-occlusion. Dactylitis is characterized by severe pain affecting the bones of the hands, feet, or both. It is often the first symptom of sickle cell anemia in children.

Solution to Question 8:
Hb M Iwata causes congenital methemoglobinemia.
Methemoglobin is generated by oxidation of the heme iron moieties to the ferric state, causing a characteristic bluish-brown muddy color resembling cyanosis. Methemoglobin has such high oxygen affinity that virtually no oxygen is delivered. Levels >50–60% are often fatal.
Congenital methemoglobinemia arises from globin mutations that stabilize iron in the ferric state (HbM Iwata) or mutations that impair the enzymes that reduce methemoglobin to hemoglobin (methemoglobin reductase, NADP diaphorase).
Acquired methemoglobinemia is caused by toxins that oxidize heme iron such as:
Chloroquine
Dapsone
Sulfonamides
Nitroglycerin
The following image shows chocolate-brown discoloration of blood in methemoglobinemia.

Solution to Question 1:
The blood group 'antigen A' is composed of N-acetyl galactosamine attached to the H substance.
H substance is formed by the addition of fucose to the glycolipid or glycoprotein backbone. It is present in all blood groups, even the O group.
A antigen = N-acetyl galactosamine + H substance
B antigen = galactose + H substance
However, in case of the Bombay phenotype, RBCs lack H antigen. Hence, these individuals have anti-A, anti-B, and anti-H antibodies. The only compatible blood donor is another person with the Bombay blood group.

The genes that determine the A and B blood groups are located on chromosome 9. The phenotypes are expressed in the Mendelian codominant manner.
Rh genes determining Rh blood grouping are present on chromosome 1.

Solution to Question 6:

Solution to Question 7:
Cryoprecipitate does not contain factor IX. Hence, it is not useful for the management of patients with Christmas disease, which occurs due to deficiency of factor IX.
Components of cryoprecipitate are:
Factor VIII
Factor XIII
Fibrinogen
Fibronectin
Von Willebrand factor
Therefore it can be used in patients with hemophilia A, factor XIII deficiency, hypofibrinogenemia, and von Willebrand disease.
Solution to Question 8:
The threshold for prophylactic platelet transfusion is 10,000/L in order to prevent spontaneous bleeding. If the patient is planned for any invasive procedures, the target platelet level is 50,000/L.
The shelf life of donor platelets is 5 days. It is stored on a special agitator at 20-24 °C. The half-life of transfused platelets is 3-5 days. One unit of pooled platelets should be transfused within 30 minutes because of the risk of bacterial proliferation.
Solution to Question 9:
Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is an acellular component and generally does not transmit viral infections.
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infects >50% of the general population and is transmitted by infected passenger WBCs in transfused PRBCs or platelet components. Cellular components that are leukocyte-reduced have a decreased risk of transmitting CMV.
Infectious complications of blood transfusion include:
Viral infections: Hepatitis C virus, hepatitis B virus, HIV, cytomegalovirus
Bacterial contamination: sudden and fulminant onset of fever, chills, septic shock, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
Platelet concentrates stored at room temperature: gram-positive and coagulase-negative staphylococci
PRBCs: Gram-negative bacteria like Yersinia, Pseudomonas, Serratia, Acinetobacter, and Escherichia species
Parasites: Malaria, Babesiosis, Chaga's disease
Others: Creutzfeldt–›akob disease (C›D)
Solution to Question 10:
Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR) is the most frequently occurring transfusion reaction.
Solution to Question 11:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR).
Solution to Question 12:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR). It is due to an anamnestic antibody response. This refers to the rapid production of antibodies in the blood after exposure to an antigen to which the recipient had been previously sensitized.
Solution to Question 13:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is the most common cause of transfusion-related fatalities.
TRALI is due to the presence of anti-HLA class II antibodies in the donor plasma. These antibodies bind recipient leukocytes, which aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. Multiparous women are frequently implicated donors. Recipients with a history of liver disease, smoking, alcohol use are at a higher risk.
It occurs within 6 hours of transfusion and results in hypoxia and signs of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema with bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray. It is managed with supportive care.
Note: According to the latest edition of Harrison's, transfusion associated circulatory overload
(TACO) is the leading cause of death followed by TRALI.
Solution to Question 14:
Massive transfusion is defined as transfusion of at least 10 units of red cells in 24 hours or 4 units in 1 hour. Hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, is a complication of massive blood transfusion.
Blood is anticoagulated with sodium citrate and citric acid. It binds to calcium and magnesium, leading to low levels of both. Citrate is also metabolized to bicarbonate, causing metabolic alkalosis.
Solution to Question 15:
The patient is being transfused blood and has complaints of backache, this is suggestive of an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction.
The first step is to stop transfusion immediately and then collect blood samples for testing.
Acute hemolytic transfusion reactions typically occur within the first 24 hours following a blood transfusion, primarily due to ABO incompatibility.
It presents with symptoms such as hypotension, tachypnea, tachycardia, fever (1-2°C increase in temperature), chills, chest and back pain, hemoglobinuria, and hemoglobinemia. In severe cases, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), acute renal failure, shock, and death can occur.
Management of immune-mediated acute hemolytic transfusion reactions is to provide supportive care, administer vigorous hydration with isotonic saline and use diuretics to maintain urine output.
Solution to Question 16:
Among the given options, the metabolic abnormality seen in a patient who has received multiple blood transfusions is metabolic alkalosis.
This is because the excess sodium citrate (anticoagulant) in the transfused blood gets converted to bicarbonate leading to metabolic alkalosis. Each mmol of citrate generates 3 mEq of bicarbonate (a total of 23 mEq of bicarbonate due to each unit of blood).
Metabolic acidosis can also be seen in multiple blood transfusions as citrate is acidic, but metabolic alkalosis is more common.

Solution to Question 1:
The time interval between primary HIV infection and the manifestation of AIDS is 10 years.

After exposure to the HIV virus, there occurs primary infection following an incubation period of 2-4 weeks, which is usually symptomatic in more than 50% of cases, following 3-6 weeks there is acute HIV syndrome due to wide dissemination of the virus, characterized by fever, sore throat, diarrhea, lymphadenopathy, and rash.
This peak viremia drops as the immune response develops, to reach a plateau about 3 months later. Following this there is a prolonged period of clinical latency, during which infected individuals are asymptomatic, lasting for a median of 10 years.
Following this period, chronic persistent infection develops which is the hallmark of HIV disease called Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
Long-term non-progressors: a small part of untreated HIV-infected people with CD4 counts within the reference range for >10 years.
Elite controllers: Some long-term non-progressors have undetectable viral loads.
Solution to Question 2:
Blood transfusion carries the highest risk of acquiring HIV. Salient features of transmission of HIV:
The highest risk of acquiring HIV from an infected source is via blood transfusion > needle sharing during drug abuse > receptive anal intercourse > needle-stick injury > vaginal & oral sexual intercourse.
The most common mode of transmission worldwide is sexual transmission (heterosexual in India) > mother to child > least common modes are blood transfusion & needle-stick injury.
Male to female transmission > female to male transmission.
Viral load is highest in blood > semen > vaginal fluid > breastmilk & saliva and minimal to absent in tears, sweat & urine.
Solution to Question 3:
HIV-1 subtype C is the most common form worldwide.
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) has two serotypes HIV-1 and HIV- 2 based on differences in the env (envelope) gene.
HIV-1 is further divided into 4 distinct groups, group M (major)/N/O/P. The M group comprises nine subtypes A, B, C, D, F, G, H, J, and K.
Subtype C is the most common form worldwide & is more associated with heterosexual transmission.
Subtype B is more associated with spread through blood and homosexual contact.
Options A, C: HIV- 2 is less pathogenic than HIV-1 and is predominantly confined to Africa. Option D: Donated blood is screened for both HIV -1 & HIV-2.
Solution to Question 4:
CCR 5 delta 32 mutation causes resistance to HIV infection. It is a mutated allele that causes a lack of surface expression of the CCR5 co-receptor resulting in blockade of HIV entry and
resistance to HIV infection.
Homozygous alleles cause complete resistance to HIV infection & heterozygous alleles cause partial resistance.
CXCR4 and CCR5 are chemokine receptors (co-receptors) present on the surface of CD4+ T-helper cells & macrophages that aid in the fusion and entry of the HIV virus.
DC-SIGN is a type of cell surface lectin receptor to which the HIV virus has the affinity to bind. The expression of this type of receptor on dendritic cells (antigen-presenting cells) enhances the infectivity of HIV.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute HIV syndrome. The virus is transmissible during this early infection period.
It is characterized by acute burst of viremia and wide virus dissemination and seeding of lymphoid organs (e.g., gut-associated lymphoid tissue), culminating in the destruction of CD4+ cells.
The p24 antigen capture assay is used as a screening test for HIV infection in patients suspected of having the acute HIV syndrome.
Option A: The incubation period for acute HIV syndrome is around 3 to 6 weeks.
Option B: The acute HIV syndrome is typical of an acute viral syndrome and is very similar to acute infectious mononucleosis. The clinical findings include fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy. Rash, headache, arthralgia, and anorexia/weight loss can also be seen.
Option D: Opportunistic infections can occur during this stage of infection, reflecting the immunodeficiency that results from reduced numbers of CD4+T cells.
Solution to Question 6:
Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement in an HIV-infected child is categorized as stage 2 of HIV disease according to WHO staging.

Solution to Question 7:
Oral candidiasis (thrush) is categorized as WHO stage 3.
Oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia are oral lesions categorized as WHO clinical stage 3. They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/L.

Solution to Question 8:
Tuberculosisis the most common opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals globally and in India.
In patients with relatively high CD4+ T cell counts, the typical pattern of pulmonary reactivation occurs (60–80%). In patients with lower CD4+ T cell counts, disseminated disease is seen.
Primary prophylaxis: Isoniazid and pyridoxine for 9 months for HIV-infected individuals meeting the following conditions:
PPD skin-test reaction of >5 mm or,
Positive IFN- release assay or,
Close household contacts of persons with active tuberculosis
Solution to Question 9:
Concurrent treatment with anti-retroviral therapy is the most likely explanation in this case resulting in Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS). Its characteristics are:
Temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms (lymphadenopathy, fever or worsening of pulmonary infiltrations, pleural effusion) and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ART. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT.
It is seen weeks to months following the initiation of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART).
It is most common in previously untreated patients starting therapy with a CD4+ T cell count
<50/L who experience a sudden drop in viral load.
The earlier ART is started and the lower the baseline CD4+ T-cell count, the greater the risk of IRIS.
In severe cases, the use of immunosuppressive drugs such as glucocorticoids may be required to blunt the inflammatory component of IRIS while specific antimicrobial therapy takes effect.
Note: Hypersensitivity to isoniazid is extremely rare and the presentation includes maculopapular rash.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario, along with a positive Kernig's sign, is suggestive of meningitis. Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/L.
Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated (yeast colonies obstruct the free flow of CSF causing increased CSF pressure).
The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with india ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination (CrAg).
Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/L.
Treatment:
Induction - IV or liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
Maintenance - Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/L fo 6 months in response to cART.
Solution to Question 11:
Melanoma is not an AIDS-defining malignancy.
AIDS-defining malignancies are those cancers that a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infected person is at a high risk of developing. When a HIV-infected person develops one of the AIDS-defining malignancies it suggests that he has AIDS.
AIDS-defining malignancies include the following:
Kaposi sarcoma - It is a multicentric neoplasm of vascular origin and has a strong association with HHV - 8.
Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
Invasive cervical cance
Given below is the image of kaposi sarcoma:

Note : The FDA has approved pomalidomide, a thalidomide analogue to be included in treating adult patients with AIDS-related Kaposi's sarcoma after failure of highly active antiretroviral therapy and Kaposi's sarcoma in adult patients who are HIV-negative.
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacillary angiomatosis in an immunocompromised patient. Warthin-Starry stain would show Bartonella henselae as the causative organism in these skin lesions.
Bacillary angiomatosis is an infectious vascular proliferative lesion presenting as reddish-purple nodules similar to KS lesions (caused by HHV-8). The diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The drug of choice for treatment is erythromycin.
The image given below shows the Warthin-Starry stained lesion showing tangled pleomorphic bacilli.

Option B: HHV 8 is strongly associated with Kaposi sarcoma. Option C: Bartonella bacilliformis causes Oroya fever.
Option D: EBV causes infectious mononucleosis.
Note: Bartonella henselae causes cat-scratch disease, a necrotizing granulomatous disorder of lymph nodes, in immunocompetent hosts.
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. MRI scan shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions.
Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/L. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts.
It usually has multiple lesions in multiple locations which are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring; this so-called eccentric target sign is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is also present.
Treatment includes sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks.
Primary prophylaxis: It is given to patients with IgG antibody to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/L. A single double strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given.
Secondary prophyaxis/maintanace therapy: It is given when CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/L. Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin is given. It is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are maintained >200/L for 6 months.
Option A: Cryptococcal meningitis presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. Seizures and focal neurologic deficits are rarely seen. MRI
findings include dilated perivascular spaces and basal ganglia pseudocysts.
Option B: Primary CNS lymphoma also presents with seizures and focal neurological
deficit. Symptoms of fever, night sweats and weight loss are present in 80% of the patients. On imaging, it is identified as a CT hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass, with MRI T1 hypointense, T2 iso- to hypointense, vivid homogeneous enhancement as well as restricted diffusion.
Option C: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, caused by JC virus, is characterized by demyelination in subcortical white matter reflected on MRI as multiple, non-enhancing white matter lesions.
Solution to Question 14:
Oral candidiasis, although seen in AIDS patients, is not an AIDS-defining illness. Candidiasis of the esophagus, trachea, bronchi, and lungs are AIDS-defining illnesses.
AIDS-defining illnesses are specific opportunistic illnesses in patients with AIDS, which signify an advanced stage of illness (Stage 3).
A case of HIV can be classified into five stages as per current CDC guidelines (0, 1, 2, 3, and unknown).

Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario, along with the pizza pie appearance on fundoscopy, is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. The majority of such cases occur in HIV-infected patients with a CD4+T cell count <50/L.
CMV retinitis is a necrotic retinal infection that results in a painless irreversible vision loss. Patients may complain of blurred vision, floaters (described by patient as flies or spiders in the field of vision), and scintillations. It is usually bilateral and is characterized by perivascular hemorrhage and exudates in the retina (pizza pie appearance or scrambled eggs and ketchup appearance).
Treatment:
Induction - IV ganciclovir (3 weeks)
Maintenance - Oral valganciclovir (till CD4 count > 100/l for 6months)
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection. It is an AIDS-defining opportunistic infection, occurring predominantly at CD4+ T cell counts of <50/L.
The most common presentation is disseminated disease with fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The diagnosis is made by culture of blood or involved tissue.
CT scan shows peribronchial inflammation of the infected lung giving rise to a tree in a bud appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures) indicated by the arrowhead. In severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation.
Treatment consists of clarithromycin / azithromycin with ethambutol/ rifabutin. Primary prophylaxis with azithromycin is indicated in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <50/L.
Solution to Question 17:
This patient with HIV presents with massive proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia. The most likely cause is HIV-1-associated nephropathy (HIVAN) - a form of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).
Proteinuria is the hallmark of this disorder. Edema and hypertension are rare. A definitive diagnosis is obtained through renal biopsy.
Solution to Question 18:
The most common form of heart disease associated with HIV infection is coronary heart disease.
In patients with HIV infection, cardiovascular disease may be a direct consequence of HIV infection, a complication of anti-retroviral therapy or due to classical risk factors like smoking.
Exposure to HIV protease inhibitors and reverse transcriptase inhibitors have been associated with an increase in total cholesterol and/or risk of MI (Myocardial infarction).
Dilated cardiomyopathy associated with congestive heart failure (CHF) is referred to as
HIV-associated cardiomyopathy. This generally occurs as a late complication of HIV infection and, histologically, displays elements of myocarditis.

Solution to Question 1:
Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is recommended for all HIV patients, regardless of CD4 T lymphocyte cell count or clinical stage.
This is done to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with HIV infection. A secondary goal of ART is to reduce the risk of HIV transmission.
Solution to Question 2:
The 4th generation HIV test combines the detection of antibodies against HIV-1 & HIV-2 with detection of the core p24 antigen of HIV-1. Inclusion of p24 antigen capture allows detection of HIV-1 infection even before seroconversion i.e., presence of antibodies in the blood.
The approximate time to positivity following infection is 15 to 20 days. Consequently, the window period between infection and detection of the infection is shortened.
Fourth-generation HIV testing is highly sensitive (99.9%) and is the CDC-recommended initial screening test for HIV. No further testing is required for specimens that are non-reactive on ELISA screening.
