Solution to Question 3:
Didanosine is the most likely causative drug. The clinical scenario, suggestive of pancreatitis, is a dose-limiting side effect of didanosine and occurs more frequently in alcoholic patients and those with hypertriglyceridemia.
Option A: Nevirapine side-effects include severe liver problems, skin rash, and skin reactions. Option C: Emtricitabine is contraindicated in pregnancy and young children.
Option D: Stavudine can cause peripheral neuropathy.
Solution to Question 4:
Enfuvirtide is the antiretroviral drug administered parenterally, used only in the treatment of those who have evidence of HIV replication i.e., high viral load, despite ongoing antiretroviral therapy.
Enfuvirtide prevents viral fusion and entry by binding to the gp41 subunit of the HIV-1 envelope. It is not active against HIV-2. It is administered as a twice-a-day subcutaneous injection.
Note: Zidovudine is also available as a parenteral formulation.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an acute infection with hepatitis B virus. The preferred regimen in the management of HIV-1 and hepatitis B co-infection is tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir.
This regimen is also the first-line management in adults, adolescents, pregnant women, and HIV-TB co-infection.
Antivirals that are effective against hepatitis C infection are sofosbuvir, grazoprevir and glecaprevir.
*Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021. Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines.
Solution to Question 6:
Abacavir is not used in HIV and hepatitis-B co-infection. It is used in the first-line ART regimen for patients with abnormal serum creatinine values.
Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) drugs like lamivudine, its closely related drug emtricitabine, and the nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) tenofovir have activity against hepatitis B virus. These drugs are preferred in combination with other antiretrovirals for the treatment of HIV & HBV co-infections.
Solution to Question 7:
Screening of patients for HLA-B5701 is recommended before initiation of abacavir since it is associated with hypersensitivity.
The hypersensitivity syndrome includes fever, maculopapular rash, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal problems, malaise and fatigue. Hence, abacavir should only be used as a last
resort and with close monitoring in patients who are HLA-B5701-positive.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenerio is suggestive of early stages of diabetic and hypertensive kidney disease. So combinaton antiretroviral therapy (cART) preparations including tenfovir should not be prescribed to this patient.
Tenofovir is primarily eliminated by the kidneys and is contraindicated in patients with renal impairment.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fat redistribution resulting in the classic buffalo hump appearance. Nelfinavir is the most likely cause.
It is a protease inhibitor and its chronic administration can result in fat redistribution and metabolic syndrome.
Note: Atazanavir has the least propensity to cause lipodystrophy and metabolic syndrome.
Solution to Question 10:
Zidovudine should be avoided in this patient because the primary toxicity of zidovudine is bone marrow suppression. It can lead to anemia and neutropenia, which may require transfusions.
Solution to Question 11:
The patient is most likely prescribed a cART regimen including efavirenz.
M ny patients treated with efavirenz note a feeling of light-headedness and dizziness following the initiation of therapy. They also complain of insomnia, vivid dreams and nightmares.
These symptoms are self-limiting and tend to disappear gradually after several weeks of therapy. If the sleep problems are persistent, stopping the drug is the only solution.
It is recommended to take efavirenz before bedtime to minimize side effects. The CNS/ psychiatric adverse effects seen with the use of efavirenz are:
Frank psychosis (depression, hallucinations, and/or mania)
Impaired concentration
Dysphori
Dizziness
Vivid dreams
Insomni
*Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021. Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines.
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of HIV-2 infection. It is intrinsically resistant to
non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTI) and also to fusion inhibitor enfuvirtide.
Western blot has a high specificity. It detects specific antibodies against multiple proteins of all 3 major HIV genes - gag, pol, and env.
Persons with HIV-2 will often have an indeterminate western blot pattern showing the presence of Gag bands and Pol bands, but an absence of Env bands. This pattern occurs because HIV-1 and HIV-2 share little similarity in the env gene. Moreover, the presence of gp36 points towards a diagnosis of HIV-2.
In India, NACO provides western blot confirmatory testing only to resolve indeterminate results on previous serological testing and not for routine confirmation after a positive result on screening tests.
Solution to Question 13:
Etravirine can be used instead of efavirenz.
Etravirine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) currently approved for the treatment of HIV infection in combination with other agents in treatment-experienced patients.
Options A, B: Etravirine is active against strains of HIV that are resistant to other NNRTIs such as delavirdine, nevirapine, and efavirenz which all exhibit cross-resistance. Rilpivirine, an NNRTI, is also effective across a broad range of NNRTI-resistant viruses but shares cross-resistance with etravirine.
Option C: Nelfinavir is a protease inhibitor and hence, does not belong to the same class.
Solution to Question 14:
ART should be initiated immediately and continued lifelong in all pregnant and breastfeeding women with HIV. This is regardless of their WHO clinical stage and CD4 cell count.
*Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021. Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines.
Solution to Question 15:
In a patient with HIV and TB start ATT first and then start ART as soon as ATT is tolerated (between 2 weeks and 2 months) by the patient. This is done in order to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS).
Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS):
Patients with HIV-related TB may experience a temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ATT. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT.
It is characterized by high fever, lymphadenopathy, expanding intra-thoracic lesions, and worsening of chest X-ray findings. Diagnosis should be made only after ruling out treatment failure and other infections. For severe cases, prednisone 1-2mg/kg is used for 1-2 weeks and then gradually tapered.
However, in patients with CD4 <50/L, the benefits of administering ART immediately after initiating ATT outweigh the risks of IRIS, and therefore ART should be started as early as possible.
Note: As per RNTCP guidelines, CBNAAT is the preferred diagnostic technique for testing TB in PLHIV (people living with HIV). Smear microscopy has poor sensitivity in detecting TB in PLHIV due to fewer organisms in sputum, and hence is not preferred.
Solution to Question 16:
In a baby born to an HIV-infected mother, HIV infection is diagnosed using HIV DNA PCR. NACO recommends the use of a qualitative HIV-1 DNA PCR (NAT) in children aged <18 months for Early Infant Diagnosis (EID).
Antibody assays (e.g., ELISA) are not reliable in infants and young children because of the persistence of transplacentally acquired maternal antibodies. For this reason, HIV virologic testing must be performed using tests that detect HIV DNA or RNA to diagnose HIV infection in children.
Scheduled repeated testing is necessary because test sensitivity increases with time from HIV virus exposure and very recent infection will not be detectable. The cord blood should not be used for testing because of the possibility of contamination of the sample with maternal blood.
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tuberculosis. Cartridge-based nucleic acid amiplification test (CBNAAT) is the diagnostic test for TB in HIV positive patients.
CBNAAT is a rapid molecular test that detects the DNA of TB bacteria in HIV-positive individuals. It uses sputum or any other biological specimen (except blood and blood-contaminated specimens). It can give a result in less than 2 hours. It can also detect the genetic mutations associated with resistance to the drug rifampicin.
Sputum microscopy has poor sensitivity for detecting TB in HIV-infected individuals due to fewer organisms in sputum.
Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL). In this condition, glucocorticoids should be administered only after a biopsy has been obtained. This is because steroids have a cytolytic effect on lymphoma cells and hence may lead to nondiagnostic tissue.
On CT, PCNSL is identified as a hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass. On MRI, vivid homogeneous enhancement, as well as restricted diffusion, is seen.
PCNSL is a type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The workup usually includes:
HIV testing
CSF analysis
MRI spine
PET/CT to assess the extent of the disease
Bone marrow biopsy

WHO recommends cotrimoxazole prophylaxis at CD4 count <350 and/or WHO stage 3/4.

Solution to Question 21:
Recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a three-drug regimen that includes lamivudine, tenofovir, and dolutegravir.
A regimen for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.

Solution to Question 1:
Coronaviruses are enveloped helically symmetrical viruses.
Being enveloped contributes to their lipid solvent susceptibility. This is the reason alcohol-based hand sanitizers and soaps are used. The lipid membrane dissolution and protein denaturation by ethanol lead to membrane disruption and inhibition of metabolism.
The coronaviridiae have a single unsegmented ss (+) RNA, which is the largest genome among RNA viruses. They are about 120- 160 nm in size and contain a helical nucleocapsid. A total of seven human coronaviruses have been identified:

Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical vignette showing breathlessness, fever, and cough with a low oxygen saturation and ground-glass opacities on HRCT is indicative of COVID-19 caused by
the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE-2) is the specific functional receptor for SARS-CoV-2 in human cells.
ACE2 is expressed in nearly all human organs in varying degrees. In the respiratory system, ACE2 is mainly expressed by the type 2 alveolar epithelial cells in the highest quantity. Hence, the primary target of SARS-CoV-2 is type 2 alveolar cells.
The functional receptor for SARS-CoV (SARS 2002) is also ACE 2.
Note: Dipeptidylpeptidase 4 is the functional receptor for MERS-CoV (MERS 2012).
Solution to Question 3:
Spike protein (marked as 1 in the image) determines the infectious nature and host specificity of SARS-CoV-2.
The spike protein also referred to as the CoV S protein is one of the key components determining virus virulence, tissue tropism, and host range. The coronavirus spike protein mediates coronavirus entry into host cells. Each spike protein has two distinct subunits S1 and S2.
S1 subunit is responsible for binding to the specific receptor (ACE 2) on the host cell surface facilitating viral attachment to the surface of target cells.
S2 subunit drives the fusion of the viral and host cell membranes.
The host protease enzymes, mainly transmembrane protease serine-type 2 (TMPRSS2) cleave the spike protein. This activates the spike protein to induce virus-cell membrane fusion at the cell surface and allows the entry of coronaviruses into the host cell.

Solution to Question 4:
Blood transfusion is not a mode of transmission of SARS-CoV-2. Option A: Droplet transmission
A type of direct transmission
Occurs when someone coughs, sneezes, speaks, or spit
Virus-containing droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air directly contact another person’s conjunctiva, oral or nasal mucosa
Limited to about 6 feet distance between the source and the host
Particle size is 5-10 µm in diameter Option B: Fomite transmission
A type of indirect transmission
Objects other than water or food contaminated by infectious agents - clothes, towels, linen, cups, poons, pencils, books, toys, door handles, taps, etc.
Transmission occurs when one touches the contaminated objects and touches his mouth, nose, or eye
Option C: Airborne - droplet nuclei transmission
A type of indirect transmission
Droplet nuclei - dried residue of droplets of size <5µm that are generated by the evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air and by a variety of atomizing device
Remain infectious when suspended in the air for some time (typically hours)
Transmission occurs when one inhales droplet nuclei/aerosols containing the virus in sufficient quantity
Solution to Question 5:
The incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 infection ranges from 1-14 days so he is most likely to develop the disease after this period. The median incubation period is around 4-6 days.
The incubation period is defined as the time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease.
Solution to Question 6:
The outbreak of COVID-19 is an example of a propagated epidemic.
The propagated epidemic results from person-to-person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. Other examples of this type include hepatitis A and polio.
Solution to Question 7:
All of the given symptoms are included in the definition of a suspect case of SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 except convulsions.
As per WHO and MOHFW, a suspect case is defined as:
A person who meets the clinical and epidemiological criteria-
Clinical criteria:
Acute onset of fever AND cough; OR
Acute onset of any 3 or more of the following: fever, cough, general weakness/ fatigue, headache, myalgia, sore throat, coryza, dyspnoea, anorexia/nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, altered mental status.
Epidemiological criteria: A person present in any of the following settings for 14 days prior to ymptom onset-
Residing or working in an area with a high risk of transmission of virus OR
Residing or travel to an area with community transmission OR
Working in any healthcare setting
A patient with severe acute respiratory illness with-
history of fever or measured fever of 38 C° along with cough
onset within the last 10 day
requiring hospitalization
An asymptomatic person not meeting epidemiologic criteria with a positive SARS-CoV-2 antigen-RDT.
Solution to Question 8:
An asymptomatic contact of a probable case with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test is considered as a confirmed case, and not a probable case.
Probable case is defined as:
A patient who meets clinical criteria and is a contact of a probable or confirmed case, or linked to a COVID-19 cluster.
A suspect case with chest imaging showing findings suggestive of COVID-19 disease.
A person with recent onset of anosmia or ageusia in the absence of any other identified cause.
Death, not otherwise explained, in an adult with respiratory distress preceding death and was a contact of a probable or confirmed case or linked to a COVID-19 cluster.
Confirmed case is defined as:
A person with a positive Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) including RT-PCR or any other imilar test approved by ICMR.
A person with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test and meeting either the probable case definition or suspect criteria.
An asymptomatic person with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test who is a contact of a probable or confirmed case.
Solution to Question 9:
A person traveling in the same environment and not having significant exposure to the confirmed case is not classified as a high-risk contact.
A contact of COVID-19 is a person living in the same household or having direct physical contact with the patient/infectious secretions without appropriate PPE or a person who was in a closed environment or at a distance of within 1 meter of a COVID-19 case.
High-risk contacts:
Touched body fluids of the patient
Had direct contact with the body of the patient during the physical examination without proper PPE
Touched or cleaned the linens, clothes, or dishes of the patient
Lives in the same household as the patient
Comes in close contact (within 1 meter) with the patient without necessary precaution

Solution to Question 2:
The nasal swab is placed in the same viral transport media tube as the throat swab. Samples that can be used for COVID-19 testing are:
Throat and nasal swab
Oropharyngeal swab
Nasopharyngeal swab
Broncho-alveolar lavag
Endotracheal aspirat
Combined throat and nasal swabs:
Tilt patient's head back 70 degrees.
Gently rotate the swab and insert less than one inch into the nostril. Rotate the swab several times against the nasal wall and repeat the same in the other nostril with the same swab.
Place the tip of the swab into the transport media tube and cut off the applicator.
For throat swab, take a second swab, insert into the mouth and swab the posterior pharynx and tonsillar areas.
Place the tip of the swab into the same tube and cut off the applicator tip. Oropharyngeal swab:
Tilt patient's head back 70 degrees.
Rub swab over both tonsillar pillars and posterior oropharynx and avoid touching the tongue, teeth, and gums.
Use only synthetic fiber swabs with plastic shafts. Avoid calcium alginate swabs and swabs with wooden shafts.
Place the swab immediately into sterile tubes with viral transport medium. Nasopharyngeal swab:
Tilt the patient's head back 70 degrees
Insert flexible swab through the nares parallel to the palate (not upwards) until resistance is ncountered
Rub and roll the swab and leave it in place for several seconds to absorb secretions befor removing
Place the swab immediately into sterile tubes with viral transport medium. Viral transport mediums:
Hanks balanced salt solution with Ca and Mg and heat inactivated fetal bovine serum, gentamicin and amphotericin B (most commonly used)
Sterile salin
Phosphate buffered saline-glycerol medium
Amies medium

Solution to Question 4:
Specimen handling for molecular testing of SARS CoV 2 would require BSL-2 or equivalent facilities.
Microbiology and pathology laboratories performing diagnostic tests on a stool or respiratory specimen should handle potential SARS-CoV specimens using Biosafety Level 2 (BSL-2). Virus culture and initial characterization of viral agents recovered in cultures requires minimum BSL-3 facilities.
Note: Biosafety levels include a specific combination of work practices, safety equipment, and facilities that are designed to minimize the exposure of workers and the environment to infectious agents. There are four biosafety levels.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario, along with CT showing bilateral multiple patchy consolidation and grid-like thickness of interlobular septa, is suggestive of COVID-19. The gold standard for its diagnosis is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) during the first week of symptoms.
RT-PCR involves the reverse transcription of the genetic material of the virus (RNA) to complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by amplification of some regions of the cDNA. Four regions of the SARS CoV2 genome are used as targets:
RdRp gene (RNA-dependent RNA polymerase)
Genes from structural proteins
E (virus envelope)
N (virus nucleocapsid),
ORF1ab gene (open reading frame 1a and 1b)
CBNAAT (cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test) uses small, chip-based, portable, battery-operated devices that detect target genetic material of SARS CoV2. Examples include TrueNat and Cepheid Xpert Xpress SARS CoV-2
Options A and B: Antibody testing- Antibodies of IgA, IgM, and IgG isotypes specific to different virus proteins are detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA). CLIA is more sensitive compared to ELISA.
Option C: Rapid antigen test (RAT)- Antigen-based assays are used as point-of-care tests for early detection of SARS-CoV-2. They are used at the field level for early detection of infection and quick containment. Most of such tests have relatively moderate sensitivity but high specificity. They are used for diagnosis along with RT-PCR.
Solution to Question 6:
A single RT-PCR/TrueNat/CBNAAT/RAT positive is considered confirmatory without repeat testing. If symptoms develop following a negative RAT, a repeat RAT or RT-PCR should be done.
Routine surveillance in containment zones and screening at points of entry for all symptomatic cases including:
Healthcare and frontline workers
Direct and high-risk contacts and individuals
Routine surveillance in non-containment areas for all symptomatic cases including:
History of international travel in the last 14 days
Contacts of a laboratory-confirmed cas
Healthcare and frontline workers involved in containment and mitigation activities
Returnees and migrants within 7 days of illness
All asymptomatic high-risk contacts
In hospital settings for all symptomatic cases including:
All patients of Severe Acute Respiratory Infection (SARI)
Patients presenting in a healthcare setting
Neonates presenting with acute respiratory/sepsis-like illness
Patients with atypical manifestations (stroke, encephalitis, hemoptysis, Guillain Barre Syndrom tc.) based on the doctor's discretion
All pregnant women in/near labor hospitalized for delivery
Asymptomatic high-risk patients who are hospitalized or seeking immediate hospitalization (eg.
immune compromise, malignancy, transplant, chronic comorbidities, elderly > 65 years) Testing on-demand for all individuals:
Traveling to countries/states mandating negative COVID-19 test at the point of entry
Who wish to get themselves tested
Solution to Question 7:
Asymptomatic individuals with a negative rapid antigen test (RAT) need to be retested only if they develop symptoms of COVID-19 such as cough, fever, and difficulty in breathing.
Rapid antigen test, when positive, is reported as positive in both symptomatic and asymptomatic patients. When the test is negative, the patient is retested with another RAT or RT-PCR only if the patient is symptomatic.
Solution to Question 8:
The paper-based Covid-19 test kit developed by CSIR and IGIB and approved by the Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) is named FELUDA.
FELUDA is an acronym for FNCAS9 Editor Linked Uniform Detection Assay. The name is inspired by a fictitious detective character in novels written by Satyajit Ray.
FELUDA uses CRISPR-Cas9 technology (CRISPR = Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats). The CRISPR technology uses a highly specific CAS9 protein to find and bind to the target Covid signature. This is then coupled with paper-strip chemistry to elicit a visual readout on a paper strip. It is a very affordable, sensitive (96%), and specific (98%) strip test which can detect viral genetic material within 45 minutes.
Solution to Question 9:
COVID Kavach ELISA is an indigenous ELISA test kit for COVID-19 antibody detection developed by ICMR Delhi and NIV Pune.
It is reported to have a 98.7% sensitivity and 100% specificity and testing is possible even at the district level. As the ELISA kit has an inactivated virus, only minimal biosafety and biosecurity requirements as compared to the real-time RT-PCR test.
IgG antibodies usually start appearing after two weeks of the onset of infection. Therefore, the IgG test is not useful for detecting acute infection. IgG based antibody tests are used in
sero-surveillance of the population.

Lymphocytosis is least likely to be seen in a patient with COVID-19. On the contrary, lymphopenia is likely to be seen.
Common laboratory abnormalities seen in COVID-19 are:
Lymphopenia
Mild thrombocytopenia
Elevated aminotransaminase levels
Elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels
Elevated inflammatory markers - eg, ferritin, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rat
Markers of a hypercoagulable state - high fibrinogen, high D-dimer levels, increased fibrin degradation products, prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
The degree of these abnormalities tends to correlate with disease severity.
Solution to Question 11:
Ground glass opacity (GGO) is the most commonly seen pattern in chest CT of patients with COVID-19.
Some of the typical features seen in the CT scans of COVID-19 patients include:
Ground glass opacities
Consolidation
Air bronchograms
Interlobular septal thickenings
Visible intralobular lines (crazy-paving pattern)
Reversed halo sign
The image below shows an axial CT scan with multiple patchy areas of pure ground-glass opacities. GGO are hazy areas with slightly increased density in the lungs without obscuration of underlying bronchial and vascular margins.

The image given below shows a CT scan with bilateral GGO in the lower lobe and an air bronchogram (arrow) in the left subpleural area. Air bronchograms appear like air-filled bronchi within a highly attenuated parenchymal background. These are dilated bronchi filled with mucus plugs and do not truly contain air.

The image given below shows a CT scan with multiple consolidation areas and interlobular septal thickening (arrows) in both lungs. The pulmonary interstitial structures such as interlobular septa and intralobular lines can thicken and manifest as small linear opacities.

The image given below shows a CT scan with crazy-paving pattern (circled area). It is defined as the presence of GGOs with superimposed interlobular septal thickening giving the appearance of irregular paving stones.

The image given below shows a CT scan with multiple lesions with reversed halo sign
(arrows). The reversed halo sign or atoll sign is the presence of a ring-like area of consolidation with a superimposed rounded GGO.

Solution to Question 1:
The given scenario is a mild case of COVID-19 who can be recommended home isolation for a duration of 7 days from testing positive.
Isolation is the separation and restriction of movements or activities of persons who are sick, to prevent the transmission of disease.
Eligibility for home isolation:
Clinically assigned as a mild or asymptomatic case
Facility at their residence for self-isolation and for quarantining the family contacts
Availability of a caregiver
Must monitor his health regularly and inform his health status to the district surveillance officer
The patient can end home isolation after 7 days from testing positive and no fever for 3 successive days. There is no need for testing after the home isolation period is over.
The patient should seek medical help if he/she develops:
Unresolved High-grade fever (more than 100° F for more than 3 days)
Difficulty in breathing,
Dip in oxygen saturation (SpO2  93% on room air at least 3 readings within 1 hour) or respiratory rate >24/ min
Persistent pain/pressure in the ches
Mental confusion or inability to arouse
Severe fatigue and myalgia
Quarantine separates and restricts the movement of people who were exposed to a contagious disease to see if they become sick.
Solution to Question 2:
The patient is suffering from severe COVID-19 and hence has to be admitted to ICU. The disease is said to be severe when there is RR>30/min, breathlessness OR SpO2<90% on room air.

Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of moderate COVID-19 (SpO2 <94%, RR24). Awake proning should be avoided in patients with hemodynamic instability.
Awake proning in moderate COVID disease is recommended for any patient with severe respiratory distress. It improves oxygenation by keeping the alveolar units open. Timely proning of patients with SpO2 < 94% can help reduce mortality.
Steps for self-proning:

One may prone up to 16 hours a day, in multiple cycles, if tolerable. Avoid proning:
Hemodynamic instability
For 1 hour after meals

Solution to Question 4:
This patient has persistent hypoxia after an adequate trial of standard oxygen therapy and should be started on high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy.
When respiratory distress and/or hypoxemia of the patient cannot be alleviated after receiving standard oxygen therapy, high–flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNO), or non–invasive ventilation can be considered. Compared to standard oxygen therapy, HFNO reduces the need for intubation.
Patients on HFNO should be closely monitored, and endotracheal intubation should be done if the patient acutely deteriorates or does not improve after a short trial (about 1 hr).
Contraindications to HFNO includes patients with:
Hypercapnia (exacerbation of COPD)
Hemodynamic instability
Multi-organ failure
Abnormal mental status
Note: If an high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) or simple nasal cannula is used to administer O2, an N95 mask should be applied over it.

Solution to Question 6:
Open suctioning of the respiratory tract is associated with significant amounts of aerosol generation and not closed suctioning.
Commonly performed aerosol-generating procedures are:
Open suctioning of the respiratory trac
Bronchoscopy
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
Non-invasive ventilation (e.g., BiPAP, CPAP)
Endotracheal intubation and extubation
Manual ventilation
It is recommended that healthcare providers should be protected with PPE while performing these procedures. It must be performed in an adequately ventilated single room with a minimum of 12 air changes/hour.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID-19 in a patient with end-stage renal disease. Unfractionated heparin is recommended for use in such patients.
Prophylactic anticoagulation is used in the management of moderate and severe COVID cases. A prophylactic dose of low molecular weight heparin or unfractionated heparin is used to prevent thromboembolism. In a COVID patient with end-stage renal disease, unfractionated heparin is the preferred agent.
Solution to Question 8:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, and 4.
Tocilizumab is contraindicated in HIV-positive patients and those with active bacterial or fungal infection.
Bamlanivimab is not authorized for patients with mild COVID-19 pneumonia who are not at a high risk for hospitalization.
Remedisivir is contraindicated in postnatal lactating women.
Convalescent plasma therapy is no longer recommended in the management of COVID patients.
Tocilizumab acts by IL-6 inhibition. It may be considered in moderate-severe COVID patients with progressively increasing oxygen requirements and mechanically ventilated patients not improving despite the use of steroids. Patients should be carefully monitored for secondary infections and neutropenia after treatment with tocilizumab. It is contraindicated in:
HIV
Active infections (systemic bacterial/fungal)
Tuberculosis
Active hepatitis
Absolute neutrophil count < 2000/mm3
Platelet count < 1,00,000/mm3
Bamlanivimab is a monoclonal antibody directed against the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2. The FDA has issued an emergency use authorization for bamlanivimab for the treatment of adult and pediatric mild to moderate COVID patients (12 years of age and older weighing at least 40 kilograms) who are at high risk for progressing to severe COVID-19 and/or
hospitalization. Possible side effects include anaphylaxis and infusion-related reactions, nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache, itching, and vomiting. There is no specific contraindication for this drug.
Remdesivir is an antiviral drug that works by inhibiting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. It may be considered in moderate and severe hospitalized COVID patients requiring supplemental oxygen/oxygen delivery through a high flow device/ noninvasive ventilation/ invasive mechanical ventilation/ ECMO. It is contraindicated in:
AST/ALT > 5 times upper limit of normal
Severe renal impairment (i.e., eGFR < 30ml/min/m2 or need for hemodialysis)
Pregnancy or lactating females
Children <12 years of age
Convalescent plasma therapy is no longer recommended in the management of COVID patients, as per the revised guidelines.
Dexamethasone is generally given to all patients of moderate and severe COVID-19. Patients with severe COVID-19 can develop a systemic inflammatory response that can lead to lung injury and multisystem organ dysfunction.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID-19 disease in a pregnant patient. The management should include an aim to keep oxygen saturation above 94% during labour in this patient. In such cases, maternal observations and assessment during labour should be continued as per standard practice, with the addition of hourly oxygen saturation.
Option A: There is currently no evidence to favour one mode of birth over another. Mode of birth should not be influenced by the presence of COVID-19, unless the woman’s respiratory condition demands urgent intervention for birth.
Option B: Awake proning is recommended. Although evidence is limited, there are reports that this is feasible with appropriate padding up to at least 28 weeks of gestation.
Option C: CT scan is relatively contraindicated. Pregnant women with abdominal shielding should not be excluded from chest CT if clinically recommended.
Solution to Question 10:
COVID-19 cases that are mild/very mild/presymptomatic can be discharged from home isolation after 7 days of testing positive and no fever for 3 successive days. There is no need for testing after the end of home isolation.
Criteria to diagnose asymptomatic COVID-19: Laboratory confirmed case with no symptoms with a saturation of more than 93% in room air.
Criteria to diagnose mild COVID-19: Laboratory confirmed case with upper respiratory tract symptoms with/without fever, without shortness of breath, and saturation of more than 93% in room air.
Patients are advised to isolate from other family members and monitor themselves at home, under proper medical guidance. Patients >60 years with co-morbidities, and immunocompromised patients are allowed to isolate only after receiving clearance from the designated medical officer.
Immediate medical attention is required if the patient experiences the following:
A 100 ºF fever persists for >3 days and does not resolve on medication.
Difficulty in breathing
Oxygen saturation 93% (at least 3 readings within 1 hour)
Respiratory rate >24/min
Persistent chest pain or pressure
Mental confusion
Severe fatigue or myalgia
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe COVID-19 disease. Severe cases of COVID-19 (and immunocompromised patients) are discharged based on their clinical recovery at the discretion of the treating medical officer.
Note: Mild and moderate cases do not need an RT-PCR test before discharge. But, at the time of discharge, they are advised to self-monitor and continue wearing masks for a duration of 7 days.
Solution to Question 12:
The presence of sore throat, rhinorrhea, cough with no fast breathing are suggestive of mild COVID-19 disease. Hence, home isolation along with supportive care is recommended in this child.

Solution to Question 13:
FDA recently sanctioned emergency use authorization to a combination of nirmatrelvir and ritonavir tablets (Paxlovid) for the treatment of mild-to-moderate COVID-19. It is the first oral antiviral for the treatment of COVID-19.
Nirmatrelvir is a peptidomimetic inhibitor of the SARS-CoV-2 main protease (Mpro). Inhibition of this enzyme makes the virus incapable of processing polyprotein precursors and thus prevents viral replication.
Ritonavir is an HIV-1 protease inhibitor. It inhibits the CYP3A-mediated metabolism of nirmatrelvir which results in increased plasma concentrations of nirmatrelvir. It is not active against SARS-CoV-2 Mpro.
Patients who tested positive with direct SARS-CoV-2 test can be administered this drug combination, provided they are:

co-administration with potent CYP3A inducers. Adverse reactions include dysgeusia, diarrhea,
hypertension, and myalgia.

Solution to Question 1:
Home quarantine for 14 days is advised when a person comes in contact with a COVID-19 positive patient.
The home quarantined person:
Should stay in a well ventilated single room and stay away from high-risk individuals
Should not attend any religious or social gatherings
Must wash hands often
Must change mask every 6-8 hrs
Their surroundings must be disinfected with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
In case the person being quarantined becomes symptomatic, all his contacts should be home quarantined for 14 days and followed up for another 14 days or till the report turns out negative on lab testing.
Isolation is the separation and restriction of movements or activities of persons who are sick, to prevent the transmission of disease. Quarantine is the separation and restriction of movements or activities of persons who are not ill but are believed to have been exposed to infection, for the purpose of preventing transmission of diseases.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID toes. The image shows pernio-like lesions caused due to COVID-19.
Pernio / chilblains are skin lesions on the acral surfaces of the body characterised by the development of erythematous-violaceous or purpuric macules. They may be accompanied by edema and pruritus.
It is usually due to cold exposure or underlying hematological disorders but has also been reported in patients with COVID-19 disease. The underlying mechanism is thought to be an inflammatory process. The lesions appear late (postviral phase) with the patients exhibiting positive IgM/ IgG antibodies for SARS-CoV-2 and negative RT-PCR. However, pernio like lesions can also be seen in early stages of the disease when the patients are still infective.
There are no treatment guidelines but high-potency topical corticosteroids may be helpful if the lesions are causing discomfort. Other cutaneous manifestations include exanthematous rash, livedo reticularis, urticaria, MIS-C etc.
Solution to Question 3:
The correct sequence of donning a PPE is first pair of gloves  coverall  Shoe cover  N-95 mask.
Preparation for donning the PPE:
To be performed only in the designated area
The health care worker must be prepared for the shift duty by
Taking a meal
Using the washroom
Drinking water prior to entering the donning area
Remove all accessories, jewelry
Change into clean hospital scrubs and closed washable footwear
Perform hand hygiene with soap and water Steps of donning/putting on the PPE:
Hand hygiene
Wear the first pair of gloves
Sterile or unsterile
Make sure the cuff of the gloves goes as far as possible
Examine and wear coverall
Examine the coverall for any damage
Start by wearing the leg sleeves and then the arm sleeves
Zip up and cover the zip with the flap attached
Wear shoe cover
Sit on the clean chair and wear shoe cover
Pull them up till your calves
Wear N-95 mask and wear hood
Hold the mask like a cup in the hand with both the straps hanging out in the front
Place the mask on the face, pull and wear the lower strap first placing it below the ears
Then pull and wear the upper strap placing above the ears
The air leakage should be minimum around the mask when forcibly exhaling
Wear the hood covering the forehead and the cheeks
Wear face shield/eye goggles over the hood and ensure the fit
Wear the second pair of gloves - pull the gloves to cover the sleeve cuff and forearm as much as possible
Solution to Question 4:
The component of the PPE kit to be removed first is the shoe covers. Preparation for doffing the PPE:
To be performed only in the designated area
Check for any leak or soiling
Doffing room should have two chairs, dirty and clean
All the PPE must be discarded in the red bin
Hand hygiene must be performed after every step Steps of doffing the PPE:
Engage the observer and ask him to check the PPE - observer should check for any leak, tear, or contamination of PPE. If contaminated, then it should be disinfected with alcohol-based wipes.
Disinfect the gloves
Remove and discard shoe covers
Sit on the dirty chair with legs apart
Remove the shoe covers by slowly pulling the outer surface starting from the top and then pull rom the toes end. Discard them
Disinfect and remove outer pair of gloves
While removing the outer gloves, inner gloves should not be torn or contaminated
Pinch the first glove on the outer surface at the wrist and pull it inside out
Hold this glove in the other hand like a ball
Slide the thumb inside the other glove and remove inside out balling around the previous glove, making it into a single bag. Then discard it.
Disinfect inner gloves
Remove face shield/eye goggle - loosen the screw and remove the face shield by holding it from the back handle. Discard it.
Disinfect inner gloves again
Remove hood and coverall
Slide back the hood by holding it from the top
Separate the zip flap and unzip the coverall suit
Holding the suit at the arms, slide it off the shoulder slightly, then pull the suit from the side o the waist
Roll the arms out one by one
By touching the inner surface of the suit carefully roll out each leg. Discard it
Disinfect and remove inner gloves as previously described
Perform hand hygiene and wear a new pair of gloves
Remove and discard N-95 mask
Do not touch the exposed surface of the mask
Stoop forward and first remove the lower strap
Then pull out the upper strap and remove the mask
Disinfect gloves
Sit on the clean chair and disinfect shoes using alcohol wipes
Disinfect and remove gloves
Perform hand hygiene
Wipe the shoes on sodium hypochlorite soaked doormat at exit
Exit the doffing area and take a shower
Solution to Question 5:
The front of the face shield is considered to be a contaminated area of the personal protective equipment (PPE). Hence, it should not be touched while doffing.
The areas that are considered clean are the parts that will be touched while removing a PPE:
Inside the gloves
Inside and back of the gown including the ties
Ties or earpieces of the mask, goggles, and face shields The areas that are considered contaminated are:
Outside front and sleeves of the isolation gown
Front of goggles, mask, respirator, and face shield
Outside of the gloves

Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. Intravenous administration o amphotericin B is the first line treatment. Other drugs which are approved for its management include isavuconazole and posaconazole. Surgical debridement is the last line management.
Immunocompromised states are important risk factors including diabetes mellitus and glucocorticoid treatment as well as patients on ventilation.
Diagnosis can be made by culturing the organisms from sterile sites like needle aspirate, pleural fluid, or a tissue biopsy specimen. The biopsy is most sensitive. It reveals characteristic wide, thick-walled, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.
It can present as:
Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis - (most common) the initial symptoms are nonspecific and include eye or facial pain and facial numbness followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and blurry vision. If untreated it can spread from the sinuses to the orbit, and then to the frontal lobe.
Pulmonary mucormycosis - (second most common)
Cutaneous mucormycosis - usually results after trauma
Gastrointestinal mucormycosis - primarily occurs in premature neonates who have disseminated disease or necrotizing enterocolitis
Disseminated mucormycosis
Solution to Question 10:
This is a case of multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C), associated with COVID-19 infection.
Diagnostic criteria for MIS-C:
Children and adolescents 0–18 years of age with fever 3 days AND two of these:
Rash or bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis or mucocutaneous inflammation signs (palmoplantar erythema, lip hyperemia, periorbital erythema and edema, strawberry tongue, and malar erythema)
Hypotension or shock.
Features of myocardial dysfunction, pericarditis, valvulitis, or coronary abnormalities (including ECHO findings or elevated Troponin/NT-proBNP)
Evidence of coagulopathy (PT, PTT, elevated D-Dimers)
Acute gastrointestinal problems (diarrhoea, vomiting, or abdominal pain) AND
Elevated ESR(>40 mm), C-reactive protein (>5 mg/L), or procalcitonin. AND
No other obvious microbial cause of inflammation including bacterial sepsis, staphylococcal or streptococcal shock syndromes.
AND
Evidence of COVID-19 (RT-PCR, antigen test, or serology positive), or likely contact with patients with COVID-19.
Types of MIS-C:
MIS-C with shock/multi-organ dysfunction
Kawasaki phenotype
MIS-C without shock
MIS-C is treated with IV methylprednisolone. The dose can be increased in patients with shock. If the condition does not improve for 48-72 hours, specialists can be consulted for the addition of biologicals to the treatment regimen.
Solution to Question 11:
APOL1 gene increases the risk of collapsing nephropathy in patients infected with COVID-19.
Glomerular lesions are reported in a minority of COVID-19 patients. They are associated with collapsing focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) and are called COVID-associated nephropathy (COVAN). Such patients present with nephrotic-range proteinuria and acute kidney injury (AKI). It specifically affects individuals of African ancestry who are carriers of this gene variant.
Thrombotic microangiopathy is another uncommon finding among these patients. Histopathology is similar to those seen in other forms of collapsing glomerulopathy. But, tubulointerstitial lesions including microcystic tubular dilatation and tubular injury are typically associated with APOL1- related disease.

Solution to Question 13:
The 51-year-old man should receive COVID-19 vaccination at least 3 months after hematopoietic cell transplantation (and not 5 weeks) to maximize vaccine efficacy.
Graft-versus-host disease and immunosuppressive regimens like systemic corticosteroids can blunt the immune responses to vaccination. Delay of vaccination until immunosuppressive therapy is reduced can be considered.
Consider additional risk factors linked to adverse COVID-19 complications including, but not limited to:
Patients with advanced age (eg, 65 years of age)
Patients with comorbidities (eg, chronic pulmonary, cardiovascular, or renal disease)
Social and demographic factors
COVID-19 vaccines should be prioritized over other vaccines. A gap of 14 days is recommended between COVID-19 vaccines and any other vaccine.
If COVID vaccine has been given first, then TT vaccine can be given on the same day. If TT vaccine have been given first, then wait for 14 days to give COVID vaccine.
Solution to Question 14:
The minimum duration of symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath to define it as post Covid-19 condition according to WHO is 2 months.
WHO clinical case definition of post Covid-19 - Post Covid-19 condition occurs in individuals with a history of probable or confirmed SARS CoV-2 infection, usually 3 months from the onset of Covid-19, with symptoms that last for at least 2 months and cannot be explained by an alternative diagnosis.
Common symptoms include
Fatigue
Shortness of breath
Cognitive dysfunction.
